Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four primary categories of damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which, based on a discussion in the Gemara refers either to the tooth of an animal that causes damage or to a person who causes damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Each of these categories is unique; therefore, the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of one cannot be derived from another. The defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox is not similar to </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> similar to </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox. And </span>the defining characteristics of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>category of Ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a living spirit </span>that causes damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">are not similar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire, in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which there is no living spirit.</span>
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the defining characteristics of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>primary category of Ox and <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>primary category of Fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">typical manner </span>of their components is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, are not similar to </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, in which </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">typical manner </span>of its components is <span class="gemarra-regular">not to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage; </span>rather, it remains in place and the damage is caused by the injured party proceeding and encountering the obstacle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The common denominator of </span>the components in all of <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>primary categories is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">their typical manner to cause damage, and </span>the responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding </span>to prevent them from causing damage is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>the owner of the animal or generator of the fire or the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>a component of any of these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage, the </span>owner or generator of the component that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to pay </span>restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage with best</span>-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>its ruling employing the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Primary categories, by inference, there are</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategorie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of those primary categories. The Gemara asks: Are <span class="gemarra-regular">their subcategories similar to them, </span>i.e., to their respective primary categories, so that the same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply to them, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>are they <span class="gemarra-regular">dissimilar to them?</span>
The Gemara cites additional areas of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> where there are primary categories and subcategories and considers the relationship between them: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to Shabbat we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 73a): <span class="gemarra-regular">The primary categories of labor </span>prohibited on Shabbat number <span class="gemarra-regular">forty-less-one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> There too, from the fact that the mishna teaches its ruling employing the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Primary categories</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inference</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, there are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategories.</span>
With regard to the primary categories of labor prohibited on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">their subcategories are similar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is no different </span>if one unwittingly performed labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category, </span>for which he is liable to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, and it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no different </span>if one unwittingly performed labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> subcategory, </span>for which he is liable to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offering. </span>Likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is no different </span>if one intentionally performed labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for which he is liable to be executed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning, and it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is no different </span>if one intentionally performed labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory, </span>for which he is liable to be executed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is there between a primary category and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a subcategory? </span>The Gemara explains: The practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if one </span>unwittingly <span class="gemarra-regular">performs two </span>labors classified as different <span class="gemarra-regular">primary categorie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> together, </span>during a single lapse of awareness, or, <span class="gemarra-regular">alternatively, </span>if one unwittingly performs <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>labors classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategories </span>of two different primary categories <span class="gemarra-regular">together, </span>during a single lapse of awareness, <span class="gemarra-regular">one is liable </span>to bring a sin-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">for each and every </span>labor that he performed. Each primary category of labor is an independent transgression. <span class="gemarra-regular">While if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>unwittingly <span class="gemarra-regular">performs </span>a labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>another labor classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">its subcategory </span>during a single lapse of awareness, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">only one </span>sin-offering.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eliezer, who deems one liable </span>to bring two sin-offerings even if one performs a labor classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory </span><span class="gemarra-regular">together with </span>a labor that is <span class="gemarra-regular">its primary category, why is</span> one labor <span class="gemarra-regular">characterized </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary categor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and why </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the other labor <span class="gemarra-regular">characterized </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory? </span>The Gemara explains: Of the labors prohibited on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a significant </span>labor <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Tabernacle, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">characterized </span>it as <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that which was not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a significant labor in the Tabernacle, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">characterized </span>it as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory. </span>The labors prohibited on Shabbat are derived from the labors employed in the construction of the Tabernacle; therefore, their classification is also based on their significance in its construction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to ritual impurities, we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 1:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">The primary categories of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ritual impurity </span>are as follows: Any of the eight species of <span class="gemarra-regular">the creeping anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> enumerated in the Torah (Leviticus 11:29–30), <span class="gemarra-regular">and semen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 2b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is impure </span>with impurity imparted by a human <span class="gemarra-regular">corpse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A person, a vessel, or food that is rendered impure through contact with an item classified as a primary category of ritual impurity is characterized as a subcategory. In that domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">their subcategories are dissimilar to them, as </span>any person or item classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category </span>of ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">impurifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person and </span>impurifies any <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>with which it comes into contact, <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>a person or item classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of ritual impurity impurifies food or drink</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but does not impurify a person or vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
After determining that there are instances where the legal status of subcategories is like that of primary categories, e.g., Shabbat, and there are instances where the legal status of subcategories is dissimilar to that of primary categories, e.g., ritual impurity, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>with regard to the laws of damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the relationship between the primary categories and their subcategories? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Papp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">There are, among </span>the primary categories of damage, some whose subcategories <span class="gemarra-regular">are similar to them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there are, among</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them, </span>some whose subcategories <span class="gemarra-regular">are dissimilar to them.</span>
§ Seeking to clarify Rav Pappa’s statement, the Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that delineates the primary categories of damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Three primary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> categories </span>of damage <span class="gemarra-regular">were stated </span>in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to an ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> An ox causes damage in three ways, and each is classified as a distinct primary category of damage represented by a part of the body of the ox: There is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>literally, horn. This is referring to an ox goring a person or an animal and causing damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>literally, tooth. This is referring to one’s ox causing damage by consuming another person’s produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">regel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>literally, foot. This is referring to an ox trampling another person’s belongings and causing damage. These are classified as primary categories because they are mentioned explicitly in the Torah.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where do we </span>derive the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring? </span>The source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>a man or a woman” (Exodus 21:28); and <span class="gemarra-regular">goring is </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a horn, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “And Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> made himself </span><span class="gemarra-regular">horns of iron, and said: So says the Lord: With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">these shall you gore the Arameans, </span>until they are consumed” (I Kings 22:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse also <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “His firstborn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bull, majesty is his, and his horns are the horns </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the wild ox; with them he shall gore the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nations” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:17).
The Gemara interrupts its citation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the purpose of citing the additional verse introduced with the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse also <span class="gemarra-regular">states? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say</span> that the first verse cited is not a legitimate source as it is a verse from the Prophets, and <span class="gemarra-regular">we do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not derive Torah matters from the texts of the tradition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Prophets and Writings, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>proof from the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His firstborn bull, majesty is his.”</span>
The Gemara rejects the possibility that the reason a second verse was cited is that the primary category of Goring cannot be derived from a verse in the Prophets: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is this </span>a halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">derivation? It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is a mere disclosure of the matter, that goring is</span> performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with a horn. </span>A verse in the Prophets can certainly serve as a source for that disclosure.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the reason the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cites a second verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say, </span>based on the first verse, that <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Merciful One distinguishes between </span>liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, for which the owner is liable to pay half of the damages for the first three times that it gores, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, which already gored three times and whose owner was cautioned to prevent the ox from goring, for which he is liable to pay the full damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement </span>applies only to damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">with a detached </span>horn, like the horn of Zedekiah described in the verse, e.g., if an animal held a detached horn in its mouth and caused damage with it; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>for damage that an ox caused <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a horn <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to its head, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>cases the legal status of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox and its owner is liable to pay for all of the damage.
Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from another verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bull</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> majesty is his, </span>and his horns are the horns of the wild ox; with them he shall gore the nations,” where the reference is to a horn attached to the ox’s head. Evidently, when an ox gores with its own horns there is a distinction between an innocuous ox and a forewarned ox.
The Gemara resumes its citation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a subcategory of Goring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It includes any action that an ox performs with its body with the objective of inflicting damage: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pushing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">negifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], biting, crouching </span>upon items with the objective of inflicting damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and kicking.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">gorin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that it is characterized </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary category </span>of damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>explicitly in the verse: “And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>a man or a woman” (Exodus 21:28); accordingly, <span class="gemarra-italic">negifa</span> should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be characterized as a primary category, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one man’s ox <span class="gemarra-regular">hurts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yiggof </span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the ox of another” (Exodus 21:35)? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">negifa</span> mentioned in the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>actually a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">goring, as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verses states: “And if one man’s ox hurts [<span class="it-text">yiggof </span>] the ox of another…or if it is known that the ox was a goring ox in time past” (Exodus 21:35–36). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">began </span>its description of the case <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the term <span class="gemarra-italic">negifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">concluded with </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring to say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>that in this context the two terms describe the same action: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>action <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">negifa</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>same action <span class="gemarra-regular">is goring.</span>
The Gemara asks: If the two terms are interchangeable, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different with regard to </span>an ox goring <span class="gemarra-regular">a person that it is written: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>a man or a woman” (Exodus 21:28), <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different with regard to </span>an ox goring <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal that it is written: “If </span>one man’s ox <span class="gemarra-regular">hurts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yiggof </span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the ox of another” (Exodus 21:35)?
The Gemara explains: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, who has </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ingenuity </span>to defend himself and is not easily injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “If </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores,” </span>a term indicating an attack of greater force. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal, which does not have </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ingenuity </span>to defend itself and is more easily injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “If </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">hurts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yiggof </span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>a term indicating an attack of lesser force. The term <span class="it-text">yiggof</span> is related to the term <span class="it-text">magefa</span>, meaning plague. The Torah employs that term with regard to the goring of an animal to indicate that when an animal is gored, regardless of the force of the blow, it will likely result in its death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Torah’s use of these terms <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us a matter in passing: </span>Because the effort required for the ox to gore a person to death is greater than the effort required for the ox to gore an animal to death, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>an ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to </span>goring <span class="gemarra-regular">a person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to an animal. But </span>an ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to an animal is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not forewarned with regard to a person.</span>
The Gemara questions the classification in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of biting, crouching, and kicking as subcategories of Goring: Isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">biting a subcategory of Eating, </span>as the animal both eats and bites with its teeth? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>in cases included in the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of damage caused by biting, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>intrinsic <span class="gemarra-regular">pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>causes, as when the ox bites forcefully, the exclusive objective of the action is to cause damage.
The Gemara asks: Aren’t <span class="gemarra-regular">crouching </span>upon items <span class="gemarra-regular">and kicking </span>items in order to damage them each <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Trampling, </span>as the animal crouches by bending its legs and kicks with its feet? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>in cases included in the primary category of Trampling, the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is commonplace, </span>as it is caused in the course of the animal’s walking; in <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases of crouching and kicking, the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is not commonplace, </span>as animals do not typically kick or crouch upon utensils.
After citing the subcategories listed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara resumes its analysis of the statement of Rav Pappa: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Pappa said: There are among them</span> some whose subcategories <span class="gemarra-regular">are dissimilar to them, to which </span>primary category was Rav Pappa referring?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that his reference was <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these </span>subcategories of Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>that defines it as a unique primary category? What is different is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">objective </span>of the ox’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to cause damage, and </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and</span> responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>its owner. In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>subcategories of Goring, i.e., pushing [<span class="it-text">negifa</span>], biting, crouching, and kicking, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">objective </span>of the oxen’s actions <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to cause damage, and </span>the oxen are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and</span> responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent your oxen from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Goring is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, and when Rav Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, he was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Eating and Trampling.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where are Eating and Trampling written </span>in the Torah that led them to be classified as primary categories? The Gemara answers: The source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “If a man causes a field or vineyard to be eaten, and he sends forth his animal, and it consumed in the field of another” (Exodus 22:4). The two parts of the verse are referring to different categories: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he sends forth,” this is </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as sending forth results in the animal trampling another’s produce and damaging it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and likewise it states: </span>“Happy are you that sow beside all waters <span class="gemarra-regular">that send forth the feet</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the ox and the donkey” </span>(Isaiah 32:20). Clearly the term “send forth” is a reference to trampling by the feet of the animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular"> “And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it consumed,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and likewise it states: </span>“And I will utterly sweep away the house of Jeroboam, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one consumes with</span>

Daf 3a

<span class="gemarra-regular">the tooth until it be all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gone” </span>(I Kings 14:10).
<span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> just cited: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he sends</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> forth,” this </span>is a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and likewise it says: </span>“Happy are you that sow beside all waters <span class="gemarra-regular">that send forth the feet of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox and the donkey” </span>(Isaiah 32:20). The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that the phrase: “And he sends forth,” is interpreted as a reference to the category of Trampling is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Merciful One writes: “That send forth the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">feet of the ox and the donkey.” </span>The Gemara asks: Were <span class="gemarra-regular">it not for this </span>verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would you have interpreted </span>that phrase?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>you say that it could have been interpreted as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>that cannot be, as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in a different verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>you say that it could have been interpreted as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that too cannot be, as Eating <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in a different verse. Perforce the reference is to Trampling, and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> had no need to prove this from the phrase: “That send forth the feet.”
The Gemara answers that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to cite the verse: “That send forth the feet of the ox and the donkey,” as it <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter your mind to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: “And he sends forth,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>phrase: “And it consumed,” are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, and that </span>phrase: “And it consumed,” is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">completely destroyed, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: “And he sends forth,” is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not completely destroyed. </span>Therefore, the verse “that send forth the feet of the ox and the donkey” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the phrase “and he sends forth,” is referring to Trampling.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And now that we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have interpreted </span>that the phrase “and he sends forth” is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Trampling, from where do we </span>derive that one is liable with regard to acts categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is not completely destroyed? </span>The primary category of Eating is derived from the phrase “and it consumed.” The connotation of that phrase is damage in which the object is completely destroyed.
The Gemara answers: It is derived because the category of Eating is juxtaposed to and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the category <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Just as </span>with regard to liability for the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, it is no different </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> completely destroyed and it is no different </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the object</span> damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is not completely destroyed; so too, </span>with regard to liability for the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, it is no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is completely destroyed and it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no different </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">the object </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">is not completely</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> destroyed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Master said </span>in that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And it consumed” </span>(Exodus 22:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating. And likewise it states: </span>“And I will utterly sweep away the house of Jeroboam, <span class="gemarra-regular">as one consumes with the tooth until it be all gone” </span>(I Kings 14:10). The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that the phrase “and it consumed” is interpreted as a reference to the category of Eating is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Merciful One writes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “As one consumes with the tooth until it be all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gone.” </span>The Gemara asks: Were <span class="gemarra-regular">it not for this </span>verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">would you have interpreted </span>that phrase?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>you say that it could have been interpreted as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>that cannot be, as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in a different verse. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>you say that it could have been interpreted as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, </span>that too cannot be, as Trampling, <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in a different verse. Perforce the reference is to Eating. The Gemara answers that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to cite the verse: “As one consumes with the tooth until it be all gone,” as it <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter your mind to say </span>that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: “And it consumed,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>phrase: “And he sends forth,” are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>phrase: “And it consumed,” is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">own, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>phrase: “And he sends forth,” is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the animal to cause damage. Therefore, the verse “as one consumes with the tooth until it be all gone” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the phrase “and it consumed” is referring to Eating.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And now </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that we have interpreted </span>that the phrase “and it consumed” is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Eating, from where do we </span>derive that one is liable with regard to actions categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own? </span>The primary category of Trampling is derived from the phrase “and he sends forth.” The connotation of that phrase is a case where the owner sent the animal to cause damage.
The Gemara answers: It is derived because the category of Trampling is juxtaposed to and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the category <span class="gemarra-regular">of Eating: Just as</span> with regard to liability for the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no different </span>if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the animal to cause damage and <span class="gemarra-regular">it is no different </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own, so too, </span>with regard to liability for the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no different </span>if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the animal to cause damage and <span class="gemarra-regular">it is no different </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let the Merciful One write </span>only the first phrase, <span class="gemarra-regular">“and he sends forth,” and there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would be no need </span>to write the second phrase, <span class="gemarra-regular">“and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it consumed,” as </span>the phrase “and he sends forth” <span class="gemarra-regular">connotes Trampling and connotes Eating. It connotes Trampling, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written: “That send forth the feet of the ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the donkey” </span>(Isaiah 32:20), and <span class="gemarra-regular">it connotes Eating, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written: “And the teeth of animals I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will send forth against them” </span>(Deuteronomy 32:24).
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If not for the additional </span>phrase in the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>“and it consumed,” <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that the verse refers <span class="gemarra-regular">either </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>category of damage <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>category of damage: It refers <span class="gemarra-regular">either </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, where its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage is </span>commonplace, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where there is pleasure</span> for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>both interpretations <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">equal </span>validity, <span class="gemarra-regular">let both of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them come </span>and be derived from the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of them will you exclude? </span>Since there is no reason to prefer one category over the other, perforce both are derived, and the phrase “and it consumed” is unnecessary. The Gemara answers: The additional phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary, </span>as it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>of liability <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the animal to cause damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own, </span>the owner would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable for the damage. Therefore, the phrase “and it consumed” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the owner is liable even in a case where the ox went and caused damage on its own.
Having clarified the sources for the primary categories of Eating and Trampling, the Gemara proceeds to identify their subcategories and to determine whether it was with regard to these primary categories of damage that Rav Pappa said: There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a subcategory of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is a case where, for example, an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">rubbed against a wall for its pleasure </span>and damaged the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">it sullied produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> by rolling on it <span class="gemarra-regular">for its pleasure.</span>
If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>that it is defined as a unique primary category? What is different is <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>its owner. In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>subcategories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, as well, there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is pleasure </span>for the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the oxen are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent your oxen from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>Therefore, the subcategories of Eating are not dissimilar to the primary category. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sub-category of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eating is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and when Rav Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a subcategory of Trampling.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> subcategory of Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The classification is applied in a case where, for example, an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage with its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> body, </span>not its legs, in the <span class="gemarra-regular">course of its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">walking; </span>or caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with its hair </span>that became entangled with an object in the <span class="gemarra-regular">course of its walking; </span>or caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope that is upon it;</span> or caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bit [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bifrumbiya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in its mouth; </span>or caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bell </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is around its neck.</span>
If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling </span>that it is defined as a unique category? What is different is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its damage is commonplace, and </span>the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>its owner. In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>subcategories of Trampling, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, their damage is commonplace, and </span>the oxen are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding,</span> to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Therefore, the subcategories of Trampling are not dissimilar to the primary category. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Trampling is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, and when Rav Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a subcategory of Pit.</span>
The Gemara examines that assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a subcategory of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Pit? If we say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">primary category </span>of Pit applies when, in the public domain, one leaves an uncovered pit that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths deep, and that is the pit mentioned in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a subcategory </span>of Pit applies when one leaves an uncovered pit that is <span class="gemarra-regular">nine</span> handbreadths deep, there is no basis for that distinction, as <span class="gemarra-regular">neither nine </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">are written </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the Torah.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him” </span>(Exodus 21:34), <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Sages have </span>an accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">tradition </span>that a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">causes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of an animal that falls into it, but a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage </span>to an animal that falls into it but <span class="gemarra-regular">does not cause death. </span>Accordingly, the pit written in the Torah (Exodus 21:33), which mentions the death of the animal that fell therein, is ten handbreadths deep. This is classified as the primary category of Pit, and a pit nine handbreadths deep is its subcategory.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, this </span>pit that is ten handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">is a primary category </span>of damage with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and that </span>pit that is nine handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> primary category </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Rav Pappa’s statement: There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, was stated in reference <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> these subcategories of Pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">His stone, his knife, or his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> load</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> any of <span class="gemarra-regular">which he placed in a public</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain </span>as obstacles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they caused damage </span>when people stumbled upon them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where one is liable for damage caused by these obstacles? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, both according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, </span>cited later in the Gemara, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>as both Rav and Shmuel agree that any obstacle declared ownerless by its owner that causes damage in the public domain is a subcategory of Pit. 

Daf 3b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not declare them ownerless, there is still a difficulty. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Rav Pappa’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, who says: We learned </span>that one is liable for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that he places in a public domain, whether or not he declares them ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s pit,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. And if </span>Rav Pappa’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says: We learned </span>that one is liable for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that he places in a public domain that he did not declare ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span> that gored another animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox. </span>With regard to the subcategories of Ox, the Gemara already established that their legal status is like that of the primary category of Ox.
The Gemara asks concerning an obstacle that is a subcategory of Pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that it is defined it as a unique category? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its initial formation, </span>i.e., the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage to others, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>subcategories of Pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, their initial formation, </span>i.e., the placement of the obstacle in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. Rather, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Pit is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, and when Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a subcategory of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The meaning of the term <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is not clear; therefore, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the primary category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> to whose subcategories the Gemara referred? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that Rav Pappa said his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>is the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, </span>this cannot be Rav Pappa’s intent. <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eating is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating? </span>Clearly, Rav Pappa was not referring to subcategories of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>one suggests that Rav Pappa said his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, </span>which includes damage caused by a person, not by his property or animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">what primary categories and what subcategories are there in </span>that category? The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is the same with regard to all damage that a person causes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that there is a distinction: The <span class="gemarra-regular">primary category </span>is a case where one causes damage while <span class="gemarra-regular">awake, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory </span>is a case where one causes damage while <span class="gemarra-regular">asleep; but didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (26a): The legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">always </span>that of one <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he is liable for any damage that he causes, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> awake and </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">he is asleep? </span>Accordingly, that is not the distinction between a primary category and a subcategory.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>perhaps Rav Pappa was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>cases where one causes damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">his phlegm or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his spittle. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where one would be liable for damage in that case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>his phlegm and spittle <span class="gemarra-regular">cause damage as they were movin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> through the air after the person expectorated, that <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>and there is no room to distinguish between the damage that it caused and any other damage caused by one’s direct action. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case where his phlegm or spittle causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">after it comes to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> res</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on the ground, e.g., if one slipped in the spittle, fell, and was injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">both according to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and according to Shmue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>as the spittle is an ownerless obstacle in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and when Rav Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them; he was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a subcategory of Fire.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a subcategory of Fire? If we say </span>that it is a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his stone, his knife, or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his load</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where he placed them on top of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his roof, and they fell </span>off the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">by means</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a common wind</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they caused damage, what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are the circumstances </span>in which one would be liable for the damage that was caused? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>those items <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage as they were moving </span>through the air propelled by the wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire.</span>
If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire </span>that defines it as a unique category? What is different is <span class="gemarra-regular">that another force, </span>the wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">is involved with </span>the fire in causing damage, as the wind causes the fire to spread, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>subcategories of Fire <span class="gemarra-regular">too, another force is involved </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the items placed on the roof and causes damage, as the wind causes them to fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. Rather, </span>it is apparent that the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Fire is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire, and when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>There are among them some whose subcategories are dissimilar to them, he was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a subcategory </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: A subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling? But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">establish that </span>the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Trampling is similar to </span>that of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling? </span>The Gemara explains: Rav Pappa was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one’s liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">pebble</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in a case where they were inadvertently propelled by the foot of a walking animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned through traditio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and not explicitly written in the Torah.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it is a unique halakhic category and the payment is different, <span class="gemarra-regular">why is it characterized </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Trampling? </span>The Gemara explains: It is due to the fact that it shares a common aspect with Trampling. One whose animal propels pebbles while it walks and thereby causes damage is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>half of the damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality</span> property, and he does not pay only from the body of his animal, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning half the cost of the damage paid by the owner of an innocuous ox that gored a person or an animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rava raise a dilemma</span> with regard to that matter? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava raised a dilemma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to one’s liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>propelled by the foot of his animal, does <span class="gemarra-regular">one pay </span>damages exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his ox that caused the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">or</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">one pay </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property?
The Gemara explains: Although <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a dilemma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for Rava, it is obvious to Rav Pappa </span>that one pays from his superior-quality property, and in that sense, he classified the pebbles that cause damage as a subcategory of Trampling.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Rava, who raises it as a dilemma, why is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it characterized </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Trampling </span>when its legal status is different both in terms of the extent of one’s liability and in terms of the manner of payment? The Gemara explains: It is classified as a subcategory of Trampling in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt </span>from liability pebbles that cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>just as damage in the category of Trampling is exempt in the public domain.
§ One of the primary categories of damage enumerated in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>another is <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that </span>is the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, </span>which includes a person who causes damage, but not the property or animal of a person that causes damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>is the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, as it is written: “The watchman said: Morning</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has come, and also night; if you will inquire [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tivayun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], inquire [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’ayu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Isaiah 21:12). The terms “<span class="it-text">tivayun</span>” and “<span class="it-text">be’ayu</span>,” meaning inquire, refer to a person, who is able to inquire. Accordingly, <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> relates to an action performed by a person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, as it is written: “How </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is Esau searched out [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">neḥpesu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; how are his hidden places </span><span class="gemarra-regular">revealed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nivu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Obadiah 1:6)? The terms <span class="it-text">nivu</span> and <span class="it-text">maveh</span> share a common root. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where may </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred </span>that <span class="it-text">nivu</span> connotes Eating? The Gemara explains that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yosef translate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the verse into Aramaic: <span class="gemarra-regular">How is Esau searched out [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">itbelish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> how are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his hidden places revealed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">itgaleyan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The meaning of the Aramaic term <span class="it-text">itgaleyan</span> means revealed, and that is the meaning of the Hebrew term “<span class="it-text">nivu</span>.” <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> references the animal’s teeth, which are covered when its mouth is closed and revealed when it eats.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel? </span>The Gemara explains that Rav could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to you: Is it taught </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-italic">Niveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span><span class="it-text">Niveh</span> is the passive form of the word <span class="it-text">maveh</span>, which would be the appropriate form if the reference was to teeth that are revealed. The term in the mishna is <span class="it-text">maveh</span>, an active form of the verb.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not say </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to the category of Man, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? </span>The Gemara explains that Shmuel could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Is it taught </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-italic">Bo’eh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span><span class="it-text">Bo’eh</span> is a form of the word <span class="it-text">maveh</span> connoting an action taken directly, which would be appropriate were the reference to one’s actions that cause damage. The term in the mishna is <span class="it-text">maveh</span>, which connotes an action that one causes another to take.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">After all, the </span>meaning of the term in the <span class="gemarra-regular">verses is not precise according to </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not precise according to </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Shmuel. It is apparent that their dispute is not based upon their interpretation of the verses; it must be based on another issue. The Gemara asks again: As for <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel? </span>The Gemara explains: Rav holds that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox </span>in the mishna. This includes damage caused by an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and all matters </span>involving damaging actions <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>are completed by <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, </span>i.e., the actions included in the categories of Goring, Eating, and Trampling. Perforce, <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to a different category of damage, i.e., Man.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel too, </span>who interpreted <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> as Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox, </span>which should include all matters involving damaging actions that are completed by an ox? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that according to Shmuel, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches Ox </span>specifically with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage caused with <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> horn, and </span>it teaches <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage caused with <span class="gemarra-regular">its tooth. And </span>when the mishna contrasts Ox with <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>The defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, where there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>inherent <span class="gemarra-regular">pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where there is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>

Daf 4a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">re’i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where it is not the objective of </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause damage, is not similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, where the objective </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is to cause damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it </span>possible to derive Goring from Eating by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where it is not the objective of </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause damage, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, where the objective of </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cause damage, </span>should the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>be liable? The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary </span>for the Torah to state the case of Goring, as it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that the owner is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as he is </span>exempt in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">slave or maidservan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> causes damage. When <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or maidservant </span>causes damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">although</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their objective is to cause damage, even so </span>their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt </span>from liability; and <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>when one’s animal causes damage, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is no different. </span>To dispel this notion, the Torah explicitly states that one is liable for damage caused by the primary category of Goring.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slave or maidservant </span>causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">there is not a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> substantial reason </span>to exempt the master?
