In that case there is concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps his master will provoke hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in retribution <span class="gemarra-regular">he will go and set fire to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another’s stack </span>of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>slave <span class="gemarra-regular">renders his master liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">maneh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> ten thousand dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">each day. </span>Therefore, there is no basis for the notion that an ox that gores would be exempt just as a slave is exempt, as perhaps, fundamentally, one is liable to pay for damage caused by his slave. A master is exempt from payment to prevent a situation where a slave would exploit that situation to take revenge against his master.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">refutes </span>any possibility to derive the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Ox from <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> or <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> from Ox in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner: The <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">objective</span> of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is to cause damage, is not similar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is not the objective of </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, is not similar to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, where there is no pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
According to Rav Yehuda’s explanation of Shmuel’s opinion, among the primary categories of damage caused by an ox, the mishna mentions only Goring and Eating. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling; </span>did the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">omit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>from the mishna? The Gemara answers: The principle stated in general terms at the end of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>a component of any of these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">causes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage, the </span>owner or generator of the component that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage is obligated </span>to remit payments of restitution for damage with best-quality land, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the intent of the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> is to teach the primary category of Trampling as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him teach it explicitly. </span>Accordingly, Rav Yehuda’s explanation of how Shmuel interprets the mishna is rejected.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that according to Shmuel, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ox </span>specifically with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>actions that cause damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">its foot and </span>it teaches <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>actions that cause damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">its tooth. And </span>when the mishna contrasts Ox with <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> saying: </span>The defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, where its damage is commonplace, is not similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its damage is not commonplace, and </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, where there is pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not similar to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, where there is no pleasure </span>for the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
According to Rav Yehuda’s explanation of Shmuel’s opinion, among the primary categories of damage with regard to an ox, the mishna mentions only Goring and Trampling. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But what </span>of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring; </span>did the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">omit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>from the mishna? The Gemara answers: The principle stated in general terms at the end of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when </span>a component of any of these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the </span>owner or generator of the component that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is obligated </span>to remit payments of restitution for damage with best-quality land, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the intent of the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> is to teach the primary category of Goring as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him teach it explicitly. </span>The Gemara explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>those categories of damage where the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the outset </span>and the owner is liable to pay for the entire damage the first time his animal causes damage that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>those categories of damage where the animal is initially <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>and the owner is liable to pay only half the cost of the damage caused by his animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately forewarned, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak </span>of them. With regard to Goring, the first three times an ox gores a person or an animal the owner of the ox pays only half of the damages. This is because an ox is considered forewarned with regard to damage categorized as Goring only after it attacks three times.
After addressing the reason that Rav did not say that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to Eating in accordance with the explanation of Shmuel, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to Man, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? </span>Shmuel could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you, if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, isn’t it taught </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the latter clause </span>of the mishna (15b): Both <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> forewarned ox, and an ox that causes damage in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>any damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">man? </span>Apparently, Man was mentioned in the latter clause of the mishna because it was not mentioned in the first clause.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>Man among the primary categories of damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first clause. </span>The Gemara explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>those categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body, </span>the category of Man, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, too, </span>the same difficulty arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>damage caused by a <span class="gemarra-regular">man taught in the latter clause </span>of the mishna? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to you: That </span>mention of damage caused by a man in the latter clause <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to enumerate </span>that damage <span class="gemarra-regular">together</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the other forms of damage in a case where the owner of the cause of damage or the generator of that damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of the statement in the mishna: The defining characteristic of the primary category of Ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not similar to </span>the defining characteristic of the primary category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>The defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox, where </span>if the ox kills a person the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the ranso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to the heirs of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, where </span>one who kills another <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>for killing him; rather, if he killed him unwittingly he is exiled and if he did so intentionally he is executed. And the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, where </span>if one injures another <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity, </span>i.e., pain, humiliation, medical costs, and the loss of livelihood, in addition to payment for the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic of the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox, where </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of indemnity </span>and is liable to pay only the cost of the damage.
The Gemara questions Rav’s understanding that Ox, as mentioned in the mishna, includes all actions an ox performs that cause damage, including goring, based on the continuation of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">The common denominator of </span>the components in all <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>primary categories of damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner to cause damage. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is it the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox to cause damage </span>by goring? The Gemara answers: The statement in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is it the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause damage </span>by goring? The Gemara answers: Yes, <span class="gemarra-regular">once it was forewarned </span>after goring repeatedly, <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner is </span>to cause damage by goring.
The Gemara questions Rav’s understanding that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is the primary category of Man: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner to cause damage? </span>The Gemara answers: The statement in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to </span>the damage one causes while <span class="gemarra-regular">sleeping. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause damage </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">sleeping? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">contracts and extend</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> his limbs while sleeping, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>to damage objects placed next to him.
If <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is referring to Man, is it correct to state, as the mishna does in its enumeration of common denominators of the primary categories: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding </span>is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you? </span>That formulation is appropriate in cases where one is safeguarding another person, animal, or item. When applied to the primary category of Man, it would indicate that responsibility to safeguard one person is incumbent upon another person. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">man, </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding his body</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him </span>alone, not upon anyone else.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, </span>that the formulation: And their safeguarding is incumbent upon you, indicates that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is not Man, there is a difficulty with <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">Karn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four primary categories of damage, and Man is one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues and states that one common denominator is: Their safeguarding is incumbent upon you. With regard to that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the same question arises: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding his body is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, </span>not upon anyone else, and the wording of Karna is imprecise. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Abbahu said to the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who was reciting the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in the study hall: <span class="gemarra-regular">Teach </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: And with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding his body is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him; </span>

Daf 4b

<span class="gemarra-regular">here too, teach </span>the mishna: And with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">man, </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding his body</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari objects </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the Gemara’s initial suggestion that the dispute between Rav and Shmuel with regard to the meaning of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is based on biblical terms with similar etymology. He suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">water, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written: “As when fire ignites brushwood; fire boils [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tiveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] water”</span> (Isaiah 64:1). The terms <span class="it-text">tiveh</span> and <span class="it-text">maveh</span> share a common root, and the reference is to water. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it written </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Water boils [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nivu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>from fire, with water, a plural noun in Hebrew, the subject of the intransitive plural verb, <span class="it-text">nivu</span>? No, <span class="gemarra-regular">“fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> boils [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tiveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] water” is written, </span>and since <span class="it-text">tiveh</span> is a transitive singular verb, the subject is fire, which is a singular noun. Therefore, no proof can be adduced from this verse that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> refers to an action performed with water.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid objects to </span>the Gemara’s initial suggestion that the dispute between Rav and Shmuel with regard to the meaning of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is based on biblical terms with similar etymology. He suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this is the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as when </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tiveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” is written </span>in the verse cited by Rav Mari, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Fire. </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, what </span>is the meaning when the mishna enumerates the primary categories of damage: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire, </span>indicating that they are two distinct categories? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you would say </span>that these are not two distinct categories but rather the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is explaining </span>the meaning of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, </span>why does the mishna say: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>primary categories of damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">three.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would say </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is Fire, and there are four categories in the mishna, as the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox, in which there are two </span>primary categories of damage, Eating and Trampling, the mishna remains difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> in the mishna is referring to Fire, what is the meaning of that which the mishna states with regard to the common denominator of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> and Ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the defining characteristics of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>category of Ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a living spirit, </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>similar to the defining characteristic of the next category in the mishna, in which there is no living spirit. Accordingly, how can <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> mean Fire; <span class="gemarra-regular">what living spirit is there in Fire? And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">furthermore, </span>if <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is Fire, what is the meaning of the next phrase in the mishna: They <span class="gemarra-regular">are not similar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire, </span>in which there is no living spirit. Clearly, <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is not Fire.
§ Contrary to the mishna, where four primary categories of damage were enumerated, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:1) that there are <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen primary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> categories of damage. </span>The thirteen categories consist of four bailees, five types of indemnity, and the four primary categories listed in the mishna. The four bailees are: The <span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who is liable for damage caused by his negligence; <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the borrower, </span>who is liable for all damage; the <span class="gemarra-regular">paid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the renter, </span>who is liable if the object is lost or stolen. The five types of indemnity one is liable to pay for injuring another person are: <span class="gemarra-regular">Damage, </span>i.e., the decrease in the injured party’s value; <span class="gemarra-regular">pain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and medical costs; loss of livelihood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and humiliation </span>that the injured party suffered from the assault. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">the four </span>primary categories enumerated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mishna, that </span>is a total of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach these </span>nine categories and enumerates only four? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, </span>who says that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is Eating, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks. With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak, </span>and the additional categories of Rabbi Oshaya are damage caused by one’s body. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, </span>who says that <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> is Man, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>these nine categories as well. The Gemara answers: According to Rav, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, and </span>included in that category are <span class="gemarra-regular">all matters </span>of damage that are caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">man, </span>among them the categories added by Rabbi Oshaya.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Oshaya too, doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man? </span>Why then did he enumerate the four bailees and the five types of indemnity? The Gemara answers: In his enumeration, Rabbi Oshaya distinguishes between <span class="gemarra-regular">two types </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a man: </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>cases involving <span class="gemarra-regular">a man who injures </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">person, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the primary category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, which involves the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a man who damages an ox </span>or damages other property belonging to another person.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox as well, let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him teach two categories of Ox. Let him teach </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that damages an ox </span>or other property belonging to another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him teach </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that injures a person.</span>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>comparison? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who damages </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>or other property, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays</span> merely for the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage; </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who injures </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">person, he pays </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">four types </span>of indemnity payments: Pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what </span>difference is there <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox that damages an ox </span>or other property belonging to another person and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference is there <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that injures a person? </span>In both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>merely for the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Therefore, unlike a case where a person causes the damage, there is no reason to distinguish between cases where an ox causes damage based on the victim of that damage.
With regard to the assertion that Rabbi Oshaya added only cases involving a man who injures another person, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But aren’t </span>there the categories of the <span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee and the borrower, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">paid bailee and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">renter, which are </span>categories that describe <span class="gemarra-regular">a man who damages </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>or other property, as the cases referred to by Rabbi Oshaya are those where the bailee fails to return the deposit that he was entrusted to safeguard? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>each type of bailee as distinct categories and does not include them under the rubric of Man, one of the four categories enumerated in the mishna.
The Gemara answers that the reason why Rabbi Oshaya enumerates Man separately from the bailees is that he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>one category, Man, referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that </span>is engendered <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action, </span>e.g., the five types of indemnity payments, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the four bailees, referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that occurs on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its own, </span>e.g., failure of the four bailees to safeguard the deposit.
The Gemara cites a third listing of primary categories of damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches </span>that there are <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-four primary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> categories of damage: Payment of double </span>the principal, paid by a thief who is apprehended and convicted based on the testimony of witnesses and who does not admit his crime; <span class="gemarra-regular">and payment of four or five </span>times the principal, paid by a thief who steals an ox or sheep, respectively, and then slaughters or sells it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>payment of the principal, by <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>who admits his crime; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> robber, who </span>steals openly and by force or threat of violence; <span class="gemarra-regular">and conspiring witnesses </span>who pay the individual against whom they falsely testified with regard to a sum that they conspired to cause him to lose.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the rapist, and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seducer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who seduces an unmarried young woman, who pay a fine of fifty <span class="it-text">sela</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the defamer, </span>i.e., one who defames his wife by claiming falsely in court that he discovered that she was not a virgin when he consummated the marriage and alleges that she engaged in intercourse with another man while betrothed, who pays a fine of one hundred <span class="it-text">sela</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who causes </span>another’s <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to become ritually impure, </span>rendering it prohibited to partake of that <span class="it-text">teruma</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who mixes </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> with another’s non-sacred food, rendering it prohibited for any non-priest to partake of it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pours </span>another’s wine <span class="gemarra-regular">as a libation </span>for idolatry. When one combines the eleven categories enumerated by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and these thirteen </span>categories enumerated by Rabbi Oshaya, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>totals <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-four </span>principal categories of damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya, what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not teach these </span>eleven additional categories? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>cases where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>that Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks. With regard to </span>cases where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> speak.</span>
The Gemara asks: What of the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thief and a robber, which </span>are cases where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Let </span>Rabbi Oshaya also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>those cases and include them in his list. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t he teach </span>those cases, as he enumerates in his list the <span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee and the borrower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>An unpaid bailee who takes a false oath that the deposit was stolen, when in fact it remained in his possession, is liable to pay restitution like a thief.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya too, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t he teach </span>those cases; as he enumerates in his list the <span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee and the borrower? </span>Why does Rabbi Ḥiyya list them separately? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ḥiyya makes a distinction between different types of theft: He <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>cases of theft with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">property that came into </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession in a permitted </span>manner, e.g., an unpaid bailee who was entrusted with a deposit and later misappropriated it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>cases of theft with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">property that came into </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>manner, e.g., the actions of a thief and a robber. 

Daf 5a

The Gemara asks: With regard to the payment made by <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses, which is </span>categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the witnesses pay the precise sum that they conspired to cause the defendant to lose, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>Rabbi Oshaya also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach it</span> as one of the categories on his list. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">do not pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the basis of their own </span>admission. Evidently, theirs is not a payment of monetary restitution; rather, it is a fine, as only one who was found liable based on the testimony of witnesses pays a fine, not one who was found liable based on his own admission.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, let him teach two </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">types of </span>categories of damage under the rubric of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox: Let him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>one category for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that damages an ox </span>or other property belonging to another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that injures a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person.</span>
The Gemara explains its question: <span class="gemarra-regular">As we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a mishna (33a): In a case where the two parties damaged each other concurrently, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that injured a person also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the difference </span>between the damage caused by his ox and the damage that the person caused the ox. Rabbi Akiva holds that if an innocuous ox injures a person, the owner pays the full cost of the damage, whereas if an innocuous ox damages another’s property then the owner is liable only for half the cost of the damage. Since the owner’s liability in the two cases is different, each case should be classified as a distinct category, and Rabbi Oshaya should list them separately in his <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t Rabbi Akiva break </span>the force of <span class="gemarra-regular">his fist </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gezizeih</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he significantly tempered the force of his statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous ox that injured a person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">would pay from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property and not merely from the body of his animal, as in the case of an innocuous ox that damages property; therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to an ox that gores a person: “According to this judgment <span class="gemarra-regular">shall it be done to him” </span>(Exodus 21:31), from which it is derived that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>proceeds of the sale of the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does not pay </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property. The mishna states that one pays restitution from his superior-quality property in instances of all primary categories of damage. Since in the case of an innocuous ox that injured a person even Rabbi Akiva concedes that the owner does not pay from his superior-quality property, it should not be included in a list of the primary categories.
The Gemara asks: As for <span class="gemarra-regular">the rapist, and the seducer, and the defamer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> all of <span class="gemarra-regular">which are </span>cases in which the offender pays <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> restitution, let </span>Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>them as categories in his list.
The Gemara explains why Rabbi Oshaya did not teach them as separate categories: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever way you </span>look at it, they should not be listed. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the payments listed by Rabbi Ḥiyya are for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused to the woman’s body, which reduces her value, he already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught it; if </span>the payments are for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain, </span>he already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught it; if </span>the payments are for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>he already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught it; if </span>the payment is for <span class="gemarra-regular">degradation, that </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which he already taught. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">have you to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say? </span>What is the nature of the payments paid by the rapist and the seducer mentioned by Rabbi Ḥiyya? In these cases, each payment paid is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kenasa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and as explained, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>cases in which one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, </span>Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not speak.</span>
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who causes </span>another’s <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to become ritually impure, and one who mixes </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> with another’s non-sacred food, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pours </span>another’s wine <span class="gemarra-regular">as a libation </span>for idolatry, each of <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span>a case in which the offender must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>to compensate the owner for his loss due to the lowered value of his food or wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>them as categories in his list.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever </span><span class="gemarra-regular">way you </span>look at it, these cases should not be listed. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Rabbi Oshaya holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">evident</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., where the object is physically unchanged but its halakhic status is changed, <span class="gemarra-regular">is characterized as damage </span>for which one is liable to pay restitution, Rabbi Oshaya already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught, </span>i.e., included in his list, restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> evident is not characterized as damage </span>for which one is liable to pay restitution, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a fine, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as explained, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>cases for which one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, </span>Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara suggests: Since Rabbi Ḥiyya lists these cases as distinct categories, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not evident is not characterized as damage </span>for which one is liable to pay restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were characterized as damage </span>for which one is liable to pay restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t </span>he already <span class="gemarra-regular">teach, </span>i.e., include in his list, restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage? </span>The Gemara rejects that suggestion: Even if he holds that damage that is evident is characterized as damage for which one is liable to pay restitution, he distinguishes between different types of damage. He <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that is evident and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage that is not evident.</span>
The Gemara considers the fact that each of the lists of primary categories is introduced with the number that they total: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">our </span>mishna, he <span class="gemarra-regular">taught the number </span>of four primary categories in introducing his list <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>those additional categories <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya. And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya taught the number </span>of thirteen primary categories <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>those additional categories <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥiyya. But what </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the number </span>of twenty-four primary categories <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥiyya </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude?</span>
The Gemara answers: He taught that number in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">an informer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who provides information to the authorities leading them to confiscate another person’s property; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>to exclude the case of a priest who <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>an offering <span class="gemarra-italic">piggul</span> by performing the sacrificial rites for one offering with the intent to sacrifice it for the sake of another offering, in which case the person who brought the offering must replace it with another.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>these cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he did not include the case of a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">who renders </span>an offering <span class="gemarra-italic">piggul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Perhaps, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>cases involving <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>items, Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak. But </span>with regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an informer, what is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach it </span>and include it in his list of categories? The Gemara answers: The case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an informer is different, as </span>the damage is caused through <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, and with regard to </span>damage caused through <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">does not speak.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t </span>there the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a defamer, where </span>the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>caused through <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, and </span>yet Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span> it and includes it in his list? The Gemara answers: He includes that case because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">speech that involves an action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One who defames his wife is liable only if he made his allegation after engaging in intercourse with her.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">speech that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">involves no action, </span>as they are liable for their testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>it and includes it in his list? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, although it involves no action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the Merciful One characterizes it </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">an action, as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: “And you shall do to him as he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> conspired to do unto his brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:19).
The Gemara considers the subcategories of the various primary categories listed: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna, his terminology is understandable, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he taught primary categories, </span>which, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there are </span>also additional forms of damage that are <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategories</span> of those primary categories. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Ḥiyya and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Oshaya, </span>why did they employ the terminology they employed? They employed the term <span class="gemarra-regular">primary categories, </span>which, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">that there are subcategories. What are the subcategories </span>of the primary categories they listed? It appears that they enumerated all the various categories of damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says: </span>When Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Oshaya characterize, as primary categories, the various categories of damage that they listed, it is not to indicate that there are subcategories; rather, it is to indicate that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are characterized as primary categories, </span>in the sense that one is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay from </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">best</span>-quality property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>for this, i.e., from where is it derived? The Gemara explains: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived </span>using a verbal analogy from the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“in place of,” “giving,” “he shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pay,” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“money.” </span>The term “in place of” is written with regard to a forewarned ox that gores (Exodus 21:36); “he shall give” is written with regard to an ox that kills a slave (Exodus 21:32); “he shall pay” is written with regard to the categories of damage of Eating and Trampling (Exodus 22:4); and “money” is written with regard to Pit (Exodus 21:34). The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one must pay from his best-quality property is stated explicitly in each of those four verses. In each of the twenty-four categories listed by Rabbi Ḥiyya one of those four terms is written, so by means of a verbal analogy, the requirement to pay from one’s best-quality property applies to each of them.
§ The mishna states: The defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox is not similar to</span> the defining characteristic of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-italic">Maveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? Rav Zevid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Let the Merciful One write one</span> of the primary categories <span class="gemarra-regular">and derive the other </span>categories <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it. Then </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>possible to <span class="gemarra-regular">derive one </span>category <span class="gemarra-regular">from one </span>other category, as each category has its unique characteristics.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the defining characteristics of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>category of Ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and that</span> category of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which there is a living </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spirit, </span>are not similar to the defining characteristic of the category of Fire, in which there is no living spirit. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? Rav Mesharshiyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>

Daf 5b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Merciful One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>of the primary categories <span class="gemarra-regular">and derive </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>categories <span class="gemarra-regular">from them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Then </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>possible to <span class="gemarra-regular">derive one </span>category <span class="gemarra-regular">from two </span>other categories, as each category has its own unique characteristics, which prevent the derivation of a new category even from a combination of two categories.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the primary categories in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">when you cast </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit among them, all </span>of the rest <span class="gemarra-regular">of them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">be derived through </span>an analogy based on <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">common factor </span>of two categories. This is the case with all of the categories <span class="gemarra-regular">except for Goring, due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is </span>room <span class="gemarra-regular">to refute </span>the analogy to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of Goring with the following contention: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about all of </span>the other categories? They are notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that they are forewarned from their outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since it is the typical manner of the animal to trample and eat, and the typical manner of fire to burn, and the typical manner of a pit to serve as an obstacle, the owner is always forewarned with regard to safeguarding against damage and is liable to pay full damages for his failure to prevent the damage even the first time. With regard to Goring, the animal is innocuous for the first three instances of damage and only thereafter is the animal forewarned, rendering its owner liable to pay full damages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: On the contrary, Goring is superior </span>in the sense that one’s liability in a case of Goring is more apparent, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the objective of </span>the ox’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is to cause damage, even Goring </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">be derived </span>from the common factor of two sources.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if all the categories can be derived from another category and Pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did the Merciful </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One write </span>all the primary categories explicitly? The Gemara answers: It is in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>unique <span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span> that apply exclusively to each category.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>is written explicitly in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish between </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Trampling </span>are written explicitly in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from liability those whose animals perform the actions in these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">in a public domain.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>is written explicitly in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt </span>one from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> caused when they fall into a pit. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who deems one liable </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>caused when they fall <span class="gemarra-regular">into a pit, </span>Pit was written in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt </span>one from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the death of <span class="gemarra-regular">a perso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> who was killed by falling into a pit. Rabbi Yehuda concedes that the possessor of the pit is exempt because the person who ultimately fell into the pit was capable of avoiding it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Man </span>is written explicitly in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to render him liable for four </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of indemnity, beyond the payment of damages for the diminution in value caused when one injures a person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Fire </span>is written explicitly in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt </span>one from liability for damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>object, e.g., one hidden by grain, that was consumed by fire. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to Rabbi Yehuda, who deems one liable </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage </span>done to <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>object damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">fire, to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> add what </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> does the Torah mention the category of Fire explicitly? 

Daf 6a

The Gemara answers: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add</span> cases where the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">scorched </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed field and</span> cases in which <span class="gemarra-regular">it singed his stones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Even though the damaged object remains intact and is not consumed by the fire, one is still liable to pay for the damage caused.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">The common denominator of </span>the components in all these categories is that it is their typical manner to cause damage. The Gemara asks: In order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> add what </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> is this statement cited in the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The stating of the common denominator in the mishna serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add </span>that one is liable in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his stone, his knife, or his load, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where he placed them on top of his roof, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they fell </span>off the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of a common </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wind and caused damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances </span>in which one would be liable for the damage that was caused? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>those items <span class="gemarra-regular">cause damage as they are movin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> through the air propelled by the wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire.</span>
Therefore, one could claim: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire </span>that defines it as a unique category? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that another force is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">involved with it </span>in causing damage, as it is the wind that causes the fire to spread and cause damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the entity propelled by the wind is <span class="gemarra-regular">your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, another force is involved with them </span>in causing damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the objects are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>Perforce, there is no need for the common denominator in the mishna to teach the case of an object that causes damage when propelled off a roof by the wind. That case is included in the primary category of Fire that is explicitly mentioned in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> perhaps the common denominator serves to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable when <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>those objects fall from the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">they come to rest </span>on the ground, and they cause damage as an obstacle on which a person or an animal stumbles. The mishna teaches that the one who placed them on the roof is liable. The Gemara questions this explanation: What are the circumstances in which one is liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ownerless, both according to Rav and according to Shmuel, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit.</span>
Therefore, one could claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that defines it as a unique category? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its initial formation, </span>i.e., the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage to others, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you.</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items he had placed on the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, their initial formation, </span>i.e., when the obstacle reached the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>Perforce, there is no need for the common denominator in the mishna to teach the case where the objects fell from the roof, came to rest in the public domain, and were declared ownerless. That case is included in the primary category of Pit that is explicitly mentioned in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>perhaps the common denominator serves to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not declare them ownerless. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Shmuel, who says: We learned </span>that one is liable to pay for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that one places in a public domain, whether or not he declares them ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The question remains: What <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does the common denominator in the mishna teach?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna teaches one’s liability in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared</span> the objects <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, and </span>even if he declared them ownerless, those objects <span class="gemarra-regular">are not similar to </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that there is no other force</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> involved with it </span>in causing the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Will you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to these </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">another force involved with it </span>in causing the damage, i.e., the wind that propelled them from the roof to rest on the ground?
The Gemara suggests: If one attempts to challenge the derivation from Pit in this manner, it is possible to respond: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prove </span>that this factor, that there is another force involved with the object in causing the damage, is not a reason to exempt one from paying restitution for the damage, as although there is another force involved in the spreading of a fire, one is liable for the damage the fire causes, so the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to these objects can be derived from that of Fire.
The Gemara questions the derivation from Fire: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about Fire? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Will you say the same with regard to these objects propelled by the wind into the public domain, where it is not their typical manner to proceed and cause damage? Accordingly, how can one learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case from that of Fire?
The Gemara suggests: If one attempts to challenge the derivation from Fire in this manner, it is possible to respond: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit will prove </span>that the lack of this characteristic, of a typical manner being to proceed and cause damage, is not a reason to exempt the owner of the objects from paying restitution for the damage, as that is the nature of Pit, and one is liable for damage caused by his pit. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as Pit and Fire each prove that the defining characteristic of the other is not decisive in establishing liability or exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">the derivation has reverted </span>to its starting point, and liability in these cases is derived from the common denominator of Pit and Fire. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> added by the common denominator stated in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The stating of the common denominator in the mishna serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> add </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit where </span>an object <span class="gemarra-regular">is rolle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">feet of a person or the hooves of an animal.</span> This is a case where one placed an obstacle in a public domain and the obstacle caused no damage where it was placed, but subsequently was kicked by passersby to a different location where it caused damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which one is liable for damage in that case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>the objects <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, both according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rav and according to Shmuel this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit.</span>
Therefore, one could claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that it is defined as a unique category? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its initial formation, </span>i.e., the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage to others, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>objects, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, their initial </span><span class="gemarra-regular">formation, </span>i.e., when the obstacle reaches the in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>Perforce, there is no need for the mishna to state their common denominator to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case where the objects came to rest and are declared ownerless. That case is included in the primary category of Pit that is explicitly mentioned in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>perhaps the common denominator serves to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not declare </span>the objects <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Shmuel, who says: We learned </span>that one is liable for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that one places in a public domain, whether or not he declares them ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s pit, this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. </span>What <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does the common denominator in the mishna teach?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna teaches one’s liability in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>the objects <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, and </span>even if he declared them ownerless, those objects <span class="gemarra-regular">are not similar to </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that one’s actions, </span>the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">cause </span>the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Will you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to these </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">where one’s actions </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not cause </span>damage? Rather, it is the feet of the passersby that caused the damage, by rolling the object to a different location where it caused damage.
The Gemara suggests: If one attempts to challenge the derivation from Pit in this manner, it is possible to respond: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox will prove </span>that this fact, that one’s actions do not cause the damage, is not a reason to exempt one from paying restitution for the damage, as although the owner’s actions do not cause the ox to cause damage, one is liable for the damage caused by his ox.
The Gemara questions the derivation from Ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about Ox? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>it is the typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of the animals in these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span> By contrast, in the case of the obstacle kicked by passersby to a different location where it caused damage, it is not its typical manner to proceed and cause damage. Accordingly, how can one learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case from the primary category of Ox? The Gemara suggests: The primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit will prove </span>that this fact, that the typical manner of a category’s components is not to proceed and cause damage, is not a reason to exempt one from paying restitution for the damage, as that is the nature of Pit, and one is liable for damage caused by his pit.
