The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as Pit and Ox each proves that the defining characteristic of the other is not decisive in establishing one’s liability or exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">the derivation has reverted </span>to its starting point, which is that the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>primary category of Ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to </span>the defining <span class="gemarra-regular">characteristic </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>category of Pit, and liability in these cases is derived from the common denominator of Pit and Ox. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> added by the common denominator stated in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Ahava said: </span>The stating of the common denominator in the mishna serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable to pay damages in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">that is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all those </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span> engage in activities that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>are permitted, i.e., those who <span class="gemarra-regular">open their gutter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and drain the sewage from their houses into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>those who <span class="gemarra-regular">flush out </span>the water from <span class="gemarra-regular">their caves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where foul-smelling water was stored, into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">during</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the summer they do not have permissio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to do so, while <span class="gemarra-regular">during the rainy season they have permission </span>to do so, since the street is rained upon in any event and thereby washed. And <span class="gemarra-regular">although </span>all these people perform their actions <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if they cause damage they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are liable to pay </span>for it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which one is liable for damage caused by the sewage? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the sewage <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage as it is moving, </span>after he poured it into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action, </span>and it is no different from any other damage caused by a person. According to Rav, it is under the rubric of <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> in the mishna. According Shmuel it appears in the next mishna, and it is not derived from the common denominator mentioned in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is in a case where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the sewage <span class="gemarra-regular">came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to rest </span>on the floor, e.g., a passerby slipped on it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If</span> it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>the sewage <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, both according to Rav and according to Shmuel, this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that it is defined as a unique category? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its initial formation, </span>i.e., the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage to others, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>sewage, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, its initial formation, </span>i.e., the placement of the sewage in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your property, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>perhaps the common denominator serves to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not declare </span>the sewage <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Shmuel, who says: We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>that one is liable for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that one places in a public domain, whether or not he declares them ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s pit, this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The question remains: What <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does the common denominator in the mishna teach?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna teaches one’s liability in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he declared </span>the sewage <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, and </span>even if he declared it ownerless, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. What</span> is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>the pit was dug in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Will you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sewage was channeled into the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission? </span>

Daf 6b

The Gemara suggests: The primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox will prove </span>that this fact, that the ox, i.e., the cause of the damage, entered the public domain with permission, is not a reason to exempt its owner from payment, as that is the nature of the primary category of Ox, and one is liable for damage caused by his ox.
The Gemara questions the derivation from Ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ox? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>it is the typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of the animals in these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>By contrast, in the case of the sewage, it is not its typical manner to proceed and cause damage. Accordingly, how can one learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case from the primary category of Ox?
The Gemara suggests: If one attempts to challenge the derivation from Ox in this manner, it is possible to respond: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit will prove </span>that the lack of this characteristic, of the typical manner being to proceed and cause damage, is not a reason to exempt one from paying restitution for the damage, as that is the nature of Pit, and one is liable for damage caused by his pit. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as Pit and Ox each prove that the defining characteristic of the other is not decisive in establishing liability or exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">the derivation has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> reverted </span>to its starting point, and liability in these cases is derived from the common denominator of Pit and Ox. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> added by the common denominator stated in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said:</span> The stating of the common denominator in the mishna serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is liable to pay damages in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">that we learned </span>in a mishna (117b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a wall or a tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that fell </span>on its own <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and caused damage, </span>the owner of the wall or tree is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying </span>damages because he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control. But if the court had sensed the potential danger and had <span class="gemarra-regular">allotted him </span>a certain amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>during which he was obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">to chop </span><span class="gemarra-regular">down the tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to demolish the wall, </span>and he had not yet done so, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wall or tree <span class="gemarra-regular">fell </span>into the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">within the </span>allotted <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and caused damage, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying damages. If he did not do so and it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">after the</span> allotted <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>expired, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to pay the damages.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>the fallen tree or wall <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, both according to Rav and according to Shmuel, this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. What is different </span>about the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that it is defined as a unique category? What is different is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its damage is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> commonplace, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is your property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> safeguarding, </span>to prevent it from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases involving the tree and the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, their damage is commonplace, and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property, and </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their safeguarding, </span>to prevent them from causing damage, is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not declare them ownerless, according to Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who says: We learned </span>that one is liable for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>obstacles that he places in the public domain whether or not he declares them ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s pit, this is </span>a subcategory of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna teaches one’s liability in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one declared </span>the tree or wall <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless, and </span>even if he declared them ownerless, they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not similar to</span> the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit. What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> initial formation, </span>i.e., the digging of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Will you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to these </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">where their initial formation, </span>i.e., the planting of the tree and the building of the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage?</span>
The Gemara suggests: The primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox will prove </span>that this factor, of not being initially formed in a manner that can result in damage, is not a reason to exempt its owner from payment, as that is the nature of the primary category of Ox, i.e., an ox is not born in a manner that results in damage, and one is liable for damage caused by his ox.
The Gemara questions the derivation from Ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about Ox? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>it is the typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of the animals in these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed </span>from one place to another <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>By contrast, in the case of the tree and wall, it is not their typical manner to proceed and cause damage. Accordingly, how can one learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in these cases from the primary category of Ox?
The Gemara suggests: If one attempts to challenge the derivation from Ox in this manner, it is possible to respond: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit will prove </span>that the lack of this characteristic, of the typical manner being to proceed and cause damage, is not a reason to exempt one from paying restitution for the damage, as that is the nature of Pit, and one is liable for damage caused by his pit. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as Pit and Ox each prove that the defining characteristic of the other is not decisive in establishing liability or exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">the derivation has reverted</span> to its starting point, and liability in the cases of the tree and the wall is derived from the common denominator of Pit and Ox. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> added by the common denominator stated in the mishna.
§ The mishna states: And <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>a component of any of these categories <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage, the </span>owner or generator of the component that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage is obligated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to pay restitution with best-quality land. The Gemara asks: Why does the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna use the unusual expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one liable for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the damage is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥav</span> to pay? He should have used the more standard expression for liability: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one liable for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the damage is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayyav</span> to pay. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Jerusalemite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who teaches </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">a light </span>and concise <span class="gemarra-regular">formulation, </span>as <span class="it-text">ḥav</span> is more concise than <span class="it-text">ḥayyav</span>.
§ The mishna continues: The owner or generator of the component that caused damage is obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>restitution for damage with best-quality land. The one liable for the damage is indebted <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>with his superior-quality land. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Torah states with regard to paying damages: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the best of his field, and of the best of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his vineyard he shall pay” </span>(Exodus 22:4). What is the meaning of “his field” and “his vineyard”? It refers to that property of the injured party; the one liable for the damage pays from land of a quality that is commensurate to <span class="gemarra-regular">the best</span>-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">field of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the best</span>-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">vineyard of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party, even if the property he damaged was of a lesser quality; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse comes only to </span>allow <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from superior-quality </span>land belonging to the one liable for the damage, in the event that he has no money or movable property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference one can derive that the Temple treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property collects from superior-quality land.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, </span>if one’s animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>garden bed, it is understandable that he <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay </span>the injured party the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>garden bed. But if it <span class="gemarra-regular">ate</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">a poor </span>garden bed, is it reasonable that he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>garden bed? While this is the straightforward meaning of his statement, it is untenable, as he would be paying more than the value of the damage he caused.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: With what are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal that caused the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from one <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bed among </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">garden beds, and we do not know </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whether it ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a poor </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">or it ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>one. In such a case, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the animal’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the injured party the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>raised a question and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: And if we would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> know that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a poor </span>garden bed, its owner would have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay only </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a poor </span>garden bed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that we do not know</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a poor </span>garden bed or <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a rich </span>garden bed, is it reasonable that he should have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rich </span>garden bed? There is a general principle governing monetary disputes that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof falls on the claimant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Therefore, so long as the injured party cannot prove that the animal ate from the rich garden bed, he should not be entitled to collect the value of such a garden bed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Aḥa bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ya’akov said: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>after appraising the damage, the court comes to collect from the one liable for the damage, but he does not have money available to pay for the damage. And the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> disagree in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">iddit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the best land, <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> equal </span>in quality <span class="gemarra-regular">to the inferior-quality </span>land<span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the one liable for the damage also has land of superior quality.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree with regard to this: Rabbi Yishmael holds: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We appraise </span>the value of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party, and therefore the one liable for the damage can pay with his inferior-quality fields, which are equal in quality to the best fields owned by the injured party. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva holds: We appraise </span>the value of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and have him pay with his fields of superior quality.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Yishmael? </span>The word <span class="gemarra-regular">“field” is stated below, </span>toward the end of the verse: “Of the best of his field, and of the best of his vineyard he shall pay” (Exodus 22:4). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“field” is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">stated above, </span>at the beginning of that same verse: “If a man causes a field or vineyard to be eaten, and he sends forth his animal, and it consumed in the field of another.” <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">field which is stated above </span>belongs to <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too the field stated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>belongs to <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva </span>holds: When the verse says: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Of the best of his field and of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">best of his vineyard he shall pay,” </span>it means from the best <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who is paying, </span>i.e., from the best fields belonging to the one liable for the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael </span>respond to this? The <span class="gemarra-regular">verbal analogy </span>between the two instances of the word “field” <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective, and</span> the straightforward meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective. The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verbal analogy is effective, as I stated. </span>It serves to teach that when it says that he pays from the best of his field, it means from land equal in quality to the best field owned by the injured party.
And the straightforward meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective, </span>as it serves to teach a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable for the damage has superior-quality </span>land<span class="gemarra-regular"> and inferior</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality </span>land<span class="gemarra-regular">, and the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">has inferior-quality </span>land<span class="gemarra-regular">, and the inferior-quality </span>land<span class="gemarra-regular"> of the one liable for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the damage is not as good as the superior-quality</span> land<span class="gemarra-regular"> of the injured </span>party. In this case, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">from his best </span>land, i.e., from the superior-quality land that he owns.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>legally <span class="gemarra-regular">unable to say to him: You </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">collect from </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land. He cannot say this because the standard for classifying land as being of superior-quality is set according to the injured party’s superior-quality land, and the inferior-quality land of the one liable for the damage is of a lower quality than that. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>his damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">best</span>-quality land of the one liable for the damage.
§ The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse comes only to </span>allow <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from superior-quality </span>land belonging to the one liable for the damage, in the event that he has no money or movable property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference one can derive that the Temple treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property collects from superior-quality land. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference from ordinary damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage involving the <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property? To which case does this refer?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">our ox, </span>i.e., an ox belonging to a Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">gored an ox that is consecrated </span>property, there is a difficulty, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states: </span>“And if one man’s ox hurts the <span class="gemarra-regular">ox of another” </span>(Exodus 21:35). This teaches that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies only if the ox hurt an ox belonging to another Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not</span> if it hurt <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is consecrated </span>property. In the latter case no damages are collected.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>we say that the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is referring not to a case of damage but <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who </span>vows and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: It is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to donate <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dinars for Temple maintenance. </span>And the inference teaches that if the one who took the vow has no money, then the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">treasurer comes and collects </span>the hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land.
The Gemara challenges this understanding: The Temple treasurer <span class="gemarra-regular">should not </span>be treated any better than an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor, </span>

Daf 7a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>is to collect only <span class="gemarra-regular">from intermediate-quality</span> land, not from superior-quality land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the money owed him <span class="gemarra-regular">from superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>there is still a difficulty; the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">be refuted</span> in the following manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor? </span>He is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his power with regard to payment of damages, </span>as an ordinary person can collect payment of damages for loss or injury caused by another’s ox. But <span class="gemarra-regular">can you say </span>the same about the Temple treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property, with regard to which the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">weakened its power with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to payment of damages, </span>not allowing it to collect such compensation? Accordingly, even if a creditor collects from superior-quality land, it does not necessarily follow that a Temple treasurer would also do so. It is therefore apparent that Rabbi Akiva’s <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is not referring to the case of one who donates money to the Temple.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>we can explain that we are dealing here with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where our ox gored an ox that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is consecrated </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to that <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>posed <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty for you </span>about this explanation, i.e., that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states: “</span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">ox of another” </span>(Exodus 21:35), which indicates that liability is incurred only for damaging another person’s ox <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox consecrated </span>to the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva </span>disagrees with that interpretation and <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Menasya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Menasya says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is consecrated </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">gored an ox belonging to a common person [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hedyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the Temple treasury is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. By contrast, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a common </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person that gore</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ox that is consecrated </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the ox that gored the other ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox, i.e., an ox with no consistent history of causing damage with the intent to injure, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, i.e., an ox whose owner was forewarned because his ox had already gored another ox three times, the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, from where </span>do you know to say that Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree about </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the superior-quality </span>land belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the inferior-quality </span>land belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage </span>are equal in quality, and the one liable for the damage also has land of superior quality, as the dispute was previously interpreted by Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps everyone, </span>including Rabbi Akiva, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we appraise </span>the value of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here they disagree with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva holds in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya, </span>that in the case of damage caused by the ox of a common person to the property of the Temple treasury, compensation is collected from superior-quality land belonging to the one liable for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael holds in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>that the owner of the ox bears no liability. In other words, perhaps in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> recording the dispute between Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva (see 6b), Rabbi Yishmael first taught that land is appraised based on the quality of the injured party’s land, and then, although it is not explicit in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, he continued to state his opinion that the Temple treasury is unable to collect damages. Accordingly, Rabbi Akiva can be understood as having first expressed his agreement concerning the valuation of land and then proceeding to dispute Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion with regard to the Temple treasury.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is so </span>that this is the disagreement, then <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> is the meaning of Rabbi Akiva’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> comes only </span>to allow injured parties to collect compensation from superior-quality land? This indicates that Rabbi Akiva disagrees about how to understand this verse.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>if the subject is the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference one can derive that the Temple treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property collects from superior-quality land. If, as suggested, Rabbi Akiva holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya, then he maintains that damage to consecrated property is dealt with more stringently than damage to another person’s property, in that if one’s ox damages consecrated property one is liable for the full cost of the damage even if the ox was considered innocuous. If damage to consecrated property is dealt with more stringently, there is no basis to derive an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, didn’t Rav Ashi say: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught explicitly </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The best of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his field and the best of his vineyard he shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pay” </span>(Exodus 22:4), teaches that the appraisal is of <span class="gemarra-regular">the best of the field of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">the best of the vineyard of the injured </span>party. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The appraisal is of <span class="gemarra-regular">the best of the field </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the best of the vineyard of the one liable for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>This clearly indicates that according to Rabbi Akiva compensation is collected from the superior-quality land belonging to the one liable for the damage.
§ The Gemara considers others issues concerning the form in which restitution should be paid: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raises a contradiction </span>and addresses it <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rava: It is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “The best of his field and of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> best of his vineyard he shall pay” </span>(Exodus 22:4), which indicates that from his <span class="gemarra-regular">best</span>-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he shall pay, but from <span class="gemarra-regular">something else, no, </span>he shall not pay.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “And if a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit and not cover it, and an ox or a donkey fall therein, the owner of the pit shall pay; <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall recompense </span>money to its owners” (Exodus 21:33–34)? Since the verse states: “The owner of the pit shall pay,” the additional term “he shall recompense” is superfluous. It therefore serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>any item <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money, and even bran, </span>a relatively inferior commodity, as valid forms of restitution.
Rava resolves the contradiction: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>the term “he shall recompense” is referring to a case where he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his own volition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without being taken to court, and he may therefore use any form of payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the phrase “of the best of his field” is referring to a case where he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">against his will, </span>after the injured party has sued him in court. Since he caused the injured party additional trouble, he must pay using his best-quality land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla, son of Rav Ilai, said: </span>According to this explanation, the language of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “He shall pay,” </span>a term that, as opposed to: “He shall recompense,” connotes that he is forced to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">against his will.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him </span>that the precise meaning of the verse does not indicate that he is paying against his will: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it written: He shall be paid, </span>in the passive form, which would clearly indicate that he did not voluntarily initiate the payment himself but rather is paying against his will? No; <span class="gemarra-regular">“he shall pay” is written, </span>which can also <span class="gemarra-regular">indicate </span>that he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">of his own </span><span class="gemarra-regular">volition.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Abaye said </span>an alternative resolution, <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to that </span>with which the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., Abaye’s teacher, Rabba, employed in order to resolve a different difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A wealthy person is not entitled to take a poor man’s tithe. He is instead expected to sell his assets and purchase food with the proceeds. But in the case of an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who owns</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> houses, fields, and vineyards, but </span>at the present time <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> find </span>buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>whom he can <span class="gemarra-regular">sell them, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may feed him </span>with food from the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor man’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> up until hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> the value of his assets.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Master <span class="gemarra-regular">discussed it </span>and asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>that led to him being unable to sell his land? <span class="gemarra-regular">If everyone’s land depreciated </span>in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">also depreciated along with theirs, let us provide him </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">even more </span>than half the value of his assets, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone’s land also depreciated, </span>the market value of his property is low and he is genuinely classified as a poor person, who may take as much poor man’s tithe as is given to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> everyone </span>else’s <span class="gemarra-regular">land appreciated </span>in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his land, since </span>people see <span class="gemarra-regular">that he goes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in and goes out for money, </span>i.e., he is in need of money, they reason that he will be forced to accept a lower offer for his property. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">his land depreciated </span>in value. 

Daf 7b

The Gemara asks: But if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">we should not provide him with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even a slight </span>amount of poor man’s tithe. Since his assets, based on their market value, have a high value, he is not to be classified as a poor person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Master, </span>Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">said concerning this: No, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that he is provided with only up to half the value of his assets is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case where he cannot sell due to seasonal fluctuations in price. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because in the days </span>of the month <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nisan, </span>which is the beginning of the harvest season, the market value of <span class="gemarra-regular">land appreciates</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in the days</span> of the month <span class="gemarra-regular">of Tishrei, </span>a time when the harvest had already been reaped and it is too late to prepare the land for the coming year, the market value of <span class="gemarra-regular">land depreciates.</span>
Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">waits until Nisan and sells </span>only at that point. <span class="gemarra-regular">But this </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he is in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> need of money, sells </span>his land in Tishrei <span class="gemarra-regular">according to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the current, </span>lower, market price. Accordingly, based on the current market prices, his assets have a low value and there is justification in regarding him as a poor person. Yet, since if he waited until Nisan, as everyone else does, his land would have a high value, he cannot truly be classified as a poor person. Therefore, he is permitted to take only as much poor man’s tithe as will cover his losses. The Gemara explains why he is permitted to take only up to half the value of his land: Since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the nature of </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">to depreciate up to half </span>its value, and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not its nature to depreciate more </span>than that, he is entitled to take poor man’s tithe that is worth up to half the value of his land and the rest he can supplement by selling his land at its current, lower price.
Abaye uses a similar distinction to resolve the contradiction he raises: <span class="gemarra-regular">And here also, with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to damages, </span>if one considers a case where the injured party comes to collect his damages during Tishrei, <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> legal right </span>is to collect payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from superior-quality </span>land. This will be a relatively large amount of land, owing to the current seasonal depreciation in its value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the one liable for the damage: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me slightly more land of intermediate quality </span>instead, then the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: If you </span>choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>superior-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is your legal right, take </span>a large amount <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with the current </span>market value; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if not, </span>and you wish to take intermediate-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">take according to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">future </span>value in Nisan, after it will have <span class="gemarra-regular">appreciated, </span>which will mean you will be entitled to a smaller amount of land. This can be used to resolve the contradiction: The phrase “of the best of his field,” which indicates that payment is made only from superior-quality land, defines the injured party’s basic rights. The term “he shall recompense,” which indicates that payment may be made in any form, is referring to a case where the injured party forgoes his rights. In such a case the value of the land or item he agrees to receive is appraised based on its appreciated value at the season when it is generally sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">akov objects to this </span>suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, you have weakened </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the power of injured </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to intermediate-quality</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and inferior-quality </span>land, as, by agreeing to receive land of a lower quality than that to which their rights entitle them, they will actually receive less land, since the land is then appraised based on the appreciated market values in Nisan. Such an opinion is untenable, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Merciful</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One states </span>that injured parties collect <span class="gemarra-regular">from the best</span>-quality land, clearly intending to enhance their rights, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot also </span>collect <span class="gemarra-regular">from intermediate-quality and inferior</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality </span>land unless he agrees that the land should be appraised based on the appreciated Nisan values, thereby lowering the value of his payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: If there is </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">to compare to </span>Rabba’s distinction, it is not compared to a case of payment of damages, but <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can compare it to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>who comes to collect the loan during Tishrei. <span class="gemarra-regular">His legal right</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land, which will be a relatively large amount owing to the current seasonal depreciation in the value of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me slightly </span><span class="gemarra-regular">more land of inferior quality </span>instead, the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">can say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: If you </span>choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the intermediate-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as is your legal right, take </span>a large amount <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the current </span>market value, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if not, </span>and you wish to take land of inferior quality, <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the future, appreciated, </span>market value in the month of Nisan. This would mean that the creditor would be entitled to a smaller amount of land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, objects to this </span>suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, you have locked the door in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> face of </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as, </span>according to your suggestion, the creditor is in a disadvantageous position. <span class="gemarra-regular">He can say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">Were I </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">to have </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money</span> I lent you, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase </span>a large parcel of land <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the current </span>depreciated market value, so why, <span class="gemarra-regular">now that the money is with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you, should I </span>be forced to <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with the future, appreciated </span>market value of the month of Nisan? If people are penalized as a result of granting loans, they will cease to do so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Aḥa, son of Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ika, said: If there is </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">to compare to </span>Rabba’s distinction, <span class="gemarra-regular">we can compare it to </span>the collection of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract </span>where she comes to collect it during Tishrei. <span class="gemarra-regular">As a woman’s legal right</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract </span>is to collect payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>her husband’s <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land, which will be a relatively large amount owing to the current seasonal depreciation in the value of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if she says to </span>her former husband: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me slightly less land of intermediate quality</span> instead, her former husband <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to her: If you</span> choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the lowest-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as is your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> legal right, take </span>a large amount <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> current </span>market value, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if not, </span>and you wish to take land of a higher quality, <span class="gemarra-regular">take in accordance with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the future appreciated </span>market value of the month of Nisan, which will mean you will be entitled only to a smaller amount of land.
The Gemara returns to examine the contradiction raised by Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any case, </span>the original <span class="gemarra-regular">difficulty</span> still remains.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Whatever he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gives </span>the injured party as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">he must give him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the best </span>of that type. For example, even if he pays in bran he must pay with his best-quality bran, and this is the meaning of the phrase “of the best of his field.” Accordingly, the contra-diction is resolved. The term “he shall recompense” indicates that payment can be given in any form, but the phrase “of the best of his field” indicates only that whichever form of payment is used, it must be of a superior quality, and not, as Abaye initially understood it, as limiting the form of payment specifically to land of superior quality.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t “the best</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of his field” written, </span>which suggests that the requirement to pay with one’s best land applies only when one pays with land?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, when Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came from Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s academy, they explained it </span>as follows: With regard to payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">all items are </span>classified as property of the <span class="gemarra-regular">best </span>quality, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be sold </span><span class="gemarra-regular">here, it can be sold in another city. </span>Since movable items are easily liquidated, they are always considered an acceptable form of payment. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">with the exception of land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is not always easily sold. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">must give </span>the injured party payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from his best</span>-quality land, which is easier to sell. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in order </span>to ensure the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that a buyer will jump at </span>the opportunity to purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>thereby providing the injured party with the possibility of liquidating it. This resolves the contradiction. The phrase “of the best of his field” indicates that if payment is made with land it must be with superior-quality land, and the term “he shall recompense” indicates that if payment is made from movable property, anything worth money may be used.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Abba from Akronya asked Rabbi Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: When </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>land to determine if it is to be classified as being of superior-quality, does <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> appraise </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of a property owner’s other land <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">it appraise </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">based </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the quality of the land in <span class="gemarra-regular">the worl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> at large?
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not raise the dilemma in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, as he says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we appraise </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of land owned by the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party, and therefore payment is made with land that is of a similar quality to the best-quality land of the injured party. Accordingly, it is obvious that the classification is based only on the land of the injured party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When you raise this dilemma,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we appraise </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of land owned by <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and he pays with his superior-quality land even if its quality exceeds that of any of the injured party’s land. Consequently, according to Rabbi Akiva it is appropriate to ask whether the appraisal is based only on his other land or based on the land in the world at large.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the answer to the dilemma? When <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One states: “The best of his field” </span>(Exodus 22:4), does the stress in the verse on “his field” serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>only the possibility of appraising land based solely on the value of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party, but land is appraised based on the quality of land in the world at large? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>does it serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the possibility of appraising land based on the quality of land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the world </span>at large <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>and it is sufficient if the land he pays with is his best-quality land?
Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Merciful One states: “The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> best of his field,” and you say </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises</span> land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of land in <span class="gemarra-regular">the world</span> at large? Certainly the term “his field” teaches that it is sufficient that the land be the best of the land of the one liable for the damage.
Rav Shmuel bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>this opinion from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that delineates the forms of payment used for paying damages, repaying a debt to a creditor, and paying a marriage contract: If the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only superior-quality </span>land,<span class="gemarra-regular"> all of them collect from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the superior-quality </span>land. Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he has only intermediate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality</span> land. And if <span class="gemarra-regular">he has only inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">he has superior-quality, intermediate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality, and inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a creditor </span>collects <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a woman’s marriage contract </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land. If he has only <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality and intermediate-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land, and payment to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land. If he has only <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality and inferior-quality </span>land, payments for <span class="gemarra-regular">damages and </span>payments owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality</span> land, while payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land. 

Daf 8a

If he has only <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality and inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>pay-ments owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor and </span>payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> contract </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land.
The Gemara explains how this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> poses a challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">middle clause: </span>If he owns only <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality </span>land, payments for <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>payments owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contract </span>are made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land. This clause demonstrates that the quality of land is appraised objectively based on the standard of the world at large. The reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of the land of the one liable for the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">let his intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">be classified as superior-quality </span>land, as that is the best land he owns, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consequently, the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be directed to </span>collect the debt from the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality</span> land.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>at the time the borrower took the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">had superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it. </span>Accordingly, no matter how land is appraised, at the time that the loan was given his intermediate-quality land would be classified as being of intermediate quality. Consequently, the creditor’s lien on the borrower’s land, which took effect from the moment the loan was given, takes effect with regard to the intermediate-quality land. Therefore, the creditor retains his right to collect from that land, regardless of the fact that by the time of collec-tion it was the borrower’s best land and at that point could be reclassified as land of superior quality.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And so says Rav Ḥisda: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> deals with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>at the time he took the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">had superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This too stands to reason, from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>If a debtor has only <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>are collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land, while payments to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor and</span> payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract </span>are made from the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land. These two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are difficult, </span>as they contradict <span class="gemarra-regular">each other. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above teaches that in this case the creditor collects the debt from the intermediate-quality land, whereas this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that he collects the debt from the inferior-quality land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above, it is a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">had superior-quality </span>land at the time that he took the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it,</span> while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> subsequently cited, it is a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not have superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he did not <span class="gemarra-regular">sell it. </span>In such a case, since his intermediate-quality land was his best land, it is classified as superior-quality land and accordingly, no lien took effect with regard to it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that the contradiction between the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> can be resolved differently: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> concern cases where the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">did not have superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">and sell it.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">is equivalent </span>in quality <span class="gemarra-regular">to the superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the world </span>at large; therefore, it is classified as superior-quality land and the creditor has no right to collect from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here, </span>the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">is not equivalent </span>in quality <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the world at large </span>but is similar to the intermediate-quality land of the world at large; consequently, the creditor has a claim to it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> concern a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land, which is the best land he owns, <span class="gemarra-regular">is equivalent </span>in quality <span class="gemarra-regular">to the intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">of the world </span>at large, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree about this: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the debtor’s land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>other land, so that his best land is classified as superior-quality land and the creditor has no claim on it. And the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the debtor’s land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the quality of land in <span class="gemarra-regular">the world </span>at large, so that his land is classified as intermediate-quality land and the creditor is entitled to claim it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>Another resolution to the contradiction between the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> is that the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla, as Ulla says: By Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> law, a creditor </span>collects <span class="gemarra-regular">from inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is stated: “You shall stand outside, and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> man you have a claim against will bring his collateral</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> out to you” </span>(Deuteronomy 24:11). One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>item would <span class="gemarra-regular">a person typically </span>choose <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring out </span>for use as collateral and potential payment? Certainly it is the <span class="gemarra-regular">most inferior of his utensils. </span>The verse thereby indicates that a creditor collects from inferior-quality land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, for <span class="gemarra-regular">what reason </span>did the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>collects <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality </span>land? They instituted this ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as not to lock the door in the face of</span> potential <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowers, </span>as, if creditors were limited to collecting from inferior-quality land they would be hesitant to offer loans in the first place.
Ravina explains: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance </span>cited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Ulla </span>that a creditor collects from intermediate-quality land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance </span>cited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Ulla, </span>so the creditor has a right to collect from only inferior-quality land, in accordance with Torah law.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 12:3): If one owes money to pay damages, repay a loan, and pay a woman’s marriage contract, and he owns inferior-quality, intermediate-quality, and superior-quality land, and he sells all of his land, then if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>all of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">or to three people </span><span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all </span>the buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">replace the </span>land’s prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>with regard to repayment of his debts. At the time when each debt was created, each creditor gained a lien on the plots of the debtor’s land, from which they have a right to collect. As a lien remains in effect even if the land is sold, then even after the sale, each creditor can collect from the plots of land upon which they have a lien.
