Accordingly, damages are collected from the superior-quality land, the loan is repaid from the intermediate-quality land, and the marriage contract is paid from the inferior-quality land.
If he sold his plots of land <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all </span>the creditors <span class="gemarra-regular">collect from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> last </span>buyer, regardless of the quality of the land he purchased. If that buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>sufficient land purchased from the debtor to pay all the debts, the creditors take the land he has and <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the remaining sums <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>purchased land <span class="gemarra-regular">before him, </span>and if he also <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>sufficient land, they <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the rest <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">before him, </span>i.e., the first buyer. The Sages instituted that creditors may not collect from land that a debtor sold, even though it is technically still liened to them, as long as the debtor still has sufficient means with which to repay the debt (see <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 48b). Accordingly, after the sale of the first plot of land, the creditors’ rights to collect are restricted to the land that remains in the possession of the debtor, and consequently they gain a lien on it, irrespective of its quality. Therefore, even if that land is subsequently sold, their rights to collect are restricted to that land, and only if the value of that land is insufficient to cover the cost of the debt may they utilize the original liens they had on the plots of land that were sold first.
The Gemara clarifies: With regard to the first case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>all the land <span class="gemarra-regular">to one</span> person, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circum-stances?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously</span> sold all of the land to one person, that is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that if he sold the land <span class="gemarra-regular">to three </span>different people simultaneously, <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possible to say </span>that the sale to <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> preceded </span>the other sales, yet <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">replace the </span>land’s prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span> equally, and the possibility that one might have proceeded the other is disregarded, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is the same in a case where all the plots of land were simultaneously <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to one </span>person?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the plots of land were sold <span class="gemarra-regular">one after the other.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But what is different </span>about the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where the plots of land were sold to <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>buyers, one after the other, and the creditors collect only from the last buyer? It is different in <span class="gemarra-regular">that each one </span>of the first two buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">can </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>any creditor who tries to seize the land they purchased: Do not collect my land, as <span class="gemarra-regular">I left </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a place for you, </span>a plot of land in the debtor’s possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">from which to collect. </span>In other words, when the first two buyers purchased their land a plot of land remained with the debtor, and therefore the creditor’s rights of collection are restricted to that land.
The Gemara continues its question: In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>where all the plots of land were sold to a single buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to each one </span>of the first two plots of land that were sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>any creditor who tries to collect: With my purchase of the first two plots of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">I left a place for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you, </span>a plot of land in the debtor’s possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">from which to collect. </span>Therefore, even though the debtor subsequently sold the buyer all of the land, the creditor’s rights of collection are restricted to the last plot of land the debtor sold the buyer, irrespective of its quality. Why then does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rule that in this case each creditor collects from the land that was originally liened to him?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the individual buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">last</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Accordingly, the buyer is satisfied with allowing each creditor to collect from the land that was previously liened to him, rather than having them each collect from the superior-quality land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And so says Rav Sheshet: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the individual buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">last.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, let them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all come and collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land, as their rights to collect should be restricted to it, since it was purchased last.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he can say </span>the following threat <span class="gemarra-regular">to them: If you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are silent </span>and do not insist on collecting from the superior-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>the land of a quality that is due to you <span class="gemarra-regular">according to your </span>standard <span class="gemarra-regular">legal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rights, </span>as in a case where you collect directly from the debtor, i.e., the injured party will collect from the superior-quality land, the creditor from the intermediate-quality land, and the woman will collect her marriage contract from the inferior-quality land, then <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>that land and I will allow you to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if not, </span>and you insist on taking the superior-quality land that I purchased last, then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will return the bil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">of the inferior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">to its </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, </span>i.e., the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you will all </span>be forced to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land, because whenever the debtor has land in his possession you are able to collect the debts only from him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that this is the reason for the ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, 

Daf 8b

then <span class="gemarra-regular">also with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to damages, let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">say this </span>to the injured party. He could threaten to return the bill of sale of the inferior-quality land to the debtor, which would force the injured party to collect directly from the debtor’s inferior-quality land. Since the buyer can do so, he can effectively force the injured party to collect from the purchased intermediate-quality land instead of fulfilling his right to collect from superior-quality land. Yet, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that in this case each party collects from the land that was originally liened to him, which means that damages are collected from the superior-quality land, indicating that this threat would not be effective.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case in which the debtor died and his inheritors are his <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans, who are not subject to </span>an obligation to <span class="gemarra-regular">repa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the debts of their father. When one dies, his monetary debts are not inherited by his children. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the lien of </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">rests </span>solely <span class="gemarra-regular">upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer </span>of the land. Any lien that was in effect with regard to the land he owned at the time he incurred the obligation remains, and his creditors can therefore collect what they are owed from that land, even if it is in the possession of a buyer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, one cannot say </span>that the ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is based on the fact that the buyer can threaten to return the bill of sale to the debtor, or in this case, to his orphans. In this case, even if he were to return the bill of sale, the creditors would not be able to collect from the land now in the orphans’ possession, as they received it anew, not as an inheritance from their father. Therefore, the creditors can still collect from the plots of land that remain with the buyer.
The Gemara suggests another explanation of the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>not all the creditors collect from the superior-quality land, which was the last plot of land purchased from the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to them: What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sages said one is not paid from liened </span>property, i.e., property liened to a creditor that has been sold by the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">whenever there is unsold </span>property still in the debtor’s possession? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ordinance </span>created solely <span class="gemarra-regular">for my </span>benefit, as I should not be expected to pay from the land I purchased when the debtor is still able to pay. If that ordinance were to be in effect in this case, all of their liens would be in effect with regard to the superior-quality land, as that was purchased last. In this case <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not </span>find <span class="gemarra-regular">this ordinance satisfactory to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and I would prefer for the lien of each creditor to remain in effect with regard to the land it had been on initially, and I will give each of you that land.
The Gemara notes: This fact that one is not required to avail himself of the financial benefit provided by a rabbinic ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava. As Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: Anyone who says: I do not want </span>to avail myself <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the financial benefit provided by <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinance of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages, such as this </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">one listens to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> does Rava mean by saying: An ordinance of the Sages, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this </span>one?
The Gemara answers: His statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna. As Rav Huna says:</span> The Sages enacted that a husband must sustain his wife. They also enacted that he receives her earnings in exchange. Yet, <span class="gemarra-regular">a wife is </span>legally <span class="gemarra-regular">entitled to say to her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> husband: I will not be sustained </span>by you, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in turn <span class="gemarra-regular">I will not wor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> i.e., you will not keep my earnings. Since his obligation to sustain her is only for her benefit, she may forgo her sustenance and retain her earnings for herself.
The Gemara discusses a limitation on the buyer’s ability to refuse the benefit of the rabbinic ordinance: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is obvious </span>that if the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer sold, </span>of the land he purchased from the debtor, the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate- and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inferior-quality </span>land to another buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">and retained in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his possession </span>only the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land, which he had purchased last, <span class="gemarra-regular">then all </span>the creditors <span class="gemarra-regular">may come and collect</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is the last </span>land he purchased and consequently was the last plot of land in the debtor’s possession. Accordingly, by virtue of the rabbinic ordinance, the creditors’ right of collection is restricted to that land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">are no longer </span>in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, </span>if the intermediate-quality and inferior-quality land are in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is able say to </span>those owed money, i.e., a creditor and a woman collecting her marriage contact: <span class="gemarra-regular">Collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>from the <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality </span>land, respectively, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not satisfactory to me </span>to avail myself <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the financial benefit provided by <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinance of the Sages. </span>In this case, the ordinance also benefits the second buyer, since it provides that as long as the first buyer retains some of the liened land, the creditors’ right of collection is only from that land. Since the second buyer also benefits from the ordinance, the first buyer cannot refuse the benefit of the rabbinic ordinance, because doing so would be at the expense of the second buyer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the first buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>only the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-quality </span>land that he had purchased last, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">retained</span> in his possession the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye thought to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: All </span>the creditors <span class="gemarra-regular">should come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land. Since that land was the last plot of land in the debtor’s possession, the creditors’ right of collection was restricted to that land, irrespective of the fact that it was then subsequently sold twice.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: What has the first </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to the second </span>in any sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">Any rights that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will come into his possession. And since, if </span>the creditors <span class="gemarra-regular">were to come to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first buyer </span>while he was still in possession of all three plots of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> could have had them collect from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inferior-quality </span>land; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when he </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality</span> land the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">unsold </span>property in the debtor’s possession. As although there is the rabbinic ordinance that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not exact payment from liened property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when there is unsold </span>property still in the debtor’s possession, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">could have said to them: I do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>find <span class="gemarra-regular">this ordinance satisfactory to me.</span>
Rava continues: Therefore, since the first buyer had the right to say this, the <span class="gemarra-regular">second buyer can also say to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them: Collect </span>from the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality and inferior-quality </span>land in the first buyer’s possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, when the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">second buyer purchased </span>the superior-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he purchased </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with the understanding that he </span>also acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">all the rights </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that the first </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">had with regard to </span>that land. Accordingly, he also acquires the right to insist that the creditors collect from the intermediate-quality and inferior-quality land.
In a related ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven, who sold all of his fields to Shimo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> simultaneously <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shimon proceeded to sell one field </span>of those purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">to Levi, and Reuven’s creditor came </span>to collect the debt, if the creditor so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires, he collects </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>one, i.e., Shimon, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires, he collects from that </span>one, i.e., Levi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we said this only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> intermediate-quality </span>land from Shimon. A creditor’s right is to collect the debt from intermediate-quality land. Accordingly, in this case, Reuven’s creditor can collect his loan from the intermediate-quality land even after it has been transferred into Levi’s possession. Nevertheless, if he so desires, he may insist on collecting his loan from any inferior-quality land left in Shimon’s possession. This is because a creditor also has the right to demand payment from a borrower’s inferior-quality land instead of his intermediate-quality land, and therefore that land is also liened to the loan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased superior-quality and inferior-quality </span>land from Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>the creditor can collect only from Shimon’s intermediate-quality land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Levi could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: For this </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">I was particular to purchase superior-quality</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and inferior-quality </span>land, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">land that is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit for you </span>to collect from as a creditor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span> Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">intermediate-quality </span>land from Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">as well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, we said </span>that Reuven’s creditor can collect from him <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not leave </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">similar intermediate-quality </span>land in Shimon’s possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> in that case, Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">is unable to say to </span>the creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">I left a place for you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a plot of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">in Shimon’s possession, </span>from which to collect. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>where Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">did leave </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">similar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> intermediate-quality </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">in Shimon’s possession, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not collect from </span>Levi, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: I left a place for you from which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to collect.</span>
In another related ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven, who sold </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a field </span>liened to his creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shimon with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>meaning that Reuven agreed to reimburse Shimon should Reuven’s creditor collect the debt from that field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Reuven’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s creditor came and seized </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">from Shimon, the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is that Reuven </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">go and litigate with </span>his creditor and claim that he had already repaid the debt, and insist that the field be returned to Shimon. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is unable to say to </span>Reuven: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not legally answerable to you, </span>as I am not taking away your land, since you sold it to Shimon. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>Reuven could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: If you extract</span> the field <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">will return to me </span>and demand that I reimburse him for his loss. Consequently, I am involved in this matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: Even </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he sold the field <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case even if the creditor seizes Shimon’s land there are no legal consequences for Reuven, Reuven can litigate with the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he could <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: It is not satisfactory for me for Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to have a grievance against me </span>because he lost the field I sold him on account of the fact that I was unable to pay my debt. Consequently, I am involved in this matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in another related ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who sold a field to Shimon without a guarantee, </span>

Daf 9a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and claimants [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">asikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> come forth about </span>the ownership of the land, disputing Reuven’s prior ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as </span>Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">has not yet taken possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can retract </span>his agreement to the transaction and is not required to pay for the land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once he has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taken possession </span>of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he cannot retract </span>his agreement to the transaction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that he cannot retract his agreement to the transaction once he has taken possession? <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>Reuven <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: </span>The purchase of the land was like purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">a tied bag [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> whose contents are unknown and might not have any value. Since <span class="gemarra-regular">you were aware </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">and accepte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that possibility, as you purchased it without a guarantee, you cannot retract your agreement.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From when is it </span>considered that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">taken possession </span>of the property? He takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">that he walks upon the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">boundarie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the land to inspect it.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to a case where the field was sold <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantee. But </span>where it was sold <span class="gemarra-regular">with a guarantee </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so, and Shimon can retract his agreement and refuse to pay for the land even after taking possession of it. The reason is that if the claimants succeed with their claims and seize the land, Reuven will then have to return the sum Shimon paid for it. In order to minimize judicial proceedings, the court allows Shimon to claim that there is no point in paying Reuven now only to have his money returned to him later. Therefore, he can retract his agreement to the transaction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>where the field was sold <span class="gemarra-regular">with a guarantee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Shimon is unable to retract his agreement to the transaction, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Reuven has the legal right to <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">show me the claim authorization document, </span>which a court provides to a buyer when the land he purchased is seized from him by a third party who proved that he had a lien on the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only then <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will pay you. </span>Consequently, Shimon cannot claim that there is no point in paying Reuven now, after he agreed to the sale but before a third party seized the land, as even if the land will be seized it does not automatically follow that Reuven will have to reimburse Shimon.
§ The Gemara returns to its earlier discussion concerning the form of the payment of damages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>Damages are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">either </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">money or </span>with one’s best-quality land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman raised an objection</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rav Huna </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">He shall recompense </span>money to its owner” (Exodus 21:34), which serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money, even bran, </span>a relatively inferior commodity, as valid forms of payment.
Rav Huna replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not have </span>any money or land. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he does not have</span> any other means with which to pay, isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he can pay using what he has? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: Go </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">trouble </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>whatever commodity you own, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">bring him money </span>as payment for the damage, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that it is unnecessary to sell one’s possessions and pay with money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: Money is equivalent to land. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> are they equivalent? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>fulfilling the requirement of paying with one’s best-quality land, meaning that he can choose to pay with money instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>precisely the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna; </span>and yet the ruling of Rav Asi is presented as an independent ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav Asi is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers who divided </span>their inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> took land and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>took <span class="gemarra-regular">money, and </span>subsequently their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor came and took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>as it was liened to his loan. Rav Asi’s ruling teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>brother whose land was taken can <span class="gemarra-regular">go and take a half </span>share <span class="gemarra-regular">of the money together </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>his brother.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">a son and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">not a son? </span>Since they are both sons and equally inherited the estate of their father, they share responsibility for their father’s debts. If the creditor takes repayment of the debt from one brother, the other one must reimburse him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the Gemara rejects this explanation not because it is obvious, but <span class="gemarra-regular">on the contrary, </span>because it is incorrect. As, one could one could look at it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the opposite </span><span class="gemarra-regular">direction, </span>saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one brother <span class="gemarra-regular">could say to </span>the other: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">with this </span>understanding that <span class="gemarra-regular">I took the money,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that if it would be stolen </span>from me <span class="gemarra-regular">I would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not be reimbursed from your </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with this </span>understanding that <span class="gemarra-regular">you took the land, that if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it would be seized </span>from you by a creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would not be reimbursed from my </span>money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav Asi is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers who divided </span>the land they inherited from their father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor came </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of one of them. </span>Since the brothers carry joint responsibility for their father’s debt, the one whose portion was seized has a right to be reimbursed by his brother. Rav Asi’s ruling teaches that this may be done either by redistributing the remaining portion of land or by reimbursing him with money.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t Rav Asi </span>already explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">once </span><span class="gemarra-regular">before? </span>Therefore, this cannot be the explanation of this ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it was stated: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who divided </span>the land they inherited from their father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor came and took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav says </span>that the initial <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the land is <span class="gemarra-regular">voided </span>and any remaining land is divided equally between the brothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says </span>that each brother, upon taking his portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">viter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> any rights to be reimbursed if his portion were lost. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Asi says </span>that the brother whose portion was seized has a right to receive half of the remaining inheritance: <span class="gemarra-regular">He takes a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter in land, and </span>he takes the other <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money.</span>
The Gemara explains the rationale behind each opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the initial <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the land is <span class="gemarra-regular">voided. </span>This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divided </span>their inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered to still be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> with respect to the inheritance, and therefore they continue to share joint responsibility for their father’s debts. Consequently, any remaining land is divided equally between the brothers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>that each brother, upon taking his portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>any rights to be reimbursed if his portion were lost, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divided </span>their inheritance are considered to be like <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of their respective portions, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>each one is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to a buyer </span>who bought his portion <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarante</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that would have provided him with a right to be reimbursed if his portion were seized by a creditor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Asi says </span>that the brother whose portion was seized has the right to receive half the remaining inheritance. <span class="gemarra-regular">He takes a quarter in land and </span>he takes the other <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter in money. </span>This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>as to <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they are similar to heirs, </span>in which case the remaining land should be redistributed between them, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they are similar to buyers </span>who bought their portions with a guarantee, in which case the brother whose portion was taken should be reimbursed by his brother with a sum of money equal to the value of the land that was seized from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, he takes a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> quarter in land and </span>he takes the other <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money.</span>
As Rav Asi had already stated the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of brothers who divided their inheritance, the Gemara suggests another explanation of his statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>did Rav Asi state that money <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to land? </span>He stated it <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the requirement of paying with one’s best-quality land, and is teaching that one may choose to pay with money instead of land.
The Gemara repeats its original rejection of this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>precisely the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Huna, </span>and yet Rav Asi is presented as an independent ruling. The Gemara resolves the problem: Emend the statement and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: And similarly, Rav Asi said.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Huna says: For </span>the purchase of an object with which to fulfill <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva, </span>one should spend <span class="gemarra-regular">up to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one-third.</span>
The Gemara asks: To <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>does this <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third </span>refer? 

Daf 9b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it means that one should spend up to <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">estat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to perform a mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if that is so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if it happened to him </span>that he became obligated in <span class="gemarra-regular">three mitzvot </span>at the same time, <span class="gemarra-regular">should he give</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his entire estate </span>away in order to fulfill those mitzvot? One is certainly not required to do so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">embellishment</span> of the performance <span class="gemarra-regular">of a mitzva, </span>e.g., to purchase a more beautiful item used in the performance of a mitzva, one should spend <span class="gemarra-regular">up to one-third </span>more than the cost <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the standard item used to perform <span class="gemarra-regular">the mitzva.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma: </span>How is this one-third calculated? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third from within, </span>i.e., he calculates the cost of a standard item, adds one-third of that value, and spends the total on purchasing a more beautiful item; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third from without, </span>i.e., one-third of the sum he ultimately spends should be the additional sum added in order to purchase a more beautiful item? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">they say in the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira: </span>Of the money one spends on purchasing a more beautiful item to perform a mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">up to one-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>more than the cost of a standard item comes <span class="gemarra-regular">from his ow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> finances, but <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward, </span>any additional sum spent on purchasing a more beautiful item comes <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the largesse of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He, </span>i.e., God will reimburse him for spending that additional sum.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anything </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which I became responsible for safeguarding it </span>to prevent it from causing damage, if it in fact causes damage, it is considered as if <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>actively <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitated that damage, </span>and accordingly I must pay for it. In any case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">I facilitated part of the damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">I am liable for payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>if I were the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who facilitated the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">entire damage it </span>caused.
One is liable only with regard to damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>were he to use it for a non-sacred purpose, he <span class="gemarra-regular">would not be</span> liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property; with regard to damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">property that belongs to members of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the covenant, </span>i.e., Jews; and with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">assigned property, </span>the meaning of which the Gemara will explain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one is liable for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in any place except for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain designated </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one responsible </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one is liable for damage caused in <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>an animal or item one is responsible to safeguard <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage, the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the damage </span>caused by insufficiently safeguarding it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to pay payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage with </span>his best-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that elucidates the mishna’s ruling: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anything </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">became responsible for safeguarding it </span>to prevent it from causing damage, if it in fact causes damage, it is considered as if <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>actively <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitated that damage </span>and accordingly must pay for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox or a pit that one transferred to </span>the care of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deaf-mute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, or a minor, </span>whose presumed limited intellectual capacity means they are deemed incapable of sufficiently safeguarding them from causing damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ox or pit <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that since the owner of the ox or pit did not fulfill his duty to safeguard them, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>for the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is not so in </span>a corresponding case where the damage is caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara elucidates: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing? If we say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> deals with <span class="gemarra-regular">a tethered ox or a covered pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which cannot cause damage in the manner in which the owner left them, then the case <span class="gemarra-regular">in the corresponding </span>situation <span class="gemarra-regular">of fire, </span>where he is not liable, is where one transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">an ember </span>to one of limited halakhic competence, which, had it been left alone, would not have erupted into a fire and caused damage. This cannot be correct, because if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different here </span>in the case of an ox and a pit, where one is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different there </span>in the case of the fire, that exempts him from liability? There seems to be no reason to differentiate between them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be dealing with <span class="gemarra-regular">an untethered ox or an exposed pit, </span>which can cause damage in the manner in which the owner left them. If so, then the case <span class="gemarra-regular">in the corresponding </span>situation <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire, </span>where he is not liable, is where one transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame </span>to one of limited halakhic competence, which can also cause damage in this form. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: But if so, why does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> state: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which is not so </span>in the case of damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a fire, as one is exempt </span>from paying damages? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this is untenable, as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t Reish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lakish say in the name of Ḥizkiyya: They taught </span>that one is exempt from damage caused by a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred an ember to </span>one of limited halakhic competence <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned </span>it into a flame. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame </span>to him, the one who transferred the flame to him <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>for any damage caused. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>He is responsible <span class="gemarra-regular">because the </span>capacity for it to cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is certain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara returns to its initial suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a tethered </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox or a covered pit, and </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">corresponding </span>situation <span class="gemarra-regular">of fire, </span>where he is not liable, is where one transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">an ember </span>to one of limited halakhic competence. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">you said </span>in order to reject this: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different here </span>in the case of an ox and a pit that causes him to be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different there </span>in the case of the fire, that exempts him from liability? Seemingly, in all these cases the item was not able to cause damage in its current form, so he is exempt from liability.
The Gemara explains: You could answer as follows: The typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of an ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is to free </span>itself  from being tethered and the typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a pit is </span>for its cover <span class="gemarra-regular">to become</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dislodged. </span>Therefore, as it is negligent to transfer an ox or pit to someone who is incapable of sufficiently safeguarding them, the one who transferred the ox or flame to them is liable. By contrast, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ember, as long as he leaves it </span>alone <span class="gemarra-regular">it progressively </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dims, </span>and the only way in which it will cause damage is if someone else actively fans it into a flame; therefore, he is not liable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says: Even </span>if the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one transferred a flame to </span>one of limited halakhic competence he <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt, </span>it is possible to say that the case <span class="gemarra-regular">in the corresponding </span>situation <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>in the first clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to an untethered ox or an exposed pit. </span>The Gemara asks: But if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different here </span>in the case of an ox and a pit that causes him to be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different there </span>in the case of the fire that exempts him from liability? Seemingly, in all these cases the item that was transferred is capable of causing damage in its current form, so he would be expected to be liable.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of fire, ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">the deaf-mute’s handling [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzevata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">causes </span>the damage, as if it were not for him moving the flame no damage would have been caused. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of the ox and the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">the deaf-mute’s handling </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">does not cause</span> the damage. Rather, the damage was caused even though they remained in exactly the same dangerous state in which the one who had transferred them to the deaf-mute did so. Therefore, the damage is a result of that person’s negligence, and he is liable.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">O</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as opposed to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>and conversely, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to Pit as opposed to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ox.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> elucidates: The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to Ox as opposed to Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox </span>kills a Jew, the owner is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a ransom </span>to the victim’s heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela </span>to the slave’s master. Furthermore, in such a case, once the court hears the evidence and the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict of </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is complete </span>and the court rules that the ox must be killed, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to derive </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>from the ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>from then, it is considered that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cause damage. </span>All of <span class="gemarra-regular">this is not so in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>that caused damage. And the <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the reason to be stringent, <span class="gemarra-regular">that applies to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Pit as opposed to Ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, its initial formation, </span>e.g., its digging, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, and </span>the one responsible for it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from its inception. This is not so with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to Ox. </span>

Daf 10a

There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to</span> the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox as op-posed to Fire, </span>and conversely, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to Fire as opposed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Ox.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> elucidates: The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox as opposed to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>kills a Jew the owner is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a ransom, and for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>. Furthermore, in such a case, once the court hears the evidence and the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict of </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is complete </span>and the court rules that the ox must be killed, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>from the ox. And if <span class="gemarra-regular">one transfers</span> his ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the care of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deaf-mute, an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> imbecile, or a minor, </span>and it causes damage, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>All of <span class="gemarra-regular">this is not so with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a fire. </span>And the <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to Fire </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as opposed to Ox is that </span>the one responsible for <span class="gemarra-regular">the fire is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from its inception, which is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not so with regard to an ox.</span>
There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> opposed to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>and conversely, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that applies to Pit as opposed to Fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> elucidates: The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit as opposed to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that its initial formation, </span>e.g., its digging, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>done in a manner that can <span class="gemarra-regular">result in damage, </span>and if <span class="gemarra-regular">one transfers it to </span>the care of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor </span>and it causes damage, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. This is not so with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a fire. </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to Fire as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">opposed to Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed and cause damage. And </span>the one responsible for <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">consuming both something that is fitting for it and something </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is not fitting for it, </span>i.e., both flammable and non-flammable items. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not so with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a pit.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let</span> the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the following additional stringency: <span class="gemarra-regular">A stringency</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that applies to Ox as opposed to Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox </span>damages vessels, the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the vessels, which is not so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to a pit, </span>which incurs liability for its owner only for damage it causes to people and to animals but not to vessels.
The Gemara explains: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught? <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>taught in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">pit.</span>
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>try to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>and explain accordingly <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>which states: The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to Fire as opposed to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed and cause damage. And </span>the one responsible for <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">consuming both </span><span class="gemarra-regular">something that is fitting for it and something that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not fitting for it. This is not so with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a pit. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Something that is fitting</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for it, what are these? </span>Pieces of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood. Something </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is not fitting for it, what are these? Vessels. </span>And yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not so with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to a pit, </span>which indicates that liability is not incurred for damage done to vessels by one’s pit. The Gemara presents the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for damage</span> caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels by </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">pit?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and </span>the additional stringency mentioned is true but was not mentioned because the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>certain cases <span class="gemarra-regular">and omitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> others. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">did he omit </span>that makes it reasonable to assume <span class="gemarra-regular">that he omitted this? </span>As a <span class="it-text">tanna</span> would never omit just a single case, perforce there must be more. The Gemara explains: He also <span class="gemarra-regular">omitted </span>the case of damage done to <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>item. Liability is incurred for damage done to a concealed item only when it was caused through a category of damage other than fire. If it is damaged by a fire that one lit, he is exempt.
The Gemara suggests another explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and </span>explain that the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Something that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not fitting for it, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span> serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to include vessels; </span>with regard to vessels there is no distinction between Fire and Pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case where a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">scorched </span>another person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed field or singed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sikhsekha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his stones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are ways of causing damage that cannot be caused by a pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi objects to this </span>suggestion: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the following additional stringency: <span class="gemarra-regular">A stringency that applies to Ox as opposed to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that in the </span>primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ox one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>if his ox damages another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>that is in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified consecrated </span>animals, i.e., an animal set aside to be an offering that was disqualified from use and then redeemed. He is liable despite the fact that even after being redeemed it retains a degree of sanctity. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not so with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to a disqualified consecrated animal, as in that case he is not liable for the damage caused.
Rav Ashi explains his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">omitted that </span>case of damage done to vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also omitted this </span>case of damage done to disqualified consecrated animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, what </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">did he omit </span>that makes it reasonable to assume <span class="gemarra-regular">that he omitted this?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He omitted </span>the case of an ox that intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">trampled on a plowed field of </span>another person in order to cause damage. Since the damage was intentional it is included in the primary category of Goring and so one is liable. This manner of causing damage cannot be done by a pit. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one claims that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> omitted the case of damage done to disqualified consecrated animals only <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that he also omitted the case of an ox that intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">trampled on a plowed field of </span>another person, that is not a sufficient justification. The latter case <span class="gemarra-regular">is not an </span>additional independent <span class="gemarra-regular">omission, as it is </span>included in that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The stringency that applies to Fire as opposed to Pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to proceed and cause damage. </span>The fact that there is no case in the category of Pit corresponding to an ox that intentionally trampled on a plowed field is addressed by this clause.
§ The mishna states: In any case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">I facilitated part of the damage it </span>caused, I am liable for payments of restitution for damage it caused, as if I were the one who facilitated the entire damage it caused.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that elucidates the mishna’s ruling: In any case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">I facilitated part of the damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">I am</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable for payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> if I were the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who facilitated the entire damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>caused. <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> digs a pit </span>to a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">and completes </span>the digging <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, the depth at which a pit, according to <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, can cause death, only <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter </span>individual is <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for injuries and death caused by the pit. Although the pit was already able to cause injury before the second individual deepened it, since by deepening it he increased its capacity to cause damage, he becomes liable for any damage it causes.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is not in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who digs a pit </span>to a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">and completes </span>the digging <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, only <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter </span>individual is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for both injuries and death caused by the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: With regard to death </span>caused by the pit, the responsibility is <span class="gemarra-regular">ascribed to the latter</span> individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to damage </span>caused by the pit, the responsibility is <span class="gemarra-regular">ascribed to the two of them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers only to a digger’s liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for death </span>caused by a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">unanimous, </span>i.e., it is in accordance with the opinions of both the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the preceding discussion took a slightly different form: The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>answered and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers only to a digger’s liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for death </span>caused by a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">unanimous.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira objects to </span>the explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that the mishna is referring only to one specific case: <span class="gemarra-regular">But are there no more </span>cases? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there </span>the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred his ox to five individual</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in order for them to safeguard it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one of them was negligent </span>in his duties <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage? </span>Isn’t this individual <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for all the damage? This seems to be an additional example of the principle in the mishna that if one facilitated part of the damage caused, he is liable for pay-ments of restitution for the damage caused, as if he were the one who facilitated the entire damage, so the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should have mentioned it.
The Gemara rejects the possibility that the mishna could be referring to this case: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which the negligent watchman bears full liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that without him </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">would not have been </span>properly <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarded </span>because the ox was particularly strong and it took all five individuals to safeguard it, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that the negligent individual is liable for all the damage. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he alone, through his negligence, <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>all the damage, not just part of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case must be <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">would still have been </span>sufficiently <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarded. </span>The Gemara asks: But if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he do </span>by not safeguarding it? It was still safeguarded without him, so he should not be liable for even part of the damage. It is apparent, then, that the mishna is not referring to this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet objects to </span>the explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that the mishna is referring only to one specific case: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there </span>also the case of a fire that was left unattended by its owner and someone else <span class="gemarra-regular">augmented </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>adding <span class="gemarra-regular">a bundl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of wood to it, thereby increasing the capacity of the fire to cause damage to another’s field? Even though he only increased the fire’s capacity to damage, he is liable for any damage it causes. Seemingly, this is an additional example of the mishna’s principle that if one facilitated part of the damage caused, he is liable for payments of restitution for the damage caused, as if he were one who facilitated the entire damage, so the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should have mentioned it.
