The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>

Daf 10b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">would not have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spread </span>to another person’s field <span class="gemarra-regular">without him </span>adding bundles the fire, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that he alone is liable for the damage because he alone did everything that led to the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case must be one where the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">would have spread </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without him. </span>The Gemara asks: But if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he do </span>by adding bundles of wood? The fire would have spread without him, so he did not cause even part of the damage. It is apparent, then, that the mishna is not referring to this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to </span>the claim of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the mishna refers only to one specific case: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t there </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were sitting on one bench [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">safsal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it did not break, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>additional person <span class="gemarra-regular">came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sat upon it and broke it </span>with his added weight, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter </span>individual is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for all the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said </span>by way of clarification that this applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the last individual to sit down was as heavy as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pappa bar Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since he could have potentially broken it even on his own, he had no right to use it. In this case, even though the weight of the first five individuals was presumably a contributing factor in causing the damage, since the damage was ultimately caused by the additional weight of the last individual, he is liable for all of the damage. Seemingly, this is an additional example of the mishna’s principle, and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should have mentioned it.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If we say that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without him </span>the bench <span class="gemarra-regular">would never have broken </span>under the weight of the first five people, then it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious</span> that the last individual is liable for all the damage, as ultimately it was his action alone that caused the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">even without him </span>the bench <span class="gemarra-regular">would have broken </span>under the weight of the first five people, and the last individual sat down just as it was about to break. The Gemara asks: But if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what did he do, </span>i.e., why should he be liable at all? It is apparent, then, that the mishna is not referring to this case.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, how is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> cited by Rav Pappa to be <span class="gemarra-regular">explained? </span>As the Gemara explained, the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is understandable only if it is referring to a case where the bench would not have broken without him. But if that is the case, as the Gemara noted, it is obvious and therefore unnecessary to state it.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where without him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it would have broken in two hours, and now it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">broke in one hour. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that the last individual alone is liable and not the first five, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they can say to </span>the last individual: <span class="gemarra-regular">Were it not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for you, we would have sat a little bit more </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">stood up; </span>consequently, the bench would never have broken. Therefore, it was ultimately you who caused the bench to break, and therefore only you are liable.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion, because in that situation the last individual would have a valid counterclaim: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let him say to them: Were it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not for you </span>continuing to sit on the bench after I sat down, the bench would not have broken, as <span class="gemarra-regular">under my </span>weight alone <span class="gemarra-regular">it would not have broken. </span>Accordingly, we should share the liability for damaging it.
The Gemara offers a different suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>instantaneously, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he was leaning upon </span>the other five people, <span class="gemarra-regular">the bench broke.</span>
The Gemara asks: If so, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that he alone is liable, as his action alone caused the damage, and the other five could not have done anything to prevent it as he was leaning upon them.
The Gemara explains: The ruling is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that when one causes damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s direct </span><span class="gemarra-regular">force </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not equivalent to </span>a situation where one causes damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body. </span>If he broke the bench by actually sitting down upon it, his action would be considered a direct act of damage completed with his body and he alone would be liable even though the other peoples’ weight was a contributing factor. In this case, since he broke the bench by merely leaning upon the others sitting there, it is his force that led to the damage, not his body, and one might have thought that since the weight of the others certainly contributed to the breakage they should share liability. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>causing damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s direct force is equivalent</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>causing damage with <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> And it teaches that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that anywhere that </span>one would be liable if <span class="gemarra-regular">his body broke </span>something, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">also</span> liable if <span class="gemarra-regular">his force broke </span>something.
The Gemara continues to consider the possibility that there are additional cases covered by the mishna’s ruling aside from the one listed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there not more </span>cases? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there </span>also the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was beaten by ten peopl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with ten sticks,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>they beat him <span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously or one after the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and he died, they are all exempt </span>from liability for killing him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>Where they beat him <span class="gemarra-regular">sequentially, the last </span>individual to beat him alone <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable, because he hastened his death. </span>In this case, the other individuals contributed to the man’s death, but the last one alone is liable. Why didn’t the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also mention this case?
The Gemara explains: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is not speaking of </span>one’s liability to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">the death penalty, </span>only of one’s liability to pay damages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>instead that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">speaking of </span>an issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t we uphold that </span>the case stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning a pit is subject to a dispute, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, but of the Rabbis? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">We will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and not </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, but <span class="gemarra-regular">we will not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interpret </span>it to be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira and not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>In other words, although we will interpret the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring to a case that is subject to a dispute, that applies only if it is in accordance with the majority opinion in that dispute.
§ The mishna teaches: In any case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">I facilitated part of the damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">I am</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable for payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage it </span>caused, as if I were the one who facilitated the entire damage. The Gemara notes that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> am liable for the damage it </span>caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">rather: </span>I am liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage it </span>caused. The Hebrew terms: Payments of restitution [<span class="it-text">tashlumim</span>], and: To complete [<span class="it-text">lehashlim</span>], share the same Hebrew root. This alludes to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the payment of damages is required only in order to complete the injured party’s compensation, which is already partially accounted for, as the injured party is able to recover his dead animal’s current value by selling its carcass. Accordingly, the one liable for the damage is not required to pay the animal’s prior value; rather, he must pay only the difference in its value from before it was damaged and its current state.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned this, as the Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The mishna uses the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Payments</span> of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage, </span>as opposed to simply stating: One is liable for the damage caused, to allude to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the one who is liable must pay only for the decrease in the value of the animal. This assumes that the injured party is able to recover his animal’s current value by selling the carcass. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the owner </span>of the injured animal <span class="gemarra-regular">attends to</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., retains ownership of, <span class="gemarra-regular">the animal carcass </span>so that, if he wishes to, he may sell it and keep the proceeds.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami said: As the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse states: “One who strikes an animal shall pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yeshallemenna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 24:18). <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not read </span>the final word <span class="gemarra-italic">yeshallemenna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning he shall pay for it; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>read it as though it were vocalized as <span class="gemarra-italic">yashlimenna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning he shall complete it, to teach that he shall complete the injured party’s compensation, which is already partially accounted for by the injured party’s right to sell his animal’s carcass.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said</span> that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: </span>The verse states with regard to a case where an animal was entrusted with a paid bailee who did not fulfill his duty to safeguard it, and the animal was attacked by a wild beast: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If it be torn in pieces, let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him bring a witness, the torn animal he shall not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pay” </span>(Exodus 22:12). Rav Kahana expounds the verse to mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall pay </span>only up <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">torn animal; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall not pay </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">torn animal itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, he pays only the difference in value between the animal before it was injured and its current torn state. If the owner of the injured animal wishes to fully recover his loss he must sell the animal’s carcass and keep the proceeds.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥizkiyya said</span> that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: </span>The verse states with regard to a person’s ox that fatally gored another ox: “He shall pay an ox for the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass shall be his” </span>(Exodus 21:36), meaning the carcass belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the injured </span>party, the owner of the gored animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, the school of Ḥizkiyya taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be his” </span>(Exodus 21:36). The verse means the carcass belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the injured </span>party. Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the injured </span>party? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">only to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for the damage? </span>To this suggestion, <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">should say: It could not have been that.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean by: <span class="gemarra-regular">It could not have been </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: If it enters your mind </span>to say that the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass is </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage, let the Merciful One write: </span>“He shall pay <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox for the ox,” and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">be silent </span>and state no more. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the verse to continue: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his”? Conclude from it </span>that the carcass belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to have multiple sources for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Merciful One wrote </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal shall pay for it,” </span>I could claim that only in that case does one have to pay for only part of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is an uncommon </span>occurrence. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a torn animal, which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a common </span>occurrence, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will say </span>that his liability should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be limited to the difference in value between what the animal had been worth and the carcass, but he should pay for the entire value of the injured animal. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to explicitly state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> also in that case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">had taught us only </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">torn animal, </span>I could claim that only in that case does one have to pay for only part of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the damage occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>i.e., it was not directly caused by the one liable for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who strikes an animal, </span>who does so <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action, I will say that </span>his liability should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be limited. Therefore, it is necessary to explicitly state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> also in that case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">had taught us only these two </span>cases, I could claim that only in those cases does one have to pay for only part of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon </span>occurrence, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the damage occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself. But </span>in a case where one’s ox gores another’s ox, of which the Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be his</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” which is a common </span>occurrence, and the damage is considered to have been inflicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>its owner’s direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since it was under his guard, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will say </span>his liability should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be limited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">had taught us </span>only the case in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be his,” </span>I could claim that only in that case does one have to pay for only part of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of one who strikes another’s animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">where one causes damage with </span>one’s own <span class="gemarra-regular">body, I will say </span>his liability should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be limited. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to explicitly state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in each case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Rav: But </span>according to the statement of Ḥizkiyya, as explained by Abaye, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>the injured party retains ownership of the carcass is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Merciful One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wrote: “And the carcass shall be his,” </span>but were <span class="gemarra-regular">it not for that I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the carcass</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rav Kahana questions the need for the Torah to teach this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, if </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>in his possession the carcasses of <span class="gemarra-regular">several </span><span class="gemarra-regular">torn animals, he could give </span>the injured party a carcass as payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Master said </span>above (7a): The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall recompense” </span>(Exodus 21:34), <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money, and even bran, </span>a relatively inferior commodity, as valid items with which to pay restitution. <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the Torah to teach that he can pay restitution with <span class="gemarra-regular">his, </span>i.e., the injured party’s, animal carcass? Granting ownership of the carcass to the injured party seems pointless, because even had the Torah granted it to the one liable for the damage, he could give it to the injured party as payment.
The Gemara explains: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only for </span>the issue of who sustains the loss due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> between its death and when the case is brought before the court. By granting ownership of the carcass to the injured party from the moment of the animal’s death, the Torah limits the damages to the difference between the value of the animal when it was alive and its value immediately after it is killed, irrespective of what happens to the carcass afterward.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that the issue of the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states with regard to a case where an animal was entrusted with a paid bailee and was attacked by a wild beast: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If it be torn in pieces, let him bring</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a witness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 22:12). 

Daf 11a

This means that the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">should bring witnesses that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mauled through circumstances beyond </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">control, and </span>based on their testimony he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shaul says: </span>The word <span class="it-text">ed</span> should not be interpreted as witness, but as carcass. Accordingly, the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">carcass [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aduda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to court </span>in order to appraise its current value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree about this </span>matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Abba Shaul, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the loss due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass is </span>sustained <span class="gemarra-regular">by the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party, and so there is a need to appraise its value immediately in order to correctly assess how much the one liable for the damage must pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the loss due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass is </span>sustained <span class="gemarra-regular">by the one liable for the damage </span>because the Torah granted him ownership of it.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone </span>agrees that the loss due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass is </span>sustained <span class="gemarra-regular">by the injured</span> party, since he owns it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here they disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>who must go to <span class="gemarra-regular">the effort </span>of retrieving the <span class="gemarra-regular">carcass </span>and transporting it to the court to be appraised.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Others say: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the owner of the pit to raise the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from his pit </span>after it was killed by falling into it? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“The owner of the pit shall pay; <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall restore money to its owner,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the carcass </span>shall be his” (Exodus 21:34). They read the term “and the carcass” as a second subject of the term “he shall restore.” It therefore indicates that the one liable for the damage must restore the carcass to the injured party by retrieving it. The fact that this opinion is introduced with the phrase: Others say, suggests that it stands in opposition to another opinion. That other opinion apparently holds that the owner of the injured animal is responsible for retrieving the carcass.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rava: What are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the circumstances </span>in which the one liable for the damage is required to go to <span class="gemarra-regular">this effort, </span>to retrieve the <span class="gemarra-regular">carcass </span>from the pit?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>while still <span class="gemarra-regular">inside the pit, </span>the carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">worth a dinar, and </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">at the edge </span>of the pit, since it is more accessible, its market value increases and <span class="gemarra-regular">is worth four </span>dinars, then <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">expends the effort </span>to retrieve the carcass, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">expending the effort for his own </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sake, </span>since by increasing the value of the carcass he reduces his own liability. Therefore, he will certainly retrieve it of his own accord, and it is not necessary for the Torah to require him to do so.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to require him to retrieve the carcass in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>while still <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>the carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">is worth </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar, and </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">at the edge </span>of the pit, despite being more accessible, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is still worth </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar. </span>Since it is of no benefit to him to retrieve it, the Torah had to require him to do so.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is there </span>ever <span class="gemarra-regular">a case </span><span class="gemarra-regular">like this, </span>where despite being more accessible its market value does not change? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, as people say, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a beam </span>of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in the city </span>sells <span class="gemarra-regular">for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinar, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam </span>of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in the field </span>also sells <span class="gemarra-regular">for a dinar, </span>despite the fact that it needs to be transported from there to the city.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The practice of the court is that when an animal or other item is stolen and then is damaged or dies, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>its current value and assign ownership of it to its owner, in order that the perpetrator should have to pay only the difference between its prior value and its current value, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief nor for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber. </span>Rather, the thief or robber acquires ownership of the carcass or damaged item and compensates the owner for its prior value. The court appraises the item or carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">only for damages</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as the Gemara explained above. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I say </span>that they appraise the item or animal <span class="gemarra-regular">even for a borrowe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> who borrowed an item and while it was in his possession it became damaged, or who borrowed an animal and while it was in his possession it died, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes to me.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dilemma was raised before them: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this what </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the value of an item or a carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">even for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a borrower, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Abba concedes to me; or perhaps, this is what </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: And I say </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not appraise </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">even for a borrower, and Abba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concedes to me?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from the following incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed an a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from another and he broke it. He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came before Rav </span>to rule if, and how much, he was liable to pay for it. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Go and pay him with a full-fledged ax, </span>i.e., you must compensate the owner for the full value of the ax that you broke. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>its value for the sake of a borrower.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rav </span>on that occasion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? And</span> Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">remained silent, </span>this suggests that he conceded to their opinion that the borrower should not have had to pay the full value of the ax. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it</span> that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>an item’s value for the sake of a borrower.
An amoraic dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>a stolen item’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">for a thief and for a robber. Rav Pappi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: It does not appraise </span>its value for them. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not appraise </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">either for a thief or for a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but it appraises </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">for a borrower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Kahana and Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Asi.</span>
§ The Gemara cites additional <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: When a woman gives birth or miscarries a fetus she is thereby rendered ritually impure (see Leviticus 12:1–5). Even if she delivers only the afterbirth, with no discernible fetus, she is rendered ritually impure due to the possibility that the fetus was dissolved in the afterbirth, and it is therefore considered as though she delivered it (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 24b). The length of the period of impurity depends on the sex of the child. In the case where it is unclear what the sex is, she must observe the longer period of fourteen days (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 29a). At the end of that period she may purify herself by immersing in a ritual bath. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">part of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">afterbirth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shilya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged on the first day </span>of a woman’s miscarriage <span class="gemarra-regular">and part of it </span>emerged <span class="gemarra-regular">on the second day, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">counts </span>the period of ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">from the first </span>day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him, </span>to Ulla: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the rationale for <span class="gemarra-regular">your opinion </span>to begin counting from the first day? It would appear to be based on the following: Ritual impurity is engendered only once the woman has delivered the fetus. This is defined as the emergence of the majority of the fetus or its head. Since in this case the fetus is not discernible, one must consider the possibility that it had already emerged on the first day, and therefore one is required <span class="gemarra-regular">to act stringently </span>and regard her as impure from the first day.
Rava questions the propriety of acting stringently in this case, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency that results in a leniency, because </span>if she begins counting from the first day, <span class="gemarra-regular">you will </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">render her </span>fit to immerse and become <span class="gemarra-regular">pure from </span>fourteen days <span class="gemarra-regular">after the first </span>day. This is a leniency because it is possible that the majority of the fetus emerged only on the second day and therefore her period of impurity began only then. She will therefore remain impure until the fifteenth day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>With regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to being concerned </span>for the possibility that she is impure from the first day, <span class="gemarra-regular">she should be concerned. </span>But with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">counting </span>the period of impurity, <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> counts only from the second </span>day.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us </span>through this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does he mean to teach us <span class="gemarra-regular">that part</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the afterbirth </span>does not emerge <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>part of the <span class="gemarra-regular">fetus </span>inside? But <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>that in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 77a): When an animal is ritually slaughtered, the animal and everything inside it becomes permitted for consumption. This applies to an unborn fetus as well. If prior to the slaughter the majority of the fetus emerged, it is considered to have been born, and therefore the entire fetus, even the part that is still within its mother, is not rendered permitted for consumption by the slaughter. Accordingly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">part</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the afterbirth emerged </span>prior to the slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited to eat </span>it, because an afterbirth is <span class="gemarra-regular">a sign</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a fetus in a woman </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a sign of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a fetus in an animal.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>I would know this only <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the mishna, I would say</span>

Daf 11b

<span class="gemarra-regular">that there is</span> a possibility that <span class="gemarra-regular">part of the afterbirth </span>will emerge <span class="gemarra-regular">without</span> part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the fetus </span>inside, and the reason that the Sages forbid eating the afterbirth is due to a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>prohibiting a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">part of </span>an afterbirth emerges from the womb and part of it remains inside, <span class="gemarra-regular">due</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the possibility that one may confuse it with a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the afterbirth emerges. Therefore, Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>that, in fact, part of the afterbirth does not emerge without part of the fetus inside.
The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ull</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>With regard to a male <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>child <span class="gemarra-regular">who was maule</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">within thirty day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of his birth and died, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not required to redeem him, </span>as the requirement to do so, by paying five <span class="it-text">sela</span> to a priest, applies only once the child is thirty days old (see Numbers 18:15–16).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it is stated:</span> “Yet <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall redeem” </span>(Numbers 18:15), one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if a male firstborn child was <span class="gemarra-regular">mauled </span>by an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">within thirty days </span>of his birth one should redeem him. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states “yet </span>you shall redeem”; the addition of the word “yet” serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">differentiate </span>and limit the requirement to redeem the firstborn male.
The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Elazar says: A large animal, </span>such as a cow or a horse, <span class="gemarra-regular">is acquired by </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling </span>the animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 25b): A large animal is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by passing </span>the reins of the animal to the buyer? The Gemara explains: Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This and that, </span>i.e., both large and small animals, are acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">pullin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon says: This and that </span>are acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting </span>the animal.
The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says:</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the estate they inherited, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises whatever </span>clothes are <span class="gemarra-regular">upon them </span>if those clothes came from, or if they were purchased with money from, the deceased’s estate, and that sum is considered part of the portion they receive. But the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not appraise whatever is upon their sons and daughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In order to save the children from the humiliation of having to appear in court, the brothers waive their rights to the clothes the children are wearing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Sometimes, it does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not even appraise what-ever is upon </span>the brothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">You find</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> such </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">eldest brothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> where the other brothers waive their rights to the value of his clothes, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is beneficial for them </span>to have the eldest brother appear well dressed in order <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>when he represents their interests in dealings with others, <span class="gemarra-regular">his words will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be listened to </span>and respected.
The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> conveyed </span>a deposit that was entrusted to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee, </span>the first bailee is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for any occurrence for which he would have been exempt had he kept the deposit with him. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not necessary </span>to state this in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee who conveyed </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to a paid bailee,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thereby increasing </span>the level of <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding, </span>since the paid bailee has a greater level of accountability than an unpaid bailee. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a paid bailee who conveyed </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee, thereby decreasing </span>the level of <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In this case, the first bailee is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for any occurrence for which he would have been exempt had he kept the deposit with him, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he conveyed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a mentally competent person </span>and thereby fulfilled his responsibility to ensure the deposit is safeguarded.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee who conveyed </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> another <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the first bailee becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for any loss to the item, even for mishaps for which he would not have been liable had he kept the deposit with him. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not necessary </span>to state this in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> paid bailee who conveyed </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, thereby decreasing </span>the level of <span class="gemarra-regular">its safeguarding. Rather, </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bailee who conveyed </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to a paid bailee, </span>thereby increasing the level of its safeguarding; he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The reason he is liable is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: You are credible to me with regard to </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>other bailee, to whom you conveyed my item, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not credible to me with regard to</span> taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath. </span>If an occurrence for which a bailee does not carry liability occurs, damaging the deposit, in order to release himself from an obligation to pay the bailee must take an oath to the item’s owner that none of the types of occurrences for which he bears liability occurred. Rava rules that the owner is required to accept an oath only from the bailee with whom he entrusted his item, but not from anyone else. Accordingly, since the first bailee was not present when the event occurred, he is unable to attest to what happened, and even if the second bailee takes an oath to that effect, the owner is not expected to accept his oath. Consequently, the first bailee bears full liability for any loss.
The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Ulla, citing Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">one can collect from </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">the slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that he owns as payment for a debt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to Ulla: </span>Did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>when collecting <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a debtor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans? </span>A creditor can collect the debt from orphans only by taking the land the debtor bequeathed to his children. Rav Naḥman asked whether this also extends to collecting any slaves the children inherited. Ulla replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>a creditor collects a debt by taking slaves only when he collects directly <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the debtor himself. Rav Naḥman challenges this: But when the creditor collects <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>he can collect the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">even from the cloak that is upon his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shoulders, </span>and therefore he can certainly also collect the debt by taking his slaves, so what is the novelty of this ruling?
Ulla explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>his slave <span class="gemarra-regular">as designated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">repayment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">appoteiki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Consequently, if the slave was subsequently sold to a third party and the debtor was later unable to repay the debt, the creditor can seize the slave from the third party as payment of the debt. Even though generally only land can be seized from a buyer as payment for the seller’s debt, a slave is considered to have similar status to land in this regard. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If a master <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside his slave </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repayment </span>of a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him, </span>the master’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor collects </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>taking the slave; but if one set aside <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">repaymen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor does not collect</span> the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>taking the ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this difference? The Gemara explains: The designation of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>slave generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since a slave is significant and identifiable, therefore any prospective buyer is assumed to have been aware of the status of the slave and accepted the consequences of purchasing him. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the designation of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span> generate <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity, </span>since one ox is not easily distinguishable from another, and a buyer cannot be assumed to be aware that the ox was set aside as designated repayment. Therefore it is unfair that one who purchases such an ox should have it seized from him. Therefore, the Sages enacted that a creditor cannot do so. 

Daf 12a

The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">exited </span>the study hall, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said to </span>the remaining Sages in the study hall: In truth, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>A slave can be collected as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>when collecting <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the debtor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Generally, when collecting a debt from the debtor’s orphans the creditor can collect only from the land that they inherited from their father, which is liened to the debt. Rabbi Elazar rules that a creditor can also collect from the slaves they inherited, as he holds that in this regard, the legal status of slaves is like that of land. Ulla did not reveal this fact to Rav Naḥman, as he knew that Rav Naḥman disagreed and held that the legal status of slaves is like that of movable property. When he heard of Ulla’s revelation, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Ulla evaded me, </span>as had he told me Rabbi Elazar’s full opinion, I would have brought proofs against his opinion.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an incident in Neharde’a, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the judges of Neharde’a collected, </span>on behalf of a creditor, slaves that orphans had inherited from the debtor. <span class="gemarra-regular">There</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was an incident in Pumbedita, and Rav Ḥana bar Bizna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> collected </span>slaves from orphans as repayment for a debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman said to </span>those judges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go and return </span>those slaves to the orphans, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span>you do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we will collect </span>the value of the slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds of <span class="gemarra-regular">your own mansions </span>in order to compensate the orphans for their loss, as you have made a elementary mistake in your ruling and therefore you are responsible to rectify it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: There is Ulla,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is Rabbi Elazar, there are the judges of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a, and there is Rav Ḥana bar Bizna, </span>all of whom ruled based on the assumption that the legal status of slaves is like that of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">does the Master, </span>i.e., you, Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold?</span>
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I know a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> that supports my opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Avimi teaches: A document that prevents the Sabbatical</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Year from abrogating an outstanding debt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">effect upon </span>a debt assumed by one who owns <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>a <span class="it-text">prosbol</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take effect upon </span>a debt assumed by one who owns <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves </span>of the debtor. And <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property is acquired together with the lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> one acquires through the act of acquisition performed on the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be acquired together with the slaves</span> that one acquires. Both <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> assume that in these cases the legal status of slaves is not like that of land.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that this issue is the <span class="gemarra-regular">subject of </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> in the following <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>.
One <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one sold slaves and lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>a buyer and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the slaves </span>alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land. </span>If he took possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the land </span>alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If one sold <span class="gemarra-regular">land and movable property to </span>a buyer and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the land </span>alone, he thereby also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the movable property. </span>If he took possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of the movable property </span>alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the land. </span>If one sold <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves and movable property to</span> a buyer and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the slaves</span> alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the movable property. </span>If he took possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of the movable property </span>alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the slaves.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the slaves </span>alone, he thereby also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the movable property? </span>This directly contradicts the ruling in the parallel clause of the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is about </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>and the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage,</span> the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property?</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, said: According</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to everyone, </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">like</span> that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, and </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that by taking possession of the slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the movable property, is <span class="gemarra-regular">properly </span>understood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which is taught </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that in such a case he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the movable property, the reason for this ruling is that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds that in order for movable property to be acquired together with land, <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>that he acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">land similar to “fortified cities in Judea” </span>(II Chronicles 21:3), <span class="gemarra-regular">which do not move around. </span>Slaves, even if their legal status is generally like that of land, do not fulfill this requirement.
The reason behind the need for land to be like the “fortified cities in Judea” is that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one can acquire movable property together with land is derived from this verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that does not serve as a guarantee, </span>i.e., movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">is acquired together with property that does serve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as a guarantee, </span>i.e., land, be it <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the buyer giving <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>to the seller, by the seller giving the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">or by </span>the buyer performing an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where is this matter </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥizkiyya said: As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “And their father gave them great </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gifts, of silver, and of gold, and of precious things, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with fortified cities in Judea” </span>(II Chronicles 21:3). The verse indicates that the acquisition of the movable property was done together with that of the cities of Judea.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that Rav Ika stated a different answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, said: According</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to everyone, </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">like</span> that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, and </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught</span> in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that by taking possession of the slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the movable property, is <span class="gemarra-regular">properly </span>understood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which is taught </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that in such a case he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the movable property, applies to a case in which at the moment the slave was acquired, the movable property was <span class="gemarra-regular">still upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., the slave was holding it, and it could therefore be acquired together with the slave. This is because one’s slave is considered like one’s courtyard, and any item that is placed within it is acquired for its owner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But even if </span>the movable property was <span class="gemarra-regular">still upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, what of it? </span>Even if one claims a slave is like a courtyard, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mobile courtyard, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a mobile courtyard does not acquire </span>items placed upon it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where the slave is standing </span>at the time of the transaction, that is still insufficient, as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: Anything that does not acquire when moving </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">standing or sitting. </span>The fact that the slave can move gives him the status of a mobile courtyard, regardless if he is currently moving or not.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a slave is <span class="gemarra-regular">bound u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> and is unable to walk, his status is like that of an immobile courtyard, and his master will acquire anything that is placed upon him at that time.
The Gemara presents another contradiction to the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above, which explicitly states that one cannot acquire slaves by taking possession of land: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> took possession of the land </span>alone, he thereby also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves?</span>
The Gemara resolves the contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">There</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> just cited, the case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">are standing within </span>the borders of the land that was acquired.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not acquire </span>the slaves, is stated with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> standing within </span>the borders of the land that was acquired.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This works out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">well according to that </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">formulation of </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ika, son of Rav Ami, said, </span>that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property. This is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">are standing within </span>the borders of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>they are acquired together with the land, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if not, no, </span>they are not acquired. The Gemara assumes that movable property is acquired together with land only if at the time of the acquisition it is placed upon the land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">formulation </span>of that which Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, <span class="gemarra-regular">said, that </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, why do I </span>need the slaves to be <span class="gemarra-regular">standing within </span>the borders of the land? As <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t Shmuel say: </span>If someone <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him ten fields, </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">in ten </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">countries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> once he takes possession of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one of them, he has acquired all of them? </span>If the legal status of slaves is like that of land, then the same principle should apply to them, and it should be unnecessary for them to be standing within the land’s borders.
The Gemara reconsiders: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">according to your reasoning, </span>one can ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to</span> the second <span class="gemarra-regular">formulation of </span>that which Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, <span class="gemarra-regular">said, that </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, why do I </span>need the slaves to be <span class="gemarra-regular">standing within </span>the borders of the land? 

Daf 12b

Don’t <span class="gemarra-regular">we maintain </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">need </span>movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">to be piled u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> upon the land one acquires in order to acquire the movable property together with it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say?</span> Perforce, <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property that moves around </span>by itself, such as slaves, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from movable property that does not move</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> around </span>by itself, i.e., inanimate objects. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that movable property does not need to be piled up upon the land applies only to the latter. Accordingly, in order to acquire slaves together with land, they must be standing within its borders.
Given this distinction, one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, also, </span>an entity legally classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">land that moves around, </span>such as a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from land that does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">move around. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, </span>which is classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that moves around, </span>is not included in Shmuel’s ruling, as in his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>he refers only to acquiring multiple plots of land, which is possible only because the <span class="gemarra-regular">crust [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sadna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the earth is one </span>block, and therefore each field is really only one part of a bigger whole. This rationale does not permit acquiring land and slaves together, as a slave is not attached to the earth and is separate from the land.
§ The mishna teaches: One is liable only with regard to damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>were he to use it for a non-sacred purpose, he <span class="gemarra-regular">would not be </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">misus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of consecrated property.
The Gemara infers: The property in question <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not have </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">is consecrated </span>property, yet one is still liable for causing damage to it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who holds like this? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>The mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings of lesser sanctity and is in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says </span>that such offerings, before they are slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">property of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">owners, </span>as opposed to property of Heaven. It is only once such an offering is slaughtered that it becomes subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of misuse of consecrated property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that concerning one who steals another’s property and takes a false oath denying he has done so, incurring the obligation to bring a guilt-offering, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And commits a trespass against the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and deals falsely with his neighbor” (Leviticus 5:21). The verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case in which one denies having in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings of lesser sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are property of </span>their owners. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t we learn </span>in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 52b): In the case of a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">who betroths </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>of an offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it is from offerings of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the most sacred orde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or from offerings of lesser sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, she is not betrothed? Shall we say that </span>this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> HaGelili?</span>
