The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as when</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili said </span>that offerings of lesser sanctity are the property of their owners, that applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal is still <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But after </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi Yosei HaGelili concedes </span>that the offering takes on a higher degree of sanctity and is now the property of Heaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">As when they receiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> their portions, they do not receive them because those portions belong to them; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">they receive </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from the table of the Most High</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., they have the right to partake of them, but do not own them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he say </span>his opinion only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the offering is still <span class="gemarra-regular">alive? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma</span><span class="it-text">’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 1:2): With regard to the male <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>of a kosher animal, which is endowed upon its birth with the sanctity of an offering of lesser sanctity, a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">may sell it </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but he may not sell it once it is slaughtered, as if an unblemished firstborn animal is slaughtered it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">blemished, </span>one can sell it both when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive or </span>after it is <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered, and one can betroth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a woman with it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This mishna assumes that even when a firstborn animal is unblemished it is considered to be the property of the priest.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: They taught</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn</span> animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the present</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since it is not fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to be sacrificed, </span>as there is no Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">priests have ownership of it. But when the Temple is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> standing, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>case the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is fit to be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sacrificed, no. </span>When the Temple is standing a priest may slaughter and eat the firstborn only if it becomes blemished. Nowadays, since it is not possible to offer it as a sacrifice, it is certain that the animal will eventually develop a blemish and the priest will then be permitted to slaughter and eat it. Consequently, the priest is considered to have ownership of the firstborn even before it develops any blemish.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman </span>from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above: The verse states: “A person who sins <span class="gemarra-regular">and commits a trespass against the Lord” </span>(Leviticus 5:21). The verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case in which one denies having in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings of lesser sanctity, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are the property of </span>their owners; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. </span>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s statement is clearly referring to a time when the Temple is standing, as it is based on a verse that continues to obligate one to bring a guilt-offering. Nevertheless, he states that offerings of lesser sanctity, of which a firstborn is an example, are considered to be the property of their owners even when they are unblemished.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Ravina answered </span>that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s statement is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> outside </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">and is in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, who says: If </span>firstborn animals <span class="gemarra-regular">came</span> from outside of Eretz Yisrael to Eretz Yisrael and they are <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished, they may be sacrificed </span>on the altar. From Rabbi Shimon’s formulation it is apparent that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they came, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>they are sacrificed, but they should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be brought <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Since the firstborn animals should not be brought to Eretz Yisrael, they are considered unfit to be sacrificed, and therefore they are considered to be the property of the priest even before they develop a blemish.
It is apparent that Ravina understood Rav Naḥman’s qualification to be true even according to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Therefore, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is so that when Rabbi Yosei HaGelili said </span>that an offering of lesser sanctity <span class="gemarra-regular">is the property of </span>its owner, that was referring only to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>they are still <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, </span>

Daf 13a

<span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">answe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> Rava’s objection by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that an offering of lesser sanctity is the property of its owner and may be sold even when the Temple stands, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, </span>and it is referring to a case where the animal is still alive. And <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>qualification of the mishna by Rav Naḥman, that the sale of an unblemished firstborn animal when the Temple is standing is invalid, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who dispute Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him </span>that this is not difficult: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you speak </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts </span>to which members <span class="gemarra-regular">of the priesthoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> are entitled, of which a firstborn animal is an example? <span class="gemarra-regular">Gifts of the priesthood are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">different </span>from other offerings of lesser sanctity, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when </span>the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">receive </span>their portions, <span class="gemarra-regular">they receive </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from the table </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Most High. </span>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili claims that the act of consecration of an animal as an offering of lesser sanctity does not nullify one’s ownership of the animal. The sanctity of a firstborn offering takes effect with its birth, so it may be that it was never owned; rather, it is reasonable that the Torah provided the priest only with the right and the obligation to partake of it after it is sacrificed.
§ The Gemara considers <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: Concerning one who steals another’s property and takes a false oath denying he has done so, incurring the obligation to bring a guilt-offering, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> commits a trespass against the Lord, </span>and deals falsely with his neighbor” (Leviticus 5:21). The verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case in which one denies having in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of lesser sanctity, which are </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of </span>their owners, and are included in the phrase “and deals falsely with his neighbor.” This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">HaGelili. Ben Azzai says: </span>This phrase serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include peace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offerings. Abba Yosei ben Dosta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: Ben Azzai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said this only with regard to a firstborn </span>offering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Azzai says: </span>This phrase serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include peace-offerings. </span>The Gemara asks: Ben Azzai’s interpretation of the phrase, limiting its interpretation to a reference only to peace-offerings, is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude a firstborn</span> offering, because he holds that a firstborn is not the property of the priest, one could reject this, as the sanctity of a firstborn offering is a lesser sanctity than that of a peace-offering, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, just </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">peace-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, which </span>have a higher degree of sanctity such that <span class="gemarra-regular">they require placing hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on the head of the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>are accompanied by <span class="gemarra-regular">libation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the waving of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">breast and </span>the right <span class="gemarra-regular">hind le</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> by the priest and owner together, <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the property of the owners, is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it necessary </span>to state that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn</span> offering, for which these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> do not apply, that the priest has ownership of it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan said: </span>Ben Azzai mentioned peace-offerings in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exclude </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>offering, i.e., every tenth animal of one’s flock that is designated as tithe for those ten animals and is sacrificed as an offering of lesser sanctity. Animal tithes are excluded because ben Azzai holds that an animal tithe offering is not the property of the owner of the flock.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a firstborn </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “You</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall not redeem” </span>(Numbers 18:17), indicating that the owner can never fully redeem the offering, thereby removing its sanctity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the firstborn offering <span class="gemarra-regular">can be sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, or </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">blemished </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or </span>blemished and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered. With regard to </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>offerings, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “It shall not be redeemed” </span>(Leviticus 27:33), indicating that the one who designated it can never fully redeem an animal tithe offering, thereby removing its sanctity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the animal tithe offering <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be sold, not </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive and not </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished and not </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">blemished. </span>The fact that the sale of an animal tithe offering is invalid demonstrates that it is not the property of the one who designated it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina taught </span>the preceding discussion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">last clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Yosei ben Dostai says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai said this only with regard to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborn </span>offering. The Gemara asks: Abba Yosei ben Dostai’s interpretation of the phrase, limiting its interpretation to a reference only to a firstborn offering, is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude peace-offerings, </span>because he holds that they are not the property of the one who consecrated them as offerings, one could reject this, as the sanctity of peace-offerings is a lesser sanctity than that of a firstborn offering, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctified </span>upon its emergence <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the womb </span>yet nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">is the property of </span>the priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it necessary </span>to state that <span class="gemarra-regular">peace-offerings </span>are the property of those who consecrated them, where the animals were already the property of its owner before they were consecrated?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>Abba Yosei ben Dostai mentioned peace-offerings in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>offering. Animal tithes are excluded because Abba Yosei ben Dostai that an animal tithe offering is not the property of the owner of the flock.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “You shall not redeem”</span> (Numbers 18:17), indicating that the owner can never fully redeem the offering, thereby removing its sanctity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the firstborn offering <span class="gemarra-regular">can be sold </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, or</span> when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">blemished </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, or </span>blemished and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. With regard to </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>offerings, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">It shall not be redeemed” </span>(Leviticus 27:33), indicating that the one who designated it can never fully redeem an animal tithe offering, thereby removing its sanctity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the animal tithe offering <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be sold, not </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered, not </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished and not</span> when <span class="gemarra-regular">blemished. </span>The fact that the sale of an animal tithe offering is invalid demonstrates that it is not the property of the one who designated it.
The Gemara asks: How can one claim that Abba Yosei ben Dostai holds that peace-offerings are also owned by those who consecrated them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t </span>Abba Yosei ben Dostai <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Ben Azzai said this <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to a firstborn </span>offering. The Gemara concedes: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara cites an alternative explanation of the mishna’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: What </span>does the mishna mean when it says: One is liable only for damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>were one to use it for a mundane purpose, one <span class="gemarra-regular">would not be </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property? It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">property that is not </span>at all <span class="gemarra-regular">subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of misuse </span>of consecrated property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is that? </span>It is referring to any property <span class="gemarra-regular">of an ordinary person, </span>which has no sanctity at all.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>explicitly: One is liable only for damage caused to property <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary individual. </span>The Gemara concedes: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba says: </span>With regard to the case of an innocuous animal that was consecrated as <span class="gemarra-regular">a peace</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that caused damage, </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">meat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., from the portion of the offering that would have been eaten by its owners. This is in accordance with the general <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the payment for damage caused by an innocuous ox is collected exclusively from the proceeds of the sale of the body of the ox and not from any other property of its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he does not collect </span>the damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sacrificial </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portions.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one collects exclusively from the meat portion and not from the <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial portions, </span>as those are <span class="gemarra-regular">to be offered up to God?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for Rabbi Abba to teach that there is no <span class="gemarra-regular">collection from </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">corresponding </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial portions. </span>Payment for damage caused by an innocuous animal is half the amount of the damages, and can be no more than the value of the animal itself. Rabbi Abba is teaching that when assessing the damage to determine the amount to be paid, one deems the owner responsible only according to his share of the animal, i.e., the meat portions, in relation to the animal as a whole.
Rabbi Natan and the Rabbis engage in a dispute concerning the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case in which an ox pushed another animal into a pit (see 53a). If it were an innocuous ox, for which the Torah limits the owner’s liability to half the damages, the Rabbis rule that liability is incurred exclusively by the owner of the ox, i.e., he pays half the value of the damage, and the owner of the pit is entirely exempt. Rabbi Natan holds that since the damage was caused jointly by the ox and the pit, the owner of the ox need pay only half of what he would pay if his animal had been solely responsible, i.e., a quarter of the damages. Rabbi Natan further rules that the remaining sum can then be fully recovered from the owner of the pit, i.e., he pays the remaining three-quarters of the damages. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion, of those <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span>, does Rabbi Abba state his ruling?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>then it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>and there is no need to state it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t </span>the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Whenever, </span>for whatever reason, the full cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be recovered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from this </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not recovered from that </span>party, i.e., even though the injured party suffered the loss of the full value of his animal and recovered only half its value from the owner of the ox, he may not demand the remaining sum from the owner of the pit. So too, in this case, where the injured party cannot collect damages from the sacrificial portions, he cannot recover that loss from the meat portions of the one who brought the offering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Natan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, doesn’t he say: Whenever </span>the full cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be recovered from this </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">recovered from that </span>one, i.e., since the owner of the ox pays only a quarter of the damages, the remaining sum can be recovered from the owner of the pit. So too, in this case, since the injured party cannot collect payment from the sacrificial portions, he should be able to recover that loss from the meat portions of the one who brought the offering, in contrast to the ruling of Rabbi Abba.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>Rabbi Abba’s ruling is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, and if you wish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, say </span>his ruling is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>Rabbi Abba’s ruling is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>as one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter, </span>the ruling of the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the damage is caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bodies, </span>such as an ox and a pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But where </span>the damage is caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one body, </span>as in the case of damage caused by a an animal consecrated as a peace-offering, the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">From anywhere that I want to, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I will recover </span>my losses, and accordingly, the injured party could collect the full cost of the damage from the meat portions of the one who brought the offering. Therefore, it is necessary for Rabbi Abba to teach that this is not the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>Rabbi Abba’s ruling is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan: </span>It is only <span class="gemarra-regular">there that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the owner of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the pit: </span>Since <span class="gemarra-regular">I found my ox in your pit, </span>ultimately you bear responsibility for any damage, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I cannot recover from the other </span>one, i.e., the owner of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will recover from you. </span>

Daf 13b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of damage caused by an animal consecrated as a peace-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the injured party actually <span class="gemarra-regular">able to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Only the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage </span>but the <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial portions did not cause damage? </span>Since the entire animal caused the damage, he does not collect the full cost of the damage from the meat portions of the one who brought the offering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>In the case of an innocuous animal consecrated as <span class="gemarra-regular">a thanks-offerin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its meat, </span>i.e., from the portion of the offerings that would have been eaten by the one who brought the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not collect from its bread, </span>i.e., from the offering of forty loaves of bread that accompanies the sacrifice of the animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he does not collect from the <span class="gemarra-regular">bread? </span>The bread is not part of the animal that caused damage.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary </span>for Rava to state this because of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of his ruling, which states: The <span class="gemarra-regular">injured</span> party <span class="gemarra-regular">eats </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>portions of the offering according to the value of the damages owed to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one achieving atonement, </span>i.e., the one bringing the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">brings the bread.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this also obvious? </span>Why should anyone else bring the bread? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say, since </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>is a necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">qualifying factor for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">thanks-offering, </span>as without it one does not fulfill one’s obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the owner of the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the one eating it, why should <span class="gemarra-regular">you eat </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat and I bring </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bread? </span>If you wish to eat, you should bring the bread. Therefore, Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the offering of the loaves of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread is the obligation of the owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the offering.
§ The mishna teaches: One is liable only for damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">property that belongs to members of the covenant.</span>
The Gemara asks: This clause serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what? If </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile, isn’t that </span>already explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>(37b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox of a Je</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that gored an ox of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentile, </span>the Jew is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>this as a principle in the mishna here <span class="gemarra-regular">and then explains </span>it in greater detail in the mishna below.
The mishna continues: One is liable only for <span class="gemarra-regular">assigned property. </span>The Gemara asks: This clause serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what? Rav Yehuda said:</span> This clause serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case in which an animal is injured but it is unclear which of two oxen, owned by different people, caused the damage. The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your ox caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> ox <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Since it cannot be proven which ox actually caused the damage, neither owner is liable. The intention of the mishna is that one is liable only where the belligerent ox is assigned to, i.e., is known to be the property of, a specific individual.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t that </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">below</span> (35a): If <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>seen <span class="gemarra-regular">pursuing a single </span>ox, and then the single ox is found to be injured, and the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your ox caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>And the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your ox caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are exempt </span>since it is uncertain which one is guilty. The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>this as a principle in the mishna here <span class="gemarra-regular">and then </span><span class="gemarra-regular">explains </span>it in greater detail in the mishna below.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> in explanation of the mishna that the term assigned property serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude ownerless </span>property. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which the mishna teaches that one is exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where an ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belonging to us, </span>i.e., to a Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an ownerless ox, </span>it is obvious that the owner bears no liability, as <span class="gemarra-regular">who is claiming </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from him? Rather,</span> it must be referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where an ownerless</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox gored an ox belonging to us, </span>and it teaches that the injured party does not have a right to damages.
The Gemara asks: What is the point of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If the injured party wishes to recover his losses, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him go and take </span>the belligerent ox for himself, since it is currently ownerless. The Gemara explains: The mishna teaches that the injured party does not have any right to the ox, in order to teach that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded him and acquired it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the injured party has no claim to it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said </span>an alternative interpretation of the mishna: The term assigned property serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case in which an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>it, or where <span class="gemarra-regular">it gored </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and subsequently </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">declared </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless. </span>Since the owners did not own the ox at the time the case was brought before the court, they are exempt from paying. Ravina explains that this is the intention of the mishna: That one is liable only when the property that caused the damage was owned a responsible party both when it caused the damage and when it was tried. In this case, at the time of the court hearing it was not owned by a responsible party, as it was either consecrated or ownerless.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that an ox that kills a person is stoned to death. The mishna states (44b) that this does not apply to an ox consecrated to the Temple or an ownerless ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, Rabbi Yehuda said: Even </span>if an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored and </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently consecrated </span>it to the Temple, or if an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored and </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently declared</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span>“And if the ox was wont to gore in time past, <span class="gemarra-regular">and had been forewarned </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with its owner, </span>and he had not guarded it in, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it killed a man </span>or a woman; the ox shall be stoned, and also its owner shall be put to death” (Exodus 21:29). The repetition of the reference to the owner at the beginning and end of the verse indicates that the ox is not stoned <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the ox’s status as the owner’s property at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at the time of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">standing trial is the same</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the ox is owned by a responsible party for both events.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But do we not </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">require</span> that the ox’s status be the same at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox shall be stoned” written with regard to </span>the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the owner of the ox is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the ox’s status as the owner’s property at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the victim and at the time of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">standing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">trial and at the verdict is the same</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the ox is owned by a responsible party for all three events.
§ The mishna teaches: One is liable for damage caused in any place <span class="gemarra-regular">except for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a domain designated </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> responsible for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara explains the reason for this: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox want in my domain? </span>One does not have to guard his ox from causing damage within his own property, since another person’s animal has no right to be there.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one is liable for damage caused in <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage.</span>
The Gemara cites a dispute concerning this case that results in two different ways of interpreting the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Avimi says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>designated for <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>joint use of two <span class="gemarra-regular">partners, </span>either one of them is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused by the ox of one partner to the property of the other partner while <span class="gemarra-regular">in it, </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and for the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling. And </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>One is liable for damage caused in any place <span class="gemarra-regular">except for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain designated </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one responsible </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage, as </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>there; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured</span> party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one responsible for the damage, when he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> causes damage, the one who is responsible for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is obligated </span>to pay damages. The statement in the mishna concerning a domain designated for joint use is the beginning of the following clause and introduces a case in which one is liable for damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>In a courtyard designated for joint use, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt for </span>one’s ox causing damage to the property of his partner in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and for </span>one’s ox causing damage to the property of his partner in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling. And</span> accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>One is liable for damage caused in any place <span class="gemarra-regular">except for a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain designated </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one responsible</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the damage, and </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">also exempt </span>for damage done in <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The statement in the mishna about a domain designated for joint use is a continuation of the previous clause and adds an additional case in which one is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the following clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">When one causes damage, the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the damage is obligated </span>to pay damages, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add </span>the fact that one is liable for damage in the framework of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>which was not previously mentioned in the mishna.
This interpretation of the concluding clause of the mishna, as a reference to Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">works </span><span class="gemarra-regular">out well according to Shmuel, </span>in his dispute with Rav (3b) concerning the meaning of Ox and <span class="it-text">Maveh</span> in the first mishna of this chapter. According to Shmuel they mean Trampling and Eating, respectively, and Goring has yet to be addressed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rav, who says: </span>The term ox in the mishna includes damage caused by the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all matters </span>involving damaging actions <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>are completed by <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox, </span>including Goring, Eating, and Trampling, Goring is already addressed in the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is added </span>by the clause: The <span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage is obligated </span>to pay damages?
The Gemara answers: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that which the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that elucidates the mishna’s statement. The mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>an animal or item one is responsible to safeguard <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one liable for the damage </span>caused by insufficiently safeguarding it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated </span>to pay payments of restitution for damage. This serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a borrower, a paid bailee, and a renter, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an animal, </span>e.g., an ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their possession. </span>If the ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damages, and </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full damages. </span>If the ox was safely enclosed and a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">broke open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">at night, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">listin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> broke it open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>that the mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>an animal or item one is responsible to safeguard <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one liable for the damage </span>caused by insufficiently safeguarding it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated </span>to pay payments of restitution for damage. This serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee, a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> borrower, a paid bailee, and a renter. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lender’s ox, </span>which was under the watch of the borrower, <span class="gemarra-regular">injure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the borrower’s ox, </span>and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is teaching that the lender is liable to pay the borrower, why is this so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>my ox <span class="gemarra-regular">had injured </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the world </span>at large, i.e., someone else’s ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">you, </span>the borrower, <span class="gemarra-regular">would be required to pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as you were entrusted with safeguarding it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that </span>my ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has injured your ox, should I be required to pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case must be <span class="gemarra-regular">that the borrower’s ox injure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the lender’s ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is teaching that the borrower is liable to pay. The Gemara asks: According to this interpretation, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that if the belligerent ox was innocuous, the borrower is liable to pay only half of the damages. But why? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the borrower: By borrowing my ox, you undertook full responsibility for it such that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>my ox <span class="gemarra-regular">had been injured</span> by an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">from the world </span>at large, <span class="gemarra-regular">you would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be required to pay </span>me <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>value of my <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, </span>irrespective of whether the belligerent ox was considered innocuous or forewarned. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your ox that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> injured </span>my ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">should you </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damages? </span>This interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is also difficult.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where the lender’s ox injured</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the borrower’s ox, and with what are we dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">undertook </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding the body of </span>the lender’s ox from being injured, 

Daf 14a

<span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he did not undertake </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the lender’s ox to prevent it <span class="gemarra-regular">from causing damage. </span>Accordingly, the lender remains responsible for his ox, and if it caused damage to the borrower’s ox the lender is liable, as in any other case in which his ox caused damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, say, </span>and try to explain accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the ox was safely enclosed and a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">broke open at night, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits broke </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it open and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, </span>the bailee is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. The Gemara infers: If it broke open <span class="gemarra-regular">during the day </span>and then caused damage, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: According to the interpretation offered in explanation of the previous clause, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns a case in which one borrowed an ox but did not undertake the responsibility to prevent it from causing damage. If so, how can the latter clause imply that there are cases in which he is liable? If <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not undertake </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the lender’s ox to prevent it <span class="gemarra-regular">from causing damage, </span>he should never be liable for the damage that it caused.
The Gemara answers that the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns a different case than that of the previous clause. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If, </span>by contrast, the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">did undertake </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the lender’s ox to prevent it <span class="gemarra-regular">from causing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if it causes damage, the borrower is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>But if the ox was safely enclosed and the wall enclosing it <span class="gemarra-regular">broke open at night, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits broke</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it open and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara returns to its prior discussion of the mishna’s statement concerning property designated for the joint use of the injured party and the one liable for the damage. The Gemara cited Rabbi Elazar’s opinion that each partner is exempt from liability for any damage that falls within the categories of Trampling or Eating that their ox caused to the other partner’s property. The Gemara challenges his opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rav Yosef teach </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of partners, or </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">an inn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pundak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for Eating </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and for Trampling </span>caused by an ox of one partner to the property of the other. It would appear that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> provides a refutation of my opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Are there not </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraitot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that disagree </span>with regard to this issue? <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in accordance with my opinion in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (1:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elaza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would state four principles </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the liability incurred based on where the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>occurs. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>location <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damage, </span>the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for all </span>the damage caused there. If a place is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damage and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party, the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt for all </span>the damage caused there.
If a place is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">e.g., a courtyard </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of partners or </span>a field in <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> valley </span>that is jointly owned, the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt for Eating and for Trampling</span> performed by his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>that place. But <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">goring, and for pushing, and for biting, and for crouching </span>upon items in order to damage them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for kicking, </span>which are all subcategories of the primary category of Goring, if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
If a place where the damage occurs is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">e.g., a courtyard that is not</span> owned by either <span class="gemarra-regular">of the two of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eating and for Trampling </span>performed by his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>that place. But <span class="gemarra-regular">for goring, and for pushing, and for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">biting, and for crouching </span>upon items in order to damage them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for kicking, </span>which are all subcategories of the primary category of Goring, if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span> that in <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>designated for the joint use <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> partners or </span>a field in <span class="gemarra-regular">the valley </span>that is jointly owned, the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt for Eating and for Trampling </span>performed by his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>that place. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> supports Rabbi Elazar’s opinion.
The Gemara comments: These <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are difficult, </span>as they seem to contradict <span class="gemarra-regular">one another.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">When that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>which under the terms of their partnership is <span class="gemarra-regular">designated for </span>the use of both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, i.e., as partners, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">both produce and oxen </span>there. Since both partners have a right to keep their oxen there, they are not liable for any damage their oxen cause in the jointly owned space. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef </span>is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>which under the terms of their partnership is <span class="gemarra-regular">designated for </span>the purpose of bringing their <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it is not designated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen </span>there. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>caused by one partner’s ox to the other’s produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>equivalent to <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> courtyard </span>owned exclusively by <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party, and therefore he is liable.
The Gemara notes: In accordance with this explanation, the language of each of these <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">also precise, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rav Yosef, the case of a courtyard that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inn, </span>where oxen are usually not allowed to be brought, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it teaches there, </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the case of a courtyard that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>a field in the <span class="gemarra-regular">valley, </span>where oxen are usually allowed to enter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it </span>that the Gemara’s distinction between the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> is correct.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Zeira objects to this </span>interpretation of Rav Yosef’s <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the courtyard is <span class="gemarra-regular">designated for </span>both of them to keep their <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>there, they should not be liable for damage caused by their oxen there, as in order for one to be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">don’t we need </span>a case that fits the depiction of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consumed in a field of another” </span>(Exodus 22:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since they both have the right to use the courtyard it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>fulfill this condition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is not designated for </span>them to keep <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen </span>there, that is sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">for it to be termed “a field</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another.”</span>
Given the distinction between the cases discussed in the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, the Gemara reconsiders the dispute between Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Elazar concerning the mishna’s statement about property whose use is designated for both the injured party and the one liable for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Difti said to Ravina: Let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraitot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not disagree, </span>as they are referring to different cases, so too, the <span class="gemarra-italic">amora’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Elazar, <span class="gemarra-regular">also do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagree, </span>as they are similarly referring to these different cases.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes, </span>that is correct. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, </span>their dispute does not concern every case of a jointly owned courtyard, as the Gemara had assumed; rather, their dispute concerns specifically a courtyard designated for the use of their produce, but not the use of their oxen. And <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree whether </span>to accept <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty </span>raised <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Zeira, </span>that such a courtyard cannot be considered “a field of another,” <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> accept <span class="gemarra-regular">the resolution of Abaye, </span>that it can be considered “a field of another.”
§ The Gemara returns to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>and analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> cited above. It states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Elazar would state four principles with regard to </span>the liability incurred based on where the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>was caused. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>location <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the injured</span> party <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the damage, </span>the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for all </span>the damage caused there. If a place is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party, the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt for all [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the damage caused there.
The Gemara infers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach: </span>One is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">al</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>damage caused there, which would suggest that one is liable for all types of damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One is liable for all [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the damage caused, which can be translated as: <span class="gemarra-regular">For </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>This indicates that even were one’s ox considered to be innocuous and caused damage of the category of Goring, which would generally incur liability for half the value of the damage, in this case the owner is liable for the full cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Whose</span> opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, who says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>performed by an innocuous animal, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical, </span>done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the injured </span>party, is that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>even if the ox is innocuous.
If this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>and try to explain accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a place where the damage occurs is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">e.g., a courtyard that is not </span>owned by either <span class="gemarra-regular">of the two of them, </span>the owner of an animal that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for Eating and for Trampling</span> performed by his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>that place.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean by saying the property is <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the intention of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is that the property is <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">at all</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>person, why should either partner be liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t I need </span>a case that fits the depiction of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it consumed in a field of another” </span>(Exodus 22:4), which is understood to mean that the consumed produce belongs to the owner of the field in which the act of consumption occurred; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since the injured party does not have any rights to this place it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>fulfill this condition?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is obvious </span>that the intention of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is that the property is <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one together; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of them, i.e., the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> latter clause teaches: </span>If the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If so, in the latter clause <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>performed by an innocuous animal, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical, </span>occurring <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the injured</span> party, is that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: Could it be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and the last clause</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda</span> with regard to another mishna (15b): <span class="gemarra-italic">Shinnana</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> leave the mishna and follow after me </span>and my interpretation that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">last clause is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis. </span>In this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as well, the different clauses are taught in accordance with different Sages’ opinions.
The Gemara presents a different interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said in the name of Rava: The entire</span> <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and what </span>does it mean by saying that the property is <span class="gemarra-regular">of neither this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one? The property does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>belong both <span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>it is designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the use of only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of them, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>him to keep his <span class="gemarra-regular">produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> there. Only the injured party has the right to keep his produce there. But it is designated both <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and for that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>them to keep their <span class="gemarra-regular">oxe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> there, as both have this right.
Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>damage of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered to be the <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard of the injured </span>party; therefore, the one responsible for the damage is liable to pay for the damage. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>since they both have the right to keep their oxen there, the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered to be like <span class="gemarra-regular">a public domain, </span>and therefore even Rabbi Tarfon agrees that if one’s innocuous ox causes damage there one is liable for only half the value of the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> list <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>principles? <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">three. </span>In other words, according to the way Ravina explains the latter clause, i.e., the fourth principle, it does not teach anything that is not already known from the first three principles, as the fact that one is liable for Eating and Trampling in property designated for the use of the injured party is explicitly stated in the first principle, and the fact that one is liable for only half the cost of the damage in a case of Goring in a jointly owned courtyard is expressed in the third principle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>

Daf 14b

There are only <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">principles, </span>but they are listed as four cases because they apply <span class="gemarra-regular">in four </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">places.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The determination of payment of damages is made by <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary appraisal. </span>One pays with items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">before a court. And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">based</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>who are <span class="gemarra-regular">free men, </span>i.e., men who are not Canaanite slaves, and who are <span class="gemarra-regular">members of the covenant, </span>i.e., Jews. <span class="gemarra-regular">And women </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are included in the </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>in the same way as men. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one liable for the damage </span>are involved <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara will explicate each of these principles.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: The determination of payment of damages is made by <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary appraisal?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: This appraisal </span>of the damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">should be </span>made <span class="gemarra-regular">only in terms of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value of the damage.
