The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learn, </span>in this mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Sages </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>explicitly: In a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow damaged</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a cloak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak injured </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow, </span>e.g., the cow tread on it, thereby damaging it, and it became entangled in the cow’s legs, causing the cow to trip, <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not say </span>that it may be presumed that the damage to the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow is offset</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by </span>the damage to the <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak and </span>the damage to the <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak is offset by </span>the damage to the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and therefore the owners of both are exempt from any payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>separately the damage caused to each side <span class="gemarra-regular">in terms of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value and only then calculates to what extent the liabilities offset each other.
§ The mishna continues: With items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money; </span>to what does this refer?
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Payment is made with items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court attends to </span>the collection of damages <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in order to collect from <span class="gemarra-regular">property that serves as a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>i.e., land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">proceeded, </span>of his own accord, <span class="gemarra-regular">to seize movable property </span>from the one liable for the damage, the <span class="gemarra-regular">court collects </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">for him from those </span>items he seized. According to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the phrase: Items worth money, is referring to land.
The Gemara analyzes this: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Payment is made with items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court attends to </span>the collection of damages <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in order to collect from <span class="gemarra-regular">property that serves </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a guarantee, </span>i.e., land. The phrase: Items worth money, therefore, is used as a term for land. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">inferred?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Ulla </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the phrase: Items worth money, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">something that is worth any </span>amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">what is that? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">something that is not subject </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>price <span class="gemarra-regular">fraud, </span>which is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to land. Unlike the sale of movable property, the sale of land is valid irrespective of the sum for which the land is sold. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But slaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and documents are also not subject to </span>price <span class="gemarra-regular">fraud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and yet these are not included in the phrase: Items worth money, as the court does not collect payments of damages from them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rabba bar Ulla said: </span>The phrase is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">something</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is acquired with money, </span>which is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to land but not with regard to movable property (see <span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a). The Gemara rejects this explanation: But <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and documents are also acquired with money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said:</span> The phrase is referring to something that is <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but is not </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">money, and all these </span>things, i.e., movable property, slaves, and documents, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered like actual <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>because they have the defining characteristics of money in that they are valuable and portable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda bar Ḥinnana raises a contradiction </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: </span>In the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited earlier <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught: </span>The mishna’s statement that payment is made with items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money teaches that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court attends to </span>the collection of damages <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in order to collect from <span class="gemarra-regular">property that serves as a guarantee,</span> i.e., land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is taught </span>also in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states the superfluous phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">recompense” </span>(Exodus 21:34), <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">worth money, and even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bran, </span>a relatively inferior commodity, is accepted as a valid form of payment. The first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that only land is a valid form of payment, whereas the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that one may pay even with movable property.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what are we dealing here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that teaches that the court collects damages only from land? We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case where damages are collected from <span class="gemarra-regular">orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> whose father was liable to pay damages. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that the liability inherited by the orphans applies only to the land they inherited from their father as it is liened to their father’s debts.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to collection <span class="gemarra-regular">from orphans, say, </span>and try to explain accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: But <span class="gemarra-regular">if the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">proceeded, </span>of his own accord, <span class="gemarra-regular">to seize movable property </span>from the one liable for the damage, the <span class="gemarra-regular">court collects </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">for him from those </span>items he seized. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If, </span>as suggested, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to collection <span class="gemarra-regular">from orphans, why does the court collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him from those </span>items he seized, as the father’s movable property is not liened to his debts?
The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that which Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman says </span>with regard to a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 84a), which teaches that creditors who seize movable property as payment for a debt may keep those items: That is referring to a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which he seized </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>the debtor was still <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Here also, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which he seized </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>the one liable for the damage was still <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Before a court. </span>What does this phrase mean?
This phrase should be understood as a qualification of the previous phrase in the mishna that teaches, as the Gemara explained, that a court collects damages only from land. The mishna then teaches that the court collects only from land that is still in the possession of the one liable for the damage when he appears in court. This <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes </span>a case where the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">sells his </span>landed <span class="gemarra-regular">property and afterward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> goes to court. </span>Since at the time of the hearing he no longer owns land, the court does not collect damages from it.
The Gemara challenges this: Should we <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sells his </span>landed <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> afterward </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">goes to the court, the court does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> collect </span>the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">from those </span>landed properties that he sold? This is certainly incorrect, as the creditor has a lien on the debtor’s property from the time that he borrows the money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the phrase: Before a court, should be understood as an independent clause that <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes a court of non-ordained judges</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hedyotot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> from judging all types of damages, as the payment for certain types of damage is considered to be a fine, and only expert judges who have been ordained are able to impose fines.
§ The mishna continues: Payment is made <span class="gemarra-regular">based </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses.</span>
The Gemara explains: This clause is stated to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>from liability one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses come afterwar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and testify that he is liable to pay it. The mishna teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>due to his admission.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">well according to the one who says: One who admits</span> he is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses come afterward </span>and testify to his liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who admits </span>he is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses come afterward </span>and testify that he is guilty, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there to say </span>in explanation of this clause of the mishna?
The Gemara answers: This clause does not serve to exclude some other case; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is needed </span>to preface <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>that teaches that the only people who are accepted as witnesses in cases of damages are both

Daf 15a

<span class="gemarra-regular">free men and members of the covenant. </span>The mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Free men, to exclude </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from being valid witnesses, and it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Members of the covenant, to exclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentiles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach both exceptions, <span class="gemarra-regular">as had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only about <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, </span>I might have presumed that he is disqualified from serving as a witness <span class="gemarra-regular">because he has no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lineage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the child of a Canaanite slave is not legally considered to be his child in any sense; <span class="gemarra-regular">but a </span>free <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile, who has lineage, I might</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say no, </span>he is qualified. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only about <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile, </span>I might have presumed that he is disqualified from serving as a witness <span class="gemarra-regular">because he has no connection to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot </span>of the Torah; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, who does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have a connection to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot, </span>as he is obligated to keep the mitzvot that a woman is obligated to keep, <span class="gemarra-regular">I might say no, </span>he is qualified. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach both exceptions.
§ The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And women are included in the </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>in the same way as men. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where is this matter </span>derived?
The Gemara presents three sources for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says, and similarly, the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states </span>with regard to the liability of one who takes a false oath that he had not stolen: <span class="gemarra-regular">“When a man or woman shall commit any of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sins </span>of a person” (Numbers 5:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse equates a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> woman with a ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">punishments</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the Torah.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Rabbi Elazar taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The verse states with regard to the civil laws given following the revelation at Sinai: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And these are the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">civil laws that you shall set before them” </span>(Exodus 21:1). The reference to “them” in the verse is referring to all those who stood at the revelation, both men and women. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">equates a woman with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">man with regard to all civil law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Ḥizkiyya and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili taught: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states </span>with regard to liability in a case where one’s ox kills a person: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it killed a man or a woman”</span> (Exodus 21:29). <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">equates a woman with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> man with regard to all killing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the Torah, </span>i.e., the liability incurred is the same whether the person killed was a man or a woman.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>all three sources <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary, as had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>source, one might have said that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>that men and women are equated, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Merciful One had pity upon </span>a woman and made her liable <span class="gemarra-regular">in order that she should achieve atonement </span>through paying restitution. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">civil law, </span>one might say that for <span class="gemarra-regular">a man, who is involved in business </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dealings, yes, </span>the civil laws apply to him, but to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, </span>who generally is not involved in business dealings, the laws do <span class="gemarra-regular">not apply.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only that men and women are equated in <span class="gemarra-regular">civil law, </span>one might have said that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in order that she should </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">sustain </span>herself by engaging in business dealings. If civil laws did not apply to a woman, one would be wary about conducting business with her. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to obligating a woman to achieve <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement, </span>one might have said that <span class="gemarra-regular">a man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who is obligated in mitzvot, yes, </span>he is similarly obligated to achieve atonement; but <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, who is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obligated in </span>all the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot </span>to the same extent as a man, no, the obligation does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply to her.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>sources, one might have limited the fact that a woman and man are equated to these two cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">here due to </span>the fact that she also needs <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement, and there due to </span>the fact that she needs to be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">sustain </span>herself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>one’s liability for his ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killing </span>a person, one might have said that only for killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a man, who is obligated in </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot, </span>yes, the owner of the ox is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ransom; </span>but for killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, </span>who is not obligated in all mitzvot, one might say he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And had </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only the equivalence of a man and woman with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, </span>one might have thought that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is a very serious matter as <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a loss </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of life, but </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>sources, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not a loss of life, I would say no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a woman is not included. Accordingly, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to have all three sources.
§ The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one liable for the damage </span>are involved <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
An amoraic dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>with regard to the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>made when one’s innocuous ox gores another’s animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> restitution </span>for the injured party’s loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav Yehoshua, says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine.</span>
The Gemara elucidates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>The payment is <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds</span> that even <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary oxen, </span>which have not been forewarned with regard to Goring, are <span class="gemarra-regular">not presumed to be safeguarded, </span>as their nature does not prevent them from acting in a belligerent manner. Therefore, the owner is responsible to safeguard them, to prevent them from doing so. Accordingly, if an ox causes damage by goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">by right it </span>should have been <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the damage. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One had pity upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him, as his ox had not yet been forewarned </span>and he was not fully aware of the possibility that it might gore, and accordingly, the Torah reduced the extent of his liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary oxen </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed to be safeguarded, </span>as their nature prevents them from acting in a belligerent manner. Therefore, the owner is not responsible for safeguarding them to prevent them from doing so. Accordingly, if an ox causes damage by goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">by right </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>should have been <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span><span class="gemarra-regular">at all. </span>Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One penalized him in order</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he will safeguard his ox, </span>even before it is forewarned, and decreed that the fine should be given to the injured party even though he is not really entitled to be compensated for his loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in the mishna: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one liable for the damage </span>are involved <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>this assumes that the injured party is theoretically entitled to receive the full value of his damaged animal but in practice receives only half. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what the mishna means by saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that the injured </span>party is also <span class="gemarra-regular">involved </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment, </span>because it is as though he is compelled to forgo half of the cost of the damage that by right he should be paid. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the</span> cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, </span>which assumes that the injured party is not really entitled to be compensated for his loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">now that </span>even the money that <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes is not his </span>by right, is it accurate to describe him <span class="gemarra-regular">as being </span>involved <span class="gemarra-regular">in the payment?</span>
The Gemara explains: The mishna’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only with regard to </span>the fact that the injured party is the one who absorbs the loss due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> between the animal’s death and the time that the case is brought before the court. Since he must absorb this financial loss, it may be said that he is involved in the payment.
The Gemara asks: How can one claim that the mishna is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass? Isn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t it </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna, which by using the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Payments </span>of restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, teaches that the owner </span>of the injured animal <span class="gemarra-regular">attends to</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., retains ownership of, <span class="gemarra-regular">the animal carcass? </span>And therefore it follows that he bears any depreciation in its value, as the Gemara (10b) explained above.
The Gemara explains why the mishna needs to teach this principle twice: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>mention is made <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>is made <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state both cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">because if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it would teach us </span>the principle only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, I might say that only there does the Torah limit the liability of the owner of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it has not yet been forewarned. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>the Torah does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>limit the owner’s liability at all and the owner must also bear the loss due to the diminishing value of the carcass. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">if it would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach us </span>the principle only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned</span> ox, I might say that only there does the Torah limit the owner’s liability <span class="gemarra-regular">because he is paying </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the damage, so the Torah does not overly burden him. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, where he is liable for only half of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>the Torah does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>limit his liability any further, so he must bear the loss of the diminishing value of the carcass. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state the principle in both cases.
The Gemara attempts to prove whether the payment of half the cost of the damage is considered to be monetary restitution or a fine: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (16b): <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the liability incurred for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox? The difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>proceeds of the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body, and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality</span> property.
The Gemara explains the challenge posed by the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so, </span>that payment for damage caused by an innocuous ox is considered a fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">also teach this </span>additional distinction: The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay based</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on his own </span>admission, in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one does not pay a fine based on one’s own admission, whereas the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> based on his own </span>admission.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> could have taught this distinction; however, <span class="gemarra-regular">he taught </span>only certain distinctions <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> omitted </span>others, including this one. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">did he omit that he omitted this? </span>A <span class="it-text">tanna</span> would never omit just a single case, perforce there must be another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> he omitted.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He omitted </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that if an innoc-uous ox kills someone, its owner does not pay even <span class="gemarra-regular">half of the ransom </span>payment, whereas if the ox is forewarned, he pays the full ransom.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one claims that the mishna omits the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of one who admits his liability <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that it also omits the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the owner of an innocuous ox does not pay even <span class="gemarra-regular">half of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the ransom, </span>that is a flawed claim, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not an omission, </span>because one could say: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says </span>that when <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox kills a person, one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the distinction between an innocuous and forewarned ox is included in the mishna’s ruling that the owner of an innocuous ox pays half the cost of the damage. Accordingly, no proof can be adduced from the mishna.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 41a): 

Daf 15b

If one admits: <span class="gemarra-regular">My</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox killed so-and-so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>my ox killed <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so’s ox, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span><span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission.
The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> innocuous ox? </span>If so, this mishna proves that one is required to pay for half the cost of the damage even based on one’s own admission, which demonstrates that the payment is monetary restitution and not a fine.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this explanation, if it had been an <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox that gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would one say that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, he does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pay based on his own </span>admission? But <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rather than teaching </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the mishna in <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span>: If one admits: <span class="gemarra-regular">My ox killed so-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">and-so’s </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">differentiate and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach </span>the distinction <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the case raised in the first clause <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. </span>The reason for the distinction between the cases when one’s ox kills a Jew or a Canaanite slave is that in the first one pays monetary restitution, while in the second one pays a fine. If the mishna wishes to demonstrate the difference between a fine and monetary restitution with regard to admission, then instead of introducing a new case, the mishna would have modified the case of the previous clause.
The mishna would have continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span>in the first clause <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an admission that one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay based on his own </span>admission. The fact that the mishna does not do so suggests that in fact one is required to pay for half the cost of the damage based on one’s own admission that his innocuous ox gored. Evidently, the payment is considered to be monetary restitution.
The Gemara rejects this: The reason the mishna did not raise the distinction between an innocuous and a forewarned ox is not because that distinction is not a valid one, but because the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox. Accordingly, no proof can be adduced from the mishna.
The Gemara suggests further: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the concluding clause of the mishna just cited: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the principle: Anyone who pays more than </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he damaged does not pay based on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>admission. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not</span> that were he liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he damaged, he would pay </span>based on his own admission? Since when an innocuous ox gores, its owner is liable to pay more than the cost of the damage, the payment is clearly not monetary restitution; perforce it must be a fine, and therefore it is not payable based on one’s own admission.
The Gemara rejects the inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>one should infer only that were he liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">as much</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he damaged, he pays</span> based on his own admission. If the sum to be paid is more or less than the cost of that which he damaged, he would not pay based on his own admission.
The Gemara asks. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to that opinion, where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>than the cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would one say that, <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>based on his own admission? <span class="gemarra-regular">If so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, instead of teaching: This is the principle: Anyone who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pays more than </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he damaged </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: Anyone who does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not pay as much as </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he damaged </span>does not pay based on his own admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>that statement <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates </span>cases where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>than the cost of that which he damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">and it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates </span>cases where one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>than the cost of that which he damaged. Evidently, the mishna holds that where one’s liability is for less than the cost of the damage, it is payable based on one’s own admission. This therefore provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion that the payment for half the cost of the damage is a fine.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is a fine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara notes the obvious inconsistency: How can it be that the Gemara offers <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion that the payment for half the cost of the damage is a fine <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then state that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakh</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> is in accordance with that opinion?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> may be in accordance with that opinion because of the following resolution of the refutation. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the Gemara held that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion that the payment for half the cost of the damage is a fine? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach: </span>Anyone who does not pay <span class="gemarra-regular">as much as </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he damaged </span>does not pay based on his own admission. This is not, in fact, a conclusive refutation, as even if one holds that the payment of half the cost of the damage for an innocuous ox is considered monetary restitution, one can still explain why the mishna doesn’t discuss cases where one is liable for less than the cost of the damage.
This is because the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot make </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an absolute </span>statement about such cases, that one never pays based on one’s own admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since there is </span>an obligation for one to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">pebble</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> inadvertently propelled by the foot of a walking animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">which, through tradition it is learne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>this payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is monetary restitution, </span>and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach </span>cases where one’s liability is valued at less than the cost of the damage.
The Gemara considers the ramifications of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And now that you have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is a fine, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">dog that ate lamb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>this innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">cat that ate a chicken, </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">is atypica</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> behavior for dogs and chickens, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not collect </span>the payment for these acts in the courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since it is not common for these animals to eat those animals, these acts are classified as Goring, irrespective of the fact that the animal gained pleasure from the damage, for which it would normally be classified in the category of Eating. Therefore, in cases where these animals had not performed this act of damaging before, and were therefore considered innocuous, the owner is liable for only half the cost of the damage, which is a fine. Since the collection of fines may be imposed only by judges who have been ordained, and ordination is given only in Eretz Yisrael, these payments are not collected in Babylonia.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>they attacked <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>animals, as it is atypical behavior for them; <span class="gemarra-regular">but where </span>they attacked <span class="gemarra-regular">small</span> animals, since that <span class="gemarra-regular">is their </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of behavior, it is classified as Eating, for which the owner pays the full cost of the damage, which is certainly considered monetary restitution. Accordingly, the payment is collected by the courts in Babylonia.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even in a case where the payment is considered a fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">seize</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the property of the owner of the belligerent animal in order to cover his loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not reclaim </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him </span>since he is entitled to it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>also, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fix a time for m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to go to Eretz </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yisrael </span>to present the case before ordained judges, <span class="gemarra-regular">we fix </span>a time <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>and require the owner of the belligerent animal to go to the court in Eretz Yisrael at that time. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not go, we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">excommunicate hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> for disobeying the orders of the court.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And either</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> way</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we excommunicat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the owner of the belligerent animal <span class="gemarra-regular">until he removes the danger</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., by killing the animal or otherwise neutralizing the danger.
The justification for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Natan, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not raise a vicious do</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his house, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and one may not set up an unstable ladder in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his house? The verse states: “You shall not bring blood </span><span class="gemarra-regular">into your house” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:8), i.e., one may not allow a hazardous situation or item to remain in one’s house. As long as the belligerent dog or cat is still alive, the owner is in violation of this verse and therefore the court may excommunicate him for failing to remove the danger.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that an animal can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> even when its owner was warned each time to prevent it from doing so. After the third time, the animal is rendered forewarned. In such cases, the owner is liable to pay only half of the damages. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five</span> damage-causing acts for which an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>at times even if it had never caused damage in that manner. In such cases the owner is liable to pay the full cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">An animal is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to Goring, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">not for goring </span>with its horns, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor for pushing </span>with its body, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">biting, nor for crouching </span>upon items in order to damage them, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor for kicking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In these cases the animal is considered to be innocuous and its owner is liable for only half of the damages.
Concerning acts of damage performed with <span class="gemarra-regular">the tooth, </span>the animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to eating that which is fitting for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to eat. Concerning acts of damage performed with <span class="gemarra-regular">the foot, </span>the animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">breaking </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">while walking. And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which gored three times and each time his owner was warned to safeguard his ox from doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that causes damage </span>to the property of the injured party while <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured</span> party. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">the person, </span>i.e., any damage done by a person. In all of these cases the one who caused the damage is considered to be forewarned, resulting in the obligation to pay the full cost of the damage.
The mishna presents the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> for wild animals: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf; the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the bear; the leopard; the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the meaning of which the Gemara will discuss; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the snake.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> These are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>even if they had never previously caused damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: When these </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domesticate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. But the snake </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is always </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in its latter clause: Concerning acts of damage performed with <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tooth, </span>the animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to eating</span> that which is fitting for it to eat, we learn, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, that we are dealing </span>throughout the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>cases of damage done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> injured </span>party, as one is exempt from liability for acts of damage classified as Eating if they occur in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet the first clause <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: An</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> animal is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to Goring. Stating that it is not forewarned indicates that the liability of its owner is limited only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to paying the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> full </span>cost <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half</span> the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is </span>it that holds that when damage classified as Goring is done within the property of the injured party the owner of the belligerent animal is liable for only half of the damages? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who say: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>performed by an innocuous animal, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical </span>behavior, done <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the courtyard of the injured </span>party, is that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
But then <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>and try to explain accordingly, the next part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox </span>that gored three times, and each time his owner was warned to safeguard his ox from doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that causes damage</span> to the property of the injured party while <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property of the injured </span>party. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">the person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In these cases, the responsible party pays full damages. With this clause <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>performed by an innocuous animal, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical, </span>done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard of the injured </span>party, is that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>even if the ox is innocuous.
The Gemara asks: Could it be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>part of the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">clause </span>of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis and </span>the next part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, as Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Yehuda: Large-toothed one, leave the mishna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and follow after me </span>and my interpretation that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>part of the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">clause </span>of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis and </span>the next part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon.</span>
The Gemara presents a different interpretation of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said in the name of Rav: </span>

Daf 16a

The <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon; the first </span>part of the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">clause </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>which under the terms of their partnership is <span class="gemarra-regular">designated for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them, </span>i.e., the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>keep his <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>keep their <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen </span>there. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>caused by one partner’s ox to the injured party’s produce in that courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>equivalent to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> courtyard </span>owned exclusively by <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party, and the ox’s owner is liable for all the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>damage of the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>since they are both allowed to keep oxen there, the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> equivalent to <span class="gemarra-regular">a public domain, </span>and if one’s innocuous ox causes damage there, one is liable for only half the cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: I stated this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teaching </span>of Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Zevid of Neharde’a,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he said to me: Are you </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">able </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to interpret </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon? But doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>Concerning acts of damage performed with <span class="gemarra-regular">the tooth, </span>the animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to eating that which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is fitting for it </span>to eat. This indicates that only if what it eats <span class="gemarra-regular">is fitting for it, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one is liable for the full cost of the damage, but if it eats something <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not fitting for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it, </span>the owner would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable for the full cost of the damage, but only for half the cost of the damage.
Rav Kahana explains his difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, </span>the owner should be liable to pay the full cost of the damage even if his animal ate something not fitting for it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t </span>Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>performed by an innocuous animal, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical, </span>done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party, is that the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>even if the ox is innocuous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav Kahana said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually </span>it must be that the entire mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis and </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>The opening clause should be understood as saying: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that animals can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, but if they were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">warned </span>for performing those acts three times, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the five </span>acts <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>i.e., the mishna is not referring to two different sets of damages, five acts for which the animal is considered innocuous and five for which it is considered forewarned. Rather, both statements in the initial clause of the mishna are referring to the same five acts of Goring, and they teach that although the animal is initially considered innocuous with regard to these five acts, it can become forewarned.
The next part of the mishna then provides another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for damage of the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, </span>an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the outset. </span>The next two items in the mishna: A forewarned ox and an ox that causes damage on the property of the injured party, should be understood as a question and an answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">And where </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">their forewarned status </span>with regard to these acts apply? It applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> injured </span>party. According to Rav Kahana’s explanation, the statement: In the courtyard of the injured party, refers only to cases of Eating or Trampling, not to acts classified as Goring, and therefore it is true even according to the opinion of the Rabbis.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina objects to this</span> explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>(24b) <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>With regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that causes damage </span>to the property of the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party, stated in the mishna here (15b), <span class="gemarra-regular">how so, </span>i.e., what are the circumstances in which one is liable to pay the full cost of the damage? The mishna below (24b) proceeds to list acts of damage classified as Goring. Ravina states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the mishna here (15b) <span class="gemarra-regular">discusses that </span>case, i.e., that it is referring to Goring, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>ruling that the mishna below <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: How so, </span>and proceeds to discuss one’s liability for Goring, as it is elucidating the case mentioned in the mishna here. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say, </span>as Rav Zevid suggests, that the mishna here (15b) <span class="gemarra-regular">does not discuss </span>Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of the mishna below when it asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How so, </span>and then proceeds to discuss one’s liability for Goring?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Ravina said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that animals can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, but if they were warned </span>for performing those acts three times with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the five </span>acts, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned.</span>
The next part of the mishna then provides another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for damage of the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the outset, and this is</span> a case in which all agree that the animal is classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>there is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that causes damage </span>to the property of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party, which <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Tarfon and the Rabbis. And there are other </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to these </span>in which animals are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from the outset, namely: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf, the lion, the bear, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">leopard, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the snake.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>interpretation of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that animals can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, but if they were warned </span>for performing those acts three times with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the five </span>acts, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. </span>The next part of the mishna then provides another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for damage of the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> outset, and this is </span>a case in which all agree that the animal is classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox. And</span> there is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that causes damage</span> to the property of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property of the injured </span>party, which <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and the Rabbis. And there are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to these </span>in which animals are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>from the outset, namely: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf, the lion, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bear, the leopard, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the snake.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who raise </span>this issue <span class="gemarra-regular">as a contradiction </span>and through doing so arrived at the same conclusions, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the opening clause of the mishna: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that animals can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, and </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts for which an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. </span>With regard to this, one can ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is there nothing else</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But aren’t there </span>the cases mentioned in the continuation of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf, the lion, the bear, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the leopard, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the snake? </span>These are considered to be forewarned even if they had never caused damage before.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>the contradiction through that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>damage-causing acts that animals can perform twice and remain <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, but if they were warned </span>for performing those acts three times with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the five </span>acts, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. </span>The next part of the mishna then provides another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for damage of the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>an animal is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the outset, and this is </span>a case in which all agree that the animal is classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned ox. And </span>there is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that causes damage </span>to the property of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, which <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and the Rabbis. And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there are other </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to these </span>in which animals are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>from the outset, namely: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the lion, the bear, the leopard, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">snake.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: An animal is not considered forewarned with regard to Goring, i.e., not for goring with its horns, nor for pushing with its body, nor for biting, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor for crouching </span>upon items in order to damage them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">large vessels, </span>as it is atypical for an animal to crouch upon them, and therefore the act is classified as a subcategory of Goring. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the animal cr0uched upon <span class="gemarra-regular">small vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since that <span class="gemarra-regular">is its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of behavior, it is classified as a subcategory of Trampling, for which the animal is considered forewarned from the outset.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">An animal is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>from the outset, <span class="gemarra-regular">to walk in its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and to break or crush a person, or an animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or vessels. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that an animal’s typical manner is to crush vessels, presumably by crouching down upon them. This would seem to contradict the mishna that states that such behavior is atypical. It would appear the only resolution to this contradiction is if one accepts the distinction made by Rabbi Elazar that the mishna concerns large vessels and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns small vessels.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps</span> the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns a case where the animal pushed against the utensils <span class="gemarra-regular">from the side </span>and crushed them against a wall, but it does not concern a case where it crouched upon them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of this discussion, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Do not say </span>that the mishna’s ruling refers only to <span class="gemarra-regular">large vessels, as it is atypical </span>for an animal to crouch upon them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the animal crouched upon <span class="gemarra-regular">small vessels, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>and for that type of damage the animal is considered forewarned. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna refers <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">small vessels, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">atypical </span>for an animal to crouch upon them.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: An animal is considered forewarned, from the outset, to walk in its typical manner and to break <span class="gemarra-regular">or crush a person, or an animal, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or vessels.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: Perhaps </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerns only a case where the animal pushed against the utensils <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the side </span>and crushed them against a wall.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who raise </span>this issue <span class="gemarra-regular">as a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> contradiction: We learned </span>in the mishna: An animal is not considered forewarned with regard to Goring, i.e., not for goring with its horns, nor for pushing with its body, nor for biting, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor for crouching </span>upon items in order to damage them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: An animal is considered forewarned, from the outset, to walk in its typical manner and to break <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">crush a person, or an animal, or vessels? </span>In order to resolve this contradiction, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult; here, </span>in the mishna, the reference is to <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the reference is to <span class="gemarra-regular">small vessels.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">The wolf, the lion, </span>the bear, the leopard, the <span class="it-text">bardelas</span>, and the snake; these are considered to be forewarned even if they had never caused damage before.
