The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bardelas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nafreza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nafreza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Yosef said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">appa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In addition to the list of animals that are considered forewarned, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Also the hyena [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzavo’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Elazar says: Also the snake. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef said </span>in explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The <span class="gemarra-regular">hyena </span>mentioned by Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the animal called <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">appa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If Rav Yosef understands a hyena to be an <span class="it-text">appa</span>, how could he also claim, above, that it is a <span class="it-text">bardelas</span>?
The Gemara explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: Here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, Rabbi Meir is <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to a male hyena</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the mishna, the reference is to <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hyena.</span>
And it is apparent that a male hyena is distinct from a female one, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A male hyen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after seven year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> metamorphoses into an insectivorous bat [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atalef </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; an insectivorous bat after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> seven years metamorphoses into a herbivorous bat [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arpad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> herbivorous bat after seven years metamorphoses into a thistle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kimosh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; a thistle after seven years metamorphoses into a briar [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥo’aḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">a briar after seven years metamorphoses </span><span class="gemarra-regular">into a demon. </span>Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person’s spine, seven years </span><span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">metamorphoses into a snake. </span>The Gemara qualifies the last statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter applies </span>only to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">did not bow during </span>the blessing of <span class="gemarra-regular">thanksgiving</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the eighteenth blessing of the <span class="it-text">Amida</span> prayer.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says </span>above: In addition to the list of animals that are considered forewarned, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Also the hyena. </span>

Daf 16b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Also the snake. </span>By using the term also, Rabbi Elazar suggests he considers a snake to be forewarned to the same extent as the other animals in the mishna’s list, which, according to his opinion, are not considered to be forewarned if they are domesticated. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: When these </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are domesticated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, but the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">snake is always </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned?</span>
The Gemara answers: Emend and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as saying that Rabbi Elazar says: <span class="gemarra-regular">A snake, </span>instead of saying: Also a snake. Accordingly, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is teaching that he holds that only a snake is considered to be forewarned under all circumstances because he holds that even if it is domesticated it is still prone to caused damage.
§ The Gemara considers cases of damage caused by a lion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a lion </span>that kills an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it clawe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> its prey <span class="gemarra-regular">and ate </span>it, the lion’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. But if it first <span class="gemarra-regular">tore apart </span>its prey with its teeth in order to kill it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> only then <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>it, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the damage.
The Gemara elucidates: If <span class="gemarra-regular">it clawed </span>its prey <span class="gemarra-regular">and ate </span>it, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since it is its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">claw </span>its prey and eat it, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to </span>the case of an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that eats fruit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and vegetables </span>belonging to someone else. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>done <span class="gemarra-regular">in a public domain, and </span>the owner of the lion is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>But if the lion first <span class="gemarra-regular">tore apart </span>its prey to kill it, since this <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, </span>the act is classified as Goring, for which an owner is liable even in a public thoroughfare.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say that tearing apart </span>its prey <span class="gemarra-regular">is not the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of </span>a lion? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“The lion tears apart for its young, </span>and it strangles for its lionesses, and it fills its caves with prey, and its den with that which was torn apart” (Nahum 2:13). The description in the verse clearly indicates that it is the typical manner of a lion to tear apart its prey. The Gemara answers that each phrase of this verse is referring not to a situation where the lion catches prey for its own immediate use, but to one where it provides food <span class="gemarra-regular">for its young, </span>as it says: “The lion tears apart for its young”; to provide food <span class="gemarra-regular">for its lionesses: “And it strangles for its lionesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”; </span>to provide food <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the young cubs in <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lair: “And it filled its lair with prey”; </span>and to provide food <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the young cubs in <span class="gemarra-regular">its den: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And its den with that which was torn apart.” </span>Therefore, we cannot learn from this verse that it is the typical manner of a lion to tear apart prey for its own immediate use.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning acts classified as Eating: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a wild</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> animal, </span>including a lion, <span class="gemarra-regular">that entered the courtyard of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and tore apart </span>the courtyard owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">animal and ate </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">meat, </span>the owner of the wild animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it tore apart </span>the animal in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to leave it </span>for later consumption. Since this is typical behavior for a lion, the lion is considered forewarned with regard to it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>its meat? The Gemara answers: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the lion initially killed the animal to leave it for later consumption but then <span class="gemarra-regular">reconsidered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and ate </span>it.
The Gemara questions this understanding: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">know </span>what the animal’s initial intentions were? <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>if one accepts this claim, then the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>called into question, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the case he ruled on <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a case like <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>where the lion initially intended to leave the prey he killed for later consumption, and therefore the owner should be exempt. The Gemara therefore rejects this understanding.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>two cases <span class="gemarra-regular">disjunctively </span>and should be understood as teaching two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: With regard to a lion <span class="gemarra-regular">that tore apart </span>an animal in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to leave </span>it for later consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>a lion that <span class="gemarra-regular">clawed </span>its prey <span class="gemarra-regular">and ate </span>it, since each acted in the typical manner of a lion, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>It is the typical manner of a wild lion to kill its prey and then eat it, and therefore such damage is classified as Eating. Accordingly, if the damage was done in the public domain, the lion’s owner is exempt from any liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Shmuel says </span>that an owner is liable if his lion does so, that was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domesticated lion and in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Elazar, who says it is not the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of a domesticated wild animal to attack. Accordingly, the act is classified as being of the category of Goring, for which one is liable even in a public thoroughfare.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>when the lion <span class="gemarra-regular">clawed</span> its prey and ate it, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable</span> for any damage it causes in a public domain, since according to Rabbi Elazar such behavior is atypical for a domesticated lion. Why then does Shmuel rule that in such a case the owner is exempt?
The Gemara concedes that its presentation of Ravina’s opinion is untenable: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Ravina’s </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">was not stated in reference to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shmuel’s </span>ruling, but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather in reference to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>cited above, that discusses a case where a lion causes damage in the courtyard of the injured party. Accordingly, Ravina’s statement should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span>that one is liable if one’s lion tore apart an animal and ate it, that was <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to a domesticated lion and in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar, who says it is not the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of a domesticated wild animal to attack.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>since the act is atypical behavior for a lion, it should be classified as Goring, and the owner should be <span class="gemarra-regular">required to pay </span>for only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the lion <span class="gemarra-regular">was forewarned.</span>
The Gemara questions further: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, what </span>is the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches this among </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategories of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eating? It should have taught it among </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategories of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Goring. </span>The Gemara concedes: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>with this explanation.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the liability incurred for damage caused by an ox that is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous and </span>the liability incurred for damage caused by an ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>differences are <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>proceeds of the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">of the body </span>of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">higher </span>property.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the mishna mean by saying he pays from his <span class="gemarra-regular">higher</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aliyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>It means that he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">with the superior-quality [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bame’ulla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>the fact that the word <span class="it-text">aliyya</span> is referring to superior-quality property is indicated by the verse that <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And Hezekiah lay with his ancestors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and they buried him in the best [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bema’ale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the sepulchers of the descendants of David” </span>(II Chronicles 32:33), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Elazar says: </span>The term <span class="gemarra-italic">bema’ale</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">beside the best of the family</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And who are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they? David and Solomon.</span>
The Gemara offers an interpretation of another verse about the burial of a king of Judea, King Asa: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they buried him in his own sepulchers, which he had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hewn out for himself in the city of David, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laid him in the resting place, which was filled with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> perfumes and spices [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zenim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> prepared by the perfumers’ art” (II Chronicles 16:14). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">“perfumes and spices</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”? Rabbi Elazar says: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">many </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zinei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>of perfumes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>The word <span class="it-text">zenim</span> sounds similar to the word <span class="it-text">zenut</span>, licentiousness, and should therefore be understood about types of <span class="gemarra-regular">perfumes that anyone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who smells them is led to licentiousness.</span>
The Gemara cites another dispute between Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani: Jeremiah requested of God to punish those who hounded him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For they have dug</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a pit to trap me and they have set snares</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for my feet” </span>(Jeremiah 18:22). In what way did they dig a pit to trap him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">They cast suspicion upon him of </span>engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who had engaged in sexual intercourse with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">man forbidden to her by the Torah [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel bar Naḥmani says: They cast suspicion upon him of </span>engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a married woman.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says that they cast </span><span class="gemarra-regular">suspicion upon him of </span>engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>because the word “pit” is used as a metaphor for a <span class="it-text">zona</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “For</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zona</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is a deep pit” </span>(Proverbs 23:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says that they cast suspicion </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon him </span>of engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a married woman,</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>reason did Jeremiah use the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“pit”?</span> The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to </span>the fact that she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a married woman, should she be excluded from the category</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>If she commits adultery she is also termed a <span class="it-text">zona</span>, and the term “pit” can justifiably be applied to her.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says that they cast suspicion upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him of </span>engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a married woman, this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is written: “You, Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, know all their plans to kill me” </span>(Jeremiah 18:23). By claiming he engaged in intercourse with a married woman, they implicated him in a prohibition punishable by the death penalty. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says that they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">suspected him of </span>engaging in intercourse with <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what</span> did he mean by saying <span class="gemarra-regular">“to kill </span>me” when there is no court-imposed capital punishment for doing so? The Gemara answers: Jeremiah was referring to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they cast him into a pit of mire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">interpreted </span>a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">homiletically: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “Let them be made to stumble</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before You</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> deal with them in the time of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Your anger” </span>(Jeremiah 18:23)? It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">Jeremiah said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Universe, even at a time when they </span>try to <span class="gemarra-regular">perform</span> acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity, make them stumble </span>by ensuring that they do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with peopl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who are unworthy </span>of charity <span class="gemarra-regular">in order that they should not receive </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reward for </span>helping <span class="gemarra-regular">them.</span>
The Gemara, above, cited a verse concerning King Hezekiah’s burial. The Gemara cites the continuation of that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they afforded him hono</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his death” </span>(II Chronicles 32:33). This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that they established a yeshiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at his grave </span>to study Torah there.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan and the Rabbis disagree </span>with regard to this yeshiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">One said: </span>They studied there for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>days. 

Daf 17a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one said: </span>They studied there for <span class="gemarra-regular">seven</span> days. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>they studied there for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty</span> days.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that offers another interpretation of the verse cited: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And afforded him [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] honor in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his death” </span>(II Chronicles 32:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is referring to the honor given to <span class="gemarra-regular">Hezekiah, king of Judea, that </span>at his burial <span class="gemarra-regular">36,000 </span>men with <span class="gemarra-regular">bared shoulder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> went out</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before him. </span>They removed their robes from their shoulders as a sign of mourning. The number 36,000 is alluded to by the numerical value of the word <span class="it-text">lo</span>, which is thirty-six. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to him: But didn’t they </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">do this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Ahab? </span>Apparently, if they did this for the wicked king Ahab, it is an honor shown to all kings, and it is was not a unique show of honor for the righteous Hezekiah.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the honor that was done for Hezekiah was <span class="gemarra-regular">that they laid a Torah scroll upon his bier</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they said: This one, </span>i.e., Hezekiah, <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that which is written in this, </span>i.e., the Torah scroll.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But nowadays as well, we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do this </span>for any great Torah scholar that dies, so what is unique about what was done to honor Hezekiah? The Gemara answers: Nowadays, <span class="gemarra-regular">we take </span>a Torah scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">out </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not lay </span>it on the bier of the deceased. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that nowadays <span class="gemarra-regular">we also lay </span>a Torah scroll on the bier of the deceased; but <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say: </span>This one <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled</span> that which is written in this.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: I was </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">walking together</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with Rabbi Yoḥanan to ask </span>him about this <span class="gemarra-regular">statement. Whenever</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he would enter a lavatory, </span>upon his exit <span class="gemarra-regular">I would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ask him </span>to explain <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he would not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> answer us until he had washed his hands and donned</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his phylacteries and made </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">blessing, and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">then would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he answer us. </span>With regard to the honor given to King Hezekiah, he said: Nowadays, <span class="gemarra-regular">we even say: </span>This one <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>that which is written in this, but <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not say: He taught </span>that which is written in this, which was a unique honor performed at the burial of the righteous King Hezekiah.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t the Master say: Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">study is grea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">study </span>of Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">leads to</span> one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">performanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the mitzvot? This indicates that the performance of mitzvot is considered of greater value than Torah study. If so, once Hezekiah had been praised with the fact that he fulfilled the mitzvot of the Torah, why mention that he studied it? The Gemara explains: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span>statement of the Master is <span class="gemarra-regular">about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> studyin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the Torah for one’s own knowledge, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>unique praise given to King Hezekiah was <span class="gemarra-regular">about teachin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the Torah to others.
§ A verse that was cited at the beginning of the this chapter (2b) as part of a halakhic exposition is now explained homiletically: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: What</span> is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “Happy are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you that sow beside all waters, that send forth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the feet of the ox and the donkey” </span>(Isaiah 32:20)? It teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever engages in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah and in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">acts of kindness merits</span> reward equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">the portion of two tribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Joseph and Issachar.
The Gemara explains how this is derived from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “Happy are you that sow.” And </span>the reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">sowing </span>refers <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “Sow for yourselves for charity, reap according to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kindness” </span>(Hosea 10:12). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>refers <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> to the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah, as it is stated </span>with regard to Torah study: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Ho, all who are thirsty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, go to water” </span>(Isaiah 55:1).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">merits </span>reward equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">the portion of two tribes </span>is derived as follows: The reference to the ox in the verse is an allusion to Joseph, who is described as an ox (Deuteronomy 33:17), and one’s reward is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he merits to </span>receive <span class="gemarra-regular">a canopy </span>of honor, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph, as it is written: “Joseph is a fruitful </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vine, </span>a fruitful vine by a fountain; <span class="gemarra-regular">its branches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">run over the wall.” </span>The branches over the wall in this verse allude to the canopy. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reference to the donkey is an allusion to the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">merits </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">the portion of Issachar, </span>who is described as a donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Issachar is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">large-boned donkey” </span>(Genesis 49:14).
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span> that the comparison should be understood in a different manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">His enemies will fall before him </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>in the blessing given by Moses to the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>in the blessing bestowed by Moses to the tribe of Joseph: “His horns are the horns of the wild-ox; <span class="gemarra-regular">with them he shall gore the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nations, even to the ends of the earth” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">And he merits the understanding of Issachar, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written:  “And of the children of Issachar, men that had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> understanding of the times, to know what Israel ought to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do” </span>(I Chronicles 12:33). 

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna in the previous chapter (15b) teaches that the owner of an animal is always forewarned with regard to the category of Trampling. The mishna elaborates: For <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>damage caused with <span class="gemarra-regular">the hoof </span>is the animal deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is deemed forewarned with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>trampling objects and <span class="gemarra-regular">breaking </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the course of its walking. An animal is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to walking in its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner and, </span>by doing so, <span class="gemarra-regular">breaking </span>objects as it proceeds.
By contrast, if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking </span>while it was walking, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>it transpired <span class="gemarra-regular">that pebble</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were </span>inadvertently <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled from under its feet and </span>those pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">broke vessels,</span> cases of that kind do not fit precisely into the primary category of Trampling. In both of these cases the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">trod upon a vesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and broke it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then a shard of that vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">fell upon </span>a second <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel and broke it, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the first </span>vessel, as its action is classified under the primary category of Trampling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the latter </span>vessel, as the damage caused by the shard is tantamount to damage caused by pebbles inadvertently propelled by the foot of an animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Chickens are </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to walking in their </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner and breaking </span>objects, and therefore, the owner of a chicken pays the full restitution for the damage done to any objects broken by his chicken. If there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a string [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">delil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>a chicken’s <span class="gemarra-regular">leg </span>as an indication of ownership and it wrapped around a vessel and broke it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">was hopping </span>in an atypical manner <span class="gemarra-regular">and breaking vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 17b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rava: </span>In the context of the category of Trampling, damage caused by an animal trampling an object with its <span class="gemarra-regular">foot is the same as </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal</span> breaking an object with its body. Why does the mishna repeat the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> twice? Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>First, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">primary categories </span>of damage, namely the category of Trampling with an animal’s foot, which is mentioned explicitly in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he teaches </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">subcategorie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of those primary categories, i.e., the animal is deemed forewarned with regard to causing damage with other parts of its body in the course of its walking.
Ravina challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, the latter clause </span>of the mishna (19b), <span class="gemarra-regular">which teaches, </span>concerning the primary category of Eating: For what damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>is the animal deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned? </span>It is deemed forewarned with regard to eating food items fit for its consumption, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">the animal is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to eating fruits and vegetables. Ravina asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What primary categories and what subcategories are there </span>in that context? No subcategories of Eating are enumerated there, and nevertheless, the phrase: The animal is deemed forewarned, is repeated. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">responded to </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">with a humorous </span>response <span class="gemarra-regular">and said to him: I resolved </span>the difficulty in <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> mishna, now <span class="gemarra-regular">you resolve </span>the difficulty in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>for the apparent redundancy in the mishna with regard to Eating? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>First the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating by an undomesticated animal and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating by a domesticated animal. </span>And it was necessary to state both, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it enters your mind to say </span>that since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And he set his animal loose” </span>(Exodus 22:4), with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">domesticated animals, yes, </span>the primary category of Eating applies, but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">undomesticated animals, no, </span>the primary category of Eating does not apply. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that undomesticated animals </span>are included <span class="gemarra-regular">in the category of domesticated animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in this regard and the owner of an undomesticated animal is liable for damage caused by his animal eating another person’s produce.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a domesticated animal <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>and only afterward taught the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an undomesticated animal, as the latter is included in the category of the former. The Gemara answers: On the contrary, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is derived from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an interpretation, is dear to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> preferred to begin with the derived <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and only then proceed to the explicit <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause, </span>in this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">too, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach that which is not </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">written first, </span>as that which is derived from an interpretation is dear to him. The Gemara distinguishes between the cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>with regard to Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>damage caused by a domesticated animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>damage caused by an undomesticated animal <span class="gemarra-regular">are primary categories </span>of damage; therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> taught first <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is derived</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from an interpretation, is dear to him. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to Trampling, would <span class="gemarra-regular">he leave aside the primary category </span>of Trampling, done with the animal’s foot, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach a subcategory </span>first?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead that the reason that in this mishna the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> begins with that which is written explicitly in the Torah and only then proceeds to teach that which is derived through an interpretation is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">concluded </span>the discussion in the final mishna in the previous chapter (15b) <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling </span>by teaching the clause: The foot of an animal is deemed forewarned with regard to trampling objects and breaking them in the course of its walking, therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">he began </span>the first mishna in the second chapter <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the primary category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: An animal is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to walking in its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner and, </span>while doing so, <span class="gemarra-regular">breaking </span>objects in the course of its walking. <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal entered into the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and it damaged </span>an object <span class="gemarra-regular">with its body </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the course of its walking; or </span>if it caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with its hair </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the course of its walking; or with the saddle that is on it; or with the </span>packed <span class="gemarra-regular">saddlebag [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shalif </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is on it; or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with the halter in its mouth; or with the bell [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zog</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> around its neck; or </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with its burden; </span>in all these cases the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>propelled by an animal in the course of its walking, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pig that was burrowing in the garbage hea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and caused damage, </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: If a pig <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that its owner must pay the full cost of the damage. What novel element is Sumakhos introducing? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">it propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pebbles, who mentioned anything about it? </span>The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>For damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by pebbles </span>that were propelled by animals walking <span class="gemarra-regular">in their typical manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a pig that was burrowin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the garbage heap and propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged </span>an object, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. Sumakhos says:</span> Both in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>that were propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pig that was burrowing in the garbage heap and propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">and damaged </span>an object, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Sumakhos does not accept the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the owner pays only half the cost of the damage caused by pebbles inadvertently propelled by the foot of an animal in the course of its walking, i.e., in its typical manner. He holds that since the damage results from the animal’s typical behavior, the owner pays the full cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 2:1): If <span class="gemarra-regular">chickens were flying from place to plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and broke vessels with their wings, </span>their owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>as this is a subcategory of Trampling. By contrast, if the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by the wind </span>generated <span class="gemarra-regular">by their wings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of pebbles. <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos says: </span>The owner pays <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">chickens were hoppin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon dough or upon produce and they sullied </span>it with their feet, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they pecked </span>at it and caused damage, their owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. If </span>in the course of their hopping <span class="gemarra-regular">they stirred up dus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. Sumakhos says: </span>He pays <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a chicken was flying from place to place and wind emerged from beneath its wings and </span>the wind <span class="gemarra-regular">caused vessels to break, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>The Gemara notes: This <span class="gemarra-regular">unattributed </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Sumakhos and hold that the owner pays half the cost of the damage in these cases, just as he does in the case of pebbles propelled by the feet of an animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>analyzed the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Granted, </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos </span>is understood, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that the status of damage resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by the animal’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of damage directly caused by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>and therefore the owner pays the full cost of the damage in both cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>they hold that the status of damage resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by the animal’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of damage directly caused by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself,</span> the owner should <span class="gemarra-regular">be required to pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And if </span>they hold that the status of damage resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">force </span>generated by the animal’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is not like </span>that of damage directly caused by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>and is not attributed to the animal, then the owner should not be required <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay even half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Then Rava said: Actually, </span>the Rabbis hold that the status of damage resulting from a force generated by the animal’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of damage directly caused by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>and in principle the owner should be required to pay the full cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the liability to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>is because the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">learned this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through tradition, </span>and it does not correspond to the standard <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damages.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>type of action <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">za</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> interacts with a vessel in that manner, he renders it <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure, </span>if the same type of action was done by an animal, resulting <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, </span>the owner of the animal is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Conversely, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>type of action <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span> interacts with a vessel in that manner, he leaves it <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure, </span>e.g., where the contact is indirect, if the same type of action was done by an animal, resulting <span class="gemarra-regular">in damage, </span>the owner of the animal is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava, did he come to teach us </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles? </span>The substance of Rava’s statement is that for damage caused by the indirect action of an animal, its owner pays half the cost of the damage. That is identical to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of pebbles articulated in the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> cited earlier. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, Rava teaches us </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf pulling a cart [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Just as with regard to a <span class="it-text">zav</span>, the status of a vessel that a <span class="it-text">zav</span> moves is like that of a vessel with which he came into contact, so too, the status of damage caused by the cart pulled by the animal is like that of damage caused by the animal’s body, and it is not considered indirect damage like in the case of pebbles.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava: An animal is</span> deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to breaking </span>objects <span class="gemarra-regular">in the course of its walking. How so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal entered into the courtyard of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it damaged </span>an object <span class="gemarra-regular">with its body </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the course of its walking; or with its hair </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the course of its walking; or with the saddle that is on it; or with the </span>packed <span class="gemarra-regular">saddlebag that is on it; or with the halter that is in its mouth; or with the bell that is around its neck; or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">with its burden; or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf </span>caused damage while <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling a cart; </span>in all these cases the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">chickens were pecking at the rope </span>tied to <span class="gemarra-regular">a bucket and the rope was severed and the bucket </span>fell and <span class="gemarra-regular">broke, </span>their owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">trod upon a vessel but did not break i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the vessel then <span class="gemarra-regular">rolled to another place and broke </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rava elaborates: In determining one’s liability for causing damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we follow the initial </span>action that ultimately led to the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>case is regarded as damage caused by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself? </span>Accordingly, the owner would pay the full cost of the damage as he would in any case classified under the primary category of Trampling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the breaking of the vessel and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case is regarded as similar to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>propelled by the foot of an animal in the course of its walking, since the vessel was not broken by a direct action of the animal, but rather, as an indirect result of the animal’s action?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Resolve </span>Rava’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba, as Rabba says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">threw a vessel from a roo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and another came and broke it with a stick </span>as it was falling, the one who hit it with the stick is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from all liability <span class="gemarra-regular">as we say to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he broke a broken vessel. </span>From the moment the vessel was tossed from the roof it was inevitable that it would break. Consequently, breaking it with a stick as it was falling had no real effect. Apparently, the initial action is the decisive factor in determining liability for damages. The same should be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where a vessel was trod upon by an animal but it did not break, and the vessel then rolled to another place and broke there. The liability should be determined based on the initial action that caused the damage. The Gemara rejects this proof: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is clear to Rabba, </span>who ruled as he did, but it remains <span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma to Rava. </span>One cannot prove the opinion of one <span class="it-text">amora</span> from the opinion of another.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the resolution of this dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping, </span>a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. And some say that it is forewarned.</span>
The Gemara questions the formulation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>to raise the possibility that a chicken is not forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping? </span>Hopping is the typical manner of movement for chickens. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>that the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the chicken was <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping and </span>the hopping <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>the vessel to roll to another place, and the vessel was broken there? <span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree with regard to this: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the initial </span>action that ultimately led to the damage, and since hopping is typical manner of movement for a chicken, its owner is responsible for any damage that resulted from its hopping. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds: We follow the breaking of the vessel, </span>and since there was an additional factor that broke the vessel, the owner of the chicken is not liable.
The Gemara rejects the parallel between the dispute and the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the dispute in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained differently. 

Daf 18a

The dispute concerns a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled pebbles </span>from underfoot as it was hopping, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute of Sumakhos and the Rabbis, </span>cited earlier, that the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree. </span>One <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that the owner pays the full cost of the damage for pebbles propelled by an animal in the course of its walking, and the other <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that its owner pays half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an additional attempt to resolve the dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">chickens were pecking at the rope </span>tied to <span class="gemarra-regular">a bucke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the rope was severed and the bucket </span>fell and <span class="gemarra-regular">broke, </span>the owner of the chickens <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the initial </span>action that ultimately led to the damage in determining liability for damage. The Gemara rejects this conclusion, and one cannot adduce proof from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Interpret </span>instead that the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">the rope, </span>while the owner pays only half the cost of the damage for breaking the bucket.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>eating <span class="gemarra-regular">a rope atypical </span>behavior for a chicken, and therefore it should be classified within the primary category of Goring, not the primary category of Eating? Why then must the owner of the chicken pay the full cost of the damage? The Gemara answers: The reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the rope <span class="gemarra-regular">was filthy [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’us</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with kneaded dough, </span>and in those circumstances it is typical for a chicken to peck at it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: And the <span class="gemarra-regular">bucket broke, </span>indicating that the dispute is with regard to damage done to the bucket, not to the rope? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>propelled by an animal, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If a shard was propelled from </span>the bucket broken by a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">and it fell upon another vessel and broke it, </span>the owner of the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the first </span>vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the second </span>one. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span> the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is he of </span>the opinion that one pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span> caused by pebbles?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difference, according to Sumakhos, between damage </span>resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> force </span>generated by the animal’s action, e.g., pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action, e.g., damage caused by the shard of the bucket, and in the latter case Sumakhos concedes that the owner pays half the cost of the damage, that would result in a difficulty. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what of <span class="gemarra-regular">this dilemma raised by Rav Ashi: According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, </span>what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by the animal’s action? Is the status of that secondary force <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action, in which case the owner is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is its status <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span> action?
Why did Rav Ashi state his dilemma; why did he not <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>the dilemma and conclude that according to Sumakhos its status is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action? Since Rav Ashi does not resolve the dilemma based on this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, apparently, Sumakhos does not distinguish between the two types of force.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that we follow the initial </span>action that ultimately led to the damage when determining one’s liability for the damage. Therefore, an owner is liable for any damage resulting from his animal’s typical behavior, and he pays the full cost of the damage done to the bucket even if the damage took place in another location.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: </span>There is no proof from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as it could be explained that the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bucket is <span class="gemarra-regular">continually </span>propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the impetus of the chicken, who caused the bucket to break. That is why the ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is that the owner of the chicken pays the full cost of the damage. The dilemma with regard to the case where an animal treads upon a vessel that rolls away and breaks elsewhere remains unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to one’s liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>inadvertently propelled by the foot of a walking animal, does the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of the animal, just as one pays half the cost of the damage caused by an innocuous ox with regard to damage categorized under the primary category of Goring? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>does he <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>land, as he does for other forms of damage? The Gemara elaborates: Does he <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we do not find </span>any case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>land? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he pays </span>restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we do not find </span>any case where an animal causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in its </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his animal?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping, </span>a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is forewarned. </span>The Gemara questions the formulation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>to raise the possibility that a chicken is not forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping? </span>Hopping is the typical manner of movement for chickens. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>that the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the chicken was <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping and propelled </span>pebbles that caused the damage?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that they disagree: The one who says </span>that the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned holds that </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of the animal, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when an innocuous animal gores, while <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarned holds that he pays</span> restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>land, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when a forewarned animal causes damage. According to this analysis, Rava’s dilemma is the subject of a tannaitic dispute.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps the dispute in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the Rabbis </span>with regard to the legal status of damage caused by a force generated by the animal’s action. It is with regard to the similarity of damage caused by an action performed by an animal’s body to the case where the chicken was hopping and propelled pebbles that caused the damage that the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution of this dilemma from a mishna (21b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">the dog took a loa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥarara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that was baking on hot coals <span class="gemarra-regular">and went to a stack of grain </span>to eat the loaf, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">ate the loaf and ignited the stack </span>of grain with one of the coals attached to the loaf, the owner of the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for </span>the damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">the loaf, </span>as it is classified in the primary category of Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for </span>the damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">the stack </span>of grain. Rabbi Elazar says: He pays the full cost of the damage for the damage to the stack of grain as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that the owner pays half the cost of the damage caused to the stack of grain? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is </span>analogous to propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>as the coal fell from the loaf held in its mouth and ignited the grain? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in that regard </span>that when the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> said that <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>he pays restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>proceeds of the sale of the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his animal.
