Apparently, half the cost of the damage caused by pebbles is paid from the body of the animal that caused the damage.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And can you understand </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in that way? According to that understanding, with regard to Rabbi Elazar, who disagrees with the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and holds that the owner of the dog pays the full cost of the damage caused to the grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we find </span>anywhere that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Elazar </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>proceeds of the sale of the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his animal?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">acted atypically with this coa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> with which he lit the stack of grain. Since the dog’s behavior was atypical, the damage is classified under the primary category of Goring, not under the category of Eating. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, who says </span>in a mishna (24b): The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">is atypical, </span>as there, the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>in contrast to half the cost of the damage that he pays when it transpires in the public domain. Nevertheless, since it was an innocuous animal that caused the damage, restitution is paid from its body.
The Gemara rejects that explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you interpreted </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the difficulty presented by the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>exclusively from proceeds of the sale of the body of the animal, which would not be so according to Rabbi Elazar.
The Gemara suggests: There is an alternative explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, who says </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, and </span>he also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>with regard to a forewarned ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">The aspect of innocuousness, </span>which dictates that the owner pays half the cost of the damage from the body of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">remains intact</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> According to Rabbi Yehuda, the owner of a forewarned ox pays half the cost of the damage from the body of his ox and half the cost of the damage from his superior<span class="gemarra-regular">-</span>quality land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>when the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the owner pays restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">from the body </span>of his animal, the reference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to the aspect of innocuousness, </span>i.e., half the cost of the damage. He pays the other half from his superior<span class="gemarra-regular">-</span>quality land as he would in the case of any forewarned animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Samma, son of Rav Ashi, said to Ravina: Say that you heard </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>stated that the aspect of innocuousness remains intact <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage categorized under the primary category of Goring, where the ox was initially <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became forewarned. In </span>the case of propelled pebbles, which is a subcategory of Trampling, where the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned from the outset, </span>

Daf 18b

<span class="gemarra-regular">did you hear hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> distinguish between the different parts of the payment? There is no aspect of innocuousness in the case of pebbles.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, when Rabbi Elazar says </span>that the owner of the dog pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>in a case that is similar to one of propelled pebbles, he was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was forewarned </span>with regard to this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree about this </span>point: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Elazar, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is forewarning with regard to </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles; </span>therefore, if there was testimony given in court that a particular animal regularly propels pebbles in the course of its walking, the animal is deemed forewarned and its owner pays the full cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no forewarning with regard to pebbles.</span> Apparently, payment for damage caused by pebbles is paid from the body of the animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if this is the case, then <span class="gemarra-regular">the dilemma raised by Rava </span>concerning whether there <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles or there is no forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>can be resolved from this dispute. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the dilemma is raised <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles. If </span>the dilemma is raised <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Elazar, there is forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles.</span>
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: When I raise the dilemma, </span>I do so specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis who disagree with Sumakhos </span>and hold that one pays half the cost of the damage in the case of pebbles; <span class="gemarra-regular">but here </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">both the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Elazar hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, who says that </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, one pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
And <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say </span>that one pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage </span>in the case of pebbles? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in the case of pebbles the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">acted atypically and was not forewarned. And </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, concerning the dog that lit the stack of grain, the dispute between the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Elazar is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of damage caused by an innocuous ox on the property of the injured party.
The Gemara rejects the parallel between the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and the opinion of Rabbi Tarfon. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that you heard </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Tarfon </span>the owner pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did you hear </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>Rabbi Tarfon restitution is paid only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the body </span>of the animal that caused the damage?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>Rabbi Tarfon holds that restitution is paid only from the body of the animal that caused the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where does </span>Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that when damage is caused by an innocuous ox on the property of the injured party its owner is liable to pay the full cost of the damage and not merely half? He derives it via an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>that is caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>as explained in the mishna (24b).
His ruling is based on the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source, </span>i.e., a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference cannot be more stringent than the source of that derivation. Since restitution for damage categorized as Goring that is caused in the public domain is paid only from the body of the damaging animal, the same is true with regard to restitution for damage categorized as Goring that is caused on the property of the injured party.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>it clear from that mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon does not accept </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source, as, if he accepted that principle, not only would he hold that payment is only from the body of the animal, he would also require payment of half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara answers: He does not reject the principle. <span class="gemarra-regular">When he does not accept </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source, it is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the result of rejecting the principle is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inference is refuted. </span>But in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the result of rejecting the principle is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inference is not refuted, </span>but will be applied in a more limited fashion, <span class="gemarra-regular">he accepts </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source. Therefore, in this case the payment of the full cost of the damage, which is derived by means of the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference, is paid only from the body of the animal based on the principle: It is sufficient for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source.
§ The Gemara discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>cited earlier. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: Is there forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that the owner would pay the full cost of the damage if he had been fore-warned three times, <span class="gemarra-regular">or is there no forewarning for </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>and he will always pay half the cost of the damage? The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we liken </span>the case of propelled pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring? </span>Accordingly, when an innocuous ox causes damage by propelling pebbles its owner pays half the cost of the damage, and when a forewarned ox does so the owner pays the full cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a subcategory </span>of the primary category <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling, </span>which is deemed forewarned from the outset? Accordingly, the owner would always pay half the cost of the damage, as there is no change in status after the third warning.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the resolution of this dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping, </span>a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. And some say that it is forewarned. </span>The Gemara questions the formulation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>to raise the possibility that a chicken is not forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping? </span>Hopping is the typical manner of movement for chickens. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>that the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the chicken was <span class="gemarra-regular">hopping and propelled </span>pebbles that caused damage?
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the chicken has <span class="gemarra-regular">done </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">three times? And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds: There is forewarning for </span>pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds: There is no forewarning for </span>pebbles. According to this analysis, Rava’s dilemma is the subject of a tannaitic dispute. The Gemara rejects this resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the chicken hopped only <span class="gemarra-regular">one time. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos and the Rabbis, </span>concerning the compensation for damage caused by pebbles.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the resolution to the dilemma from an amoraic dispute: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal dropped excremen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> onto doug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> and damaged it, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>The owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and Rabbi Elazar says: </span>He pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal has <span class="gemarra-regular">done </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">three times? And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, </span>as one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds: There is forewarning for </span>pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds: There is no forewarning for </span>pebbles.
The Gemara rejects this resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the animal dropped excrement only <span class="gemarra-regular">one time. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos and the Rabbis, </span>concerning compensation for damage caused by pebbles. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical </span>behavior of the animal, and since all behavior that deviates from the norm is classified within the category of Goring, the owner should be liable to pay only half the cost of the damage? The Gemara answers: The case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was force</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> into a narrow place and had no alternative to relieving itself onto the dough; therefore, it does not constitute atypical behavior.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the amoraic dispute parallels the tannaitic dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">let Rav Yehuda say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, and let Rabbi Elazar say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>instead of stating their dispute in the context of the particular case of the animal and the dough. The Gemara answers: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for them to state their dispute in this case, as there is a novel element concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">excrement. It </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say: Since </span>the excrement <span class="gemarra-regular">is drawn after </span>the body of the animal, its legal status is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">its body, </span>not like pebbles propelled by the animal. Therefore, their stating the dispute with regard to excrement <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that its status is like that of propelling pebbles. Therefore, the dispute between Rav Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar can be explained as parallel to the dispute between Sumakhos and the Rabbis with regard to pebbles.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>resolution to the dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rooster that extended its head into the airspace</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a glass vessel and crowe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">and broke it </span>with the sound waves, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And Rav Yosef said </span>that the Sages from <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a horse neighed or a donkey brayed and </span>the sound waves <span class="gemarra-regular">broke vessels, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>These are cases similar to the case of pebbles, and there is a dispute between the Sages with regard to these cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the rooster or animal has <span class="gemarra-regular">done </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">three times? </span>

Daf 19a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree:</span> One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited by Rami bar Yeḥezkel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: There is forewarning </span>for pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Yosef, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: There is no forewarning </span>for pebbles.
The Gemara rejects this resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps the reference in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to a case where the rooster or animal damaged the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">one time. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos and the Rabbis, </span>concerning compensation for damage caused by pebbles. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">atypical</span> behavior for an animal to insert its head into a glass vessel, and isn’t all atypical behavior classified within the category of Goring, meaning that the owner should be liable to pay only half the cost of the damage? The Gemara answers: The case is one where <span class="gemarra-regular">there were seeds in </span>the vessel, and therefore the rooster extending its head into the vessel is considered typical behavior.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: Is there </span>any halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>and therefore if an animal propelled pebbles in an atypical manner its owner is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of the damage, </span>i.e., half the restitution for damage caused by pebbles? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, is there no </span>halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>propelling <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles, </span>resulting in its owner being liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of the damage,</span> and therefore, even in an atypical case, the owner pays the standard restitution of half the cost of the damage?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Resolve </span>Rav Ashi’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from Rava’s </span>dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava raises a dilemma: Is there forewarning for pebbles, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or is there no forewarning for pebbles? </span>Based on that dilemma, one may conclude <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that there is no </span>halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior with regard to pebbles propelled by an animal, resulting in its owner being liable to pay only one-quarter of the damage, as, were that the case, forewarning would lead to an animal owner’s liability to pay half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rava stated </span>his dilemma employing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say. If you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior with regard to propelling pebbles, resulting in its owner being liable to pay only one-quarter of the damage, and the owner pays half the cost of the damage in every case, <span class="gemarra-regular">is there forewarning for </span>pebbles, meaning that after three incidents the owner pays the full cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">or is there no forewarning for </span>pebbles? According to that understanding, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to Rav Ashi’s dilemma cannot be inferred from Rava’s dilemma. Rav Ashi’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma </span>with regard to pebbles: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, </span>that one pays the full cost of the damage in the case of propelled pebbles, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by the animal’s action? Is the status of that secondary force <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action, in which case the owner is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is its status <span class="gemarra-regular">not like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action?
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did </span>Sumakhos <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one pays half the cost of the damage caused by pebbles as <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition </span>transmitted to Moses at Sinai, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he interprets </span>that tradition as applying in a case where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force</span> generated by the action of an animal? By contrast, in a typical case of damage caused by pebbles, which is an example of a force generated by the action of an animal, the owner pays the full cost of the damage, as it is a subcategory of Trampling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he did not learn </span>any <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition </span>in this regard <span class="gemarra-regular">at all, </span>and therefore even in a case where the damage was caused by a force generated by a force generated by the action of an animal, the owner pays the full cost of the damage, as it is a subcategory of Trampling. The Gemara concludes: This dilemma, too, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking </span>while it was walking, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">that pebbles were </span>inadvertently <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled from under its feet and </span>those pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">broke vessels, </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaking?</span>
The Gemara elaborates: Is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> saying that if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking and caused damage </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">with its kick, </span>which is a subcategory of Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the animal was walking and propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles in its typical manner, </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and, </span>accordingly, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis, </span>who hold that one pays half the cost of damage caused by pebbles? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> is saying: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking and caused damage </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">with its kick, or </span>if the animal propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles due to its kick </span>and the pebbles caused damage, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>Accordingly, one may infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the animal propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles </span>as it was walking <span class="gemarra-regular">in its typical manner, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and </span>if so, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of the mishna: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">trod upon a vessel and broke it and </span>then a shard of that vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">fell upon </span>a second <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel and broke it, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the first </span>vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the latter </span>vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, does he hold </span>that one pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused by pebbles?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Sumakhos, and can be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span>vessel, concerning which the owner of the animal pays the full cost of the damage, is <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>vessel damaged following the <span class="gemarra-regular">propellin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> of shards from the vessel upon which the animal trod, i.e., the second vessel that was broken. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the second </span>vessel, concerning which the owner of the animal pays half the cost of the damage, is <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>vessel following the <span class="gemarra-regular">propelling </span>of shards from the vessel upon which the animal trod, i.e., the third vessel that was broken by shards from the second vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason for the difference in liability is that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a difference, according to Sumakhos, between </span>damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by the action of an animal, for which the owner pays the full cost of the damage, and damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action, for which he pays for only half the cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if one were to say this explanation, what can be said of <span class="gemarra-regular">that dilemma which Rav Ashi raised: According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos, </span>that one pays the full cost of the damage in the case of propelled pebbles, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by the animal’s action? Is the status of that secondary force <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action, in which case the owner is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is its status <span class="gemarra-regular">not like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action? Why does he have a dilemma? Let him <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>from here <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>its status is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like </span>that of damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a force </span>generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action.
The Gemara answers: Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi interprets </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>that one pays half the cost of the damage in the case of propelled pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">raises this dilemma: </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking and caused damage </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">with its kick, </span>which is a subcategory of Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the animal was walking and propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles in its typical manner, </span>the owner of the animal pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>Accordingly, one may infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the pebbles were propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a kick, </span>the owner pays <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of the damage. And there is </span>halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior with regard to a case of pebbles, resulting in its owner being liable to pay only one-quarter of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> is saying: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was kicking and caused damage </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">with its kick or </span>if the animal propelled <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles due to its kic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> and the pebbles caused damage, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. And there is no </span>halakhic significance to <span class="gemarra-regular">deviation </span>from typical behavior with regard to a case of pebbles. The Gemara concludes: Rav Ashi’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami, and some say </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was walking in a place where it is impossible for it </span>to walk <span class="gemarra-regular">without propelling </span>pebbles as it proceeds, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it kicked and propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">and caused damage, what is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara elaborates: Does one say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is impossible for it</span> to walk without propelling pebbles, propelling pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">is its typical manner </span>in that situation and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case would be the same as any case of pebbles? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">now, in any event, the pebbles were propelled due to a kick</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is different. The Gemara concludes: Rabbi Abba bar Memel’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira: </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was walking in the public domain and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">kicked and propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">and caused damage, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we liken </span>the damage in this instance <span class="gemarra-regular">to Goring, </span>since the action was performed with intent, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>even though the incident transpired in the public domain? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>since this is a case of pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a subcategory of Trampling and </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability in the public domain. Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It stands to reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a subcategory of Trampling.</span>
Rabbi Yirmeya continued and asked Rabbi Zeira another question: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and caused damage on private property, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him, </span>employing terminology from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Shabbat: If <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is there </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">placing here? </span>Since the animal propelled the pebbles in the public domain, the owner is exempt from liability for any damage that it causes. The fact that the damage occurred on private property is not relevant.
Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rabbi Zeira’s first statement, that one is exempt from liability for one’s animal propelling pebbles in the public domain because it is classified as a subcategory of Trampling, from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was walking along the way and it propelled </span>pebbles, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay damages. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>a case where the pebbles were <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled in the public domain and caused damage in the public domain? </span>Rabbi Zeira replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the reference is to a case where the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>the pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and caused damage on private property. </span>Rabbi Yirmeya asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t you say:</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting here, is there </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">placing here? </span>Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I retrac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> my previous statement, as there is proof from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that there is liability in that case.
Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rabbi Zeira’s first statement from the mishna: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">trod upon a vessel and broke it and </span>then a shard of that vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">fell upon </span>a second <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel and broke it, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the first </span>vessel, as its action is classified under the primary category of Trampling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the latter </span>vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said in a case where the incident transpired <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>private <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the injured </span>party; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it transpired <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>the owner of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for the first </span>vessel, as it is classified as a subcategory of Trampling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>the damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not</span> that the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>the pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and it caused damage in the public domain, </span>indicating that one does not pay for damage caused by pebbles in the public domain?
Rabbi Zeira replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps the reference in the mishna is to a case where the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>the pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and it caused damage on private property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Yirmeya said: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t you say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting here, is there </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">placing here? </span>Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I retract </span>my previous statement.
Rabbi Yirmeya raises an additional objection to Rabbi Zeira’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? </span>Is the owner of the animal exempt from liability for pebbles propelled by his animal in the public domain? 

Daf 19b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: </span>Payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is not differentiated </span>between private and public domains, as there is no exemption from payment <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>for damage <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property nor </span>for damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain? What, is </span>this principle <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated even in a case where the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and caused damage in the public domain? </span>Rabbi Zeira said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan stated this principle in a case where the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">propelled </span>pebbles <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and caused damage on private property.</span>
Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t you say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting here, is there </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">placing here? </span>Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I retract </span>my previous statement. Or, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>that payment of half the cost of the damage is not differentiated between private and public domains, and there is no exemption from payment neither for damage on private property nor for damage in the public domain, he said it only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>but not with regard to the case of propelled pebbles, for which one is exempt in the public domain.
§ The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda Nesi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Oshay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sat in the antechamber [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aki</span><span class="gemarra-italic">l’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Yehuda </span>Nesia. <span class="gemarra-regular">A matter emerged from among them </span>and one of them raised a dilemma: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">swung its tail </span>and thereby caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">The other </span>Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Must </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">grasp its tail and walk </span>to prevent the animal from causing damage? Since this is typical behavior for the animal, the owner should be exempt from liability. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, with regard to </span>damage in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, too, let us say: Must </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">grasp its horn and walk </span>to prevent the animal from causing damage? Nevertheless, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the owner is liable for damage in the category of Goring.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span>Damage in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring is not </span>caused in the course of the <span class="gemarra-regular">typical </span>behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the animal. Consequently, the owner is required to prevent his animal from causing damage in that manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>damage caused by the swinging of an animal’s tail is caused in the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its typical </span>behavior, and therefore the owner is required to prevent his animal from causing damage in that manner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And since that is its typical behavior, what is the dilemma </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he raised? </span>Obviously one has no liability for the damage caused by the typical behavior of his animal in the public domain. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He raised a dilemma </span>with regard to a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">excessive </span>tail <span class="gemarra-regular">swinging</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> is excessive tail swinging considered typical behavior?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Eina raises a dilemma: </span>If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">swung its peni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say just as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to Goring: Is it not </span>so in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>that the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">inclination overcame it </span>and caused it to gore? <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, it is no different: </span>The animal’s inclination overcame it and that is why it caused damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the cases are different, as in the case of damage in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">objective </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action <span class="gemarra-regular">is to cause damage, </span>whereas in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case the <span class="gemarra-regular">objective </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>action <span class="gemarra-regular">is not to cause damage. </span>The Gemara concludes: This dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Chickens are </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to walking in their </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner and breaking </span>objects. If there was a string tied to a chicken’s leg and it broke a vessel, or if the chicken was hopping in an atypical manner and breaking vessels, its owner pays half the cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: They taught </span>that one pays half the cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the string <span class="gemarra-regular">was tied </span>to the leg of the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a string became entangled on the leg of a chicken without the involvement of the owner and an item was broken by the string; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if a person tied </span>the string to the chicken, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of the damage, as the string is in the category of Pit.
The Gemara asks: If the string <span class="gemarra-regular">was tied on its own, who is liable </span>to pay half the cost of the damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the string </span>who pays, as the damage was caused by the string, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances? If </span>it is a case where the owner of the string <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed </span>the string in a secure place and the chicken became entangled in it, the owner of the string <span class="gemarra-regular">is a victim of circumstances beyond his control </span>and would be exempt from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he did not conceal it </span>and instead left it exposed where it could become entangled in the feet of a passing chicken, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is negligent </span>and liable as though he actually tied the string to the chicken.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case in the mishna is one where the owner of the string concealed it and is exempt from liability, and Rav Huna means that the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the chicken </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Here too, the question arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in this case where one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>obligated to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, as it is written </span>(Exodus 21:33): <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man shall open a pit, </span>or if a man shall dig a pit and not cover it, and an ox or a donkey fall therein,” he pays the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> written: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>shall open <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit. </span>This indicates that if an ox opens a pit, the owner of the ox is exempt from liability. With regard to the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage as well, </span>the owner should be exempt from liability, as it is written: “If <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span>shall open <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit,” and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>written: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>shall open <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>is one where the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">moved </span>the string and thereby caused damage. Since the chicken did not cause damage with its body, the owner pays half the cost of the damage, as he does in a case of pebbles. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when Rav Huna’s </span>distinction between whether the string was tied on its own or by a person <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, it was stated in a general </span>sense, and not with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ownerless string </span>tied to the leg of a chicken, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>If the string <span class="gemarra-regular">was tied </span>to the leg of the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own, </span>the owner of the chicken is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt; but if a person tied </span>the string to the chicken, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to what </span>primary category of damage is he <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna bar Manoaḥ says: </span>He is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that although the string is not stationary, as in the standard obstacle in the primary category of Pit, this is an example of <span class="gemarra-regular">his pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is rolle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the feet of a person and at the hooves of an animal, </span>and that too is a subcategory of Pit.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Within the context of the primary category of Eating, for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>damage caused with <span class="gemarra-regular">the tooth </span>is an animal deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned? </span>It is deemed forewarned with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to eating </span>food items <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for its </span>consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">The domesticated animal is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to eating fruits and vegetables. </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span><span class="gemarra-regular">garment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or vessels, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>As these are not items fit for its consumption, the animal is not deemed forewarned in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span>applied, that one pays the full value of the food eaten by the animal? It is a case where the animal ate the food <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the animal ate food <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>the owner of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even if the animal ate food in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derives benefit </span>from eating another’s produce in the public domain, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that it derives</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> just not for the full cost of the food.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Under what </span>circumstances does the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that it derives? </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the public <span class="gemarra-regular">square </span>in the area before the storefronts, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that it derives.</span> If the animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>food placed at <span class="gemarra-regular">the side of </span>the public <span class="gemarra-regular">square, </span>which is not a public thoroughfare, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged, </span>as the legal status of that area is like that of the property of the injured party. If the animal ate produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from the entrance of the store, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that it derives, </span>as the status of a store entrance is like that of the public domain. If the animal ate produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from inside the store,</span> its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: Eating is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in that an animal tends <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat that which is fit for it </span>to eat. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is this applied? In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a domesticated animal that entered the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and it ate food fit for it </span>to eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">or if it drank drinks fit for it </span>to drink, the owner of the animal must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And similarly, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal that entered the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and tore apart a domesticated animal and ate </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>there, the owner must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
And in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow that ate barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> although this is not normally a food that a cow would eat, or in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey that ate vetches, </span>i.e., legumes which are usually fed to cows but not to donkeys, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dog that licked oil or a pig ate meat, </span>the owner of the animal must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Although these animals do not ordinarily consume these items, doing so is not a significant deviation from the animal’s typical behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Now that you said </span>that eating <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not typical for </span>an animal to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it eats it under duress </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">considered </span>an ordinary act of <span class="gemarra-regular">eating, </span>it can be deduced that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cat that eats date</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a donkey that is eating fish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>despite the fact that these animals do not ordinarily eat these items.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain donkey that ate bread and </span>while eating it also <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in which the bread was stored. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda obligated </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for </span>the loss of <span class="gemarra-regular">the bread and half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage to the basket. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why? Since it is typical for </span>a donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat bread, it is also typical </span>for it <span class="gemarra-regular">to break the baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in which the bread is stored; therefore, the owner should pay the full cost of the damage for the basket as well. The Gemara answers: This case is one where the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">and then </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">broke </span>the basket, a sequence which demonstrates that its intent was to cause damage. The breaking of the basket is therefore a subcategory of Goring, and the owner is liable to pay only half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is it typical for </span>a donkey to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">bread? </span>The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>against this based on a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">it ate bread or meat or a cooked dish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay for half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. What, is it not referring to a domesticated animal </span>and thereby implying that it is not typical for a domesticated animal to eat bread? The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal, </span>which does not typically eat bread, but a domesticated animal does eat bread.
The Gemara questions this explanation: If the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal, </span>then it is <span class="gemarra-regular">typical for it </span>to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">meat. </span>The Gemara clarifies: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">meat that is roasted, </span>and it is not typical for an undomesticated animal to eat roasted meat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, if you wish, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not stated with regard to an undomesticated predator, but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a deer, </span>which does not ordinarily eat meat and bread. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, if you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>it is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">a domesticated animal, </span>but it is discussing a case where the animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">at the table, </span>and this is not typical behavior for an animal. 

Daf 20a

The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain goat that saw a turnip on top of a clay barrel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dedanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It climbed </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">went up </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">ate the turnip, and </span>in doing so it <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the barrel. Rava obligated </span>the owner of the goat to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">for the turnip and for the barrel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that he held the owner fully liable for the clay barrel as well as for the turnip? After all, breaking barrels is not the typical behavior of a goat. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it is typical </span>for the goat <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">turnip, it is also typical </span>for it <span class="gemarra-regular">to clim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">b</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and go up</span> in order to get it. Consequently, breaking the vessel is categorized as Eating.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Ilfa says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a domesticated animal </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, and it stretched out its neck and ate from </span>a sack of produce that was loaded on <span class="gemarra-regular">the back of another </span>animal, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of the damage. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The back of the other </span>animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">considered like the courtyard of the injured </span>party, and for this reason the owner of the animal is liable for damage classified as Eating there.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">supports his </span>opinion (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 1:7): If a person was standing in the public domain, and <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> basket </span>containing food <span class="gemarra-regular">was slung behind his back, and </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">stretched out its neck and ate from it, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara rejects this: This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not support Ilfa’s opinion, because one could explain that the case in that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava says </span>in a different situation: The ruling is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a jumping </span>animal; <span class="gemarra-regular">here also </span>it can be suggested that the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a jumping </span>animal, and since the animal engaged in atypical behavior it is classified as a case of Goring as opposed to a case of Eating. For damage classified as Goring, the owner of the animal is liable for his animal’s actions in the public domain, although he pays only half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And where, </span>i.e., in what context, <span class="gemarra-regular">was Rava’s </span>interpretation initially <span class="gemarra-regular">stated? </span>The Gemara answers: It was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to that which Rabbi Oshaya says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a domesticated animal </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking along and eating in the public domain </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>but if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">standing and eating </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara questions this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">was walking? </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>eating while walking <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">typical </span>behavior of an animal? But <span class="gemarra-regular">standing </span>and eating <span class="gemarra-regular">is also </span><span class="gemarra-regular">typical </span>behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>Rabbi Oshaya’s ruling is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a jumping </span>animal, which is not typical behavior for the animal.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma: </span>If an animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">rolling, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case about which Rabbi Zeira inquires? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheaf </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it was rolled along </span>by the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the sheaf <span class="gemarra-regular">went from the private property into the public domain, </span>and the animal ate it there, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Should this be treated as a case of Eating on private property, rendering the owner of the animal liable, or should it be treated as a case of Eating in the public domain, thereby exempting him from liability?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a load </span>of food was located <span class="gemarra-regular">partly inside </span>the property of its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and partly outside </span>of his property, i.e., in the public domain, and an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate inside </span>the private property, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as this is a case of damage classified as Eating on the property of the injured party. But if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate outside, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Eating in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that the case is one where the food was <span class="gemarra-regular">rolling along, </span>and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> follows the location where it was actually eaten? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">It ate, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">for that which was </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span>the private property, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if the food rolled out of the private property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for that which was </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">outside, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead that there is a different resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Ḥiyya stated</span> his ruling it was with regard to a long <span class="gemarra-regular">stalk of fodder [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">de’a</span><span class="gemarra-italic">spasta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that was partly inside and partly outside at the time it was consumed, and as the animal ate it the entire stalk was pulled to where the animal was standing.
§ The mishna teaches: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate garments </span>or vessels, the owner must pay for half the cost of the damage. In what case is this statement said? It is said when the animal ate them while located on the property of the injured party, but if he ate them in the public domain the owner of the animal is exempt from liability.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">To which</span> case is this referring? In which case is one exempt from liability if the damage occurred in the public domain? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the cases. One is exempt from liability in the public domain even if his animal ate garments or vessels, despite the fact that this is an unusual thing for the animal to do and therefore eating garments or vessels should be classified as a case of Goring, which would normally result in liability when it occurs in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Rav answers his own question by stating a principle: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who deviate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from normative behavior in his actions, <span class="gemarra-regular">if another came along </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">and deviates </span>from the norm <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the action the first has done and thereby causes damage to him, the one who causes the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from liability. In this case, the injured party left his garments or vessels in the public domain and thereby deviated from normative behavior, and therefore the owner of the animal that acted atypically and ate them is exempt from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: They taught </span>in the mishna that one is exempt from liability for damage caused in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where his animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit or vegetables, </span>in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Eating in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">garment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or vessels </span>in the public domain, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay for half the cost of the damage. Since this is atypical animal behavior, it is classified as a case of Goring, for which the owner of the animal is liable even if it occurs in the public domain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, Reish Lakish said, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Rav: The exemption discussed in the mishna was said in reference <span class="gemarra-regular">to all of </span>the cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish follows his </span>own line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Reish Lakish says: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two cows in the public domain, one prone and one walking, </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>cow <span class="gemarra-regular">kicked the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prone </span>cow, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability; but if the <span class="gemarra-regular">prone </span>cow kicked <span class="gemarra-regular">the walking </span>cow, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>This indicates that Reish Lakish accepts the principle: Anyone who deviates from normative behavior, if another came along afterward and deviates from the norm with regard to the action the first has done and thereby causes damage to him, the one who causes the damage is exempt. Since it is atypical behavior for a cow to lie down in the public domain, even if the walking cow also behaved atypically and kicked the prone cow, its owner is exempt from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel: <span class="gemarra-regular">They taught</span> in the mishna that one is exempt from liability in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if his animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit or vegetables, but </span>if the animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">garments or vessels, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for half the cost of the damage.
