The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan does not accept Reish Lakish’s opinion even in </span>the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">two cows? </span>The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, actually </span>it is possible that Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>the opinion of Reish Lakish, but he distinguishes between the cases. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">garments, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">people to put their cloaks down </span>in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to rest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">umitpeḥi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and this is not considered atypical behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is not common </span>for an <span class="gemarra-regular">animal </span>to lie down in the public domain, and since this animal behaved in an atypical manner, no liability is borne by the owner of the walking cow for engaging in atypical behavior and kicking the prone cow.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derives benefit </span>from eating another’s produce in the public domain, although the owner is exempt from paying for the damage it caused, nevertheless the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for the benefit that it derives. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>is this payment, i.e., how is it calculated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of, </span>i.e., the amount one would pay, for an equal quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks </span>of hay or straw. This is because the owner can claim that had his animal not eaten the produce, he would have fed it inexpensive straw, so the animal’s benefit is limited to the cost of the straw that it would have eaten. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If the animal ate barley, his owner must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the barley, </span>i.e., as that is typical animal food, but <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cheapest </span>price available in the market.
The Gemara notes: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba </span>and it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava. </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba: Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai said: </span>The animal’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only the value of stalks </span>of straw.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 1:7): <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived benefit </span>from eating another’s produce, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that it derived</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> How so? </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should pay their value. Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">estimates how much a person would pay in order to feed his animal </span>typical food <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for it </span>to eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>this particular animal <span class="gemarra-regular">does not usually </span>eat that food, as its owner gives it cheaper food. Therefore, if the animal ate barley, which is typical animal fare, even though it does not usually do so, its owner must pay compensation for the barley that was eaten, at its cheapest market price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate wheat or </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">item that is detrimental to </span>it, so that it did not derive any benefit, if this occurred in the public domain the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from all liability.
§ In connection to the principle stated in the mishna, that if the animal derives benefit the owner of the animal pays for the benefit that it derived, the Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said to Rami bar Ḥama: You were not with us at night within </span>our <span class="gemarra-regular">boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when we raised dilemmas </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">exceptional matters. </span>Rami bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>are the <span class="gemarra-regular">exceptional matters</span> you discussed? Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge </span>or permission, <span class="gemarra-regular">must he pay him ren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for living there <span class="gemarra-regular">or does he not need to </span>pay him rent?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this question? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the case concerns <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard that does not stand to be rented out, </span>i.e., if the squatter would not have lived there the owner would have kept it vacant, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the man </span>squatting there is someone who would <span class="gemarra-regular">not have rented </span>other living quarters because he has other lodgings available to him for free, then it is a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the squatter, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not derive benefit, and that </span>one, the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not suffer a loss</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> in that case certainly no payment is necessary. Rather, say that the discussion concerns a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard that stands to be rented out, and the man </span>squatting there would <span class="gemarra-regular">have rented </span>other living quarters. If so, then this is a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">derives benefit and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">suffers a loss, </span>and in that case he certainly must make payment. The dilemma was not with regard to either of these circumstances.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> to raise the dilemma in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard that does not stand to be rented out, but the man </span>squatting there <span class="gemarra-regular">would have rented </span>other living quarters had he not squatted in this property. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? Is the squatter legally <span class="gemarra-regular">able to say to </span>the owner of the courtyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">What loss have I caused you, </span>as you would not have rented it out anyway? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the owner of the courtyard is legally <span class="gemarra-regular">able to say </span>to the squatter: 

Daf 20b

<span class="gemarra-regular">You have derived benefit </span>from my property, as by living there you saved the money you otherwise would have had to pay in order to rent out a different courtyard, and therefore you must pay me for the benefit you derived.
Rami bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This dilemma is not new; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>discussed in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, </span>and the mishna already provided a solution. Rav Ḥisda asked him: To <span class="gemarra-regular">which mishna </span>are you referring? Rami bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: After you serve me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> I will tell you. Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>hold of Rami bar Ḥama’s <span class="gemarra-regular">scarf [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">suderei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and wrapped </span>it around <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>in the manner it is usually worn. Rami bar Ḥama then <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This is the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derives benefit, </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived. </span>This demonstrates that one who derives benefit must pay for the benefit he derives, even if the injured party is not entitled to payment for his loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: How </span>little does <span class="gemarra-regular">a man who has the assistance of his Lord have to worry or be concerned </span>about the possibility that his opinion may not be accepted, <span class="gemarra-regular">as even though </span>the dilemma that was raised is in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">not similar to </span>the case in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>quoted by Rami bar Ḥama, Rav Ḥisda nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted it from him. This </span>case in the mishna, about the animal eating produce in the public domain, is where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one suffers a loss, and that </span>case of the squatter living in the courtyard, is where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama </span>think? Why does he equate the two cases? The Gemara explains: He holds that if <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>is left <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain without specification </span>with regard to its ownership, it is assumed that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has rendered it ownerless. </span>The owner does not expect to derive benefit from the produce, and therefore when the animal ate it he suffered no loss. Consequently, it is a case where this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, and it is comparable to the case of the squatter in the courtyard.
The Gemara attempts to cite conclusive evidence from another case: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned</span> in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 4b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s </span>fields <span class="gemarra-regular">surround </span>the fields of <span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on three sides, and he fenced in the first, the second, and the third </span>field, thereby providing protection also to the other man’s field, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>the owner of the inner field to share in the costs of the fence, as he can claim that he does not derive benefit from it, since his field remains exposed on the fourth side. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this indicates that if his fields surrounded the inner field on all four sides, and the owner of the outer fields fenced the field on the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth </span>side as well, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does obligate </span>the owner of the inner field to share in the expenses.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, </span>the one who derives benefit is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay for that benefit. In this case, the owner of the inner field benefits from the fence while the owner of the outer field does not suffer a loss, because in any event he would have needed to build those fences, and the owner of the inner field is obligated to share in the expense. The Gemara rejects this: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there </span>because the owner of the outer field <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the inner field: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">caused me to have to </span>build the fence with <span class="gemarra-regular">a larger circumference </span>than I would have otherwise needed to had your field not been there, and therefore your field caused me an additional expense. This case is therefore similar to those where this one derives benefit and that one suffers a loss.
The Gemara attempts another resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the continuation of that mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: If </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the surrounded, </span>i.e., inner, field <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and enclosed the fourth </span>side on his own, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon him </span>the obligation to pay his share of <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of it, as through his actions he demonstrated that he was interested in having the fence installed. The Gemara infers from this: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>the court imposes upon him the obligation to pay his share of all of it is because the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the surrounded </span>field arose and <span class="gemarra-regular">enclosed</span> the fourth side himself. By inference, had the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the surrounding </span>field built the fourth fence, the owner of the inner field would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, </span>the one who derives benefit is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara rejects this: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there </span>because the owner of the inner field <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the surrounding fields: <span class="gemarra-regular">For me, the protection </span>of a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">worth a dinar would have been sufficient; </span>I did not wish to pay for such an expensive fence.
The Gemara attempts another resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 117a): If <span class="gemarra-regular">a house and its upper story, </span>which belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to two </span>separate people, <span class="gemarra-regular">collapsed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> necessitating that the entire structure be rebuilt, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the upper story told the owner of the </span>lower story of the <span class="gemarra-regular">house to build </span>the lower story again so that he could rebuild the upper story, but the owner of the lower story <span class="gemarra-regular">does not want to </span>do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the upper story may build </span>the lower story of the <span class="gemarra-regular">house and live in it until </span>the owner of the lower story <span class="gemarra-regular">will pay him for his expenses,</span> and only then will he be required to vacate the lower story of the house and build the upper story.
The Gemara infers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">his expenses that the owner of the </span>lower story of the <span class="gemarra-regular">house is obligated to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">him, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>subtract from the amount compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for rent </span>for the time that the owner of the upper story lived in the lower story of the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, </span>the one who derives benefit is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as the owner of the upper story derived benefit from living in the lower story, while the owner of the lower story did not suffer a loss, since he said he did not need it. The Gemara rejects this proof: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there because the </span>lower story of the <span class="gemarra-regular">house is subjugated to the upper story, </span>because it also serves as the foundation of the upper story, and therefore the owner of the lower story of the house is obligated to provide lodging to the owner of the upper story in the interim.
The Gemara attempts another resolution. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a proof from the continuation of the mishna, in which Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and holds that the owner of the upper story may not reside in the lower story of the house without payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>A proof that the owner of the upper story must pay rent is from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">even this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must pay him rent. Conclude from </span>the mishna that when <span class="gemarra-regular">this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, </span>the one who derives benefit is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay. The Gemara rejects this: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, </span>as there it is possible to claim that the owner of the lower story suffers a loss <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the blackening of the walls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as when a person lives in a home, the value of the house depreciates due to the use.
This dilemma was not successfully resolved so <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent it </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">academy of Rabbi Ami </span>to ask his opinion. Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">said: And what did </span>this squatter <span class="gemarra-regular">do to</span> the owner? <span class="gemarra-regular">What loss did he cause him? How did he damage him? </span>Rav Ami holds that if this one derives benefit and that one does not suffer a loss, no payment is necessary. When asked about this dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Let us consider the matter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> After waiting and not receiving a response <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent </span>the question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba again. He said: They keep sending me this </span>dilemma; <span class="gemarra-regular">had I found a response </span>to their question, <span class="gemarra-regular">would I not have sent them </span>a reply? They should have realized that Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba did not have an answer for them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> discussed this matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He need not pay him rent, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He must pay him rent.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: This </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abbahu, </span>citing Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">was not stated explicitly; rather, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated from an inference </span>that Rabbi Abbahu drew from something that Rabbi Yoḥanan said in a different context. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Me’ila</span> 5:4): If the treasurer of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">a ston</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>a cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>that had been <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, he has not </span>violated the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property. This is because his act of taking the stone or the beam has not effectively removed it from within the jurisdiction of Temple property, as any item under his control is in the possession of the Temple treasury.
If the treasurer <span class="gemarra-regular">gave it to another </span>as a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>has then <span class="gemarra-regular">misused </span>consecrated property, as he removed it from the possession of the Temple and conveyed it into the possession of another. But <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>man, who received the item, has <span class="gemarra-regular">not misused </span>a consecrated item until he actually uses the item. If the treasurer himself <span class="gemarra-regular">built it into his house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has not </span>violated the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">until he has lived beneath it </span>for an amount of time <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: And this </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> provided <span class="gemarra-regular">that he placed it over the skylight, </span>as were he to have built it into the actual structure of the house, he would have violated the prohibition of misuse with the very act of construction, as by doing so he effects a change in the stone itself. By contrast, when he places the stone in a place from which it is easy to remove it and give it back, then as long as he has not lived beneath it, he has not, as yet, misused consecrated property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Abbahu sat before Rabbi Yoḥanan and </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">saying in the name of Shmuel: That is to say, one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge must pay him rent,</span> similar to the treasurer who resides beneath the consecrated beam without detracting from the value of the beam in any way but has nevertheless violated the prohibition of misuse since he has derived personal benefit from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">remained silent </span>and offered <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>no reply.
Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he was silent, </span>this must mean <span class="gemarra-regular">he concedes to his </span>conclusion, and therefore, from then on he would cite this opinion in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not so. </span>The reason Rabbi Yoḥanan was silent was because <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not pay attention </span>to Rabbi Abbahu and did not bother to contradict his opinion on the issue. In truth Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion is as was reported in his name by Rav Kahana, that a squatter living on someone else’s premises without his permission and without causing him any loss does not need to pay the owner any rent.
The Gemara explains the distinction between that case and the case of the consecrated stone or beam. The reason the treasurer of consecrated property is considered to have misused consecrated property by deriving benefit from it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba, as Rabba says: Consecrated </span>property from which one derived benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>the Temple treasury’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge</span>

Daf 21a

is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to an action involving non-sacred property belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary person, </span>which was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge </span>and against his wishes. This is because consecrated property belongs to the Almighty, and it is therefore meaningless to speak of a situation where the owner is unaware of what is being done. Consequently, anyone who derives benefit from consecrated property is in violation of the prohibition of misuse, but it cannot be inferred from this that one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge must pay him rent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Zavda sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to Mari bar Mar </span>saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Raise </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna: </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge need to pay him rent or not? In the meantime, </span>before he was able to respond to the question, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna died.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, son of Rav Huna, said to him </span>in response to the question that was asked of his father: <span class="gemarra-regular">So did my father, my Master, say in the name of Rav: He does not need to pay him rent. And </span>he also stated another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who rents a house from Reuve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must pay rent to Shimon. </span>The Gemara is puzzled: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon? What does he </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">do</span> with this? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what he is <span class="gemarra-regular">saying, </span>i.e., what he means: If it <span class="gemarra-regular">is discovered that the house </span>he rented did not actually belong to Reuven but rather it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon’s, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay rent to </span>Shimon.
The Gemara questions this statement: Did Rav Huna state <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>contradictory <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>? On the one hand he says that one who resides in a courtyard without the owner’s knowledge does not need to pay rent, but on the other hand he says that if it is discovered that the true owner of a rented house was someone else, and therefore the tenant was living in another’s courtyard without the owner’s knowledge, he is obligated to pay him rent. The Gemara resolves the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>second <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, which stated that he is obligated to pay rent, is referring to a courtyard that <span class="gemarra-regular">stands to be rented out, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, which stated that he is not obligated to pay rent, is referring to a courtyard that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not stand to be rented out.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was also stated: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says, and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: One who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge does not need to pay him rent, and one who rents a house from the residents of the city must pay rent to the owners. </span>The Gemara is puzzled: <span class="gemarra-regular">Owners? What do they </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>with this? The case concerns one who rents a property from the residents of the city, i.e., the house is public property. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">discovered that</span> the house <span class="gemarra-regular">did have owners </span>and was not public property, the renters <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay rent to </span>those owners.
The Gemara wonders about this: Did he state <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>contradictory <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>second <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, which stated that he is obligated to pay rent, is referring to a courtyard that <span class="gemarra-regular">stands to be rented out, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, which stated that he does not need to pay rent, is referring to a courtyard that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not stand to be rented out.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Seḥora says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge does not need to pay him rent because it is stated: </span>“Desolation remains in the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the gate is stricken unto ruin” </span>(Isaiah 24:12), i.e., a house that is not lived in will collapse at some point due to neglect. Consequently, one who lives inside an otherwise uninhabited house is providing a service to the homeowner, as he maintains the house and prevents it from falling apart. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi said: I saw this </span>ruin <span class="gemarra-regular">and it gores like an ox, </span>i.e., it is devastating. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef stated </span>a similar idea: <span class="gemarra-regular">A home that is lived in is settled </span>and safeguarded, while a home that is not lived in has no one to look after it and maintain it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>what Rav said and what Rav Yosef said? The Gemara answers: The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them</span> is with regard to a house that the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">uses </span>to store <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and straw. </span>The house is not empty and desolate but there is nobody living in it. According to Rav Yosef’s reasoning, a squatter there would not have to pay rent to the homeowner.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who built a mansion [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apadna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a garbage heap [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akilkalta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belonging to orphans, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman confiscated his mansion from him </span>as he did not pay the owners of the property. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge must pay him rent? </span>The Gemara rejects this: No, there is no proof taken from this case, because it was a unique situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">In that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">Carmanians</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> nomadic tribes, <span class="gemarra-regular">were initially living on </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they would pay the orphans a small amoun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for the use of the land, and when this man built his mansion he removed the Carmanians from there. Rav Naḥman had <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the man who built the mansion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go and appeas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the orphans </span>with regard to their lost income, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not pay attention</span> to the ruling. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman confiscated his mansion from him.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: Under <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> circumstances does the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> benefit that </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived? </span>If the animal ate produce in the public square in the area before the storefronts, the owner of the animal pays for the food from which it benefits. If the animal ate from food placed at the side of the public square, which is not a public thoroughfare, the owner of the animal pays for what it damaged, as the legal status of that area is like that of the property of the injured party. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>When the mishna says that the owner of the animal pays for what it damaged, it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head to reach the food but the animal itself is standing completely inside the public domain and it eats while standing there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: Even if</span> it is standing in the public domain and it <span class="gemarra-regular">turns</span> its head to eat from food placed at the side of the public square, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">also exempt, </span>as the animal itself is in the public domain.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, how can you find </span>a case in which the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for all of the damage caused when his animal ate from food placed at the side of the public square, as indicated by the mishna? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>when an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square and goes and stands at the side of the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and eats the food stored there. In that case its owner certainly pays for what it damaged, as this area is comparable to the property of the injured party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are those who teach this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> as <span class="gemarra-regular">an independent </span>dispute and not as an explanation of the mishna: If an animal is standing in the public domain and <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head to eat from food placed at the side of the public square, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>Its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and Shmuel says: </span>Its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Sages asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, </span>with regard to that which was said in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna, that its owner pays for what it damaged, how can you find a case in which its owner will be liable? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>when an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square and goes and stands at the side of the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square, </span>and eats the food stored there.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak raises an objection </span>to this explanation of Shmuel’s opinion: The mishna says that if the animal ate produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from the entrance of the store, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived, </span>as the status of a store entrance is like that of the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">How can you find</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these </span>circumstances? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the discussion in this case concerns an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head from the public domain to the entrance of the store, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the Master <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived.</span> Evidently, for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived, yes, </span>this is what the owner pays, but he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>pay for that <span class="gemarra-regular">which it damaged.</span>
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the objection, and he resolved it </span>by explaining that the case in the mishna is one where a store <span class="gemarra-regular">is located on a corne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and it is situated in a way that some of the produce there would be in an animal’s path as it turns the corner, and therefore the animal would not need to turn its head away from the public domain in order to eat the produce.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who state </span>a different explanation of the dispute between Rav and Shmuel. In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it turns </span>its head to eat from the sides of the public square, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree </span>it is with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one allocates space from his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he does not have a use for it, and he adds this space <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain </span>by leaving it accessible for the public to use, and the damage took place in that area. The dispute is about whether the area is categorized as private property or the public domain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this is what was stated, </span>meaning this was their dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">they taught </span>that one is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head to the sides of the public square, as this area is categorized as private property, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if one allocated some space from his property </span>and added it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain </span>and the damage happened there, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as that area is treated as part of the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: Even if he allocates space from his property </span>and adds it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>as the damage took place in an area with the legal status of private property.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say they disagree with regard to</span> the question of damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that one dug <span class="gemarra-regular">inside one’s </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">domain </span>and then declared the area ownerless? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says </span>that the owner of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for eating the produce placed in an area that the owner added to the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that if one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit</span> or creates an obstacle that can cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">within his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>and he then declares his property to be ownerless, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for any damage that is caused by the pit, as now that it is in the public domain, he bears the responsibility for it. Similarly, the produce is viewed as if it is in the public domain, and the animal’s owner is exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel, who says </span>that the owner of an animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for eating the produce placed in an area that the owner added to the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that if one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit within his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span> and he then declares his property to be ownerless, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as he dug the pit when the property was his. Similarly, the produce is viewed as if it is in the property of the injured party, and the animal’s owner is liable.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Actually, I will say to you</span>

Daf 21b

that <span class="gemarra-regular">usually, </span>if one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit within his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>and he then declares his property to be ownerless, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as he dug the pit when the property was his. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, because </span>here the owner of the animal can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to the owner of the produce: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not all in your power to bring your produce close to the public domain and to </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">hold my ox liable for </span>eating <span class="gemarra-regular">it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Usually, </span>if one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>or creates an obstacle that can cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">within his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>and he then declares his property to be ownerless, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> for any damage that is caused by the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">pit, granted, it is possible to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he was not aware, </span>meaning the injured party was not thinking about the possibility that there may be a pit there that could cause him harm, and therefore the one who dug the pit is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>that is spread out over the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">can it be said that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was not aware </span>of it? It cannot be, because the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">sees </span>the produce.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that actually, the amoraic dispute about an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head and eats produce at the side of the road <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the subject of a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square, </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived; </span>but if it ate <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sides of the </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">square, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for that <span class="gemarra-regular">which it damaged. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Elazar say: It is not typical </span>for an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat </span>in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">but only to walk </span>there. Consequently, the owner is liable.
Initially, the Gemara understands Rabbi Yosei’s opinion as also referring to a situation in which the animal eats from the sides of the public square, and since this is so, it seems that the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei is </span>the same as that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Rabbi Meir, and the mishna presents their opinions as differing. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is clear that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to a case in which the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head to eat. <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head, the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">also pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived, while Rabbi Yosei holds </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for that <span class="gemarra-regular">which it damaged.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is possible to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone </span>agrees about the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">turns </span>its head, <span class="gemarra-regular">either in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav or in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel. And here they disagree </span>about the exemption inferred from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“It consumed in the field of another” </span>(Exodus 22:4), which renders the owner of an animal liable for damage classified as Eating. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that only if it ate from private property is its owner liable, as the verse stating the owner’s liability means: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it consumed in the field of another,” but not</span> when it eats <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yosei, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>it means that even if it ate from the public domain its owner is liable, as the verse stating the owner’s liability means: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it consumed in the field of another,” but not </span>when it eats <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of the one responsible for the damage; </span>only if the animal ate produce of another that was on the property of the animal’s owner, is its owner is exempt.
The Gemara challenges this: But not when it eats <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of the one responsible for the damage?</span> What is the novelty in this statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to the owner of the produce: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is your produce doing on my property? </span>The owner would certainly not be liable if the produce is damaged in that case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is with regard to the dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">between Ilf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Oshaya </span>concerning an animal that ate produce from the back of another animal or the like. Rabbi Meir holds that one is never liable for damage classified as Eating in the public domain, even if his animal ate from the back of another, and Rabbi Yosei holds that if it ate off the back of another animal, this is equivalent to Eating from the property of the injured party.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dog or a goat that jumped from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">roofto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and broke vessels </span>while doing so, their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>these animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> concerning to jumping. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dog that took a cake </span>that had been baked directly on hot coals, <span class="gemarra-regular">and went to a stack </span>of grain to eat it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it ate the cake </span>and at the same time <span class="gemarra-regular">ignited the stack </span>of grain with a coal that it had taken along with the cake, the owner of the dog must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the cake, and </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay for half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage to the stack </span>of grain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>the owners must pay the full cost of the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">jumped </span>off the rooftop. This indicates that if <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> off the roof, they would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from all liability despite his obligation to keep them from climbing onto the roof and jumping down from there. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that in an incident that <span class="gemarra-regular">begins with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">negligence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning carelessness or even an intention to cause damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and ends in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accident</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the one who caused the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt,</span> as in this case the owner was careless in allowing the animals to go to the rooftop, but since they did not jump off the roof but rather fell accidentally, he is exempt.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If a dog or a goat jumped from a rooftop and broke vessels </span>while doing so, their owners must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. If they fell </span>from there, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from all liability. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who says </span>that if an incident <span class="gemarra-regular">begins with negligence and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ends in an accident, </span>the one who caused the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, but according to the one who says </span>that in such a case he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, what can be said? </span>It seems that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> constitutes conclusive proof against that opinion.
The Gemara answers: The case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the vessels were brought close to the wall </span>by their owners, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">jump </span>off the rooftop <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">leap they do not fall on top of them, </span>and the vessels broke because the animal fell and didn’t jump. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>since in an ordinary circumstance no damage should occur, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case does <span class="gemarra-regular">not even begin with negligence. </span>Since the damage was caused by falling, the entire case is ruled an accident.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: Sometimes </span>one can be <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case where the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">fell </span>from the wall of their owner’s house. <span class="gemarra-regular">You find</span> such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the wall was unstable, </span>and the owner was negligent in allowing the animals to go up to the roof due to the danger of the wall collapsing. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because it should have occurred to him that bricks may fall </span>from the wall and break the vessels? But <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately, no bricks fell and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">fell, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>actually a case that <span class="gemarra-regular">begins with negligence and ends in an accident. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a narrow wall, </span>in which case it is clear that if when they climb up there they will fall, and that is why he is liable for the damage they cause by falling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If a dog or a goat jumped from below to </span>something that was <span class="gemarra-regular">above</span> them and thereby caused damage, their owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this is atypical behavior. But if they jumped <span class="gemarra-regular">from above to below,</span> their owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of any damage they cause, as this is typical behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">If a person or a chicken jumped </span>and broke something, <span class="gemarra-regular">regardless of whether they jumped from above to below or from below to above, they are liable. </span>

Daf 22a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If a dog or a goat jumped</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>they jumped <span class="gemarra-regular">from above to below or from below to above, </span>their owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from all liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa interpreted </span>it in the following way: Their manners of movement <span class="gemarra-regular">were changed </span>from the typical manner of movement for their species. The <span class="gemarra-regular">dog </span>moved <span class="gemarra-regular">by leaping [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bizkira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> while the <span class="gemarra-regular">goat </span>moved <span class="gemarra-regular">by climbing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bisrikha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, why </span>are the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability? After all, they still caused damage. The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not intend to say that they are completely exempt, but that they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage; they are, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage,</span> as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in any case of damage caused by atypical behavior, as such acts are classified as Goring.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dog that took </span>a cake that had been baked directly on hot coals, and went to a stack of grain to eat it, and it ate the cake and at the same time ignited the stack of grain with a coal that it had taken along with the cake, the owner of the dog must pay the full cost of the damage for the cake, and he must pay for half the cost of the damage to the stack of grain.
With regard to damage caused by a fire lit by one person spreading to a location other than where it was lit, the Gemara cites a dispute among the <span class="it-text">amora’</span><span class="it-text">im</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>His liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that damage caused by a fire in a location other than where it was lit is comparable to damage caused by an arrow shot at a distant target. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says: </span>His liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> he is responsible for this damage just as he is responsible for damage caused elsewhere by any of his possessions, e.g., one of his animals.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish did not state </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan? </span>The Gemara answers: He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that fire is not comparable to an arrow, as <span class="gemarra-regular">an arrow proceeds </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">of his </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">force, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">does not proceed </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">of his </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">force, </span>but requires a wind to carry it from the location where it was lit to the location of the damage. The Gemara asks about the other opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan did not state </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish? </span>The Gemara answers: He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that one’s fire is not comparable to his possessions, as <span class="gemarra-regular">property is </span>a tangible <span class="gemarra-regular">substance </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>a tangible <span class="gemarra-regular">substance.</span>
The Gemara attempts to settle the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dog that took a cak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that had been baked directly on hot coals, and went to a stack of grain to eat it, and it ate the cake and at the same time ignited the stack of grain with a coal that it had taken along with the cake, the owner of the dog must pay the full cost of the damage for the cake, and he must pay for half the cost of the damage to the stack of grain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, </span>this fire is similar to <span class="gemarra-regular">the arrows of the dog, </span>and therefore he must pay for half the cost of the damage caused by the dog’s force, as in a case of pebbles.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, this fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not the property of the owner of the dog; </span>rather, it is the property of the owner of the cake, so why is the owner of the dog liable?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case where the dog took the coal and did not place the cake on the stack, rather <span class="gemarra-regular">it threw it </span>onto the stack. The ruling of the mishna is: <span class="gemarra-regular">For the cake </span>which the dog ate, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">spot </span>on the stack of grain that was damaged by the throwing of the <span class="gemarra-regular">coal </span>there, the owner must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay for half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>as in a case of pebbles. <span class="gemarra-regular">And for the stack </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">as a whole, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>because his liability for damage caused by the spread of the fire is due to its similarity to his property, and in this case it was not his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>can explain the mishna in a more straightforward manner. It is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>the cake with the coal directly on the stack of grain in order to eat the cake. Accordingly, the owner of the dog must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage for the cake and for the </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">spot </span>where the <span class="gemarra-regular">coal </span>was put down, as these cases of damage were caused directly by the dog. <span class="gemarra-regular">And for </span>the rest of <span class="gemarra-regular">the stack </span>of grain, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay for half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion one is liable for the damage caused by fire due to its similarity to arrows shot by his force. The damage to the rest of the stack of grain is an indirect result of the dog’s force, and therefore his liability is according the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of pebbles.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (62b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a camel </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">laden with fla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and was passing through the public domain, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">its flax extended into a store </span>at the edge of the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the flax <span class="gemarra-regular">caught fire from a lamp </span>in the store <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to the storekeeper, and </span>as a result of the burning flax the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">set fire to the building </span>together with all its contents, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the camel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the damage. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">the storekeeper placed his lamp outside </span>in the public domain, thereby causing the flax on the camel to catch fire, and consequently the building was set on fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">the storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. Rabbi Yehuda says: In </span>a case where the lamp placed outside was <span class="gemarra-regular">a Hanukkah lamp, </span>the storekeeper is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability, as there is a mitzva to place a Hanukkah lamp outside.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, </span>the fire in the store <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>similar to <span class="gemarra-regular">the arrows of the camel, </span>and that is why the camel’s owner is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that liability for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not the property of the owner of the camel. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the camel moved the burning flax around and <span class="gemarra-regular">ignited the entire building, </span>lighting one spot after another. The fire did not need to spread since the camel directly set the building on fire in each of those spots, and therefore this case is comparable to that of a dog who moved the coal around from place to place.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the storekeeper placed his lamp outside, the storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And if </span>the case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">ignited </span>the entire building, spot by spot, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> His fire did not spread through the building; it was the camel that moved it around from one place to another. The Gemara answers: The case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the camel did not move around, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">stood </span>still, but since there was an extremely large load of flax on its back, once it caught fire it ignited the entire building simultaneously.
The Gemara asks: If the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">stood </span>without moving from place to place, but did shift the load on its back and thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">ignited </span>the entire building, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">that the storekeeper </span>should be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from any liability <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">camel </span>should be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as it was his responsibility to move the camel away from there. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Manoah said in the name of Rav Ika: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">stood </span>still in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to urinate </span>and while doing so set the building ablaze; in that case the incident is deemed an accident as the owner could not have moved the camel from the spot. 

Daf 22b

Consequently, in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the camel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not have overloaded </span>the camel with flax to such a degree that it extended out so far from the sides that it could catch fire and ignite the store. But in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, as he should not have placed </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">lamp outside.</span>
The Gemara attempts again to resolve the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a mishna (61b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who ignites a stack </span>of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there was a goat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tied to </span>the stack, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there was also a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave adjacent to i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> who was not tied to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>both the goat and the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">were burned </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the stack of grain and killed, the one who ignited the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation for both the stack and the goat, but he is exempt from paying for the slave because the slave should have run from the fire. Conversely, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">slave was tied to </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a goat adjacent to it </span>that was not tied to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the slave and the goat <span class="gemarra-regular">were burned </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the stack of grain, the one who ignited the fire is completely <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment for damage because he is liable to receive capital punishment for murder, and he is punished only for the greater transgression.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, due to that </span>reasoning he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> for the damage to the stack of grain in the second case, because it is as if he killed the slave with his arrows and consequently became subject to receive court-imposed capital punishment, and one who is subject to the death penalty is not liable to pay monetary compensation for the same act, as he receives the greater punishment of the two. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that liability for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? If his ox, </span>which is his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">were to kill a slave, would he also not be liable </span>to pay for the damage?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he lit the body of the slave on fire, </span>consequently becoming subject to the death penalty as would anyone who kills a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he receives the greater </span>punishment, the death penalty, but he does not also have to pay for the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, what </span>is the purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">of stating </span>this; what novel idea is it supposed to teach? One who lit a slave on fire is most certainly a murderer, and a murderer is exempt from paying for damage caused while committing the murder. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> for the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the goat </span>belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and the slave </span>belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span>different person; in that case one might have thought that since payment is due to someone other than the owner of the murdered slave, he would be required to pay the owner of the goat, despite being subject to the death penalty for killing the slave. Therefore, this mishna teaches that since he committed one act, for which he is liable to receive the death penalty, he is exempt from paying compensation to anyone as a result of that act.
The Gemara attempts another resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a mishna (59b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sends a fire, </span>i.e., places a burning object, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the hand of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a mino</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for any damage later caused by the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that he would not be held liable in court, but nevertheless he remains responsible to pay for what he has done.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>similar to the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">the arrows of a deaf-mute </span>or an imbecile or a minor, and this is why the one who gave them the fire is exempt from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if he were to convey his ox to a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, would he also not be liable? </span>That is impossible, as there is an explicit statement in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (10a) saying that he would be liable.
The Gemara answers: But it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">about this that Reish Lakish says in the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥizkiyya: They taught </span>that one is exempt from the damage caused by a fire that he had entrusted in the care of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he conveyed a coal to him and </span>the deaf-mute <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned </span>the coal into a flame, which then caused damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he conveyed an open <span class="gemarra-regular">flame to him </span>and it caused damage, the one who gave him the flame is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. What is the reason </span>for this? This is because the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage is self-evident, </span>i.e., it is clear that damage will ensue, and it is as if he placed a goring ox under his care. Therefore, if one’s liability for damage classified as Fire is due to its similarity to damage caused by one’s property, he would be liable in this case.
