<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>who holds that one’s liability for damage caused by fire is due to its similarity to one’s arrows, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt even </span>if he conveyed an open <span class="gemarra-regular">flame </span>to him, because <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the deaf-mute’s handling </span>of the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">that causes </span>the blaze, and it is therefore not similar to a case of arrows shot; the one who conveys a fire to the deaf-mute <span class="gemarra-regular">does not become liable </span>for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">until he hands </span>the deaf-mute <span class="gemarra-regular">chopped wood, kindling chips, and a lamp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as in that case, the damage that will ensue is self-evident and it is as if he started the blaze himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: A verse and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> both <span class="gemarra-regular">support Rabbi Yoḥanan’s </span>opinion. The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>supporting his opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “If fire breaks out” </span>(Exodus 22:5), indicating that the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">breaks out on its own; </span>yet the verse continues, <span class="gemarra-regular">“the one who ignited the fire shall pay,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> indicating that the fire was ignited by a person. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the verse that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire is due to </span>its similarity to damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, </span>as the resolution of the apparent inconsistency in the verse is that it relates to the individual as if he had himself started the blaze, and that is why he is obligated to pay for the damage.
The <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> supporting his opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught: The verse </span>concerning liability for a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">opened</span>

Daf 23a

<span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s possessions, </span>as it is written: “If fire breaks out,” indicating that his responsibility for the fire is the same as his responsibility for any of his possessions that cause damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it concludes with </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body,</span> as the verse refers to the person by calling him “the one who ignited the fire,” <span class="gemarra-regular">telling you </span>that his liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>raised <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty: According to the one who says </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire is due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows, how can you fin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One exempted </span>one from liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed </span>items damaged by a <span class="gemarra-regular">fire? </span>If one caused damage by shooting an arrow, he would be equally liable for damaging both exposed and concealed items. Consequently, if one’s liability for the damage caused by his fire is due to its similarity to his arrows, he should similarly be liable for concealed items damaged by a fire.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">satisfactory for him, </span>i.e., Abaye resolved the difficulty. He explained that the exemption from liability for concealed items damaged by a fire applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a fire broke out in that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, and </span>afterward the <span class="gemarra-regular">fence </span>separating this courtyard from the neighbor’s courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">collapsed, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to the fire, and</span> therefore the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">spread and ignited </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">and caused damage in another courtyard. </span>In such a circumstance he would be exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because there, </span>in this case, it is as if <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows were depleted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he bears responsibility for the fire that he had started, which initially was confined to his courtyard alone. The fire that spread to the neighboring courtyard is not similar to his arrows, and therefore he is exempt.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>he should be exempt not only with regard to concealed items but also <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to exposed </span>items that were damaged by the fire, as <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows are also depleted </span>when the fire spreads and causes damage. If his exemption is due to fact that the damage was caused because the wall that had separated the two courtyards had collapsed, there should be no distinction between exposed and concealed items.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who holds </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by his fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that his liability is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fire’s similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property. </span>Consequently, it remains possible for a circumstance to exist in which one will be exempt from liability for damaging concealed items and yet be held liable for exposed items. <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, if he had </span>the ability to repair the breach <span class="gemarra-regular">and fence</span> in the courtyard again <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not fence </span>it in, he will be liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">as there,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>is similar to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>was in danger of escaping from his property and <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not strike </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in its fac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to hold it back, and therefore he is liable for any ensuing damage. In this case, however, the fire is not similar to his arrows since it was not responsible for the collapse of the fence, and therefore he is exempt from damage caused to concealed items, according to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Fire.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this conclusion, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the one who holds </span>that one’s liability for the damage caused by his fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows also holds </span>that his liability is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the opinions of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish?
The Gemara answers: The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">holding him liable </span>for the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> in a case where the fire injured a person. In such an instance Rabbi Yoḥanan would require, in addition to the costs of the damage itself, payments for pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation, as in any case of personal injury, given that Rabbi Yoḥanan considers Fire to be no different than an arrow he had shot at the injured party.
§ The mishna teaches that he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the full cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">for the cake </span>the dog ate but must pay for only half the cost of the damage to the burned stack of grain. The Gemara elucidates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the one <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay for the cake? The <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dog. </span>The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">coal also be liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he shares some of the responsibility, being that he did not safeguard his coal and it ultimately caused damage? The Gemara answers: The case under discussion is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the coal <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarded his coal </span>properly.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where he safeguarded his coa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> properly, <span class="gemarra-regular">what does the dog want, </span>i.e., what is it doing <span class="gemarra-regular">there? </span>If the dog was able to get in there, it cannot be that the owner of the coal safeguarded it properly. The Gemara answers: The case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">burrowed </span>under the fence, entered the property, and took the cake and the coal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary doors are </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">vulnerable to being burrowed </span>under <span class="gemarra-regular">by a do</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> because if it would be atypical for a dog to burrow under the door, the owner of the dog would be exempt from payment. Therefore, it must be that it is typical behavior for a dog to burrow beneath a door, and therefore it was incumbent upon the owner of the door to prevent it from causing damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where did it eat </span>the cake? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that it ate it </span>after placing it <span class="gemarra-regular">on a stack </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to another, </span>i.e., someone other than the owner of the cake, then he should not be liable for the damage to the cake under the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in order to hold someone liable <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>fulfillment of scenario described in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it consumed in the field of another” </span>(Exodus 22:4), meaning that an act of damage classified as Eating must be caused on the property of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that is not</span> the case in this instance. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>only in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>the cake after placing it <span class="gemarra-regular">on a stack </span>of grain owned <span class="gemarra-regular">by the owner of the cake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and that is why the dog’s owner is liable, as it ate it while on the property of the injured party.
§ The Gemara suggests: From here it is possible to <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>a dilemma and prove <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mouth of a cow</span>

Daf 23b

<span class="gemarra-regular">is like the courtyard of the injured </span>party, i.e., it is not a separate domain from the place in which the animal is eating. <span class="gemarra-regular">As if </span>the mouth of the animal were to be considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like the courtyard of the one responsible for the damage, let </span>the owner of the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is your bread doing in my dog’s mouth? </span>The dog’s mouth is my domain, and I am not liable for damage classified as Eating done to your property in my domain.
The Gemara notes: The need for this type of inference arises from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that a dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the mouth of a cow like the courtyard of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">or is it like the courtyard of the one responsible for the damage, </span>i.e., the owner of the cow?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the mouth of the cow is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the courtyard of the one responsible for the damage,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> how can you find </span>a case of damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>for which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One holds </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one must pay for damage classified as Eating only if it occurred on the property of the injured party. If the mouth of an animal is deemed the domain of the animal’s owner, damage caused by an animal eating would always take place in the domain of the animal’s owner and he would therefore be exempt from liability in every case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: </span>It is possible to describe a case of Eating that would render the animal’s owner liable according to the one who holds that the mouth of a cow is like the domain of its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>if the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">rubbed </span>up <span class="gemarra-regular">against a wall for its pleasure </span>and broke it, or if the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">soiled produce </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for its </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">pleasure. </span>Any action in which an animal engages for its own pleasure is classified as Eating, and if the animal causes damage thereby within the domain belonging to the injured party, its owner will be held liable since nothing has entered the mouth of the animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra objects to </span>these examples of Eating: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in order to create liability under the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">I require </span>fulfillment of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As consumes the tooth until it be all gone” </span>(I Kings 14:10), meaning that the damaged item must be completely destroyed or consumed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>here that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case, as the stones of the broken wall and the soiled produce have not been destroyed. To answer Mar Zutra’s question, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>It is possible for a cow to cause complete destruction by rubbing against a wall, e.g., a cow <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">erases </span>any decorative <span class="gemarra-regular">image</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that were adorning the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>It is possible for cow to cause complete destruction by soiling produce, e.g., a cow <span class="gemarra-regular">that trods on</span> the produce and crushes it, thereby totally eradicating it. Consequently, the initial question about the status of the cow’s mouth remains.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a resolution from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he incited a dog against </span>another person, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he incited a snake against </span>another person, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>(<span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 66b). The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? The one who incited </span>the dog is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dog </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And if you say </span>that the mouth of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the courtyard of the one liable for the damage, let </span>the owner of the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">What does your hand want, </span>i.e., what is it doing, <span class="gemarra-regular">in my dog’s mouth, </span>which is my domain?
The Gemara answers: The mishna could be understood a different way. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the one who incited </span>the dog is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as the dog is not his property, but the dog owner is also exempt because his dog’s mouth has a legal status similar to that of the dog owner’s courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that the case under discussion is one where the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">extended his canine teeth and scratched the </span>victim, but the victim’s hand was not inside his mouth, and therefore this incident cannot be treated as if it took place in the domain of the owner of the dog.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution based on the continuation of the above mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one caused the snake to bite </span>a person by bringing the fangs of the snake to the victim’s body, and the snake killed him, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>the one who instigated the attack <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to receive the death penalty <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis exempt </span>him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says </span>in explanation of the dispute: When you analyze the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">you will find that according to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, the venom of a snak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>deemed to be constantly <span class="gemarra-regular">present between its fangs, </span>and therefore when the snake is made to strike the victim it is not actively engaged in any action. <span class="gemarra-regular">Consequently, </span>the person handling the snake is liable, similar to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">strikes </span>a victim <span class="gemarra-regular">with a sword, </span>while the <span class="gemarra-regular">snake </span>itself is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>as it has not done anything. And <span class="gemarra-regular">according to according to the statement of the Rabbis, the venom of a snake </span>is not present between its fangs but rather the snake must <span class="gemarra-regular">secrete </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">of its own volition. Consequently, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">snake </span>receives the penalty of <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning </span>like any animal that kills a person, while the one who instigated the attack <span class="gemarra-regular">and striking </span>with it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mouth of the cow </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the courtyard of the one responsible for the damage,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let </span>the owner of the snake metaphorically <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is your hand doing in my snake’s mouth? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We do not say </span>this principle <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to matters relating to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty; therefore, one who kills another is always liable, regardless of whether it occurred within the domain of the killer or within the domain of the victim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do you say </span>this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 5:13): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who enters the courtyard of a property owner without </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the property owner’s ox gores </span>the intruder <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, the ox </span>receives the penalty of <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning while </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>having to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom? </span>He is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because he can </span>metaphorically <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">What do you want in my domain, </span>i.e., why were you there without permission? Since he entered the premises without authorization, he bears responsibility for his own fate. But if that is so, the same applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox as well, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">What do you want in my domain? </span>Rather, it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that this principle applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to matters relating to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty. Consequently, these cases do not prove that the mouth of the cow is like the courtyard of the victim within the scope of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damages.
§ The Gemara relates: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">these goats, </span>belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Tarbu family</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that would </span>frequently <span class="gemarra-regular">damage Rav Yosef’s </span>property. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Abaye: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">tell their owners that they must keep </span>their goats enclosed within their own property. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yosef in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why should I go</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If I go </span>and deliver this message, <span class="gemarra-regular">they will say to me: Let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master put a fence up around his property</span> so that the goats will not be able to get in there.
The Gemara questions this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">did put up a fence</span> to safeguard his property from the Eating of other animals because he was required to do so, and had he not done so the owners of those animals would not be liable to pay for the damage caused by their animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you find </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating for </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One </span>holds the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>As, if it is the responsibility of the injured party to fence in his property, animals will not be able to get inside. The Gemara answers: A case in which the Torah holds the owner of the animal liable can be explained as one <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">burrowed under </span>the fence. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it could be explained as a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the separating <span class="gemarra-regular">fence collapsed in </span>middle of <span class="gemarra-regular">the night </span>and the owner of the fence did not have the opportunity to repair it before the animals caused damage.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, would announce: Those that ascend </span>to Eretz Yisrael from Babylonia, bringing with them the rulings of the Babylonian Sages, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well as those that descend </span>to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael, bringing the rulings of the sages of Eretz Yisrael with them, all agree to the following <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these goats </span>that loiter <span class="gemarra-regular">in the marke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> until they are slaughtered and in the meantime <span class="gemarra-regular">cause damage </span>to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">we warn their owner two or three times. If </span>the owner of the goats <span class="gemarra-regular">heeds </span>the warning and safeguards his animals from damaging others, then <span class="gemarra-regular">he heeds</span> it and no further action is necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if not, we say to him: </span>Go, <span class="gemarra-regular">sit next to the butcher shop and take your money, </span>meaning we instruct him to slaughter his goats immediately. Since he in any event intends to slaughter them, the court can force him to do so immediately. Otherwise, he cannot be forced to slaughter them as preventive measure.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>type of ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and which </span>is deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> An ox is deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified about it </span>that it gored on <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">days.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>it reverts back to its previous <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>status <span class="gemarra-regular">from when it reverses its </span>behavior and refrains from goring for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>consecutive <span class="gemarra-regular">days; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: </span>It is deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>in any case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>gored <span class="gemarra-regular">three times, </span>regardless of the number of days on which this behavior occurred. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it reverts back to its previous <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>status in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where children pet it </span>and play with it <span class="gemarra-regular">and it does not gore </span>them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda</span> that an ox is deemed forewarned only if it gored on three separate days? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>It states in the verse: “Or if it is known that the ox was a goring ox from yesterday and the day before yesterday, and its owner has not secured it” (Exodus 21:36). This leads to the following inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Yesterday” </span>indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>day, <span class="gemarra-regular">“from yesterday” </span>indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>days, <span class="gemarra-regular">“the day before yesterday” </span>indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>days, <span class="gemarra-regular">“and its owner has not secured it”; </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at a fourth </span>incident of <span class="gemarra-regular">goring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for which the owner pays the full amount of damages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: “Yesterday” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“from yesterday” </span>are not to be expounded separately. Rather, the inference from this phrase is that “from yesterday” indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>day, <span class="gemarra-regular">“the day before yesterday” </span>indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>days, <span class="gemarra-regular">“and its owner has not secured it” </span>indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">now, </span>the third incident of goring, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>as a forewarned animal for the third goring.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>for the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>who does not determine the forewarned status of an ox by the number of days on which the animal gored but simply by the number of times? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir said: </span>

Daf 24a

When the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">performs its gorings at intervals, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">performs its gorings successively</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>that its owner is liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to </span>Rabbi Meir: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who experiences a discharge of uterine blood after her </span><span class="gemarra-regular">menstrual period [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will prove </span>that your <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is invalid: If <span class="gemarra-regular">her sightings occur at intervals, </span>i.e., if she sees a flow of uterine blood on three consecutive days, she becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure; </span>while if <span class="gemarra-regular">her sightings were consecutive, </span>for example if all three occurred on the same day, she remains <span class="gemarra-regular">pure.</span>
Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>The case of the <span class="it-text">zava</span> does not disprove my opinion, because the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>in reference to the parallel <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<span class="it-text">zav</span>]: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And this shall be his ritual impurity when he has a discharge” </span>(Leviticus 15:3). The word “this” emphasizes that in this matter the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> requires following the instructions of the verse precisely as they were recorded, and in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse associates </span>the impurity of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with</span> the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">sighting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of discharges the man observed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it associates <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>impurity of the <span class="gemarra-italic">zava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> during which she experienced sightings of blood, as it says: “Many days” (Leviticus 15:25). By contrast, with regard to the goring ox, the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference remains in place.
The Gemara asks about this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it determined <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>additional phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And this,” </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">zava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>having her status determined by individual <span class="gemarra-regular">sightings </span>of blood, associating it instead with the number of days on which she experienced bleeding? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>instead that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>having his status determined by sightings on separate <span class="gemarra-regular">days, </span>indicating that he will be rendered a <span class="it-text">zav</span> only if he experienced three discharges on a single day and not on separate days. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>elsewhere: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And one who has a discharge, whether it be a man or a woman” </span>(Leviticus 15:33). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes </span>the ritual impurity of <span class="gemarra-regular">a male to </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">female’s </span>ritual impurity is caused by sightings on multiple <span class="gemarra-regular">days, so too </span>the ritual impurity of <span class="gemarra-regular">a male </span>can be caused by sightings on multiple <span class="gemarra-regular">days.</span>
The Gemara asks: The derivation from the verse could just as easily lead to the opposite conclusion. <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">compare </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">female to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">male; just as a male </span>becomes ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">sightings, </span>even if they all occur on the same day, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>become ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">sightings, </span>even on the same day. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Merciful One excluded </span>this possibility by making use of the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“and this.”</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what did you see </span>to make you exclude associating the ritual impurity of women with the number of sightings, rather than excluding associating the ritual impu-rity of men with the number of days? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It stands to reason </span>that this is so, as the context of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">deals with sightings, </span>and therefore an additional phrase serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude sightings, </span>but can you say that in a context where it <span class="gemarra-regular">deals with sightings it excludes days? </span>The exclusionary term “and this” appears in the section discussing the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the <span class="it-text">zav</span>, in the context of which it mentions sightings and not days, and therefore when it excludes something from these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> and limits them to specific cases, it will exclude it from being associated with sightings.
The Gemara returns to the subject of classifying an ox as innocuous or forewarned: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>type of ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned? Any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">about which </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified </span>that it gored on <span class="gemarra-regular">three days </span>is forewarned. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it reverts to its former <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>status <span class="gemarra-regular">if children pet it and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it does not gore; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Shimon says: A forewarned </span>ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">about which </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified </span>that it gored <span class="gemarra-regular">three times, and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">three days only with regard to reversals, </span>meaning that in order for an ox to revert to innocuous status, the ox must refrain from goring on three separate days. Each of these additional views on this subject combine aspects of both of the opinions mentioned in the mishna, those of Rabbi Yehuda and those of Rabbi Meir.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda concerning </span>the criteria for deeming an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, as Rabbi Yosei concedes to his </span>opinion on this issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir concerning </span>the criteria for reverting the status of an animal to <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, as Rabbi Yosei concedes to his </span>opinion on that issue.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: And let the Master say </span>the reverse, that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir concerning </span>the criteria for deeming an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, as Rabbi Shimon concedes to his </span>opinion on this issue <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda concerning </span>the criteria for reverting the status of an ox to <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, as Rabbi Shimon concedes to his </span>opinion on that issue. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">replied to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">I hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, as Rabbi Yosei’s analysis [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nimmuko</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is with him, </span>i.e., it is sound.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised </span>before the Sages: The <span class="gemarra-regular">three days that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the context of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion with regard to the testimony needed to assign the status of forewarned to an ox, are they needed in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to render the ox forewarned, or </span>are they needed in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to forewarn the man </span>who owns the ox, to inform him that he needs to take precautions to keep it from causing further harm?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>between the two possibilities? The Gemara answers: The practical difference is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where three groups of witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to the court <span class="gemarra-regular">on one day, </span>each testifying about a separate instance of goring caused by the ox on three separate days. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that their testimony serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">render the ox forewarned </span>by determining that it gored on three separate days, then in this case the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has been classified </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>on the basis of their testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that their testimony serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarn the man,</span> the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has not been classified </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>on the basis of this testimony since the owner heard all of the testimony on a single day. This enables <span class="gemarra-regular">him to say: </span>It is only <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">testified against me; </span>and therefore his ox will not be deemed forewarned until he has been issued warnings over the course of three separate days. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>then, is the solution to the dilemma raised above?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 2:3): <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox does not become forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testify against it in the presence of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner and in the presence of a court. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they testified against it in the presence of a court but not in the presence of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner but not in the presence of a court, it does not become forewarned until they testify against it in the presence of a court and in the presence of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner.</span>
Furthermore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified against </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>incident of goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two </span>other witnesses testified against it <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>incident, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two </span>other witnesses testified against it <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>incident, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are three </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies here, but </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">one with regard to rendering </span>their statements as <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring testimony.</span>
Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the first set </span>of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">is determined to be conspiring </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">two testimonies </span>remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>that claim that the ox gored, and the owner must pay for half the cost of the damage in each case. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from having to pay the full cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the conspiring witnesses are <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from paying the owner what he would have had to pay were their testimony accepted and his ox deemed forewarned, as they testified only concerning the first incident of goring, and the ox would not have been deemed forewarned on the basis of this testimony alone. And similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the second set </span>of witnesses was also <span class="gemarra-regular">determined to be conspiring </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is one testimony </span>remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>that claims that the ox gored, the third. At this point too, the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from having to pay the full cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the conspiring witnesses are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from having to pay the owner the full cost of the damage.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the third group </span>of witnesses was also <span class="gemarra-regular">determined to be conspiring witnesses, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the witnesses become <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The third group is liable to pay the owner of the animal the payment for half the cost of the damage they tried to make him pay for the third incident of goring, and all three groups must share in the payment of the other half of the damage for the final incident that they tried to charge him for by classifying his ox as forewarned. <span class="gemarra-regular">And concerning this it is stated: “And you shall do unto him as he had conspired to do </span>unto his brother” (Deuteronomy 19:19).
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that the purpose of the testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">to render the ox forewarned, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> presented in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well, </span>as according to this opinion it can be said that all of the witnesses came on the same day at the behest of the alleged victim of the third incident, and therefore they were all certainly aware of each other’s testimony. Consequently, the first set of witnesses shares in the responsibility for the testimony of the last group, as they are all co-witnesses in the effort to have the ox rendered forewarned. 

Daf 24b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the witnesses came <span class="gemarra-regular">to forewarn the man, </span>to caution him to safeguard his animal from causing harm, then they must have come on three separate days. And if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let these first </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Did we know that after three days these </span>other witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were going to come to testify about </span>the animal? Therefore, it must be that the case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is one where the three groups of witnesses all came on the same day, and if that is so, the purpose of the testimony must be to render the ox forewarned.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: I recited </span>this <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rav Kahana and he replied to me </span>in response to this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does it work out well </span>to say that they are coming <span class="gemarra-regular">to render the ox forewarned? </span>Even in a case where all of the witnesses arrive in court on the same day, <span class="gemarra-regular">let these last </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: From where were we to know that all </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">standing in court came to testify about the ox? We came to make this person liable </span>to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>his animal allegedly caused, but we are not responsible for the attempt to make him pay the full cost of the damage for the third incident.
The Gemara answers: It must be that the case concerns a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the different groups of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>observed <span class="gemarra-regular">signalin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to each other, and therefore it is clear that they were aware of each other’s testimony and that they came to the court for this purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>The case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">came in succession,</span> one following the other, and therefore it is clear that the latter witnesses are aware of the former.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>In this case the witnesses said that they were <span class="gemarra-regular">acquainted with the owner of the </span>goring <span class="gemarra-regular">ox but </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">not familiar with the ox </span>itself. This indicates that they were coming to court to render the ox forewarned, as the witnesses are not able to identify the goring ox and they would not be able to hold its owner liable to pay for half the cost of the damage, as this payment is paid only from the proceeds of the sale of the animal. Therefore, the only purpose of their testimony would be to hold the owner liable to pay the full cost of the damage for the third incident, as this payment is made from the owner’s superior-quality land.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if they were not familiar with the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">how could they render it forewarned? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They said</span> to the animal’s owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">You have a goring o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> among your cattle, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">you need to safeguard all of the cattle.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>the Sages: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who incites another’s dog against another, </span>i.e., a third person, and he is injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who incited </span>the animal against him is <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly exempt, </span>since he did not cause the damage directly and neither did his property; but <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the dog? </span>The Gemara explains the different sides of the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that the owner of the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did I do to </span>the dog? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps we say to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Since you were aware that if others incite your dog it is prone to </span>being <span class="gemarra-regular">affected </span>by the <span class="gemarra-regular">incitement </span>and attacking, <span class="gemarra-regular">you ought not to have kept it </span>in your possession. Since you did, you are liable for the damage and the injuries it causes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>an ox reverts to its former <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>status <span class="gemarra-regular">if children pet it and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it does not gore. </span>It can be inferred from this that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it gores </span>when the children pet it, the owner would be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage. An ox that gores because children pet it can be likened to one that gores because it was incited to do so, and nevertheless the mishna holds the owner liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Is it taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if <span class="gemarra-regular">it gored </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? Perhaps </span>that is not what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means. It merely means that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it gored it </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>revert to <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>status; but the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable for </span>any of the damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">that goring </span>because the children incited the animal to do so, and therefore nothing can be conclusively demonstrated from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara attempts to prove this point from another source: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a solution from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 76b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">incited a dog against another </span>person, or <span class="gemarra-regular">incited a snake against another </span>person, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What, is it not that the one who incited </span>the dog against him is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, but</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the dog </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the one who incited </span>the animal against him is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as well as the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">incites the dog of another against </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>nevertheless if <span class="gemarra-regular">he incited the dog against himself, </span>i.e., the dog bit the one who was inciting it to attack, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason </span>for this? Due to the principle that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who deviates </span>from normative behavior in his actions, <span class="gemarra-regular">if another came along </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">and deviates </span>from the norm <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the action the first has done and thereby causes damage to him, the one who causes the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from liability. Since this individual deviated from the normative behavior and incited the dog against himself, the owner of the dog is not responsible for any damage the dog causes to him as a result, although generally speaking any time a dog bites it is in and of itself a deviation from its typical behavior and something for which its owner would normally be held liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Rava: It was stated in the name of Reish Lakish in accordance with your </span>opinion, that if anyone deviates from normative behavior in his actions, if another came along afterward and deviates from the norm with regard to the action the first has done and thereby causes damage to him, the one who causes the damage is exempt from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two cows in the public domain, one prone </span>in the street <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one walking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>cow <span class="gemarra-regular">kicked </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prone </span>cow, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. But if the <span class="gemarra-regular">prone </span>cow kicked the <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>cow, its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The rationale for this is that since it is typical behavior for cows to walk in the public domain and the prone cow deviated from this behavior, even if the walking cow also acted atypically and kicked the prone cow, the owner is exempt from liability.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Pappa: That is not in accordance with my opinion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have held </span>the owner of the walking cow <span class="gemarra-regular">liable in that </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>in my opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">we say to him </span>on behalf of the prone cow: It is true <span class="gemarra-regular">that you have the right to tread on me </span>in the public domain but <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not have the right to kick me, </span>and therefore Rava’s and Reish Lakish’s opinions are not exactly the same.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is </span>the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ox that causes damage </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, mentioned in an earlier mishna (15b) that listed animals that are forewarned? If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">gored, pushed, bit, squatted </span>upon, or <span class="gemarra-regular">kicked </span>another animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>the owner is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>if the ox was innocuous, but if it acted while <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon says: </span>He must pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and the Rabbis say: </span>He must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage,</span> as in any other case classified as Goring.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon said to the </span>Rabbis: <span class="gemarra-regular">If in a place where </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">was lenient with regard to </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and with regard to Trampling, </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, as </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>from liability, nevertheless the Torah was <span class="gemarra-regular">strict</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to these </span>forms of damage if they occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, requiring him <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>then in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">was strict with regard to</span> cases of damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>requiring the owner liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay for half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, is it not right that we </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">be strict with regard to this </span>form of damage if it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party to likewise require the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage?</span>
The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Although there is an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference being applied here, still <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> cannot be stricter with the inference than it is with the case that serves as the source of the inference. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>classified as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, so too, </span>for damage classified as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party he is liable to pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>If that is your opinion, then <span class="gemarra-regular">I as well</span>

Daf 25a

<span class="gemarra-regular">will not derive an inference </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring from </span>a different case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring. I will </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">derive an inference </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring from Trampling: And if in a place where </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">was lenient with regard to </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>as the owner is exempt from liability, nevertheless the Torah was <span class="gemarra-regular">strict</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>requiring him to pay half the cost of the damage, then in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> strict with regard to </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party as the animal’s owner is obligated to pay the full cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right that we </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>equally <span class="gemarra-regular">strict with regard to </span>damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>and require payment of the full cost of the damage in this case as well?
The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Here as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sufficient </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source, </span>and therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>classified as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, so too, </span>for damage classified as Goring <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party he will be liable to pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>as ultimately your inference still depends on the fact that for Goring in the public domain one pays half the cost of the damage.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> is it true that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon does not accept </span>the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that cannot be, as the principle that begins with: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>an aspect <span class="gemarra-regular">of Torah law, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Sages said that one of the ways in which the Torah may be interpreted is <span class="gemarra-regular">by an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inference. How </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">so? </span>It is written (Numbers 12:14): <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Lord said to Moses: If her father had but spit in her face, should she not hide in shame seven days? </span>Let her be shut up seven days outside the camp, and after that she shall be brought in again,” and therefore, using <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference it can be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the Divine Presence </span>reprimanded her, she should hide in shame for <span class="gemarra-regular">fourteen </span><span class="gemarra-regular">days</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Why was Miriam banished for only seven days? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sufficient </span>for the conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">that emerged from the </span><span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like the source </span>of the inference. Consequently, this principle is mandated by the Torah itself.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">does not accept </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>this principle completely <span class="gemarra-regular">refutes </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, leaving no <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived from it. But <span class="gemarra-regular">where it does not </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">refute </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is sufficient. </span>Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>with regard to Miriam, the <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>days during which she deserved to be banished from the camp due to the rebuke <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Divine Presence were not written, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>those days plus additional days, adding up to a total of <span class="gemarra-regular">fourteen, </span>and then the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">removed seven </span>days <span class="gemarra-regular">and left seven </span>days intact. Consequently, the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference was effective with regard to the seven days during which she was banished from the camp.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is written </span>explicitly in the Torah with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of Goring in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and brings an additional </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, forming </span>a payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. If you interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> employing the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, </span>to reduce the payment to half the cost of the damage, this completely <span class="gemarra-regular">refutes </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, as no <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would be derived from the inference; the initial payment for half the cost of the damage was written explicitly in the Torah. Consequently, in this case, Rabbi Tarfon does not employ the principle: It is sufficient.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>understand this matter? How do they respond to Rabbi Tarfon’s reasoning? The Gemara answers: In their opinion, the <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>days during which Miriam had to be banished due to the reprimand she received <span class="gemarra-regular">from the Divine Presence </span>are in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Let her be shut up seven days.</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> This indicates that the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is not required to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the seven days she was banished, as it would have added only the extra seven days. This means that according to the Rabbis, there is a source in the Torah that the principle: It is sufficient, is employed even when it refutes the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference completely.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon </span>say about that reasoning? The Gemara answers: He would say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Let her be shut up </span>seven days,” is necessary to teach us the basic fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that we interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> according to the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what would <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>say in response? The Gemara answers: They would point out that <span class="gemarra-regular">a different verse is written </span>about Miriam: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Miriam was shut up </span>outside the camp seven days” (Numbers 12:15). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon </span>respond to that? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>verse teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that we interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> according to the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, even generally, </span>and not only in this specific case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this point is necessary so that <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not say: Here </span>the principle: It is sufficient, is employed <span class="gemarra-regular">due to respect for Moses, but generally </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>done. This verse therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: </span>Is the fundamental principle: It is sufficient for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source, actually accepted by all authorities? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who does not interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in accordance with the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, even though </span>it is a case where the principle <span class="gemarra-regular">does not refute </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference completely. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived that the <span class="gemarra-regular">semen of a man who experiences</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a gonorrhea-like discharge [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> imparts ritual impurity by someone carrying it as well as by coming into contact with it, just as the actual gonorrhea-like discharge does? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is a logical </span><span class="gemarra-regular">derivation </span>from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>spittle, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>when coming <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a person who is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure </span>when coming <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>someone like a <span class="it-text">zav</span> who is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, is it not logical that </span>semen, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure </span>when coming <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>someone who is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure, should be impure </span>when coming <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>someone who is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>this derivation and applies it <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>discussing ritual impurity imparted <span class="gemarra-regular">by contact </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>discussing impurity imparted <span class="gemarra-regular">by carrying. And why </span>is this the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective in </span>teaching that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">by contact </span>alone, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the semen of a pure man, and the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, is effective </span>by limiting the scope of the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> from imparting ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">by carrying. </span>Since the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> does not formulate his derivation in this manner, it appears that he rejects the principle: It is sufficient, in all situations.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">was not necessary </span>to teach that the seminal emission of the <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">by contact, as it is </span>certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">no less </span>impure <span class="gemarra-regular">than </span>if it had come from <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">pure, </span>so the inference was necessary only to teach that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts impurity by carrying, this is not correct.
