In fact, it <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary </span>to teach this point, as it may <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written </span>in the verse: “If there be among you any man that is not clean because of something that <span class="gemarra-regular">happens to him by night” </span>(Deuteronomy 23:11), this means that a seminal emission is ritually impure if it came from <span class="gemarra-regular">someone who </span>had something <span class="gemarra-regular">happen to him, </span>and this <span class="gemarra-regular">causes him </span>to experience the emission, but the verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding this </span><span class="it-text">zav</span>, who did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have something <span class="gemarra-regular">happen to him </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">cause him </span>to experience the emission, but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather another matter, </span>i.e., his gonorrhea-like condition, <span class="gemarra-regular">caused him </span>to experience the emission. Consequently, it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is incorrect.
Abaye responded: In the verse “something that happens to him by night,” <span class="gemarra-regular">is it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">written: But not another matter? </span>This limiting clause is not written in the verse, and therefore the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts ritual impurity by contact can be understood from the explicit verse in the Torah, and there is no need to derive it from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference. Therefore, the only function of the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is to teach the halakha that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts impurity by carrying. Applying the principle: It is sufficient, would refute the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference completely, so there is no proof that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> would apply the principle in all circumstances.
Once the Gemara raised the issue, it clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> about whom <span class="gemarra-regular">you heard that he said: Semen of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> imparts ritual impurity by carrying? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">not Rabbi Eliezer and not Rabbi Yehoshua. As we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Semen of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> imparts ritual impurity by contact but </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not impart ritual impurity by carrying; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">also imparts ritual impurity by carrying, as it is impossible </span>for semen to emerge <span class="gemarra-regular">without small drops of gonorrhea-like discharge [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ziva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>accompanying it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says there </span>that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts ritual impurity by carrying <span class="gemarra-regular">only because it is impossible </span>for semen to emerge <span class="gemarra-regular">without small drops of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ziva</span> accompanying it. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if not for this </span>reason, the semen would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>impart ritual impurity by carrying, according to the opinions of both Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Eliezer. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the one who holds the opinion that the semen of a <span class="it-text">zav</span> imparts ritual impurity by carrying, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna listing the sources of ritual impurity (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 1:3): <span class="gemarra-regular">Of a greater degree than </span>the ritual impurities listed previously in the mishna, i.e., the impurity of a creeping animal, semen, and one who contracted ritual impurity from a corpse, 

Daf 25b

are the <span class="gemarra-italic">ziva</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his spittle, and his semen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his urine, and the blood of a menstruating woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> all of which <span class="gemarra-regular">impart impurity both by touching and by carrying.</span>
The Gemara questions this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>here too the reason for the severity of ritual impurity of the semen is <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed because it is impossible </span>for it to emerge <span class="gemarra-regular">without small drops of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ziva</span> accompanying it, but it is not due to the impurity of the semen itself. The Gemara rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>that would be <span class="gemarra-regular">so, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach it </span>in the list of bodily fluids <span class="gemarra-regular">along with, </span>meaning list it immediately following, <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ziva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What is different </span>about semen <span class="gemarra-regular">that he teaches it along with: His spittle? Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because its </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">comes from, </span>i.e., it is derived from, that of <span class="gemarra-regular">his spittle, </span>and therefore the semen itself imparts impurity by carrying, even if there would not be small drops of <span class="it-text">ziva</span> accompanying it.
The Gemara returns to the primary discussion concerning the principle: It is sufficient for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: But </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">does not apply </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, </span>at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>such application would <span class="gemarra-regular">not refute </span>the entire <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived that a thick <span class="gemarra-regular">ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> can contract ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">from a corpse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It is a logical derivation </span>based on an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as small </span>clay <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> into which even a finger cannot be inserted because of their narrow opening and <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>despite contact <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">become impure </span>if present under one roof <span class="gemarra-regular">with a corpse, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right that a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mat, which can become impure </span>due to contact <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, will </span>similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">become impure </span>if present under one roof <span class="gemarra-regular">with a corpse?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">cites this </span><span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>to derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the mat becomes ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">with impurity </span>that lasts until <span class="gemarra-regular">nightfall, </span>as it would if it were to come into contact with a <span class="it-text">zav</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>to derive that the mat becomes ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">with impurity </span>that lasts for <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>days, as would any vessel that contracted ritual impurity from a corpse. <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>does he do so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>instead that the <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective </span>in deriving the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the mat can contract ritual impurity from a corpse, but only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>rendering it <span class="gemarra-regular">impure until nightfall, </span>and also say that the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, is effective </span>by limiting the scope of the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the possibility that the mat would be rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">impure for seven </span>days.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Aḥa: This question <span class="gemarra-regular">was already raised </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Zekharya to Abaye, and Abaye said to him </span>in response: This <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> does not derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the mat through an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference from the case of a <span class="it-text">zav</span>. Rather, he <span class="gemarra-regular">derives it from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mat </span>that came into contact <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">he is saying: </span>The first derivation is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">a ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is susceptible to impurity imparted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal? And it is a logical derivation </span>based on an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as small vessels, which </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">pure </span>despite contact <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>nevertheless become <span class="gemarra-regular">impure from </span>contact with the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal, is it not right that a mat, which </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">impure from the impurity of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, will </span>likewise become <span class="gemarra-regular">impure from </span>contact with the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal?</span>
The second derivation is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from where </span>is it derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">a mat </span>contracts impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse? </span>It is derived through a verbal analogy. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>impurity imparted by the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal, it is stated: </span>“Or <span class="gemarra-regular">a garment or leather” </span>(Leviticus 11:32), <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to </span>impurity imparted by <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse it is stated: “A garment, or </span>anything made of <span class="gemarra-regular">leather” </span>(Numbers 31:20). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“garment” and “leather” stated with regard to a creeping animal, a mat </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">impure from it, so too </span>with regard to the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“garment” and “leather” stated with regard to a corpse, a mat </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">impure from it.</span>
The Gemara notes: It must be that the words “garment” and “leather” are <span class="gemarra-regular">free</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., those terms must be extraneous in their contexts, and the Torah included them for the express purpose of establishing the verbal analogy, as a verbal analogy that is based on otherwise extraneous terms cannot be logically refuted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Because if </span>these terms are <span class="gemarra-regular">not free, </span>the verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">can be refuted: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is unique <span class="gemarra-regular">about a creeping animal? </span>It is unique in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">impure </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">a lentil-bulk </span>of a creeping animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall you </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a corpse, </span>whose <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are less strict <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not render </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">impure by means of </span>contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">a lentil-bulk </span>of a corpse but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather by means of </span>contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk? </span>Unless the terms are free, the analogy can be refuted.
The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed,</span> the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">are free. </span>The Gemara proves that the terms “garment” and “leather” are extraneous in their context. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, since </span>ritual impurity imparted by contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal is juxtaposed to </span>ritual impurity imparted by contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">semen, as it is written: </span>“And one who comes into contact with anyone impure with impurity imparted by a corpse, <span class="gemarra-regular">or a man from whom </span>semen <span class="gemarra-regular">is emitted” </span>(Leviticus 22:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">and juxtaposed to that </span>verse is the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or a man who touches any creeping animal </span>which makes him impure, or a person who may make him impure with any impurity that he has” (Leviticus 22:5); <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written with regard to </span>the impurity of <span class="gemarra-regular">semen: “And every garment and all leather that has semen on it </span>shall be washed with water and will be impure until evening” (Leviticus 15:17), since the verses appear next to each other, the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of each can be derived from the other.
Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the words <span class="gemarra-regular">“garment” and “leather” that the Merciful One wrote with regard to a creeping animal? </span>The relevant <span class="it-text">halakha</span> could be derived from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of seminal impurity. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from it </span>that “garment” and “leather” were mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to render them free, </span>i.e., extraneous, but the Torah included them for the express purpose of establishing the verbal analogy.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And still, </span>the terms “garment” and “leather” <span class="gemarra-regular">are free </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from one side </span>of the verbal analogy, because although the terms “garment” and “leather,” stated with regard to ritual impurity imparted by a creeping animal, are extraneous in their context, as the relevant <span class="it-text">halakha</span> could have been derived in another manner, those terms stated with regard to impurity imparted by a corpse are not extraneous in their context. <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who says </span>that with regard to a verbal analogy that is <span class="gemarra-regular">free from </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one side, one can derive from it and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot refute </span>it logically; <span class="gemarra-regular">it is well. But according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one can derive </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verbal analogy of this kind <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">refute </span>it logically, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can be said? </span>It has already been established that the carcass of a creeping animal is stricter in some senses than a corpse.
The Gemara answers: The terms “garment” and “leather,” as stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>impurity imparted by <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse, are also free. Since </span>the impurity of <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse is juxtaposed with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">semen, as it is written: “And one who comes into contact with anyone impure with impurity imparted by a corpse, or a man from whom </span>semen <span class="gemarra-regular">is emitted” </span>(Leviticus 22:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written with regard to semen: “And every garment and all leather that has semen on it” </span>(Leviticus 15:17), <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“garment” and “leather” that the Merciful One wrote with regard to </span>impurity imparted by <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Learn from it </span>that they are mentioned in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to render them free, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it is free from both sides.</span>
The Gemara questions this from a different angle: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who says: Infer </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from it and interpret it according to its </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">place. </span>This would mean that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a mat becomes impure from a corpse is derived from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a mat becomes impure from semen, but the details of that impurity, i.e., the length of the time it is impure, are interpreted according to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of impurity imparted by a corpse, for seven days. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says: Infer </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from it and </span>infer the details of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from it </span>as well, which would mean that the details of the impurity would also be interpreted according to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of impurity imparted by semen, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can be said? </span>According to the latter opinion, it should be concluded that just as the impurity imparted to a mat by the carcass of a creeping animal lasts only until nightfall, so too, a mat rendered impure by a corpse remains impure only until nightfall.
In response to this, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This opinion does not lead to that conclusion, as there is a Torah edict indicating otherwise. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>(Numbers 31:24): <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall wash your garments on the seventh day.” </span>This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">any ritually impure </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">that you render impure </span>due to contact <span class="gemarra-regular">with a corpse must </span>remain impure for a period of <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than seven </span>days. Therefore, since it has been inferred that the mat is susceptible to the impurity imparted by a corpse, it automatically falls into the same category of other items similarly rendered impure by a corpse and must remain impure for a period of at least seven days.
§ Up to this point, the Gemara discussed how to properly apply the principle: It is sufficient for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source. It now returns to discussing the main subject of the mishna, which is the various views concerning Goring, the primary category of damage. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>one be held <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling </span>if these take place <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>with regard to damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, for which, </span>if it took place <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, according to the Rabbis one is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay only half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, yet </span>the owner of the animal is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>then with regard to damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>whose <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are more strict, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right that </span>one should be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain?</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>with regard to Eating or Trampling (Exodus 22:4): <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it consumed in the field of another,” </span>meaning that one’s liability for this form of damage is limited to damage caused on the property of the injured party, but <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. </span>

Daf 26a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are we saying </span>that based on the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference one should have to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the damage caused in the public domain for Eating and Trampling? That would be false, as the verse indicating one’s liability to pay the full cost of the damage limits the application to damage caused in “the field of another.” <span class="gemarra-regular">We are saying</span> only that he should be liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of the damage there, just as with regard to Goring.
The Gemara rejects this as well: This is also incorrect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to the payment of half the damages: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And divide its monetary value” </span>(Exodus 21:35). The use of the expression “its monetary value,” and not “the monetary value,” emphasizes that it is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">the price of this</span> ox that caused damage classified as Goring whose money will be divided, i.e., the owner of the ox will be obligated to pay half the cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the price of another, </span>i.e., not in other cases of damage caused by one’s ox.
The Gemara suggests a derivation from a different inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>one be held <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">only half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling </span>even if the incident took place <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party. This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference drawn <span class="gemarra-regular">from Goring, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>for damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>which is governed by a stricter <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as one is held <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage classified as Goring even if it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>yet one nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">pays</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, then with regard to damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>which are governed by more lenient <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, as one is completely <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, is it not right that </span>he should have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>with regard to Eating and Trampling: “The best of his field and the best of his vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall pay” </span>(Exodus 22:4). The intent of the verse is to emphasize that the owner of the ox pays <span class="gemarra-regular">a proper, </span>meaning complete, amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">payment, </span>and not half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara suggests a derivation from a different inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be held <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>at all with regard to damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the public domain. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>for damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, for which </span>one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>for incidents that took place <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, one is completely <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, </span>then with regard to damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>which is governed by a more lenient <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as one is held <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right that </span>one should be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt in the public domain?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The verse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>in reference to an innocuous ox: “And the carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">they shall </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">divide” </span>(Exodus 21:35), to indicate that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no difference </span>with regard to the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, whether </span>the damage occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">in a public domain or </span>whether it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property.</span>
The Gemara suggests a derivation from a different inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let a person</span> who inadvertently kills another be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay ransom. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the owner of an <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity, </span>i.e., pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation, if his ox injures a person, is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay ransom </span>if it killed someone, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, who is liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity </span>if he injures another, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right that he should be liable to pay ransom </span>if he were to kill him?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> states </span>with regard to an ox killing a person: “He shall give for the redemption of his life <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever is imposed upon him” </span>(Exodus 21:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">“Upon him”: </span>This means upon the owner of an ox who kills a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not upon a person </span>who kills another.
The Gemara suggests the reverse derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that injured a person be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity.</span> This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if a person, who is not obligated to pay ransom </span>if he kills someone, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity </span>if he injures another, then with regard to the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable to pay ransom, is it not right that he should </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">be liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>with regard to this matter: “And if <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span>maims <span class="gemarra-regular">another” </span>(Leviticus 24:19), from which it can be derived that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies when a man harms another person <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>harms <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, </span>in the case of an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that tramples a child in the courtyard of the injured </span>party and kills the child, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the liability of the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay ransom? </span>The Gemara explains the different sides of the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it is with regard to Goring? </span>Accordingly, just with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, once </span>an animal has gored <span class="gemarra-regular">two or three times </span>this becomes defined as <span class="gemarra-regular">its usual manner </span>and therefore it is deemed forewarned <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay ransom </span>in the event that it kills a person by an act classified as Goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too it is not different, </span>as with regard to the category of Trampling the owner is deemed forewarned from the start and he must therefore pay ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>should we say that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>is more stringent, as Goring requires the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intent to cause damage, </span>and that is why the owner must pay ransom in the event of a death; but in a case of Trampling, where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no intent to cause damage, </span>the owner would be exempt from paying ransom?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to this dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into the courtyard of a homeowner without </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">permission, and it gored the homeowner and he died, the ox </span>is killed <span class="gemarra-regular">by stoning and the owner </span>of the ox is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>amount of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, </span>regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Tarfon.</span>
The Gemara proceeds to clarify: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an innocuous </span>ox the owner must also pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>amount of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom? </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not because he holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says </span>that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox that killed a person <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>if the incident took place <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain? And he derived </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">via </span>an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> And if in a case of Trampling, for which one is exempted entirely from liability when it occurs in the public domain, one must nevertheless pay the full ransom if the incident took place on the property of the injured party, with regard to Goring, for which one must pay half the ransom when it occurs in the public domain, is it not right that one should be obligated to pay full ransom for an incident that took place on the property of the injured party? <span class="gemarra-regular">Evidently, </span>it is clear that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a ransom </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shimi of Neharde’a said: </span>It is possible to explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> derived </span>his <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by Trampling: </span>And if in a case of Trampling, for which one is completely exempt from liability when it happens in the public domain, one pays the full cost of the damage done on the property of the injured party, with regard to Goring, for which one must pay half the ransom payment if the ox kills a person in the public domain, is it not right that one would certainly be obligated to pay the full ransom if the person was killed on his own property? According to this reasoning there is no indication that one pays a ransom payment in the case of a child that was killed by Trampling.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if this is the basis for Rabbi Tarfon’s opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">refute </span>it in this way: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>can be learned about ransom <span class="gemarra-regular">from damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by Trampling? These </span>same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">apply to Fire; </span>nevertheless, there is no obligation to pay ransom when a person is killed by Fire, as was stated explicitly in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above (10a). Consequently, the attempt to derive an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference about ransom from Trampling is obviously flawed. The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference can be <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed </span>articles caused by Trampling on the property of the injured party. One would be exempt for damage such as this if it were caused by Fire.
The Gemara responds to this challenge with a different one: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable about damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to concealed </span>articles caused by Trampling? It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that these </span>same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">apply to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>but nevertheless there is no ransom paid if a person is killed by a pit. Consequently, an attempt to derive an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference about ransom from this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is obviously flawed. The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference can be <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>by Trampling on the property of the injured party. One would be exempt for damage of this nature if it were caused by a pit.
The Gemara rejects this as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable about damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels </span>by Trampling? It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that these </span>same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">apply to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire.</span> The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference can be <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed vessels </span>by Trampling. In this case, one would be liable for Trampling but exempt from liability for both Fire and Pit, so this can be the basis for the ransom payment, via the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference stated by Rav Shimi of Neharde’a. The Gemara rejects this as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable about damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to concealed vessels </span>by Trampling? It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that these </span>same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">apply to </span>the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Man, </span>as a person is liable for damage to these items but does not pay ransom if he inadvertently kills another person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that since the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the ransom payment with regard to Goring cannot be deduced from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damages with regard to Trampling, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>his <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling, </span>and therefore it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that this is so. Consequently, in the case of a child trampled to death by Trampling while on his parents’ property, the owner of the animal must pay ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: So too, it is reasonable </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is </span>an obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling, as, if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling, and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> derived </span>his <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by Trampling, let </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">refute it </span>in this way: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable about <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by Trampling? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that these </span>same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">apply to Trampling, </span>while there is no obligation to pay ransom in a case of Trampling. In other words, it would be possible to derive the obligation to pay a full ransom where a person was killed by the Goring of an innocuous ox while on the property of the victim only if there is also an obligation to pay ransom where the person was killed by Trampling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference must be <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling, </span>and therefore it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">evidently, there is </span>an obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Trampling? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it</span> that this is so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">always </span>that of one <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the damage was <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentional or intentional, whether </span>he was <span class="gemarra-regular">awak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> while he caused the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">asleep</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whether <span class="gemarra-regular">he blinded another’s eye or broke vessels, he must pay the full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">He blinded another’s eye, </span>and presumably this is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the other example: <span class="gemarra-regular">Broke vessels. </span>From this it can be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as there, </span>in the case of the broken vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>one must pay for the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>he caused but he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the four types of indemnity, so too, </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he blinds another, yes, </span>he must pay for the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>he caused, but he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the four types of indemnity, </span>since he caused the injury while asleep or unintentionally. 

Daf 26b

With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one must pay the full cost of the damage in a case where there was no intent to cause damage, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥizkiyya says, and similarly, the school of Ḥizkiyya taught: The verse states: “Wound for wound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">petza taḥat patza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 21:25). This phrase is superfluous, as the Torah states elsewhere (see Leviticus 24:19) that one is liable to pay compensation when injuring another. This verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to render him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the unintentional </span>damage just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">for the intentional</span> damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">accident </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">willingly.</span>
The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>indicate that one must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case </span>where he pays compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> caused by the injury. Consequently, it seems that that verse cannot also be the source of the principle derived by the school of Ḥizkiyya. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span> that the superfluous phrase is intended to teach only that, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse write: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Petza</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">befatza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which carries the same meaning. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>then, is meant by the superfluous word <span class="it-text">taḥat</span> in the phrase “<span class="it-text">petza</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">taḥat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">patza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”? </span>It indicates that we must <span class="gemarra-regular">derive two </span>conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from it: </span>That one is liable to pay for pain even in a case where he pays compensation for damage, and that he is liable for unintentional damage as he is for intentional damage, and for damage caused by accident as for damage caused willingly.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a stone lying in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lap and</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">was unaware of it, and he arose and it fell </span>and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damages </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the full cost of the damage caused by the stone. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to the four types of indemnity, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. With regard to Shabbat,</span> if the falling stone caused him to violate one of the prohibited categories of labor; for example, if the stone fell from a private domain to the public domain, he is exempt. The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah prohibited </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">planned, </span>constructive <span class="gemarra-regular">labo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> on Shabbat, and he did not plan to perform this labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to exile, </span>the punishment prescribed for one who unintentionally but negligently kills another, were this stone to kill someone he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as the incident is deemed accidental.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave</span> whose tooth was destroyed or eye was blinded by the stone, potentially enabling the slave to earn his freedom (see Exodus 21:26–27), this is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis, as it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:25): <span class="gemarra-regular">If the master was a doctor and </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Paint </span>the lid of <span class="gemarra-regular">my eye </span>in order to heal it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded it </span>during the procedure, or if the slave requested from his master: <span class="gemarra-regular">Scrape my tooth </span>in order to heal it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">knocked out </span>the tooth while scraping it, the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">has mocked the master, as he is emancipated </span>due to the act of the master himself.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The slave is not emancipated in these cases because the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And destroy it” </span>(Exodus 21:26), from which it is derived that the slave is emancipated <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">intends to destroy </span>the eye or the tooth, but not if he intended to heal the slave. So too, in the case where a stone fell and accidentally blinded a slave’s eye or knocked out his tooth, according to the Rabbis the slave would be emancipated and according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel he would not.
All of the above cases relate to situations where the individual did not know the stone was in his lap. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he was </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">aware of it but forgot about it and he arose and it fell,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to damages </span>he is certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> being that he is liable even if he was unaware of the stone. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to the four types of indemnity,</span> here too he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as he did not intend to cause injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to exil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, as the verse states:</span> “One who <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly </span>strikes a person mortally” (Numbers 35:11), indicating <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>some previous <span class="gemarra-regular">awareness, and </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">he was </span>in fact previously <span class="gemarra-regular">aware </span>of the stone in his lap. The term “unwittingly” is employed to describe someone who possessed knowledge of the potential transgression then forgot about it. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt,</span> as this was not a planned, constructive labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis </span>applies.
In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he intended to throw </span>the stone, and he intended to throw it for a distance of only <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>instead he <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>it a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits, as it went farther than he wanted it to go, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. With regard to the four types of indemnity </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. With regard to Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> he is exempt, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we require planned, </span>constructive <span class="gemarra-regular">labo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> as a condition for liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to exil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> he is liable, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man lie not in wait” </span>(Exodus 21:13), which serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>from the death penalty a situation where one <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to throw </span>the stone for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he actually <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>it for <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits, as he did not intend to kill, so he is exiled. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis </span>applies.
And if <span class="gemarra-regular">he intended to throw </span>the stone <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>instead he <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. With regard to the four types of indemnity</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. With regard to Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if he said </span>to himself when he threw the stone that he would be satisfied <span class="gemarra-regular">wherever it may land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he is liable, as he intended to throw it a distance of four cubits, which is the minimum necessary to violate the prohibited labor of carrying in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>throw the stone aimlessly but rather had selected a target that was eight cubits away, then he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable as he did not perform the precise planned, constructive labor that he had intended. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to exile, </span>the Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man lie not in wait” </span>(Exodus 21:13), which serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>from the death penalty a situation where one <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to throw </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he actually <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>cubits, as he did not intend to kill, so he is exiled. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis </span>applies.
§ Since the Gemara cited Rabba’s comments about various actions for which the perpetrator is liable with regard to certain matters but exempt with regard to others, the Gemara cites similar rulings: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">threw a vessel, </span>such as an earthenware jug, <span class="gemarra-regular">from a roof and another came </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">and broke i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a stic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> during its descent, the latter is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">he broke a broken vessel, </span>meaning that once the vessel was thrown from the roof it was clear that it would be broken upon landing, and therefore it is considered as if it were already broken and the one who broke it while it was still in the air is not liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">threw a vessel from a roof and there were cushions or blankets belo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> so that if the vessel would land on them it would not break, and then <span class="gemarra-regular">another came and removed </span>the cushions or blankets, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the individual who threw the vessel went quickly <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>it landed and <span class="gemarra-regular">removed </span>the cushions or blankets himself, and as a result the vessel shattered, the one who threw the vessel is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from liability even though the vessel broke as a consequence of his actions. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? At the time that he threw </span>the vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows were stopped, </span>i.e., what he did at the time he threw the vessel, which is an act comparable to the shooting of an arrow, did not have the capacity to break the vessel. Therefore, he is not viewed as having broken the vessel, and is exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">threw a child from a roof and another came </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">and impaled him on his sword </span>and the child died, the question of who is liable to receive the death penalty for killing the child is dependent upon <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dispute between Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira and the Rabbis. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">ten people beat </span>a victim <span class="gemarra-regular">with ten sticks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>they did so <span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously or sequentially, they are all</span>

Daf 27a

<span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is impossible to sentence any one of them to death since no one person killed the victim and there is no death penalty for partially killing a person. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: </span>If they beat him <span class="gemarra-regular">sequentially the last one </span>to beat him is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the death of the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he brought </span>the victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death closer. </span>So too, in this case, although the first one threw the child, the one to impale him on his sword was the one to hasten his death, and therefore according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira he would be liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara discusses a similar scenario: If one threw a child from a roof and a forewarned <span class="gemarra-regular">ox came </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">and impaled </span>the child <span class="gemarra-regular">on its horns </span>and the child died, the question of whether or not the owner of the ox is liable to pay ransom is dependent upon <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute between Rabbi Yishmael, son of </span>Rabbi <span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan ben Beroka, and the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall give for the redemption of his life” </span>(Exodus 21:30), indicates that he must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the injured </span>party, i.e., the one who was killed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: </span>He must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the one responsible for the damage. </span>Since the child that was thrown off the roof had no monetary value at the time he was gored by the ox, as it was as if he were already dead, the Rabbis would exempt the owner of the ox from paying ransom. According to Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, the owner of the ox must pay his own value to the family of the victim.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says</span> another similar <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: If a man <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from a roof and </span>while falling <span class="gemarra-regular">was inserted into a woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> due to the force of the fall, but he did not have the intention to engage in sexual intercourse, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the four types of indemnity. And if </span>this woman was <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yevama</span> waiting for him to perform levirate marriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not acquired </span>her as his wife through this act of intercourse. This is true even though a levirate marriage is ordinarily effected through sexual intercourse, even if unintentional, i.e., if he thought she was someone else. Nevertheless, since in this case he did not intend to engage in intercourse at all, the levirate marriage is not effected.
The Gemara explains: What are the four types of indemnity that he is liable to pay? <span class="gemarra-regular">He is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage, for the pain, for the medical costs, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">for the loss of livelihood. But </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable to pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, as we learned </span>in a mishna (86a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One is not liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for humiliation unless he intends </span>to humiliate the injured party, and that was certainly not the case in this situation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>another, similar <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from a roof due to an atypical wind</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such that it could not have been anticipated in advance that he would fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>while falling <span class="gemarra-regular">he caused damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and humiliated </span>the injured party, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the damage </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">the four types of indemnity, </span>as he did not intend to fall. If he fell <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a typical wind and caused damage and humiliated </span>the injured party while falling, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the four types of indemnity, </span>as his fall was caused by negligence. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>as he did not intend to fall. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he tumble</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> while falling so he could fall on this person in order to protect himself from the impact with the ground, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for humiliation as well, </span>because although he did not intend to cause shame he did intend to land on the person.
The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one is exempt from paying compensation for humiliation unless he intended to strike his victim is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the fact that it is stated: “And she extended her hand” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">do I not know that she took </span>hold of something? Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning when further on in <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And she took </span>him by his genitals”? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach you that one who intends to cause damage, even if he does not intend to humiliate </span>the injured party, is nevertheless liable to pay compensation for humiliation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>a hot <span class="gemarra-regular">coal over another’s hear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the latter was burnt and <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the one who placed the coal is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> because the victim should have removed the coal from himself, and the one who placed it there did not need to assume that the victim might not remove it. If he placed the coal <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">garment and </span>the garment <span class="gemarra-regular">was burnt, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage, as it is possible that the one whose garment was burnt thought to sue the one who placed the coal on his clothes for the cost of the garment, and that is why he did not bother to remove it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: We have learned both </span>of these rulings through intimation in <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> elsewhere. With regard to the case of the coal placed <span class="gemarra-regular">over his heart,</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 76b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">held another in a fir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in water, and </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is unable to extricate himself from there and he dies </span>as a result, the one who attacked him is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to receive the death penalty as a murderer. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed him into fire or into the water, and </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to extricate himself from there but he dies </span>anyway, the one who attacked him is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from the death penalty. The case of one who places a coal on another’s chest is similar to the one where he pushes the victim into the fire or the water in a situation where the victim has the ability to escape.
With regard to the case of one who placed a coal on <span class="gemarra-regular">the garment </span>of another, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (92a): If one said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Tear my garment, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Break my jug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the other person does so, the latter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> for the damage. But if one said to another: Tear my garment <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that</span> you will be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from all liability, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span> It is therefore clear that even when one is granted permission by the owner of an item to damage it, that does not grant him an exemption from liability for the damage caused unless that exemption was stated explicitly. Consequently, in a case where the owner did not grant permission, the one who caused the damage is certainly liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raises a dilemma </span>in summation of this discussion: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he placed a coal over the heart of </span>another’s Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave </span>and the slave died as a result, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is the body of the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable to the body </span>of any other person and therefore the assailant would be exempt from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable to </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>owned by the master and therefore the assailant would be liable? Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say</span> that the body of the slave is <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable to the body </span>of any ordinary person, as the slave had the ability to remove the coal from himself and therefore the assailant would be exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where he placed the coal on the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox?</span>
After raising the dilemma Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolves it: </span>The body of <span class="gemarra-regular">the slave is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">comparable to the body </span>of any other person, as the slave possesses an intellect and should have the sense to remove the coal from himself, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox is comparable to </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
We learned in the Mishnah: 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who places a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and stumbles on it and breaks it, </span>the other person is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for what he broke. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the one who stumbled <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damaged by </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">began </span>its presentation of the case <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>stating: In the case of one who places a <span class="it-text">kad</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and ended </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>stating: The owner of the <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span> is liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we learned </span>this interchanging of the words <span class="it-text">kad</span> and <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span> in a mishna (31b) <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: </span>If two people were walking down the street, <span class="gemarra-regular">this one coming with his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that one coming with his </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this one’s </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was broken by that one’s </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the one holding the beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Here too the mishna changed its wording, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">began </span>its statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and ended </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we learned </span>this in another mishna (115a) <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came with his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came with his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of honey, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of honey, </span>which is more valuable, <span class="gemarra-regular">cracked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">poured out his wine and saved the honey </span>by collecting it <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>his vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>receives <span class="gemarra-regular">reimbursement only </span>for his trouble, and he cannot claim the value of the wine that he poured out since the owner of the honey did not tell him to do so. Here too the mishna changed its wording, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">began </span>its statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span> of honey <span class="gemarra-regular">and ended </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span> of honey.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>These examples show that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and the two words are used interchangeably. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>does this make <span class="gemarra-regular">a difference? </span>This makes a difference <span class="gemarra-regular">for buying and selling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If a customer asks for a <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span>, intending a large vessel, and the seller gives him a <span class="it-text">kad</span>, which is a smaller vessel, the buyer cannot claim that he did not receive the item he asked for.
