The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where this is relevant? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a locale where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">do not refer to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor do they refer to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and a <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span> is understood to be referring to a larger vessel, clearly one who asks for a <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span> does not wish to buy a <span class="it-text">kad</span>, as people <span class="gemarra-regular">do not call it </span>that.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that they are equivalent terms with regard to a locale <span class="gemarra-regular">where most </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">call a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., most people use the term <span class="it-text">kad</span> for the smaller vessel and the term <span class="it-text">ḥavit</span> for the larger one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there are also </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who call a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>not distinguishing between the two terms. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority </span>and the seller and the buyer must accept this distinction, 

Daf 27b

the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not follow the majority with regard to monetary matters, </span>and in cases of uncertainty the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
§ The mishna teaches concerning the vessel placed in the public domain: If <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stumbled on it and broke it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>Although this happened in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should examine </span>the road <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then continue <span class="gemarra-regular">walking.</span>
The Sages of the <span class="gemarra-regular">school of Rav said in the name of Rav: </span>The ruling of the mishna is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> one who placed not just one barrel in the road, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">filled the entire public domain with barrels, </span>blocking the path. Since the public domain belongs to everyone, a pedestrian is entitled to traverse the road even if it necessitates breaking the vessels. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says:</span> The ruling of the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught with regard to </span>a case where he broke it in <span class="gemarra-regular">the dark. </span>Therefore, he could not have avoided breaking the barrel by examining the road in front of him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The ruling of the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught with regard to </span>a case where the barrel was placed at <span class="gemarra-regular">the corner </span>of the road, and so the pedestrian could not have seen it, as he rounded the corner, before stumbling on it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: The mishna is precise</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only according to either </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel or </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>but not that of Rav. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>the mishna is explained <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, what </span>is the reason it refers <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled </span>on the barrel? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even if he broke </span>the barrel intentionally he should not be liable to pay, as the owner of the barrel had no right to block the public road.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava </span>in defense of Rav’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">The same is true even if he broke </span>the barrel intentionally. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he wants to teach </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause: And if he incurred damage due to </span>the vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liable</span> to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. As </span>this ruling applies <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically when he stumbled, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he broke</span> the barrel intentionally and incurred damage in the process, the owner of the barrel is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to compensate him. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Although the pedestrian had the right to break the barrel, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is he who damaged himself,</span> by not being careful while breaking it. Therefore, in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled. </span>Accordingly, the mishna’s wording is precise according to Rav’s explanation as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what they say in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Ulla, </span>in explanation of the mishna: Even if the barrel is clearly visible, one who stumbles on it is exempt from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">because the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of people is no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to examine the roads, </span>as they assume that the road is unobstructed. Therefore, one who breaks an item placed in the road as a result of not watching is not liable to pay restitution.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an incident in Neharde’a </span>where a pedestrian stumbled on a jug in an open area and broke it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel deemed him liable </span>to pay for the damage. A similar incident took place <span class="gemarra-regular">in Pumbedita, and Rava deemed </span>the person <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, Shmuel </span>ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his halakhic </span>opinion that the exemption stated in the mishna refers specifically to a case where one stumbles in the dark, as otherwise he is liable for breaking the barrel, since he should have examined the road. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, shall we say that he holds in accordance with Shmuel’s </span>opinion that one who breaks an item in the public domain is exempt from paying for it only if it was dark?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>That inference is not necessary, as this incident <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>at <span class="gemarra-regular">the corner where </span>there was an olive <span class="gemarra-regular">press [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">de’atzera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where it is known that people put their jugs down while waiting for oil. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they were acting with permission, </span>a pedestrian <span class="gemarra-regular">should examine </span>the road <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then continue <span class="gemarra-regular">walking.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda sent </span>the following question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Naḥman: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that when one strikes another, humiliating him, the judges determine liability according to the following formula: <span class="gemarra-regular">For kneeing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rekhuva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> him, he must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">for kicking, five; and for punching [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">velisnokeret</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> him, <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">For </span>hitting him with <span class="gemarra-regular">the handle of a hoe [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">demara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and for </span>hitting him with <span class="gemarra-regular">the top [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ulkofina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a hoe, what </span>amount is one liable to pay him?
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him </span>the following response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥisda, Ḥisda, are you collecting a fin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where judges are not authorized to collect fines? <span class="gemarra-regular">Tell me how the incident itself </span>transpired.
Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him </span>in response: There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain cistern belonging to two </span>people whose arrangement was to alternate its use so <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every day one of them would draw </span>from it in turn. It happened that <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them came and was drawing</span> water <span class="gemarra-regular">on a day that was not his </span>turn. His co-owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is my day </span>to draw, not yours. His colleague <span class="gemarra-regular">did not pay attention to him. </span>The person whose turn it was therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">took the handle of a hoe </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">struck</span> the person who was stealing his water, who then sued for damages.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>In that case, he was right to do so, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">hit him </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">a hundred times with the hoe. Even according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not take justice into his own </span>hands but should go to court, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there would be <span class="gemarra-regular">a loss</span> involved if no immediate action is taken, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may take justice into his own </span>hands.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was stated, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: A person may not take justice into his own </span>hands, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: A person may take justice into his own </span>hands.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Where there is </span>an imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">loss </span>that will be suffered if the injured party does not take action, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that a person may take justice into his own </span>hands. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">when there is no </span>imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">loss </span>that will be suffered. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not take justice into his own </span>hands, <span class="gemarra-regular">because since there is no loss, he should go before the judge </span>to have him enforce the law. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may take justice into his own </span>hands. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he is acting lawfully, </span>as he is clearly in the right, <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not trouble </span>himself to go before the judge to have him enforce the law.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana raises an objection </span>to Rav Yehuda’s opinion based on a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Bag Ba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: Do not enter another </span>person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard </span>secretly <span class="gemarra-regular">to take what is </span>rightfully <span class="gemarra-regular">yours without permission, lest you appear to him as a thief </span>trying to steal his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, break his teeth, </span>i.e., take it by force, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: I am taking what is mine. </span>Evidently one may take justice into his own hands.
Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>

Daf 28a

You can keep this question <span class="gemarra-regular">to yourself, </span>as it poses no difficulty at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Bag Bag </span>states <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual </span>opinion in this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis disagree with him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yannai says </span>an alternative response to Rav Kahana’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean by the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Break his teeth? </span>It means sue him <span class="gemarra-regular">in judgment.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the subsequent statement in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And say to him, </span>is inaccurate. It <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they, </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him. </span>Likewise, the wording: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am taking what is mine, </span>is inaccurate. Since it is the court who makes this statement, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is taking what is his. </span>The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>for Rav Yehuda’s version of the response.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an alternative proof for Rav Naḥman’s opinion. It is stated in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that climbed on the back of another </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to kill it, and the owner of the </span>ox on the <span class="gemarra-regular">bottom came and removed his </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">on top </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fell and died, </span>the owner of the ox on the bottom is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the dead ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the attacker is <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no loss </span>to the owner of the bottom ox, since even if the owner of the ox on the bottom does not remove his ox, he will eventually receive full restitution from the owner of the belligerent ox? Yet he is exempt from paying restitution for causing the death of the belligerent ox. Evidently, he had the right to take justice into his own hands.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the attacker is <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a loss </span>for the owner of the ox on the bottom if he does not save it, since the owner of an innocuous ox pays for only half the damages resulting from his ox’s attack.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say the latter clause </span>of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If, instead of removing his own ox, the owner of the ox on the bottom <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed the one on top and it died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And if </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> He is defending his property so as not to incur a loss.
The Gemara answers: He is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because he should have removed </span>his ox from underneath the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not remove it. </span>Instead, he pushed the belligerent ox and caused it to die. Although one may take justice into his own hands, if he damages another person’s property when he could have protected his own property in a harmless manner he is liable.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof for Rav Naḥman’s opinion from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who fills another’s courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with jugs of wine and jugs of oil, the owner of the courtyard may break </span>his way through them <span class="gemarra-regular">and exit </span>his courtyard or he <span class="gemarra-regular">may break </span>his way through them <span class="gemarra-regular">and enter </span>his courtyard. Since the one who put the jugs there had no right to do so, the owner of the courtyard may take justice into his own hands. This is apparently the ruling even where there is no loss involved to the owner of the courtyard.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said </span>in response that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained as follows: The owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">may break </span>the jugs <span class="gemarra-regular">and exit to court, </span>and he <span class="gemarra-regular">may break </span>the jugs <span class="gemarra-regular">and enter </span>his house <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring </span>proof of <span class="gemarra-regular">his rights,</span> i.e., documents proving that the courtyard belongs to him. Since by refraining from doing so he would sustain a loss, he may break the jugs when exiting and entering. He may not take justice into his own hands beyond this extent. Therefore, no proof for Rav Naḥman’s opinion can be inferred from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an alternative proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to a Hebrew slave </span>who had his ear <span class="gemarra-regular">pierced </span>with an awl to extend his tenure as a slave, but <span class="gemarra-regular">whose days </span>of servitude <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">ende</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with the arrival of the Jubilee Year; <span class="gemarra-regular">and his master is urging [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mesarhev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him to leave </span>but he insists on remaining; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">and inflicted an injury on him </span>in the process of forcing him out, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>from paying for this injury?
To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “You shall take no ransom…that he should return” </span>(Numbers 35:32). Although this verse is referring to the prohibition against an unintentional killer paying a ransom instead of going to a city of refuge, this verse is also interpreted to mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall take no ransom for </span>a Hebrew slave who is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>to his family. In other words, if the slave refuses to return to his family and is injured in the process of his eviction, he does not receive compensation. This seems to indicate that the master may take justice into his own hands even for a matter that involves no loss to him.
The Gemara responds to this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a slave </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and consequently, if he remains a slave, his master will sustain a loss. Therefore, it is permitted for the master to take justice into his own hands and evict the slave by force.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Until now he did not steal, and now he will </span>begin to <span class="gemarra-regular">steal? </span>Why would the master be worried about this just when the slave’s tenure ends? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Until now, </span>while he was still a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">the awe of his master was upon him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so he did not steal from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that he may go free <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have the awe of his master upon him, </span>and the master is therefore worried that he might steal from him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</span> an alternative explanation: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a slave whose master provided a Canaanite maidservant to hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> as a wife and he wishes to remain with her. <span class="gemarra-regular">Until now, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for him to engage in sexual intercourse with her, <span class="gemarra-regular">but now </span>that he is free, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>for him to do so. In this case, his master may evict him forcefully, assuming the role of an emissary of the court, to prevent him from violating the prohibition. Therefore, this is not considered taking justice into his own hands.
The Gemara suggests a proof for Rav Yehuda’s opinion from the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who places a jug in the public domain and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and stumbles on it and breaks it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>It may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>he is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">is that he stumbled on it. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">broke it </span>intentionally, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>This indicates that one may not take justice into his own hands.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: </span>That is not a proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true even if he broke </span>the barrel intentionally. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he wants to teach </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause: </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">if he incurred damage due to </span>the vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥavit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liable</span> to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damages. As </span>this ruling applies <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically when he stumbled, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he broke</span> the barrel intentionally and incurred damage in the process, the owner of the barrel is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to compensate him. Although the pedestrian had the right to break the barrel, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is he who damaged himself, </span>by not being careful while breaking it. Therefore, in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause</span> the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which relates to the case of a woman who, during a fight between her husband and another man, grabs the other man’s genitals: The verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then you shall cut off her hand” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:12), should not be taken literally; rather, it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution. What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she cannot save </span>her husband from his attacker <span class="gemarra-regular">by a means other </span>than grabbing the attacker’s genitals, and nevertheless she is punished? This indicates that one may not take justice into his own hands. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the verse is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she can save</span> him <span class="gemarra-regular">by other means. </span>Otherwise she is exempt from paying restitution.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if she cannot save</span> him <span class="gemarra-regular">by other means, </span>is it possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? If so, instead of teaching </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the expression mentioned in the previous verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And extended her hand” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes an emissary of the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who is authorized to act in this manner and is therefore exempt from paying restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish and teach within </span>the case under discussion in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span>that the wife is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she can save </span>her husband <span class="gemarra-regular">by another means. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she cannot save </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">by other means, she </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is also </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she can save </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">by other means. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she cannot save </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">by other means, her hand is rendered like an emissary of the court, and she is exempt.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof for Rav Yehuda’s opinion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 99b): In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a public thoroughfare would pass through </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">he appropriated it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the public an alternative route <span class="gemarra-regular">on the side </span>of his property, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the route <span class="gemarra-regular">that he has given </span>is the route <span class="gemarra-regular">that he gave </span>them, and they may use it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But his </span>property, which he appropriated, <span class="gemarra-regular">has not reached him, </span>i.e., he cannot appropriate it for his personal use since it was already in public use.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say that a person may take justice into his own </span>hands, why does the owner of the field not have the right to close the thoroughfare? Since it is his property and he gave the public an alternative route, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him take a stick </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pazra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in his hand <span class="gemarra-regular">and sit </span>by the side of the road, preventing the public from passing through.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said in the name of Rava: It is </span>a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree, lest he give them a circuitous route. </span>Since the public has the right to pass through his field, as the Gemara will soon explain, the owner cannot appropriate their thoroughfare without giving the public a similar alternative route. Therefore, the Sages decreed that he cannot appropriate it without their consent, lest he provide an inadequate route.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya said: </span>The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">gave them a circuitous route. </span>If one in fact gives the public a straight path, he need not surrender his rights, and he may take justice into his own hands by blocking the original thoroughfare.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Any </span>route <span class="gemarra-regular">on the side </span>that the property owner might give them <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>necessarily considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a circuitous route, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is close for this </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is far for that </span>person. While some will benefit from the change, it will be detrimental for others.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why has his </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">not reached him? </span>If he cannot make the change, why can he not reclaim the path that he intended to turn over to the public? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him say to them: Take your </span>original route <span class="gemarra-regular">and give me </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>property, so that he will not lose both pieces of land.
The Gemara answers that he cannot reclaim it <span class="gemarra-regular">due to Rav Yehuda’s </span>statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a path that the masses establishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> as a public thoroughfare, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to destroy it </span>for them. Therefore, since the public already began using the alternative route, the owner cannot appropriate it from them.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an alternative proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of a field <span class="gemarra-regular">who left produce in the corner of the field, which is given to the poor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on one side </span>of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and poor people came and took from another side, this </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>produce are both considered <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And if you say that a person may take justice into his own </span>hands, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>both considered <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Let him take a stick and sit </span>in his field on the side from which the poor people are taking produce without his permission, and let him warn them to take only from the side that he allocated.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>In terms of monetary law he can prevent them from taking <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> from the side that he did not allocate. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by the ruling of: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>produce are both considered <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It means that they are considered <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to exempting </span>both portions of produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from tithes. </span>Just as the portion that the poor people took is exempt from tithes, so is the portion that he allocated initially.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and arose early in the morning </span>before anyone else took possession of it <span class="gemarra-regular">and harvested it, </span>the one who renounces ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">individual fallen </span>grapes left for the poor [<span class="gemarra-italic">peret</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">incompletely formed clusters </span>of grapes left for the poor [<span class="gemarra-italic">olelot</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">forgotten </span>clusters of grapes left for the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the four gifts to the poor that the Torah requires one to give from a vineyard (see Leviticus 19:9–10). <span class="gemarra-regular">But he is exempt from the </span>mitzva to <span class="gemarra-regular">tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> his produce, because this requirement does not apply to an ownerless field. Likewise, in the above case the portion of the field that was allocated for <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> is exempt from tithes even after the owner reclaims it, as <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> is considered ownerless property in this regard.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">jug broke in the public domain and </span>another person <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped in the water </span>from the jug and was injured from the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured by the shards </span>of the broken jug, the owner of the jug is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. Rabbi Yehuda says: In </span>a case where the owner of the jug acted <span class="gemarra-regular">with intent, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">without intent, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>that the owner of the jug is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only when the clothes of </span>the one who slipped <span class="gemarra-regular">were soiled by the</span> dirty <span class="gemarra-regular">water. </span>

Daf 28b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the person <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>was injured, the owner of the jug is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the ground </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused his injury, </span>not the jug or the water.
Rav Yehuda continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I stated this </span>ruling of Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shmuel, he said to me: After all, we derive </span>the cases of damage caused by leaving <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s stone, one’s knife, or one’s loa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s pit, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">read, </span>i.e., apply, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all of them </span>the inference of the Sages from the verse: “And an ox or a donkey fall therein” (Exodus 21:33), that the one who dug the pit is liable only if what incurred damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, but not a person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey, but not vessels.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement applies with regard to </span>a situation where the person is <span class="gemarra-regular">killed, </span>i.e., if one fell into a pit and was killed, the person who dug it is exempt from paying restitution, since the verse refers exclusively to an animal that was killed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to damage, </span>the digger of the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay restitution for injury to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, but exempt </span>from paying restitution for damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for which no distinction between death and injury can be applied. Therefore, the ruling in the case of the jug that broke in the public domain should be the opposite. The owner of the jug is liable to pay restitution for injury caused to another, as Shmuel holds that he is liable even if the injury is caused by the impact with the ground, but that he is exempt from paying restitution for the damage done to the clothes of the one who slipped.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> how would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>answer this difficulty? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>presumption that liability for damage caused by one’s stone, knife, or load is derived from the category of Pit, thereby exempting him from payment for damage to vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he renounced ownership of them. But </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not renounce ownership of them, it is </span>considered to be like any other case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his property </span>causes damage. Therefore, he is liable to pay for damage caused to the vessels.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Oshaya raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discussing Pit: It is derived from the verse: “And if a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit and not cover it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fall therein” </span>(Exodus 21:33), that the digger is liable to pay restitution only if what incurred damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox but not a person, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey but not vessels. From here </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox with its equipment fell into </span>a pit, and the ox was wounded <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the equipment <span class="gemarra-regular">broke; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey with its equipment </span>fell in, and the donkey was wounded <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the equipment <span class="gemarra-regular">tore, </span>then the one who dug the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>any injury sustained by <span class="gemarra-regular">the animal but exempt </span>from paying restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">equipment. To what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this similar? </span>It is similar <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his stone, or his knife, or his load that he left in the public domain, and they caused damage.</span>
The Gemara questions the wording of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, it should have </span>stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is similar to this, </span>since the cases of one’s stone, knife, or load are not mentioned in the Torah, but are derived from the case of Pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the wording should be emended as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is similar to this? </span>It is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his stone, or his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">knife, or his load that he left in the public domain, and they caused damage.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">dropped his flask on a stone </span>that was left in the public domain, breaking the flask, the owner of the stone is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The first clause </span>of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav,</span> since it compares the cases of a stone, a knife, and a load to the case of Pit, and it does not distinguish between a situation in which he renounced ownership of them or one where he did not. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the last clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which deems the owner of a stone in the public domain liable to pay restitution for the damage to the broken flask, is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult according to</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel. </span>According to him, the owner should be liable only for causing injury and not for damaging vessels.
The Gemara responds to this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">itself should pose a difficulty for you,</span> since <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>states that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for damage to vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the last clause </span>states that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav resolves </span>the contradiction according <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, and Shmuel resolves </span>it according <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav resolves </span>it according <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>Concerning what case does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rule that a stone, a knife, and a load are analogous to Pit, exempting their owner from liability for breakage to vessels caused by them? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he renounced ownership of them. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not renounce ownership of them he is liable. Therefore, </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">dropped his flask on a stone </span>belonging to another person in the public domain, the owner of the stone is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage to the flask.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel resolves </span>the contradiction according <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you said </span>that the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s stone, one’s knife, and one’s load are similar to one’s pit, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yehuda, who deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels by </span>falling into <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>that he dug, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">therefore liable </span>in a case where someone <span class="gemarra-regular">dropped his flask on </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">stone </span>belonging to him, and the flask broke.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: They taught </span>that the owner of the stone is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pedestrian <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled on the stone and </span>the flask <span class="gemarra-regular">scraped against the stone </span>and broke. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled on the ground,</span> not the stone, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the flask consequently fell and <span class="gemarra-regular">scraped against the stone, </span>causing the flask to break, the owner of the stone is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this statement? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, </span>who maintains that if damage is caused by two people and one of them is exempt from paying compensation, the other must pay the entire amount. Similarly here, since there is no liability for damage caused by stumbling on the ground, compensation should be collected from the owner of the stone.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>an alternative version of this discourse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Do not say </span>that it is only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pedestrian <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled on the ston</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the flask <span class="gemarra-regular">scraped against the stone, </span>causing the flask to break, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is deemed liable, but </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stumbled on the ground and </span>the flask <span class="gemarra-regular">scraped against the stone, </span>causing the flask to break, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Rather, even </span>if the pedestrian <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled on the ground and </span>the flask <span class="gemarra-regular">scraped against the stone, </span>causing the flask to break, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this statement? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that if someone’s jug broke in the public domain and one slipped in the water from the jug and was injured from the fall, or if he was injured by the shards of the broken jug, the owner of the jug is liable. Rabbi Yehuda says: In a case where the owner of the jug acted <span class="gemarra-regular">with intent, </span>he is liable, and in a case where he acted without intent, he is exempt. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which it is considered that he acted with <span class="gemarra-regular">intent?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>Even <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">intends to lower </span>the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">off his shoulder </span>and accidentally breaks it, he is liable to pay for the damage he causes, according to Rabbi Yehuda. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: By inference, does Rabbi Meir, </span>who is the anonymous first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable even </span>if the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">cracked </span>by itself? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Indeed, Rabbi Meir would deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable even </span>if he were holding <span class="gemarra-regular">the handle of </span>the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">in his hand,</span> the optimal manner for holding it, and the handle snapped, causing the jug to fall and break, an accident clearly beyond his control.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is this so? Isn’t he the <span class="gemarra-regular">victim of circumstances beyond his control? And the Merciful One exempts </span>a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond his contro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> from punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to a betrothed young woman who is raped: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But to the young woman you shall do nothing” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:26).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>exemption from the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to damages </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even for circumstances beyond his control, <span class="gemarra-regular">but isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">jug broke and he did not remove its </span>shards, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">his camel </span>fell <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not stand it up, Rabbi Meir deems him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>they cause, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say </span>that

Daf 29a

he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis concede to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s stone, one’s knife, or one’s load, that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he placed them on top of his roof and they fell </span>as a result of being blown off <span class="gemarra-regular">by a typical wind, </span>i.e., one of ordinary force, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they caused damage, that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And Rabbi Meir concedes to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis in </span>the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">puts pitchers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kankanin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the roof in order to dry them, and they fell </span>as a result of being blown off <span class="gemarra-regular">by an atypical wind, </span>i.e., one of unusual force, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they caused damage, that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Evidently, even Rabbi Meir concedes that if one’s property causes damage due to circumstances completely beyond his control, he is exempt.
Accordingly, Abaye rejects Rabba’s explanation of Rabbi Yehuda’s statement, that he deems the owner of the jug liable even if he merely attempted to take it off his shoulder and it broke, and offers another explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye said</span> that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to two </span>different situations. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree</span> with regard to a situation where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they disagree </span>with regard to a situation where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span>in a situation where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall, with regard to </span>whether or not <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles, </span>thereby causing his jug to break, is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles </span>is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as his carelessness caused him to stumble. Therefore, he is liable to pay for damage caused by the shards of the jug, which broke as result of his stumbling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span>in a situation where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall, with regard to one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> renounces ownership of his hazardous property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Presumably, the owner of the jug has no interest in keeping the shards, and it is considered as though he renounced his ownership of them. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property is liable </span>to pay restitution for damage caused by it, despite the fact that it no longer belongs to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exempt </span>from paying restitution, as it does not belong to him anymore.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is this interpretation derived? It is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches two </span>possible cases of damage, stating: Another person <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped in the water or was injured by the shards. This </span>case, slipping in the water, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>seemingly identical to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, injured by the shards. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>necessary to explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>Another person <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped in the water at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall, or was injured by the shards after </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall?</span>
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span>the dispute in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is with regard to two </span>situations, the dispute in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis must <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>relate <span class="gemarra-regular">to two </span>situations, as there too, two cases are mentioned, a case where one’s jug broke and a case where one’s camel fell. Apparently, the dispute is with regard to damage caused both at the time of the fall and after the fall. Rabbi Meir holds that one who stumbles and breaks his jug, causing damage to others, is considered negligent and that one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property is liable, and the Rabbis disagree with regard to both issues.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>with regard to the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s jug </span>broke, <span class="gemarra-regular">you find </span>these circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">either at the time of the fall or after the fall. But </span>with regard to the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his camel </span>fell, <span class="gemarra-regular">granted, you find </span>this circumstance <span class="gemarra-regular">after the fall, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when he renounces his ownership of the carcass, </span>not considering it worth keeping, <span class="gemarra-regular">but how can you find </span>these circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the fall? </span>How can the camel’s falling be considered to be due to the owner’s negligence, possibly rendering him liable to pay for injuries caused by it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa said: For example, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed through water, through the inundation [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">serata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a river </span>that overflowed its banks, and it stumbled there, the owner was negligent, as he should not have gone this way.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If there was another route, </span>and he nevertheless chose this one, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent </span>according to all opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there was no other route, he is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> victim of circumstances beyond his control, </span>and he is exempt from liability according to all opinions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, you find </span>this circumstance in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled and the camel </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled on him. </span>In this case, the Sages engage in a dispute whether or not one who stumbles is considered negligent.
The Gemara asks: According to Abaye’s explanation that the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda is with regard to a situation where the owner of the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">renounces ownership of his hazardous property </span>after it falls, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of Rabbi Yehuda’s statement that if the owner of the jug acted <span class="gemarra-regular">with intent </span>he is liable? What intention <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>after the jug fell and broke?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>It is a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he intends to acquire the shard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the broken jug, and he does not renounce his ownership of them. It is specifically in that case that Rabbi Yehuda holds him liable to pay for damage caused by the shards. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, Rav Ashi said: </span>It is a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he intends to acquire the shards.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: The dispute </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is with regard to a situation where the damage occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But after the fall, </span>according to this statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agree </span>that the owner of the jug is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there Rabbi Meir, who deems </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since he did not remove the shards? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable? But aren’t there the Rabbis, who deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>is the explanation of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">At the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall?</span> It means <span class="gemarra-regular">even at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the dispute is referring to a situation where the damage occurred after the fall and also to a situation where it occurred at the time of the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with Abaye’s </span>explanation of the mishna. 

Daf 29b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>is with regard to a situation where the damage occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after the fall.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But at the time of </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fall, </span>according to this statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agree </span>that the owner of the jug is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">But from the fact that Rabbi Yoḥanan says later </span>(31a), with regard to another mishna in this chapter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not say that the mishna is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, by inference </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir deems </span>one who stumbles <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages. Evidently, it is not unanimously agreed upon that he is exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Does </span>he say that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that he is liable? But from the fact </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says later: Do not say that the mishna is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, by inference </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this </span>is what Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: That </span>the circumstance in <span class="gemarra-regular">which the Rabbis deem one who renounces ownership of his hazardous propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exempt is </span>only the situation stated <span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., where he stumbled, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he is the victim of circumstances beyond his control. But in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> general </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property, they deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for damage caused by it.
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property </span>that he left in the public domain, there is a dispute between the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One said </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and one said </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who deems </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and the one who deems</span> him <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis?</span>
The Gemara responds: No; <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, everyone agrees </span>that one who renounces owner-ship over his hazardous property is liable. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">when they disagree </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>They disagree as to what the opinion of the Rabbis is. <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who deems </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>holds that his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. And the one who deems </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I</span> maintain <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">I say is </span>correct <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis; the Rabbis deem one who renounces ownership over his hazardous property exempt only </span>in the situation <span class="gemarra-regular">here, because he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control. But </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a general </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property, they deem </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">It may be concluded that Rabbi Elazar is the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable, as Rabbi Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">two entities </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">are not in a person’s </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">possession and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse rendered them as though they were in his possession </span>with regard to certain halakhic responsibilities. <span class="gemarra-regular">And these are: A pit </span>that he dug <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and leavened bread </span>remaining in his possession on the eve of Passover <span class="gemarra-regular">from six hours, </span>i.e., noon, <span class="gemarra-regular">onward</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although deriving any benefit from the bread is prohibited, and it is therefore no longer in its owner’s legal possession, nevertheless he is commanded to destroy it. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">It may be concluded </span>that Rabbi Elazar is the one who says that he is liable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Elazar </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this, </span>that one who renounces ownership of his hazardous objects is liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say the opposite? As we learned </span>in a mishna (30a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who turns over dung in the public domain and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. And Rabbi Elazar says: They taught </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who turned over the dung <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to acquire it,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not intend to acquire it </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Apparently, </span>according to Rabbi Elazar, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property is exempt, </span>since he is liable only if he intends to take possession of the dung, even if he moved it significantly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava said: </span>Rabbi Elazar was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he returned </span>the dung <span class="gemarra-regular">to its </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">place. </span>Therefore, he is exempt unless he intended to acquire it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>This can be explained by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a parable: To what is </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava comparable?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> To one who finds an uncovered pit </span>in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">and covers it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">uncovers it again</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since he left the pit as he found it, he is exempt from paying damages, and the liability lies with the one who dug the pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: Is </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, </span>in the case of the pit, the result of <span class="gemarra-regular">the initial act </span>of digging the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">was not removed, </span>since even when he covered the pit, the pit itself still existed. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>the result of <span class="gemarra-regular">the initial act was removed, </span>since once the dung was moved from its prior place, there was no longer any hazardous object there. Therefore, by returning it to its place, the hazard is created anew.
Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is comparable only to one who finds an uncovered pit and fills it </span>with dirt <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">digs it up again, as </span>in this case the result of <span class="gemarra-regular">the initial act is removed, and </span>the new pit therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">exists in his possession </span>and he is liable. Likewise, one who moves dung in the public domain and then restores it to its prior place is deemed liable whether or not he intends to acquire it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said </span>that Rabbi Elazar was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he turned it over at </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">less than three </span>handbreadths, which is not considered removal of the dung from its place.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">what forced Rabbi Elazar to interpret </span>the mishna as referring specifically to the unique case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he turned over </span>the dung <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">less than three </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">is that he intended to acquire it, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not intend to acquire it </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him interpret </span>the mishna as referring to a case where he turned over the dung at a height <span class="gemarra-regular">above three </span>handbreadths, in which case <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he did not intend to acquire it, he is liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>What forced him was that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna was difficult for him. Why </span>does it state <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he turned over </span>the dung? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it teach </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he lifted </span>the dung. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, learn from </span>the fact that the mishna does not use the term: Lifted, which generally is referring to the act of lifting an object three handbreadths for the purpose of acquisition, that <span class="gemarra-regular">whenever </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">turned over </span>is used, it is referring to an act in which the object is lifted to a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">under three </span>handbreadths from the ground.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Elazar </span>was evidently the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that one who renounces ownership of his hazardous object in the public domain is still <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for any damage it causes, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>is clearly the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this, </span>that if one renounces ownership of his object he is exempt from liability for any damage it causes? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (30a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who conceals a thorn or </span>a piece of <span class="gemarra-regular">glass, or who puts up a fence of thorns, or </span>who puts up <span class="gemarra-regular">a fence that </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into the public domain, and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to </span>any of <span class="gemarra-regular">these, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>this person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to one who puts up a fence of thorns, <span class="gemarra-regular">they taught </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only in </span>a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">projects </span>the thorns out into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in </span>a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">restricts </span>them to his own property, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara infers: In a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">restricts </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt?
