Is it not because it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit on his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> By inference, the liability </span>in the category <span class="gemarra-regular">of Pit, </span>according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">is in the public domain, </span>where a pit generally does not belong to the one who dug it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property is liable.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, actually I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>that in principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renounces ownership of his hazardous property is exempt. </span>Nevertheless, one who puts up a fence of thorns is liable, because he does not renounce ownership of the thorns that protrude into the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he restricts </span>the thorns to his own property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>The reason is not that he is not liable to pay for the damage of a pit in his own property, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">because it was stated about </span>this case that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: </span>He is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of people to rub against walls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but to keep a small distance from them. Therefore, if a pedestrian is injured by the thorns, it is considered an unusual accident, for which the owner of the fence is not liable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>one who renounces ownership of his hazardous objects is exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>that in general, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna, and we learned </span>in an unattributed mishna (50b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs a pit in the public domain and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span> This mishna is referring to one who digs a pit in the public domain, where it is not owned by the one who dug it, yet the mishna deems him liable.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that one who renounces ownership of his hazardous objects is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>is it evident that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar say</span>

Daf 30a

<span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Yishmael </span>that one is liable to pay for damage caused by a pit that he dug in the public domain, even if it is not his personal property?
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>ruling, that he is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">is his own </span>opinion, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling, that he is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of his teacher </span>Rabbi Yishmael, and he disagrees with it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who pours water in the public </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">in-curred damage due to it, </span>the one who poured water <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who conceals a thorn or a piece of glass </span>in his wall adjacent to the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">or one who puts up a fence of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thorns</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>one who puts up <span class="gemarra-regular">a fence that </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into the public domain, and others incurred damage due to </span>any of <span class="gemarra-regular">these, he is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for their damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case of one who pours water in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only when the clothes </span>of one who slipped <span class="gemarra-regular">were soiled by the </span>dirty <span class="gemarra-regular">water, but </span>if the one who slipped <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>was injured, the one who poured the water <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt, </span>as it is the impact with <span class="gemarra-regular">the ground </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">injured him, </span>not the water.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said to Rav: </span>Why should he be exempt from paying restitution for the injury? Even if the water that he poured is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">only like his filt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> that he tossed in the public domain, he should be liable. Since the muddy ground caused the injury, and the mud belongs to him, as it results from the addition of his water to the dirt, he should be liable.
Rav responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the water was not absorbed </span>into the ground? It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the water was absorbed, </span>leaving only moist dirt. Since there is no mud there that can be deemed as belonging to the one who spilled the water, he is exempt from liability.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the mishna’s ruling refers only to the soiling of the pedestrian’s clothes, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? According to Rav, this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was already addressed in the previous mishna, with regard to a jug that broke, causing a pedestrian to fall and his clothes to become soiled.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> was stated with regard to a case where this occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">in the summer, </span>the dry season, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one</span> with regard to a case where it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">in the rainy season.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all those</span> people <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>engage in activities that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>are permitted, i.e., those who <span class="gemarra-regular">open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">potkin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their gutters </span>and drain the sewage from their houses into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>those who <span class="gemarra-regular">flush out </span>the water from <span class="gemarra-regular">their caves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where foul-smelling water was stored, into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">during the summer they do not have permission </span>to do so, while <span class="gemarra-regular">during the rainy season they have permission </span>to do so, since the street is rained upon in any event and thereby washed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And although </span>all these people perform their actions <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, if they cause damage they are liable to pay </span>for it. Because of the difference between the summer and the rainy season with regard to whether it is permitted for one to pour water into the public domain, both <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> are necessary, one for each season. This is in order to teach that even in the rainy season, when it is permitted to pour water into the public domain, one is nevertheless liable to pay for damage resulting from the water.
§ It is stated in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who conceals a thorn </span>or a piece of glass, or one who puts up a fence of thorns, is liable to pay for damage resulting from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">projects </span>these obstacles into the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">restricts </span>them to his own property, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exempt? Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of people to rub against walls, </span>but to keep a certain distance from them. Therefore, if a pedestrian is wounded by the thorns, it is considered an unusual accident, for which the owner of the fence is not liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 2:6): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who conceals his thorns </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or his pieces of glass in another’s wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the owner of the wall came and demolished his wall and it fell into the public domain, </span>and the thorns or glass <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, the one who concealed them is liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unstable wall, </span>since the one who concealed his items should have anticipated that the owner of the wall would soon demolish it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a stable wall, the one who concealed</span> his items <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt, and the owner of the wall is liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: That is to say </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who covers his pit with another’s bucket</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the owner of the bucket came and took his bucket, </span>and the pit causes damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the pit is liable.</span>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>This is exactly the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement with regard to one who conceals thorns in an unstable wall, i.e., that the hazardous item was likely to be revealed from the moment that it was concealed, and therefore its owner is liable to pay for any damage that it causes. What is the novel element in Ravina’s statement?
The Gemara answers: It is necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: </span>It is only <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of the thorns, that the owner of the wall is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he did not know </span>who concealed the hazardous item in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to inform him </span>that he should remove them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, since </span>the owner of the bucket <span class="gemarra-regular">knew </span>who dug the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have informed him </span>that he was taking his bucket and is consequently liable to pay for damage caused by the pit, Ravina therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that he is not required to inform the owner of the pit, and he bears no responsibility for any damage caused.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: The early pious people would conceal their thorn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and their pieces of glass in their fields, and would dig to the depth of </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>in order to bury them, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that they would not obstruct the plow.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet would toss </span>his thorns <span class="gemarra-regular">into fire, </span>so they would not cause damage to others. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava would toss them into the Tigris [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Diglat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> River.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: One who wants to be piou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should observe the matters of </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Nezikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so as to avoid causing damage to others. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>he should observe <span class="gemarra-regular">the matters of </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Avot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And some say </span>he should observe <span class="gemarra-regular">the matters of </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Berakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes out his straw [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">teven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and his hay [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain to </span>use afterward as <span class="gemarra-regular">fertilizer and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to them, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage, and whoever </span>takes possession of the hay and straw <span class="gemarra-regular">first acquires </span>them for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who places obstacles in the public domain and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they cause damage, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">and whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them.
In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who turns over dung in the public domain and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to it,</span> the former <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the ruling in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>that one is liable to pay for damage caused by straw or hay that he put in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: During the period when fertilizer is taken out</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person may take his fertilizer out to the public domain and let it accumulate </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">for a full thirty days, so that it gets trampled by people’s feet and by animals’ feet, as </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on this condition</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua bequeathed Eretz </span>Yisrael to the Jewish people (see 80b). In other words, people do not have the right to prevent someone from taking out his straw to the public domain, since they received their portion of Eretz Yisrael following Joshua’s conquest on this condition. Apparently, since one has the right to take out his straw, he is not held liable to pay for damage caused by it.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>possibly <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes that if </span>the fertilizer <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>he is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay for the damage it caused, </span>although he acted within his rights.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says:</span> If a pile of straw on the back of an animal that was passing through the public domain catches fire <span class="gemarra-regular">from a Hanukkah lamp </span>that was placed outside a store, the owner of the lamp is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, since he </span>put it there <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission </span>(see 62b)? <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not because </span>he put it there with the <span class="gemarra-regular">permission of the court </span>and is therefore exempt from paying for damage caused by it?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he put it there with the <span class="gemarra-regular">permission </span>granted to those performing <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva. </span>Permission of the court is not sufficient to exempt him from paying damages, unless, in addition, permission was granted for the purpose of performing a mitzva. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that if it caught fire <span class="gemarra-regular">from a Hanukkah lamp </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt because </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">permission </span>to put it there in order to perform <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> an alternative proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>cases in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>for people <span class="gemarra-regular">to place obstacles in the public domain,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if they caused damage, </span>these people <span class="gemarra-regular">are liable to pay, and Rabbi Yehuda exempts </span>them. Evidently, according to Rabbi Yehuda, if one has the permission of the court to put an item in the public domain, he is exempt from paying damages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: The mishna</span> is referring to a case where one put his fertilizer outside <span class="gemarra-regular">not during the period when fertilizer is taken out. </span>Therefore, he did not have permission to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who holds that one is liable only if he acts without permission.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>an alternative explanation of the mishna according to Rabbi Yehuda: 

Daf 30b

What <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna was specifically with regard to a case where one put out <span class="gemarra-regular">his straw and his hay, </span>which are more likely to cause injury than fertilizer and other objects, <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">slippery. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda agrees that in this case he is liable to pay for damage they cause.
§ It is stated in the mishna that if one puts his straw and hay out in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them. The Sages disagreed with regard to the extent of this acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>He acquires them <span class="gemarra-regular">both with regard to </span>the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves and with regard to </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t,</span> which took place while they were in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ze’eiri says: </span>He acquires them <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancement but not with regard to </span>the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves, </span>and he must pay the owner of the straw according to their value at the time he placed them in the public domain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they disagree? Rav holds </span>that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">penalized </span>the owner by revoking his ownership of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves due to </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancement </span>that he stands to earn by putting them in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas Ze’eiri holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not penalize </span>him by revoking his ownership of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves due to </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancement. </span>Rather, he loses only the increase in their value due to their enhancement.
The Gemara attempts to prove that Ze’eiri’s opinion is correct from a case where there is no enhancement at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the continuation of the mishna that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who turns over dun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the public domain and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to it, </span>the former is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. But it does not teach </span>in this clause that <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever </span>takes possession of it <span class="gemarra-regular">first acquires </span>it. Apparently the Sages did not revoke his ownership of the dung, as it has no enhanced value. This does not seem to accord with Rav’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that whoever takes possession of it acquires it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught in the first clause, </span>with regard to one who puts out straw, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true in the last clause,</span> with regard to one who turns over dung. It is unnecessary to repeat it. Therefore, no support for the opinion of Ze’eiri can be derived from here.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in that regard, </span>i.e., a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses the same cases as the mishna, that the hay and straw <span class="gemarra-regular">are forbidden due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, </span>which apparently means that one may not take possession of the dung, contrary to Rav’s opinion?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are forbidden due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, it applies to the entire mishna, </span>not just to this particular clause, and it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>taking the items from <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who came first and acquired </span>them. In other words, once someone takes possession of them, it is forbidden for anyone else to take them from him, as that is considered robbery.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is not taught in this manner </span>elsewhere, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes out his straw and his hay to the public domain to </span>use afterward as <span class="gemarra-regular">fertilizer and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">incurred damage due to them, he is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and is permitted </span>to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery. And </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who turns over dung in the public domain and another incurred damage due to it, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable, but it is forbidden </span>to take possession of it <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>Is it from the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dung </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you raise a contradiction </span>to Rav’s opinion that one may take possession of straw and hay in the public domain? With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that has </span>added value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>over time as a result of lying in the public domain, Rav holds that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">penalized </span>one who leaves it in the public domain, revoking his ownership of the item <span class="gemarra-regular">itself because of its </span>added value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement, </span>but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that does not have </span>added value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>by lying in the public domain, such as dung, perhaps Rav concedes that <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not penalize </span>him in this manner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the statement of </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">who says that they penalized </span>him by revoking his ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">the items themselves because of its </span>added value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement, do we impose </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">penalty immediately </span>when he takes the straw out, allowing one to take possession of it even before it has time for its value to become enhanced, <span class="gemarra-regular">or do we impose the penalty </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">when its enhancement </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof that the penalty is imposed immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that we spoke of </span>a difficulty to Rav’s opinion from the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dung, </span>whose value does not become enhanced, indicating that according to Rav the penalty is imposed before there is any enhancement.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>this proof? <span class="gemarra-regular">When we spoke </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">dung, </span>this was <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Naḥman </span>bar Yitzḥak <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved </span>the difficulty, explaining that perhaps Rav concedes that there is no penalty in this case. But <span class="gemarra-regular">after Rav Naḥman resolved </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it at all possible to raise an objection </span>to Rav’s opinion from the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dung? </span>Therefore, no proof can be brought from there.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that this dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is stated in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a document in which </span>a loan with <span class="gemarra-regular">interest is written</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we penalize </span>the lender, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">collects neither the principal nor the interest; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: He collects the principal but not the interest. Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir,</span> whose penalty applies to the value of the loan itself due to its enhancement, i.e., the interest, which is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ze’eiri stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who impose the penalty only on the interest?
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I stated </span>my opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis. The Rabbis were saying there </span>that the principal is not forfeited by the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">only because the principal </span>was loaned <span class="gemarra-regular">in a permissible </span>manner, as the prohibition applies only to the interest. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of one who put his straw in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal, </span>i.e., the hazardous object <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, causes damage. </span>Therefore, the penalty should relate to the object itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ze’eiri </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I stated </span>my opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir. </span>The reason <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir was saying there, </span>in the case of a loan with interest, that the principal is also forfeited is <span class="gemarra-regular">only that </span>the prohibition was already violated <span class="gemarra-regular">from the time of the writing</span> of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">by making an appraisal [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shuma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of how much money is to be repaid, which included interest. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of straw that one placed in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that it will cause damage? </span>Since the damage was not inevitable at the time that the straw was placed there, there is no justification for revoking the ownership of the straw itself.
The Gemara suggests alternatively: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the dispute between Rav and Ze’eiri is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is stated in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes his straw and his hay out to the public domain to </span>use afterward as <span class="gemarra-regular">fertilizer, and another incurred damage due to them, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for his damage. And whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they are forbidden due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who places obstacles in the public domain and they cause damage, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay. And whoever </span>takes possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">them first acquires </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are permitted </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter itself is difficult. </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and then it says that they are forbidden due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, </span>indicating that one may not take possession of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is this not what </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>This statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancement. </span>And this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">But they are forbidden due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves? And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel came to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>with regard to the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves, whoever </span>takes possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of them first acquires </span>them. Therefore, this tannaitic dispute apparently relates to whether the penalty applies to the items themselves or just to the value of their enhancement.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Ze’eiri, it is certainly </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel explicitly deems it permitted for one to take possession of the items. According <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav, shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara responds that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span>According <span class="gemarra-regular">to all </span>opinions, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">imposed a penalty </span>revoking his ownership of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves due to </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">their enhancement. And here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>whether or not it is ruled that this is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>a public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling is not issued to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that effect, as it was stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed as to whether the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> revoking his ownership of the items themselves should be taught to the public. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>This is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but </span>a public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not issued to that effect</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, although it is permitted for one to take possession of the straw, halakhic authorities should not publicly rule that people may do so, lest people become accustomed to taking items that belong to others. This is the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava says: </span>This is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>a public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling is issued to that effect. </span>This, Rav could have said, is the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But didn’t Rav Huna declare dried barley [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥushelei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that people laid out in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless? </span>Similarly, didn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava declare ownerless</span>

Daf 31a

<span class="gemarra-regular">residue from dates?</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, Rav Adda bar Ahava </span>acted <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his halakhic </span>opinion that although this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, a public ruling is not issued to that effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he retracted </span>his prior opinion?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>owners of the barley <span class="gemarra-regular">were forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to remove the barley from the public domain, and they did not comply. Therefore, they were penalized by Rav Huna declaring publicly that their barley was ownerless.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">potter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> carrying pots <span class="gemarra-regular">who were walking one after the other </span>in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the first stumbled </span>on a bump <span class="gemarra-regular">and fell, and the second stumbled over the first </span>and fell too, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage incurred by the second.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Do not say that the mishna is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, even </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Rabbis, who say </span>that one who stumbles <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstances beyond his control and is </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, here, </span>in the case in the mishna, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, since </span>after falling <span class="gemarra-regular">he had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not stand </span>up.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">he had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to warn </span>the person behind him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not warn </span>him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to war</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> the other person either, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> busy </span>trying to stand up. Therefore, the mishna, which holds him liable, must be referring to a case where he could have stood up.
The Gemara attempts to prove that the opinion of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak is correct. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the next mishna (31b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of </span>a cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam was </span>walking in the public domain carrying his beam <span class="gemarra-regular">first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the owner of a barrel was</span> walking with his barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">last, </span>i.e., behind him, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel was broken by the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the one who carried the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But if the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam stopped, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since the accident was caused by his stopping.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one carrying the cross beam <span class="gemarra-regular">stopped </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to adjust </span>the load <span class="gemarra-regular">on his shoulder, which is the normative behavior </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>one carrying a beam, and is not considered negligence? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>nevertheless the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as, although <span class="gemarra-regular">he had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to warn</span> the person behind him that he was about to stop, he did not warn him. This supports the opinion of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he stopped to rest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which could not have been anticipated by the person walking behind him. Consequently, he is liable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this interpretation, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stop-ped to adjust </span>the load <span class="gemarra-regular">on his shoulder, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">rather than teaching </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of that mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to the owner of the barrel: Stop, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish and teach within </span>the former case <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that he is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stopped to rest. But </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stopped to adjust </span>the load <span class="gemarra-regular">on his shoulder, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara answers: The mishna is presented in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner because it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this </span>novelty, <span class="gemarra-regular">that even if he stopped to rest, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he says to the owner of the barrel: Stop, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an alternative proof from what is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">potters and glazier</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who were walking one after the other, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the first stumbled</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fell, and the second stumbled over the first, </span>sustaining damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the third </span>stumbled <span class="gemarra-regular">over the second, </span>also falling and sustaining damage, in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of the second, and the second </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of the third. But if they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">fell because of the first, the first </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of them all. And if they warned each other, </span>i.e., each one warned the next, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, and they are nevertheless liable to pay for not warning the people behind them, in accordance with the opinion of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up and they did not do so.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this interpretation, if <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would they be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? If so, rather than teaching </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If they warned one another, they are exempt, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish and teach within </span>the former case <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that they are liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not have </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are exempt.</span>
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is presented in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner because it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this </span>novelty, <span class="gemarra-regular">that even if they had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when they warned each other they are exempt.</span>
§ With regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The first </span>one who stumbled is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of the second, both for damage caused </span>to the second person <span class="gemarra-regular">by his body and for damage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">by his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of the third </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage caused by his body </span>as result of the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not with regard to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> caused by his property.</span>
The Gemara questions Rava’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever way</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you </span>look at it, this is difficult to understand. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Rava maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the second </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">should also be liable </span>to pay for all forms of damage caused by his negligence. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>Rava maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, even the first should be exempt</span> from liability for the damage incurred by the second. 

Daf 31b

The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first is certainly</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and is therefore liable to pay for damage caused by both his body and his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">The second is deemed liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his body, as he had </span>the opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to stand </span>up <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not stand </span>up. <span class="gemarra-regular">For </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his property </span>that was lying there and that caused the third person to stumble and fall, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as he can say to him: I did not dig this pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., I did not cause this obstacle. Since it was the first person who stumbled and brought about the situation where the items of the second were lying on the ground, the second is not deemed liable.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rava’s statement from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that comments on this case: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of them are liable</span> to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage caused by their bodies and exempt </span>from paying restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage caused by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their property. What, does this not </span>refer <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the first, </span>indicating that even he is exempt from damage caused by his property?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to all of them <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the first. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them, </span>indicating that the first is also included? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava said: </span>The term <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them </span>refers only to <span class="gemarra-regular">those who incurred damage,</span> and excludes the first one, who only caused damage to others.
The Gemara questions this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>interpretation? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the term includes <span class="gemarra-regular">even the first, this </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught: All of them. But if you say </span>that it is referring to all of them <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the first, what is </span>the reason that the misleading term: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of them </span>is used? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>more accurately that <span class="gemarra-regular">those who incurred damage </span>are liable in turn for the damage caused by their bodies, but are exempt from paying restitution for damage caused by their property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this entire explanation of Rava’s statement should be rejected, and it should be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable both for injury </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the body of the second and for damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the property of the second, and the second </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">incurred by the third with regard to injury to his body but not with regard to damage to his property. What is the reason </span>for the exemption in the last case? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>after his fall, the body of the second person <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, and we do not find that </span>in the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shmuel, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any obstacle </span>that was placed in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">constitutes a pit, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a pit apply to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the one who placed it there <span class="gemarra-regular">renounces ownership </span>of the hazardous object it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>renounce ownership of it then it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>The second one who fell obviously did not renounce ownership of his body, so why is he exempt from damage he caused to vessels as though he were a pit?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually,</span> Rava’s statement should be explained <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he was understood to have <span class="gemarra-regular">said initially, </span>i.e., that he distinguishes between damage caused by another’s body and damage caused by his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And as for your difficulty </span>from the statement in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of them are liable </span>to pay for the damage caused by their bodies but exempt from paying restitution for the damage caused by their property, apparently including even the first one, contrary to Rava’s opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Minyumi interpreted it before Ravina </span>as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where vessels were damaged by vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, it is not the body, but the vessels of the second that were damaged by the property of the first, and since the broken vessels of the first have the status of a pit, the owner is exempt from liability for damage caused to the vessels of others.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>above: <span class="gemarra-regular">If they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">fell because of the first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the first </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for the damage of them all. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How did they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">fall because of the first? Rav Pappa said: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he blocked the road like a skeleton [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keshilda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> filling the entire width of the road and causing the rest to stumble over different parts of his body. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>He fell diagonally <span class="gemarra-regular">like a blind man’s cane</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and they all stumbled over him.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">with his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">barrel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>from the opposite direction <span class="gemarra-regular">with his </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this one’s jug was broken by that one’s </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the one carrying the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, because this one had permission to walk </span>in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">had permission to walk </span>there.
If they were walking in the same direction, so that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam was </span>walking <span class="gemarra-regular">first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in front, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of a barrel last, </span>behind him, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel was broken by the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since the owner of the barrel saw him in front of him and should have been more careful. 

Daf 32a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But if the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam stopped</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> causing the barrel to collide with the beam and break, the former is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since the latter had no way of anticipating that he would stop. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he said to the owner of the barrel: Stop, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for breaking the barrel.
Conversely, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the barrel was </span>walking <span class="gemarra-regular">firs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam last, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel was broken by the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if owner of the barrel stopped, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for breaking the barrel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said to the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam: Stop, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And similarly, </span>these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one came with his lamp and that one came with his flax, </span>and the lamp set fire to the flax.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Natan asked Rav Huna: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who causes injury to his wife during sexual </span><span class="gemarra-regular">intercourse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is he liable to pay damages? Is it reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he is acting in a permitted manner </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, or perhaps he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should pay attention </span>and be more careful?
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabba bar Natan: <span class="gemarra-regular">You learned this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna concerning one person walking with a cross beam and another with a barrel, which rules that the owner of the cross beam is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because this one had permission to walk and that one </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">had permission to walk. </span>Similarly, since the husband has permission to engage in intercourse with his wife, if he injures her in the process he is exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>disagreed with Rav Huna’s opinion and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The husband is liable due to an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to manslaughter, as it is stated in the Torah: “As when a man goes into the forest with his neighbor to chop wood…and the head slips off the helve, and finds his neighbor, and he dies; he shall flee to one of these cities and live” (Deuteronomy 19:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">forest, where this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">entered his domain and that </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">entered his domain, </span>as it is the domain of the public, and nevertheless the one who kills unintentionally is <span class="gemarra-regular">considered like one who entered another’s domain and </span>is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to be exiled to a city of refuge, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">enters another’s domain, all the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that he should be liable for the injury he causes her?
The Gemara raises an objection to Rava’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> what of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">which teaches </span>that the owner of the cross beam is exempt, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this one had permission to walk and that one had permission to walk, </span>and Rav Huna inferred from here that the husband is likewise exempt.
The Gemara answers: The two cases are different. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>sides <span class="gemarra-regular">were similarly </span>walking, and the one who caused the damage is therefore exempt due to his right to walk there. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>the husband is the only active participant in the intercourse. Therefore, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">performing an action, </span>he is liable even though he is acting with permission.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is she not </span>considered an active participant? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written </span>with regard to forbidden sexual intercourse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Even the souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people” </span>(Leviticus 18:29), indicating that both the man and woman are considered to be performing an action?
The Gemara answers: The verse is referring to the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">they both have pleasure</span> from the act. The woman’s pleasure is tantamount to active transgression, and she is therefore punished if she participates willfully. But with regard to a wife’s injury, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>the one who is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">performing an action,</span> and he is therefore liable.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam was </span>walking <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>and the owner of the barrel was walking behind him, if the barrel was broken by the cross beam, the owner of the cross beam is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">two cows </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">prone and one walking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the cow that was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking kicked the </span>cow that was <span class="gemarra-regular">prone, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">prone </span>cow <span class="gemarra-regular">kicked </span>the cow that was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>this statement, as it states: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam was first and the owner of the barrel was last, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel was broken by the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, he is exempt. But if the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam stopped, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">prone </span>cow kicked the cow that was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking, </span>since the one carrying the barrel was walking and the one carrying the cross beam stopped in the public domain, causing damage to the former. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in this case that the owner of the cross beam <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable.</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>that reasoning? <span class="gemarra-regular">You wanted to support </span>the statement of Reish Lakish from the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Not only does it not support </span>Reish Lakish; <span class="gemarra-regular">it even raises a difficulty </span>to his opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>Reish Lakish stated that the owner of the prone cow is liable is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it kicked</span> the walking cow; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the walking cow <span class="gemarra-regular">was damaged </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself </span>it collided with the prone cow, he would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But the mishna </span>discusses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one carrying the barrel ran into the cross beam <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself, </span>without the one carrying the cross beam actively hitting it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it teaches </span>that the owner of the cross beam is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the cross beam <span class="gemarra-regular">blocked the </span>entire width of the <span class="gemarra-regular">road like a carcass. </span>Since the one carrying the barrel could not avoid it, the one carrying the cross beam is liable although he did not actively break the barrel. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>Reish Lakish’s statement is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">was lying down on one side </span>of the public domain, and the other cow <span class="gemarra-regular">should have walked on the other, </span>unobstructed <span class="gemarra-regular">side. </span>Therefore, if the damage is caused only as a result of their collision, the owner of the prone cow is exempt.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause of the mishna </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">supports Reish Lakish’s </span>statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches: </span>Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if the owner of the barrel was </span>walking <span class="gemarra-regular">first and the owner of the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam last, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel was broken by the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if the owner of the barrel stopped, </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for breaking the barrel. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the walking</span> cow kicked <span class="gemarra-regular">the prone </span>cow. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the owner of the cross beam is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>lending support to Reish Lakish’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>exempts the one carrying the cross beam <span class="gemarra-regular">because he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was walking in his normal manner </span>when he hit the barrel. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>perhaps the owner of the prone cow <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the walking cow: <span class="gemarra-regular">Although you have permission to walk over me, </span>i.e., for your cow to walk over my cow, <span class="gemarra-regular">you have no permission to kick me, </span>i.e., for your cow to kick my cow.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who were walking in the public domain, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">running and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or who were both </span><span class="gemarra-regular">running</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and they damaged one another, both of them are exempt.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Isi ben Yehuda. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isi ben Yehuda says </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">runs </span>in the public domain and causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay for any damage he causes <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>his behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">is unusual </span>in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Isi concedes </span>with regard to one who runs and causes damage at <span class="gemarra-regular">twilight on the eve of Shabbat that he is exempt, because he is running with permission.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Isi ben Yehuda. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this, </span>that if one runs and causes damage he is liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say, </span>as a principle, that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with an unattributed mishna? And we learned </span>in this mishna that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one was running and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one was walking, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they were both running, they are exempt.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna, </span>which exempts one who was running, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> twilight on the eve of Shabbat, </span>when people are permitted to run in the public domain.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it inferred that the mishna is referring to twilight on the eve of Shabbat? It is inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it teaches: Or who were both running, they are exempt. Why </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do I need this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well? Now </span>that the mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one was running and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one was walking, </span>the one running is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state that he is exempt when <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them were running? Rather,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was running and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one was walking, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to twilight on the eve of Shabbat, </span>when running in the public domain is permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">But on a weekday, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one was running and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one was walking, </span>the one who was running is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">both were running, even on a weekday, they are exempt. </span>This emendation explains the need to mention the case where both were running.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>above: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Isi concedes </span>with regard to one who runs and causes damage at <span class="gemarra-regular">twilight on the eve of Shabbat that he is exempt, because he is running with permission. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the reason that running at twilight <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of Shabbat </span>is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rabbi Ḥanina </span>would say, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥanina would say </span>at twilight on the eve of Shabbat: 

Daf 32b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Come and let us go ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to gree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the bride, the queen. And some say </span>that this is what he would say: Come and let us go out <span class="gemarra-regular">to greet Shabbat, the bride, the queen. Rabbi Yannai would wrap himself </span>in his <span class="it-text">tallit</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and stand </span>at the eve of Shabbat at twilight, <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: Come, bride</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> come, bride. </span>Similarly, it is appropriate for one to run out in honor of Shabbat.
