<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who was chopping </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and </span>a chip flew off and <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">private property </span>of another person, or one who was chopping wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property and caused </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage in the public domain, </span>or one who was chopping wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">private property </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">another, </span>in all these cases he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to teach that he is liable in all these cases because in each one there is a novel element. <span class="gemarra-regular">As if it had taught </span>only the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who was chopping </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property and caused damage in the public domain,</span> it might have been reasoned that he is liable, despite the fact that he was working in his private property, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">multitudes </span>to be there. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if a chip flew <span class="gemarra-regular">from the public domain to </span>another person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">private property, where </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not common </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">multitudes </span>to be, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. Therefore, it is necessary to teach this case as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if it had taught </span>that he is liable where the chip flew <span class="gemarra-regular">from the public domain to </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">private property, </span>it might have been reasoned that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because at the outset he was acting without permission by chopping wood in the public domain. But </span>if it flew <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property to the public domain, since he was acting with permission </span>by chopping wood in his private property, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. Therefore, it is necessary to teach both cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">had taught </span>only that he is liable in <span class="gemarra-regular">these two</span> cases, it might have been reasoned that in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where the damage was caused in the public domain, he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">multitudes </span>to be there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he was chopping in the public domain, he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he was acting <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission. But </span>in the last case, where the chip flew <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">another’s private property, </span>where neither of the above reasons applies, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not common </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">multitudes </span>to be in the place where the damage was caused <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>was acting <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission at the outset, </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to teach all these cases.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 6:25): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who entered the workshop of a carpenter without </span>the latter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">permission, and a chip of wood flew off and hit him in the face and he died, </span>the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if he entered </span>the shop <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission,</span> the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it rules that the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: </span>If the other person was injured, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of indemnit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that one who injures another must pay. These are: Cost of the damage, pain, medical costs, and loss of livelihood. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the one who entered was killed, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from exile.</span>
The Gemara explains that he is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forest, </span>which is the archetypal case stated in the Torah requiring one who kills unintentionally to be exiled, as it is written: “As when a man goes into the forest with his neighbor to chop wood, and his hand fetches a stroke with the axe to cut down the tree, and the head slips off the helve, and finds his neighbor, and he dies” (Deuteronomy 19:5). This is because in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">forest, </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this one entered his domain and that one entered his domain, </span>as anyone may use the public domain, whereas in <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> case, the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">entered another’s property. </span>Therefore, the carpenter is not exiled.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>On the contrary; it can be inferred <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that he is exiled. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">forest, </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">this one entered of his own accord and that one entered of his own accord, </span>neither asking for the other’s permission, nevertheless the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered like one who entered with the other’s consent and </span>therefore the one who kills unintentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">is exiled, all the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">entered another’s </span>workshop <span class="gemarra-regular">with his consent, </span>the carpenter should be exiled?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: What </span>is the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exempt from exile? As exile is not sufficient for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this is the reason of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, </span>who exempts him from exile: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because it is </span>an <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentional </span>killing that is <span class="gemarra-regular">approaching intentional </span>manslaughter. The purpose of exile is to atone for one who kills another completely unintentionally; if he was exceedingly negligent, exile is not sufficient to atone for him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>to his own explanation from a mishna: If one is sentenced to be flogged in court and the doctors assessed that he would be able to endure only a certain number of lashes, but the one administering the lashes <span class="gemarra-regular">added one lash to his </span>punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">and he died, </span>the agent of the court <span class="gemarra-regular">is exiled on account of him </span>(<span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 22b). <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unintentional </span>killing that is <span class="gemarra-regular">approaching intentional </span>manslaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it should have entered his mind that people can die by one </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">lash. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the agent of the court <span class="gemarra-regular">is exiled. Rav Shimi of Neharde’a said </span>in response: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he erred in the counting, </span>which is not considered approaching intentional manslaughter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava slapped </span>Rav Shimi <span class="gemarra-regular">on his sandal, </span>a gesture of disparagement, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Is that to say </span>that the one administering the lashes is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">counts</span> them? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the eldest of the judge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> recites </span>the verses that are read to a person while he receives lashes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>judge <span class="gemarra-regular">counts, and the third says </span>to the one administering the lashes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Strike him? </span>Accordingly, it is not the one administering the lashes who erred in counting.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Shimi of Neharde’a said: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the judge himself erre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in counting, and the one administering the lashes did not notice this error and meted out an extra lash, causing the person to die. It is therefore considered a completely unintentional killing. Consequently, he is exiled.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from another mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who throws a stone into the public domai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and kills </span>someone, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exiled.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But here, </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional </span>killing that is <span class="gemarra-regular">approaching intentional </span>manslaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it should have entered his mind that people are commonly </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exiled.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak said: </span>It is not a case where one threw a stone into the public domain for no purpose, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">where he demolishes his wall, </span>which borders on the public domain, and stones fall into the public domain. Therefore, it is not considered to be approaching intentional manslaughter.
The Gemara questions this assertion: Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have paid attention </span>to see if there was anyone there, and therefore it should be considered an unintentional killing that approaches intentional manslaughter. The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he demolishes </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">at night.</span>
The Gemara asks: Even <span class="gemarra-regular">at night, he should also have paid attention </span>to see if there was anyone there. The Gemara suggests an alternative interpretation: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he demolishes his wall during the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day into a garbage dump</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where people are not commonly found.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this garbage dump? If </span>it is a garbage dump <span class="gemarra-regular">where the multitudes are commonly </span>found, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">intentional </span>manslaughter. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the multitudes are not commonly </span>found there, he should be considered not only one who kills unintentionally, but <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstances beyond his control,</span> since he could not have anticipated that someone would be there. Therefore, he should be exempt from exile.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a garbage dump where </span>people are <span class="gemarra-regular">given to relieve themselves at nigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and are not given to relieve themselves during the day, </span>as it is near the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">But there are those who chance by and sit </span>there for this purpose even during the day. On the one hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not </span>one who kills <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, as </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are not given to relieve themselves </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">during the day. </span>On the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not a victim of circumstances beyond his control either, as there are those who chance by and sit there. </span>Therefore, he is considered one who kills unintentionally and is liable to be exiled.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa taught in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>aforementioned statement of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina is in reference not to the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> but is <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the first clause: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who enters the workshop of a carpente</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without permission, and a chip </span>of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">flies off and strikes him in the face and he dies, </span>the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>In reference to this clause <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: </span>If the one who entered was merely injured, the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity. But </span>if the one who entered was killed, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from exile.</span>
The Gemara comments: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who teaches this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the last clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where one enters with permission, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>would he teach it <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the first clause, </span>where one enters without permission. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the one who teaches this</span> statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the first clause </span>teaches it only in reference to that clause. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in the </span>case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">last clause, since </span>he entered <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission </span>the carpenter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to go into <span class="gemarra-regular">exile.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is he liable </span>to go into <span class="gemarra-regular">exile </span>when the victim had permission to enter? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who enters the workshop of a welder, and sparks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nitzotzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fly off and strike him in his face and he dies, </span>the welder is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">entered with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permission?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here, </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with the welder’s apprentice </span>who enters his workshop. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does the welder’s apprentice stand to be killed, </span>i.e., is it permitted to kill him? The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where his mentor is urging him to leave, and he does not leave.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And because his mentor is urging him to leave, does he stand to be killed? </span>The welder should be careful until his apprentice leaves. The Gemara answers: The welder <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>had already <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>when the accident happened. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>why establish that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers specifically to an apprentice? The welder would be exempt if it were any <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">also. </span>

Daf 33a

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have awe of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his mentor. </span>Therefore, even if the welder urges another person to leave, he must ascertain that that person actually did so, and otherwise he is liable to be exiled. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>apprentice <span class="gemarra-regular">has awe of his mentor, </span>and so the welder may assume that if he instructed him to leave, he certainly did. Therefore, if in reality the apprentice did not leave and is killed by the sparks, the welder is not liable to be exiled, as he is not held accountable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid taught in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>aforementioned statement of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina is in reference not to the above <span class="it-text">baraita</span> but is <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is stated in the verse concerning one who kills unintentionally: “And the head slips off the helve, <span class="gemarra-regular">and finds </span>his neighbor, and he dies” (Deuteronomy 19:5); this serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who introduces himself </span>into an area of danger, in which case the one who kills unintentionally is exempt from exile. <span class="gemarra-regular">From here Rabbi Eliezer Ben Ya’akov says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one whom a stone departe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from his hand, and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">stuck out his head and received </span>a blow from <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>and died, the one who threw the stone is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from exile. It is in reference to this statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: He is exempt from exile </span>for killing him. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the victim was merely injured, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who teaches this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>he would teach it <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the first </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where one entered the workshop of the carpenter. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the one who teaches it with regard to the first </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches it only in reference to that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from liability for injury, as one could claim that he is completely blameless.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to salaried <span class="gemarra-regular">laborers who came </span>into their employer’s courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">to claim their wage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the homeowner, and the homeowner’s ox gored them, or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the homeowner’s dog bit them, and </span>a laborer <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Others say </span>that he is liable, as salaried <span class="gemarra-regular">laborers are allowed </span>to enter their employer’s property <span class="gemarra-regular">to claim their wages from the homeowner.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>the employer <span class="gemarra-regular">can be found in the city, what is the reason of the others, </span>who hold him liable? The laborers could have met him in the city to claim their wages and did not need to enter his courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he can be found </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at home, what is the reason of the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who exempts him? Clearly they are entitled to claim their wages.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>these are not the circumstances under discussion. This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a man who can </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">be found </span>in town <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be found </span>in town, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the laborers <span class="gemarra-regular">called </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">at the gate </span>of his courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he said to them: Yes. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>referred to as the others, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">yes </span>in this context <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates: Come in. </span>Therefore, he is liable for their death. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">yes </span>in this context <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Stand in your plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and I will come out to you. Since he did not give them permission to enter, he is exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes </span>in this context <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates: Stand in your place. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to a salaried <span class="gemarra-regular">laborer who entered </span>his employer’s courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">to claim his wages from the homeowner, and the homeowner’s ox gored him, or his dog bit him, </span>the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt, although </span>the laborer <span class="gemarra-regular">entered with permission. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if the laborer entered with permission? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>because it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the laborer <span class="gemarra-regular">called </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">at the gate, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes? Conclude from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes </span>in this context <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates: Stand in your place.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two innocuous oxen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span><span class="gemarra-regular">other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the respective damages are evaluated, and if one amount is more than the other, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half the damages with regard to the difference. </span>In other words, the owner of the ox that caused the greater damage pays the other owner half the difference. If <span class="gemarra-regular">both oxen were forewarned, </span>the owner of the ox that caused the greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference.</span>
In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the oxen was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox caused greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox than the reverse, the owner of the forewarned ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference. </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox caused greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half the damage with regard to the difference.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two people who injured each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the one who did greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference, </span>since one is always considered forewarned with regard to damage he causes.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">person, </span>whichever side caused the greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference. </span>In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">person, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the person </span>caused greater financial damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference. </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox caused greater damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to the person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half the damage with regard to the difference. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that injured a person also pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference. </span>Rabbi Akiva does not distinguish between an innocuous and a forewarned ox in a case where an ox injures a person.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis about a case where an ox injures a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>It is derived from the verse: “Whether it has gored a son, or has gored a daughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to this judgment shall it be done to him” </span>(Exodus 21:31), that <span class="gemarra-regular">as is the judgment </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox</span> that causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ox, so is the judgment </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to a person. Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ox,</span> if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>he pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to a person, </span>if it is an <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and </span>if it is a <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox the owner pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">full</span> cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>It is derived from the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“according to this judgment” </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an ox that gores a person is judged <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the case that appears in <span class="gemarra-regular">the lower </span>verse, i.e., the case of a forewarned ox, which appears in Exodus 21:29, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not like </span>the case that appears in <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper </span>verse, i.e., the case of an innocuous ox, which appears in Exodus 21:28.
One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that since the case of an ox that gored a person is compared to the case of a forewarned ox, the owner also <span class="gemarra-regular">pays from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Shall it be done to him [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">l</span><span class="gemarra-italic">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>indicating <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the proceeds of the sale of the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of his belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not pay from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, as the word <span class="it-text">lo</span> can also be understood as referring to the ox. In this manner the case of an innocuous ox that gores a person is compared to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of an innocuous ox that gores another ox, whereas with regard to the amount of restitution, it is compared to the case of a forewarned ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who do not differentiate between an ox that gores a person and one that gores an animal, inasmuch as the distinction between an innocuous and a forewarned ox applies in both cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the seemingly superfluous word <span class="gemarra-regular">“this”? </span>The Gemara answers: The word is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt him from the four</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> types of indemnit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that one who injures another person is liable to pay, thereby emphasizing the comparison to the case of an ox that gores an ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where does Rabbi Akiva </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">exempting him from </span>paying these <span class="gemarra-regular">four types of indemnity? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He derives it from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if a man maims his neighbor, </span>as he has done, so shall be done to him” (Leviticus 24:19). Rabbi Akiva derives from here that only when <span class="gemarra-regular">a man </span>injures <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor </span>is he liable to pay these four types of indemnity, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>injures <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>not derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from that verse? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it would have been derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have said </span>that he is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>from paying for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs and loss of liveli-hood, </span>I would <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give him </span>compensation. Therefore, the phrase “according to this judgment” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span> that he is not liable to pay compensation for anything other than the damage itself.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass </span>of the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not worth anything, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">takes the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>that gored it, since it is worth half the value of the damage.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna, </span>which rules that the injured party takes the ox immediately? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: After it gores another ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>belligerent <span class="gemarra-regular">ox shall be appraised in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> before it is taken by the injured party, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: The ox was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">assigned </span>to the owner of the dead ox as payment, and if the amount of damages is not contested by the owner of the goring ox, no further legal steps are required.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? Rabbi Yishmael holds </span>that the owner of the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>of the owner of the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is money that he is claiming from him, </span>but he has no ownership of the body of the belligerent ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are partners, </span>i.e., from the time the innocuous ox killed the other ox, the owner of the dead ox has a share of ownership in the belligerent ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree with regard to </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">this verse: “Then they shall sell the live ox, and divide its monetary value” </span>(Exodus 21:35). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is commanding the court</span> to evaluate the damages in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is commanding the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage </span>to split ownership of the live ox, without the involvement of the court.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two opinions as to whether or not they are considered partners? The Gemara answers: There <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>the ox to the Temple. According to the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael, until the court transfers the ox to the injured party, it still belongs to its owner, and therefore the injured party cannot consecrate it. According to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, the injured party owns the ox from the time the damage was inflicted, and he can therefore consecrate it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava asked Rav Naḥman: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage sold </span>the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yishmael? </span>Is it that <span class="gemarra-regular">since Rabbi Yishmael says </span>that the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor, and it is </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">money that he is claiming from him, it is sold? Or perhaps</span>

Daf 33b

does he say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liened </span>to the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">to the injured </span>party, who will collect it should the ox’s owner not have sufficient funds, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not in his </span>power to sell it? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is not sold.</span>
Rava asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, it is sold? </span>Rav Naḥman replied: Nevertheless, the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">then collects it</span> from the purchaser. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">then collects it </span>from the purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">is it sold? </span>His right to collect it negates the effectiveness of the sale. The Gemara answers: It is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ridya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The purchaser may use the ox for plowing until the injured party collects it from him, and the purchaser is not required to reimburse the injured party for the use of his ox.
The Gemara asks: Should one <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>this ruling that with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sells </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, the court can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of </span>the creditor, as according to Rabbi Yishmael the belligerent ox is only a lien for the debt owed to the injured party? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is different,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like one who rendered it designated payment </span>of the debt, since the Torah specifies that the injured party collects damages from the ox. In general, however, movable property that is sold by a debtor cannot be collected by the creditor.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rava say </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered his slave </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repayment </span>for a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor collects </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the purchaser, whereas if one rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repayment and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it, the creditor cannot collect </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the purchaser? This contradicts the previous statement that the belligerent ox is considered designated repayment, and therefore even if it is sold the injured party can collect it from the purchaser.
The Gemara answers: The distinction made in Rava’s statement answers this question. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave </span>who was rendered as designated repayment can be collected from the purchaser? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>rendering a slave as designated repayment is not common and generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity. </span>The purchaser was therefore aware of this when he bought the slave. Similarly, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, since it gored </span>an animal, it generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity, as </span>it is publicly <span class="gemarra-regular">called a goring ox,</span> and so the purchaser was aware of the lien attached to it. Therefore, the injured party can collect it from the purchaser.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Taḥalifa from the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Abbahu: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, it is not sold, </span>but if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, it is consecrated.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who sold it? </span>Is it the injured party or the liable party? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for the damage, whose </span>opinion is it that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not sold? It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">assigned </span>to the injured party. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the following statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox shall be appraised in court.</span>
If, <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party selling it, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is it that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, it is not sold? </span>It is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael,</span> who holds that the injured party has no share of ownership in the ox until it is transferred to him by the court. But in the statement that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not seem to accord with either opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one liable for the damage, and everyone agrees </span>with its ruling. The ruling that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, it is not sold </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, as </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liened to the injured </span>party, precluding the owner from selling it.
The statement that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Akiva, </span>since it is not actually consecrated but is considered so only <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abbahu. As Rabbi Abbahu says </span>that if one consecrates liened property, although the consecration does not take effect, nevertheless he is required to redeem it, due to a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree lest </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property can be <span class="gemarra-regular">removed </span>from the ownership of the Temple treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">without redemption. </span>Therefore, the ineffectiveness of the ox’s consecration notwithstanding, he is still required to redeem it, by means of minimal payment, so as not to cause the denigration of Temple property.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous ox that caused damage, </span>if, <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he sold it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">sold</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or gave it as a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what he did is done, </span>i.e., takes effect. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he stood tria</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> and is now obligated to pay the injured party, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, it is not sold; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, it is not consecrated; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it or gave it is a gift, he has done nothing.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">creditors</span> of the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">collected </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he owed </span>the creditors <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>his ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage or whether it caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage before he owed </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they have done nothing. </span>Their collection is void, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>compensation to the injured party is <span class="gemarra-regular">paid only from the body of </span>the ox, as it was innocuous, and it is therefore designated exclusively for this compensation.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial or whether he did not stand trial, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">sold; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it or gave it as a gift, what he did is done. </span>Likewise, if <span class="gemarra-regular">creditors collected </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">first, whether he owed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">before it caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it caused </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage before he owed </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">did is done. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the restitution is <span class="gemarra-regular">paid only from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, not from the body of the ox. Therefore, what he or his creditors do with the ox takes effect.
The Gemara explains the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>above, with regard to an innocuous ox, that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">sold. </span>As explained above, the sale is valid only with regard to the purchaser using the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing</span> in the interim, until the injured party collects it.
The statement that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>does not mean that it is actually consecrated, but rather that it must be redeemed through payment of a minimal sum, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to Rabbi Abbahu’s </span>statement mentioned above.
With regard to the statement that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it or gave it as a present, what he did is done, </span>the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave it as a present, what he did is done </span>with regard to the recipient’s permission to use it <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it, </span>how does that affect the injured party’s rights? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him come and receive payment from </span>the slaughtered ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">meat.</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is stated in the Torah: “Then they shall sell the <span class="gemarra-regular">live </span>ox” (Exodus 21:35). <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that the injured party receives a share of ownership if the belligerent ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive. From where</span> do I derive that this applies even if the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it? The verse states: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“Then they shall sell </span>the live <span class="gemarra-regular">ox,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case, </span>whatever the circumstances, the injured party is paid from proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheizevi said: </span>This statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to the diminished </span>value of the ox due to its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. </span>Although the value of the ox may no longer cover the damage, its owner is not liable to compensate the injured party beyond the ox’s current value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who causes damage to another’s liened property is exempt </span>from paying compensation, since the property does not actually belong to the one who holds the lien.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this inference from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, states this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case where one slaughters a liened ox, that he is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he can say to him: I have not detracted anything from </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">yours, as he can say to him: I took only spirit from </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">yours. </span>He detracted only the life of the ox, not its physical body, and one who causes damage to another’s liened property might be exempt from liability for this intangible damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But generally </span>one who causes damage to another’s lien <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable. </span>Therefore, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that one is exempt from liability for all types of damage he causes to another’s liened property.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba stated this </span>principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>and there would be no need for Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, to state it. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabba says: One who burns another’s documents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which other people’s debts to him are recorded, <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt,</span> although the owner of the documents can no longer collect payment from liened property.
The Gemara answers: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, states this principle <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span> specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>that he is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the perpetrator of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the documents: <span class="gemarra-regular">I burned your mere paper, </span>for which I am prepared to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one dug pits, ditches, or caves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>liened land, causing substantial damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should be liable </span>to compensate the one holding the lien. Therefore, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that even in a case of substantial damage he is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>where the ox was slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">is like one who dug pits, ditches, or caves, </span>as slaughter is considered substantial damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">what he did is done.</span>
The Gemara continues to explain the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states: If <span class="gemarra-regular">creditors collected </span>the innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">first, whether </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">owed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>his ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage or whether it caused damage before he owed </span>them, they <span class="gemarra-regular">have done nothing, because </span>restitution is <span class="gemarra-regular">paid only from the body of </span>the ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>in the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it caused damage before he owed </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured parties came first, </span>and the ox is liened to the debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he owed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">before it caused damage, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">creditor </span>collected it <span class="gemarra-regular">first, </span>so why does he not have the preemptive right to the ox? 

Daf 34a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, even </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage before he owed </span>them, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">the creditor </span>came <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>and seized what he rightfully deserved. Should one <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if <span class="gemarra-regular">a later credito</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> collected </span>a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>an earlier creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">his collection is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not valid </span>and payment should instead be given to the earlier creditor?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; actually, I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the collection of </span>the later creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is valid, and there, </span>in the case where a creditor seized the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is different, as </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the creditor who seized the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was in your possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would I not have collected it from you? </span>The reason I would take it is <span class="gemarra-regular">that I am paid from this ox that caused me damage. </span>Therefore, the creditor cannot collect the ox, even if the debt preceded the damage.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> injured it, </span>reducing its value <span class="gemarra-regular">by fifty dinars [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zuz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the injured ox subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">appreciated </span>in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at four hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> while if </span>the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">had not injured it, its </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">would have </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at eight hundred dinars, </span>in this case the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him </span>only twenty-five dinars, which is half the value of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time the injury </span>occurred.
If the injured ox <span class="gemarra-regular">depreciated </span>in value and its worth is now less than at the time it was injured, the damage is evaluated <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the ox’s worth at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial. </span>In other words, the owner of the belligerent ox must pay the difference between its value before it was injured and its current value.
If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that caused the injury, </span>from which the owner of the injured ox collects damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">appreciate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in value, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the injured party a share of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the injury. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">it depreciated</span> in value, the owner gives him a share <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the first clause of the second half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that caused the damage appreciated </span>in value, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the injured party a share <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the ox’s value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the injury. </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>apparently in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor, and it is money that he is claiming from him, </span>as he has no share of ownership in the belligerent ox.
The Gemara states a difficulty with this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the second half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">depreciated </span>in value, the owner gives the injured party a share <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial. </span>Here <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that the owners of the two oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">are partners, </span>i.e., the injured party has a share of ownership in the belligerent ox. How can it be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael’s </span>opinion, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>follows the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is all </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva </span>that they are partners, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here, </span>in the case where the belligerent ox appreciated in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the reason it appreciated is that its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">fattened it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Though the injured party has a share of ownership in the ox, he has no share in the appreciation in value, and his share is therefore calculated according to its value at the time of the injury.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">fattened it, say the first clause </span>of the first half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, stated with regard to the injured ox: If <span class="gemarra-regular">it appreciated </span>in value, and its value <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at four hundred dinars, </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the injury. If </span>this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">fattened it, need it be said </span>that the owner of the belligerent ox is not exempt from compensation?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: You find </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the first half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to be true <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he fattened it or whether it appreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself. And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">found it necessary </span>to mention this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach </span><span class="gemarra-regular">us that </span>even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">appreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the injury </span>and not at the time of the trial. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">you find </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the second half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, with regard to a case where the belligerent ox appreciated in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">fattened it.</span>
It is stated in the latter clause of the first half of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the injured ox <span class="gemarra-regular">depreciated </span>in value, it is evaluated <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>its worth at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to what did it depreciate </span>in value? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">depreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">due to labor </span>for which it was used, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the liable party <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You reduced </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">value and I should </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>you extra compensation?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it depreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span>continuous effect of the <span class="gemarra-regular">wound, as </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: The horn of your ox is buried in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it is still losing value due to the wound.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred, and the carcass is worth nothing, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">about this </span>type of case that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “Then they shall sell the live ox, and divide its monetary value” </span>(Exodus 21:35).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said to him: And that is </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>yet your interpretation of the verse is incorrect. <span class="gemarra-regular">You have upheld </span>the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then they shall sell the live ox and divide its monetary value,” </span>which fits your interpretation of the case. But <span class="gemarra-regular">you have not upheld </span>the latter clause of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the dead they shall also divide,” </span>since in the case you mentioned the carcass is worthless. Rather, to <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>case is the verse referring? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worth fifty dinars. </span>In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the living </span>ox, one hundred dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the </span>value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dead</span> ox, twenty-five dinars; <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>party also <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the living </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dead </span>ox.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored an ox worth two hundred</span> dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worth fifty dinars, this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the living </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dead </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>party also <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the living </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dead </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this is the </span>case of the belligerent <span class="gemarra-regular">ox stated in the Torah. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: This is not </span>the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ox stated in the Torah. Rather, </span>it is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worth nothing. </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">about this </span>case that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then they shall sell the live ox, and divide its monetary value.” Rather, how do I realize </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the dead they shall also divide”?</span> This clause means that the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminished </span>value of the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that was diminished by </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>is compensated for by <span class="gemarra-regular">dividing </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the live </span>ox between the two parties, while its owner does not receive a share in the carcass of the dead ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, both Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda </span>hold that in the case described by Rabbi Yehuda, where the carcass is worth fifty, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred and twenty-five, and that </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred and twenty-five. </span>Rabbi Meir holds that the injured party keeps the carcass, worth fifty, and receives another seventy-five dinars, half the value of the damage, from the proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox. Its owner is thereby left with one hundred and twenty-five dinars out of the two hundred that it is worth. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that the value of both oxen is split between the two parties, leaving each with one hundred and twenty-five. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span>? Why does it matter in which manner the compensation is calculated?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> There is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the carcass depreciates in value between the ox’s death and the time it is sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass </span>is sustained <span class="gemarra-regular">by the injured </span>party. The one liable for the damage is not responsible for any depreciation in value that occurs after the loss caused by the attack has been evaluated. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">half of the diminishing </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the carcass </span>is sustained <span class="gemarra-regular">by the one liable for damage, </span>since he receives half of the dead ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, we have found, according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rabbi Yehuda, </span>

Daf 34b

a case where the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox that causes damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is more stringent than </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, since according to all opinions, in a case where a forewarned ox kills another ox, the carcass belongs exclusively to the injured party, and he sustains any subsequent decrease in its value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, </span>Rabbi Yehuda holds that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an innocuous ox is more stringent than with regard to a forewarned ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>If a bailee did not safeguard an ox properly, and it escaped and caused damage, if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox he <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable, and </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox he <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>(45b), that mishna cannot serve as proof for the issue under discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you heard Rabbi Yehuda </span>express this opinion, that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an innocuous ox is more stringent, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding, as verses are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the Torah from which this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is derived. But <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to compensation, did you </span>ever <span class="gemarra-regular">hear him </span>express this opinion?
