On the contrary; <span class="gemarra-regular">but isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth one hundred dinars that gored an ox worth five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worth one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., four dinars, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half the living </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the dead </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half the living </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the dead </span>ox. Accordingly, the injured party receives fifty-two dinars in value, which is much more than his ox was worth before it was killed.
Instead, continues Rabbi Yehuda, you should <span class="gemarra-regular">say: For what </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">singled out </span>by the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">to render it </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent </span>than the case of an innocuous ox, or <span class="gemarra-regular">to render it </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient? </span>Clearly, <span class="gemarra-regular">you must say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to render it </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent. </span>And therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">what he damaged </span>and no more, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient, all the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that the owner is not liable to pay more than the value of the damage? Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda does not allow for liability in the case of an innocuous ox to be more stringent than in the case of a forewarned ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rava’s explanation, that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda disagree with regard to a case where the carcass depreciated in value, should be rejected. Instead, their dispute should be explained according to what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said, </span>i.e., that the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the appreciation of the carcas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in value after the ox’s death; <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the entire increased value of the carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the injured </span>party, since the owner of the belligerent ox has no share in the carcass, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the increased value belongs to the injured party and half goes to the one liable for the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>explains <span class="gemarra-regular">what was difficult for Rabbi Yehuda </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One has mercy on the one liable for damage, as he takes </span>a share <span class="gemarra-regular">of the increased value </span>of the carcass, <span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>it be that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored an ox worth one hundred dinars, and the carcass is worth fifty dinars, this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half the live </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the dead </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half the live </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the dead </span>ox? Accordingly, the owner of the belligerent ox receives thirty-five dinars in value, which is more than his ox was worth.
Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Where do we find </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage gains </span>from the damage, comparable to this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">where this </span>owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gains, </span>receiving more than the value of his ox? Clearly there is no such case, as one who is liable for damage does not gain from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in addition, <span class="gemarra-regular">it says: “He shall pay” </span>(Exodus 21:36), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays, and the owner does not take </span>more than the amount his animal was worth at the time of the damage.
The Gemara asks: For <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>reason was it necessary to add the claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says: </span>“He shall pay”? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter, </span>that the one liable for damage does not gain, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a loss sustained by the injured </span>party, as in this case, where the decrease in the ox’s value is fifty dinars, and if the carcass is shared by the liable party, the injured party receives only thirty-five dinars, thereby sustaining a loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no loss sustained by the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox worth five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the carcass </span>appreciated in value and is now <span class="gemarra-regular">worth thirty dinars, </span>more than the ox was worth when it was alive, in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage also takes </span>a share <span class="gemarra-regular">of the increased value, </span>since the injured party ends up not having sustained any financial loss, as he receives a share of ten dinars in the belligerent ox and another fifteen in the carcass, gaining five dinars over the value of his ox.
It is to counter this claim that Rabbi Yehuda adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says: “He shall pay,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays, and the owner does not take </span>more than the amount his animal was worth at the time of the damage.
§ With regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion that the two owners split the value of both the belligerent ox and the dead ox between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Taḥalifa said to Rava: If so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we find </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yehuda, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox gores an ox that is worth less than it, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays more than half the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But the Torah stated: “Then they shall sel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the live ox, and divide its monetary value” </span>(Exodus 21:35).
Rava answered him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that only the <span class="gemarra-regular">diminished </span>value of the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that was diminished</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>is compensated for by <span class="gemarra-regular">dividing the live </span>ox between the two parties. The liable party never pays more than half the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>does Rabbi Yehuda derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass they shall also divide” </span>(Exodus 21:35), from which Rabbi Meir derived it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Yehuda </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">derive from </span>this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the live </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and half the dead </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the live </span>ox and <span class="gemarra-regular">half the dead </span>ox?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if that is the only <span class="it-text">halakha</span> indicated by this clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">write: And the carcass </span>they shall divide. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the reason that the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“also” </span>is added? It is added so that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude two </span>conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the clause: That the carcass is also divided between the two parties, and that the liable party is never required to pay more than half the damage.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>are cases where one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for an act of </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox, but exempt </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>if he performed it <span class="gemarra-regular">himself. </span>Conversely, there are also cases where one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for the action of his ox, but liable for his own action.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox caused </span>a person<span class="gemarra-regular"> humilation,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox blinded the eye of his slave or knocked out his</span> slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">tooth, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from having to emancipate the slave for this mutilation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his slave’s eye or knocked out his tooth, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to emancipate him, as stated in the Torah (Exodus 21:26–27).
By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox injured </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father or his mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">injured his father or his mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation. Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox set fire to a haystack on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">set fire to a haystack on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying damages. He is exempt from payment in these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty for injuring his father or mother or for desecrating Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yoḥanan: Anyone who performs </span>labor <span class="gemarra-regular">destructively </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">except for one who injures </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">or kindles </span>a fire. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not fit for discussion in the study hall. The opinion that deems one liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">injuring </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">or kindling </span>a fire on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a mishna </span>and should be ignored. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say that it is a mishna, one who injures </span>another would be liable only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he requires </span>the blood to give <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dog</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who kindles </span>a fire would be liable only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he requires its ashes. </span>In these cases, the act is not purely destructive but has some constructive purpose.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox set fire to a haystack on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">set fire to a haystack on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. And </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>set the fire in a scenario that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his ox </span>did so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where his ox </span>set the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need </span>the ashes, as an ox does not act with such intentions, 

Daf 35a

<span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>in the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>set the fire, it is presumably a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not need </span>the ashes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>nevertheless, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt because he is sentenced to death. </span>Apparently, one who lights a fire on Shabbat is liable even if he does not need the ashes, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the comparison is the other way around; the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>set the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>set the fire. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>is liable for lighting a fire on Shabbat is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where he needs </span>the ashes, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>setting fire to the haystack is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where it needs </span>the ashes.
The Gemara asks: In the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>set the fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you find these </span>circumstances, where it did so because it needed the ashes? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avya said to him: Here we are dealing with an intelligent ox that was bitten on its back and wants to burn down</span> the haystack <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">roll around [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">iggandar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the ashes </span>in order to heal the bite.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we know </span>that this is the reason that it set the fire? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because after </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>the haystack, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was rolling around </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the ashes.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is there </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">a case like this? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, as a certain ox that was at the house of Rav Pappa had a toothache. It went inside, and broke the lid </span>of a utensil, <span class="gemarra-regular">and drank the liquor </span>inside <span class="gemarra-regular">and was cured</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Evidently there are oxen with this level of intelligence.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said before Rav Pappa: How can you say </span>that the case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox is similar to </span>the case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">him? But doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox caused </span>a person<span class="gemarra-regular"> humiliation</span>, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he humiliated </span>someone, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>If the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox is </span>understood to be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">him, how can you find </span>a case where the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to humiliate </span>the person? One is liable for humiliating someone only when he intends to do so, and an ox never has intention to humiliate.
The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to cause injury. </span>If it was the action of a person, he would be liable for the humiliation he caused as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Master said: </span>In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a person intended to cause injury, </span>he is liable for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he did not intend to humiliate </span>his victim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span> a different solution with regard to the difficulty that the mishna poses to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where one lit a fire on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally. </span>Although he is not liable to receive the death penalty, nevertheless, since he performed a prohibited action that would carry the death penalty were it to be performed deliberately, he is still exempt from monetary restitution.
The Gemara explains: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with what the school of Ḥizkiyya taught, as the school of Ḥizkiyya taught: </span>The verse states: “And he who kills an animal shall pay for it, and he who kills a man shall be put to death” (Leviticus 24:21), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who kills a man and one who kills an animal </span>are comparable.
This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who kills an animal, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">did not differentiate </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally or whether </span>he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, whether advertently or inadvertently, whether by way of descent or by way of ascent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and this was not <span class="gemarra-regular">to exempt him from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>in all these cases but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather to render him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span><span class="gemarra-regular">restitution, </span>as one who kills an animal is liable in any event, <span class="gemarra-regular">similarly, with regard to one who kills a man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not differentiate </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally or unintentionally, whether advertently or inadvertently,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether by way of descent or by way of ascent, </span>and this was not <span class="gemarra-regular">to render him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>for the damage he causes in the process of killing him, but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather to exempt him from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>in any event. It is derived from here that one who commits a transgression carrying the death penalty is exempt from paying damages for his action, even if he is not in practice given the death penalty.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said to Rava: Can you </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">interpret </span>the mishna as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the transgression was <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentional? But doesn’t it teach </span>that the transgressor is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because he is sentenced to death, </span>which is only the case if the transgression was intentional?
Rava answered that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying:</span> He is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>when this action is performed <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, </span>the transgressor is liable to be <span class="gemarra-regular">sentenced to death. And what are the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances </span>in which one is liable to receive the death penalty for deliberately lighting a fire on Shabbat? It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he needs the ashes. </span>Therefore, even <span class="gemarra-regular">now, when </span>the transgression was <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentional, he is exempt </span>from paying damages.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that was pursuing another </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ox being pursued <span class="gemarra-regular">became injured, </span>but there are no witnesses as to how it was injured, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the owner of the injured ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the pursuing ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your ox injured </span>my ox, and you are liable to pay me damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the owner of the pursuing ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; rather, it was hurt by a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and I am not liable, then in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rests upon the claimant. </span>As long as the owner of the injured ox cannot prove that the injury was inflicted by the pursuing ox, the owner of the pursuing ox is not liable.
In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>oxen, belonging to two different owners, <span class="gemarra-regular">were pursuing on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> ox belonging to a third person, and that ox was injured by one of the pursuing oxen, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the owner of one of the pursuing oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the other: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">your ox </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the injury, and that </span>one, the owner of the other pursuing ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>No, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">your ox </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the injury, </span>

Daf 35b

<span class="gemarra-regular">the two of them are exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since each of them rejects the claim of the injured party that his ox caused the injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">If both </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to one person, both are liable, </span>as will be explained in the Gemara.
If the pursuing oxen both belonged to one person, and were both innocuous, so that restitution is paid exclusively from proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox, and <span class="gemarra-regular">one was large and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one small</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in this case, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the large </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, </span>and he is therefore entitled to receive restitution for half the damage from the value of the large ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the one liable for damage says: No; rather, the small </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, </span>and half of its value is not sufficient to cover half the damage; or, similarly, in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is innocuous and one is forewarned, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, </span>and the injured party is therefore eligible to receive full damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the one liable for damage says: No; rather, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, </span>in which case he is liable to pay only half the damage; in both of the above cases, the principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">burden of proof rests upon the claimant.</span>
If the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">were two </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">one large and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one small, and the ones that caused the damage </span>were also <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">one large and one small, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: The large one injured the large one and the small one injured</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the small one, and the one liable for damage says: No; rather, the small one </span>injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the large one, </span>in which case, if half the value of the belligerent ox does not cover half the damage, he is not required to pay more, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the large one </span>injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the small one;</span> or, similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the belligerent oxen was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous and one forewarned, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">injured the large </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the small one,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the one liable for damage says: No; rather, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the large one and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the small one; </span>here too, <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rests upon the claimant.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna rules that in a case where there is uncertainty with regard to whether it was the pursuing ox that caused the injury to the other ox, the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the colleagues of Sumakhos, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">property of uncertain ownership is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divided</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with his </span>opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel said to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Does Sumakhos state </span>this principle <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim, i.e., where both parties maintain the certainty of their claims, as appears to be the case in the mishna? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes, Sumakhos says </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">that the mishna </span>is referring to a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the owner of the injured ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Your ox injured </span>my ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the owner of the pursuing ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: No, </span>indicating that both make their claims with certainty.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to this </span>interpretation of the case: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the suggestion <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the case in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna is one where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain</span> claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>the subsequent clause in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>is referring to a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim.
If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was large and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one small, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the large </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, and the one liable for damage says: No; rather, the small </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is innocuous and one is forewarned, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but the one liable for damage says: No; rather, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, the burden of proof rests upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the claimant.</span>
This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not bring proof, he takes </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to what the one liable for damage says. </span>If it is a case where both parties maintain certainty of their claims, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>that this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is a conclusive refutation of </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Natan, who says </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">claims </span>that another owes him <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which he claims he deposited with him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes </span>that he owes <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> barley, </span>which is less expensive than wheat, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from any payment, since he did not admit to what was claimed, and what he did admit was not claimed. Similarly, here, the injured party claims that it was the large ox that injured his ox, and the defendant admits that his small ox caused the injury, but not the large ox. His admission does not correspond to the claim. Yet, he is apparently liable to pay according to his admission, contrary to the ruling of Rabba bar Natan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this clause must be referring to a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and an uncertain </span>claim, i.e., one party maintains certainty of his claim, while the other merely states his claim as a possibility.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who states a certain </span>claim, and <span class="gemarra-regular">who is</span> the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who states an uncertain </span>claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party who <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim that the large ox caused the injury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">states an uncertain claim </span>that it was the small one, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us still say that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is a conclusive refutation of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Natan, </span>since the defendant does not admit to the claim of the injured party, and nevertheless he is liable to pay compensation from the small one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">states an uncertain </span>claim that it was the large ox that caused the injury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage states a certain </span>claim that it was the small one. Since the claimant does not contradict the defendant’s admission, the latter is liable to pay the amount that he admitted he owes.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the mishna is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party states <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage </span>states <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party states <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim that it was the defendant’s ox that injured his ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage </span>states <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim that it was injured by a stone. It is not referring to a case of two certain claims as inferred above.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Sumakhos state </span>his ruling that the disputed property is divided between the two parties <span class="gemarra-regular">even with regard to this </span>case, where the claimant states an uncertain claim, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that it was necessary </span>for the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach us that </span>according to the other Rabbis it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divided? Certainly Sumakhos would concede that in this case the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>although <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party states <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage </span>states <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party states <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for damage </span>states <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim. It is with regard to this case that the Rabbis disagree with the opinion of Sumakhos that the property is divided.
The Gemara questions this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this interpretation, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause is not similar to the last clause. </span>Why not explain the first clause as referring to a case of two certain claims?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: A case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an uncertain </span>claim, and a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">are one matter. </span>Therefore, the two clauses are congruent. By contrast, a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim, and a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and a certain </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">are two</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matters. </span>Therefore, the first clause of the mishna cannot be referring to a case of two certain claims.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>that was mentioned above. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Natan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">claims </span>that another owes him <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes </span>that he owes <span class="gemarra-regular">him barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the latter is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>novel element <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>it in a mishna: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">claims </span>that another owes him <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes </span>that he owes <span class="gemarra-regular">him barley, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>(<span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> 38b).
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it had been taught only <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, I would say </span>the mishna means that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the wheat but liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the barley, </span>which he conceded that he owes. Therefore, Rabba bar Natan <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the mishna means that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">completely exempt, </span>even from paying for the barley.
The Gemara raises an objection to this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna here that if the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">were two </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">one large and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one small, </span>and the ones that caused the damage were also two oxen, one large and one small, and the injured party claims that the large one injured the large one, and the small one injured the small one, and the liable party claims that the small one injured the large one, and the large one injured the small one, the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bring proof </span>for his claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to what the one liable for damage says. </span>According to Rabba bar Natan’s statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does he receive compensation at all? The case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>parallel to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley, </span>and the defendant should be entirely exempt.
The Gemara answers: The mishna does not indicate that the injured party receives compensation, rather, that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fitting for him to take </span>compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in practice <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not </span>receive any compensation.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">receives payment for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">small ox from the </span>liable party’s <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">large</span> ox <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>liable party’s <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>ox? Evidently he does receive payment.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">seized </span>the defendant’s ox, in which case the court allows it to remain in his possession, since his taking it was appropriate, although the court cannot compel the defendant to pay him <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
The Gemara raises an objection to Rabba bar Natan’s statement from the last clause of the mishna as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the belligerent oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">was innocuous and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">injured the large one and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the small one, and the one liable for damage says: No; rather, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the large one and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox injured <span class="gemarra-regular">the small one, </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. </span>This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not bring proof </span>for his claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes</span> compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to what the one liable for damage says. Why </span>does he receive compensation at all? The case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>parallel to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley. </span>

Daf 36a

The Gemara answers: The mishna does not indicate that the injured party receives compensation. Rather, it indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fitting for him to take </span>compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in practice <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not </span>receive any compensation. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">he receives payment for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">small ox from the </span>liable party’s <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>liable party’s <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox? Evidently he does receive payment. The Gemara answers: This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is also referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">seized </span>the defendant’s ox, in which case the court allows it to remain in his possession. The court cannot compel the defendant to pay him <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where an ox was injured by one of two oxen that were pursuing it, if <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to one person, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">both are liable. Rava of Parzika said to Rav Ashi: </span>Should one <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>the fact that both are liable that in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous oxen that caused damage, </span>if the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds from the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he wishes, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect from </span>the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ox?
Rav Ashi rejected this inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with forewarned </span>oxen, in which case the injured party does not collect damages exclusively from the belligerent ox but rather from any of its owner’s property. Therefore, he can collect from either ox as compensation.
Rava of Parzika replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to forewarned </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the belligerent oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">was large and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">small, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the large </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, but the one liable for damage says: No; rather, the small </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the damage, the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. If </span>this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to forewarned </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">what difference does it make to him </span>which one caused the injury? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>the liable party <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of a full ox </span>in any case.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The latter clause </span>of the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to innocuous </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the first clause </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to forewarned </span>oxen.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa the Elder said to Rav Ashi: If </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span> oxen, where compensation is not collected specifically from the belligerent ox, why does the mishna state: <span class="gemarra-regular">They are liable, </span>in the plural form? <span class="gemarra-regular">It should have </span>stated: The <span class="gemarra-regular">man is liable. And furthermore, what </span>is the word <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>in the statement: Both are liable, referring to?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the first clause of the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to innocuous </span>oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that the injured party and the liable party <span class="gemarra-regular">are partners, </span>as they share ownership of the belligerent ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that the owner of the belligerent oxen is liable is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the two of them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>available, <span class="gemarra-regular">so he cannot dismiss </span>the injured party by claiming that this ox is not the one that caused the injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the two of them are not </span>available, e.g., if one died or was lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can say to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go bring proof that </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">this ox </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused you damage, and I will pay you </span>compensation.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox that gored four or five </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">oxe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one after the other, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">shall pay </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">of them </span>half of the damages from the proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox; <span class="gemarra-regular">and if there is surplus </span>value left <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his ox after he pays that owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the previous </span>ox that was gored; <span class="gemarra-regular">and if there is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">surplus</span> value left <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his ox after he pays that owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">prior to the previous </span>one. The principle is that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latest </span>of the oxen gored in succession <span class="gemarra-regular">gains. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says </span>that the division of the compensation is as follows: With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gored an ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, thereby killing it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worthless, </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred dinars, </span>i.e., half the cost of the damage, from the proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars.</span>
If the ox, after goring the first ox but before compensation had been paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">again gored another ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, and the carcass is worthless, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>ox that was gored <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred dinars, and </span>with regard to payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">the previous</span> goring, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox that was gored <span class="gemarra-regular">takes fifty </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinars, </span>which is half the remaining value of the belligerent ox after one hundred dinars were paid to the last injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty dinars.</span>
If the ox, after goring the first two oxen but before compensation had been paid, again <span class="gemarra-regular">gored</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, and the carcass is worthless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinars, the previous one </span>takes <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty dinars, and the first two, </span>i.e., the first injured party and the owner of the belligerent ox, divide the remainder, each receiving <span class="gemarra-regular">one gold dinar, </span>which is worth twenty-five silver dinars.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Apparently the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">neither in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, nor in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva </span>(see 33a).
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the mishna had been <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, who says </span>that the owners of the gored oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">creditors </span>of the owner of the belligerent ox, then instead of stating <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latest </span>of the oxen gored in succession <span class="gemarra-regular">gains, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have</span> stated that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the earliest </span>of the oxen gored in succession <span class="gemarra-regular">gains, </span>since the creditor to whom the ox is initially liened collects first. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the mishna had been <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>belligerent <span class="gemarra-regular">ox belongs to </span>its owner and to the injured party, who are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">partners </span>in the ownership of the ox, then instead of stating <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is surplus </span>value remaining in the ox after he pays that owner

Daf 36b

<span class="gemarra-regular">he shall return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">previous </span>ox, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>ruled that the surplus shall be returned <span class="gemarra-regular">to all of them, </span>i.e., all the prior injured parties, since they all share joint ownership of the belligerent ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, who says </span>that all the injured parties <span class="gemarra-regular">are creditors. And as for the difficulty you </span>pose, that instead of stating that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latest </span>of the oxen gored in succession <span class="gemarra-regular">gains, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the earliest </span>of the oxen gored in succession <span class="gemarra-regular">gains, </span>that can be answered. <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">seize</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from it, and </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">became like a paid bailee </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to damage </span>it causes. Therefore, he is responsible for any subsequent attacks by the ox. Similarly, if the next injured party seizes the ox from the first as compensation, he becomes responsible for any subsequent attacks.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>instead of the mishna stating that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is surplus </span>value left <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his ox after he pays that owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the previous </span>ox that was gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">it should have </span>stated that <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall return it to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, </span>since half the value of the belligerent ox belongs to its owner, who is not responsible for any later damage it causes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: If there is surplus </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its damages, </span>i.e., the latter injured party sustained less of a loss than the previous one, that injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">shall return </span>this surplus value <span class="gemarra-regular">to the previous </span>injured party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, when Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">touched</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on this </span>topic <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a bailee’s negligence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with which </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you interpret </span>the ruling in the mishna? Was it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael? If so, say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says </span>that the division of the compensation is as follows: With regard to an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored an ox worth two hundred</span> dinars, thereby killing it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the carcass is worthless, </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one hundred dinars </span>from the proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars.</span>
If the ox, after goring the first ox but before compensation had been paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">again </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gored another ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, and the carcass is worthless, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>ox that was gored <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred dinars; and </span>with regard to payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">the previous </span>goring, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox that was gored <span class="gemarra-regular">takes fifty dinars, </span>which is half the remaining value of the belligerent ox after one hundred dinars were paid to the last injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty dinars. </span>If the ox, after goring the first two oxen but before compensation had been paid, again <span class="gemarra-regular">gored another ox worth two hundred </span>dinars, and the carcass is worthless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes one hundred dinars, the previous one </span>takes <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty dinars, and the first two </span>divide the remainder, each receiving <span class="gemarra-regular">one gold dinar, </span>which is worth twenty-five silver dinars.
The Gemara continues: In the ruling of Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox belongs to </span>its owner and to the injured party, who are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">partners </span>in the ownership of the ox. Is it possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael and the latter clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shinnana</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> leave </span>the presumption that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna </span>follows one opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">and follow my </span>interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael and the latter clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was also stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the opinions of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon in the mishna is with regard to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>the ox. If he is a partner in the ownership of the ox, his consecration takes effect; if he is considered merely a creditor, the consecration is ineffective. Evidently, Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds that the dispute in the mishna corresponds to the dispute between Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva.
§ With regard to the gold dinar mentioned in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in another mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(90a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who slaps [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hatokea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sel</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> as a compensatory fine. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: </span>He is liable to give him <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who slapped another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Toviya bar Mattana sent </span>an enquiry <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Yosef, </span>asking him whether the <span class="it-text">sela</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>about in the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Tyrian </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is worth four dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>whether the <span class="it-text">sela</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>about in the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a provincial </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>worth only half of a dinar, or one-eighth of a Tyrian <span class="it-text">sela</span>.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You learned this </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the first two </span>divide the remainder, each receiving <span class="gemarra-regular">one gold dinar, </span>worth twenty-five silver dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span>monetary sums using <span class="gemarra-regular">a provincial </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> in order to calculate compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the value that the first two litigants receive <span class="gemarra-regular">and teach </span>a case where the belligerent ox gored an additional ox, so that their shares decrease <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>they reach <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve dinars and one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> apiece, which are twelve and a half dinars. The fact that he does not do so indicates that the mishna does not use a provincial <span class="it-text">sela</span>, whose value is less than one dinar, and therefore a gold dinar cannot be divided in a manner that leaves each party with whole coins.
Rav Toviya bar Mattana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This is not proof; <span class="gemarra-regular">should the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have continued teaching </span>additional cases, exhausting all possibilities, <span class="gemarra-regular">like a peddle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> selling his wares, who advertises every item of his merchandise? The cases cited in the mishna suffice to illustrate the point.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>halakhic conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>reached <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>this matter? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved it based on </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: All </span>references to <span class="gemarra-regular">coinage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mentioned in the Tora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> refer to <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian coinage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whereas </span>all mentions <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>coinage in the <span class="gemarra-regular">statements of </span>the Sages refer to <span class="gemarra-regular">provincial coinage. </span>Therefore, a person who slaps another is fined a provincial <span class="it-text">sela</span>, worth half of a dinar.
Following the verdict, <span class="gemarra-regular">that man </span>who was slapped <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the fine <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half a dinar, I do not want it, </span>as it is beneath me to collect such an amount. Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him give it to the poor. Then </span>he retracted his decision, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him give it to me, and I will go and sustain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’avri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> myself with it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said to him: </span>Since you already committed to give it to charity, <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor have already acquired i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and it now belongs to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And although there are no poor </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>to acquire it, <span class="gemarra-regular">we, </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">are the hand, </span>i.e., the legal extension, <span class="gemarra-regular">of the poor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> We represent them, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Orphans</span>

Daf 37a

<span class="gemarra-regular">do not require a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year from abrogating an outstanding debt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> by transferring the right of collection to the court. The reason that orphans do not require this document is because the court is legally considered to be their steward, and their debts are therefore transferred to the court automatically, even without a <span class="it-text">prosbol</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, Rami bar Ḥama taught: Orphans do not require a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel and his court were </span>tantamount to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fathers of orphans, </span>as they were vigilant to collect all of the debts owed to orphans. Subsequently, the courts in every generation have this status.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanan the wicke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slapped a certain man. He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Huna</span> for judgment. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go give him a half-dinar, </span>which is the fine imposed for such an act. Ḥanan the wicked <span class="gemarra-regular">had a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clipped dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">wanted to give him a half-dinar from it, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">there was no one </span>who wanted <span class="gemarra-regular">to take i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from him to give him smaller coins for it. Ḥanan the wicked then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave him another slap, </span>rendering himself liable to pay an additional fine of half a dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave him </span>the clipped dinar as payment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is forewarned with regard to its </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">species</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it already gored other oxen three times, <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned with regard to other species; </span>or an ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned with regard to animals; </span>or one that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to small </span>specimens of a species, <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned with regard to large </span>specimens of that species; in all these cases, if the ox gores the type of animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is forewarned, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and </span>if it gores an animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is not forewarned, he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said before Rabbi Yehuda: </span>What would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarned with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbato</span><span class="gemarra-italic">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned with regard to weekdays? He said to them: For </span>damage it causes on <span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span> its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and for </span>damage it causes on <span class="gemarra-regular">weekdays, he pays half </span>the cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When is it</span> rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> again after being forewarned with regard to Shabbat? It reverts to its innocuous status <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>its behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">reverts </span>to normal, i.e., when it refrains from goring for <span class="gemarra-regular">three days of Shabbat, </span>i.e., Shabbat in three successive weeks.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>The version of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>states: With regard to an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, referring to an ox that is proven to be innocuous with regard to other species, if it gores another species, its owner pays only half the cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The version of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>states: An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species. Accordingly, the mishna is teaching that the fact that it is forewarned with regard to goring one species does not render it forewarned with regard to goring other species, until it is proven otherwise.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said </span>that the version of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>states: With regard to an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, indicating that it is referring specifically to an ox that is proven to be innocuous with regard to other species. This implies that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, where there is no such proof, the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to all species. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the version of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>states: An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to other species.
