<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid inferred </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of the mishna, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa inferred </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">from the former </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clause.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid inferred </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause, as it teaches: </span>An ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to small </span>specimens of a species, <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned with regard to large </span>specimens of that species. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the first clause: With regard to an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned</span> with regard to other species, indicating that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to all animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that even from </span>being forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>specimens of a species, in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>thereby considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to large </span>specimens of that species, which is a more far-reaching statement, as an ox is less likely to gore large animals.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, meaning that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, where there is no proof to the contrary, the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to other species, there is a difficulty with the latter clause of the mishna.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it can be said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>being forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>oxen, in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>thereby considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to small </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">in general,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> need it be said that from </span>being forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>specimens of a species <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>thereby considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to large </span>specimens of that species? It must be that the mishna reads: But is not forewarned, indicating that only when the ox is proven to be innocuous with regard to other species and then it gores another species is its owner liable to pay only half the cost of the damage. Otherwise, he must pay the full cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in response that even if the mishna reads: An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, the latter clause is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, </span>as otherwise it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it breached </span>the norm by attacking one <span class="gemarra-regular">of that species, it </span>is considered to have <span class="gemarra-regular">breached </span>the norm entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>that species, and there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the species <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">of it, </span>as the ox is now likely to gore any of them. Therefore, this clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to the large animals of that species.
As stated previously, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa inferred </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">from the former clause </span>of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>An ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to people is not forewarned with regard to animals. Granted, if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>that the mishna states: An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, which would indicate that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, where there is no proof to the contrary, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to other species, then the mishna, in the next clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this, that even from </span>being forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to animals. </span>The ox is considered innocuous with regard to animals, although it is more common for an ox to gore an animal than a person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the first clause: With regard to an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, indicating that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard to other species, then there is a difficulty with the following clause of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it can be said </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>being forewarned with regard to one species of <span class="gemarra-regular">animal, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>thereby considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>other species of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals, need it be said that from </span>its being forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">people it is </span>also considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to animals?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Zevid </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The former clause </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">relates to </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">reverting </span>to its innocuous status, i.e., a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was forewarned with regard to man and forewarned with regard to animals, and reverted </span>to its innocuous status <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to animals, as it stood in </span>close <span class="gemarra-regular">proximity to an animal three times and did not gore. Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it did not </span>demonstratively <span class="gemarra-regular">revert to </span>its innocuous behavior toward <span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>as it did not refrain from goring people, its <span class="gemarra-regular">reversal with regard to animals is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reversal, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">reversal with regard to animals is nevertheless </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reversal, </span>and it no longer has the status of a forewarned ox with regard to goring animals.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav Zevid’s opinion from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos says: </span>An ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to people is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to animals, due to an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is forewarned with regard to people, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>that it is forewarned <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to animals?</span> The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned</span> with regard to animals, in accordance with the opinion of Rav Pappa.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos’s </span>statement can be interpreted as <span class="gemarra-regular">relating to </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">reverting </span>to its innocuous status, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying to the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Contrary to <span class="gemarra-regular">what you are saying, </span>that the ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">reversal with regard to animals is considered a reversal </span>although it has not yet reversed its behavior toward people, I maintain that its <span class="gemarra-regular">reversal with regard to animals is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a reversal, due to an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of an animal forewarned with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">people: If </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has not reverted to </span>its innocuous behavior toward <span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>that it has not truly reverted <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its innocuous behavior toward <span class="gemarra-regular">animals?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a proof for Rav Zevid’s opinion from the mishna: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said before Rabbi Yehuda: </span>What would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarned with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but is not forewarned with regard to weekdays? He said to them: For </span>damage it causes on <span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span> its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage it causes on <span class="gemarra-regular">weekdays, he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: But was not forewarned </span>with regard to weekdays, <span class="gemarra-regular">they were asking him </span>about the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">and likewise, he was answering them </span>with a ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches: </span>This ox that is forewarned with regard to <span class="it-text">Shabbatot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to weekdays, the mishna would be understood as saying that an ox that is forewarned with regard to Shabbat is not considered forewarned with regard to weekdays. Is it possible that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">were teaching him </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, what was he responding to them?</span> They had already stated themselves that the ox is not considered forewarned with regard to weekdays.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yannai said: </span>Rav Zevid’s opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">can be inferred from the former clause</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, as it teaches: </span>If the ox gores an animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is forewarned, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and</span> if it gores an animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is not forewarned, he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in the first clause: With regard to an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not forewarned</span> with regard to other species, this clause <span class="gemarra-regular">is explaining </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in that case, i.e., if the ox is forewarned only with regard to its species, its owner is liable to pay the full cost of the damage only if it gores another ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>An ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forewarned </span>with regard to other species, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was already <span class="gemarra-regular">determined </span>at the beginning of the mishna, namely, that the ox is not considered forewarned with regard to other species, then <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>need is there for the mishna to <span class="gemarra-regular">further </span>state: If the ox gores an animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is forewarned, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>if it gores an animal or person <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to which it is not forewarned, he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Has </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">not taught us until now that for an innocuous </span>ox its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and for a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage?</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa’s </span>opinion, which says that an ox that is forewarned with regard to its own species is not considered forewarned with regard to other species, <span class="gemarra-regular">is accepted, </span>nevertheless, if an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored an ox, a donkey, and a camel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to all </span>of them. The ox is rendered forewarned with regard to all three species, regardless of the fact that it did not gore each individual species three times.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">saw an ox</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it, and subsequently saw another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, again saw <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it and then saw <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, and a third time saw <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it and saw <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">it is rendered forewarned with regard to alternate oxen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The ox is considered forewarned with regard to goring every other ox that it sees and is considered innocuous with regard to the oxen in between. If it then gores two oxen in a row, the owner of the ox is liable for only half the cost of the damage for the second ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">saw an ox </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it, and then saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, and saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a horse </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it, then saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a camel </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, and saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a mule </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>it, and then saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a wild donkey [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arod</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not gore </span>it, in this case it <span class="gemarra-regular">is rendered forewarned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to alternate </span>animals of <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>species.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>the Sages: If an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored</span>

Daf 37b

<span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, and </span>a third <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, </span>and then <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and a camel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>it considered forewarned?
The Gemara presents the possibilities: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this last ox </span>that was gored together with the donkey and the camel, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the previously gored <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen, and </span>accordingly the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was still rendered forewarned </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to oxen, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to other </span>species it <span class="gemarra-regular">was not rendered forewarned? Or perhaps we place</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this last ox </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the donkey and the camel, and it was rendered forewarned with regard to all of the species </span>it gored.
The Gemara adds a similar dilemma: If an ox gored <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and a camel, </span>and then <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, an ox, and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara presents the possibilities: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this first ox</span> that it gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the camel and donkey, and </span>the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>accordingly <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered forewarned with regard to all species? Or perhaps we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen </span>that it gored afterward, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was still rendered forewarned </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to oxen, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">it was not rendered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> forewarned with regard to other species.</span>
Similarly, if it gored on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>i.e., on three consecutive <span class="it-text">Shabbatot</span>, and then on <span class="gemarra-regular">Sunday and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this last Shabbat, do we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the previous <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was still rendered forewarned </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Shabbat, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to weekdays it was not rendered forewarned? Or perhaps we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the goring on <span class="gemarra-regular">Sunday and Monday, and it was </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered forewarned with regard to all days </span>of the week.
If an ox gored on <span class="gemarra-regular">Thursday, and Friday, and Shabbat, </span>and then the next <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat and </span>the next <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>after that, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this first Shabbat, do we place it </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with Thursday and Friday, and </span>thereby hold that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was rendered forewarned with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to all days </span>of the week? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps we place this first Shabbat </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the other <span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is rendered forewarned only with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
These dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand</span> unresolved.
§ If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox gored </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fifteenth day of this month, and </span>subsequently gored on <span class="gemarra-regular">the sixteenth da</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">month </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">that, and </span>then on <span class="gemarra-regular">the seventeenth </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">month </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel </span>with regard to a parallel discussion concerning a woman whose menstrual cycle begins on a different day each month.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it was stated: </span>If a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>menstrual blood on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fifteenth day of this month, and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the sixteenth day of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">month </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">that, and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the seventeenth </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">month </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">that, Rav says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">She has </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">established her menstrual cycle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a month and one day. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>Her menstrual cycle is not established <span class="gemarra-regular">until she skips </span>a day <span class="gemarra-regular">three times</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> According to Shmuel, the cycle is established in this case not by the date per se, but rather by the pattern of one additional day every month. Only when this occurs for three consecutive months, i.e., when she menstruates in the fourth month, is this pattern established.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>If an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">heard the sound of a shofar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gored</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and again heard <span class="gemarra-regular">the sound of a shofar and gored, </span>and a third time heard <span class="gemarra-regular">the sound of a shofar and gored, it is rendered forewarned with regard to </span>the sound of <span class="gemarra-italic">shofarot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t this obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this first shofar merely startled [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">siyyuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> the ox, prompting it to gore, and that consequently it should not count for the purpose of rendering the ox forewarned, Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that since the ox repeatedly gored upon hearing the sound of a shofar, this sound is considered a consistent impetus for its goring.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a Jew that gored a consecrated</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">a consecrated </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored a non-sacred ox, </span>i.e., an ox owned by a Jew, the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span>“And if one man’s ox hurts <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox of another” </span>(Exodus 21:35). It is derived from the phrase “the ox of another” that one is liable only if it is a non-sacred ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a consecrated ox, </span>which belongs to the Temple treasury, regardless of whether the latter was the ox that gored or the ox that was gored.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a Jew that gored the ox of a gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the belligerent ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a gentile that gored the ox of a Jew, </span>regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the goring ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned, </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred ox that gored a consecrated ox, or a consecrated </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored a non-sacred ox,</span> the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “The ox of another,” </span>indicating: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not a consecrated ox. Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a consecrated ox that gored a non-sacred ox, </span>the Temple treasury is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored a consecrated ox, whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: What does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>ben Menasya <span class="gemarra-regular">hold? </span>Why does he distinguish between a consecrated ox that gored a non-sacred ox and a non-sacred ox that gored a consecrated ox? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored a consecrated ox </span>the owner of the belligerant ox <span class="gemarra-regular">should be exempt </span>from liability, as the victim is not the ox of another, but belongs to the Temple treasury. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, but rather, includes all oxen, then <span class="gemarra-regular">a consecrated </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gored a non-sacred </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">should render </span>the Temple treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">liable as well.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, and accordingly, if a consecrated ox gores a non-sacred ox the Temple treasury is exempt from liability; <span class="gemarra-regular">but nevertheless, when a non-sacred </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores a consecrated </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the reason </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable: Because </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya <span class="gemarra-regular">infers it </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred </span>ox, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that gores </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred </span>ox the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so that when it gores a consecrated </span>ox the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable?</span>
If this is Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya’s reasoning, then his ruling that the owner of the ox pays the Temple treasury the full cost of the damage, whether his ox was innocuous or forewarned, is problematic, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source. </span>In other words, a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived by means of an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference cannot be more stringent than the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the source from which it is derived. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as there, </span>in a case where an individual’s <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>non-sacred ox gores another non-sacred ox, the owner pays only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, here too, </span>if an innocuous non-sacred ox gores a consecrated ox, its owner should be liable to pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Reish Lakish said </span>that Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya’s reasoning is as follows: In principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>cases of damage <span class="gemarra-regular">were included </span>among those <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> which the owner pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that in a case of an innocuous ox the owner pays only half the cost of the damage is an exception to the rule, and <span class="gemarra-regular">when the verse specified </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” with regard to an innocuous </span>ox, it intended <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically when one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox gores the ox of <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, </span>if it gores <span class="gemarra-regular">a consecrated </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is innocuous or forewarned </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>

Daf 38a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Because if so, </span>if one whose ox gores a consecrated ox is exempt from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse write this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Of another,” with regard to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox. One could then infer that the owner is exempt from liability in the case of an innocuous ox as well, as the liability with regard to an innocuous ox is less severe than with regard to a forewarned ox. The stating of this exemption specifically in the context of an innocuous ox indicates that the exemption is only concerning the leniency stated in the verse, that if the gored ox belongs to another person, the owner of the belligerent ox is liable to pay only half the cost of the damage.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a Je</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that gored the ox of a gentile, </span>the owner of the belligerent ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability; whereas if a gentile’s ox gores a Jew’s ox, the owner is liable to pay the full cost of the damage. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>This statement is difficult <span class="gemarra-regular">whichever way you </span>look at it. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another”</span> is meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, and therefore the liability applies only if his ox gores the ox of another Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">when a gentile’s </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores that of a Jew he should also be exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when a Jew’s </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gores that of a gentile </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu said </span>that the reason for this ruling is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “He stood and shook the earth; He beheld, and made the nations tremble [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vayyatter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Habakkuk 3:6). This is homiletically interpreted to mean that God <span class="gemarra-regular">saw the seven mitzvot that the descendants of Noah accepted upon themselve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to fulfill, and <span class="gemarra-regular">since they did not fulfill </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">He arose and permitted [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehittir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their mone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Jewish people, </span>so that in certain cases Jews are not liable for damage caused to gentiles.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>that the source for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">from here:</span> It is stated in reference to the giving of the Torah: “The Lord came from Sinai and rose from Seir unto them; <span class="gemarra-regular">He appeared from Mount Paran” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:2), which is homiletically interpreted to mean: <span class="gemarra-regular">From</span> the time God came from Mount <span class="gemarra-regular">Paran, </span>when giving the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">the money of </span>the gentile nations <span class="gemarra-regular">appeared, </span>i.e., it was revealed and granted <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a Jew that gored the ox of a gentile, </span>the owner of the belligerent ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. By contrast, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a gentile that gored the ox of a Jew, whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned, </span>the owner of the belligerent ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, as it is stated: “He stood and shook the earth; He beheld, and made the nations tremble.” And </span>another verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “He appeared from Mount Paran.”</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the reason the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>another verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states, </span>indicating that the first verse is not a sufficient source?
The Gemara explains that this is how the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to be understood: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He stood and shook the earth” is necessary to</span> express <span class="gemarra-regular">that which Rav Mattana and Rav Yosef </span>derived from the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> another source: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He appeared from Mount Paran,” </span>meaning: <span class="gemarra-regular">From Paran their money appeared to the Jewish people. What is Rav Mattana’s </span>exposition? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Mattana says: “He stood and shook the earth.” What did He see?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He saw the seven mitzvot that the descendants of Noah were commanded but did not fulfill, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">He arose and exiled them from their lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on account of their transgressions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where may </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred that this </span>term <span class="gemarra-italic">vayyatter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is a term of exile? It is written here: “And made the nations tremble [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vayyatter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Habakkuk 3:6), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there: “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Lenatter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon the earth” </span>(Leviticus 11:21), <span class="gemarra-regular">which is translated </span>into Aramaic as: <span class="gemarra-regular">“To leap upon the earth.” </span>Apparently, the root <span class="it-text">nun</span>, <span class="it-text">tav</span>, <span class="it-text">reish</span>, common to both words, indicates uprooting from one place to another.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is Rav Yosef’s </span>exposition? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yosef says: “He stood and shook the earth; He beheld.” What did He see? He saw the seven mitzvot that the descendants of Noah accepted upon themselves and did not fulfill, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">He arose and permitted </span>their prohibitions <span class="gemarra-regular">to them.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did they </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">profit, </span>in that their prohibitions became permitted to them? <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, we have found a transgressor </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">is rewarded. Mar, son of Rabbana, says: </span>This is not to say that for them to transgress their mitzvot is no longer a sin; rather, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that even if they fulfill them, they do not receive reward for </span>fulfilling <span class="gemarra-regular">them.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>do they <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>receive reward for fulfilling those mitzvot? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that even a gentile who engages in Torah is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a High Priest? The verse states </span>with regard to the mitzvot: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Which if a person does, he shall live by them” </span>(Leviticus 18:5). It <span class="gemarra-regular">is not stated: </span>Which if <span class="gemarra-regular">priests and Levites and Israelites </span>do, they shall live by them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but rather: A person, </span>indicating that all people are included. <span class="gemarra-regular">You have therefore learned that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even a gentile who engages in Torah </span>study <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a High Priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: Rav Yosef meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not receive the reward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is commanded </span>to perform a mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">and performs </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but as </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is not commanded </span>to perform a mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">and performs </span>it anyway. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Ḥanina says: </span>One who is <span class="gemarra-regular">commanded </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and performs </span>a mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">is greate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">is not commanded and performs</span> it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>the following story in the context of the aforementioned <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Roman kingdom once sen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two military officials [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sardeyotot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Sages of Israel, </span>and ordered them in the name of the king: <span class="gemarra-regular">Teach us your Torah. </span>The officials <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and repeated </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>repeated it again, reading it for the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>time. <span class="gemarra-regular">At the time of their departure, they said to </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">We have examined your entire Torah and it is true, except </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">matter that you state</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a Jew that gored the ox of a gentile, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability, whereas with regard to the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a gentile that gored the ox of a Jew, whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The officials’ reasoning was that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is difficult <span class="gemarra-regular">whichever way you </span>look at it. <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span> the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, that the owners of both oxen must both be Jewish, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even when </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a gentile gores the ox of a Jew </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">should be exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“of another” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>meant in <span class="gemarra-regular">a precise </span>manner, and the oxen of all are included, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even when </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a Jew gores the ox of a gentile </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable. </span>They added: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we will not inform this matter to the kingdom; </span>having acknowledged that the entire Torah is true, we will not reveal this ruling, as it will displease the kingdom.
§ Incidentally, it is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Yehud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> died. The Sages said to Ulla: Arise; let us go console him. </span>Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: What </span>business <span class="gemarra-regular">do I have with the consolation of Babylonians, which is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">heresy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As, they say </span>while consoling mourners: <span class="gemarra-regular">What can be done</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> This seems to suggest that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it were possible to do </span>something, acting against the Almighty’s decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">they would do </span>so, which is tantamount to heresy. Therefore, Ulla declined to accompany the Babylonian Sages.
Ulla therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">went to </span>console Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Lord said to me, do not be at enmity with Moab, neither contend with them in battle”</span> (Deuteronomy 2:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">What entered Moses’s mind, </span>that God had to warn him not to undertake a particular action? Did it enter his mind <span class="gemarra-regular">to wage war </span>with the Moabites <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission? Rather, Moses reasoned an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself, saying: And if </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Midianites, who came only to help the Moabites </span>harm the Jewish people (see Numbers, chapter 22), <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah said: “Harass the Midianites and smite them” </span>(Numbers 25:17), 

Daf 38b

with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Moabites themselves, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>that they should be attacked?
To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: That which has entered your mind has not entered Mine, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">I have two virtuous fledglings [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">feridot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., girls, <span class="gemarra-regular">to extract from them: Ruth the Moabite, </span>who will be the foremother of the dynasty of David, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Naamah the Ammonite, </span>Solomon’s wife, from whom the continuation of that dynasty will emerge. For the sake of these women, the Moabites and Ammonites must not be destroyed.
Ulla continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">And are </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">matters not </span>inferred <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? If for the sake of two virtuous fledglings the Holy One, Blessed be He, had pity on two large nations and did not destroy them, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">if the daughter of my teacher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">was righteous, and she had </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">potential for something good to emerge from her, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">that she would have lived.</span>
§ Having mentioned the Moabites and Ammonites, the Gemara cites that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not deprive any creature of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">reward</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He rewards every person for his good deeds, and provides <span class="gemarra-regular">reward even for </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">pleasant speech </span>by using euphemisms.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>with regard to the descendants of the <span class="gemarra-regular">elder </span>of the two daughters of Lot, <span class="gemarra-regular">who said </span>that the name of her son, whom she conceived with her father, would be <span class="gemarra-regular">Moab, </span>meaning: From father, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: “Do not be at enmity with Moab, neither contend with them in battle,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>a full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">battle was not</span> authorized <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>that the Jewish people could <span class="gemarra-regular">impose forced labor [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">angarya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on them.</span>
By contrast, with regard to the descendants of the <span class="gemarra-regular">younger </span>daughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">who said </span>her son’s name would be <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Ami, </span>meaning: Son of my nation, merely alluding to the fact she conceived him through an incestuous union, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He said to Moses: “And when you come near against the children of Ammon, do not harass them, nor contend with them” </span>(Deuteronomy 2:19). In other words, do not contend with them <span class="gemarra-regular">at all; do not even impose forced labor on them. </span>This additional prohibition was a reward for her employing a euphemism when naming her son.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to the daughters of Lot, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says: A person should always hasten to perform a mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one night by which the elder </span>daughter of Lot <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded the younger </span>daughter, with the intention of performing a mitzva by bringing children into the world, <span class="gemarra-regular">she preceded her by four generations </span>in having her descendants enter <span class="gemarra-regular">into the Jewish people. </span>They are: <span class="gemarra-regular">Obed, </span>son of Ruth the Moabite, <span class="gemarra-regular">Yishai, David, and Solomon. Whereas, </span>the descendants of <span class="gemarra-regular">the younger </span>daughter did not join the Jewish people <span class="gemarra-regular">until Rehoboam, </span>Solomon’s son, was born, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And his mother’s name was Naamah the Ammonite” </span>(I Kings 14:31).
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox of a Jew that gored the ox of a Samaritan, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a Samaritan that gored the ox of a Jew, </span>if the Samaritan’s ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, and </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, he pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>Accordingly, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to Samaritans is not identical to that of a gentile, who is liable to pay the full cost of the damage even for the act of an innocuous ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox of a Jew that gored the ox of a Samaritan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a Samaritan that gored the ox of a Jew, whether </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>like a gentile.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that Rabbi Meir holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Samaritans are converts </span>who had converted due to fear <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lions</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the original conversion of the Samaritans was under duress and consequently meaningless, and therefore he assigns to them the same status as gentiles with regard to liability for damages?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>to this suggestion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 56b): <span class="gemarra-regular">All bloodstained </span>clothes, presumably from menstrual blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">that come from </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are ritually pure, </span>since most of the residents there are gentiles, and the bloodstains of gentile women are not ritually impure. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">impure because, </span>in his opinion, the inhabitants of Rekem <span class="gemarra-regular">are converts who are mistaken, </span>i.e., they converted, and they do not observe the mitzvot because they have forgotten Judaism. He holds that since they are halakhically Jewish, their blood is ritually impure.
Bloodstained clothes that come <span class="gemarra-regular">from among gentiles </span>are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">pure. </span>With regard to bloodstained clothes that come <span class="gemarra-regular">from among Jews or from among Samaritans, Rabbi Meir deems </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, </span>as he suspects them of not taking care to keep impure clothes out of the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis deem </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">pure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Jews </span>and Samaritans <span class="gemarra-regular">are not suspected of </span>not being careful about <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bloodstains.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, Rabbi Meir holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Samaritans are true converts; </span>otherwise the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning them would be the same as for gentiles, whose bloodstains are not impure at all. This being the case, why does Rabbi Meir regard them as gentiles with regard to liability to pay damages?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says: </span>They are true converts, and are therefore considered Jews by Torah law inasmuch as in the event that a Jew’s ox causes damage to them, the owner of the ox is liable to pay damages, and if an innocuous ox belonging to them gores a Jew’s ox, the owner pays only half the cost of the damage. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir imposed a monetary fine on them, </span>giving them the status of gentiles, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that</span> Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">would not assimilate with them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises an objection </span>to this answer from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 29a): <span class="gemarra-regular">And these </span>are the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">young women for whom there is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> paid to their fathers by one who rapes them. Not only is one who rapes a Jewish young woman of unflawed lineage liable to pay this fine, but so is <span class="gemarra-regular">one who engages in intercourse with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mamzeret</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or with a female Gibeonite, or with a female Samaritan. </span>Rabbi Zeira states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind that Rabbi Meir imposed a monetary fine on them </span>to render them like gentiles, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, let us fine </span>a female Samaritan who is raped, by rendering her ineligible to receive the fine for rape, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>people will not consider them regular Jews and <span class="gemarra-regular">will not assimilate with them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>According to Rabbi Meir, the reason the Sages did not revoke this fine is <span class="gemarra-regular">in order</span>

Daf 39a

<span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sinner, </span>i.e., the rapist, <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be rewarded.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him give </span>the fine <span class="gemarra-regular">to the poor </span>instead of to the Samaritan who he raped, to prevent assimilation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari said: </span>This is not done, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is money that has no claimants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since one would not be liable to give it to a specific poor person, the rapist could evade payment by responding to any claimant that he wants to give it to a different poor person. The Sages upheld the Torah law as it stands, and the fine is given to the Samaritan so that the sinner will not benefit.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ox of </span>a halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent person gored an ox of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deaf-mute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, or a minor, </span>all of whom are not considered halakhically competent, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damages. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor gored an ox of </span>a halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent person,</span> the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If an ox belonging to a deaf-mute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an imbecile, or a minor gored </span>another ox and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">the court appoints a steward for them and warns them </span>with regard to the ox that gored <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of the steward. </span>The ox is thereby rendered a forewarned ox, since the steward is considered its owner with regard to the requirement of the verse: “And warning has been given to its owner” (Exodus 21:29).
If, after the ox was rendered forewarned in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">the deaf-mute </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regained his hearing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the imbecile became </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent, or the minor reached </span>the age of <span class="gemarra-regular">majority, </span>the ox has thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">reverted to its </span>status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir, </span>who maintains that the ox had the status of a forewarned ox only while it was under the custody of the steward. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: It retains its </span>previous <span class="gemarra-regular">status </span>of being forewarned.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">a stadium [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ha’itztadin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one that is trained to fight in a stadium, gores and kills a person, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, as it is stated: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">if an ox gores </span>a man or a woman” (Exodus 21:28). This is referring only to an ox that gores on its own initiative, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not to </span>the case of an ox where others <span class="gemarra-regular">induced it to gore. </span>Therefore, the owner of a stadium ox, which is trained to gore, is exempt from liability if it does.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter itself is difficult. </span>First the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">said: If </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor gored an ox of </span>a halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent person, </span>the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appoint a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stewar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">collecting </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds of the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If an ox belonging to a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor gored </span>another ox and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">the court appoints a steward for them and warns them </span>with regard to the ox that gored <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of the steward. Apparently, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints a steward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">collecting </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its body.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaching: </span>A steward is not appointed to enable collection of compensation from the bodies of innocuous oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they have acquired the reputation of being habitually goring </span>oxen, as this was not an isolated incident, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints a steward </span>for the owners, <span class="gemarra-regular">and warns them in the presence of the steward, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>the oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. </span>This is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that when </span>one of the oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">gores again, </span>the owner will be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, and not only from the proceeds of the sale of the goring ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From whose superior-quality </span>property is compensation collected for damage caused by a forewarned ox belonging to minor orphans? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the orphans. Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: From the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the steward.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not attend to the property of orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to have them pay a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span><span class="gemarra-regular">interest is eroding </span>their estate. In other words, in a case where the orphans’ father borrowed money from a gentile with interest, the court ensures that the debt is paid from the orphans’ property, since if they wait to pay the debt, it will grow dramatically. Apparently, in other cases the court does not collect from their property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The court collects from them <span class="gemarra-regular">either to </span>pay a debt recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">a document that has </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">interest </span>stipulated in it, in order to ensure that the interest does not diminish the value their estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">or for </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to </span>their interest in not paying for her <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance. </span>A widow can claim her marriage contract from her deceased husband’s property, and as long as she does not receive it, her husband’s heirs are responsible for providing her sustenance. In a case where the heirs are minor orphans, the court collects payment of the marriage contract from the orphans’ property, so that they will not have to pay for her sustenance in the interim. Evidently, Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that with the exception of these two cases, the court does not collect debts from the property of orphans.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that payment for damage caused by forewarned oxen is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the steward, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina </span>is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that it is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the orphans.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to the difficulty </span>created by the contradiction between the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">you render Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina mistaken, </span>by attributing an opinion to him that is not the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Wasn’t Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina a judge who delved into the complexities of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one can resolve the contradiction in another manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, do not reverse </span>the opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the resolution to the contradiction is that although Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that debts are not collected from the property of minor orphans, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who causes damage </span>to another by not safeguarding his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that compensation is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the orphans, because if you say </span>that it should be collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the steward, </span>

Daf 39b

people <span class="gemarra-regular">will refrain from becoming </span>stewards, fearing that they would incur a financial loss by having to pay for damage caused by the orphans’ animals. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says </span>that it is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from the superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the steward, and </span>there is no concern that people will refrain from becoming stewards, because if they pay for the orphans <span class="gemarra-regular">they are subsequently repaid by the orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when they grow up.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the matter of whether or not the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints stewards for </span>the halakhically incompetent owners <span class="gemarra-regular">of an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">collecting </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body </span>if it gores <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>subject to a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox whose owner became a deaf-mute, or whose owner became an imbecile, or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose owner went overseas, </span>if the ox gores, <span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nakosa</span> said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos said: It retains its </span>status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness until </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">renders it forewarned in the presence of the owner. And the Rabbis say: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints stewards for them, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is rendered forewarned in the presence of the stewards.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the deaf-mute regained his hearing, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">the imbecile became </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent, or the minor reached majority, or its owner came </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">from overseas, Yehuda ben Nakosa </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos said: </span>The ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has reverted to its </span>previous status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness, until it is rendered forewarned in the presence of the owner. Rabbi Yosei said: </span>The ox <span class="gemarra-regular">retains its status </span>of being forewarned.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: What did Sumakhos </span>mean <span class="gemarra-regular">by saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it retains its </span>status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness? If we say that </span>he meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not rendered forewarned at all, </span>and is still considered innocuous, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Sumakhos himself <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has reverted to its </span>previous status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness, </span>it is clear <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>previously <span class="gemarra-regular">it was rendered forewarned.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>did Sumakhos mean by saying that <span class="gemarra-regular">it retains its </span>status of <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuousness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">betammuto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]? </span>He meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">it retains its completeness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bitmimuto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], as we do not reduce its </span>owner’s share of it by collecting compensation from the sale of its body. Rather, the injured party must wait until the owner becomes competent or returns. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appoint a steward for </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of an innocuous </span>ox to enable the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its body. And the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Sumakhos, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints a steward for </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and renders </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned in the presence </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the steward. Apparently, </span>they hold that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does appoint a steward for </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of an innocuous </span>ox to enable the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its body.</span>
