The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? </span>The Gemara answers: The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is with regard to whether a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos holds </span>that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas Rabbi Yosei holds </span>that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not change </span>it; rather, it is determined by the actions of the ox itself, regardless of its custody.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that gored </span>that belonged to <span class="gemarra-regular">a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, Rabbi Ya’akov pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did Rabbi Ya’akov do </span>that he should pay for the damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>emend the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing? If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? Everyone </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>holds that one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>caused by their ox that gored, so what is the novel element of Rabbi Ya’akov’s statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox it is unclear why the owner pays half the cost of the damage, as <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he provided </span>adequate <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding for it he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not required to pay at all, and if </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not provide </span>adequate <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding for it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to pay the entire </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>Rabbi Ya’akov stated his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he provided reduced safeguarding and did not provide superior safeguarding for it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ya’akov holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that when an ox is rendered forewarned the liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">its element of innocuousness remains in place. </span>In other words, with regard to half of the damages, it is treated like an innocuous ox, and it is treated as a forewarned ox only with regard to the other half of the damages. Therefore, half the cost of the damage is still collected from the proceeds of the sale of its body. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, with regard to another issue Rabbi Ya’akov <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that although superior safeguarding is necessary for an innocuous ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced safeguarding is sufficient for a forewarned </span>ox. Consequently, one who safeguards his forewarned ox in this manner is exempt from paying the additional half that he would be liable to pay due to the ox’s forewarned status. He is liable with respect to the half that he pays due to its remaining element of innocuousness.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Ya’akov also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say</span> that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints a steward for </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of an innocuous </span>ox to enable the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its body. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Ya’akov rules that in the case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where a forewarned ox owned by a halakhically incompetent person is safeguarded in a reduced fashion, half the cost of the damage must be paid from the proceeds of the sale of its body.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">But do </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Ya’akov <span class="gemarra-regular">not disagree </span>with regard to this matter? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, that gored, Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and Rabbi Ya’akov says that he pays </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage? Rabba bar Ulla says: </span>There is no disagreement here; <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">explained what Rabbi Yehuda deems him liable </span>to pay.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Abaye,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says </span>that Rabbi Ya’akov and Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree, with regard to what</span> principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree?</span>
The Gemara answers: Abaye could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">here we are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dealing with a forewarned </span>ox whose owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not safeguard it at all </span>and that is consequently liable for the full cost of the damage.
And <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda with regard to one </span>issue <span class="gemarra-regular">and disagrees with him with regard to one </span>issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">He holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda with regard to one </span>issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that when an ox is rendered forewarned <span class="gemarra-regular">its element of innocuousness remains in its place, </span>and Rabbi Ya’akov agrees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he disagrees with him with regard to one </span>issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints a steward for </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox to enable the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from its body, whereas Rabbi Ya’akov </span><span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appoint </span>a steward. Therefore, the owner is exempt from paying the half for which he would be liable due to the ox’s element of innocuousness, <span class="gemarra-regular">and pays only the half </span>damages he is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>status.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Abaye said to Ravina: Granted, according to Abaye, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, </span>the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well. But according to Rava, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not disagree, instead of interpreting </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have interpreted it </span>as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to an innocuous </span>ox. 

Daf 40a

There are two scenarios in which the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> could be interpreted as referring to an innocuous ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one wants to interpret it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>it can be discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he provided reduced safeguarding for it and did not provide superior safeguarding for it. If </span>one wants to interpret it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, </span>it can be discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not provide safeguarding for it at all.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">both an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">whose</span> owner <span class="gemarra-regular">provided reduced safeguarding for them, he is exempt. </span>The owner is liable only if he did not safeguard them at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov teaches us this, that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints stewards for </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">of an innocuous </span>ox to enable the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds of the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body.</span>
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying </span>by interpreting Rabbi Ya’akov’s statement with regard to a forewarned ox: Rabbi Ya’akov stated <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">containing two </span>elements of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ta’ama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, namely, that a forewarned ox retains its element of innocuousness, and that reduced safeguarding is sufficient for a forewarned ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> a different explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Ya’akov <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> with regard to whether a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>in a case where the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was forewarned </span>while in the custody of the steward <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the deaf-mute regained his hearing, or the imbecile became </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent, or the minor reached majority, </span>and the ox returned to its owner’s custody. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">in its </span>previous <span class="gemarra-regular">status, </span>the change of custody notwithstanding, and that therefore the owner is liable for the full cost of the damage. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov holds</span> that the change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox, which reverts to innocuousness, and so the owner pays only half the cost of the damage.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Stewards </span>are liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay from </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property for damage caused by forewarned oxen under their custody, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they do not pay a ranso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> if the oxen killed a person.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span> that the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">atonemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for the owner of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that therefore a minor orphan’s steward is exempt from liability to pay it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans are not subject to </span>the obligation of <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement </span>since they are not morally responsible?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse: “If a ransom is imposed upon him, <span class="gemarra-regular">then he shall give for the redemption of his life” </span>(Exodus 21:30), is referring to the monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> injured </span>party. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: </span>The ransom corresponds to the monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the one liable for the damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, do they not disagree with regard to this </span>very issue? In other words, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom is monetary restitution </span>for the damage caused, and therefore the heirs of the victim must be paid the monetary value of the victim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement </span>for causing the death of a person. Accordingly, the amount of the ransom is the monetary value of the one liable, since, from the perspective of his moral responsibility for the incident, he deserves to pay with his life. Although the court does not impose capital punishment, his atonement is through payment of his own value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: No, </span>it is possible <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone ransom is atonement, and here they disagree with regard to this </span>issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we evaluate </span>the amount that is appropriate for atonement <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the monetary value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party,<span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we evaluate </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one liable for the damage. </span>All agree that the purpose of the ransom is atonement.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of the Rabbis? Imposing is stated </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">later </span>verse: “If ransom is imposed upon him” (Exodus 21:30), <span class="gemarra-regular">and imposing is stated </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier </span>verse, concerning a person who injures a pregnant woman, causing her to miscarry: “He shall be punished as the husband of the woman shall impose upon him” (Exodus 21:22). This verbal analogy indicates comparison of the two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>with regard to compensation for causing miscarriage, the evaluation is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the monetary value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party<span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the fetus, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>the ransom is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, holds </span>that the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And he shall give for the redemption of his life,” </span>indicates that the ransom is redemption of the life of the ox’s owner, and its amount should accordingly be the owner’s monetary value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis </span>would respond to this reasoning that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For the redemption of his life,” is written, </span>indicating that the purpose of the ransom is redemption of his life. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nevertheless,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when we evaluate </span>the amount he is liable to pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">we evaluate </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of the injured </span>party.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava was praising Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov before Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman, </span>saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is a great man. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: When he </span>happens to <span class="gemarra-regular">come to you, bring him to </span>visit <span class="gemarra-regular">me.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">came to him, </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Ask me something. </span>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <span class="gemarra-regular">asked him: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to two partner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> kills a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">how do they pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom?</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in full <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>partner also pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in full, it would seem incorrect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one ranso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> shall be paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not two ransoms. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>partner pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom and that </span>partner pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, </span>it would also seem incorrect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a full ranso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> shall be paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not half a ransom.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">While </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">was sitting and pondering this </span>question, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov asked him another question. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna: The court <span class="gemarra-regular">repossesses </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from those liable </span>to pay their <span class="gemarra-regular">valuation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who are delaying their payments. But the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not repossess </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from those liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">sin-offerings and guilt-offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> they are relied upon to bring their offerings of their own initiative, as it is assumed they want to atone for their transgressions (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 21a). In light of this mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
Should it be reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is atonement, it is similar to </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering and a guilt-offering, </span>which a person <span class="gemarra-regular">treats seriously, </span>as it is in his interest to achieve atonement, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need to repossess </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from him? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>it should be reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he is required to give </span>the ransom <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>person, he considers <span class="gemarra-regular">it a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> financial </span>liability <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>an obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the Most High, and </span>consequently he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not treat it seriously </span>enough; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore the court <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to repossess </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>as he might not pay it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it could be reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">did not sin but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his property, </span>i.e., his ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">that caused the damage, he does not treat the matter seriously </span>enough, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore the court <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to repossess </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from him </span>to ensure payment.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Leave me alone. I am </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">stuck on the first </span>question and have no solution, so you must not raise further difficult questions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>Even though one who borrows an ox from another is generally responsible for damage that it causes, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he borrowed it on the presumption </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>and it gored and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it was </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, the owner pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and the borrower pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was rendered forewarned in the house of the borrower, </span>i.e., it gored three times while in his possession, and he was warned in court, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it to the owner </span>and it subsequently gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>as with regard to him it is still considered innocuous, having become forewarned while not in his custody, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the borrower is exempt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>compensation, since the ox is no longer in his custody.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">on the presumption </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous and it was found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, the owner pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and the borrower pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>should the borrower pay at all? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">I borrowed an ox; I did not borrow a lion.</span> I did not accept responsibility for safeguarding a forewarned ox, which behaves violently like a lion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: Here we are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">was aware </span>at the time he borrowed it <span class="gemarra-regular">that it was a goring </span>ox and liable to cause damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him say to</span> the owner: Even though I knew that it was a goring ox, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">I borrowed an innocuous </span>ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not </span>intend to <span class="gemarra-regular">borrow a forewarned </span>ox and thereby accept responsibility for safeguarding an ox for which one must pay the full cost of its damage.
The Gemara answers that the borrower is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: Ultimately, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if it was innocuous, you would be required to pay half the damages. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">now too, go pay half the damages.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it was innocuous, </span>the damages <span class="gemarra-regular">would be paid from </span>the proceeds of the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">the body of </span>the ox, not from my property.
The Gemara answers: The borrower cannot say this, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: Ultimately, would you not have been required to pay me </span>back the full value of my <span class="gemarra-regular">ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> As a borrower you are obligated to return the ox to me in the same condition that you borrowed it. Even if compensation was collected from the proceeds of its sale you would still have been required to return its full value to me. Therefore, in any event you would effectively be paying for the damage, so you are not losing anything from the fact that the ox is forewarned.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>

Daf 40b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was innocuous, I would have admitted </span>my liability <span class="gemarra-regular">and would </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">have been exempt. </span>A fine is imposed only as result of the testimony of two witnesses; if the offender admits his liability, no fine is imposed. Therefore, since the liability to pay half the cost of the damage for the act of an innocuous ox is a fine, the borrower could have rendered himself exempt from liability through admission.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to the one who says </span>that payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">half the damage is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution, </span>not a fine, and therefore his admission would not have rendered himself exempt from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: If </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was innocuous, I would have smuggled it out to the marsh [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">agma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> so that the injured party would not find it in my possession. He would then be unable to collect damages from me, since he can collect payment only from the proceeds of the sale of the ox. By contrast, compensation for damage caused by a forewarned ox can be collected from all of the owner’s property, and the borrower had no way of render-ing himself exempt from liability. Therefore, it is unclear why the borrower is liable to pay half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the court seized </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> before the borrower had the chance to admit his liability or to smuggle the ox to the marsh. Therefore, the borrower cannot claim that he would have been able to render himself exempt from liability.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why does the owner pay half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage? Let him say to </span>the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">You let my ox be seized by </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">with whom I cannot engage in litigation </span>in an attempt to reach a compromise; the court collects full payment, and you are responsible for this situation. Therefore, you should pay the entire amount. The Gemara answers that the owner is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: If I would have returned it to you, would </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">not have taken it from you?</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you would have returned it to me I would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have smuggled it to the marsh, </span>and the court would not have been able to seize it. The Gemara answers: The owner cannot say this, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: Ultimately, would </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">have received payment from </span>your <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of a forewarned ox, where the compensation paid is not only from the proceeds of the sale of the belligerent ox?
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>from which compensation can be collected, besides the ox. But <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not have </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">property, what is there to say? </span>In that case, the borrower has in fact caused him loss.
The Gemara answers: The reason the borrower is exempt is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as I am indebted to you, </span>to return your ox to you, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, I am indebted to that </span>injured party to whom you owe compensation. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Natan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: From where </span>is it derived that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">is owed one hundred dinars by another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the other </span>person, i.e., the debtor, is owed one hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">by another </span>person, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriates </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>latter debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">and gives </span>the money directly <span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>first creditor, without going through the middleman, who is both the first debtor and the second creditor? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states, </span>with regard to returning stolen property: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he gives it to the one with regard to whom he is guilty” </span>(Numbers 5:7), indicating that there is a situation where the liable party pays a third party to whom his creditor owes money in turn.
It is stated at the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited earlier (40a): If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was rendered forewarned in the house of the borrower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the borrower then <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it to the owner</span> and it subsequently gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the borrower is exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>compensation.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">The last clause </span>of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox; if it was rendered forewarned while in the borrower’s possession and was then returned to its owner, the owner pays only half the cost of the damage for any subsequent damage it might cause, as it is no longer considered forewarned. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which teaches that the ox retains its status as forewarned even after being borrowed, indicates that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody does not change </span>the status of the ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">disjointed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tavra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who taught this </span>clause <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach that </span>clause.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: From </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>follows the opinion that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody does not change </span>the status of the ox, it is inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause also </span>follows the opinion that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody does not change </span>its status. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is the reason </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>the ox reverts to its status of innocuousness: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to</span> the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not in your power to render my ox forewarned, </span>as I did not give it to you with that intention and it was your negligence that caused the change in its status. Therefore, the owner is not liable to pay additional compensation that results from the status the ox acquired under the custody of the borrower.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: From </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>follows the opinion that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>the status of the ox, it is inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause also </span>follows the opinion that a change of <span class="gemarra-regular">custody changes </span>its status. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is the reason </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause</span> the ox is considered forewarned even when in the custody of the borrower: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because wherever it goes, the name of its owner is upon it. </span>Since it was rendered forewarned under its owner’s custody, with whom it remains identified, it is not considered to have undergone a change of custody.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a stadium ox is not liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>since it was trained to gore. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If an ox kills a person it may not be brought as an offering, even if it is not put to death. If a stadium ox kills a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> sacrificing it on <span class="gemarra-regular">the altar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>to be brought as an offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified. Rav says </span>that the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>because it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">due to circumstances beyond its control, </span>as goring is what it was trained to do; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified as, </span>in any event, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">transgression was committed through it.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that interprets the verse: “You shall bring your offering from the cattle, even from the herd or from the flock” (Leviticus 1:2). The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“from the cattle” </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality and </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">was the object of bestiality </span>from eligibility to be brought as an offering. The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“from the herd” </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>an animal that had been <span class="gemarra-regular">worshipped </span>as a god. <span class="gemarra-regular">“From the flock” </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>an animal that had been <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>for idol worship. The additional conjunction “or,” in the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“or from the flock” </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>a person, killing him.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said: If it is stated </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality </span>is disqualified from being brought as an offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">why is it stated </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>is disqualified? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is stated </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>is disqualified, <span class="gemarra-regular">why is it stated </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality </span>is disqualified?
He explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is </span>a stringency <span class="gemarra-regular">pertaining to </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality that does not pertain to </span>one that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and, </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a stringency <span class="gemarra-regular">pertaining to </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores that does not pertain to </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality.</span>
He clarifies: With regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span> is a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control like </span>a case where it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">willfully, </span>as it is disqualified in either case. By contrast, with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">does not render </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control like </span>a case where it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">willfully. </span>Conversely, with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom; </span>whereas the owner of an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pay a ransom. Therefore, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">had to state </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality </span>is disqualified <span class="gemarra-regular">and had to state </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores </span>is disqualified.
The Gemara explains the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control like </span>a case where it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">willfully. </span>By contrast, with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">does not render </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control like </span>a case where it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">willfully. With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is this stated? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not with regard to </span>the animal’s eligibility to be brought as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering? </span>Accordingly, a stadium ox, which is considered a victim of circumstances beyond its control, is fit to be brought as an offering, contrary to Shmuel’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, it is with regard to </span>the animal being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>i.e., the ox is not killed if it is a victim of circumstances beyond its control.
<span class="gemarra-regular">So too, it is reasonable, as if you say </span>that the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the animal’s eligibility to be brought as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering, </span>how can the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> state the following: By contrast, with regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores, </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">does not render </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control like </span>a case where it acted <span class="gemarra-regular">willfully. Neither </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances beyond its control written </span>in that context, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor is its willingness written; </span>the issue is not mentioned in the Torah at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>is the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the animal being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>where this distinction is indicated in the Torah? The mishna interprets the phrase: “And if an ox gores” (Exodus 21:28), as indicating that the ox is not put to death in a case where it is induced to gore; therefore, this distinction is mentioned in the Torah with regard to the animal being put to death. Accordingly, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not address the topic of dispute between Rav and Shmuel.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">gores, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the ransom, </span>whereas the owner of an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality does not pay a ransom. What are the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> circumstances </span>under which the owner of an animal that engaged in bestiality is not liable to pay the ransom? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>is when the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality with </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">and killed he</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in the process, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">it killed her with its horn, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">it killed her through bestiality?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And rather, </span>if the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality with her but did not kill her, </span>in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not pay a ransom is </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">it did not kill her,</span> so paying ransom is irrelevant; it is not a feature associated with the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of an animal that engaged in bestiality.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Actually, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality with her but did not kill her, </span>and it is still noteworthy that its owner is not liable to pay ransom, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">was brought to court, and they executed her </span>for her transgression. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say</span>

Daf 41a

that the ox should be considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like one that killed her, </span>as it was the reason for her execution, and therefore its owner should be liable to pay a ransom, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in bestiality with her and killed her </span>in the process. <span class="gemarra-regular">And as for the difficulty you </span>pose: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">it killed her with </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">horns, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">it killed her through bestiality, </span>the answer is that in that case of an animal killing with its <span class="gemarra-regular">horn, its intention is to cause injury</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereas in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of killing through bestiality <span class="gemarra-regular">its intention is to </span>achieve <span class="gemarra-regular">its own pleasure.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>other case <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span>Abaye and Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? </span>They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">trampled a child with its foot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> killing it, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the injured </span>party. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Abaye, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, </span>as he holds that ransom is paid even if the animal’s objective was not to cause injury or death. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Rava, he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav: A stadium ox </span>that killed a person <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to </span>be sacrificed as an offering on <span class="gemarra-regular">the altar, because it is as though it was compelled </span>to behave in this manner.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that gored a person and </span>the person <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays ransom, but </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous he is exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">the ransom.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>forewarned ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">are liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>for killing a person. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the same </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the animal killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where it killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a girl. </span>If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>and killed a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservant, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the victim’s master <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, whether he was </span>a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">maneh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., one hundred silver dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">or worth only one dinar.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since we kill </span>the ox for killing a person <span class="gemarra-regular">when it is </span>still considered <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, how can you find </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox killing a person?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where in three </span>instances of attacking <span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">assessed </span>that had the people not escaped, the ox would certainly have killed them. Therefore, despite the fact that the ox did not kill anyone, it now has the status of a forewarned ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said:</span> Such <span class="gemarra-regular">an assessment is not </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">anything. </span>Since the ox did not actually kill them, it is not rendered forewarned even if it intended to kill. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> endangered </span>the lives of <span class="gemarra-regular">three people </span>by goring them, and they all died only after the third goring. Therefore, the ox had not been put to death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it killed three animals, </span>which is sufficient to render the ox forewarned but for which it is not put to death.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to animals </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to people </span>as well? Certainly it is not. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Shimi said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it killed three gentiles, </span>for which the animal is not put to death.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to Jews </span>as well? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it killed three people who had wounds that would have caused them to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>Since they were on the verge of dying anyway, the ox is not put to death for killing them. Nevertheless, it is rendered forewarned with regard to its future goring and killing of people.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an intact </span>person, i.e., one who is not a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Pappa said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it killed </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">and fled to the marsh, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">and fled to the marsh, </span>and then killed again and fled to the marsh, so the court was not able kill it before it had killed three times, rendering it forewarned.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">who had rendered </span>the witnesses who testified to the three incidents of goring as <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>result-ing in the animal not being put to death, <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>themselves subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">proven </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses </span>by other witnesses. Consequently, the testimonies of the witnesses who testified about the incidents of goring were reinstated, rendering the ox forewarned.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well if </span>it is assumed that the purpose of testifying to the ox’s goring is because <span class="gemarra-regular">we wish to establish the ox as forewarned; </span>once the testimony concerning the incidents of goring is reinstated, it is established that the ox gored three times. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if we wish to warn the man </span>who owns the ox by testifying that the animal gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">he could say to </span>the judge, after it is established that his ox was forewarned: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not know </span>that my ox was forewarned, since the witnesses had previously been rendered conspiring witnesses. The Gemara answers: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Each time his ox killed </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">he was standing by it, </span>so that he cannot claim ignorance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized the owner of the o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but did not recognize the ox </span>itself. Therefore, with regard to the first incidents of goring, they testified that it was his ox that gored, but they did not testify with regard to the ox itself. That is why the ox was not put to death. Only afterward did they realize that this was the ox that had gored three times previously.
The Gemara asks: If so, why is the ox rendered forewarned? <span class="gemarra-regular">What could </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">have done </span>to prevent it from goring again, as he did not know which of his oxen had gored? The Gemara answers that it is rendered forewarned <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the court effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have </span>a habitually <span class="gemarra-regular">goring ox in your herd, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">you must safeguard your entire herd.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>forewarned ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">are liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death. The Sages taught: </span>We learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference from </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is stated </span>with regard to an ox that killed a person: “And if an ox gores a man or a woman, that they die, <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox shall be stoned, </span>and its flesh shall not be eaten; but the owner of the ox shall be clear” (Exodus 21:28). <span class="gemarra-regular">Don’t I know </span>from this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the stoning makes it an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass, and it is prohibited to eat </span>an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Its flesh shall not be eaten”? The verse is telling you that </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if one slaughtered </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">after its verdict had been reache</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> but before it was stoned, it is still <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to eat </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that one is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is it derived that one is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>from the ox as well? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “But the owner of the ox shall be clear.”</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the inference? </span>How is this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived from the statement that the owner shall be clear? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon ben Zoma says: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a person who says to his friend: So-and-so was left clear of his property, and has no benefit from it at all. </span>Similarly, “but the owner of the ox shall be clear” means that he may not derive benefit from the ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it known <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh shall not be eaten,” </span>serves to teach a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he slaughtered </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">after its verdict was reached, </span>but before it was stoned, and is teaching that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to eat </span>it? Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say that it is permitted to eat </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">if he slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">after its verdict had been reached. And this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh shall not be eaten,” </span>serves to teach a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span>had already <span class="gemarra-regular">stoned it, </span>but not to teach a prohibition against eating it, as that is already known due to the fact that it was stoned. Rather, it serves to prohibit deriving benefit from the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that would be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abbahu.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Abbahu says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">wherever it is stated: “It shall not be eaten”</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">“you,” </span>singular, <span class="gemarra-regular">“shall not eat”; or “you,” </span>plural, <span class="gemarra-regular">“shall not eat”; both a prohibition </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">eating and a prohibition </span>against deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>are indicated. This is so <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the verse specifies for you </span>that one may derive benefit, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner that it specified for you with regard to an animal carcass, </span>from which the verse explicitly permits one to derive benefit.
The Gemara continues: This is so <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the verse specifies for you </span>that one may derive benefit, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner that it specified for you with regard to an animal carcass, </span>from which the verse explicitly permits one to derive benefit, as it states: “You may sell it to a foreigner” (Deuteronomy 14:21). Accordingly, it is permitted to transfer an unslaughtered animal carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ger</span> <span class="it-text">toshav</span>, i.e., a gentile who resides in Eretz Yisrael and observes the seven Noahide mitzvot, <span class="gemarra-regular">through givin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> it to him as a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">and to </span>any other <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile through selling </span>it to him. Apparently, without this explicit permission, it would be prohibited to derive any benefit from a carcass, due to the prohibition: “You shall not eat.” Here, too, with regard to the ox that is stoned, the phrase: “Its flesh shall not be eaten,” may serve to teach that one may not derive benefit from the stoned ox.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">That statement </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the prohibition of eating and the prohibition of deriving benefit are derived from a verse </span>using an expression such as: <span class="gemarra-regular">“It shall not be eaten.” But here, where the prohibition of eating is derived </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the statement: “The ox <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be stoned,” if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh shall not be eaten,” is </span>stated only in reference to the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition of deriving benefit, let the Merciful One write </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">Benefit shall not be derived </span>from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>let the verse simply state: <span class="gemarra-regular">“It shall not be eaten”; why do I </span>require the specific term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh”? </span>Clearly, the intention of the verse is to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that even if he has rendered it like </span>kosher <span class="gemarra-regular">flesh by </span>properly <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering it </span>after the verdict, one is still <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to eat it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra objects to this: Say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies

Daf 41b

only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he checked </span>a sharp piece of <span class="gemarra-regular">flint</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and, </span>seeing that it did not have any defects, <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">with it. </span>In that case, one could say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>by slaughtering it with a stone, <span class="gemarra-regular">he performed the equivalent to stoning. </span>Therefore, it is prohibited to eat it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he slaughtered it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a knife </span>made of metal, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>prohibited from eating it.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written in the Torah </span>that slaughter must performed specifically with <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife, </span>which would justify a distinction between slaughtering with a stone and a knife? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 15b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters with a hand-sickle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>a piece of <span class="gemarra-regular">flint, or with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if these implements were suitable to be used for slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">his slaughter is valid?</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to Rabbi Abbahu, <span class="gemarra-regular">now that he derives the prohibition of eating and the prohibition of deriving benefit from</span> the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh shall not be eaten,” why do I </span>require the statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear”? </span>The Gemara answers: This is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>prohibit <span class="gemarra-regular">deriving benefit from its hid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> after it has been killed; <span class="gemarra-regular">as it could enter your mind to say that it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">its flesh from which it is prohibited to derive benefit, </span>as the verse states: “Its flesh shall not be eaten,” but <span class="gemarra-regular">deriving benefit from its hide will be permitted. </span>Therefore, the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox shall be clear, </span>to indicate it is prohibited to derive benefit from any part of the ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to those </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who expound this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” for another interpretation, as we wish to state below, from where do they derive </span>this prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">deriving benefit from </span>the ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hide?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They derive it from </span>the wording: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its flesh </span>may not be eaten [<span class="it-text">velo</span> <span class="it-text">ye’akhel</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">et</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">besaro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].” </span>The verse could have been formulated: <span class="it-text">Velo</span> <span class="it-text">ye’akhel</span> <span class="it-text">besaro</span>, which already means: And its flesh shall not be eaten. The addition of the word “<span class="it-text">et</span>” teaches that the prohibition applies also to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is secondary to the flesh. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">what is that? </span>That is <span class="gemarra-regular">its hide.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who derives it from the statement: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” <span class="gemarra-regular">does not interpret </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>as a means to derive new <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. He considers the word “<span class="it-text">et</span>” to be an ordinary part of the sentence structure and not a source for exegetical exposition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon HaAmasoni, and some say </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Neḥemya HaAmasoni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would interpret all </span>occurrences of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” in the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> deriving additional <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to the particular subject matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once he reached </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall fear the Lord your God” </span>(Deuteronomy 6:13), which is written with the added word “<span class="it-text">et</span>,” <span class="gemarra-regular">he withdrew </span>from this method of exposition, as whose fear could be an extension of the fear of God? <span class="gemarra-regular">His students said to him: Our teacher, what will be with all </span>the occurrences of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” that you interpreted </span>until now? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: Just as I received reward for the exposition, so I received reward for </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">withdrawal </span>from using this method of exposition.
The word “<span class="it-text">et</span>” in this verse was not explained <span class="gemarra-regular">until Rabbi Akiva came and expounded: “You shall fear the Lord your God”: </span>The word “<span class="it-text">et</span>” serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include Torah scholars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that one is commanded to fear them just as one fears God. In any event, Shimon HaAmasoni no longer derived additional <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> from the word <span class="it-text">et</span>.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>with regard to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But the owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall be clear from paying half a ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although the owner of an innocuous ox that causes damage is liable to pay half the cost of the damage, if an ox kills a person its owner is not liable to pay any ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to him: </span>Why is it necessary for the verse to teach this? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>compensation for damage caused by an innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>anyway <span class="gemarra-regular">paid only from </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body? </span>Here too, its owner can say to the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring it to court and it will pay you, </span>i.e., you will be paid from its value. Since the ox is stoned, there is nothing from which he can receive payment. Therefore, according to your interpretation, the verse does not introduce any <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that could not have been inferred by logic, and is therefore superfluous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer said to him: Is this how I </span>appear <span class="gemarra-regular">in your eyes, that my derivation </span>from the verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> case, that of an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that is liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death? </span>Obviously no verse would be required to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in such a case. <span class="gemarra-regular">My derivation is only </span>with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the assumption that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed a person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the admission of <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner. </span>Such proof is not sufficient for the ox to be put to death by stoning, but one might have thought that it is sufficient to require its owner to pay ransom.
The Gemara asks: If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the admission of <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner, </span>he clearly would not be liable to pay ransom, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span> would be <span class="gemarra-regular">admitting to </span>an act that results in <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case a person is exempt from paying the fine; so why would it be necessary for the verse to state this exemption?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>is for the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement, </span>and is not considered a fine. Accordingly, one might have assumed that even in a case where there is not conclusive testimony, the owner must pay ransom to atone for the killing. Therefore, the verse states that in the case of an innocuous ox, the owner is not liable to pay half a ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer said to him: Akiva, is this how I </span>appear <span class="gemarra-regular">in your eyes, that my derivation </span>from the verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> case, that of an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that is liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death? My derivation is only </span>with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill an animal but killed a person </span>instead; or where it intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>kill <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile but killed a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jew; </span>or where it intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>kill <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-viable baby but killed a viable person. </span>An ox is not put to death if it intended to gore in a manner which would not render it liable to be put to death, even if it did gore in such a manner. In such a case, the owner of the ox must pay ransom. Therefore, the verse states that if it is an innocuous ox, the owner is exempt from paying half a ransom.
These two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> cite different responses that Rabbi Eliezer gave Rabbi Akiva. <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>one of these explanations <span class="gemarra-regular">did he say to him first?
