Rav Kahana said in the name of Rava: He first said to him </span>the explanation referring to the ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intention </span>to kill someone for which it would not be liable to be put to death, and subsequently gave him the second explanation with regard to the testimony of a single witness, or the owner’s admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tavyumei said in the name of Rava: He first said to him </span>the explanation that it is a case where the assumption that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>was based on one witness or its owner’s admission.
The Gemara explains the reasoning behind the two opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">first he said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>the explanation involving the ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intention, </span>since this opinion is preferable to the other one, against which a difficulty was raised earlier. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">analogous to a fisherman pulling fish from the sea. </span>

Daf 42a

When <span class="gemarra-regular">he finds big ones he takes </span>them, and when he finds <span class="gemarra-regular">small ones he takes </span>them as well. Here too, although Rabbi Eliezer’s first explanation was sufficient, he added an additional response, despite the fact that it was not as good as the first.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tavyumei said in the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he first said to him </span>the explanation involving inconclusive testimony asserting that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed, </span>since this is <span class="gemarra-regular">analogous to a fisherman pulling fish from the sea, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">finds small ones </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>them, and when he then <span class="gemarra-regular">finds big ones, he discards the small ones and takes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the big ones. </span>Here too, once Rabbi Eliezer thought of a better response to Rabbi Akiva’s question, he suggested it instead of the first.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: </span>It means he shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">clear from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, if an innocuous ox causes a woman to miscarry, the owner is not liable to pay half the compensation for the miscarried offspring.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to him: </span>It is unnecessary for the verse to teach this. <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t it say</span> with regard to paying compensation for miscarried offspring: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If men struggle and hurt a </span>pregnant <span class="gemarra-regular">woman </span>and her offspring emerge, and there is no tragedy, he shall be punished as the husband of the woman shall impose upon him and he shall give as the judges determine” (Exodus 21:22); from which it is inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">men </span>who cause a woman to miscarry are liable to pay compensation for the offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen </span>who cause a woman to miscarry is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable?
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva is saying well; </span>he states a reasonable objection. What would Rabbi Yosei HaGelili have responded to him?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ulla, son of Rav Idi, said: It was necessary </span>for the verse to teach this exemption, as otherwise it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that this inference should be limited, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Men </span>are liable to pay compensation for miscarried offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen that are comparable to men </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. Only some oxen are excluded from this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as men are </span>categorically considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, so too </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen, </span>which are contrasted with men in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of miscarriage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">would be liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to pay compensation for miscarried offspring. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One wrote </span>with regard to an innocuous ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>to teach us <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said, </span>in objection to this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">The native is on the groun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the stranger is in the heavens. </span>The aforementioned suggestion contradicts the principle that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a forewarned ox is more stringent than that of an innocuous ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different way for Rabbi Yosei HaGelili to counter Rabbi Akiva’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary </span>for the verse to teach this exemption, as otherwise it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">men </span>are liable to pay for miscarried offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen that are comparable to men </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as men are </span>categorically considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, so too </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen, </span>which are contrasted with men in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And for </span>miscarriage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous oxen, </span>their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>due to an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One then wrote </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span>innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox shall be clear,</span> indicating that only for <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox is one <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation for miscarried offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: If that is so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>which is derived from the verse: “When men struggle together, a man and his brother, and the wife of one drew near to deliver her husband from the hand of the one who smites him, and extended her hand, and grabbed his genitals” (Deuteronomy 25:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say this as well: </span>Only <span class="gemarra-regular">men </span>are liable to pay for humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen that are comparable to men </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as men are </span>categorically considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, so too </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen, </span>which are contrasted with men in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And for </span>humiliation caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous oxen, </span>their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>due to an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One then wrote </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the </span>innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox shall be clear, </span>indicating that only for <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous</span> ox is one <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation for humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>that is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> according to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>that with regard to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: He is exempt </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring and from </span>paying compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation.</span>
Rava then retracted this explanation of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye and Rava both say </span>that Rabbi Akiva’s inference is correct, according to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, but with regard to the continuation of the verse: “But if any harm follows, you shall give life for life” (Exodus 21:22). With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">men, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no harm </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the woman, </span>i.e., she is not killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">they shall be punished </span>financially and are liable to pay compensation for miscarried offspring. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is harm </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the woman </span>and she dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">they shall not be punishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> financially, as they are liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment. This distinction applies only with regard to men <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as even if there is harm </span>caused to the woman, the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be punished </span>financially. In order to preclude this inference, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One then wrote: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation for miscarried offspring.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava objects to this: Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the issue </span>of financial liability <span class="gemarra-regular">is dependent on </span>whether or not there was <span class="gemarra-regular">harm </span>caused to the woman? Clearly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the issue is dependent on the intent </span>to strike the woman.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Adda bar Ahava said </span>a different inference: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">men, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they intended to </span>strike <span class="gemarra-regular">each other, even if there is harm </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the woman, </span>i.e., she dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">they shall be punished </span>financially, and are liable to pay compensation for miscarried offspring. But <span class="gemarra-regular">when they intended to </span>strike <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman herself </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they shall not be punished </span>financially, as they are liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this distinction does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as even if they intended to </span>strike <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman herself, </span>their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be punished. </span>In order to preclude this inference, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One wrote: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying compensation for miscarried offspring.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, when Rav Ḥaggai came from the South, he came and brought a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his hand </span>that interprets the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Adda bar Ahava.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear” </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says:</span> This statement teaches that if an innocuous ox kills a Canaanite slave, its owner shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">clear from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for the slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> unlike the case of a forewarned ox that killed a Canaanite slave, where the ox’s owner is liable. 

Daf 42b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let Rabbi Akiva say to himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> the same objection that he raised against Rabbi Eliezer’s interpretation of the verse, that the owner of an innocuous ox is exempt from paying half a ransom (see 41b): Why is it necessary for the verse to teach this? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>compensation for damage caused by an innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">itself paid only from </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body? </span>Therefore, its owner can say to the slave’s owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring it to court and you will be paid from it. </span>Since the ox was stoned, there is nothing from which he can collect payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: </span>Rabbi Akiva’s interpretation is applicable in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where its owner slaughtered it first</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> before it was sentenced to stoning. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that the slave’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should be paid from </span>the value of the flesh, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was subject to be killed, although </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it, </span>the slave’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be paid from it.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>why did Rabbi Akiva raise this objection against Rabbi Eliezer’s interpretation? <span class="gemarra-regular">According </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Eliezer as well, </span>it could be explained as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it first.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed, </span>Rabbi Eliezer’s interpretation could also be explained in this manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason Rabbi Akiva raised this objection was because <span class="gemarra-regular">he reasons: Perhaps </span>Rabbi Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">has another explanation that is better than this one, and will state it.</span> Rabbi Eliezer did in fact respond with another explanation.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let Rabbi Eliezer also answer him that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it first. </span>Why did he offer a different explanation? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Eliezer could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Specifically there, </span>in the case Rabbi Eliezer referred to in his explanation, namely, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">animal but killed a person </span>instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the ox was not subject to be killed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">at all, </span>it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should be liable </span>to pay half a ransom from the ox’s body. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse is necessary to exclude </span>the owner from liability to pay half a ransom. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, since </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was initially subject to be killed, a verse is not necessary </span>to teach that the owner is exempt from paying half a ransom <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he slaughtered it.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Akiva also, certainly it is so, </span>that a verse is not necessary to teach that if the owner slaughters the ox before its verdict he is exempt from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Asi said: </span>The above explanation of Rabbi Akiva’s interpretation should be rejected, as <span class="gemarra-regular">I heard this </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">statement from a great man, and who is he? </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. </span>This is what he said: It might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Akiva says </span>in the mishna (33a) that in a case where a person and an innocuous ox damaged each other concurrently, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that injured a person also pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage with regard to the difference </span>between the two valuations of the damage, as there is no distinction between an innocuous ox and a forewarned ox with regard to injuries caused to a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for the slave is also paid from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, not from the body of the ox; just as in a case where a forewarned ox kills a slave. Therefore, its owner cannot say: Bring it to court and you will be paid from it. To counter this possibility, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One wrote: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>indicating that he is exempt from this liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Asi: But didn’t Rabbi Akiva </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">break </span>the force of <span class="gemarra-regular">his fist, </span>i.e., qualify this opinion of his? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that the owner of an innocuous ox that injured a person <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, the same as the owner of a forewarned ox. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “According to this judgment shall be done to him [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 21:31), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>restitution exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">body </span>of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not pay from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property, as the word <span class="it-text">lo</span> also means: To it. This negates Rav Asi’s explanation of Rabbi Akiva’s interpretation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different explanation of Rabbi Akiva’s statement: The verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>because it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since I, </span>referring to the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">am more stringent with regard to </span>a forewarned ox that kills a person in the case of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave than </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman; as </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> in ransom, and if he was worth <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives thirty; but </span>in the case of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave </span>the Torah imposes a fixed amount, so even if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>only one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives thirt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>, therefore, since the Torah is more stringent in the case of a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">payment for the slave should also be paid from </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property. To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>indicating that payment is not required in a case where an innocuous ox kills a slave.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>to Rabbi Akiva’s statement. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that with regard to the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” Rabbi Akiva says: </span>He shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">clear from payment for </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave.</span>
Rabbi Akiva discusses this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>could this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be derived through <span class="gemarra-regular">logical inference, </span>without the verse? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the killing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave and deemed </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>the killing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman</span> as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as when </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for a freeman you distinguished between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox, as no ransom is paid in the case of an innocuous ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, when </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for a slave, let us distinguish between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Furthermore, </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> could be proven through an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">If, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman, where he, </span>the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">gives his full value, you distinguished between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, where he gives only thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span> and not more, even if the slave was worth more, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not logical that we should distinguish between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox, and exempt him from liability for an innocuous ox?
Rabbi Akiva rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>one could disagree and say the opposite: <span class="gemarra-regular">I, </span>referring to the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">am more stringent with regard to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave than </span>with regard to that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman; as </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman worth </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives</span> only one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and if he is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives thirty. But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, </span>even if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>only one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he gives thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>. Therefore, one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should be liable </span>to pay for a slave killed by his innocuous ox. To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “The owner of the ox shall be clear,” </span>indicating that he shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">clear from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for a slave.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>The verse states with regard to a forewarned ox: “But if the ox was a goring ox in time past and warning has been given to its owner, and he has not secured it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and it killed a man or a woman; </span>the ox shall be stoned” (Exodus 21:29). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said: And what does this come to teach us? If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to deem </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>the killing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>for the killing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a man,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is already stated </span>with regard to an innocuous ox, where it is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“When an ox gores a man or a woman, </span>and they die, the ox shall be stoned” (Exodus 21:28).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the verse is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">to compare a woman to a man </span>with regard to another issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a man, </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">his injuries </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to his heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">her injuries </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to her heirs, </span>and not to her husband.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rabbi Akiva hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a husband does not inherit </span>from his wife? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall inherit it [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">otah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Numbers 27:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">From here </span>it is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the husband inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as <span class="it-text">otah</span> also means: Her. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish said: </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that her heirs and not her husband receive the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to ransom,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since it is paid only posthumously and is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">considered </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to her; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the husband does not take </span>in inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">du</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property she <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed. </span>For instance, an inheritance that would have gone to the woman had she been alive is not awarded to the husband, but rather, to her other heirs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the assumption that even if it is clear that the victim is about to die, the husband is not owed ransom? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “And it killed a man or a woman; the ox shall be stoned, and its owner also shall be put to death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If a ransom is laid on him, </span>then he shall give for the redemption of his life whatsoever is laid on him” (Exodus 21:29–30), indicating that the owner’s liability to pay ransom is dependent on the ox’s liability to be stoned, which, in turn, applies only after the death of the victim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And with regard to damages, did Rabbi Akiva not say</span> that damages due to a wife are paid to her heirs and not to her husband, just as with regard to ransom?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If an assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">struck the woman and her offspring emerge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> due to miscarriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage and pain to the woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring to the husband. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband is not </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives</span> the compensation for the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">to his heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman is not </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>the payment owed to her <span class="gemarra-regular">to her heirs. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she was </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she was emancipated, </span>

Daf 43a

and subsequently married a Canaanite slave who had also been emancipated, and became pregnant from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if she was <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert</span> who became pregnant from a male convert, and both the husband and wife died without heirs, the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">gains</span> by not having to pay, since there are no heirs. In any event, it is explicitly stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the beneficiary of the compensation due to her, including that which she would have received during her lifetime, is not her husband but rather her heirs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> relates <span class="gemarra-regular">to a divorcée; </span>since they got divorced, the husband does not inherit from her. <span class="gemarra-regular">Likewise, Rav Naḥman said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> relates <span class="gemarra-regular">to a divorcée.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: If she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a divorcée, </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">should also shar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>the miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring. </span>Why should her ex-husband receive the full payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The Torah awarded the </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring to the husband, even if he </span>is not actually her legal husband but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in licentious sexual intercourse with her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although he has no rights to her property, the damages for the miscarried offspring belong to him alone, as he is the father of the offspring. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “As the husband [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ba’al</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the woman shall impose upon him” </span>(Exodus 21:22), indicating that damages are not collected by the woman, but by the man who engaged in intercourse [<span class="it-text">ba’al</span>] with her, impregnating her. Therefore, if they got divorced, the ex-husband receives the payment.
The Gemara asks: Why do Rabba and Rav Naḥman explain this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring to a divorcée? They could have answered, in accordance with their own opinions elsewhere (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 124b), that it is referring to payments that are not considered to have been in the woman’s possession during her lifetime, but rather are considered property due to the woman, which her husband does not inherit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us establish </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabba, </span>as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they collected money</span> for the damage and pain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Naḥman, where they collected land.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>with regard to the right of a firstborn to receive a double portion of the inheritance of his father, he receives a double portion only of the property possessed by his father, not of the property due to him. In a case where money was owed to the father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>If the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">collected </span>the debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to a double portion, since it is considered property that was already in the father’s possession. If <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected money, he does not have </span>a double portion, as it is considered property due to the father. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected money, he has </span>a double portion, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected land, he does not have </span>a double portion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That statement </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the residents of the West</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>who limit the rights of a firstborn to his father’s property to the extent that they hold he does not receive a double portion of any appreciation in the property occurring after his father’s death.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">when they state </span>that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>relates to a divorcée, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi that the firstborn receives a double portion even in the appreciation of the property occurring after the father’s death. According to this opinion, clearly everything due to the father is considered to be in his possession, whether he receives his compensation in money or in land. The same applies to a husband, who inherits the rights to inherit compensation for damage and pain inflicted on his wife. That is why Rabba and Rav Naḥman had to interpret this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as relating to a divorcée.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that killed </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave unintentionally, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying the fine of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty shekels, as it is stated: “He shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned” </span>(Exodus 21:32). It is derived from the verse that the liability to pay thirty shekels is dependent on the stoning of the ox; <span class="gemarra-regular">whenever the ox is </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be killed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning, the owner pays thirty shekels </span>as compensation for the damage. If <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be killed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning, </span>e.g., if it killed unintentionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner does not pay thirty shekels.</span>
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that killed a freeman unintentionally, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom; as it is stated: “The ox shall be stoned, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its owner also shall be put to death. If a ransom is laid on him” </span>(Exodus 21:29–30). This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">whenever the ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be killed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning the owner pays ransom; </span>and if <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox is not </span>liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be killed by <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning the owner does not pay ransom.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised an objection to</span> Rabba’s statement from a mishna: If a person admits: <span class="gemarra-regular">My ox killed so-and-so, or: </span>My ox killed <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox of so-and-so, this </span>owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays based on his own </span>admission (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 41a). This cannot be referring to the payment of a fine, as a person who admits his responsibility for an act incurring a fine is exempt from paying the fine. Clearly, it must be referring to a payment for which one can render himself liable through admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If so, this proves that payment of ransom is not dependent on whether the ox is liable to be killed by stoning, as the ox cannot be killed based on its owner’s admission alone.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to payment of the monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim. Although he is not liable to pay ransom, as the ox is not killed, nevertheless, since by his own admission his ox caused damage, he is liable to pay damages.
Abaye challenged this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">value</span> of the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of that mishna: If a person admits: <span class="gemarra-regular">My ox killed the </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave of so-and-so, he does not pay based on his own </span>admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if, </span>as you claim, the mishna is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim, not to the thirty-shekel fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>should he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>pay?
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">I could have answered you </span>by saying that <span class="gemarra-regular">the former clause, </span>which discusses an ox killing a freeman, is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the latter clause, </span>which relates to an ox that gored a slave, is referring to payment of the thirty-shekel <span class="gemarra-regular">fine. But I will not answer you with a forced answer. </span>Instead, I will answer as follows: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>clause <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>clause refer to the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim; 

Daf 43b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>there is a distinction between the two cases. With regard to an ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman,</span> there is a scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays ransom based on his own </span>admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what are the circumstances? If witnesses came and testified that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>a freeman and is therefore liable to be killed by stoning, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they did not know whether it was innocuous </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">if it was forewarned, and its owner said that it was forewarned. </span>In this case, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays ransom based on his own </span>admission, since the ox is liable to be killed, and the ransom is for atonement and does not constitute a fine. Therefore, even <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses, </span>and the ox is therefore not liable to be killed by stoning for killing a person, nevertheless, the owner at least <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim based on his admission.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, </span>there is a scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay the fine</span> of thirty shekels <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what are the circumstances </span>where one would be liable to pay this fine due to his own admission? <span class="gemarra-regular">If witnesses came and testified that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they did not know whether it was innocuous </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">if it was forewarned, and its owner said that it was forewarned. </span>In this case, even though the ox is liable to be killed, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay the fine based on his own </span>admission, due to the principle that one does not pay a fine based on his own admission. Therefore, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses, he does not </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim based on his own admission.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states a principle: In <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>his ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>his ox killing a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, whether with regard to </span>liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom or with regard to </span>the ox being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
The wording of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is unclear: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there a ransom </span>to be paid <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave? </span>Ransom is paid only for the killing of a freeman. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to payment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim? This poses a difficulty for Rabba’s opinion that one is not liable to pay the value of the victim for admitting to his ox’s killing of a slave.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he, </span>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak, <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the objection and he resolved it, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response, that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> a person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom for </span>his ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman, </span>e.g., where it gored <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine for </span>his ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave. And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his ox killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman, </span>e.g., where it gored <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, for a slave </span>too, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">value, </span>namely, where it gored <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses.</span> Accordingly, one does not pay the value of a slave based on his own admission, although he does pay the value of a freeman if he admits that his ox killed him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that one is liable to pay the value of the victim in cases where he is exempt from paying ransom, then if a person burns another to death <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the proof is <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, he should, </span>likewise, at least <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where does Rava </span>know <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not pay </span>the value of the victim if he started the fire unintentionally?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">from what we learned </span>in a mishna (61b): If one ignites a heap of grain and <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a goat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bound </span>to an item adjacent <span class="gemarra-regular">to it, and </span>there was also <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave adjacent to it </span>but not bound, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the heap of grain, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay for the heap of grain and for the goat. If the <span class="gemarra-regular">slave </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">bound to it </span>in such a way that he was unable to flee from the fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">goat </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">adjacent to it, and </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">burned with it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability. Apparently, there is no liability even if he unintentionally burned the slave to death.
The Gemara comments: If this is Rava’s source, there is no proof from here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Reish Lakish say </span>that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ignited the body of the slave </span>directly, in which case he is exempt from paying damages <span class="gemarra-regular">because he receives the greater </span>punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">of them?</span> Since he is liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment for killing the slave, he is not liable to pay damages. Therefore, this does not serve as proof that one is not liable to pay the value of a fire victim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if Rava’s proof is <span class="gemarra-regular">rather from that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (10a): The <span class="gemarra-regular">stringency that applies to Fire as opposed to Pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one responsible for <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">consuming both something that is fitting for it and something that is not fitting for it, </span>i.e., both flammable and non-flammable items. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not so with regard to Pit, </span>as damages are not paid for everything that can be damaged by a pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach: That </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire, </span>one is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim even if the fire was ignited <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally. This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not so with regard to Pit. </span>This would seem to support Rava’s opinion that one is not liable to pay the value of an unintentional victim of fire.
The Gemara comments: If this is Rava’s source, there is no proof from here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>one distinction <span class="gemarra-regular">and omitted </span>another; it simply did not enumerate all the differences.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rava’s statement should not be understood as an objection to Rabba’s opinion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava himself had a dilemma </span>with regard to the matter: If a person burns another to death <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire, does he pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">or not?</span>
The Gemara elaborates on the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is specifically with regard to </span>death caused by one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, where </span>if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally he pays ransom </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally he pays </span>the victim’s monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>instead; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to death caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire, where </span>even if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally he does not pay ransom, </span>if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally he does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value either? Or perhaps, since with regard to </span>the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox </span>gored <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, although there is no </span>liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the victim. One should say that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his fire too, even though </span>in a case where it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally he does not pay ransom, </span>when it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, he should pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value in any event.</span>
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we do not kno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> the solution to this dilemma, which <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ With regard to Rabba’s statement that for an ox that killed a person unintentionally one is exempt from paying ransom, the Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he reported that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>It would have been sufficient for the verse to state: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A ransom </span>is laid on him.” <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “If a ransom </span>is laid on him” (Exodus 21:30)? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>in a case where the ox killed <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>when it killed <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, </span>in contrast to Rabba’s opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Dimi: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan’s interpretation <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so, </span>it should be implemented with regard to the fine for a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave as well, </span>and it would have been sufficient for the verse to state: The ox gores a slave or a maidservant, he shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “If </span>the ox gores <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave” </span>(Exodus 21:32)? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>liability in a case where the ox killed a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave unintentionally, </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>when it killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave intentionally. And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but doesn’t Reish Lakish say </span>that for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that killed a slave </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally</span> its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying the <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty shekels?</span>
Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are you setting </span>the statement of one <span class="gemarra-regular">man</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against </span>the statement of another <span class="gemarra-regular">man? </span>It could be that although Reish Lakish maintains that he is exempt, Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that he is liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he confirmed that this is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>as he <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that it would have been sufficient for the verse to state: “The ox gores a <span class="gemarra-regular">slave.” What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">states: “If </span>the ox gores <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave”? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>liability in a case where the ox killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave unintentionally, </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>when it killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave intentionally.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Reish Lakish, let us say similarly </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not interpret </span>the difference between the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a slave” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a slave” </span>to derive an additional <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not interpret </span>the difference between the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a ransom” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a ransom” either, </span>and holds that ransom is not paid if the incident was unintentional.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: No,</span> that is not a valid comparison. Although Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">does not interpret </span>the difference between the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a slave” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a slave,” he does interpret </span>the difference between the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a ransom” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a ransom.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what is different </span>between the two verses? The terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a slave” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a slave” are not written where </span>the liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>is stated, but rather in the presentation of the case: “If the ox gores a slave.” Therefore, the use of the word “if” is warranted. By contrast, the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“a ransom”</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a ransom” are written where </span>the liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>is stated, where it would have been sufficient for the verse to state: “A ransom is laid on him.” Therefore, the superfluous word “if” lends itself to interpretation to include liability to pay ransom even in a case where the killing was unintentional.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the same </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the ox killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy or in </span>a case where it killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a girl. The Sages taught: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Whether it has gored a son or has gored a daughter” </span>(Exodus 21:31), <span class="gemarra-regular">to deem </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>the death of <span class="gemarra-regular">minors </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as for adults.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">this not </span>be derived through <span class="gemarra-regular">logical inference? Since </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders a person liable </span>to receive court-imposed capital punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing another <span class="gemarra-regular">person, and,</span> similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">renders an ox liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, </span>it should be derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as when </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders a person liable for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>the Torah makes <span class="gemarra-regular">no distinction between </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">minors and </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">adults, so too, when it renders an ox liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, do not differentiate with regard to it between minors and adults.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>could be inferred <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: If </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">does not render minors </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">like adults with regard to this </span>act, inasmuch as minors are exempt from liability for killing, but nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it renders </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">minors </span>as well <span class="gemarra-regular">as adults, </span>

Daf 44a

then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, where </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders small </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">like large </span>ones <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>act, as a young calf that kills a person is killed just as an adult ox that kills a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it not logical that </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">minors, </span>i.e., a boy or a girl, just <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>for killing <span class="gemarra-regular">adults? </span>Why is it necessary for the verse to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
The Gemara rejects this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this cannot be derived by logic alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>who kills <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>is liable even when the victim is a minor, this may be due to the extra severity in the case of a human assailant, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he is liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">four types </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of indemnity </span>for causing injury; pain, humiliation, medical costs, and loss of livelihood, in addition to payment for the actual damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall you </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an ox, whose </span>owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable to </span>pay these <span class="gemarra-regular">four</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> types of indemnity? </span>Clearly, this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> cannot be derived merely through logical comparison between the two cases. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Whether it has gored a so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or has gored a daughter,” to render </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for minors </span>as well <span class="gemarra-regular">as adults.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And I have </span>derived this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to forewarned </span>oxen; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>do I derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, it is killed if it kills a boy or a girl?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: Could this not be derived through <span class="gemarra-regular">logical inference? Since </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman, and </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy or a girl; </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">just as when it renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman you do not differentiate between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox, as both are stoned, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, when it renders </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy or a girl do not differentiate between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>it can be inferred <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman, whose power is diminished with regard to damages </span>because adults who cause damage are liable to pay, but nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not differentiate between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox that kills them; then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy or girl, whose power is enhanced with regard to damages </span>because they are not liable to pay for damage they cause, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not logical that you should not differentiate between an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox that kills them?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">you could say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does one derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a lenient </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">from a stringent </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to </span>be more <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent with regard to it? If </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">is stringent with regard to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is a stringent </span>matter, rendering it liable to be killed for killing a minor, does that mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">you should be stringent with regard to an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span>a relatively <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient </span>matter?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore,</span> there is another reason to reject the earlier opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that an innocuous ox is liable to be killed <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>killing <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman, as they are obligated to </span>observe the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot, </span>which gives them importance, does that mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">you should say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a boy or a girl, who are exempt from the mitzvot?</span>
Since this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> could not have been derived through logic alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Whether it has gored a son or has gored a daughter,” </span>stating the phrase “has gored” twice, to teach that it is referring both to the <span class="gemarra-regular">goring of an innocuous </span>ox and to the <span class="gemarra-regular">goring of a forewarned </span>ox, and both to <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>that causes <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>and to <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>that causes <span class="gemarra-regular">injury. </span>In all these cases the owner of the ox is liable even if the ox gores a minor.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox was rubbing against a wall, and </span>as a result the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">fell on a person </span>and killed him; or if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">animal but killed a person; </span>or if it intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>kill <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile but killed a Jew; </span>or intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>kill <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-viable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bab</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but killed a viable person; </span>in all these cases the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from being killed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>since it did not intend to kill, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav says: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from this </span>liability <span class="gemarra-regular">and from that </span>liability.
The Gemara asks about Shmuel’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>is he liable to pay ransom? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>with regard to this action? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in a different context, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an ox that was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to falling on people in pits. Here too, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an ox that was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to rubbing against walls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> causing them to fall <span class="gemarra-regular">on people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if it was forewarned with regard to this behavior, it clearly intended to kill the person and <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">subject to </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>contrary to the ruling in the mishna. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted there, </span>in the case where the ox was forewarned with regard to falling on people in pits, it could be <span class="gemarra-regular">that it saw a vegetable </span>on the edge of the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fell </span>in, without any intention to kill. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here,</span> where it rubbed against a wall, causing it to fall on a person, and was forewarned with regard to this behavior, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say </span>in its defense?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here also </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where it rubbed against the wall for its pleasure </span>and not in order to kill. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we know </span>that it did not intend to kill? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">fell it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was still rubbing against it, </span>which proves that this was its intention. 

Daf 44b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But still, is it </span>not a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">pebbles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Is this case not analogous to damage caused by pebbles inadvertently propelled from under the feet of an animal while it is walking, which is not considered damage caused directly by the ox, but rather, damage caused indirectly? Ransom is not imposed for such indirect killing. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">gradually gave wa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> under the pressure applied by the ox, and so while the ox was still pushing the wall it collapsed and killed the person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, and </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav: There are </span>cases where the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death and </span>the owner is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there are </span>cases where the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to</span> pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom but </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, and there are </span>cases where the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death but </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, and there are </span>cases where they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from this </span>punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">and from that </span>one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox kills a person <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death and </span>the owner is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox kills <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom but </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox kills <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death but </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom; </span>and if <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox kills <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from this </span>punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">and from that </span>one. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states explicitly that although a forewarned ox that kills a person unintentionally is exempt from being put to death, its owner is liable to pay ransom, in accordance with Shmuel’s opinion, and in contrast with Rav’s opinion.
