The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">injuries</span> caused by an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from which the victim is not killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay for the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Shimon exempts </span>him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He derives </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to injury caused by the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>payment he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if the ox gores <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">injuries </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">also liable </span>even if it gores <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon derives </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the putting to <span class="gemarra-regular">death of an ox </span>by the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>if it kills a person <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, so too, </span>if it causes <span class="gemarra-regular">injuries unintentionally </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment.
The Gemara questions the above explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let Rabbi Yehuda also derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning an ox unintentionally causing injury <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>The Gemara answers: In his opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">we can derive </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>for injury <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of ransom, which is another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">payment. But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we cannot derive </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">payment from </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
Conversely, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let Rabbi Shimon also derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> here <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>payment. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We can derive </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">liability of an ox from </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">liability of an ox, to the exclusion of </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom, which is the liability of the owner. </span>Compensation for injury is considered the ox’s liability, as it is the ox that caused the injury, whereas the ransom paid is for the owner’s atonement. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning injury cannot be derived from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of ransom, as they are dissimilar.
§ The mishna teaches that if an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">animal but killed a person, </span>or if it intended to kill a person for whom it would not be liable to be put to death but killed a person for whom it would be liable, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara infers: If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill this </span>person, for whom it would be liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">but killed that </span>person instead, it is still <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: Even </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to kill this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">but killed that </span>person, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon? </span>The Gemara answers that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the verse states: “The ox shall be stoned, and its owner also shall be put to death”</span> (Exodus 21:29); the juxtaposition of the ox and its owner indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">as the death of the owner, </span>i.e., a person, for killing another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">death of the ox </span>for killing a person. In other words, the two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are applied in the same circumstances. Specifically, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as the owner, </span>i.e., a person, is not liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he intends </span>to kill the person whom he ultimately kills, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, an ox </span>is not put to death <span class="gemarra-regular">either, unless it intends </span>to kill the one whom it ultimately kills.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner himself, from where do we </span>derive that he is not liable unless he killed the one whom he intended to kill? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: “And he lay in wait for him, and rose against him, </span>and struck him mortally and he died” (Deuteronomy 19:11). From the term “for him,” Rabbi Shimon derives that the killer is not liable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he intends </span>to kill <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the one whom he ultimately killed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what do the Rabbis, </span>who deem the killer liable in that case and who therefore disagree with Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">do with this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he lay in wait for him”? </span>How do they interpret it? The Gemara answers that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Rabbi Yannai say </span>that this phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">one who throws a stone into </span>an area where there are several people, some of whom are people for whom he would not be liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment, e.g., gentiles, and a stone killed a person for whom he would receive court-imposed capital punishment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that there are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nine gentiles </span>in the crowd <span class="gemarra-regular">and one Jew among them, </span>even without the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the exemption from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that a majority of them are gentiles. Alternatively, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the people are gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>are Jews, derive the exemption from the principle that when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are nine Jews and one gentile. Although a majority of them are Jews, </span>the thrower is exempt from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is one gentile among them </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered fixed </span>in his place, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">any</span> item <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed </span>in its place <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of an uncertainty that is <span class="gemarra-regular">equally balanced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient. </span>This is what the Rabbis derive from the phrase: “And he lay in wait for him.”
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to </span>orphans, and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>belonging to orphans that is in the custody <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">steward, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a desert ox, </span>which is ownerless, and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>to the Temple treasury, and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no heirs, </span>rendering the ox ownerless; all of <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">are liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>for killing a person. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A desert ox, a consecrated ox, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died are exempt from </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, since they have no owners.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the passage discussing an ox that kills a person (Exodus 21:28–32), the Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“An ox,” “an ox,” </span>repeating this word <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>times, <span class="gemarra-regular">to include</span> an additional six cases, in addition to the classic case of an ox goring and killing a person. They are: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox belonging to a woman, an ox belonging to orphans, an ox </span>belonging to orphans that is in the custody <span class="gemarra-regular">of a steward, a desert ox, a consecrated ox, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no heirs. Rabbi Yehuda says: A desert ox, a consecrated ox, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no heirs are </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>being put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, since they have no owners.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: Rabbi Yehuda would deem </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt even </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>and killed <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately consecrated </span>it, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">it gored and he ultimately renounced </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership </span>over it, since at the time of the trial in court the ox does not have an owner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>did Rav Huna derive this assertion? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches two </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">a desert ox and an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no heirs.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What is </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died? Since he has no heirs it is considered to be an ownerless ox. </span>Accordingly, the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a desert ox is </span>the same as the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no heirs, </span>and it does not seem necessary for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to state both cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, does it not teach us this: That even if </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he ultimately consecrated </span>it, or, if <span class="gemarra-regular">it gored and he ultimately renounced ownership</span> over it, it is exempt, just as in a case where a convert’s ox gores and subsequently the owner dies? The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>assertion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, Rabbi Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even if it gored and he ultimately consecrated </span>it, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">it gored and he ultimately renounced ownership </span>over it, the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: “And warning has been given [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehuad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to its owner</span>…<span class="gemarra-regular">and it killed</span>…the ox shall be stoned” (Exodus 21:29). It is derived from here that the owner of the ox is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the ox’s status as the owner’s property at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at the time of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">standing tria</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the same</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that the ox has an owner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t we require </span>that the ox’s status be the same at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict </span>as well? <span class="gemarra-regular">And isn’t </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“the ox shall be stoned” </span>also referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict? Rather, </span>emend the statement and <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the owner of the ox is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the ox’s status as the owner’s property at the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at the time of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">standing trial and </span>at the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">the verdict are identical as one.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> leaving </span>court <span class="gemarra-regular">to be stoned </span>for killing a person <span class="gemarra-regular">and its owner </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated it, it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, </span>i.e., the consecration does not take effect, since deriving benefit from the ox is prohibited and the ox is therefore worthless. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it, its flesh is forbidden </span>to be eaten and it is prohibited to derive benefit from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if its owner consecrated it before its verdict </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and if he slaughtered it its flesh is permitted.</span>
If the owner of an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to a borrower, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">to a paid bailee, or to a renter, </span>and it caused damage while in their custody, <span class="gemarra-regular">they enter </span>into the responsibilities and liabilities <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of the owner. </span>Therefore, if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, and </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous he pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that killed </span>a person, if its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it before its verdict, </span>

Daf 45a

<span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered legally <span class="gemarra-regular">sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and belongs to the purchaser for all purposes. Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, it is </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and all the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of consecrated property apply to it. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">its meat. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee </span>charged with safeguarding it <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it to its owner’s house </span>before the verdict <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">returned, </span>and the owner has no further claim against the bailee.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">once its verdict has been issued</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sells it, it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">sold, </span>since the ox is no longer his. Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrates it, it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters it, its meat is forbidden. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee returns it to its owner’s house it is not </span>considered to have been <span class="gemarra-regular">returned, </span>since the ox is considered to have been killed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says: Even once its verdict has been issued, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the bailee returns it to its owner it is</span> considered to have been <span class="gemarra-regular">returned.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that they disagree about this: The Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to items from which it is prohibited to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit one does not say: That which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yours is before you, </span>and no compensation is required. Once the deposited item was rendered forbidden, the bailee cannot return it as is to its owner, claiming that since it has not been physically damaged he has fulfilled his obligation to return it and therefore the owner has no further claims against him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ya’akov holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does say, with regard to items from which it is prohibited to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit: That which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yours is before you.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>Clearly, according <span class="gemarra-regular">to everyone, one says with regard to items from which it is prohibited to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit: That which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yours is before you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as, if </span>this was the subject of disagreement, <span class="gemarra-regular">let them dispute </span>this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to leavened bread on Passover, </span>which is a more common case of an item from which it is prohibited to derive benefit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, here they disagree with regard to </span>the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">issuing the verdict for an ox in its absence. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis hold that the verdict for an ox can be issued only in its presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Therefore, the bailee is not exempt by returning it after the verdict, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">could say to him: If you had returned </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>before the verdict <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have smuggled it to the marsh, </span>and the court would not have been able to sentence it to stoning. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now you </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">let my ox be seized by </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">with whom I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cannot engage in litigation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ya’akov holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verdict for an ox can be issued in its absence. </span>Therefore, the bailee is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he can say to </span>the owner in response to his claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, they would have issued the verdict </span>anyway, so I did not cause your ox to be stoned by not returning it to you before the verdict.
According to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>that the ox’s verdict can be issued only in its presence? The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The ox shall be stoned, and its owner also shall be put to death” </span>(Exodus 21:29), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">as the death of the owner, </span>i.e., a person, for killing another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the death</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the ox </span>for killing a person. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as the owner </span>is sentenced to death only <span class="gemarra-regular">in his presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too, an ox </span>is sentenced to death only <span class="gemarra-regular">in its presence.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ya’akov </span>holds that the owner and the ox cannot be compared. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> owner </span>must be present when the verdict is issued, as people <span class="gemarra-regular">are able to present claims </span>in their defense; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, is it capable of presenting claims? </span>Consequently, it makes no difference whether or not the verdict is issued in its presence.
§ The mishna teaches: If the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee, or to a borrower, or </span>to a paid bailee, or to a renter, they enter into the responsibilities and liabilities in place of the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>people who <span class="gemarra-regular">enter into </span>the responsibilities and liabilities <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of the owner, and they are: An unpaid bailee, and a borrower, a paid bailee, and a renter. </span>If the oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">killed</span> people while in the possession of one of these people, if the oxen were <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>at the time they killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are killed and </span>the bailees are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom. </span>If they were <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they are killed and </span>the bailees <span class="gemarra-regular">pay ransom. And </span>regardless if they were innocuous or forewarned, the bailees <span class="gemarra-regular">are liable to return the value of the ox to its owner, with the exception of an unpaid bailee.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What are the circumstances </span>in which the bailees are liable, with the exception of an unpaid bailee? <span class="gemarra-regular">If he safeguarded </span>the ox appropriately but the ox killed a person anyway, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of the </span>other bailees <span class="gemarra-regular">should also be exempt </span>from reimbursing the owner for the ox and not just an unpaid bailee, as they did everything that was required of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he did not safeguard it </span>properly, <span class="gemarra-regular">even the unpaid bailee should be liable, </span>as he was also required to safeguard it.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">provided reduced safeguardin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and did not provide superior safeguarding. </span>In this case <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unpaid bailee has fulfilled his safeguarding </span>duties; since he does not receive anything in exchange this level of safeguarding is sufficient. <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>other bailees, who have a greater responsibility, <span class="gemarra-regular">have not fulfilled their </span>required level of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said, </span>in clarification of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>

Daf 45b

<span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like an unpaid bailee </span>with regard to his responsibility for the rented item, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it teach </span>that bailees are liable to compensate the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">with the exception of an unpaid bailee and a renter.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let it teach: With the exception of an unpaid bailee, </span>as it in fact states; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>it should also state that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the oxen are <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, all of them are exempt with regard to ransom, </span>as Rabbi Yehuda says in the next mishna that a forewarned ox requires only a reduced level of safeguarding. Therefore, this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not appear to be in accordance with the opinion of either <span class="it-text">tanna</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said: </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, who says </span>that an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>at all <span class="gemarra-regular">other than </span>slaughtering it with <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife;</span> i.e., there is no degree of safeguarding that exempts the ox’s owner, or in the context of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the bailee, from liability if the ox causes damage or kills. <span class="gemarra-regular">And with regard to a renter, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir; and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabba bar Avuh reversed </span>the two opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">and taught: How does a renter pay? </span>In other words, what is his degree of responsibility? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Like a paid bailee.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda says: Like an unpaid bailee.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed his ox to an unpaid bailee, </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span><span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>the bailee is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages; but if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What are the circumstances? If </span>Rabbi Elazar was referring to a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accepted </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">guarding it from </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured he should be liable. And if </span>he was referring to a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who did not accept </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">guarding it from </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, even if it causes damage he should be exempt </span>from payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>Rabbi Elazar was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he accepted </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">guarding it from causing damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was a goring </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">the normal way of things is that </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted upon himself </span>responsibility for safeguarding it so <span class="gemarra-regular">that it would not go and injure others, </span>since he knew that it was dangerous. But <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">did not enter his mind that other </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">would come and injure it. </span>Therefore, he did not accept responsibility for safeguarding against such an occurrence.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">owner tied it with reins </span>to a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">or locked </span>the gate <span class="gemarra-regular">before it in an appropriate </span><span class="gemarra-regular">manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>nevertheless the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged and caused damage, whether </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since this is not considered sufficient precaution to prevent damage; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if he safeguarded it appropriately, since the Torah does not limit the required safeguarding for an innocuous ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from paying compensation for damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the verse describing damage by a forewarned ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the owner has not secured it” </span>(Exodus 21:36), <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>ox that was tied with reins or behind a locked gate <span class="gemarra-regular">was secured.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>An ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding</span> at all <span class="gemarra-regular">other than </span>slaughtering it with <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife; </span>there is no degree of safeguarding that exempts the ox’s owner from liability.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Meir? He holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary oxen are not presumed to be under safeguarding, </span>as their owners do not ordinarily safeguard them; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Merciful One stated </span>in the Torah that one <span class="gemarra-regular">will be liable </span>even for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> innocuous </span>ox inasmuch <span class="gemarra-regular">as it requires </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">a reduced </span>level of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding, </span>such as with reins. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One then stated with regard to a forewarned </span>ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured it,” </span>to indicate that it is not sufficient to provide it with only a reduced level of safeguarding, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it requires superior safeguarding. And </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">derives</span> this requirement with regard to an innocuous ox from a verbal analogy between the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an innocuous </span>ox and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox. In both cases superior safeguarding is required; otherwise the owner is liable.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary oxen are presumed to be under </span>some reduced level of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding.</span> Since <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One stated </span>nevertheless that even for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will pay, </span>it may be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">that it requires superior safeguarding. The Merciful One then states with regard to a forewarned </span>ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured it,” </span>emphasizing again <span class="gemarra-regular">that one must provide it with superior safeguarding. This constitutes </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">amplification following</span> another <span class="gemarra-regular">amplification, and </span>the principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification following an amplification is </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to restrict </span>its extent. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse excludes </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">superior safeguarding</span> with regard to a forewarned ox, and therefore reduced safeguarding is sufficient to exempt the owner from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that through the verbal analogy between the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> innocuous </span>ox and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox the Torah compares their <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One restricted </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> by emphasizing: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured it,” </span>referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to it, </span>a forewarned ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not to the other, </span>i.e., innocuous, ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t this </span>phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary for the negative [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>statement that if the owner does not provide superior safeguarding he is liable? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, let the Merciful One write: And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured. What </span>is the purpose of the added emphasis: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured it”? </span>It is to indicate that the restriction of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> relates specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to it, </span>a forewarned ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not to the other, </span>i.e., innocuous, ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that there is a fourth opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: </span>In the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">both an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">provided reduced safeguarding, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from liability.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for his opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">He holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced safeguarding is sufficient for a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he derives </span>from the verbal analogy between the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a forewarned </span>ox that just as reduced safeguarding is sufficient for a forewarned ox, it is sufficient for an innocuous ox as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Rabbi Yehuda deemed only the forewarned element of </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Rabbi Yehuda’s ruling that reduced safeguarding is sufficient to exempt the owner of a forewarned ox relates only to the additional half of the damage that is paid for a forewarned ox beyond the half of the damage that one is liable to pay for an innocuous ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> the liability for its <span class="gemarra-regular">element of innocuousness remains in place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, if the owner did not provide superior safeguarding for the forewarned ox he is still liable to pay half the cost of the damage as he would if it were innocuous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> If an ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to </span>goring with its <span class="gemarra-regular">right horn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned with regard to </span>goring with its <span class="gemarra-regular">left horn.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: In accordance with whose </span>opinion is Rav’s statement made? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Meir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doesn’t </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">require superior safeguarding? If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda, why </span>did he state that the ox still has an innocuous element <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">left horn? Even with regard to the right horn </span>itself it has both elements; <span class="gemarra-regular">it has an element of innocuousness and it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">has a forewarned element.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Actually, </span>Rav’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and he does not hold </span>in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Adda bar Ahava </span>that the ox’s innocuous element remains. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is what he is saying: You find an element </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">of innocuousness and of a forewarned </span>status in the same ox specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case like this, </span>where an ox is forewarned with regard to one horn but not with regard to the other. 

Daf 46a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if an ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely </span>rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, you do not find an element of innocuousness with regard to it at all. </span>If it is forewarned with regard to goring with either horn, its status of innocuousness is completely revoked.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>An ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>at all <span class="gemarra-regular">other than </span>slaughtering it with <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife. Rabba said: What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states </span>with regard to a forewarned ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has not secured it” </span>(Exodus 21:36), meaning that once it is rendered forewarned the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer has </span>any sufficient manner of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding this </span>animal, and the owner is responsible for all damage it causes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is written </span>with regard to a pit: “And if a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and not cover it” </span>(Exodus 21:33), <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>mean that once a pit has been dug the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer has </span>any adequate way of <span class="gemarra-regular">covering this </span>pit, which would exempt its owner from paying damages?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed</span> that is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (52a) that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropri-ately, and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt?</span> Evidently, a pit can be covered adequately.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye </span>rejected Rabba’s explanation of Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not raise a vicious dog in his house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not set up an unstable ladder in his house? As it is stated: “You shall not bring blood into your house” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:8), which means that one may not allow a hazardous situation to remain in his house. Similarly, a person should not keep a forewarned ox in his possession, as it is dangerous. This is why Rabbi Eliezer rules that no level of safeguarding is sufficient for it; the ox should be slaughtered so that it will not cause damage. 

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox that gored </span>and killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the cow’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fetus was found </span>dead <span class="gemarra-regular">at its side, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and it is not known whether </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth before </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it </span>and the fetus’s death is unrelated to the goring or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it gave birth after </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it </span>and the fetus died on account of the goring, the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the cow and one-quarter </span>of the cost <span class="gemarra-regular">of the damage for the offspring. </span>Since it is uncertain whether the ox was responsible for the death of the fetus, in which case he would pay half the damages, its owner pays only half the amount for the fetus that he would ordinarily be required to pay, i.e., one-quarter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And likewise, </span>there is uncertainty in the case of an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">cow that gored an ox, and </span>the cow’s newborn <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring was found at its side </span>dead or alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is not known whether </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth before it gored </span>the ox or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth after it gored. </span>When damage is caused by an innocuous animal, the liability of the owner is limited to the value of the animal that gored. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is paid from </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the cow, </span>as in the standard case of an innocuous animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if that does not suffice to pay for half the cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from the offspring. </span>Since it is uncertain whether the offspring was part of the cow at the time the cow gored, the owner pays only half of what he would pay if it were certain that it was part of the cow.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: This</span> ruling in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who says: Property of uncertain ownership </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">divided </span>by the two parties. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the significant principle of </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">law: The burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>and the disputed sum is not divided. According to the Rabbis, in the cases of uncertainty in the mishna, no payment is made for the fetus or from the offspring, respectively.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need for the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the significant principle of </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">law? </span>Why not just state the principle? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary </span>to say them <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">states: </span>I am <span class="gemarra-regular">certain </span>that such and such occurred, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one liable for the damage says: Perhaps </span>it was otherwise, without definitively refuting the claim against him, <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. </span>Although the injured party claims with certainty that he is correct and the defendant’s claim is only speculative, the definite claim still does not render the defendant liable to pay, absent proof.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>the phrase: This is the significant principle of monetary law, was necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>instances <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, as it was stated: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells an ox to another and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>to be one that <span class="gemarra-regular">habitually gores, Rav says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a mistaken transaction, </span>since the purchaser can claim that he bought the ox specifically for labor, and an ox that gores is not suitable for such tasks. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>The seller can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I sold it to you for slaughter, </span>and the fact that it gores is immaterial.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why</span> are Rav and Shmuel speculating about the purpose of the sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">see if </span>the purchaser is <span class="gemarra-regular">a person who buys </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a person who buys </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for slaughter. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for them to engage in a dispute in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a person who buys </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and for that </span>reason, and in this instance it was unclear for which purpose it was intended.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us see </span>what the purchase price was: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he paid <span class="gemarra-regular">the price of </span>an ox fit for <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a large amount of money, then it can be assumed it was intended <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he paid the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of </span>an ox for <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering, </span>which is a much smaller amount, it can be assumed that it was sold <span class="gemarra-regular">for slaughtering.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for them to engage in a dispute in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">meat rose and </span>an ox purchased for slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">stands at the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">price</span> as an ox purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing. </span>In that case, Rav and Shmuel dispute whether the purchaser can claim that the transaction was made in error, or whether the seller can claim that he sold it to be slaughtered and the purchaser must provide proof for his claim.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>

Daf 46b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the loss to the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be reimbursed from </span>the purchasing money by returning it, e.g., if the seller spent it already, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">take the ox </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">in lieu of the money, as people say: </span>Allow yourself to be <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid by your debtors </span>even in <span class="gemarra-regular">bran</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since anything may be used as payment for a debt. In the event that the seller has no money with which to reimburse the purchaser, even if it is a mistaken transaction the result may be that the purchaser keeps the ox in lieu of having his money returned. Accordingly, there would be no practical difference between the opinions of Rav and Shmuel.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for them to engage in a dispute in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does have </span>sufficient funds <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">to repa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the purchaser, and the purchaser demands that his money be returned as opposed to keeping the ox as payment.
The Gemara now explains the logic of Rav and Shmuel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mistaken transaction, </span>due to the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">Follow the majority, and the majority of people buy oxen for plowing. And Shmuel says </span>that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I sold it to you for slaughtering, and we do not follow the majority </span>in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">When do we follow the majority </span>according to Shmuel? Only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>determining the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>or permitted status of an item. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in monetary matters </span>such as this, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not follow the majority</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, </span>the operative principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>which Rav Yehuda stated above, that the mishna follows the opinion of Sumakhos, <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that gores a cow, and its fetus is found </span>dead <span class="gemarra-regular">at its side, and he does not know whether it gave birth before </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it or it gave birth after </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it, </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the cow and one-quarter </span>of the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage for the offspring; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. The Rabbis say: The burden of proof rests upon the claimant.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the burden of proof rests upon the claimant? As it is stated </span>in the Torah when Moses appointed Aaron and Hur to judge the people: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Whoever has a cause, let him come near </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yiggash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to them” </span>(Exodus 24:14). This is interpreted to mean that whoever has a claim against another <span class="gemarra-regular">should submit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yaggish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] proof to them. </span>According to this interpretation, this verse demonstrates clearly that the claimant is responsible for supplying the proof.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi objects to this: Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse </span>to derive this? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>based on <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning that one who suffers from pain goes to the doctor. </span>Just as here the individual with the problem has the responsibility to resolve it, so too, someone with a claim against another must bring a proof to corroborate his claim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, the verse </span>is needed <span class="gemarra-regular">for that which Rav Naḥman </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a court <span class="gemarra-regular">first attends only to</span> the arguments of <span class="gemarra-regular">the claiman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and only afterward attends to the counterclaims of the defendant and discusses them? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “Whoever has a cause, let him come near </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yiggash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to them,” </span>which is interpreted to mean that whoever has a claim against another <span class="gemarra-regular">should submit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yaggish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] his claim to them </span>first before the defendant.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say </span>that despite this principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes </span>a court <span class="gemarra-regular">attends to the defendant first </span>and listens to his defense before discussing the arguments of the claimant. <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where this occurs? This occurs in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his assets are depreciatin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> because of the claim against him. In that situation, the court allows him to present his arguments first so that he can sell his assets at their true price.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And likewise, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow that gored an ox, </span>and the cow’s newborn offspring was subsequently found at its side, half the cost of the damage is paid from the cow and one-quarter of the cost of the damage is paid from the offspring. The Gemara asks: The mishna’s wording indicates thatthe owner of the cow pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>thereby amounting to three-quarters of the cost of the damage. This is difficult to understand, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to pay </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>since the ox is innocuous. If the mishna states that he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">three-quarters of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, what is its purpose?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>actually means <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fourth</span> of the cost <span class="gemarra-regular">of the damage. </span>Since there are two animals that may have accomplices in the incident, the owner of the cow pays only half of the normal amount from the value of the cow, i.e., one-quarter of the cost of the damage. The other half of the payment, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>should be paid from the value of the newborn, who is the accomplice of the cow. Yet, due to the uncertainty of whether it was born before the goring or afterward, only half of that amount is paid from it, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-eighth of the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the owner of the ox receives a total of three-eighths of the cost of the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if the cow and the offspring are </span>owned <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>person, the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">can indeed say to the owner of the cow: Whichever </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>look at it, <span class="gemarra-regular">give me half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>either from the value of the cow or the newborn, which both belong to you. Why is it necessary to give half of the payment specifically from the cow and half from the newborn? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this ruling of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is not necessary </span>except for the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the cow </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and the offspring to another, </span>and so each can claim that he is only partially responsible for the damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">came forward </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">claimed </span>payment from <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the cow first, he can indeed say to the owner of the cow: Your cow </span>certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>property, so <span class="gemarra-regular">bring me a proof that you have a partner. </span>The owner of the cow would then have to prove that the newborn calf was still a fetus at the time and therefore a partner in the incident, in order to exempt himself from paying the entire payment of half the cost of the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case of the mishna is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where he claimed </span>payment from <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the offspring first,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>in this case the owner of the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him:</span> Since you claimed payment from the owner of the newborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">disclosed your opinion </span>on the matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">that I have a partner </span>who is responsible for part of the damage. Therefore, I am not prepared to pay the full amount required, i.e., half the cost of the damage, but only half of that amount, i.e., one-quarter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: Even though</span> the injured party came forward and <span class="gemarra-regular">claimed </span>payment from <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the cow first, </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">can dismiss his </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he can say to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I know that I have a partne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in this matter, i.e., the owner of the newborn calf.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said, </span>in challenging Abaye’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: One-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and one-eighth of the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage? </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage and one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. Rather, Rava said: Actually, </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow and </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring belong to one</span> person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this is what we are saying: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that with regard to damage caused by an innocuous animal, restitution is paid only from the money realized by selling the belligerent animal. Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the cow is here, half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is paid from </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the cow </span>itself; 

Daf 47a

if <span class="gemarra-regular">the cow is not </span>here, e.g., it went astray, only <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is reimbursed from the offspring.</span>
The Gemara infers: According to Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason</span> for paying only one-quarter of the cost of the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we do not know if the offspring was with it, </span>as a fetus, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gored or whether it was not.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious to us that the offspring was with it </span>as a fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">when it gored, the full </span>amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage may be reimbursed from the offspring</span> if the cow is not there.
The Gemara comments: In this respect, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow that caused damage </span>while pregnant, the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from its offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the offspring that had been a fetus at the time of the goring. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered an integral part of <span class="gemarra-regular">its body </span>and therefore may be used to collect payment. By contrast, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a hen that caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">does not collect </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from its egg. </span>Payment can be collected only from the body of the hen. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>The egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is simply a secretio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and not an integral part of the hen’s body.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>When assessing the damage inflicted by a goring ox on a cow whose newborn calf is found dead by its side, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to the cow by itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">to the offspring by itself. Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises the offspring together with the co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> and evaluates the overall damage inflicted on the pregnant cow, which will be slightly less than it would be with two separate evaluations. The reason for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if you do not say this, you </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>to have ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">weakened the one liable for damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> by inflicting a loss on him, as the market value of a newborn calf is greater than the difference in market value between a pregnant cow and one that is not pregnant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, you find </span>this principle in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> someone <span class="gemarra-regular">severed the hand of another’s slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The difference in value between a slave with a hand and a slave without a hand is assessed, rather than determining how much money the owner would request in exchange for allowing the hand of his slave to be cut off. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, you </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">find </span>this principle in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of one who causes damage </span>to part of <span class="gemarra-regular">another’s field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The court appraises not the garden bed that was eaten or trampled, but the depreciation in value of the bed as part of the surrounding area. This results in a smaller payment, as the damage appears less significant in the context of a larger area.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</span> The main reason invoked by Rava is that otherwise you will be found to have ultimately weakened the one liable for damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if this is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of assessing the damage, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let the one liable for damage be weakened </span>by losing money.
Rav Ashi answered: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the one liable for damage <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I caused damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>through injuring <span class="gemarra-regular">a pregnant cow, </span>and so <span class="gemarra-regular">I am assessing </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pregnant cow for you. </span>Therefore, it is not correct to evaluate separately the damage to the cow and the damage to the offspring.
The Gemara raises a question: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the cow </span>belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and the offspring</span> belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>that the compensation for the cow’s loss of <span class="gemarra-regular">fat </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the cow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The additional value that the cow had due to the fact that it was fatter due to the pregnancy is paid to the owner of the cow. The question is: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning the cow’s <span class="gemarra-regular">bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> There is an increase in value of a pregnant cow that it is attributed to its improved appearance, which results from its carrying a fetus. Who is considered the injured party with regard to that sum? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>This too belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the cow, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> They divide </span>the restitution. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>the restitution.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a potter who brought his</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">pot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">into a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and the homeowner’s animal broke </span>the pots, the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. If </span>the owner’s animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured by </span>the pots, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the pots is liable. But if </span>the potter <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">inside</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with permission, the owner of the courtyard is liable </span>if his animal caused damage to the pots.
Similarly, if someone <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into the homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and the homeowner’s animal ate them, </span>the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. If </span>his animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">injured by them, </span>e.g., if it slipped on them, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the produce is liable. But if he brought</span> his produce <span class="gemarra-regular">inside with permission, the owner of the courtyard is liable </span>for the damage caused by his animal to them.
Similarly, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into the homeowner’s courtyard without</span>

Daf 47b

<span class="gemarra-regular">permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the homeowner’s ox gored it or the homeowner’s dog bit it, </span>the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>If it <span class="gemarra-regular">gored the homeowner’s ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the goring ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Furthermore, if the ox that he brought into the courtyard without permission <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and contaminated its water, </span>the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation for despoiling the water. If the homeowner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father or son were inside </span>the pit at the time the ox fell and the person died as a result, the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the ransom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if he brought </span>the ox into the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the owner of the courtyard is liable </span>for the damage caused.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> The homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable in any </span>of the cases in the mishna, even if he gave his permission for the items to be brought into his premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself to safeguard </span>them.
