<strong>GEMARA:</strong> From the first case of the mishna, it can be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the potter is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>that he brought his pots into another’s courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission. But </span>if he brought them in <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, the potter would not be liable for damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to the courtyard owner’s animal; and we do not say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the potter accepted </span>responsibility for the <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding of the courtyard owner’s animal </span>from his own pots.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>at the conclusion of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">any case </span>where permission is granted to allow an item into one’s premises <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification, </span>i.e., without an explicit agreement as to who is responsible for safeguarding the item, it is assumed that with regard to each party, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not accepted upon himself </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the item. Therefore, the potter who received permission to bring his pots into the owner’s courtyard similarly did not accept responsibility to safeguard against damage to the property of the owner of the courtyard.
But <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause: If </span>the potter <span class="gemarra-regular">brought them into </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, the owner of the courtyard is liable. </span>In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who </span>disagree with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that, even <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where permission is granted to allow an item into one’s premises <span class="gemarra-regular">with-out specification, </span>where the owner merely said he could bring them into the courtyard, the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the items to ensure that they are not damaged, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore,</span> the end of the mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable in any </span>of the cases in the mishna, even if he gave his permission for the items to be brought into his premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the homeowner </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself to safeguard </span>them. Therefore, it emerges that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause and the last clause </span>of the mishna are in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the middle clause</span> of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>Is this a reasonable way to read the mishna?
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>This mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">disjointed </span>and doesn’t follow a single opinion. Rather, the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who taught this </span>clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach that</span> clause of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The beginning of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is entirely </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the potter received <span class="gemarra-regular">permission </span>to place his pots there, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the courtyard accepted </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the pots, and even </span>to the extent that if the pots <span class="gemarra-regular">broke due to the wind, </span>he would be liable. The owner of the pots, by contrast, did not accept any responsibility to ensure that his items would not cause damage.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he brought his produce into the homeowner’s courtyard </span>without permission, and the owner’s animal was injured by the produce, he is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped on it </span>and fell, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it ate </span>from the produce and was injured, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason? </span>The animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>it, and it was not the owner of the fruit who acted improperly but the animal itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: I say that Rav stated this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> while dozing and lying down</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is not entirely precise, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who places poiso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before another’s animal </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. </span>From the above statement, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically where he put <span class="gemarra-regular">poison </span>before the animal that he is exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is not suitable for eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if he put <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span> before it, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is suitable for eating, </span>and the animal dies from eating it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is also liable according to human laws. </span>The Gemara analyzes this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> why </span>is he liable? Here also Rav’s logic can be invoked, that the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>it. Therefore, this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> poses a difficulty for Rav.
In order to explain Rav’s statement, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: The same is true, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the animal was injured by eating the produce, he would <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws, and this</span> <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this, that even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">poison, which is not suitable for eating, </span>the one who placed the poison before the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that the case where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> exempts from liability according to human laws the one who placed <span class="gemarra-regular">poison </span>before the animal is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an item suitable for eating <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>such as <span class="gemarra-italic">afrazta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of herb that appears edible for animals but is actually poisonous. Therefore, this herb <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>halakhically equivalent to any other <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>for which he is exempt from liability according to human laws, since, as Rav explained, the animal should not have eaten it.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav’s statement from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who entered </span>the house of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">homeowner without permission </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to grind wheat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the homeowner’s animal ate </span>the wheat, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span> Moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the homeowner’s animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured </span>by the wheat, the woman is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Now according to Rav’s explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is she liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>here as well that the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>it.
In order to explain Rav’s statement, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>What is the difficulty here? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable to the mishna that we interpreted </span>as a scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped on </span>the produce? Similarly, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is also referring to a case where the animal was injured by slipping on the wheat, not by eating it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he who asked it, why did he ask it? </span>This answer seems obvious. The Gemara answers: The questioner could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Granted, the mishna </span>that teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">injured by them [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bahen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], is </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped on them [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bahen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. But here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is injured,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach </span>the additional term: <span class="gemarra-italic">Bahen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Since this case is immediately preceded by the case of: And the owner’s animal ate them, it is reasonable to surmise <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the case of the animal being injured, the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>due to <span class="gemarra-regular">eating.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the other </span>one, i.e., the one who provided the answer, could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in response: There <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>whether it states: It was injured, or: It was injured by them, as in both cases the injury can be explained as resulting from slipping and not from eating.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">ate wheat </span>belonging to the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consequently was stricken with <span class="gemarra-regular">diarrhe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and died, </span>then the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>in the latter case, is the owner liable for the damage to the ox? Shouldn’t the assertion: The ox <span class="gemarra-regular">shouldn’t have eaten </span>it, be invoked, and any injury that follows is the responsibility of the ox’s owner?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are you raising a contradiction </span>from a case <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission </span>and applying it <span class="gemarra-regular">against </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission? </span>There is no difficulty here, since <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case where the ox’s owner brought the ox into the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, </span>the homeowner thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against any damage to the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ox. And even </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled itself, </span>he would still be liable.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted upon himself </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguardin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the items entering his premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Did he accept upon himself only </span>the responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>and his animals from causing damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, perhaps he even accepted </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against all forms of damage that originate <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution based on <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda bar Simon taught in </span>the tractate of <span class="gemarra-italic">Nezikin</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Karna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his produce into a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and an ox came from elsewhere and ate it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the phrase: He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>referring to, <span class="gemarra-regular">and who </span>is the phrase: He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>referring to? <span class="gemarra-regular">Does it not</span> mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt and the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>This would indicate that by granting permission for the produce to be brought in, he accepts responsibility to safeguard against other damage as well, such as that caused by another ox entering from the outside.
In response, <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>that this interpretation should be rejected: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it means that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox </span>that causes damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox, </span>

Daf 48a

<span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>reason is there to rule one way where the produce is brought in <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, and what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>to rule another way where the produce is brought in <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission?</span> With regard to damage done by the ox of a stranger, it should not make any difference.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: If he brought in the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, it is </span>a case of damage under the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating </span>(see 2a), <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of the injured </span>party, since, with respect to the produce, the courtyard is treated as belonging to its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if an animal causes damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating in the domain of the injured </span>party, the ox’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>But if he brought it into the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, it is </span>a case of damage under the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating in the public domain, and </span>if an animal causes damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating in the public domain, </span>the ox’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span> Given this explanation, the answer to the question of what type of safeguarding the courtyard owner accepted cannot be derived from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox from elsewhere comes and gores it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But if he brought </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt and who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? Is it not the owner of the courtyard</span> who is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt and the owner of the courtyard </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>If so, this proves that the owner of the courtyard accepted responsibility for all damage occurring on his premises.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox </span>that gored is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and the owner of the ox </span>that gored is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, what </span>significance is there to specifying the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, and what </span>significance <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>to specifying the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission </span>with regard to this ox? For damage categorized as Goring (see 2b), the owner of the animal is liable wherever the goring occurred, even in the public domain.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, who says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, </span>and the owner of the goring animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span> According to this opinion, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be interpreted as follows: If the injured party brought his ox into the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, it is </span>a case of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the property of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the Goring animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span> But if he brought it in <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, it is </span>a case of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the public domain, and he pays only half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
§ The Gemara relates that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who entered a certain house to bake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Subsequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">a goat </span>belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the house came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">ate the </span>woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">dough, </span>and as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">it became overheated and died. Rava deemed </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay compensation for the goat.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rav says </span>that in a case where someone brings in his produce to another’s courtyard without permission, and the latter’s animal is injured by eating it, the owner of the produce is nevertheless exempt, since the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>it.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case where someone brought in his produce <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not accept </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon himself </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against the produce causing damage, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>where the woman brought in the dough <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, </span>the woman did <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">upon hersel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against the dough causing damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mentioned previously: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who entered </span>the house of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> homeowner without permission </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to grind wheat, and the homeowner’s animal ate </span>the wheat, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? And </span>moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the homeowner’s animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured </span>by the wheat, the woman is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>she is liable is specifically that she entered <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, but</span> if she entered <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, </span>she would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: If she entered the house <span class="gemarra-regular">to grind wheat, since she does not require any privacy,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the owners of the courtyard do not need </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">absent themselves </span>from there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against damage therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">rests upon them. But </span>if she enters <span class="gemarra-regular">to bake, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">since she requires privacy </span>for this, as the process of kneading involves exposing her elbows, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owners of the courtyard absent themselves </span>from there to allow her to bake. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>the responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>against damage to anything in the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">rests upon her.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox inside the homeowner’s courtyard</span> without permission and the homeowner’s ox gored it or the homeowner’s dog bit it, the homeowner is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">dug pits, ditches, or caves in it, the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the damage </span>caused by his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to the courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but the owner of the courtyard is liable for </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>if someone falls inside.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Even though the Master says </span>that when the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if a man shall open a pit” </span>(Exodus 21:33), it limits the liability for the pit to a person who digs a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not an ox </span>that digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case the owner of the courtyard should be exempt, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in Rava’s statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">since this</span> owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">should have filled </span>the pit with earth <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fill it, </span>he is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like someone who </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">dug </span>the pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>In the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his ox into</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a homeowner’s courtyard without permission, and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">injured the homeowner, or the homeowner </span>stumbled and <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured by it, </span>the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">crouched [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ravatz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>and by doing so caused damage, the ox’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt because </span>the animal caused damage when it <span class="gemarra-regular">crouched? Rav Pappa said: What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">ravatz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">that it dropped fece</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hirbitz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>on the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the clothes of the homeowner were soiled. </span>Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">the feces constitute a pit, and we do not find </span>a case of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one is liable </span>for causing damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">utensils. </span>Therefore, the owner of the animal is exempt.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, who says: Any obstruction is </span>categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit,</span> and the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> exempting the one responsible for the pit from damage to utensils applies to them as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says </span>that one’s property is not categorized as Pit <span class="gemarra-regular">until he renounces ownership of it, what is there to say?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: The animal’s owner usually <span class="gemarra-regular">renounces ownership </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary feces,</span> and so they are categorized as Pit even according to the opinion of Rav.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>In the case of a person or an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">entered the courtyard of a homeowner without permission and injured the homeowner, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or the homeowner was injured by </span>stumbling on the intruder, the person or owner of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Moreover, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the homeowner damages </span>the person or animal, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: We said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not know of his</span> presence. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he knew of his </span>presence, even if he entered without permission, then if the <span class="gemarra-regular">homeowner injured him, </span>the homeowner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the injured party can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the courtyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">Although you have the right</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to eject </span>me from your courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not have the right to injure me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rava and Rav Pappa, who hold that one who enters without permission is liable if damage is caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">follow their </span>lines of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava says, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>who said it: 

Daf 48b

In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people who were both somewhere <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or two </span>people who were both somewhere <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they injure each othe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> directly, they are both <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they were injured by one another</span> through stumbling over one another, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>From this statement, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>both are liable if either damages the other is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">two of them </span>were both there <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission or the two of them </span>were both there <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one, </span>i.e., the homeowner, was there <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission, and the other </span>entered <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission, </span>then the one who was there <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if he injured the other, but the one who entered <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>if he injured the homeowner, in accordance with the opinion of Rava and Rav Pappa.
§ The mishna teaches: If the ox that he brought into the courtyard without permission <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">pit and contaminated its water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. Rava says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">contaminated </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the fall. But </span>if it contaminated the water <span class="gemarra-regular">after the fall, </span>e.g., the animal died there and the decomposing carcass despoiled the water, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason? </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">ox, </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered as a <span class="gemarra-regular">pit, and the water </span>has the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">utensils </span>that fall into a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we have not found </span>a case of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit that renders one liable </span>for causing damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">utensils. </span>Therefore, he is exempt.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, who says: Any obstruction is </span>categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span>and the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> exempting the one responsible for the pit from damage to utensils applies to them as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says </span>that one’s property is not categorized as Pit <span class="gemarra-regular">until he renounces ownership of it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>Presumably, the owner did not renounce ownership of the ox or even of the carcass.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, it was stated like this: Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">contaminated </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its body, </span>i.e., its carcass. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">contaminated</span> the water <span class="gemarra-regular">with its stench, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason? </span>It is because the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">an indirect </span>action. Although the ox’s owner was initially responsible for his animal falling into the pit, the stench did not result directly from this action. It subsequently occurred on its own, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable </span>for damage that is caused <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">an indirect </span>action.
§ The mishna teaches: If the homeowner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father or son were inside </span>the pit at the time the ox fell and the person died as a result, the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the ransom. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>does he pay a ransom? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>in which case its owner is not liable to pay a ransom? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>Here <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>an ox that is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned for falling on people in pits.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to be put to <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>because if it is forewarned for this behavior, it is considered to have acted intentionally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said </span>in response: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it saw </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">gras</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that it intended to eat on the edge of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and fell </span>in the pit instead. Since there was no intention to cause damage by falling, the ox is not liable to be put to death, but since it was forewarned for this behavior, its owner still pays ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>This ox mentioned in the mishna is innocuous, and in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this? It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says: </span>The owner of an <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox that caused damage pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half a ransom. </span>Therefore, when the mishna states that he pays a ransom, it means that he pays half a ransom.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who </span>maintains that payment of a ransom is applicable even in the case of an innocuous ox, but he <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, who says: </span>For damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>that is carried out by an innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the injured </span>party, the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. So too, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays a full ransom </span>despite the fact that the ox is innocuous.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to Ulla, this </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">his father or his son were inside </span>the pit at the time the ox fell and the person died as a result, the owner of the ox pays the ransom. The mishna thereby provides a case of damage categorized as Goring in the courtyard of the injured party. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Shmuel’s </span>explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>mention <span class="gemarra-regular">his father or his son specifically? Even </span>if the injured party were <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person, not a close relative of the owner of the property, the owner of the animal would be required to pay half a ransom, and even if it was in the public domain.
The Gemara answers: Indeed, that is the case, and the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching </span>this ruling by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">the typical scenario, </span>that presumably it was someone from the family of the one who owns the property containing the pit that was inside the pit.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he brought </span>the ox into the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the courtyard is liable </span>for the damage caused. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: The homeowner is not liable in any of the cases in the mishna, even if he gave his permission for the items to be brought onto his premises, unless he explicitly accepts responsibility upon himself to safeguard them. It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that the Sages disagreed with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and Shmuel said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>a case similar to that of the mishna: If the owner of the courtyard said to the owner of the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring your ox into </span>my courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and safeguard it, </span>then if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage</span> to the property of the owner of the courtyard, the animal’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>And if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured,</span> the owner of the courtyard is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>If he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring your ox in and I will safeguard it, </span>then if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured, </span>the owner of the courtyard is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult: You said </span>in the first clause that if the courtyard’s owner said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring your ox into </span>my courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and safeguard it, </span>then if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>And if it <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured, </span>the owner of the courtyard is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason that the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable and the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">Safeguard it. </span>One can infer that if he granted permission for the ox to enter <span class="gemarra-regular">without specifying </span>that the owner of the animal safeguard it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>if the ox was injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if it caused damage. The reason the owner of the courtyard is liable is that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds <span class="gemarra-regular">that in an unspecified </span>case, where the obligation to safeguard the animal was not mentioned, the owner of the courtyard implicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the ox.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause: </span>If he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring your ox in and I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">safeguard it, </span>then if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured, </span>the owner of the courtyard is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>if the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason that the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I will safeguard it. </span>One can infer that if the owner of the courtyard granted permission for the ox to enter <span class="gemarra-regular">without specifying </span>that the owner of the animal safeguard it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>if it damages the property of the owner of the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of the courtyard </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if the ox is damaged. The reason the owner of the courtyard is not liable is that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds <span class="gemarra-regular">that in an unspecified </span>case, where the obligation to safeguard the animal was not mentioned, the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">does not accept upon himself </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>the ox.
The Gemara concludes its analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">We come to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the homeowner </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding, </span>he is not liable. Based on this understanding, the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the latter clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>Indeed, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">disjointed, </span>and the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who taught this </span>clause <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach that </span>clause. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The entire </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>and no inference should be drawn from the extra words: And I will safeguard it, in the latter clause. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the first clause mentions </span>that the owner of the courtyard instructed: <span class="gemarra-regular">Safeguard it, the latter clause also teaches </span>that he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I will safeguard it, </span>to maintain symmetry. The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies even when granting permission to enter without specification, since, according to the Rabbis, granting permission to enter includes an implicit acceptance of responsibility for safeguarding.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: The entire </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that if no specification was made, the owner of the courtyard does not accept responsibility, as inferred from the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the inference drawn from the first clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, who says: </span>For damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span>that is carried out by an innocuous ox <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of the injured </span>party, the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>if the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">Safeguard it, </span>he is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">not transferring </span>the rights to any <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of the courtyard to him, </span>as evident from the fact that the owner of the ox must safeguard it and may not treat the courtyard as if it were his own. Consequently, if the ox gored, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a case of damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the courtyard of the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one responsible for damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring in the courtyard of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
By contrast, if the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to </span>the owner of the ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">Safeguard it, </span>then by granting him permission to bring the ox onto his courtyard, he effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">transfers </span>rights to <span class="gemarra-regular">an area within the courtyard. </span>Therefore, with regard to damages, it becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard of partners, and </span>the one responsible for damage categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard of partners pays only half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that was intending to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">but struck </span>a pregnant <span class="gemarra-regular">woman, and her offspring, </span>i.e., the fetuses, <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged </span>due to miscarriage, the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person who was intending to </span>injure <span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but struck</span> a pregnant <span class="gemarra-regular">woman </span>instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">and her offspring emerged </span>due to miscarriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span><span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">How does he pay compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., how is their value assessed? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman </span>by calculating <span class="gemarra-regular">how much she </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>if sold as a maidservant <span class="gemarra-regular">before giving birth, and how much she </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">worth after giving birth. </span>He then pays the difference in value to the woman’s husband. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: </span>

Daf 49a

<span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the consequences would be absurd, as <span class="gemarra-regular">when a woman gives birth </span>her value <span class="gemarra-regular">increases. Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises how much the offspring are worth, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the one liable for the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>that amount <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband. And if she does not have a husband, </span>e.g., her husband died, he <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to his heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If the pregnant woman <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she was emancipated, or a convert, </span>and she was married to an emancipated Canaanite slave or to a convert who died without any heirs, the one who caused the damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from pay-ing compensation for miscarried offspring. This is because this payment is made specifically to the husband, not to the woman.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The first clause of the mishna indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the owner is exempt from paying compensation for the offspring when an ox unintentionally gores a pregnant woman is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that it was intending to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">another</span> ox. By inference, if it <span class="gemarra-regular">was intending to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman,</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring. Shall we say </span>that this <span class="gemarra-regular">should be a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Adda bar Ahava,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rav Adda bar Ahava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen that intended to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>and then did so, the owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring?</span>
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava</span> could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: The same is true, that even </span>if the oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman, </span>the owners are <span class="gemarra-regular">also exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring. </span>As for <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that was intending to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>ox, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>taught this way <span class="gemarra-regular">since it wants to teach the latter clause: A person that was intending to </span>injure <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">as this </span>case is <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>explicitly in <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse: </span>“And if men struggle and hurt a pregnant woman and her offspring emerge” (Exodus 21:22). In the case in the verse, the assailant intended to injure another person but injured the woman instead. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">also teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>in that style: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox that was intending to </span>gore <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that gored </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and her offspring emerged </span>due to miscarriage, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring. What is the reason? </span>The ox <span class="gemarra-regular">injured a mere pregnant donkey. </span>With regard to the matter of compensation for offspring, who would be the property of the master were they to be born, a Canaanite slave is considered property of the master. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states </span>that Abraham addressed Eliezer, who was a Canaanite, by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You remain here with [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the donkey” </span>(Genesis 22:5), on which the Sages expound that he was alluding to the idea that Eliezer is of <span class="gemarra-regular">a people [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">am</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] that is similar to a donkey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the case of an ox goring a Canaanite maidservant is not included in the Torah’s exemption from paying compensation for miscarried offspring.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">How does he pay compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring? </span>The court appraises how much the value of the woman increased due to the offspring. The Gemara asks: Would this be a correct interpretation of the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring? </span>If this is how the sum is calculated, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated: How does he pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the increase </span>in value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is also what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: How does he pay compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the increase </span>in value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring? </span>In other words, apart from evaluating the compensation for the miscarried offspring, the court also appraises the value of the woman before giving birth and her value after giving birth.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: If so, </span>the consequences would be absurd, as <span class="gemarra-regular">when a woman gives birth </span>her value <span class="gemarra-regular">increases.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? Rabba said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: But is </span>the monetary value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman higher before she gives birth than after she gives birth? But isn’t</span> the opposite true, that the monetary value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">higher after giving birt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than before giving birth, </span>since the concern for her dying during childbirth, which lowers her monetary value prior to giving birth, is no longer a concern? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the fetuse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gives </span>that amount <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This</span> explanation of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span>the monetary value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman higher before she gives birth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">than after she gives birth? But isn’t </span>the opposite true, that the monetary value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">higher after giving birth than before giving birth? Rather,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the fetuses and gives </span>that amount <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: This is what </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: But is </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman higher </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for the one for whom she gives birth, </span>i.e., her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she herself does not have any increase </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">at all</span> due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring? </span>A pregnant woman’s monetary value is increased on account of her pregnancy, beyond the monetary value of the offspring. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring and gives </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in addition, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>husband and wife <span class="gemarra-regular">divide the increase </span>in her value due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>explanation of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: But is </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman higher </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for the one for whom she gives birth, </span>i.e., her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she herself does not have any increase </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">at all</span> due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring? Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises damage by itself and pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by itself, and appraises </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and gives </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband, and the </span>husband and wife <span class="gemarra-regular">divide the increase </span>in her value due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring.</span>
The Gemara asks: The opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that the woman’s value decreases because of pregnancy, poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty for that of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that it increases.
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>since each <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a different case: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which stated that the woman’s value increases after giving birth, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">giving birth to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Her value decreases prior to birth out of concern that she might die in childbirth. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which stated that her value increases due to pregnancy, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">who is not giving birth to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: The increase </span>in her value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband? </span>The Gemara answers: They derive it from a redundancy in a verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “And hurt a pregnant woman and her offspring emerge” (Exodus 21:22). <span class="gemarra-regular">From the fact that it is stated: “And her offspring emerge,” don’t I know </span>by inference <span class="gemarra-regular">that she was pregnant? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “A pregnant </span>woman,” and not just “a woman”? <span class="gemarra-regular">To inform you </span>that even the <span class="gemarra-regular">increase </span>in her value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the pregnancy </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel expound on this </span>extra word <span class="gemarra-regular">“pregnant”? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires it for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says </span>that one who injures a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">is never liable </span>to pay compensation for miscarried offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he strikes her opposite the womb, </span>i.e., on the abdomen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Do not say</span> that it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">literally opposite the womb. Rather, </span>he is liable if she was struck <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that the wound’s </span>impact could <span class="gemarra-regular">reach the offspring, </span>i.e., any part of the torso, <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude</span> a wound to her <span class="gemarra-regular">hand or foot, for which </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> liable, since it could be argued that it was not the wound to the hand or foot that caused the miscarriage.
§ The mishna teaches: If the pregnant woman <span class="gemarra-regular">was a maidservant and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she was emancipated, or a convert, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the payment of damages for miscarried offspring. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one injured her during the lifetime of the convert, </span>i.e., her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the convert died </span>before the payment was given. The reason for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">that since </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">injured her during the lifetime of the convert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the convert acquires </span>the money, although it is still in the possession of the one liable for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And once the convert dies </span>without heirs, the money is ownerless. Therefore, the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires it from the convert. </span>Since anyone can assume ownership of ownerless property, the assailant, who already possesses the money, becomes the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he injured her after the convert had died, she acquires </span>the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he must pay the woman herself.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>in amazement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of this ruling! Is that to say</span> that compensation for the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring is </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>of money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she acquires them </span>when her husband dies? Rabba seems to understand that the pregnant woman assumes ownership of the offspring by virtue of being in possession of them when the husband dies, and therefore has the right to compensation for them. That is not the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband is present, the Merciful One grants</span> compensation for the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>but if <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband is not </span>alive, the Torah does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>grant compensation to anyone else.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against the opinion of Rabba from the following: If the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">struck the woman and her offspring emerged </span>due to miscarriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage and pain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the woman and compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring to the husband. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband is not </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>the compensation for the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">to his heirs. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman is not </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>the payment owed to her <span class="gemarra-regular">to her heirs. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she was a maidservant and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she was emancipated, or a convert, </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the money. This indicates that if the husband is no longer alive, the woman doesn’t receive anything.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response to this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable to the mishna, which we interpreted </span>as a referring to case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he injured her during the lifetime of the convert, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the convert </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died? Here also, </span>it must be explained <span class="gemarra-regular">that he injured her during the lifetime of the convert, and the convert</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">died. And if you wish, say </span>instead that he injured her even <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death of the convert. </span>

Daf 49b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the expression in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: He acquires, referring to the one who causes the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: She acquires.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the dispute between Rabba and Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">is parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish woman who was married to a convert, and she became pregnant from him, and </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">injured her, </span>causing her to miscarry: If this was <span class="gemarra-regular">during the lifetime of the convert, </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">gives compensation for</span> miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring to the convert, </span>i.e., her husband. If this was <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death of the convert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the assailant is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the assailant is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What, is it not </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly</span> a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>His opinion does not accord with the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, shall we say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
This is not necessarily so, as Rav Ḥisda could say that both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> are in accordance with his opinion. As for the difference between them, that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>They can be explained as referring to the increase in the woman’s value due to the offspring, which is subject to dispute in the mishna, rather than referring to the payment of compensation for miscarried offspring. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which taught that he is exempt, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who maintain that the increase in her value on account of the offspring belongs to the husband. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which taught that he is liable, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</span> who maintains that the woman has a share in her increase in value due to pregnancy, and this is paid even if the incident occurred after the husband’s death.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, why </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>that it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death</span> of the husband? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even during </span>the husband’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">she also has a half </span>share, as explained earlier in the discussion. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">While </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, she has a half </span>share, but <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death, all of it</span> belongs to her.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, </span>but they refer to different payments. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that taught that he is liable, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the increase </span>in her value due to the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring, </span>which belongs partly to the woman, and if the husband dies, she acquires the rights to all of it. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that taught that he is exempt, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring, </span>which belongs exclusively to her husband. Since he is a convert, the one liable for damage is exempt after his death.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said, </span>in questioning this answer: Why is there a difference between the two cases? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that after the husband’s death the woman acquires his share of the <span class="gemarra-regular">increase </span>in her value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring, let </span>it be <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>that according to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel she also acquires the rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring </span>if she was wounded after his death.
