Moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, let </span>us <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>that this is also the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>since there is no dispute between them with regard to the payment of compensation for miscarried offspring.
In response, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: No, </span>the first assumption is untenable, since with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">increase </span>in her value due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring, in which she has a share </span>from the outset, <span class="gemarra-regular">she acquires all of it </span>after her husband’s death. By contrast, with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring, in which she does not have a share </span>from the outset, <span class="gemarra-regular">she does not acquire </span>the rights <span class="gemarra-regular">to it at all, </span>since she has no greater claim to this than any other individual does.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeiva the Elder raises a dilemma to Rav Naḥman: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes possession of the documents of a convert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> after the death of the convert? On the one hand, it can be argued that one <span class="gemarra-regular">who takes possession of the document takes possession with the intention </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>acquiring <span class="gemarra-regular">the land </span>that the document states is under lien, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not take possession of the land </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he also does not acquire the document. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he had no intention </span>to acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the document, </span>but just the property specified in the document. Therefore, since the convert has died, perhaps the lien is canceled and can no longer be collected, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps his intention is also to </span>acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the document, </span>and the paper on which it is written belongs to him.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Answer </span>this, <span class="gemarra-regular">my Master: Does he need </span>to acquire the document to use as paper <span class="gemarra-regular">to cover the opening of his flask</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why would he want the document if it does not grant him ownership of the land described therein? Rav Yeiva the Elder <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Indeed, his intention is even <span class="gemarra-regular">to cover </span>the flask <span class="gemarra-regular">and to cover </span>it with the paper, albeit a mundane purpose.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>In a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">collateral of a Jew </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of a conver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> who lent him money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the convert died, and another Jew came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and took possession of it, </span>then, since the convert has no heirs, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriates it from his possession </span>and returns it to its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? Since the convert died,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his lien </span>on the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is abrogated. </span>Therefore, the deposit automatically returns to its owner, and no one else has the right to take it.
By contrast, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">collateral of a conver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of a Jew </span>who lent him money <span class="gemarra-regular">and the convert died, and another Jew came and took possession of it, this </span>one, i.e., the one owed money, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>a share of the collateral <span class="gemarra-regular">corresponding to the money </span>owed <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>by the convert, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, i.e., the one who took possession of it, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the rest.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>doesn’t the creditor acquire the entire collateral? If it is in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">let his courtyard effect acquisition for him, as doesn’t Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina say: A person’s courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> effects acquisition for him </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without his knowledge?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not</span> standing next to the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Anywhere that he is </span>present, next to the collateral, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he wants to acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">could </span>pick it up and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">his courtyard also effects acquisition for him. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that he is not </span>present, next to the collateral, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that if he wants to acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he could not acquire </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">his courtyard also does not effect acquisition </span>for him.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>where the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">in his courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not acquire </span>the rest of the collateral.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who digs </span>part of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on private </span><span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>digs a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property, </span>or digs a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property and opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">on another </span>person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">private </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused by the pit in each case.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who digs a pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on private property and opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, or </span>who digs a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain and opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and this is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit that is stated in the Torah; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">renounced ownership of his property but did not renounce ownership of his pit </span>located in the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit that is stated in the Torah.</span>
In explanation of this dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: With regard to a pit</span> that a person digs or opens <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain, everyone agrees that he is liable </span>for damage that occurs as a result. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? The verse states: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall open </span>a pit,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it also states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall dig </span>a pit” (Exodus 21:33), which raises the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for opening</span> a pit by removing the cover of a pit that has already been dug, then is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>obvious that he should be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for digging </span>a new pit? What, then, does the latter phrase add? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the interpretation of the verse must be that the responsibility for the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to him by engaging in opening </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and by engaging in digging </span>the pit. Although he does not own the area itself, he is liable for creating a public hazard. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree only</span>

Daf 50a

in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one dug <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit on his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> and then renounced ownership of the surrounding area. Consequently, the entire area except for the pit is now open to public passage. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva maintains </span>that one who digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit on his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also liable, </span>not only when the pit is located in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the pit </span>shall pay” (Exodus 21:34). Clearly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is referring to a pit that has an owner. </span>Therefore, the owner of the pit pays even if it is located on private property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael maintains </span>that “the owner of the pit” means that <span class="gemarra-regular">the one responsible for the hazard </span>is liable even if he dug the pit in the public domain and then renounced ownership of it. But one who digs a pit on his own property is not liable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>according to Rabba’s explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> is meant by the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit that is stated in the Torah, </span>in reference to digging a pit on one’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Akiva states? </span>According to him, one is liable for damage in all cases, including digging in the public domain. The Gemara answers: It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the pit </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse initially introduces </span>the subject <span class="gemarra-regular">of compensation</span> for damage caused. In that context, the Torah states: “The owner of the pit shall pay” (Exodus 21:34), indicating that even a pit owned on one’s private property renders one liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef said </span>that one can explain the dispute between Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>one who dug <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit on </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">private property </span>and then renounced ownership of the property aside from the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that he is liable. What is the reason? </span>Since <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states: “The owner of the pit,” </span>it indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with a pit that has an owner.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the pit</span> was dug <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. Rabbi Yishmael maintains </span>that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">also liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>dug <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, as it is written: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall open </span>a pit,” and: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall dig</span> a pit” (Exodus 21:33), which raises the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for opening </span>a pit by removing the cover of a pit that has already been dug, then is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>obvious that he should be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for digging </span>a new pit? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the verse means that the responsibility for the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to him by engaging in opening </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and by engaging in digging </span>the pit. Although he does not own the area itself, he is liable for creating a public hazard.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva, </span>by contrast, holds that one is liable only in the case of a pit located on private property, where he renounced ownership of the property aside from the pit, and one cannot derive otherwise from any extraneous phrases. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>phrases <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary, for if the Merciful One wrote </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall open </span>a pit” (Exodus 21:33), <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span> specifically when <span class="gemarra-regular">one opens </span>the covering of a pit that has already been dug <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is sufficient for him to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">a covering </span>on it to absolve himself of responsibility for damage it causes. This is the case where the Torah states: “And not cover it” (Exodus 21:33). But if one actually <span class="gemarra-regular">digs </span>a pit, it <span class="gemarra-regular">would not be sufficient </span>to place <span class="gemarra-regular">a covering </span>on it, and one would not be exempt from damages <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">packs it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if the Merciful One had written </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall dig,” I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">digging that a covering is required </span>to exempt one from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he performed an action </span>of creating the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for merely <span class="gemarra-regular">opening </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">where one has not performed an action, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not require a covering </span>to absolve him of liability. Therefore, the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he is liable for damage caused by a pit in both cases, and one should interpret the verse that states: “The owner of the pit” (Exodus 21:34), in its plain sense, i.e., that he is the owner of the pit because it is located on his private property. Accordingly, one would not be liable for a pit dug in the public domain.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, </span>according to Rav Yosef’s explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit that is stated in the Torah, </span>in reference to digging a pit in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yishmael </span><span class="gemarra-regular">states? </span>Isn’t one liable for any pit, including one dug on his own property? The Gemara answers: It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the pit </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse initially introduces </span>the subject <span class="gemarra-regular">of damage </span>caused by Pit, as explained by Rabbi Yishmael above. Only afterward does it state: “The owner of the pit shall pay,” referring to a pit dug on one’s own property.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who digs a pit </span>whose hollow space is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">opens its </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">into private property </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though he does not have permission to do so. </span>The reason he does not have permission to do so is <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not create a hollow </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">under the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">One who digs pits, ditches, and caves on private property and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">opens their </span>entrances <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>In addition, one <span class="gemarra-regular">who digs pits on private property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is adjacent to the public domain </span>but not actually located in the public domain itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as these </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who dig foundations [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ushin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> for their houses or walls, is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even for damage caused by pits made to lay foundations, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he builds a partition </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths high in front of the pits, <span class="gemarra-regular">or unless he distances </span>them by <span class="gemarra-regular">four handbreadths </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from the area where pedestrians walk and from the area where animals walk.</span>
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>for the exemption is that one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">foundations, </span>which is the usual and accepted practice, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>dig <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">foundations, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Although he did so on his own property, he is nevertheless liable, since people walk there.
The Gemara clarifies: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to Rabba, the first clause, </span>where one is seemingly exempt for opening a pit onto private property even if he subsequently renounced ownership of the area, can be established in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, and the last clause </span>can be established in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>who maintains that one is liable for a pit dug on his own property if it is open to public traffic.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rav Yosef’s</span> explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">granted, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause, all agree </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>which exempts one who digs a pit on his own property, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this? </span>It appears to be <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael nor </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>since Rav Yosef explained that both of them maintain that one is liable for a pit on his own property, even if he subsequently renounces ownership of the area.
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Everyone agrees </span>with the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>passage. As for <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>which exempts one who digs a pit under the public domain and opens it onto his own property, it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not renounce ownership of either his property or his pit. </span>This certainly is not included in the category of Pit with regard to damages, and the owner is therefore exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Now that you have interpreted Rav Yosef’s </span>explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with all </span>opinions, then <span class="gemarra-regular">also according to Rabba, </span>you are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">establish it as </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rather, one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since the first clause </span>is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, </span>who exempts one who renounces ownership of his property but not the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be explained in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael. And </span>it was previously inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>for the exemption when digging on one’s private property adjacent to the public domain is that one digs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>lay <span class="gemarra-regular">foundations. But </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not to </span>lay <span class="gemarra-regular">foundations, </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. For instance, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one widene</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the pit unnecessarily, extending it <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain, </span>he has effectively dug a pit in the public domain itself.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">who digs a pit on private property and opens it into the public domain </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>But if he dug it <span class="gemarra-regular">on private property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that was adjacent to the public domain, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Granted, according to Rabba, </span>this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, </span>who does not hold one liable for digging on his own property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to Rav Yosef, granted, the first clause </span>works out well in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, </span>who holds one liable even for digging in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">but whose </span>opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause? </span>It appears to be <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael nor </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva.</span>
The Gemara answers that Rav Yosef could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span>The latter clause of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">digs to </span>lay <span class="gemarra-regular">foundations, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>with the ruling.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If someone <span class="gemarra-regular">dug or opened </span>a well <span class="gemarra-regular">and transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the publi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> for their use, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from damage caused by the well. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he dug or opened </span>a well <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not transfer </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And this </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">the practice of Neḥunya the digger of pits, ditches, and caves, who would dig, open, and transfer </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public </span>so that there would be wells of water for public use. <span class="gemarra-regular">When the Sages heard about the matter, they said: This </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">has fulfilled this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: Only <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and no more?</span> Isn’t it well known that Neḥunya was a great man? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say: </span>He fulfilled <span class="gemarra-regular">even this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> and did not forget to transfer the wells to the public.
Having mentioned the deeds of Neḥunya, the Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: An incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving the daughter of Neḥunya the ditchdigger, where she fell into a large cister</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and no one could extricate her from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came and informed Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa </span>so that he would pray on her behalf. When <span class="gemarra-regular">the first hour </span>had passed from the time of her fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: </span>She is at <span class="gemarra-regular">peace </span>and unharmed. After the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>hour, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: </span>She is at <span class="gemarra-regular">peace. </span>After the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>hour, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: She has ascended </span>from the well, and indeed this was the case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">They said to her: Who brought you up </span>out of the well? <span class="gemarra-regular">She said to them: A male sheep</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a ram, <span class="gemarra-regular">happened</span> to come <span class="gemarra-regular">to me, and a certain old man, </span>i.e., Abraham, <span class="gemarra-regular">was leading it, </span>and he pulled me out. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to </span>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are you a prophet? </span>How did you know she had ascended? Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: “I am no prophet, neither am I a prophet’s son” </span>(Amos 7:14), <span class="gemarra-regular">but this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">I said </span>to myself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall the offspring</span> of Neḥunya <span class="gemarra-regular">stumble by means of </span>the very <span class="gemarra-regular">matter which distressed that righteous man?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa says: </span>Although Neḥunya ensured that others would have water, <span class="gemarra-regular">even so, his son died of thirst, </span>fulfilling that which <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “And around Him it storms [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nisara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] mightily” </span>(Psalms 50:3). This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is scrupulous with those around Him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the righteous, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to the extent <span class="gemarra-regular">of a hairsbreadth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hasa’ara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>so that even minor transgressions elicit a severe punishment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥunya says: </span>The same idea may be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>in the following verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A God dreaded in the great council of the holy ones, and feared by all those that surround Him” </span>(Psalms 89:8), indicating that God is most careful and exacting with those that surround Him, i.e., the righteous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says: Anyone who states </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, is forgiving [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vateran</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of transgressions, <span class="gemarra-regular">his life will be relinquished </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yivatru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], as it is stated: “The Rock, His work is perfect, for all His ways are justice” </span>(Deuteronomy 32:4). In other words, God does not waive heavenly justice. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥana says, and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani </span>says: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written</span>

Daf 50b

in the verse that recounts the thirteen attributes of mercy: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Long-suffering [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">erekh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">appayim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 34:6), using the plural form, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is not written </span>as <span class="gemarra-italic">erekh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">af</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in the singular? In order to teach that He is <span class="gemarra-regular">long-suffering for </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the righteou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and for the wicke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and does not punish them immediately for their transgressions.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: A person should not throw stones from his property into the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> An incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving a certain individual who was throwing stones from his property into the public domain, and a certain pious man found him. </span>The latter <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Lowlife [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">reika</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">are you throwing stones from property that is not yours into your property? </span>The man <span class="gemarra-regular">mocked him, </span>as he did not understand what he meant, as the property from which he was throwing stones was his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some days </span>later, <span class="gemarra-regular">he was forced to sell his field </span>from which he had thrown the stones. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he was walking in the same public domain </span>into which he had thrown them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he stumbled on those same stones.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He said: That pious man said </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">well to me </span>when he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">are you throwing stones from property that is not yours into your own property, </span>since that property no longer belongs to me, and only the public domain remains mine to use.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs a pit in the public domain and an ox or a donkey fell into it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span> The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">same </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs </span>either <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit; a ditch, </span>which is narrow and long; <span class="gemarra-regular">or a cave, </span>which is rectangular and roofed; <span class="gemarra-regular">trenches and </span>water <span class="gemarra-regular">channels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In all these cases he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. If so, why</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, </span>as it states: “And if a man shall open a pit” (Exodus 21:33)? To teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a pit that has sufficient</span> depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>when falling into it is at least <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, any </span>other excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">that have sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>may be no less than <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths. </span>If any of the types of excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">were less than ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fell into </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them and died, </span>the digger of the excavation is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But if it was injured in it, </span>not killed, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>Damage by <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit for which the Torah obligates one </span>to pay is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage caused by the pit’s lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., suffocation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not to </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">impac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of hitting the ground, for which the digger of the pit is exempt from paying compensation. The Gemara continues to explain: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it can be inferred that Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">impact </span>of hitting the bottom of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is merely the ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that injures him. </span>The digger of the pit does not own the ground, so it is not a case where his property caused damage. Therefore, he does not bear responsibility for the damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>The Torah renders one liable for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by its </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, and all the more so for </span>damage resulting from <span class="gemarra-regular">the impact</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Shmuel adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah spoke </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">its impact and not for its </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>one could respond that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah testifies about a pit </span>without specifying for which type of pit one is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this includes <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">full of woolen sponges [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sefogin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which would completely absorb the impact.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the opinions of Rav and Shmuel, given that falling into any pit involves injury due to both the lethal fumes and the impact? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">fashioned a moun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with a height of ten handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain </span>without digging, and an animal fell from this raised platform and died. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Rav, </span>the one who fashioned the mound <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable for </span>damage by Pit in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mound, </span>since there are no fumes, as the animal fell to the level ground. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Shmuel, he is also liable for </span>damage by Pit in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mound</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since there is nevertheless an impact when hitting the ground.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the source for <span class="gemarra-regular">the reasoning of Rav, </span>that one is not liable in that case? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the verse states:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And </span>an ox or a donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">fall </span>therein” (Exodus 21:33), indicating that there is no liability for damage by Pit <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">falls </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">normal manner of falling, </span>but not where it first climbed onto an elevated surface and then fell from there to the level ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Shmuel, </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span> an ox or a donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">fall,” indicates any manner </span>of falling, regardless of whether the animal fell into a hole or fell to the ground from an elevated surface.
The Gemara challenges Rav’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">why is </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, </span>as it states: “And if a man shall open a pit” (Exodus 21:33)? To teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a pit that has sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>when falling into it is at least <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, any </span>other excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">that have sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>may be no less than <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths. </span>Now, <span class="gemarra-regular">granted </span>that according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shmuel, </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, any </span>other, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the case where the animal fell from <span class="gemarra-regular">a height </span>of ten handbreadths, in which case the one who fashioned the mound would also be liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rav, </span>who exempts him in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>does the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, any </span>other, <span class="gemarra-regular">add?</span>
The Gemara answers: According to Rav, it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span><span class="gemarra-regular">trenches and </span>water <span class="gemarra-regular">channels. </span>The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">trenches and </span>water <span class="gemarra-regular">channels </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are explicitly taught </span>in the mishna. Why does the mishna then allude to them again? The Gemara answers: It first <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> about them <span class="gemarra-regular">and then explain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> its source in the Torah.
Having mentioned these details, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">that are taught </span>by the mishna? The Gemara answers: They are <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, for had </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>only the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, I would say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that contains </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, because it is constricted and round. </span>Therefore, this measurement suffices to cause death. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a ditch, which is long,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>and there is no liability. Therefore, the mishna teaches both the case of a pit and a ditch.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ditch </span>in addition to the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">a ditch </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that contains </span>the necessary lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">because it is narrow. But </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a cave, which is rectangular </span>and not narrow, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>and there is no liability. Therefore, the mishna teaches the case of a cave as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">had</span> the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cave </span>in addition to the previous two, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">a cave of ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that contains </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, because it is covered.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">trenches, which are not covered, say </span>that at a depth <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ten </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>and there is no liability. Therefore, the mishna also teaches the case of trenches.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">trenches </span>in addition to the previous three, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">trenches </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that contain </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, since they are no wider at the top than at the bottom. But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to channels, which are wider at the top than at the bottom, say </span>that at a depth <span class="gemarra-regular">of ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>and there is no liability. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>the case of channels as well, and each subsequent case listed contains a novel aspect.
The Gemara raises a further challenge from that which <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna: If any of the types of excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">were less than ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fell into </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them and died, </span>the digger of the excavation is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. But if it was injured, </span>not killed, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the ruling of: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? Is it not because </span>at this height <span class="gemarra-regular">there is not </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">impact</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> although there are lethal fumes?
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>he is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes. </span>The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>that a pit less than ten handbreadths deep lacks sufficient lethal fumes, why is the one who dug it <span class="gemarra-regular">liable if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is injured; but there are no </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes? </span>The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">answers: There are not </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes to </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">death, but there are </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes to </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain ox that fell into a water channel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">la’arita</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">dedala’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> whose depth was one cubit, i.e., six handbreadths. Because it suffered the impact of the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">its owner </span>assumed it would die and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it </span>first, in order to eat the meat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, </span>who was concerned that its organs were crushed by the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed it an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which it is prohibited to consume.
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: If the owner of this ox had taken a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of flour </span>to bake into bread to eat instead of slaughtering his animal for its meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and gone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and learned in the study hall </span>that although an ox that falls and hits the ground is considered <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> if slaughtered immediately, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">remaine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> alive <span class="gemarra-regular">for twenty-four hour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and is then slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fit to eat, he would not have lost </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">ox that was worth several </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of flour. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, Rav Naḥman maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an impact</span> caused even <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>a pit that is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than ten </span>handbreadths, as Rav Naḥman was concerned in this case that its organs were crushed and it was fatally wounded.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>from the mishna: If any of the types of excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">were less than ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fell into </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not because there is no </span>significant <span class="gemarra-regular">impact </span>capable of causing death? If so, why is this animal deemed a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>? 

Daf 51a

Rav Naḥman responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>he is exempt here <span class="gemarra-regular">because there are not </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>to cause death, in accordance with the opinion of Rav. Nevertheless, the impact from hitting the ground is sufficient to cause death, and therefore an ox that fell into a water channel is suspected of being a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>. Rava again challenges him: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then how is the statement: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured by it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>to be explained? <span class="gemarra-regular">There are not </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes? </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There are not </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes to </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">death, but there are </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes to </span>cause <span class="gemarra-regular">injury.</span>
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 45a): <span class="gemarra-regular">The structure </span>from which <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>punishment of <span class="gemarra-regular">stoning </span>was implemented <span class="gemarra-regular">was a height of two </span>people, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is taught in that regard </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the two-person height of the structure is combined with <span class="gemarra-regular">his height, </span>i.e., the height of the one being stoned, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a total height equal to that of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>people. Rava explains his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an impact </span>capable of causing death <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">less than ten </span>handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">all of this </span>height?
Rav Naḥman answered him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, let us make</span> the structure a minimal <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths. Why must it have a height of two people? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>no proof can be brought from here, since the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “And you shall love your fellow as yourself” </span>(Leviticus 19:18), teaching that even with regard to a condemned prisoner, <span class="gemarra-regular">select a good, </span>i.e., a compassionate, <span class="gemarra-regular">death for him. </span>Therefore, the structure used for stoning is constructed sufficiently high that he dies quickly, without any unnecessary suffering.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let us raise </span>the structure even <span class="gemarra-regular">more, </span>so that his death will be even less painful. The Gemara answers: This is not done, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>if he fell from a greater height, his organs would be crushed and he would become completely <span class="gemarra-regular">disfigured, </span>which is certainly not a way one would prefer to die.
Rava again <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rav Naḥman: The Torah requires constructing a parapet on the roof of one’s house to prevent anyone from falling to his death, as the verse states (Deuteronomy 22:8): “You shall not bring blood upon your house, <span class="gemarra-regular">if any man falls from it.” </span>The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“from it” </span>teaches that liability exists only for falling from the roof of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not onto </span>the roof  of a house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">so? </span>If an area in the <span class="gemarra-regular">public domain was ten handbreadths higher than </span>a private house and the owner did not construct a fence between his house and the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from inside </span>the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">onto </span>the house, the owner of the house is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>By contrast, if the public domain was <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths lower than </span>the house, and the owner did not construct a fence on his roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from </span>the roof of the house <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>the public domain, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a sufficiently strong <span class="gemarra-regular">impact </span>to cause death even at a height <span class="gemarra-regular">of less than ten </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the roof to be <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths high for there to be a requirement to construct a parapet? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the parapet for the roof of <span class="gemarra-regular">a house </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is different, since any </span>structure <span class="gemarra-regular">less than ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, </span>and only a house requires a parapet.
Rava objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>i.e., if the requirement to build a parapet is limited to a house that is ten handbreadths high, then <span class="gemarra-regular">also now, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">is ten </span>handbreadths higher than the public domain when measured <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outside, remove </span>the height of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ceiling and the plaster, </span>which is an additional layer on top of the ceiling. When measured <span class="gemarra-regular">from the inside </span>in this manner, its height <span class="gemarra-regular">is not ten. </span>According to you, then, it is not classified as a house. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he hollowed out </span>an extra space <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span>in the floor of the house so that its height would be ten handbreadths.
Rava challenges him: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>in a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">is not ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outside as well, you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">find </span>a scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the inside,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> such as where he hollowed out extra </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the floor, thereby transforming it into a house with the required height. Why, then, would a person be exempt in this case?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the previous explanation must be entirely rejected, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the reasoning of Rav Naḥman </span>when he ruled that one must suspect that the ox’s organs were crushed upon falling into the water channel. He <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>the following argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>far <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the distance <span class="gemarra-regular">from the stomach of the o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the ground? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>deep <span class="gemarra-regular">is the water channel? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>totals <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">transpires that when </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">hits </span>the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is from </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that it hits </span>the ground, since it landed on its stomach and not on its feet.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, which teaches: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Just as a pit that has sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>when falling into it is at least <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, any </span>other excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">that have sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>may be no less than <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>deep, why not say that a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">with six </span>handbreadths would <span class="gemarra-regular">also be sufficient?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">rolled into the pit, </span>in which case the pit would be required to have a depth of ten handbreadths. By contrast, if it fell while walking, the extra height from the ground to its stomach is included in calculating the ten handbreadths.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit belonging to two partners </span>was uncovered and <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">passed by it and did not cover it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>passed by it <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not cover it, the second </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for any damage caused by means of the pit.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: How can you find </span>such a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit belonging to two partners? This works out well if we hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that one who digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>on his own property and then declares the property, but not the pit, ownerless, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage. According to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">you find </span>such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the courtyard belongs to both of them and the pit belongs to both of them, and they renounced ownership of their property but did not renounce ownership of their pit. </span>In that case, both are responsible for any damage caused.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if we hold </span>that one who digs <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit on his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>and then declares the property, but not the pit, ownerless, is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability for damage caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you find </span>a case of a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>a person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>It can only be a case where it is located <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, and how can you find </span>a case of a <span class="gemarra-regular">pit belonging to two partners in the public domain?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If they both </span>jointly <span class="gemarra-regular">appointed an agent and said to him: Go dig </span>a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">for us, and he went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">dug </span>a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>both of <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>then neither is liable. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no agency for transgression, </span>and the digger is solely responsible. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if this </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">dug </span>a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>partner dug <span class="gemarra-regular">five</span> further handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>significance of the initial <span class="gemarra-regular">act of </span>digging performed by <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">has been removed. </span>Now all responsibility rests with the second partner, who deepened the pit to ten handbreadths, which is the minimum depth for which one is liable for an animal’s death. Therefore, this is also not treated as a jointly owned pit.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you find in </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>that both would be liable, as the Gemara will soon explain. Therefore, it qualifies as a case of a pit belonging to two partners. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, the first partner is not held liable at all in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pit causes an animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death; and according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>the first partner is not held liable both in a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where it causes death</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>in a situation where it merely causes <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">how, can you find </span>an instance of a pit belonging to partners?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they both extracted a chunk </span>of earth from the bottom of the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">completed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths. This, then, would constitute a pit belonging to both of them.
Having mentioned the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis, the Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs a pit nine</span> handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and completed </span>the digging <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter </span>individual alone is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for an injury or death caused by the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the latter </span>for restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for death </span>caused by the pit. The latter is solely liable, since only a pit of ten handbreadths renders a person liable for an animal’s death. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows both of them </span>for restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>caused by the pit.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis? As the verse states: “If </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall open </span>a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">or if </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">shall dig </span>a pit” (Exodus 21:33), it raises the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for opening </span>a covered pit that has already been dug, then is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>that he should be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">for digging </span>a new pit? What, then, does that latter phrase add? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the case of one person who begins to <span class="gemarra-regular">dig </span>a pit and <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>he does so, a second person continues to <span class="gemarra-regular">dig. </span>By subsequently stating: “If a man shall dig a pit,” the Torah teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a new pit is effectively created by the second digger, whose digging <span class="gemarra-regular">removed, </span>i.e., rendered irrelevant, <span class="gemarra-regular">the action of the first </span>digger and who bears full responsibility for the pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: These </span>two clauses in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, </span>and the second clause cannot serve to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the sole liability of the second digger. The reason they are necessary is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we said</span> earlier (50a), where interpretations were cited according to both Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>don’t <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis also </span>agree that they <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary </span>for those interpretations? If so, what is the source of their opinion that responsibility for the pit rests solely with the second partner?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the previous explanation must be rejected, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the reason of the Rabbis: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “If a man shall dig a pit,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not two. </span>Therefore, if two people jointly created the pit, the second bears responsibility and not the first.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi understand the phrase “if a man shall dig a pit”? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires that </span>phrase to teach another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“if a man shall dig a pit” </span>indicates that a person who digs a pit is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable if his <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>digs a <span class="gemarra-regular">pit.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>from where do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara answers that the combination of words: <span class="gemarra-regular">Man </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">pit, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">written twice: </span>“If a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit.” From one phrase, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is derived that a person must do the digging, and not an animal. From the second phrase, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is derived that one person bears responsibility for the damage, and not two people.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi derive from this repetition? The Gemara answers: In his opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote this </span>first clause using this wording, it similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote this </span>second clause in the same fashion. The repetition is for stylistic reasons, and is not meant to teach a new <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The Gemara continues to ask about the opinion of the Rabbis: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even if they derive from the verse that only one person is liable for damage caused through the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>do they know <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the Torah intends <span class="gemarra-regular">to render </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter one liable </span>for the damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to render the first one </span>who started the digging <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the damage.
The Gemara answers: It should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind </span>to suggest this, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the verse states: “And the carcass shall be for him” </span>(Exodus 21:34). This indicates that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who causes the death, </span>i.e., the second one, who is liable, and not the first. This is because it is the second one who completed digging the necessary depth for causing death, and not the first.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him,” necessary for that which Rava </span>states? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a disqualified consecrated ox that fell into a pit, </span>the pit’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: “And the carcass shall be for him.” </span>Evidently, the verse is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the carcass belongs </span>to him. This ox, which was consecrated and subsequently disqualified, does not fully belong to anybody, since its use is restricted. Since this verse serves to teach Rava’s ruling, it cannot serve to teach about the liability of the second digger.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">And can’t you learn from </span>the words and emphasis of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself that we are dealing with the one who caused </span>the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>even if these words are also used to derive Rava’s ruling? Therefore, the verse can serve as a source for both rulings.
On a similar subject, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs a pit </span>to a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another comes and completes </span>the depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to twenty </span>handbreadths by digging an additional ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another comes and completes it to thirty, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">all liable </span>for any damage caused by this pit. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">raise a contradiction</span> against this from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who digs a pit </span>to a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and plastered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and cemented [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vekhiyyeid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage, and not the first. 

Daf 51b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which teaches that they are all liable, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, who holds both liable for digging, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which holds the latter liable, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold only the last one liable?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>The way the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> accords with their opinion is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the last one</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable only where the first </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">did not make the </span>pit of sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">measurement </span>to cause <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>but dug less than ten handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">But where the first one made </span>a pit of sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">measurement </span>to cause <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>such as in this case, where the first one dug ten handbreadths himself and it was subsequently deepened further by others, <span class="gemarra-regular">even the Rabbis concede that they are all liable.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where <span class="gemarra-regular">he plastered and cemented </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first made </span>a pit of sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">measurement </span>to cause <span class="gemarra-regular">death, and </span>nevertheless, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the last person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. They said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">did not have fumes </span>capable of leading <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>since it was very wide. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the other came, and</span> by narrowing it with plaster and cementing it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">added to it </span>the characteristic of having <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>capable of leading <span class="gemarra-regular">to death.</span>
