<span class="gemarra-regular">There are</span> those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that this is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">which teaches: They are all liable, </span>fits <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>with his opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">which teaches: The last one </span>alone is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">did not have</span> sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes in it </span>that were capable of leading to <span class="gemarra-regular">either death or damage, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and </span>by narrowing it with plaster and cementing it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he added to it </span>the characteristic of having <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>capable of leading <span class="gemarra-regular">to both death and damage.</span>
Elaborating on this subject, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">placed a stone at the opening of a pit </span>less than ten handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">and brings </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a depth of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths by raising the ground next to the opening of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis </span>concerning whether only the second or both are responsible for damage caused.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>This is precisely the case they are disputing, so what does Rava’s statement add to this? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that there is a distinction between a person deepening a pit <span class="gemarra-regular">at the bottom, </span>in which case it <span class="gemarra-regular">is his </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes</span> that he caused <span class="gemarra-regular">that kill </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he added to the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">at the top, where it is not his </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">kill </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable. Rava’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the last one is liable, and this case is subject to dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis as to whether only the last one or both are liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>If someone dug another handbreadth in a pit that was nine handbreadths deep, so that it reached a depth of ten handbreadths, and subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">closed up </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth </span>inside the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he removed his stones </span>that he had placed at the opening of the pit so that the depth of the pit was reduced to less than ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say that what he did </span>to increase the depth of the pit to ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>removed, and restored the initial situation that existed before he dug the extra handbreadth, causing responsibility for damage to revert solely to the original digger?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>by closing it up, he <span class="gemarra-regular">removed the action of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>digger, since he has removed the ability of the pit to cause death? If so, it <span class="gemarra-regular">moves entirely into his possession </span>and he now assumes full responsibility for the pit of nine handbreadths. The Gemara concludes: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel bar Marta says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>handbreadths deep and <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths of it </span>contain <span class="gemarra-regular">water, </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? Each handbreadth of water </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is like two </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">of dry space. </span>Therefore, the pit is effectively ten handbreadths in depth and contains a sufficient quantity of lethal fumes to render its owner liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and from that </span>measurement, <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth </span>contains <span class="gemarra-regular">water, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this case equivalent to the previous one? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>a quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>as in the case stated by Rabba bar bar Ḥana, the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>a sufficient quantity of lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>to render the digger liable? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>it can be argued that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">deeper </span>than the one in the previous case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it does have </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>despite containing less water?
Similarly, the following question can be raised: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>handbreadths deep <span class="gemarra-regular">and three of the handbreadths </span>contain <span class="gemarra-regular">water? Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>there is a <span class="gemarra-regular">much larger </span>quantity <span class="gemarra-regular">of water </span>in this case, it is equivalent to a pit of ten handbreadths and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, or perhaps since it is not </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">deep, it does not have </span>a sufficient quantity of lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes</span> to render the digger liable? The Gemara concludes: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheizevi asked </span>the following question <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba:</span> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">widened </span>the opening of a pit that was already ten handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>By doing so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>and has not worsened the situation. Therefore, he should not be liable. Rav Sheizevi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> On the contrary, </span>by widening the opening of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has brought the </span>potential for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage closer </span>to an animal that might fall inside.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said </span>concerning this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us see: If </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because of the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>the one who widened the pit should be exempt, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he reduced the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">died because of the impact, </span>he should be liable, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he has brought the </span>potential for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage closer </span>to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Let us see: If </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fell on that side </span>that he widened, then his action <span class="gemarra-regular">has brought the </span>potential for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage closer, </span>and so he should be liable. But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fell on the other side, </span>he should bear no responsibility, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he reduced the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit whose depth is equal to its width, Rabba and Rav Yosef both say </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, who says </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Mani, </span>but each present it differently. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>A pit <span class="gemarra-regular">always contains </span>a quantity of lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes</span> sufficient for liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless its width is greater than its depth. </span>Therefore, when they are equal, the digger is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one says: </span>A pit <span class="gemarra-regular">never contains </span>a quantity of lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes </span>sufficient for liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless its depth is greater than its width. </span>Consequently, when they are equal, the digger is exempt.
§ The mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">passed by </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not cover it, </span>and then the second also passed by it and did not cover it, the second is liable. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from what point is the first exempt </span>from responsibility for the pit? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and Rav Yosef both say </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, who says </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Mani, </span>but each one presents it differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">One says:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> From </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">he leaves </span>the other partner <span class="gemarra-regular">using it, and one says: </span>The first is absolved of responsibility only <span class="gemarra-regular">when he conveys to him his bucket, </span>with which he will draw water from the pit.
The Gemara notes: This dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who draws water from a cistern, and his friend comes and says to him: Leave me and I will draw water, once </span>the first person <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves </span>the second person while the second is <span class="gemarra-regular">using </span>the cistern, the first is now <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if he did not cover it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: </span>The first person is not absolved of responsibility until the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he conveys his bucket to </span>the second person.
The Gemara clarifies the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a legal concept of <span class="gemarra-regular">designation. </span>According to this principle, a situation in which certain aspects were not initially clearly defined can become clarified retroactively after a certain action or event occurs. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> treats all the aspects as being clearly defined and identifiable from the outset.
In this case, the water is considered divided between the partners even before they draw it. When they do draw it, it is treated as if <span class="gemarra-regular">this one were filling from his </span>part, the location of which has now been determined retroactively, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this one were filling from his </span>part. Therefore, as long as the first partner has not conveyed his bucket to the second, he, as an owner of a defined part of the water, has not absolved himself of responsibility for the cistern. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no designation </span>and they both have the right to draw water from the cistern. Therefore, as soon as the second partner is left alone to draw water, he is responsible for the cistern and all the water it contains, even without conveying the bucket.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: And </span>in this regard, they <span class="gemarra-regular">follow </span>their lines of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>in an analogous case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 45b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">partners </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that vowed </span>not to derive any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from each other, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited for them to enter </span>their jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>as this would violate their vows. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: </span>It is permitted for them to enter the courtyard, since <span class="gemarra-regular">this one enters into his </span>portion of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one enters into his </span>portion.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and retroactively the section of the courtyard that each one enters becomes the portion that belongs to him. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">this one enters his </span>part, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one enters his </span>part. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no</span> retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and each portion of the courtyard belongs jointly to both.
§ Having mentioned this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning conveying a bucket to transfer responsibility for the pit, the Gemara cites that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a cistern to another,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> once </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">conveys his bucket to </span>the buyer for drawing water from the cistern, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the cistern. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span>How does conveying the bucket serve to effect acquisition of the cistern? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he is acquiring the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of paying <span class="gemarra-regular">money, let him acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money </span>that he paid. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he is acquiring the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by taking possession, </span>which is accomplished by using it.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cistern was acquired through <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession, and </span>in that case, the seller usually <span class="gemarra-regular">must say to him: Go, take possession, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it for yourself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he conveys his bucket to him, he is like one who says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: Go, take possession, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it. Therefore, once he begins drawing water from the cistern, he has acquired it through taking possession.
The Gemara cites a related ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sells a house to another, </span>

Daf 52a

<span class="gemarra-regular">once he has conveyed the key to him, he has acquired </span>it.
Here too, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>involving this sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it was a transaction <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">money. If </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">by taking possession </span>of it, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by taking possession. </span>What is the significance of transferring the key? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the transaction occurred by <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession, and </span>in that case, the seller usually <span class="gemarra-regular">must say to him: Go, take possession, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it for yourself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he conveys the key to him, </span>he is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like one who says to him: Go, take possession, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Yannai: </span>With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a flock </span>of sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, once he conveys the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashkukhit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>the flock.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the transaction occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling </span>the flock into his possession, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling. If </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">by conveying </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">conveying </span>it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it was a transaction <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling, and </span>in that case, the seller usually <span class="gemarra-regular">must say to him: Go, pull </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and acquire </span>it for yourself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he conveys the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashkukhit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">like one who says to him: Go, pull </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and acquire </span>it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is this <span class="gemarra-italic">mashkukhit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Here, </span>in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">they translate </span>it as <span class="gemarra-regular">a bell [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karkashta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>that the shepherd rings and whose sound the flock follows. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says: </span>It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the goat that goes at the front </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the flock </span>that they follow. The Gemara notes: This explanation of Rabbi Ya’akov is similar to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which a certain Galilean taught </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of Rav Ḥisda concerning </span>this goat: <span class="gemarra-regular">When a shepherd is angry with his flock, he renders </span>the goat <span class="gemarra-regular">leading [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lenaggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>them, i.e., the <span class="it-text">mashkukhit</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">blind. </span>Similarly, when God is angry with the Jewish people, he appoints unsuitable leaders for them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna lists several <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> that pertain to damage classified as Pit: In the case of a pit that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>person who passed by <span class="gemarra-regular">covered </span>after using <span class="gemarra-regular">it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the second came </span>to use it <span class="gemarra-regular">and found it uncovered </span>after the cover fell off or was damaged, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover it, the second </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused by the pit. If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
If a man was digging or widening a pit, and an ox passing by <span class="gemarra-regular">fell forward </span>into it in fright <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sound </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the digging, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">backward </span>into the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sound</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">the digging, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and its accoutrements, </span>i.e., the vessels it was carrying, <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">were broken, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and its accoutrements </span>fell in <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the accoutrements <span class="gemarra-regular">were torn, </span>the owner of the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">the animal </span>caused by the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">the vessels, </span>by Torah edict.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that was impaired by being <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf, </span>or an ox that was <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, or </span>an ox that was very <span class="gemarra-regular">young fell into </span>the pit, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy or a girl, </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave or </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservant </span>fell in, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since there is a Torah edict that the digger of a pit is liable only for damage caused to an animal.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the first case in the mishna, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And until when </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> if the pit is later uncovered? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>He is exempt from liability for the time necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>become <span class="gemarra-regular">aware </span>that it became uncovered. Once this time has passed, he bears responsibility. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>He is exempt for the time necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>realize that the pit is uncovered and <span class="gemarra-regular">inform him. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>He is exempt for the time necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> others <span class="gemarra-regular">to inform him </span>that the cover has fallen down <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>for him to <span class="gemarra-regular">hire workers and cut cedar trees </span>to make a suitable cover <span class="gemarra-regular">and cover it. </span>After this period of time has passed, the first bears responsibility.
§ The mishna teaches: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately and an ox or a donkey fell inside and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately, how </span>did it <span class="gemarra-regular">fall </span>in? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak bar bar Ḥana says: </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside, </span>and he could not have known that the cover was damaged. Therefore, he is not responsible for damage caused as a result.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">covered it </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a cover </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">able to withstand </span>the weight of <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen but cannot withstand</span> the weight of <span class="gemarra-regular">camels, </span>which are heavier, <span class="gemarra-regular">and camels came and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">weakened it, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen came </span>and broke the weakened cover <span class="gemarra-regular">and fell into </span>the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> circumstances? If camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is negligent, </span>since he should have constructed the cover suitably for camels as well. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if camels are not </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, then <span class="gemarra-regular">he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control</span> if by chance they did come and weaken the cover.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>camels <span class="gemarra-regular">come occasionally, </span>in which case the question effectively becomes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since they come occasionally, he is</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, since he should have anticipated </span>their coming? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps since now, in any event, there are no </span>camels, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a possible proof from the mishna: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately, and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Now <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances? If we say </span>that he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and appropriately for camels, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>did they <span class="gemarra-regular">fall </span>in? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>the case that he covered it with a covering that was <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate for oxen</span>

Daf 52b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but not appropriate for camels? </span>In this case, the following must be clarified: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a location <span class="gemarra-regular">where camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found, why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? He is negligent. And if camels are not </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that he is exempt, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstances beyond his control. Rather, is it not </span>the case that this is a location <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>camels <span class="gemarra-regular">come occasionally, and camels came and weakened </span>the covering, after which <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen came and fell into it?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>with regard to this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Apparently, since now, </span>in any event, the camels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>there, he is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstances beyond his control.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They said </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">actually, </span>the scenario is where he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen and appropriately for camels, and as for </span>what was <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult for you </span>to explain: <span class="gemarra-regular">How did they fall? Rabbi Yitzḥak bar bar Ḥana says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside, </span>and so nothing can be derived from here with regard to the question posed above with regard to the camels.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof from the mishna: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately, and an ox or a donkey fell in and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Now, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances? If we say </span>that he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>cover it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen and </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>cover it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for camels, </span>and they fell in, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious. </span>Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">need to be said that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>in that case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a case where he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen but not appropriately for camels? </span>And if this is the case, the following point must be clarified: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If camels are</span> commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, but if camels are not </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>camels <span class="gemarra-regular">come occasionally, and camels came and weakened it, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen came and fell into it? And </span>in this case, it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Apparently, since they </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">come occasionally, he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, since he should have anticipated </span>that they would come.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is possible that he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriately for camels, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And as for </span>what was <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult for you </span>to explain: In such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent </span>and should be liable, rendering the ruling in the mishna superfluous, one may answer that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> needs to <span class="gemarra-regular">cite the first clause </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if he <span class="gemarra-regular">covered it appropriately, he cites the latter clause as well, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that if he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover it appropriately, he is liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are</span> those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the discussion is as follows: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this also we certainly did not raise the dilemma, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">since they occasionally come, he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, as he should have anticipated </span>this possibility.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When we raised the dilemma, this is the dilemma that we raised: </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">covered it </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a cover that is able </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">withstand the presence of oxen but is unable to withstand the presence of camels, and camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>in that location. What actually transpired was that the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inside. </span>In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say: Since he was negligent concerning camels, he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent also concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">rotting? Or perhaps we do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>he was negligent concerning camels he is considered negligent concerning rotting, and since in practice he is not to blame for the incident, he is not held liable?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. And</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to </span>this that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak bar bar Ḥana says: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If we say </span>that it is referring to where he covered it in a manner <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate for oxen and appropriate for camels</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside, </span>isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>Being unaware of this, <span class="gemarra-regular">what should he have done?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a case where he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriately for camels, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>in that location? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the strength of the cover vis-à-vis oxen and camels is not relevant to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> here because the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside. And </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Apparently, we do not say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent concerning camels, he is </span>also considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent with regard to the rotting.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; actually, </span>the case is where the cover was <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate for camels and appropriate for oxen, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted from the inside. And as for </span>what was <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult for you </span>to explain: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted </span>from the inside, <span class="gemarra-regular">what should he have done, </span>and shouldn’t he be exempt? There is, nevertheless, a novelty in this ruling: It is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have gone and knocked on </span>the covering to ensure it was not hollow on the inside. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he is not required to check to this extent.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the continuation of the mishna: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fell into it and died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If we say </span>that it is referring to where he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>cover it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen and </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>cover it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for camels, </span>does it <span class="gemarra-regular">need to be said that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>a case where he covered it <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriately for camels? </span>In this case, the following point needs clarification: <span class="gemarra-regular">If camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is negligent </span>and should be liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if camels are not </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstances beyond his control. Rather, is it not </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it rotted from the inside, </span>and the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? Apparently, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he is negligent concerning the camels, he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent concerning the rotting, </span>and he is therefore liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">They said</span> in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; actually </span>it is referring to where he covered the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately for oxen </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriately for camels; and camels are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and camels came and weakened </span>the cover. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, </span>subsequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen came and fell in. And as for </span>what was <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult for you </span>to explain: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that he is liable, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent, </span>so what novelty is being introduced? The answer is that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he </span>needs to <span class="gemarra-regular">cite the first clause </span>of the mishna, i.e., where he <span class="gemarra-regular">covered </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriately, he </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">cites</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the latter clause as well, </span>i.e., where he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not cover it.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof from the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox</span> that was impaired by being <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf</span>, or an ox that was <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, or </span>an ox that was very <span class="gemarra-regular">young, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a blind </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the pit, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>If the ox was of <span class="gemarra-regular">standard intelligence </span>for its species <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">walking in the day, </span>the owner of the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since the ox should have been aware of the pit. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>is he exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that since he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent concerning </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf</span> ox<span class="gemarra-regular">, he is also negligent concerning </span>an ox of <span class="gemarra-regular">standard intelligence. Rather, is it not </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude </span>the following principle <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>here: <span class="gemarra-regular">We do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>he is negligent with regard to one matter, it is also considered negligence with regard to another matter, but he is held liable only for the damage actually attributable to his negligence? The Gemara affirms: Yes, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: If a man was digging or widening a pit, and an ox passing by <span class="gemarra-regular">fell forward </span>into it in fright due to the sound of the digging, he is liable. If it fell backward into the pit due to the sound of the digging, he is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> The term <span class="gemarra-regular">forward </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">literally forward, </span>and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">backward </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">literally backward, </span>

Daf 53a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>refer <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>where it fell into <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>itself, but nevertheless if it fell backward, he is exempt.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rav says:</span> Damage classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit for which the Torah obligates him </span>to pay is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>damage caused by the pit’s lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>such as if an animal suffocates inside it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not to </span>damage caused by the <span class="gemarra-regular">impact</span> of hitting the ground, for which he is exempt from paying compensation. Since the ox in this case fell backward on its back, the owner of the pit is exempt from paying compensation, as the ox wasn’t killed by the lethal fumes of the pit, but by the impact of the fall.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>If the ox fell <span class="gemarra-regular">into the pit, whether </span>it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">forward </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">backward, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>With regard to damage classified as Pit, the Torah holds one liable for damage caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by its </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, and all the more so for </span>damage resulting from the <span class="gemarra-regular">impact </span>of the fall. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> according to Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances </span>concerning which the mishna stated that if the ox fell <span class="gemarra-regular">backward </span>into the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sound</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the digging that </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>The Gemara answers: This applies, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">stumbled on the pit,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">fell behind the pit </span>and was injured <span class="gemarra-regular">outside the pit.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rav from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an animal that fell into <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, whether </span>it fell in <span class="gemarra-regular">forward </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it fell in <span class="gemarra-regular">backward, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>This constitutes <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation of Rav.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>in explanation of how Rav’s opinion could accord with the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav concedes </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a pit on his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if the animal fell backward, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the owner of the animal can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever way you </span>look at it, you are liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>my animal <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>due <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">are your </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes. If </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>on account <span class="gemarra-regular">of the impact, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is the impact </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span>land, and not the impact of land in the public domain, which is the typical case of Pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said </span>that this is how the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be explained according to Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tumbled, </span>i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it began to <span class="gemarra-regular">fall on its face, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">tumbled and </span>continued to <span class="gemarra-regular">fall on its back. </span>In this case, he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because the </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, which were effective </span>in injuring the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">effective </span>in killing <span class="gemarra-regular">it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: Here, </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>that is caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by the ox. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the damage? The damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it contaminated the water </span>in the pit, in which case the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it makes <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if the animal fell <span class="gemarra-regular">forward and </span>it makes <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">backward,</span> since he <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>either way.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥananya taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in support of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav: </span>The verse states with regard to damage caused by a pit to an animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>an ox or a donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">fall </span>therein” (Exodus 21:33), which is interpreted to mean that one is not liable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">falls</span> in the usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of falling. From here </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that if it <span class="gemarra-regular">fell forward due to the sound of the digging, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>but if it fell <span class="gemarra-regular">backward due to the sound of the digging, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case refer to damage <span class="gemarra-regular">by a pit.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the mishna: If it <span class="gemarra-regular">fell forward due to the sound of the digging, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>is this so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say</span> that it is the sound of <span class="gemarra-regular">the digger </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>the animal to fall, and not the pit itself. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this? </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, who says: The owner </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit causes the damage </span>by his digging, <span class="gemarra-regular">and anywhere that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not possible to collect </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>one who caused the fall, i.e., the digger, payment is <span class="gemarra-regular">collected from that</span> one, i.e., the owner of the pit. This is because in any event, he bears responsibility for the hazard he created.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that pushed another </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">into a pit, the owner of the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. Rabbi Natan says: The owner of the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">ox pays half </span>the amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of the pit pays half </span>the amount.
The Gemara clarifies Rabbi Natan’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: </span>If an ox pushed another ox into a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the pit pays three-quarters, and the owner of the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">ox</span> pays <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter? </span>The Gemara resolves the contradiction: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to an innocuous </span>ox that pushed the second ox. Therefore, the owner of the ox that caused damage pays only one-quarter of the cost of the damage, which is half of the half for which he is responsible. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>other <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a forewarned </span>ox that pushed a second ox. Consequently, the owner of the forewarned ox pays the full amount for which he is responsible, i.e., half the value of the total damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to an innocuous </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">what does </span>Rabbi Natan <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>as to why this person pays one-quarter and the owner of the pit pays three-quarters? <span class="gemarra-regular">If he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, i.e., the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">performed all the damage and the other, </span>i.e., the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>all the damage, then he should have ruled that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half, </span>since they are both fully responsible. Although the ox was innocuous, the owner is still liable to pay half the cost of the damage, as that is the liability incurred for an act of damaging by an innocuous ox.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>Rabbi Natan <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, i.e., the owner of the ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">performed half the damage, and that </span>one, i.e., the owner of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">performed half the damage, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the pit </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">pay half </span>of the amount for which he is responsible, i.e., half the cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner of the </span>innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>should pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter, </span>which is half the amount for which he is responsible. As for <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter,</span> the injured party has no recourse to claim it, and <span class="gemarra-regular">loses </span>it. Why, then, does Rabbi Natan hold that the owner of the pit pays for three-quarters of the damage?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Rabbi Natan is a judge and </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">plumbed the full depths of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Actually, he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">performed all of the damage and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">performed all of the damage. And as </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">your difficulty, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">should pay half and that </span>one should pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half, </span>that is not difficult. The owner of the ox pays only one-quarter, <span class="gemarra-regular">because the owner of the ox </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the owner of the pit: How</span> did <span class="gemarra-regular">my partnership </span>with you in this situation <span class="gemarra-regular">help me? </span>Even if my ox caused all the damage and none of the damage was caused by the pit, I would be required to pay only half the cost of the damage. Therefore, as we are partners in this situation, I should pay half of what I should have paid, which is one-quarter. You should pay the other half of what I should have paid, in addition to your share, since you would have had to pay full damages.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead a different explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>Rabbi Natan <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">performed half the damage and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">performed half the damage. As </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">your difficulty </span>with the fact that the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the pit </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">pay half and the owner of the ox </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">pay one-quarter, and </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">loses the other </span>remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter, </span>that is not difficult. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the owner of the </span>killed <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the owner of the pit: I found my ox in your pit. </span>Consequently, I am assuming that <span class="gemarra-regular">you killed it. </span>Therefore, concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>portion of the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">that I can receive from the other,</span> i.e., the owner of the damaging ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will receive </span>it. Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">that I am unable to receive from the other </span>individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will receive it from you.</span>
On the same subject, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">left a stone at the opening of a pit </span>belonging to another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox came and stumbled on it and fell into the pit, we have arrived at the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan and the Rabbis </span>concerning the division of responsibility between them. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, </span>since what is the difference whether the ox fell into the pit due to another ox pushing it or due to the stone?
The Gemara answers: This ruling needed to be stated explicitly, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">there the owner of the pit </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the owner of the ox </span>who was responsible for the damage: <span class="gemarra-regular">If not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">my pit, your ox would have killed </span>the second ox anyway, in which case my pit was not the cause of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, the owner of the stone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can say to the owner of the pit: If not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">your pit, what would my stone have done? If </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">would have stumbled on it, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">would have </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">fallen and gotten up, </span>and I should be exempt. Therefore, Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this claim is not a valid one, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the owner of the pit can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of the stone: <span class="gemarra-regular">If not for </span>your <span class="gemarra-regular">stone, </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">would not have fallen into the pit </span>in the first place.
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>

Daf 53b

There is a dispute with regard to a case of an ordinary innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox and a disqualified consecrated ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that gored </span>another ox together. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>this case of an ox that was consecrated and disqualified? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn ox that </span>became blemished and was consequently disqualified as an offering. Nevertheless, its initial consecration remains, and therefore it may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">redeemed. </span>Consequently, the priest in possession of it is not liable to pay damages, since it is not classified as: The ox of another, as its status is not that of a non-sacred ox belonging to a person. Given this background, what is the liability of the owner of the non-sacred ox that gored together with it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: He pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: He pays one-quarter of </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage.</span>
The Gemara explains the dispute: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> one, Abaye, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, Ravina, refer <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the ordinary ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous. This </span>opinion stated by Ravina is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>that each party is responsible for only half the damage. Since the non-sacred ox was innocuous, its owner pays half the cost of the damage for which he is responsible, i.e., one-quarter of the total. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>opinion stated by Abaye is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan </span>that each party in turn is responsible for all the damage. Consequently, since the non-sacred ox is innocuous, its owner pays half the total amount.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead that there is no dispute, and that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, Abaye, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, Ravina, state their opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. This </span>one, Ravina, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>where the non-sacred ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous, </span>and so its owner pays half of a half, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, Abaye, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>where the non-sacred ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>so its owner pays his entire share, i.e., half the total damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that there was another version of this dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says </span>that he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: </span>He pays <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage. </span>The Gemara explains their reasoning: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>where the ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned. This </span>one, Abaye, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>that each one is responsible for half the damage, and so he pays his share of half the total cost of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>one, Ravina, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, </span>that each one is fully responsible for the damage, and when one perpetrator of the damage is exempt from payment, such as this case, the entire amount is collected from the other.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead that there is no dispute, and that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, Ravina, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>where the ox was <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>and the owner pays the full cost of the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that</span> one, Abaye, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>ox, for which only half the cost of the damage is paid.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and a person that push </span>a person or animal <span class="gemarra-regular">into a pit, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>that they caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">they, </span>i.e., the man who pushed the person or animal, the owner of the ox, and the owner of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">are all liable </span>to pay the indemnity of damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Concerning the four</span> additional <span class="gemarra-regular">types of indemnity, </span>which are loss of livelihood, pain, medical costs, and humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for</span> miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">person </span>who pushed is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since the Torah did not impose any obligation on them to pay these payments.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">ransom </span>if it was a person who was pushed and killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also concerning the <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span>shekels paid <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave</span> who was killed, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ox </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the man </span>who did the pushing <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the pit </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> With regard to vessels </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a disqualified consecrated ox </span>that fell into the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">the man </span>who did the pushing <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, and </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">pit </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
Rava explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the owner of the pit is exempt from liability for damage caused to a disqualified consecrated ox? Since <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to a pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him”</span> (Exodus 21:34), it teaches that the obligation to pay damages is imposed only <span class="gemarra-regular">on the one to whom the carcass </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs, </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding this</span> case of a disqualified consecrated ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">where the carcass does not belong to him. </span>In this case, it is prohibited to sell the carcass. The owner of the pit cannot derive benefit from it, and it no longer belongs to anyone, so the conditions written in the verse are not in effect.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that </span>this matter was <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious to Rava? Is it not a dilemma </span>that was already raised <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rava, as Rava asked: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a disqualified consecrated ox that fell into a pit? </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him,” </span>referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the one </span>to whom <span class="gemarra-regular">the carcass belongs, </span>i.e., the owner of the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the carcass does not belong to him, </span>and therefore the owner is exempt from paying for it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him” comes to teach that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">attends to, </span>i.e., retains ownership of, <span class="gemarra-regular">the carcass, </span>and the perpetrator of the damage pays him the difference?
The Gemara answers: Initially, Rava was in doubt about the matter, but <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemma,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolved it </span>and concluded that the verse imposes liability for the cost of damage only on a person to whom the carcass belongs, excluding the case of a disqualified consecrated ox.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, from where does he </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> attends to the animal carcass? </span>The Gemara answers: He <span class="gemarra-regular">derives it from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him” </span>(Exodus 21:36), stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Ox.</span> The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did you see </span>to determine <span class="gemarra-regular">that from </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him,”</span> stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Ox, you derive </span>from it the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">attends to the carcass, </span>and from the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass belongs to him,” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Pit, you derive from it </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that only <span class="gemarra-regular">the one to whom the carcass belongs </span>pays damages? Why can’t <span class="gemarra-regular">I reverse </span>the derivations from each verse and say the opposite?
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">exemption </span>applies to the verse stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Pit, since </span>the Torah also <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>one from paying for damage classified as Pit caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>that fall into it and break. The Gemara challenges this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>one could claim that the <span class="gemarra-regular">exemption </span>applies to the verse stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Ox, since </span>the Torah also <span class="gemarra-regular">exempted </span>the owner from <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage </span>in the case of an innocuous ox. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, we do not find </span>that the owner of the ox is exempt from compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>By contrast, with regard to Pit, there are certain items for which a person is not liable at all. Therefore, it is logical to conclude that the Torah is more lenient in cases of Pit than of Ox.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and its accoutrements, </span>i.e., the vessels it was carrying, <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">were broken, </span>or if a donkey and its accoutrements fell in and the accoutrements were torn, the owner of the pit is liable for damage to the animal caused by the pit, but he is exempt from liability for damage caused to the vessels, by Torah edict. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda obligates </span>a person to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels in </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Rabbis? Since the verse states: “And an ox or a donkey fall therein” </span>(Exodus 21:33), it is inferred that it is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, but not a person, </span>for whose death the owner of the pit is liable. Moreover, one is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey, but not vessels. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>expounds the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>in the expression “an ox or a donkey” <span class="gemarra-regular">to include vessels. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>explain the word “or”? 

Daf 54a

The word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary to separate </span>the cases of the ox and donkey.
