This indicates that if either falls in individually, the owner of the pit is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to separate </span>the cases in the verse? He derives it <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the use of the singular form of the verb: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And </span>an ox or donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">fall [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">venafal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>indicating that he is liable if even one animal falls. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis </span>maintain that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">and fall </span>can also <span class="gemarra-regular">indicate many </span>animals, as the use of the singular form of a verb does not prove that the subject is necessarily singular.
The Gemara now challenges both opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“and fall” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>whereas the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“an ox or a donkey” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail. </span>According to the principles of halakhic exegesis, when the Torah presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a detail, the generalization </span>includes <span class="gemarra-regular">only what </span>is contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in the detail. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and a donkey</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>included, but <span class="gemarra-regular">anything else </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>included.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: The following verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The owner of the pit shall pay” </span>(Exodus 21:34), means that <span class="gemarra-regular">it then generalized </span>again. The verses are structured according to the principle of halakhic exegesis of: <span class="gemarra-regular">A generalization, and a detail, and a generalization.</span> According to this principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">you may deduce </span>that the verses are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items that are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the detail. </span>In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as the explicit detail </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">animals, so too, all </span>items included in the generalization must be <span class="gemarra-regular">animals.</span>
The Gemara now challenges this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>so, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the explicit detail, </span>i.e., the ox and donkey, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">items whose carcass renders </span>a person ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure by contact or by carrying, so too,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all items, </span>i.e., all animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose carcass renders </span>a person ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure through contact or by carrying, </span>should be included in the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damage classified as Pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But birds, </span>whose carcasses do not render a person impure through contact or by carrying, would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be included.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, let the Merciful One write </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one detail, </span>from which the exclusion of birds could be derived. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>detail <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">write? If </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">writes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I would say </span>that an item that <span class="gemarra-regular">is sacrificed on the altar, </span>such as an ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>renders the owner of the pit liable, whereas an item <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not sacrificed on the altar </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>render him liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the Merciful One writes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I would say: </span>Those animals whose <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctified, </span>such as a donkey, as described in the Torah (Exodus 13:13), do <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>render their owners liable, but animals whose <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not sanctified </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>render them liable. Therefore, the Torah states both an ox and a donkey.
The original difficulty therefore resurfaces: Why is the verse not expounded as a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, thereby excluding birds? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the previous method of deriving liability for a pit must be rejected, and instead it should be derived as follows: The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And the carcass shall be for him” </span>(Exodus 21:34), from which it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything subject to death </span>is included.
The Gemara asks: If this is the basis for liability for a pit, then <span class="gemarra-regular">both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to the Rabbis, who exclude vessels </span>from liability based on another verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">and according to Rabbi Yehuda, who has amplified </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to include <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, </span>one could ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are vessels subject to death? </span>Clearly, vessels cannot be subject to death. Why, then, is a separate source necessary to derive their halakhic status? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in reply: Vessels may also be considered subject to death in the sense that <span class="gemarra-regular">their shattering is </span>tantamount to <span class="gemarra-regular">their deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h.</span>
The Gemara continues to challenge this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rav, who says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for which the Torah deems </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, but not for </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">the impact </span>of the fall, the following question may be raised <span class="gemarra-regular">both according to the Rabbis and according to Rabbi Yehuda: Are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessels capable </span>of being broken by the lethal <span class="gemarra-regular">fumes, </span>such that a verse is necessary to exclude them? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> in reply: There is such a case concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">new </span>vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">which crack from the fumes.</span>
The Gemara asks further: But isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the carcass shall be for him,” necessary </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for that which Rava </span>ruled, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a disqualified consecrated ox that fell into a pit, </span>the owner of the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: “And the carcass shall be for him.” </span>It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a person to <span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">carcass belongs, </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding this </span>person, to <span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">carcass</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">not belong. </span>Once a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> has already been derived from this verse, it cannot be used as the basis for deriving a second <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of liability for Pit must be derived from another source. The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states </span>concerning Pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall recompense money to its owners” </span>(Exodus 21:34), thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">including any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that has an owner </span>within the scope of liability. The Gemara challenges this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even vessels and people </span>should be included <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>which presents a difficulty for all opinions.
The Gemara answers: This is why <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “An ox,” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but not a person; “a donkey,” but not vessels. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rabbi Yehuda, who amplifies </span>the scope of liability to include <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, granted </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“an ox” </span>is necessary, as he <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people based on it, </span>for which he is not liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“a donkey,” what </span>does he <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude based on it?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Pit, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“sheep” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:1), stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a lost </span>item, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>(see <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 27a) are <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>There is no explanation for why they are stated.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥeresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shoteh</span> ox <span class="gemarra-regular">or a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span> ox <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>the pit, the owner of the pit is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥeresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shoteh</span> ox <span class="gemarra-regular">or a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span> ox? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it means: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox belonging to a deaf-mute [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥeresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], an ox belonging to an imbecile [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shoteh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox belonging to a minor [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>then it can be inferred that if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>belonging to a halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent </span>adult, the owner of the pit would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>What would be the reason for this exemption?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>Instead, it should be interpreted as: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox that is </span>impaired by being <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is an imbecile, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">young. </span>

Daf 54b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>can it be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is of </span>standard <span class="gemarra-regular">intelligence </span>fell into a pit, the owner of the pit would be <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>utilizing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary,</span> and should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to state that if <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is of </span>standard <span class="gemarra-regular">intelligence </span>fell into a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the pit’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf, an imbecile, or </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">young, say </span>that it was not due to the pit alone that it fell in, but <span class="gemarra-regular">its deafness caused it </span>to fall in or <span class="gemarra-regular">its young age caused it </span>to fall in, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">should be exempt. </span>Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he is liable in these cases as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa said to Ravina:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a living being that is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent fell into </span>a pit, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What, is it not </span>referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent? </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> No, </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person. </span>Rav Aḥa challenges this response: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>you should then infer that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>only for the injuries of a <span class="gemarra-regular">person </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, but </span>if one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not mentally competent, </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he would be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>But the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“an ox” is written </span>in the Torah as causing liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not a person.</span>
Rava responded to Rav Aḥa: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>does the term <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent</span> mean? It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a species </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent, </span>and thereby includes all humans in the exemption from liability. Rav Aḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox</span> that was <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent fell inside it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that Rabbi Yirmeya’s explanation should be rejected, and the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is deaf, an ox that is an imbecile,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and an ox that is </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">young, </span>for which he is liable; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is </span>of standard <span class="gemarra-regular">intelligence, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason? </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">should have looked carefully</span> while <span class="gemarra-regular">walking. </span>If it did not, it is responsible for its own injury. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>idea <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to an <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">deaf, an imbecile, or </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">young, blind, or </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">walking at night </span>and unable to see, if it <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into </span>a pit, the pit’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>But if the ox is of standard <span class="gemarra-regular">intelligence </span>or is <span class="gemarra-regular">walking during the day, </span>the pit’s owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since normal behavior for oxen is that, ordinarily, they watch where they are going and avoid pits.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is the same <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox or whether </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">animal with regard to </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and with regard to </span>keeping its <span class="gemarra-regular">distance </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">Mount Sinai </span>at the time of the receiving of the Torah, when it was forbidden for any animal to ascend the mountain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to the payment of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> double </span>the principal by a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to</span> the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning a lost item, and with regard to unloading </span>its burden, and <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">muzzling </span>it while threshing, and <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, and with regard to </span>the prohibition against its working on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, undomesticated animals and birds </span>are subject to the same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>domesticated animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>all of the above <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>in the Torah only in reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox or a donkey? Rather, </span>the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the verse speaks of a common </span>scenario, from which the other cases may be derived.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara explains the sources for all of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> enumerated in the mishna that apply to all animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to falling </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “He shall recompense money to its owners” </span>(Exodus 21:34), which means that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that has owners </span>is included, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we mentioned </span>(see 54a). <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the requirement that animals keep their <span class="gemarra-regular">distance</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">Mount Sinai </span>before the giving of the Torah, this is derived from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Whether it be animal or person, it shall not live” </span>(Exodus 19:13), <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an undomesticated animal [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">included in </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">animal [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">behema</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].</span> In addition, the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“whether” </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include birds.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to the double payment</span> of a thief, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we say </span>in a halakhic exegesis of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For any matter of trespass” </span>(Exodus 22:8), that it is a general statement which <span class="gemarra-regular">includes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">any matter </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence. With regard to </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning a lost item, </span>the verse states comprehensively: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For every lost thing of your brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">unloading </span>a burden, <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat,</span> as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey </span>is employed in the context of unloading a burden (see Exodus 23:5), and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Deuteronomy 5:14), and that verse is clearly referring to any animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">muzzling </span>an animal, mentioned in the verse: “You shall not muzzle an ox while it is threshing” (Deuteronomy 25:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> a verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>is employed in the context of muzzling, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Deuteronomy 5:14), and that verse is clearly referring to any animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, if </span>it is referring to the prohibition against using <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing, </span>due to which it is forbidden to plow with an ox and a donkey together (see Deuteronomy 22:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>is employed in the context of plowing with diverse kinds, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox”</span> is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Deuteronomy 5:14), and that verse is clearly referring to any animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring to the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for crossbreeding, derive </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>as the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle” </span>is employed in the context of crossbreeding animals (see Leviticus 19:19), and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle” </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Exodus 20:10), and that verse is clearly referring to any animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning Shabbat </span>itself that the words “ox” and “donkey” are referring to all types of animals? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: In the first </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “Your manservant, your maidservant, nor your cattle” </span>(Exodus 20:10), whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">in the second </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “Nor your ox, nor your donkey, nor any of your cattle” </span>(Deuteronomy 5:14). Now, <span class="gemarra-regular">aren’t an ox and a donkey </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">included in </span>the category of: <span class="gemarra-regular">All animals, </span>which are included in the term “cattle”? <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, were they <span class="gemarra-regular">specified? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">To teach you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">ox and donkey that are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stated here, undomesticated animals and birds </span>have the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as them, so too, </span>everywhere that an ox and donkey are mentioned, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">undomesticated animals and birds </span>have the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as them.</span>
The Gemara asks: But why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the verses be expounded as follows: The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“cattle” </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>and the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“your ox and your donkey” </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">in the latter </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail. </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">detail, </span>the principles of halakhic exegesis dictate that <span class="gemarra-regular">the generalization includes only what </span>is specified <span class="gemarra-regular">in the detail. </span>Therefore, with regard to this subject, <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and a donkey </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>be included, but <span class="gemarra-regular">anything else </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be included.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in reply: In the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“nor any of your cattle” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> latter </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments </span>following the phrase “your ox and your donkey,” <span class="gemarra-regular">it then generalized </span>again. Therefore, the verse is structured as <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization. </span>According to the principles of halakhic exegesis, <span class="gemarra-regular">you may deduce </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the detail. </span>Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as animals, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so too, all </span>items included in the general term must be <span class="gemarra-regular">animals.</span>
The Gemara challenges the answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as an item, </span>i.e., an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose carcass renders </span>a person ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure through contact or through carrying, so too, all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">items whose carcass renders </span>a person ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure through contact or through carrying </span>should be included. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">birds, </span>whose carcasses do not render one impure through contact or through carrying, should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be included.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let the Merciful One write </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one detail </span>from which this could be derived. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>detail <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Merciful One write? If the Merciful One writes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I would say: </span>An animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">is sacrificed on the altar, </span>such as an ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>renders the owner of the pit liable, whereas an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not sacrificed on the altar </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>render him liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the Merciful One writes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey, I would say:</span> An animal whose <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctified, </span>such as a donkey, as described in the Torah (Exodus 13:13), does <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>render him liable, but an animal whose <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not sanctified </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>render him liable. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>and a donkey.
Consequently, there is no redundancy, and each detail is required for correctly deriving other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. If so, the previous question resurfaces: Why are the verses not expounded such that the prohibition does not include birds? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Nor any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vekhol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of your cattle,” </span>should be understood as <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification, </span>encompassing any item that is even partially similar to the detail.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it the case that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that the Merciful One states </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>intended as an <span class="gemarra-regular">amplification? But concerning tithes, where it is written</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we expound </span>the verses <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the method of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a detail, </span>rather than using the method of amplification and restriction.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning second-tithe money brought to Jerusalem: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall give the money for anything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekhol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] your soul desires” </span>(Deuteronomy 14:26), which is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>followed by: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For oxen, or for sheep, or for wine, or for strong drink,” </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail, </span>and concludes with: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or for anything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvkhol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] your soul asks of you,” </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">it then generalized </span>again.
Therefore, the verse is structured as <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization. </span>According to the principles of halakhic exegesis, <span class="gemarra-regular">you may deduce </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the detail. </span>Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as produce of produce, </span>i.e., they grow from a parent organism, such as agricultural produce or animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">grown from the ground, </span>i.e., their sustenance comes from the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>it includes <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>things that are <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce of produce and are grown from the ground. </span>It is evident from here that the method of a generalization and a detail is used in connection with the term “kol,” as opposed to interpreting it as an amplification.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: A distinction may be drawn between the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For anything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekhol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],”</span> as in: “Any of your cattle,” which is <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> And <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>instead that the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is a generalization as well, </span>in addition to “for anything [<span class="it-text">bekhol</span>].” <span class="gemarra-regular">But this </span>word <span class="gemarra-regular">“any,” </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">here, is an amplification. </span>This is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">since it could have written: And your cattle, as it is written in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments, and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">it writes: “Nor any of your cattle.” Learn from </span>this that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification </span>and encompasses other animals as well.
The Gemara continues to analyze this matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” is an amplification, why do I </span>need the words <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle,” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments, and </span>the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">“an ox or a donkey,” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the latter </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments? </span>The phrase “and any of your cattle” already includes any animal.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: Each of these terms is required. The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>can be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">muzzling, </span>as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>is employed in the context of muzzling, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat.
The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey” </span>can be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">unloading </span>a burden, as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey” </span>is employed in the context of unloading a burden (see Exodus 23:5), and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey” </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Deuteronomy 5:14).
The term <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle” </span>can be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, </span>as the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle”</span> is employed in the context of crossbreeding animals (see Leviticus 19:19), and the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“your cattle” </span>is employed in the context of the prohibition against having one’s animal perform labor on Shabbat (see Exodus 20:10).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that this redundancy is the source for extending the prohibition of diverse kinds, then it <span class="gemarra-regular">should be prohibited even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>to plow together with an ox or another animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">did we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 8:6): It is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person to plow and pull with any of them, </span>indicating that the prohibition relates only to animals?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>The Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">Paphunya know the reason for this matter, and who </span>are these Sages? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</span> who resided in Paphunya. The reason is that the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“You shall not perform any labor, neither you, your son, your daughter, your slave, your maidservant, your ox, your donkey, any of your animals, or the stranger residing within your city gates, <span class="gemarra-regular">that your manservant and your maidservant may rest as well as you” </span>(Deuteronomy 5:14), as if to say: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have equated </span>people with animals only <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning resting </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not with regard to another matter.</span>
Having discussed some differences between the two versions of the Ten Commandments, the Gemara now discuses a related matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina ben Agil asked Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">For what reason is </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good not stated in the first </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">in the latter </span>version of the Ten <span class="gemarra-regular">Commandments, </span>

Daf 55a

in the context of the mitzva to honor one’s parents, the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good is stated there: </span>“In order that it shall be good for you” (Deuteronomy 5:16)? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Before you ask me why </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good is stated, ask me if </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">stated there or not, since</span> I am not sufficiently proficient in my knowledge of the biblical verses to remember the precise wording, and <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not know</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good is stated there or not. Go to Rabbi Tanḥum bar Ḥanilai, who was </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found at </span>the academy of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, who was an expert in </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Perhaps he heard something from him on this matter and can answer your question.
Rabbi Ḥanina ben Agil <span class="gemarra-regular">went to him </span>and asked him. Rabbi Tanḥum <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I did not hear </span>anything on this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">himself. But this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel bar Naḥum, the brother of the mother of Rav Aḥa, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said to me, and some say</span> it was <span class="gemarra-regular">the father of the mother of Rav Aḥai, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: </span>It does not mention the word good in the first tablets, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately </span>destined <span class="gemarra-regular">to be broken </span>after the Jews made the Golden Calf.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it had mentioned the term good, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they were ultimately </span>destined <span class="gemarra-regular">to break, what of it? Rav Ashi said: </span>If this term had been mentioned in the first tablets, all <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>would have, <span class="gemarra-regular">God forbid, ceased from Israel </span>once they were broken. Therefore, only the second version, which was written after the breaking of the tablets, contains the word good, so that there would always be good for the Jewish people.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one sees</span> the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">tet</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his dream, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a good sign for him. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? If we say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">good [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is written </span>in the Torah and begins with the letter <span class="it-text">tet</span>, then one could <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead that it is an allusion to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And I will sweep it with the broom [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vetetetiha</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">bemate’ateh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of destruction” </span>(Isaiah 14:23), which also contains the letter <span class="it-text">tet</span> several times but is referring to punishment. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We mean </span>that when someone sees <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tet</span> in his dream, it is a good sign, but this latter verse contains several.
The Gemara asks: This latter statement is problematic, as even according to this explanation, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that a single letter <span class="it-text">tet</span> alludes to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Her filthiness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumatah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is in her skirts” </span>(Lamentations 1:9), which begins with the letter <span class="it-text">tet</span>. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We mean </span>that when one sees the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">tet</span> together with the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">bet</span> in his dream, it is a good sign for him, as the word <span class="it-text">tov</span> is written with both. The Gemara asks further: According to this, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that it alludes to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Her gates are sunk [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tave’u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] into the ground” </span>(Lamentations 2:9), which begins with the letter <span class="it-text">tet</span> followed by the letter <span class="it-text">bet</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is not merely because it is the first letter of the word good [<span class="it-text">tov</span>] that it is considered a good omen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the Torah initially introduces </span>the letter <span class="it-text">tet</span> in a context <span class="gemarra-regular">of good, </span>with the word good [<span class="it-text">tov</span>] itself, it is a good omen. <span class="gemarra-regular">As from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">bereshit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the first word in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And God saw that the light </span>was good [<span class="it-text">tov</span>]” (Genesis 1:4), the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">tet</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not written </span>anywhere.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one sees a eulogy [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hesped</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his dream, </span>it is an allusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">in Heaven they had pity [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥasu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] on him and saved him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eda’uhu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>from actually being eulogized. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This statement </span>applies specifically when he actually saw the word: Eulogy [<span class="it-text">hesped</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">in writing.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, undomesticated animals and birds </span>are subject to the same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>domesticated animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: Here Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>a ruling from the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> that illustrates the statement that birds and undomesticated animals are also subject to the prohibition of diverse kinds: <span class="gemarra-regular">A cock, a peacock [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tavvas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and a pheasant [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ufasyonei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds with </span>respect to <span class="gemarra-regular">each other, </span>since this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies to birds as well.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious; </span>what novelty is stated here? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥaviva said: </span>The novelty here is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">reared together.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lest you say: </span>Since they are reared together, they <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>essentially <span class="gemarra-regular">one species,</span> and not considered diverse kinds. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that they are actually separate species, and the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of diverse kinds do apply to them.
Following the discussion of the prohibition of diverse kinds as it relates to birds, <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The domestic <span class="gemarra-regular">goose and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wild goose </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds </span>with respect <span class="gemarra-regular">to each other</span> and are not one species. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav Ḥanan objects to this: What is the reason? If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the beak o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this one </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">long and the beak of that one </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">short, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if that is so, </span>then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Persian camel and an Arabian camel, where the neck of this one </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">thick and the neck of that one </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">thin, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">should indeed be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds </span>with respect <span class="gemarra-regular">to one another. </span>Clearly, though, the camels are in fact two variants of a single species.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye says: </span>That is not the reason, but rather another difference exists between the domestic goose and the wild goose, concerning the male: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>type, i.e., the wild goose, <span class="gemarra-regular">its testicles </span>are visible <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outside, and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, i.e., the domestic goose, <span class="gemarra-regular">its testicles are inside. Rav Pappa said </span>that another difference exists between them, concerning the female: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, i.e., the wild goose, <span class="gemarra-regular">releases </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one egg in </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">ovary </span>and later releases another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, i.e., the domestic goose, <span class="gemarra-regular">releases several eggs </span>at once <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">ovary. </span>Consequently, they are not considered to be the same species.
In connection with the prohibition of diverse kinds, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who crossbreeds two species </span>of creatures <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>live <span class="gemarra-regular">in the sea</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is flogged </span>for transgressing the prohibition of crossbreeding diverse kinds. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason, </span>i.e., where is there an allusion to this in the Torah? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava said in the name of Ulla: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived </span>from a verbal analogy between the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“According to its species [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leminehu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 1:21), referring to animals living <span class="gemarra-regular">on dry land, </span>and the same term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“According to its species [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leminehu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 1:25), referring to sea creatures. In the same way that the former may not be crossbred, similarly, the latter may not be crossbred.
The Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">Raḥava raises</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a dilemma: </span>With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who drives </span>a wagon on the seashore <span class="gemarra-regular">with a goat and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shibbuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a certain species of fish, together, pulled by the goat on land and the fish at sea, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Has he violated the prohibition against performing labor with diverse kinds, in the same way that one does when plowing with an ox and a donkey together, or not? The two sides of the question are as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since the goat does not descend into the sea and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shibbuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not ascend onto the land, </span>they are not working together at all, and so he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not done </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anything </span>forbidden? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">now driving </span>the wagon with both of them, he thereby transgresses the prohibition?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina objects to this: But if that is so </span>that one is liable, then if a person <span class="gemarra-regular">joined wheat and barley </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">in his hand and sowed the wheat in Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">and the barley outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael, where the prohibition of diverse kinds does not apply to seeds, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable. </span>Clearly, however, they are two distinct regions, and the seeds are not considered to be mixed together.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response to this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can</span> these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of planting diverse kinds of seeds, it is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael that is <span class="gemarra-regular">the location</span> subject to this <span class="gemarra-regular">obligation, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael is <span class="gemarra-regular">not a location </span>subject to this <span class="gemarra-regular">obligation. Here, </span>by contrast, in the case of the person driving a wagon, both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>location, i.e., the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>location, i.e., the sea, are <span class="gemarra-regular">locations </span>subject to this <span class="gemarra-regular">obligation. </span>Consequently, if one works together two different species either on the land or in the sea, he is liable. Therefore, the question is a valid one.


Daf 55b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who brough</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> his flock of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep into the pen and locked </span>the door <span class="gemarra-regular">before it </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>despite this sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage </span>in another person’s field by eating produce or trampling it, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since he safeguarded the animals appropriately. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not lock </span>the door <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the sheep in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate, and </span>sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since his negligence led to the damage.
If the owner locked the door appropriately but the wall of the pen <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached at night</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or bandits breached it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>sheep subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage </span>by eating or trampling, the owner of the sheep is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from liability. If the <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">out </span>of the pen and the animals subsequently caused damage, the <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the sun, </span>causing it to suffer, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he conveyed it to a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, </span>who are not able to safeguard it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>because he was negligent.
If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to a shepherd </span>to care for it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the shepherd enters in his place </span>and is responsible for the damage.
If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into a garden and derives benefit </span>from produce there, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">derives</span> and not for other damage caused. If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">descended </span>into the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">in its usual manner and caused damage </span>there, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged. How does </span>the court appraise the value of the damage when the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged? </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>a large piece of land with <span class="gemarra-regular">an area required for </span>sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in that field, </span>including the garden bed in which the damage took place. This appraisal includes <span class="gemarra-regular">how much it was worth </span>before the animal damaged it <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much is it worth </span>now, and the owner must pay the difference. The court appraises not only the garden bed that was eaten or trampled, rather the depreciation in value of the bed as part of the surrounding area. This results in a smaller payment, as the damage appears less significant in the context of a larger area.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>This principle of appraisal applies only in a case where the animal ate unripe produce; but if <span class="gemarra-regular">it ate ripe produce,</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ripe produce. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it ate <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of produce, he pays for <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it ate <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he pays for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies the definition of locking the door in a manner that is appropriate. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: What is </span>considered locking in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate, and what is </span>considered locking in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriate? </span>If one locked the <span class="gemarra-regular">door </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is able to withstand a typical wind </span>without collapsing or opening, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate, </span>whereas if he locked the door such <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is unable to withstand a typical wind, this is </span>considered a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not appropriate.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Mani bar Patish said: Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>with regard to animals that are <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned that it is sufficient </span>for the owner to provide only <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced safeguarding? </span>Since the mishna deals with damage categorized as Eating or Trampling, for which all animals are considered forewarned, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>must be in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned </span>in a mishna (45b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">tied it with rein</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">or locked </span>the gate <span class="gemarra-regular">before it </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate, but </span>nevertheless the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, whether </span>the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>because this is not considered sufficient precaution to prevent damage; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if he safeguarded it appropriately, since the Torah does not limit the required safeguarding for an innocuous animal. But if the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment of damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the verse describing the liability for damage caused by a forewarned animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the owner has not secured it” </span>(Exodus 21:36), <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>ox that was tied with reins or behind a locked gate <span class="gemarra-regular">was secured. Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>A forewarned ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding </span>at all <span class="gemarra-regular">other than </span>slaughtering it with <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife. </span>According to this mishna, only Rabbi Yehuda maintains that reduced safeguarding is sufficient to render exempt from liability the owner of an ox that is forewarned.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>who holds that the owner of a forewarned ox is liable even if he provides only reduced safeguarding. Although animals are considered forewarned with regard to Eating and Trampling, one cannot apply to them a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated with regard to an animal that is forewarned with regard to Goring. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is different </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling since the Torah limited </span>the required standard of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for them. As </span>the <span class="it-text">amora</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says, and some say it was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four matters </span>for which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah limited their </span>required standard of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding, and these are: Pit, and Fire, Eating, and Trampling.</span>
Where does the Torah limit the required standard of safeguarding with regard to the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pit? As it is written: “If a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit and not cover it, </span>and an ox or a donkey fall therein, the owner of the pit shall pay” (Exodus 21:33). One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he covered it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability, even though it is possible that the pit would become uncovered in the future.
Where does the Torah limit the required standard of safeguarding with regard to the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Fire? As it is written: “The one who kindled the fire shall pay compensation” </span>(Exodus 22:5), which is interpreted to mean that one is exempt from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he acts </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to actively <span class="gemarra-regular">kindling </span>the fire in another’s property by being negligent.
Where does the Torah limit the required standard of safeguarding with regard to the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating? As it is written: </span>“If a man causes a field or vineyard to be eaten, and he set his animal loose, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it feed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvi’er</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in the field of another” </span>(Exodus 22:4). This indicates that the owner does not bear liability <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he acts </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to causing his animal to <span class="gemarra-regular">feed </span>there, by being negligent.
Where does the Torah limit the required standard of safeguarding with regard to the category of <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling? As it is written: </span>“If a man causes a field or vineyard to be eaten, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he set </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">loose [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veshilaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],</span> and it feed in the field of another” (Exodus 22:4). This indicates that the owner is not liable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he acts </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">setting </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">loose.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to the term <span class="gemarra-italic">veshilaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: This </span>is referring to damage by <span class="gemarra-regular">Trampling, and similarly, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “That send forth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meshaleḥei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the feet of the ox and the donkey” </span>(Isaiah 32:20). With regard to the term <span class="gemarra-italic">uvi’er</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: This </span>is referring to damage by <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating, and similarly, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “As one consumes with the tooth, until it be all gone” </span>(I Kings 14:10).
Evidently, <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>for the owner’s liability is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that he acted </span>in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>setting the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">loose </span>or causing it <span class="gemarra-regular">to feed. </span>One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not act </span>in such a manner, even if he provided only reduced safeguarding, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>The wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> precise, as it taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> specifically with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep. </span>This raises the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since we have been dealing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>cases involving <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>in all the previous <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span>, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>this mishna also <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox. What is different </span>in this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that it teaches </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep? Is it not because the Torah limited </span>its requirements specifically with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the safeguarding </span>against damage that is more likely to be caused by sheep, i.e., caused by Eating and Trampling, since sheep are unlikely to gore? If so, the wording of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who holds that a reduced level of supervision is sufficient only with regard to Eating and Trampling, but not Goring.
The Gemara rejects this: One can <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>necessarily derive from the wording of the mishna that it is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir. Perhaps the mishna specifically uses the case of sheep to teach the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>if it would have used an example of an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>one might have thought that it also includes damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">Goring, </span>about which it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the Torah that reduced supervision is sufficient. Therefore, the mishna specifically uses the example of sheep, to indicate damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">which it is written </span>that reduced supervision is sufficient. And <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches us that </span>only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling, for </span>which animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned </span>from the outset, is reduced supervision sufficient according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. The Gemara concludes that this is a valid reading of the mishna and one may <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>it that the mishna may even be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua said: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four matters </span>in which one <span class="gemarra-regular">who commits </span>an offense concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and it would be proper for him to pay compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who breaches a fenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that stood <span class="gemarra-regular">before another’s animal, </span>thereby allowing the animal to escape; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who bends another’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> standing </span>grain <span class="gemarra-regular">before a fire </span>so that it catches fire; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who hires false witnesses to testify; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and one who knows testimony </span>in support <span class="gemarra-regular">of another but does not testify on his behalf.</span>
The Gemara clarifies each of the cases listed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says: </span>With regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who breaches a fence </span>that stood <span class="gemarra-regular">before another’s animal, what are the circumstances? If we say </span>it is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of a stable wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that would not have fallen by itself, the one who breached it <span class="gemarra-regular">should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also be liable according to human laws, </span>at least for the damage caused to the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>here

Daf 56a

the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of an unstable wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that was about to fall and break in any event, and so his action did not actually cause any loss to the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says: </span>With regard to the case mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who bends another’s standing </span>grain <span class="gemarra-regular">before a fire, what are the circumstances? If we say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fire would <span class="gemarra-regular">reach </span>the bent grain <span class="gemarra-regular">in a typical wind, let him </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">be liable </span>for the damage according to <span class="gemarra-regular">human laws. Rather, </span>it must be a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fire could <span class="gemarra-regular">reach </span>the bent grain only <span class="gemarra-regular">in an atypical wind. </span>Therefore, he is exempt according to human laws, and, since the grain was destroyed due to his action, he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ashi </span>offered an alternative explanation and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>item; in other words, this person did not bend the grain toward the fire but bent it over another item in order to conceal it. One is not liable to pay restitution for concealed items damaged by fire. Therefore, when this person bent the grain over an item, he caused indirect damage to the owner of that item <span class="gemarra-regular">because he made it into a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concealed </span>item that was subsequently damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">fire, </span>and the owner cannot reclaim his loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says: </span>With regard to the case mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who hires false witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what are the circumstances? If we say </span>that he hired them <span class="gemarra-regular">for his own </span>benefit, in order to extract payment from another, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to reimburse </span>that person with <span class="gemarra-regular">money,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he is liable according to human laws </span>for receiving money under false circumstances. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case is one where he hired false witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the benefit of <span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In such a case the injured party cannot sue the other litigant, since the latter did not hire the witnesses, nor can he sue the person who hired them, since that person received no personal benefit.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who knows testimony in support of anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but does not testify on his behalf </span>is exempt from liability according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing? If we say </span>that the case <span class="gemarra-regular">involves two </span>people who could testify, and their evidence would render the other party liable to pay, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that each of them is liable according to the laws of Heaven; he has committed a transgression <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law: “If he does not utter it, then he shall bear his iniquity” </span>(Leviticus 5:1).
