Therefore, it is unnecessary for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to mention this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">concerns a single </span>witness, whose testimony is not sufficient to render another liable, and to which the transgression of Torah law consequently does not apply. Nevertheless, a litigant can be forced to take an oath based on the testimony of a single witness, and refusal to take this oath would obligate the litigant to pay. Therefore, the witness has caused an indirect loss and is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is there nothing else, </span>i.e., is there no other case in which one is exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven? <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>such a case. And before citing several cases that are not written in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> the Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who performs; with poison; and an agent; another; is broken. </span>The Gemara returns to the first case: One <span class="gemarra-regular">who performs labor with water of purification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which were meant to be used to purify one rendered ritually impure by a corpse, thereby rendering the water unfit for use, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>who performs labor <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>red <span class="gemarra-regular">heifer of purification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> invalidating the animal for use as an element of the purification ritual, is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws, </span>since the damage he caused is not evident, <span class="gemarra-regular">but liable according to the laws of Heaven, </span>as he caused a financial loss.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>the following <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who places poiso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before another’s animal,</span> and the animal eats it and dies, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws, </span>since the animal caused its own death, <span class="gemarra-regular">but liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sends </span>an exposed <span class="gemarra-regular">flame in the hand of a deaf-mute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an imbecile, or a minor, </span>and the fire spreads, causing damage; he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who frightens anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> without touching him, but causes him injury; he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>the case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">whose jug broke in the public domain and he did not remove </span>the broken pieces, or one <span class="gemarra-regular">whose camel fell and he did not stand it up </span>again. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir deems </span>the owner of jug or of the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the damage thereby caused to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Since there are so many other cases, why did Rabbi Yehoshua claim in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that there are only four cases when one is exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, there are, in any event, many </span>other cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>Rabbi Yehoshua held that it <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary for him </span>to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>four cases. The reason he stated them is <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that in these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">one should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in these cases one is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
The Gemara explains why one might have thought that there is no liability at all for each case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Rabbi Yehoshua taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who breaches a fence </span>that stood <span class="gemarra-regular">before another’s animal, </span>thereby allowing the animal to escape, is liable according to the laws of Heaven, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: Since </span>the fence <span class="gemarra-regular">is about to collapse </span>even without this person’s intervention, <span class="gemarra-regular">what did </span>he really <span class="gemarra-regular">do? </span>Based on that logic, one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in such a case he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
Rabbi Yehoshua taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who bends another’s standing </span>grain is liable according to the laws of Heaven, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: Let </span>the one who bent the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did I know that an atypical wind would come </span>and cause the fire to spread? Based on that logic, one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in such a case he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rav Ashi, who said </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>with regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>item, Rabbi Yehoshua mentioned liability according to the laws of Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that the one who concealed the item could say: <span class="gemarra-regular">I covered it for you</span> in order to protect it from the fire. Based on that logic, one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in such a case he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehoshua taught that there is liability <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who hires false witnesses, lest you say: Let </span>the one who hired them <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>If the witnesses hear <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of the teacher, </span>i.e., God, Who prohibited giving false testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the statement of the student, </span>i.e., the one who hired them, <span class="gemarra-regular">to whose statement </span>should they <span class="gemarra-regular">listen? </span>Although the one who hired them encouraged these witnesses to sin, ultimately it was they who transgressed by not adhering to the instructions of God. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>based on this logic one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in such a case he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
Finally, Rabbi Yehoshua taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who knows testimony </span>in support <span class="gemarra-regular">of another </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but does not testify on his behalf </span>is liable according to the laws of Heaven, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that the witness could claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who says that had I come forward </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">testified on behalf of </span>one litigant, the other litigant <span class="gemarra-regular">would admit </span>liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he would have </span>chosen to <span class="gemarra-regular">take a false oath </span>and absolve himself. Based on that logic one might have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not be liable even according to the laws of Heaven. </span>Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in such a case he is liable according to the laws of Heaven.
§ The mishna teaches: If the pen <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached at night, or bandits breached it, </span>and sheep subsequently went out and caused damage, the owner of the sheep is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: And this </span>first instance of a pen that was breached is referring specifically to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tunneled </span>under the wall of the pen and by doing so caused the wall to collapse. In that case, the owner is completely blameless and therefore exempt from liability for any damage that ensues.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">did not tunnel </span>under the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would the owner be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? What are the circumstances? If we say </span>that the pen had <span class="gemarra-regular">a stable wall, </span>then even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">did not tunnel, why </span>is the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? What should he have done? </span>Clearly, he cannot be held liable for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the pen had <span class="gemarra-regular">an unstable wall. </span>The Gemara asks: Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tunneled </span>under the wall and knocked it down, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The damage in this case is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who said </span>that in any case of damage that is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately by accident, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability, since the ultimate cause of the damage was not his fault. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that in any case of damage that is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as even without the accident his negligence could have caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concerns a stable wall, and even </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">did not tunnel </span>under the wall the owner is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba was stated, it was stated with regard to the latter clause </span>of the mishna that says: If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the su</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or conveyed it to a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, and </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">went out and caused damage, </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Concerning this <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba stated: And </span>the owner is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tunneled </span>its way out under the wall of the pen.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>for the mishna to mention the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the animal did not tunnel </span>its way out. In that case the owner is clearly liable, since <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire </span>incident occurred due to his <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence</span> of leaving the animal in the sun, thereby causing it distress and leading it to attempt escape by any possible means. <span class="gemarra-regular">But even if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">tunneled </span>its way out, the owner is liable, and this is the novelty in this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>a case of damage that is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident, </span>because animals do not typically tunnel their way out of a pen, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>it is considered as though <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire </span>damage resulted from the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the owner is liable? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one who suffered the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the sheep: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should have known that since you left it in the sun, it would utilize any means [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tatzdeka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> available for it to use and </span>it would <span class="gemarra-regular">escape, </span>so you are ultimately responsible for the damage.
§ The mishna teaches: If the <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">out, the bandits are liable. </span>

Daf 56b

The Gemara questions the need for this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as <span class="gemarra-regular">once they removed </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">in their custody for all purposes, </span>including responsibility for any ensuing damage.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they stood before </span>the animal and encouraged it to leave the enclosure but did not lead it out directly. This case is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the case in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stands another’s anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> near </span>a third <span class="gemarra-regular">person’s standing </span>grain, and the animal eats the grain, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">stands </span>the animal there, isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he is liable? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">stood before the animal </span>and encouraged it to go toward the grain without leading it, and he is nevertheless liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: You told us </span>when explaining the statement of Rav Mattana in the name of Rav that it is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he hit </span>the animal with a stick, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly, the mishna can <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be explained as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits hit i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with a stick and did not lead it.
§ The mishna teaches that if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to a shepherd </span>to care for it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the shepherd enters </span>in his place and is responsible for all damage. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in clarification: The shepherd enters <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of whom? If we say </span>that the shepherd is <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of the owner of the animal, </span>didn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learn on one occasion </span>in a mishna (44b): If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee, or to a borrower, to a paid bailee, or to a renter, they all enter </span>into the responsibilities and liabilities <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of the owner. </span>What novelty is there in stating that the responsibility now lies with the shepherd to whom the owner conveyed the animal? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> it means that the shepherd enters <span class="gemarra-regular">in place of a bailee </span>to whom the owner conveyed the animal, who is no longer liable once he conveys the animal to a shepherd.
The Gemara asks: If so, this mishna indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first bailee exempts himself completely </span>by conveying the sheep to a shepherd, the second bailee, and he bears no further responsibility. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say that </span>mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation of </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, as Rava says: A bailee who conveyed </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee </span>nevertheless remains <span class="gemarra-regular">liable?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the mishna mean when it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">He conveyed it to a shepherd? </span>It is referring to a shepherd who conveyed the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the shepherd’s <span class="gemarra-regular">assistant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is </span>the typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a shepherd to convey </span>animals in his charge <span class="gemarra-regular">to his assistant. </span>Therefore, anyone who gives his animal to a shepherd understands that the shepherd’s assistant may also care for the animal, and it is not a violation of the terms of his assignment for the shepherd to convey it to his assistant. Consequently, this mishna does not refute Rava’s opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>the same answer in a similar manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the case using the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">He conveyed it to a shepherd, and does not teach </span>it using the less specific expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">He conveyed it to another, conclude from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>it means by: <span class="gemarra-regular">He conveyed it to a shepherd, </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the shepherd conveyed it to his assistant, as it is the </span>typical <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of a shepherd to convey </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to his assistant. But </span>if the shepherd conveyed it <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>to care for it in his place, the mishna does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>rule that the other person enters in his place.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the wording of the mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">supports Rava’s </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava says: A bailee who conveyed </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">baile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> remains <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in rejection of that suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>one cannot infer from the wording of the mishna that it is referring specifically to a shepherd conveying the animal to his assistant, since <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps it teaches the matter in the manner in which it </span>typically occurs, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the same is true </span>even if the shepherd conveyed the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to another. </span>Therefore, no support can be brought from here for Rava’s opinion.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that there is a dispute between <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> concerning the following issue: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is safeguarding a lost item</span> that he has not yet returned, what level of responsibility does he bear? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>He is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like an unpaid bailee, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>He is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee.</span>
Their respective opinions are explained: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said </span>that he is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like an unpaid bailee </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">what benefit comes to him </span>through safeguarding it? Therefore, he is just like any unpaid bailee. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said </span>that he is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on account of the benefit that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not required to giv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a poor person </span>while looking after the lost item, since one who is engaged in one mitzva is exempt from performing another. Consequently, since there is some benefit involved in looking after the lost item, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee.</span>
This is one interpretation, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who explain like this: Rav Yosef said </span>that he is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Once the Merciful One obligates him against his will </span>to look after lost items, the Torah presumably imposes the high standard of safeguarding on him. Therefore, he is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee.</span>
The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> and difficulties to be discussed: <span class="gemarra-regular">He returned it, always, returned, Ḥiyya, you say, breaks, payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>from that which is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: 

Daf 57a

If one found a lost item and <span class="gemarra-regular">he returned it to a place where </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will see it, he is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">responsible to deal with it. </span>If the item <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen or lost, </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate for the loss.
Rav Yosef states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>meant <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">Was stolen or lost? </span>Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>mean that it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen from </span>the finder’s <span class="gemarra-regular">house or lost from his house </span>before he returned it? Since he is liable for theft or loss, it appears that he has the same status as a paid bailee.
Rabba rejects this challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it means that it was stolen or lost <span class="gemarra-regular">from the place where </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it, </span>in which case even an unpaid bailee is liable on the grounds of negligence.
Rav Yosef challenges Rabba’s response: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">responsible to deal with it, </span>indicating that failing to deal with it is not negligence, and the finder has no further responsibility for it.
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With what are we dealing here, </span>at the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where it teaches that the finder is liable? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he returned it at midday, </span>which is a time when the owner of the lost item is not typically present. Therefore, the finder has not returned the item properly, and if it is then stolen or lost, he bears responsibility even if he is an unpaid bailee.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching two </span>separate <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is teaching: </span>If the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it in the morning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when people are typically present, <span class="gemarra-regular">to a place where </span>the owner of the lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">will see it, and </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">typically enters and exits and </span>it is likely that <span class="gemarra-regular">he will see it, </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">responsible to deal with it, </span>nor does he bear responsibility if it is then stolen or lost. By contrast, if the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it at midday </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a place where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will see it, since </span>it is a time when the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does not typically enter and exit and will not see it, if it is </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen or lost </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>for the loss.
Rav Yosef again <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rabba from that which is taught in the continuation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The finder of the lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">always</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bears responsibility </span>if the item is stolen or lost <span class="gemarra-regular">until he returns it to </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property. What </span>does the word <span class="gemarra-regular">always </span>add? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not </span>teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the lost item was stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the finder’s <span class="gemarra-regular">house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is liable? If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>this that one who finds a lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee.</span>
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yosef in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">I concede to you in </span>a case of one looking after lost <span class="gemarra-regular">animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that he is liable if they are stolen or lost. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that since </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">taken </span>to the habit of <span class="gemarra-regular">walking ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of their usual path and not behaving in their typical manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">they require extra safeguarding,</span> corresponding to that required of a paid bailee. But with regard to other items that are lost, those that do not move by themselves, the finder bears no greater responsibility to secure them than does an unpaid bailee.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef: </span>The verse states in the context of returning lost items: “Return them” (Deuteronomy 22:1), repeating the verb “<span class="it-text">hashev</span> <span class="it-text">teshivem</span>.” The Sages expounded as follows: From the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hashev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that one may return the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to the house </span>of the owner of the lost article. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do I derive that even if one returns it <span class="gemarra-regular">to his garden or to his ruin, </span>i.e., an unused structure on his property, he has discharged his obligation and is no longer responsible for the item that he found? For this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Teshivem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>repeating the verb for emphasis, to teach that he fulfills the mitzva by returning the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to any place </span>belonging to the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">To his garden or to his ruin? If we say </span>that the finder returned the lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>of the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">that is secured, </span>i.e., properly enclosed, <span class="gemarra-regular">or to his ruin that is secured, </span>it would be unnecessary to state this, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">his house, </span>since these spaces are secured in the same way as his house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that it means that he returned them <span class="gemarra-regular">to his garden that is not secured</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to his ruin that is not secured, </span>and nevertheless, the finder is no longer liable for subsequent damage or theft of the found item. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that a finder <span class="gemarra-regular">is like an unpaid bailee </span>in terms of his liabilities, and this reduced level of safeguarding when returning the item is sufficient.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Actually, </span>one can explain that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the finder placed it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">garden that is secured, or his ruin that is secured; and </span>with regard to that which poses a <span class="gemarra-regular">difficulty to you, </span>that this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">his house, </span>there is nevertheless a novelty in this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not require the owner’s knowledge </span>that the article has been returned, and this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Elazar says: All </span>those who are obligated to return items to their owners, e.g., a bailee or a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">require </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner’s knowledg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that they are returning it <span class="gemarra-regular">except </span>for one fulfilling the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning a lost item. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the Torah included many </span>permitted ways of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning </span>lost items by employing the double expression “<span class="it-text">hashev</span> <span class="it-text">teshivem</span>,” which serves to permit the return of the lost item without the knowledge of the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: And you, do you not hold that one safeguarding a lost ite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is like an unpaid bailee? But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to one who finds <span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item </span>but falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the item from him and takes an oath to that effect, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a double payment, </span>i.e., twice the value of the item. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that the finder of a lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered to have the same status as <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> paid bailee, why </span>in such a case must he <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a double payment? He </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">be required to pay </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal, </span>since a paid bailee is liable in any event if the article is stolen or lost, and he did not stand to benefit from the claim that the item was stolen.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With what are we dealing here? </span>It is with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the finder took a false oath <span class="gemarra-regular">stating the claim </span>that the deposit was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and in such a case even a paid bailee is exempt. Consequently, his claim would have absolved him from liability, and if the item is subsequently found in his possession, he is liable to pay double for his false claim that it was stolen.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit </span>has the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>and not of a thief, so according to this explanation, why did Rabbi Yoḥanan state that it was stolen by a thief?
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The reason that only a thief pays the double payment and not a robber is that a thief denigrates God by exhibiting fear of people by stealing surreptitiously while not exhibiting fear of Heaven. This is in contrast to a robber, who robs openly. Accordingly, the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that I say that an armed bandit is </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">since he hides from people </span>rather than stealing openly. Although he in fact does steal openly, since he does so by employing a weapon he also exhibits fear of people, and is akin to a thief. Therefore, armed bandits are liable to pay a double payment as is a thief, and a claim that the deposit was seized by armed bandits is considered to be the same as a claim that it was stolen by thieves. Consequently, since a paid bailee is absolved by means of such a claim, if it is determined that his claim was false he must pay double.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rav Yosef from that which is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: 

Daf 57b

<span class="gemarra-regular">No, if you sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an unpaid bailee, who pays a double payment, shall you </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> that this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a paid bailee, who does not pay a double payment?</span>
Abaye states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit is </span>considered like <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, it turns out </span>that there is a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a paid bailee pays a double payment, </span>and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">when he states the claim that </span>the deposit was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit.</span>
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: No, if you say </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an unpaid bailee, who pays a double payment for any clai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> that he makes concerning the theft of the item if he is subsequently found to be lying, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall you </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a paid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who pays a double payment </span>for a false claim <span class="gemarra-regular">only when he states the claim that </span>the deposit was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit.</span>
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>the opinion of Rav Yosef from that which is taught in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Torah states with regard to a case where one borrows an object or an animal from another: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it breaks or dies, </span>he shall pay restitution [<span class="it-text">shalem</span> <span class="it-text">yeshalem</span>]” (Exodus 22:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that the borrower is liable in a case where the object or animal <span class="gemarra-regular">breaks or dies; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>do I derive that he is also liable if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen or lost? You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>the following <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as a paid bailee, whom </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered exempt </span>in a case where the item <span class="gemarra-regular">breaks or dies, </span>is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft or loss, </span>then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a borrower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even if the item <span class="gemarra-regular">breaks or dies, is not it logical that he is liable for theft or loss? And this is an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has no refutation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit </span>is considered like <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is this an argument that has <span class="gemarra-regular">no refutation? It can be refuted </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about a paid bailee? </span>He is notable in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double </span><span class="gemarra-regular">payment if he states the claim that </span>the deposit was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit, </span>whereas a borrower does not pay double in such a case, but only the principal amount.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that the requirement of a borrower to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal without </span>having the option to exempt himself by <span class="gemarra-regular">taking an oath is stricter than </span>the requirement of a paid bailee to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment </span>when claiming that it was stolen by an armed bandit, as this obligation is in effect only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he took <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath. </span>Therefore, this doubled payment pertaining to a paid bailee cannot be used as a refutation of the <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>Rav Yosef’s opinion: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who rents a cow from another and it is stolen, and this </span>renter <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I will pay </span>for it <span class="gemarra-regular">and I am not taking an oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> that the cow was stolen, since I do not wish to take an oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward the thief is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> found, </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the double payment to the renter </span>and not to the owner.
The Gemara notes: The Sages who sought to use that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to support Rav Yosef’s opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says: A renter is like a paid bailee </span>and is liable for theft or loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">but from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it teaches: And he said: I will pay </span>for it <span class="gemarra-regular">and I am not taking an oath </span>that the cow was stolen, one can learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that if </span>the renter <span class="gemarra-regular">wants, he can exempt himself</span> from payment <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span>Is it not a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the renter <span class="gemarra-regular">states a claim </span>that the item was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit, </span>in which case, as a paid bailee, he does not bear liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>despite this, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward the thief was found, </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the double payment to the renter. Conclude from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is considered like <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says</span> in rejection of this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee? Perhaps </span>this <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like an unpaid bailee, </span>and on account of that he is absolved of responsibility even if he claimed it was a regular theft.
Alternatively, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to an unarmed bandit and is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh, who reversed </span>the opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">and teaches </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">How does a renter pay? Rabbi Meir says </span>he has the same liability <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a paid bailee, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>he has the same liability <span class="gemarra-regular">as an unpaid bailee. </span>Therefore, even if this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, it does not provide support for Rav Yosef’s opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>Even without reversing the opinions, it is possible to explain that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not provide support for Rav Yosef’s opinion by saying as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case where the renter <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim that </span>the deposit was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit, </span>and so he could have absolved himself by taking an oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">it is found that it was </span>stolen by <span class="gemarra-regular">an unarmed bandit. </span>On account of this, the bandit pays the double payment to the renter. No conclusive proof is brought as to whether one who found a lost item has the status of a paid or unpaid bailee.
§ The mishna teaches: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into a garden and derives benefit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">derives.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the vegetables softened the impact of <span class="gemarra-regular">strikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the ground, and the owner pays for this benefit of the animal being saved from injury.
The Gemara comments: This statement of Rav indicates that the owner pays only for what occurred while the animal landed, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>the animal then <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from the garden, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derives. Shall we say that Rav </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning? As Rav says </span>that in a case where one placed his produce in the courtyard of another without permission, and an animal belonging to the owner of the courtyard ate the produce and was sickened thereby, the owner of the produce is not liable, as he can claim: The animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>it. Similarly, here the owner of the animal can say: This animal fell through no fault of mine, and so it is not my fault that it ate.
The Sages of the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">say:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span>One could <span class="gemarra-regular">say that Rav said there </span>that the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten </span>the produce. This claim is relevant <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">itself was injured </span>by eating another’s produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">because the owner of the produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can say: I will not pay, </span>because the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have eaten. </span>This is a claim to exempt the owner of the produce from paying the owner of the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Did </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage to another’s </span>produce, the owner can <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">from paying </span>the owner of the produce by stating this claim?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>

Daf 58a

one cannot make such an inference from Rav’s statement. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>utilizing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary,</span> and this is how to understand his statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to state that if the animal fell into the garden and <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>from its produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">derives. But </span>if the produce softened the blow of <span class="gemarra-regular">striking</span> the ground and thereby the animal avoided injury, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the owner of the animal should not pay, on the grounds that the owner of the garden may be viewed, analogously, to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">repels a lio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from another’s property. </span>In such a case, although the latter benefited from his action, he is not obligated to pay for it. Similarly in this case, one might think that the owner of the animal does <span class="gemarra-regular">not pay even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">derived. </span>For this reason Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the owner of the animal must pay for this benefit as well.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is indeed </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and the owner of the animal should be exempt for paying for the benefit of his animal not being injured?
The Gemara answers: One who <span class="gemarra-regular">repels a lion from another’s property </span>does so <span class="gemarra-regular">with intent, </span>knowing that he would be ineligible for payment. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner of the garden did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">with intent </span>and would have preferred for the incident not to have happened. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>one could say that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">repels a lion from another’s property does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">have any loss </span>himself. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner of the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">has a loss, </span>in that his produce is damaged.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How did </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In which case does this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> apply? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says: It slipped on its </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">urine. Rava says: Another </span>animal belonging to the same owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed it, </span>causing it to fall there.
The Gemara explains: Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says that </span>the mishna is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed it, </span>in which case the owner pays only for the benefit that the animal derived and is exempt from paying for the damage caused, holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would apply in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it slipped on its urine, </span>which is beyond the owner’s control. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>Rav Kahana, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">slipped on its urine, </span>holds that if, <span class="gemarra-regular">however, another </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed it, </span>this indicates that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">was negligent </span>and should have prevented this happening. Therefore, in such a case, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged, since </span>the owner of the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should have led </span>your animals <span class="gemarra-regular">across one by one, </span>so that they would not be able to push each other.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says: They taught only </span>that the owner pays for the benefit that it derives <span class="gemarra-regular">in the same garden bed </span>into which it fell, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it went <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">garden bed to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">garden be</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and ate from that one, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even </span>if the animal goes <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">garden bed to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">garden be</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and eats, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even </span>if the animal continues going from one bed to another and eating for <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire day,</span> the owner pays only for the benefit that the animal derived and not for what it damaged, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless it leaves </span>the garden entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">and returns with </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said, </span>explaining Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not say </span>this means: <span class="gemarra-regular">Unless </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves with </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge and returns with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge; rather, once it leaves </span>the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span> the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if it returned without </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge, </span>the owner is liable to pay for what it damaged. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of the garden can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to</span> the owner of the animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>that the garden is there with food to eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">every time it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> strays it will run to there.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">descended </span>into the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">in its usual manner and caused damage </span>there, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged. Rabbi Yirmeya asks: </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">descended in its usual manner and </span>gave birth to a calf there and <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">with amniotic fluid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does the owner of the animal have to pay for this damage?
The Gemara clarifies Rabbi Yirmeya’s question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not raise the dilemma in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>in a case of damage that is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident, </span>since in this case the owner was negligent in allowing the animal to enter another person’s courtyard, although the actual causing of the damage was ultimately by accident. <span class="gemarra-regular">When should you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raise this dilemma? </span>Raise it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the one who says </span>that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>in a case that is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case?
The two sides of the question are as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say</span> that, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>this case is <span class="gemarra-regular">initially through negligence and ultimately by accident, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps here, </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is entirely </span>due to his <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence; since he saw that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was close</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to giving birth, he should have safeguarded it </span>adequately

Daf 58b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and taken care of it, </span>and he bears responsibility for failing to do so. The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">How does </span>the court appraise the value of the damage when the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged? </span>The court appraises a large piece of land with an area required for sowing one se’a of seed [<span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>] in that field, including the garden bed in which the damage took place, it appraises how much it was worth before the animal damaged it and how much is it worth now, and the owner must pay the difference. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana says: As the verse states: “And it feed in another field [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvi’er</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">bisde</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">aḥer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 22:4). This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to another field, </span>i.e., relative to the damaged field as a whole and not an appraisal of only the specific garden bed that was damaged.
The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Uvi’er</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">bisde</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">aḥer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>can be understood as meaning: “And it feed in another’s field,” and accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>to teach that the owner is not liable unless it was a field with an owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>damage caused by an animal in <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain,</span> for which the owner is not liable.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if this was the sole intention of the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it feed in a field belonging to another [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvi’er</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">bisde</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥaveiro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], or alternatively, </span>let it write: And it consume <span class="gemarra-regular">another field [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sedeh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">aḥer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].” What </span>is conveyed by the particular expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In another field [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bisde</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">aḥer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”? </span>It is to teach that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises </span>the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to another field.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">entirely for this </span>purpose, i.e., to teach that the court appraises the damage relative to another field? And in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where do we </span>derive the <span class="gemarra-regular">exclusion </span>of liability for damage by Eating in <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that the verse was referring solely to the method of appraising the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One should have written this </span>in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">in the context of payment, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">His best-quality field and the best quality of his vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he shall pay in another field </span>(see Exodus 22:4), thereby adding the term: In another field, and, by extension, the directive concerning how the damage is appraised, to the verse discussing payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One to write it in </span>the context of the act of damaging, in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it feed </span>in another field”? <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude two </span>conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from it:</span> The verse is referring to both the place where the damage occurred and the method by which the damage is appraised.
§ The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How do we, </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">appraise </span>the value of the damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: </span>The court appraises the value of an area required for sowing one <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of seed [<span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area required for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of seed, and according to this calculation determines the value of the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yannai says: </span>The court appraises each <span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> equivalent to half a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Ḥizkiyya says: </span>The court appraises the value of each <span class="gemarra-regular">stalk </span>eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to sixty stalks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>compensation according to <span class="gemarra-regular">their value, </span>i.e., the value of the actual damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">view it as if it were a small garden bed and evaluate it </span>accordingly. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that this means that the court evaluates that garden bed according to what it would cost if sold <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>which contradicts all the previous explanations?
The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it means that the court appraises the value <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>relation to an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>When appraising the damage, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>it based on an area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, because </span>doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">enhances his </span>position, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they also do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>appraise it relative to an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>equivalent to the area in which one can plant thirty <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of seed, <span class="gemarra-regular">because this weakens his </span>position.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? Rav Pappa said: This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>the value of one <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> relative to </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which, being too large for an individual but too small for a trader, is always sold in the market at a lower price, <span class="gemarra-regular">because that </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">enhance </span>the position of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage. </span>Conversely, the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>appraise the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> relative to </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>an area so large that it is purchased only by a person with a specific need and therefore for a high price, <span class="gemarra-regular">because that </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">weaken </span>the position of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one liable for damage.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Manoaḥ objects to this: </span>According to this interpretation, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>term employed by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>they also <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span>appraise it relative to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>is imprecise. According to the explanation of Rav Pappa, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: And </span>they also <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span>appraise it relative to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>to parallel the term in the previous clause: A <span class="it-text">kav</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Huna bar Manoaḥ said in the name of Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by itself, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">because that </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">enhance </span>the position of <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>does the court appraise <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> as one part of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, because that </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">weaken </span>the position of <span class="gemarra-regular">the injured </span>party, since damage inside such a large area is insignificant. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court appraises the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>relation to an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater than the area that was damaged.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who cut down a date palm [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kashba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to another. </span>The latter <span class="gemarra-regular">came</span> with the perpetrator for arbitration <span class="gemarra-regular">before the Exilarch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Exilarch <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the perpetrator: <span class="gemarra-regular">I personally saw </span>that place where the date palm was planted, and it actually contained <span class="gemarra-regular">three date palms [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">talata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> standing </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">in a cluster,</span> growing out of a single root, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they were worth </span>altogether <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars. </span>Consequently, since you, the perpetrator, cut down one of the three, <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give him thirty-three and one-third </span>dinars, one third of the total value. The perpetrator rejected this ruling and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Why do I </span>need to be judged by <span class="gemarra-regular">the Exilarch, who rules according to Persian law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He came before Rav Naḥman </span>for judgment in the same case, who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span> The court appraises the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>relation to an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater than the damage caused. This amount is much less than thirty-three and one-third dinars.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the court appraises <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by one’s property,</span> such as his animal, relative to an area sixty times greater, <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span>they also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the court appraises damage relative to an area sixty times greater even <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rava: With regard to damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is your opinion? </span>Are you basing your opinion on the following, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">destroys the vineyard of another </span>while the grapes are <span class="gemarra-regular">budding [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">semadar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views how much </span>the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth before </span>he destroyed it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much it is worth afterward. </span>Abaye states the inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whereas, </span>the method of appraising one part in <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty is not taught. </span>Is the basis of your ruling the fact that in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses damage caused directly by a person, the method of appraising one part in sixty is not mentioned?
Abaye continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> animal it is not taught </span>in a mishna or <span class="it-text">baraita</span> without mentioning the method of appraising one part in sixty <span class="gemarra-regular">like this case? </span>But this is not so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">broke down a sapling </span>that had not yet borne fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: Those who issue decrees in Jerusale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the damages are determined based on a fixed formula: If the <span class="gemarra-regular">sapling </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in its first year, </span>the owner of the animal pays <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>pieces of <span class="gemarra-regular">silver; </span>if the sapling was <span class="gemarra-regular">two years old,</span> he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>pieces of <span class="gemarra-regular">silver. </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate unripe blades of grain </span>used for pasture, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: It is judged according to what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> remains of it, </span>i.e., the court waits until the rest of the field ripens and then appraises the value of what was previously eaten. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views how much </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth </span>before he destroyed it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much it is worth </span>now. 

Daf 59a
