If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>the grapes while they were in the <span class="gemarra-regular">budding </span>stage, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the grapes that were damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">as if they were grape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about to be picked, </span>and appraise the damage based on this. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views how much </span>the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth </span>before the animal ate the grapes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much it is worth </span>now. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that the court appraises the vineyard or group of trees that were damaged, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate young branches [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lulevei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gefanim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of vines or shoots of fig </span>trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">it ate unripe figs or unripe grapes, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views them </span>and appraises them <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes ready to be picked.</span>
Abaye continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, it teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views how much </span>the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth </span>before the animal ate the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much it is worth </span>now, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach </span>that the court appraises the damage relative to an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say? </span>You must say that the wording employed by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to be understood to mean that the court appraises the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater, so <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> dealing with one who himself causes damage, the wording is to be understood to mean that the damage is valued <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Yishmael </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">said the same thing. </span>They are of the same opinion that the appraisal for damages is based on the value of the produce remaining in the field once it ripens.
The opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this that we stated </span>above in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, i.e., that the damages paid for an animal eating unripe grain is assessed according to what remains of the grain.
The opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The best of his field and the best of his vineyard he shall pay” </span>(Exodus 22:4), which means he must pay according to the <span class="gemarra-regular">best</span>-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">field of the injured </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">or the best</span>-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">vineyard of the injured </span>party. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: The verse comes only </span>to allow <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>land of the one liable to pay for the damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>by an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference it is derived that this applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to consecrated </span>property. Compensation for damaging consecrated property is paid from one’s best-quality assets.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And do not say </span>that Rabbi Yishmael’s statement should be interpreted <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin, as Rav Idi bar Avin says: </span>Here it concerns a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>the produce of <span class="gemarra-regular">one garden bed from among </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">garden beds, but we do not know whether </span>the garden bed it ate from <span class="gemarra-regular">was lean or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">choice. Therefore, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the owner of the animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">Arise </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">pay choice </span>land, equivalent <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the best</span>-quality land <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is now </span>remaining, and the court does not assume that the animal ate produce from the lesser-quality garden bed, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we do not say this.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that Rabbi Yishmael does not hold in accordance with the opinion of Rav Idi bar Avin? It is because he accepts the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant; </span>without such proof, the owner of the animal pays only the value of a lesser-quality garden bed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Yishmael interprets the Torah’s expression “the best of his field” as requiring payment <span class="gemarra-regular">with the best</span>-quality land <span class="gemarra-regular">before him, and what is this? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>remained in the field and subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">sprouted, </span>and the compensation is based on the value of this.
The Gemara examines the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: In what</span> case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span>that the court appraises the vineyard or group of trees that were damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate young branches of vines or shoots of fig </span>trees. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>indicates that if the animal ate <span class="gemarra-regular">budding </span>grapes the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views them </span>and appraises them <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes ready to be picked. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>and try to explain accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which teaches that if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate unripe figs or half-ripe grapes, that is </span>where the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views them as if </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes ready to be picked, </span>indicating that if the animal ate the grapes in the <span class="gemarra-regular">budding </span>stage, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views how much </span>the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth </span>before the animal ate them <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much it is worth </span>now. Therefore, the two clauses of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> appear to be contradictory.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Bind </span>them together <span class="gemarra-regular">and teach </span>them as a single statement, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said </span>that the court appraises how much the field was worth when the animal ate from it? It is said in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate young branches of vines or shoots of fig trees. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>grapes in the <span class="gemarra-regular">budding </span>stage, <span class="gemarra-regular">unripe figs, or half-ripe grapes, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views them </span>and appraises them <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes ready to be picked.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda is </span>identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua</span> with regard to grapes in the budding stage. Why would the mishna state their opinions separately?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the weakening of the vine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A vine is weakened by the grapes growing on it, as they draw nutrients from the roots and branches. Now that the grapes have been eaten, the vine is no longer weakened. Therefore, according to one opinion, the court takes into consideration this reduction of the weakening of the vine, and that amount is deducted when calculating the damages, whereas according to the other opinion, the court does not take this into account. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>their respective opinions are <span class="gemarra-regular">not defined, </span>and it is not clear which <span class="it-text">tanna</span> takes this weakening into account and which does not.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>Their respective opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">are certainly defined, </span>and it is possible to know which Sage held which opinion, since <span class="gemarra-regular">who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">is concerned for the weakening of the vine? It is Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya: </span>With regard to the indemnity payments that <span class="gemarra-regular">a rapis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> must pay his victim, who had been a virgin, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">the pain </span>caused by the rape. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">she will ultimately suffer </span>the same pain during her first act of sexual intercourse <span class="gemarra-regular">with her husband </span>when she marries. The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The pain of a woman who <span class="gemarra-regular">has intercourse willingly is not comparabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the pain of a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">who has intercourse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by rape. </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda considers future pain when considering payment of damages, and similarly, he considers the reduced weakening of the vine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: These </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> following <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda said the same thing </span>concerning this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda </span>said <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">that we said </span>with regard to the case of rape and the case of the vine. As to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>other <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the case about which they gave a similar ruling?
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of one who injured a pregnant woman, thereby causing her to miscarry, for which the Torah holds him liable to pay her husband compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span>The court appraises the compensation for the miscarried offspring and <span class="gemarra-regular">deducts </span>the amount they would have paid for <span class="gemarra-regular">a midwife. </span>Since she miscarried, the husband no longer has to pay for a midwife, so that is deducted from the compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Azzai says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">deducts </span>the value of the extra <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance </span>the husband would have been required to provide for his pregnant wife.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that the court appraises the compensation for the miscarried offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>the amount they would have paid for <span class="gemarra-regular">a midwife</span> would <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>concede that the appraisal is <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>the value of the extra <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance. But the one who says </span>that the appraisal is <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>the value of the extra <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>necessarily hold that the court appraises the compensation for the miscarried offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>the money they would have paid for <span class="gemarra-regular">a midwife, since </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the assailant: <span class="gemarra-regular">My wife is capabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and does not require a midwife</span> to assist her when giving birth.
Returning to the discussion of the appraisal of compensation for damage, the Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, acted in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman </span>and appraised a damaged date palm <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times greater than the particular area where the tree was standing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A different version </span>of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is also stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, appraised </span>the damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a date palm relative to </span>the assessment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the patch of land </span>where the tree stood, i.e., how much it was worth with the tree and how much it was worth without it.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, with regard to an Aramean date palm, </span>i.e., one of lesser quality, and it is assessed relative to the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Exilarch with regard to a Persian date palm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they are of higher quality and each one is valuable, and it is not assessed relative to the land.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Eliezer Ze’eira</span>

Daf 59b

<span class="gemarra-regular">was wearing black shoes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> unlike the Jewish custom of that time, <span class="gemarra-regular">and standing in the market of Neharde’a. </span>Officials <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of the Exilarch found him and said to him: What is different </span>about you that causes you to wear <span class="gemarra-regular">these shoes? He said to them: </span>I am wearing them <span class="gemarra-regular">because I am in mourning over </span>the destruction of the Temple and <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and so I wear black shoes, as is the custom of mourners. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: Are you </span>a man of such <span class="gemarra-regular">importance to </span>publicly <span class="gemarra-regular">mourn over Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> They thought that it was </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptuousness </span>on his part. Since he was acting against the prevalent Jewish custom, <span class="gemarra-regular">they brought him </span>to the prison <span class="gemarra-regular">and incarcerated him.</span>
Eliezer Ze’eira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I am a great man, </span>a scholar, and it is fitting for me to mourn publicly over the destruction of Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: How do we know </span>that you are a scholar? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: Either you ask of me a matter </span>of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and I will answer you, <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will ask you a matter </span>of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and you will answer me. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: You ask.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who cuts </span>a cluster of flowers on <span class="gemarra-regular">the stem </span>of a date palm belonging to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is he required to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay? They said to him: He pays the value of the </span>date <span class="gemarra-regular">stem. </span>He said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">they will become </span>ripe <span class="gemarra-regular">dates, </span>which are worth more. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the value of </span>the future <span class="gemarra-regular">dates. He said to them: But he did not take </span>ripe <span class="gemarra-regular">dates from </span>the other person, so how can the court obligate him to pay for damage that he did not cause?
<span class="gemarra-regular">They said to </span>Eliezer Ze’eira: <span class="gemarra-regular">You tell us </span>the correct appraisal for the date stem. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them:</span> The court appraises the damage relative to a similar piece of land <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>times the size. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: Who says </span>an opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as you </span>do, so that you can prove you are correct? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: Shmuel is alive and his court exists; </span>you can ask him. <span class="gemarra-regular">They sent </span>the question <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shmuel, </span>together with the ruling of Eliezer Ze’eira. Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: He is saying well to you, </span>because the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as he says; the appraisal is <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty</span> times greater. Upon hearing this, the officials of the Exilarch realized that he was a great man <span class="gemarra-regular">and they released him.</span>
§ The mishna (55b) teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>If the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate ripe produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner pays the value of the ripe produce eaten. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for Rabbi Shimon’s opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">This that the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it feed in another’s field” </span>(Exodus 22:4), which <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises</span> the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">relative to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">field, this statement </span>applies specifically with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">requires a field </span>to grow. For one’s animal eating this <span class="gemarra-regular">produce, which do not require the field </span>in order to ripen further, the animal’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay </span>their value <span class="gemarra-regular">as they are.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says: Rav judged </span>a practical <span class="it-text">halakha</span> on a certain issue <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>despite the fact that in general the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is not in accordance with his opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">he rule</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>even though in that case his was a minority opinion.
Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav judged </span>a practical <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of a field designated by its owner as a lien for his wife’s marriage contract, which he subsequently wants to sell, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he wrote </span>a document of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">to a first </span>buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">did not sig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for him</span> to endorse the sale, and subsequently the husband wrote a document of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">to a second </span>buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">signed for him, she </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">loses </span>the lien of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract, </span>since the sale is effective and she can no longer collect from this field; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she can say: I did </span>it only to <span class="gemarra-regular">please my husband, </span>but I did not mean it and never intended to forgo my rights. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">do you, </span>the purchasers, <span class="gemarra-regular">have against me? </span>Therefore, the lien is still in effect. Rav judged a case in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, as we learned</span> in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>If one’s animal <span class="gemarra-regular">ate ripe produce, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">ripe produce </span>eaten. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span> it ate <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of produce, he pays the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of produce, and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it ate <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he pays for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Although Rabbi Shimon’s opinion is the minority one, Rav ruled in accordance with it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stacks </span>his produce <span class="gemarra-regular">in another’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">without permission </span>from the owner of that field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an animal belonging to the owner of the field eats </span>the produce, the owner of the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. And if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is injured by </span>the produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the stack </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But if he stacked </span>them in that field <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the field </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for damage caused to the produce.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we learned </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi? <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>the mishna were <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t he say: </span>A homeowner who gives another permission to bring items into his courtyard is not responsible for them <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the homeowner accepts on himself to safeguard </span>them? The mishna does not mention any such acceptance of responsibility. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Here we are dealing with the supervisor of the threshing floors, </span>to whom people would entrust their produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, since the supervisor says</span> to the owner of the produce: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in and stack</span> it, it is as though he had said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in and I will supervise </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for you.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sends a fire, </span>i.e., places a burning object, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the hand of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deaf-mute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, or a minor </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>for any damage later caused by the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he sent </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the hand of a </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent </span>person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>not the one who sent him.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> person <span class="gemarra-regular">brought the fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one </span>other person subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">brought the wood, </span>causing the fire to spread, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who brought the woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for any damage caused. Conversely, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person first <span class="gemarra-regular">brought the wood, and</span> subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other person <span class="gemarra-regular">brought the fire, the one who brought the fire </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since it was he who actually kindled the wood.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">another came and fanned </span>the flame, and as a result the fire spread and caused damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who fanned it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since he is the proximate cause of the damage. If <span class="gemarra-regular">the wind fanned </span>the flames, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the people involved are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since none of them actually caused the damage.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says in the name of Ḥizkiyya: They taught </span>that one who sends fire in the hand of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">only when he conveyed to him </span>a glowing <span class="gemarra-regular">coa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one of these people <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned </span>it himself and set it alight. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">conveyed a torch to </span>a deaf-mute, imbecile, or minor, the one who gave it to him is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. What is the reason </span>for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">The action </span>of the one who gave it to him directly <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>the fire to spread.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he conveyed a torch to him, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason? </span>It is the <span class="gemarra-regular">tong</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the deaf-mute that caused </span>the damage, since torches do not cause fires on their own. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the one who gives dangerous objects to a deaf-mute is <span class="gemarra-regular">not rendered liable </span>for the damage caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he conveys branches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gavza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him</span>

Daf 60a

<span class="gemarra-regular">of thin wood </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a candle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheraga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">action, </span>i.e., that of the one who sent the flame, <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely caused</span> the fire to spread.
The mishna teaches that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">in the hand of a </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent </span>person is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable…</span>If another came and fanned the flame the one who fanned it is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says </span>with regard to the correct text of the mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches </span>it using the word <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">libba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is not mistaken</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches </span>it using the word <span class="gemarra-regular">blew [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nibba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is not mistaken.</span>
Rav Naḥman explained: The <span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches </span>using the word <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">libba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is not mistaken, as it is written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “With a flame [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">belabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of fire” </span>(Exodus 3:2), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches</span> using the word <span class="gemarra-regular">blew [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nibba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is not mistaken, as it is written: “He creates the fruit [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">niv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the lips” </span>(Isaiah 57:19), which can be interpreted as referring to the breath of the lips.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the wind fanned </span>the flames, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the people involved <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt,</span> indicating that even if one fanned the fire at the same time that the wind was blowing he is exempt. The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught </span>the same idea explicitly: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one fanned </span>the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at the same time <span class="gemarra-regular">the wind </span>fanned it, <span class="gemarra-regular">if his fanning has </span>sufficient strength by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">to fan </span>the flames, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> for damage caused by the fire, since even without the wind the fire would have spread. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>his fanning alone was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sufficient, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is he exempt if his fanning is not sufficient? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let it be </span>the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">winnows </span>grain on Shabbat by throwing it into the air, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wind assists him </span>by separating the chaff from the grain. In such a case he is liable for desecrating Shabbat, despite the fact that without the assistance of the wind he would not have been able to winnow the grain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: With what are we dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he fanned </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">from one side and the wind fanned </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the other side, </span>and the fire was blown in the direction the wind was blowing. Therefore, it is clear that his fanning did not help the fire spread, so he is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he fanned </span>it along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a typical wind, </span>and this was not sufficient to cause the fire to spread, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>suddenly <span class="gemarra-regular">an atypical wind </span>came and <span class="gemarra-regular">fanned it. </span>Therefore, he is exempt since he could not have anticipated this. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he only <span class="gemarra-regular">heated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">de</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzamera</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tzamurei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the fire by breathing on it, rather than fanning it properly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When we say </span>that one is liable in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">winnows and the wind assists him, this statement </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat. </span>With regard to Shabbat, the principle is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Torah prohibited planned, </span>constructive <span class="gemarra-regular">labor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The primary consideration is that his objective is accomplished, even if he did not perform the entire act of labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the context of damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>considered to have caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one who causes <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sends </span>forth <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, </span>i.e., allows it to escape, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it consumes wood, or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or earth, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, as it is stated: “If a fire breaks out, and catches in thorns, so that a stack of grain, or standing grain, or the field, is consumed, the one who kindled the fire shall pay compensation” </span>(Exodus 22:5), which teaches that he is liable also for destroying the field itself.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the verse cited in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One </span>to write in the Torah all of these terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Thorns,” “a stack of grain,” “standing grain,” and “field,” </span>which seem to be redundant?
Rava explains: All the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary, because if the Merciful One had written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“thorns” </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that it is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">thorns for which the Merciful One renders one liable, because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">fire </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">near them, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is common that </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a stack of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">grain, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">which it is not common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">fire </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">near it, </span>as grain is valuable, so one keeps it out of harm’s way, and it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not common that </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent </span>in allowing it to catch fire, I would <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the Merciful One had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A stack of grain,” I would say </span>that it is specifically for such <span class="gemarra-regular">a stack </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One renders him liable, because </span>it involves <span class="gemarra-regular">a substantial </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">loss. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">thorns, </span>which involve only <span class="gemarra-regular">a minimal loss, </span>I would <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable. Therefore, the verse teaches that he is liable for damage to thorns as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the Torah to state the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“standing grain”? </span>It is in order to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as standing grain is exposed, so too, </span>one is liable only for damage caused by fire <span class="gemarra-regular">for all </span>items that are <span class="gemarra-regular">exposed. </span>One is exempt from liability for damage to items that are concealed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for a concealed </span>article damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">by a fire, why do I </span>need the Torah to state the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Standing grain”?</span> The Gemara answers: The term serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">that have stature</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., trees and animals, and not only produce. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of concealed articles from the term “standing grain,” <span class="gemarra-regular">from where do they </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">that have stature </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">included? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They derive it from </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or standing grain,” </span>since the additional word “or” is an inclusive term.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>derive from the additional word “or”? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” to divide </span>the terms, i.e., to teach that one is liable for damage to any one of the items listed, and not only where the fire burned all of them together. The Gemara then asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do the Rabbis </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to divide </span>the terms so that one is liable for damage to each one independently? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They derive it from </span>the second instance of the word “or,” as the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or the field.”</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span> derive from the phrase “or the field”? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the Merciful One wrote </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or standing grain,” He </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote: “Or the field,” </span>for stylistic consistency, but no additional <span class="it-text">halakha</span> may be derived from this term.
Rava continues to elaborate on the different terms in the verse: And <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“field” </span>in the verse? It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include</span> liability for damage in a case when the flames <span class="gemarra-regular">licked a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plowed field and charred its stones. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let the Merciful One write </span>only the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“field,” and </span>then it would <span class="gemarra-regular">not require all these </span>other terms. If one is liable for damage to a field, which is not totally destroyed by the fire, he is certainly liable for damage to other items that are completely destroyed. The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to write the other terms as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">because if the Merciful One </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“field,” I would say that </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what is in the field, yes, </span>one is liable, but for <span class="gemarra-regular">anything else, no, </span>one is not liable. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that one is liable for any damage caused by fire.
§ The Gemara cites an aggadic midrash based on this verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: Calamity befalls the world onl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when wicked </span>people are <span class="gemarra-regular">in the world, but </span>the calamity <span class="gemarra-regular">begins only with the righteous first, as it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a fire breaks out, and catches in thorns, </span>so that a stack of grain, or standing grain, or the field, is consumed” (Exodus 22:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">When does the fire, </span>i.e., calamity, <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge? </span>At a time <span class="gemarra-regular">when the thorns, </span>i.e., the wicked, <span class="gemarra-regular">are found with it. But </span>calamity <span class="gemarra-regular">begins only from the righteous first, as it is stated </span>in the continuation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And a stack of grain is consumed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vene’ekhal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].” It is not stated: </span>If a fire breaks out, and catches in thorns, <span class="gemarra-regular">and consumes [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’akhal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the stack of grain; rather, </span>it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A stack of grain is consumed,” </span>meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stack, </span>i.e., the righteous, <span class="gemarra-regular">has already been consumed </span>before the thorns.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written </span>with regard to the plague of the firstborn: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And none of you shall go out of the opening of his house until the morning” </span>(Exodus 12:22)? If the plague was not decreed upon the Jewish people, why were they not permitted to leave their homes? <span class="gemarra-regular">Once permission </span>is granted <span class="gemarra-regular">to the destroyer </span>to kill, <span class="gemarra-regular">it does not distinguish between the righteous and the wicked. And not only </span>that, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it begins with the righteous first, as it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And will cut off from you the righteous and the wicked” </span>(Ezekiel 21:8), where mention of the righteous precedes the wicked.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef cried </span>and said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are all these </span>righteous people <span class="gemarra-regular">also compared to nothing </span>when calamity strikes? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: It is goodness for </span>the righteous that they die first, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “The righteous is taken away because of the evil to come” </span>(Isaiah 57:1), so that he will not have to endure the suffering that will befall the people.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>

Daf 60b

<span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">always enter </span>an unfamiliar city <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>a time of <span class="gemarra-regular">good, </span>i.e., while it is light, as the Torah uses the expression “It is good” with regard to the creation of light (see Genesis 1:4). This goodness is manifest in the sense of security one feels when it is light. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>likewise, when one leaves a city <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">leave at </span>a time of <span class="gemarra-regular">good, </span>meaning after sunrise the next morning, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And none of you shall go out of the opening of his house until the morning” </span>(Exodus 12:22).
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">plague in the city, gather your feet, </span>i.e., limit the time you spend out of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And none of you shall go out of the opening of his house until the morning.” And it says </span>in another verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Come, my people, enter into your chambers, and shut your doors behind you;</span> hide yourself for a little moment, until the anger has passed by” (Isaiah 26:20). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says: “Outside the sword will bereave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in the chambers terror” </span>(Deuteronomy 32:25).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the reason for citing the additional verses introduced with the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says? </span>The first verse seems sufficient to teach the principle that one should not emerge from one’s house when there is a plague. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter, </span>the first verse that states that none of you shall go out until morning, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">at night, but in the day </span>one may think that the principle does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply, for this reason the Gemara teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: “Come, my people, enter into your chambers, and shut your doors behind you.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no fear inside, </span>which explains why it is preferable to remain indoors, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where there is fear inside, </span>one might think that <span class="gemarra-regular">when he goes out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sits among people in general company </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">better, </span>therefore, the Gemara introduces the third verse and says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: “Outside the sword will bereave, and in the chambers terror.” </span>This means that <span class="gemarra-regular">although there is terror in the chambers, outside the sword will bereave, </span>so it is safer to remain indoors.
<span class="gemarra-regular">At a time </span>when there was a <span class="gemarra-regular">plague, Rava would close the windows </span>of his house, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “For death is come up into our windows” </span>(Jeremiah 9:20).
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">famine in the city, spread your feet, </span>i.e., leave the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And there was a famine in the land; and Abram went down into Egypt to sojourn there” </span>(Genesis 12:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says: “If we say: We will enter into the city, then the famine is in the city, and we shall die there; </span>and if we sit here, we die also, now come, and let us fall unto the host of the Arameans; if they save us alive, we shall live; and if they kill us, we shall but die” (II Kings 7:4).
<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the reason for citing the second verse, introduced with the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says? And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter, </span>the principle of leaving the city, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no uncertainty </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a life-threatening </span>situation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where there is uncertainty </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a life-threatening </span>situation this principle does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: “Come, and let us fall unto the host of the Arameans; if they save us alive, we shall live; </span>and if they kill us, we shall but die.”
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a plague in the city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person should not walk in the middle of the road, due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Angel of Death walks in the middle of the road, as, since </span>in Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">they have given him permission </span>to kill within the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">he goes openly </span>in the middle of the road. By contrast, if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">peace </span>and quiet <span class="gemarra-regular">in the city, do not walk on the sides of the road, as, since </span>the Angel of Death <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have permission </span>to kill within the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">he hides </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and walks </span>on the side of the road.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a plague in the city, a person should not enter the synagogue alone, as the Angel of Death leaves his utensils there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and for this reason it is a dangerous place. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter, </span>the danger in the synagogue, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when there are no children learning in </span>the synagogue, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">not ten </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">praying in it. </span>But if there are children learning or ten men praying there, it is not a dangerous place.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs </span>in a certain place <span class="gemarra-regular">are crying </span>for no reason, it is a sign that they feel the <span class="gemarra-regular">Angel of Death has come to the city. </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs are playing, </span>it is a sign that they feel that <span class="gemarra-regular">Elijah the prophet has come to the city. These matters </span>apply only <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no female </span>dog among them. If there is a female dog nearby, their crying or playing is likely due to her presence.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ami and Rav Asi sat before Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage said to </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Master say </span>words of <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage said to </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Master say </span>words of <span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">began to say </span>words of <span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage did not let him, </span>so he <span class="gemarra-regular">began to say </span>words of <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage did not let him.</span>
Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I will relate a parable. To what can this be compared? </span>It can be compared <span class="gemarra-regular">to a man who has two wives, one young and one old. The young </span>wife <span class="gemarra-regular">pulls out his white </span>hairs, so that her husband will appear younger. <span class="gemarra-regular">The old </span>wife <span class="gemarra-regular">pulls out his black </span>hairs so that he will appear older. And it <span class="gemarra-regular">turns out </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">bald from here and from there, </span>i.e., completely bald, due to the actions of both of his wives.
Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa continued and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: If so, I will say to you a matter that is appropriate to both of you, </span>which contains both <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and <span class="it-text">aggada</span>. In the verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a fire breaks out, and catches in thorns” </span>(Exodus 22:5), the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“breaks out” </span>indicates that it breaks out <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself. </span>Yet, the continuation of the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The one who kindled the fire shall pay compensation,” </span>which indicates that he must pay only if the fire spread due to his negligence. The verse can be explained allegorically: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Holy One, Blessed be He, said </span>that although the fire broke out in the Temple due to the sins of the Jewish people, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is incumbent upon Me to pay </span>restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">for the fire that I kindled.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">I, </span>God, <span class="gemarra-regular">kindled a fire in Zion, as it is stated: </span>“The Lord has accomplished His fury, He has poured out His fierce anger; <span class="gemarra-regular">and He has kindled a fire in Zion, which has devoured its foundations” </span>(Lamentations 4:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">And I will build it with fire </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, as it is stated: “For I, </span>says the Lord, <span class="gemarra-regular">will be for her a wall of fire round about; and I will be the glory in her midst” </span>(Zechariah 2:9).
There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> that can be learned from the verse in Exodus, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse begins with damage </span>caused through one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property: </span>“If a fire breaks out,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and concludes with damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s body: </span>“The one who kindled the fire.” This indicates that when damage is caused by fire, it is considered as though the person who kindled the fire caused the damage directly with his body. That serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to say to you </span>that the liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire </span>damage is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>its similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">his arrows. </span>Just as one who shoots an arrow and causes damage is liable because the damage was caused directly through his action, so too, one who kindles a fire that causes damage is liable because it is considered as though the damage were caused directly by his actions.
§ The Gemara continues with another statement of <span class="it-text">aggada</span> on a related topic: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And David longed, and said: Oh, that one would give me water to drink of the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate! And the three mighty men broke through the host of the Philistines, and drew water out of the well of Bethlehem, that was by the gate, </span>and took it, and brought it to David; but he would not drink it, but poured it out to the Lord” (II Samuel 23:15–16). The Sages understood that David was not simply asking for water, but was using the term as a metaphor referring to Torah, and he was raising a halakhic dilemma.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the dilemma </span>that David <span class="gemarra-regular">is raising</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: He was asking </span>about the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concealed </span>article damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He wanted to know whether the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who holds that one is liable to pay for such damage, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold that one is exempt from liability for damage by fire to concealed articles. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Sages in Bethlehem <span class="gemarra-regular">answered him what they answered him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna stated </span>a different explanation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">There were stacks of barley belonging to Jews in which the Philistines were hiding, and </span>David wanted to burn down the stacks to kill the Philistines and save his own life. <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to save oneself </span>by destroying <span class="gemarra-regular">the property of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They sent </span>the following answer <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: It is prohibited to save oneself </span>by destroying <span class="gemarra-regular">the property of another. But you are king</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a king may breach the fence </span>of an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to form a path for himself, and none may protest his </span>action, i.e., the normal <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damage do not apply to you since you are king.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis, and some say </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Mari, </span>give an alternative explanation of the dilemma and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: The stacks of barley belonged to Jews, and </span>there were <span class="gemarra-regular">stacks of lentils belonging to the Philistines. </span>David needed barley to feed his animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>David <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? I know that I may take the lentils belonging to a gentile to feed my animals, but is it permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to take a stack of barley </span>belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew, to place before one’s animal </span>for it to consume, <span class="gemarra-regular">with the intent to pay </span>the owner of the barley with the <span class="gemarra-regular">stacks of lentils belonging to the Philistines?</span>
The Sages of Bethlehem <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the following reply <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: “If the wicked restore the pledge, give back that which he had taken by robbery, </span>walk in the statutes of life, committing no iniquity; he shall surely live, he shall not die” (Ezekiel 33:15). This verse teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">repays </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item, he </span>is nevertheless considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">wicked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and is described as such in the verse, and a commoner would not be allowed to act as you asked. <span class="gemarra-regular">But you are king, and a king may breach the fence </span>of an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to form a path for himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and none may protest his </span>action.
The Gemara discusses the different explanations: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that David was asking whether he could take the stacks of barley and <span class="gemarra-regular">exchange </span>them, i.e., repay the owners of the barley, with stacks of lentils, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is as it is written </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one verse: </span>“And the Philistines were gathered together into a troop, <span class="gemarra-regular">where was a plot of ground full of lentils; </span>and the people fled from the Philistines” (II Samuel 23:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">verse: </span>“He was with David at Pas Dammim, and there the Philistines were gathered together to battle, <span class="gemarra-regular">where was a plot of ground full of barley;</span> and the people fled from before the Philistines” (I Chronicles 11:13). This apparent contradiction can be reconciled by saying that there were two fields, one of barley and one of lentils.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that David’s question was asked because he wanted <span class="gemarra-regular">to burn </span>the stacks of barley, for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">does he require these two verses? </span>How does he explain this contradiction? Rav Huna could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you that there were also stacks of lentils belonging to Jews, inside which the Philistines were hiding.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that David asked his question because he wanted <span class="gemarra-regular">to burn </span>the stacks, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is as it is writ-ten </span>in the following verse with regard to David: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But he stood in the midst of the plot, and saved it, </span>and slew the Philistines; and the Lord performed a great victory” (II Samuel 23:12). <span class="gemarra-regular">But according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>that David’s question was asked <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to exchanging </span>the lentils for the barley, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And saved it”?</span>
The Rabbis answer that David saved it in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not permit them to exchange </span>the value of the barley with the lentils.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>according to both of <span class="gemarra-regular">these two </span>opinions, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is as it is written </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">verses, </span>one describing the field of lentils and one describing the field of barley. 

Daf 61a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>Rava, who cited Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says</span> that David <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>article damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>purpose does <span class="gemarra-regular">he require the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">verses </span>that describe a field of lentils and a field of barley? Rav Naḥman could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that David <span class="gemarra-regular">was asking</span> both about <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed </span>articles damaged by a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">and one of these </span>other two dilemmas.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">these two </span>explanations, that David was asking either about repaying barley with lentils or burning the stacks of barley, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is as it is written </span>of David: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But he would not drink it” </span>(II Samuel 23:16). David <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since there is a prohibition </span>involved in this action, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not satisfactory to me </span>to act in this manner, even though technically it is permitted for a king. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that David <span class="gemarra-regular">was raising a dilemma </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed </span>article damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, since they sent him </span>an answer that was <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of: “But <span class="gemarra-regular">he would not drink it”?</span>
The Gemara answers: This means <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not say the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in their names. </span>He did not transmit the ruling in the name of those who went in the time of battle to ask the Sages what the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is. David <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is the tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">I received from the court of Samuel of Rama: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who hands himself </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">to die for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">words of Torah, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">do not say a matter of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his name, </span>so that others will not follow this ruling and endanger their lives.
The Gemara asks another question: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He poured it out to the Lord” </span>(II Samuel 23:16), which indicates that David acted stringently and did not rely on the lenient ruling that he received. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>either of <span class="gemarra-regular">these two </span>explanations, that David asked either about burning the stacks of barley or about replacing their value with lentils, he poured out the water to God <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he acted for the sake of Heave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and did not rely on the lenient ruling he had received. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that David asked about <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concealed </span>article damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, what </span>is the reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">he poured out </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Lord? </span>The Gemara answers: The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that they said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of the tradition, </span>without associating it with any specific individual.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one kindled a fire that <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that is four cubits high, or </span>if the fire crossed <span class="gemarra-regular">the public thoroughfare, or </span>if the fire crossed <span class="gemarra-regular">a river, </span>and in each case it caused damage on the other side, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed a fence that is four cubits in height, </span>the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>This appears to contradict the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>There is no dispute between the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna and the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>; there is merely a difference of how they stated their rulings. <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">counts </span>downward <span class="gemarra-regular">from above to below. </span>In other words, if the fire crossed a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">six cubits </span>high, the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt; </span>if it crossed a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">five cubits </span>high, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt; </span>and this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the fire crosses a fence of a minimum of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>high, where the one who kindled the fire is still <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> counts </span>up <span class="gemarra-regular">from below to above. </span>The meaning is that if the fire crossed a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">two cubits </span>high, the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>if the fire crossed a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">three cubits </span>high, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>and this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the fire crosses a fence of a maximum of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>high, where the one who kindled the fire is still <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>Accordingly, there is no contradiction between the mishna and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: When they said </span>in the mishna with regard to a fire crossing a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>high <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">even in a field of thorns. Rav Pappa says: And </span>Rava’s statement is referring to a case where the height of the fence <span class="gemarra-regular">is four cubits </span>counting <span class="gemarra-regular">from above </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>upper <span class="gemarra-regular">limit of the thorns.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>in the mishna that one is exempt from liability if the fire crosses a public thoroughfare <span class="gemarra-regular">only in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes high [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekolaḥat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes low [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">benikhpefet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and therefore spreads easily along the ground, the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable even </span>if the space that the fire crossed was <span class="gemarra-regular">up to one hundred cubits. And Shmuel said: The mishna </span>exempts one from liability if the fire crosses a public thoroughfare <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes low,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes high, even any </span>minimal gap between where the fire was kindled and where it caused damage renders the one who kindled the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said </span>that one is exempt if the fire crosses a public thoroughfare? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes high.
