But in </span>a case where the flame <span class="gemarra-regular">blazes low and there is wood</span> to keep <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>burning, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable even </span>if it causes damage at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">up to one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed a river or a pool [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shelulit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>of water <span class="gemarra-regular">that is eight cubits wide, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the damage caused, regardless of whether the fire blazed high or low.
§ The mishna teaches: If the fire crossed <span class="gemarra-regular">the public thoroughfare, </span>he is exempt. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who holds this opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: It is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, as we learned </span>in a mishna (61b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One is liable up to a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits, like </span>the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain. </span>By inference, one is exempt if a fire crosses a greater distance, i.e., across a public thoroughfare.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>if the fire crossed <span class="gemarra-regular">a river, </span>he is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The term stream means <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual river. And Shmuel says: </span>This term means <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel.</span>
The Gemara explains their dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual river, </span>Rav, deems exempt one whose fire crosses a riverbed <span class="gemarra-regular">even when there is no water </span>in it, since it is sufficiently deep and wide to prevent a typical fire from crossing it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the one who says </span>that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel, </span>Shmuel, holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the fire crosses a water channel that <span class="gemarra-regular">has water in it, yes,</span> the one who kindled the fire is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the fire crosses a water channel that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have water in it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 2:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">And these, </span>the following list of features, <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>a field <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purpose of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., it is no longer considered a single field, but instead <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> must be given from each separate section: <span class="gemarra-regular">A stream, a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shelulit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a private road, and a public thoroughfare</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shelulit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where rainwater gathers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sholelin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. Rav Beivai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>says: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel that distributes </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">spoils</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shalal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to its banks, </span>since the water spreads to the adjacent cisterns.
The Gemara points out that according to the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that it means <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where rainwater gathers, </span>Shmuel, since gathered rainwater divides a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel, </span>which is both larger and permanent, divide a field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> water channel </span>divides a field, Rabbi Yoḥanan, he holds that only that divides a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a place where rainwater gathers does not divide </span>the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">since these</span>

Daf 61b

<span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>simply <span class="gemarra-regular">called pools of the land,</span> and are not considered significant enough to divide the field.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who kindles </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">on his own </span>premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">up to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>distance <span class="gemarra-regular">may the fire travel </span>within his property for him to still bear liability for damage caused? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azaria says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views his </span>location where he kindled the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">as if it were in the center of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, if the fire spreads and causes damage farther away than half a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>, the one who kindled the fire is exempt, since he could not anticipate that the fire would spread so far. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One is liable up to a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits, like </span>the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a public thoroughfare. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>One is liable up to a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits. Rabbi Shimon says: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The one who kindled the fire shall pay [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shallem yeshallem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] compensation” </span>(Exodus 22:5), to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">everything is according to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Rabbi Shimon appears to hold that there is no maximum distance which would exempt one from liability for the spreading of a fire. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t Rabbi Shimon</span> of the opinion that there is a maximum <span class="gemarra-regular">limit </span>concerning liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for a fire, </span>beyond which one is exempt?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 20b): <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not stand an ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inside the house unless there is a height of four cubits </span>to the ceiling <span class="gemarra-regular">above it, </span>out of concern that the ceiling might catch fire. Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stood it in the attic, </span>he should not do so <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there is plaster [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’aziva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> underneath it, </span>above the ceiling of the floor below, <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>in thickness, out of concern that the floor might catch fire. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a stove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is smaller and does not reach temperatures as high as those of an oven, a thickness of one <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth</span> is sufficient. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even though he may place his oven or stove in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the fire from the oven or stove <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he must pay </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what it damaged.</span>
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: These measurements were stated only </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the fire from the oven or stove <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage </span>after the owner takes these precautions, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying </span>compensation. Evidently, Rabbi Shimon does have a maximum distance beyond which one is not liable for fire.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>This is how Rabbi Shimon’s statement in the mishna should be understood: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everything is according to the height of the fir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> he initially kindled. If it was a small fire he is not liable to pay for damage caused by it if it traveled far, whereas if he started a large fire, he is liable even if it traveled a great distance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon. And so Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who kindles a stack </span>of wheat or barley <span class="gemarra-regular">and there were vessels </span>concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">and they </span>caught fire and <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>together with the stack, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The one who kindled the fire also <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for what was inside </span>the stack, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Rabbis say: He pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the stack of wheat or barley, </span>as the case may be, and he is not responsible for that which was concealed within it.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a goat tied to </span>the stack of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there was a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave nearby </span>who was not tied to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>both the goat and the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">were burned </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the stack and killed, the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation for both. Conversely, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">slave was tied </span>to the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a goat nearby </span>that was not tied to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they were both <span class="gemarra-regular">burned together with it,</span> the one who kindled the fire is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from payment for damage because he is liable to receive capital punishment for murder, and he is punished only for the greater transgression.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda and exempt one from payment for vessels concealed inside the stack in the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">concede to Rabbi Yehuda </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sets fire to a building</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything that was </span>burned <span class="gemarra-regular">inside it, since it is the </span>normal <span class="gemarra-regular">way of people to place </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">in houses.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda concerning vessels concealed in a stack is referring specifically to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one kindled </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">on his own </span>premises <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">spread and consumed </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">on another’s </span>property. In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>the one who kindled the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed </span>articles damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Rabbis exempt </span>him. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>a case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">kindles </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">on another’s </span>premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">everything that is </span>contained <span class="gemarra-regular">within it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: If so, </span>that the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda in the case of one who kindles the fire on the premises of another, then <span class="gemarra-regular">rather than teaching the latter clause </span>that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sets fire to a building he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything </span>that was burned <span class="gemarra-regular">inside it, since it is the </span>normal <span class="gemarra-regular">way of people to place </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">in houses, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> instead <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish and teach </span>the concession of the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">the same </span>case of one setting fire to a stack: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he kindled the fire on his own </span>premises <span class="gemarra-regular">and it spread and consumed </span>a stack <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the premises of <span class="gemarra-regular">another. But if he kindled </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>property belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another, all agree that he pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything that was </span>contained <span class="gemarra-regular">within it.</span> Since the mishna is not worded in this manner, it seems that this is not the opinion of the Rabbis.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to two </span>issues: <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span>with regard to the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">kindles a fire on his own </span>premises <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it then <span class="gemarra-regular">spreads and consumes </span>a stack <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>property belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another, as Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">for a concealed </span>article damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but the Rabbis hold </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable. And they disagree also </span>in the case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who kindles a fire on </span>premises belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another, as Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything within it, even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a purse </span>of money if it was concealed within the stack, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Rabbis hold </span>that it is only for <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels that are typically concealed inside a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stack, such as threshing tools or yokes for cattle, that he must pay </span>compensation, but for <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>or other items <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not typicall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concealed inside a stack </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who kindles a stack and there were vessels inside it </span>that were <span class="gemarra-regular">burned, Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The one who kindled the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything that was inside it, but the Rabbis say: He pays</span> compensation only for the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a stack of wheat or a stack of barley, </span>and he does not pay compensation for the vessels. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views the place </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">the vessels </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">as if it were filled with grain, </span>and calculates the amount of compensation accordingly.

<span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is in a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">kindled a fire on his </span>premises <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">spread and burned </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>premises belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another. But </span>with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">kindles a fire on </span>premises belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>that destroys a stack of wheat, <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">everything that was inside </span>the stack.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda concedes to the Rabbis that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">lends space to another </span>in his field <span class="gemarra-regular">to stack grain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>this person <span class="gemarra-regular">stacked </span>grain in the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and concealed </span>items inside the stack, if the owner of the field causes the stack to be burned down, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays compensation for the stack alone, </span>since the other person did not have permission to conceal items inside his stack. Similarly, if one received permission <span class="gemarra-regular">to stack wheat</span> in the field of another <span class="gemarra-regular">and he stacked barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> or conversely, if he received permission to stack <span class="gemarra-regular">barley and he stacked wheat; </span>or similarly, if he stacked <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and covered </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">with barley, </span>or stacked <span class="gemarra-regular">barley and covered </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">with wheat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in all these cases, Rabbi Yehuda concedes <span class="gemarra-regular">that he pays </span><span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">barley alone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is less than the value of wheat.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives a gold dina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for safekeeping <span class="gemarra-regular">and says to her: Be careful with this </span>dinar because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>made of <span class="gemarra-regular">silver, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>herself <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged </span>the dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">she must pay </span>compensation for the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gold dinar. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to her: What </span>business <span class="gemarra-regular">did you have damaging it? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she was negligent </span>and it was lost or stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">she pays </span>as compensation only the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a silver </span>dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">since she </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">undertook to safeguard only a silver </span>dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I did not undertake to safeguard a gold </span>dinar.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: You teach this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> as a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, </span>but for <span class="gemarra-regular">us </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> that taught: If one stacked <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and covered </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">with barley, </span>or stacked <span class="gemarra-regular">barley and covered </span>the stack <span class="gemarra-regular">with wheat, </span>the one responsible for the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">pays compensation</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the barley alone. Evidently, </span>the one who kindled the fire can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the stack: <span class="gemarra-regular">I undertook to safeguard </span>a stack of <span class="gemarra-regular">barley </span>but not a stack of wheat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the case of a golden dinar presented as a silver dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>woman <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I did not undertake to safeguard a gold </span>dinar.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: I heard </span>a halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>in connection <span class="gemarra-regular">with Rabbi Yehuda’s </span>opinion in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">but I do not know</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what it is. Shmuel said: And does Abba, </span>which was Rav’s name, really <span class="gemarra-regular">not know what he heard? </span>This is the statement that he heard: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for concealed </span>articles damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">applied the ordinance of a robbery victi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>one whose concealed items are damaged by <span class="gemarra-regular">his fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Just as the Sages instituted an ordinance that a robbery victim can take an oath as to what was stolen from him and the robber must repay him accordingly, similarly, according to Rabbi Yehuda the owner of the stack can take an oath that certain items were inside the stack, and the one responsible for the fire must pay compensation for them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar asks: </span>Did <span class="gemarra-regular">they apply </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of a robbery victim in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an informe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> who causes another person’s property to be confiscated by the gentile authorities, <span class="gemarra-regular">or not? </span>The question is clarified: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not judge </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not ask </span>the question, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>according to that opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">we also do not judge </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">informers </span>who cause indirect damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, when you ask </span>this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we judge </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action, and the question is: Did the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">apply the ordinance of a robbery victim to </span>one whose items were taken due to an <span class="gemarra-regular">informer,</span> meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">can take an oath </span>to support his claim with regard to what was taken <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>this amount in compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">or not? </span>No conclusion was reached about this, and the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
An incident was related about <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who kicked a saf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belonging to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">sending it </span>flying <span class="gemarra-regular">into the river. The owner </span>of the safe <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: I had such and such inside it. Rav Ashi sat and was investigating </span>the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">In a case like this, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does the court believe the claimant or not?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Is this not </span>identical to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, as we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sets fire to a building,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for everything that was </span>burned <span class="gemarra-regular">inside it, since it is the </span>normal <span class="gemarra-regular">way of people to place </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">in houses? </span>Similarly, it is the normal way of people to place money in a safe, and the court should rely on the claim of the victim.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">were to claim </span>that there were <span class="gemarra-regular">coins</span> in the safe, this ruling would apply <span class="gemarra-regular">here also. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">with what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">claims </span>that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a pearl [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">marganita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in the safe. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do people </span>typically <span class="gemarra-regular">place pearls in a safe, </span>in which case he should be believed, <span class="gemarra-regular">or not? </span>The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: </span>If the one whose home was burned by the fire were to <span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>that he had, among other items, <span class="gemarra-regular">a silver goblet in the building</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is he believed or not? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We view </span>his situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he is a wealthy person, who </span>would typically <span class="gemarra-regular">have a silver goblet, or alternatively, if he is a trustworthy person with whom people entrust </span>valuable items, he <span class="gemarra-regular">can take an oath </span>that this is what he had <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>compensation according to his claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>such a person, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in his </span>power to be believed in such a claim.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: </span>Concerning two terms used to describe those who take another’s property against his will, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gazlan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥamsan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥamsan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gives mone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> for the article that he takes from its owner, albeit against the owner’s will, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gazlan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not give money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rav Adda was puzzled by this response and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If he gives money, do you </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">call him a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥamsan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Since he pays money for it, he acquires it lawfully, despite the fact that its owner did not sell it voluntarily. <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Huna say: </span>If one was <span class="gemarra-regular">strung up </span>so that another could coerce him to sell a certain item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. </span>This indicates that a sale under duress is considered a valid sale. Rav Ashi answered: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>case, where the sale under duress is legally considered to be a sale, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I want </span>to sell the item, despite having been forced. By contrast, in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where the sale is invalid, <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say: I want </span>to sell the item. 

Daf 62b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a spar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that emerged from under the hamme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of a blacksmith and started a fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">causing damage, </span>the blacksmith is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the damage caused.
In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a camel that was lade</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with flax and was passing through the public domain, and its flax extended into a store and </span>the flax <span class="gemarra-regular">caught fire from a lamp </span>in the store <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to the storekeeper, and </span>as a result of the burning flax the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">set fire to the building </span>together with all its contents, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the camel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>But if <span class="gemarra-regular">the storekeeper placed his lamp outside,</span> thereby causing the flax on the camel to catch fire, and consequently the building was set on fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">the storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. Rabbi Yehuda says: In </span>a case where the lamp placed outside was <span class="gemarra-regular">a Hanukkah lamp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the storekeeper is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>since it is a mitzva for a Hanukkah lamp to be placed outside.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said in the name of Rava: Conclude from Rabbi Yehuda’s </span>statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mitzva is to place the Hanukkah lamp within </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths from the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if it enters your mind </span>to say that the mitzva can also be fulfilled by placing it <span class="gemarra-regular">above ten handbreadths, why did Rabbi Yehuda say that </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Hanukkah lamp </span>placed outside, the storekeeper is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? Let </span>the owner of the camel <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the storekeeper: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should have placed </span>the lamp <span class="gemarra-regular">above the </span>height <span class="gemarra-regular">of a camel and its rider </span>so that the flax would not catch fire. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>here that Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mitzva is to place it within ten handbreadths </span>of the ground and not higher?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>there is no proof from here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>that one may place a Hanukkah lamp <span class="gemarra-regular">even above </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, and as for <span class="gemarra-regular">what you said, </span>that the owner of the camel can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should have placed </span>the lamp <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>the height <span class="gemarra-regular">of a camel and its rider, </span>in response to this one can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the store owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is performing a mitzva </span>by placing his Hanukkah lamp outside, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not trouble him to such an extent </span>to have him place his lamp at a height that would be inconvenient for him to reach.
Further on the subject of the height of a Hanukkah lamp, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Natan bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Minyumi taught in the name of Rabbi Tanḥum: A Hanukkah lamp that is placed higher than twenty cubits </span>from the ground is <span class="gemarra-regular">unfit </span>to be used for the mitzva, since people do not generally look up to such a height, and the main purpose of the Hanukkah lamp is for it to be seen by others. In this regard, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the height of a Hanukkah lamp is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the height of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the height of a cross beam at the entrance to <span class="gemarra-regular">an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are unfit for their respective purposes if they are higher than twenty cubits.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The principle of double payment </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span><span class="gemarra-regular">broadl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">than the principle of fourfold or fivefold payment, as the principle of double payment applies both to </span>the theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">something that is alive and to </span>the theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">something that is not alive, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but the principle of fourfold or fivefold payment applies only to </span>the theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox or a sheep, as it is stated: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, and slaughter it or sell it, </span>he shall pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep” (Exodus 21:37).
Having stated a limitation to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of fourfold and fivefold payment, the mishna mentions a further limitation, which applies to all three types of payments. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">after a thie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> has already stolen it, i.e., one who steals a stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the thief or to the prior owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor does one who slaughters or sells </span>an ox or a sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">after a thief </span>has already stolen it <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>Rather, he pays only the principal, i.e., the value of the item he stole.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches one particular difference between double payment and fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">while it does not teach </span>this difference between them: <span class="gemarra-regular">The principle of double payment applies both in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the case of a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit entrusted to him and who takes an oath to that effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the principle of fourfold or fivefold payment applies only in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span>not in the case of one who falsely claims that a deposit was stolen.
The fact that the mishna does not teach the latter distinction <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole a <span class="gemarra-regular">deposit </span>from him, and it is discovered that he himself is the thief, he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. </span>And if the stolen item is an ox or sheep and <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>According to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, there is no difference between the applications of double payment and fourfold or fivefold payment in this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of this discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, as Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole a <span class="gemarra-regular">deposit </span>from him, and it is discovered that he himself is the thief, he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. </span>And if the stolen item is an ox or sheep, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
The Gemara rejects the inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>double payment and fourfold or fivefold payment except for the one mentioned in the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It teaches </span>merely that the principle of double payment applies <span class="gemarra-regular">more broadly </span>than the principle of fourfold or fivefold payment, and it provides an example of this statement. This does not mean that this is the only difference, and it is possible that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>this one case <span class="gemarra-regular">and omitted </span>others.
§ The mishna teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that the principle of double payment applies </span>both to the theft of something that is alive and to the theft of something that is not alive. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the verse that discusses double payment: “For any matter of trespass, whether it be for an ox, for a donkey, for a sheep, for a garment, or for any manner of lost thing about which one shall say: This is it, the claims of both of them shall come before the judges, the one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">“For any matter of trespass” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">generalization; “whether it be for an ox, for a donkey, for a sheep, for a garment” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail. </span>And when the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or for any manner of lost thing,” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it then generalizes </span>again.
Consequently, this verse contains <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">detail, and a generalization</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and one of the thirteen rules of exegesis states that in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">you may deduce </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the detail. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>each of the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> detail </span>is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as an item that is movable property and </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>double payment is practiced with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any item that is movable property and </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Land is excluded</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is not movable property. </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves are excluded, as they are compared to lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in many areas of <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. Financial <span class="gemarra-regular">documents are excluded, as, although they are movable property, they do not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value. The value of the material on which the document is written is negligible; documents are valuable only because they serve as proof for monetary claims. Finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">is exclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written </span>in the verse that the one found liable shall pay double to <span class="gemarra-regular">“his neighbor,” </span>i.e., to another person, rather than to the Temple treasury.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of double payment is limited to cases similar to the details mentioned in the verse, it should also be derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>each of the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail</span> is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as an item whose carcass transmits impurity through contact and carrying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too any item whose carcass transmits impurity through contact and carrying </span>it is subject to double payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But birds, </span>whose carcasses do not transmit impurity through contact or carrying, should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be subject to double payment.
The Gemara objects to the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">But how can you say this? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t “garment” written </span>in the list of specified items (Exodus 22:8)? It is impossible to speak of the impurity of carcasses with regard to clothing. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say, </span>in response to this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are speaking </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">of animals, </span>and this is the question that was asked: Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to animals, </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose carcass transmits impurity through contact and carrying, yes, </span>it is subject to double payment, whereas an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose carcass does not transmit impurity through contact and carrying, </span>such as a bird, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>a thief would not pay double payment for stealing it? 

Daf 63a

This line of reasoning is correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">because we expound each on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the listed items in the <span class="gemarra-regular">generalization, and detail, </span>and generalization <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself. </span>Each item is treated individually as representing a category, but the different items are not grouped together into one broad category. Since several animals are listed, it is concluded that if the stolen item is an animal it must resemble the listed animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">birds </span>do not transmit impurity through contact or carrying, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>subject to double payment.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, let the Merciful One write </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">one detail, </span>i.e., animal, and that would have been enough to teach that animals are subject to double payment only if they transmit impurity through contact and carrying, so birds are excluded. Since the Torah listed several animals, birds are included.
The Gemara questions this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>individual animal <span class="gemarra-regular">should the Merciful One have written?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If the Merciful One had written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox,” I would say </span>that only an animal that is similar to an ox, in that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is sacrificed on the altar, yes, </span>it is subject to double payment. But an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not sacrificed on the altar, no, </span>it is not subject to double payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the Merciful One had written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey,” I would say </span>that only an animal that is similar to a donkey, in that its firstborn male offspring is <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred with </span>the sanctity of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yes, </span>it is subject to double payment. But an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not sacred with </span>the sanctity of <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn, no, </span>it is not subject to double payment. The principle of double payment would then include cattle, sheep, goats, and donkeys, but not other animals (see Exodus 13:13 and Deuteronomy 15:19).
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>in answer to this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the Torah had wished to limit double payment to cases where cattle, sheep, goats, or donkeys were stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” and “donkey”; why do I </span>need the verse to mention <span class="gemarra-regular">“sheep”? Conclude from it </span>that the Torah intends <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>even animals that do not meet these criteria, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">birds.</span>
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But say </span>that the verse mentions sheep in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">kosher birds, </span>which are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">shee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> listed in the verse, in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a carcass of these birds <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>both the one who eats it and his <span class="gemarra-regular">garments </span>ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure </span>when it passes through his <span class="gemarra-regular">esophagus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the carcass of a sheep also transmits ritual impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">But non-kosher birds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose </span>carcasses <span class="gemarra-regular">do not have ritual impurity </span>at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they do not render </span>either the one who eats them or his <span class="gemarra-regular">garments impure </span>when they pass through his <span class="gemarra-regular">esophagus,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no, </span>they are not subject to double payment. The Gemara answers: The word <span class="gemarra-regular">“any [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>in the phrase “for any [<span class="it-text">kol</span>] matter of trespass” is <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> amplification, </span>and serves to include even non-kosher birds in the principle of double payment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is an amplification? But isn’t it </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe, </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written </span>in the verse: “And you shall bestow the money for whatever [<span class="it-text">bekhol</span>] your soul desires, for oxen, or for sheep, or for wine, or for strong drink, or for whatever your soul asks of you” (Deuteronomy 14:26)? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we expound </span>that verse <span class="gemarra-regular">as a generalization, and a detail, </span>and a generalization.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall bestow the money for whatever your soul desires,” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>as no particular type of food is specified. <span class="gemarra-regular">“For oxen, or for sheep, or for wine, or for strong drink,” </span>is a <span class="gemarra-regular">detail, </span>as specific types of food are mentioned. When the verse concludes with <span class="gemarra-regular">“or for whatever your soul asks of you,” it has generalized again. </span>Since the verse is formulated as <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> detail, and a generalization, you may deduce </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the detail. </span>This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>each of the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as the produce of produce, </span>i.e., they grow from a parent organism, e.g., agricultural produce or animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">grown from the ground,</span> i.e., their sustenance comes from the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>the category of items one may purchase with second-tithe money includes <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>items that are <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce of produce and are grown from the ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>in answer to this question that the term <span class="gemarra-italic">bekhol</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>whereas the term <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is an amplification. And if you wish, say </span>an alternate answer: The word <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span> is usually <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> generalization. But </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the verse concerning double payment (Exodus 22:8), is an exception. It is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification, </span>as the Gemara will explain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">After all, </span>there is another <span class="gemarra-regular">generalization, and a detail, and a generalization written at the beginning </span>of this passage, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“If a man gives his neighbor money or vessels to safeguard and it was stolen from the house of the man, if the thief shall be found he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man gives his neighbor” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization. “Money or vessels” is a detail. </span>When the verse concludes <span class="gemarra-regular">“to safeguard,” it has generalized again.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>later verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For any matter of trespass” </span>(Exodus 22:8), <span class="gemarra-regular">is also coming </span>to state <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, </span>and a generalization, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write these details, </span>i.e., ox, donkey, sheep, and garment, which are cited in the later verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">together with that </span>previous <span class="gemarra-regular">generalization, and detail, </span>and generalization. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the latter verse beginning with <span class="gemarra-regular">“for any matter of trespass”? Conclude from it </span>that the word <span class="it-text">kol</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is an amplification </span>in this instance, and it includes all animals.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you said </span>that the word <span class="gemarra-italic">kol</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification, why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">all these details </span>listed in the verse, i.e., ox, donkey, sheep, and garment? The Gemara answers: As for the three animals listed, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude land, one to exclude </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, and one to exclude </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">documents. </span>The example of <span class="gemarra-regular">a garment </span>is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude an item that is not </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">delineated </span>in size or quantity. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or for any manner of lost thing” </span>is written <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole

Daf 63b

<span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item </span>that he had found, which he had been obligated to safeguard until it could be returned to its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays double payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “For any manner of lost thing about which one shall say: </span>This is it…the one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8). 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(108b) about a case where an owner of an item said to the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my deposit? </span>The bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you </span>that it was actually lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>thereby accepting the oath; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed </span>the deposit. In this case, the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the principal, </span>i.e., the value of the deposit, to the owner. If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted on his ow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that he stole the deposit before any witnesses testified to this effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the principal and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>of the principal amount to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering </span>to atone for his sin (see Leviticus 5:20–26).
The mishna continues with another case: The owner said to the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my deposit? </span>The bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It was stolen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen; and the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole </span>the deposit. In this case, the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>his theft <span class="gemarra-regular">on his own</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he pays the principal and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering </span>to atone for his sin.
The Gemara says: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays double payment, but in </span>the case of a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">claims that </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost, he does not pay double payment. And </span>it also teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>to substantiate his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">that he pays double payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>for simply lying <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath he does not pay double payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Torah states: “If a man gives his neighbor money or vessels to safeguard and it was stolen from the house of the man, <span class="gemarra-regular">if the thief shall be found </span>he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse is speaking of </span>a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">claims that </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen, or is it </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">only about the thief himself, </span>teaching that if the actual thief is caught he must pay double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in the following verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If the thief shall not be found</span>…the one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:7–8), <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking of one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, as it states that no other thief was found. Since the latter verse is speaking of one who falsely claims that a deposit was stolen, it stands to reason that the earlier verse is speaking of this case as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If the thief shall be found </span>he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6), <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse is speaking of the thief himself. </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that it is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about the thief himself, or is it </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">only about one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole? If so, then <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the verse then <span class="gemarra-regular">says: “If the thief shall not be found</span>…the one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:7–8), the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">stated. How, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the first verse about paying double: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If the thief shall be found,” </span>so that it not be superfluous? It must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">verse is speaking of the thief himself.</span>
The Gemara comments: Although the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> disagree about the meaning of the earlier verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event everyone </span>agrees that the latter verse, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If the thief shall not be not found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yimmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hagannav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span>…shall pay double to his neighbor,” is referring to a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is this interpretation <span class="gemarra-regular">inferred </span>from the verse? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that the verse should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is not found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yimmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">as he said, </span>i.e., if his claim that the deposit was stolen is found to be untrue, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he himself stole it, he shall pay double </span>to his neighbor.
The Gemara turns its attention to another facet of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this double payment of one who falsely claims that the deposit was stolen applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the bailee has taken <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>that it was stolen?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the verse: “If the thief shall not be found, <span class="gemarra-regular">the homeowner shall approach the judges </span>to determine if he laid his hand [<span class="it-text">shalaḥ</span> <span class="it-text">yado</span>] on his neighbor’s goods” (Exodus 22:7). This means that he shall come to court <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath. </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>he comes to court <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath, or is it only for </span>the purpose of facing <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment? </span>The meaning may be determined by means of a verbal analogy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Laying </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">hand [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shliḥut</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],</span> referring to misappropriation, <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated later, </span>in the verse: “The oath of the Lord shall be between them both, to see whether he has not laid his hand [<span class="it-text">shalaḥ</span> <span class="it-text">yado</span>] on his neighbor’s goods” (Exodus 22:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laying the hand is stated above, </span>i.e., Exodus 22:7. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as laying </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">hand later </span>is referring explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">to an oath, so too </span>laying the hand <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to an oath.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> cited earlier: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse about double payment is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">two verses are written, </span>as each verse teaches a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>of the verses <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">two verses? </span>One verse should be sufficient.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Both verses are necessary because <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>from double payment the case of one who falsely states <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>that the item has been <span class="gemarra-regular">lost. </span>Double payment is paid only when the bailee falsely claims that the item under his care was stolen.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about the thief and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, so that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no superfluous </span>verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where does he </span>learn <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>from double payment a bailee who falsely states <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>that the item has been <span class="gemarra-regular">lost? </span>The Gemara answers: He derives it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact that the verse could have stated: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gannav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>shall not be found, but it states instead: “If <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hagannav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>shall not be found.”
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>verses are speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit one of the verses <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes </span>the case of a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">claims that </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost, what does he derive </span>from the fact that the verse did not state: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>shall not be found, but it states instead: “If <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief </span>shall not be found”?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that this terminology <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary to </span>teach <span class="gemarra-regular">what Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>One who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thief </span>stole the <span class="gemarra-regular">deposit pays double payment, </span>and if the deposit was an ox or sheep and <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about a thief and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">who employed this </span>change in terminology, i.e., the fact that the verse could have stated: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>shall not be found, but states instead: “If <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief </span>shall not be found,” <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude</span> the case of a bailee who falsely states the <span class="gemarra-regular">claim that </span>the deposit was <span class="gemarra-regular">lost, </span>there seems to be no source to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated by Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where does he </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, </span>that if the bailee slaughtered or sold the animal he pays a fourfold or fivefold payment?
The Gemara answers: He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: It is a juxtaposition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as liability for double payment for a thief and for a bailee who falsely claims that the deposit was stolen are juxtaposed to each other. Therefore, just as a thief pays a fourfold or fivefold payment if he slaughtered or sold the animal, so must the bailee. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>although these two cases are not entirely comparable, this derivation cannot be refuted on that basis, as there is a principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">one cannot refute </span>a derivation based on <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtapositio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> by drawing distinctions between the two juxtaposed cases.
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the thief and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thief </span>stole the deposit, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well.
