But according to the one who says that both </span>verses are speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where does he </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief himself </span>must pay double payment for stealing?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Let it be derived by an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the case of the bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, because if one is obligated to pay double payment for falsely claiming that a deposit was stolen, which constitutes passive theft, all the more so must a thief himself pay double payment, this derivation is not possible. The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source. </span>In other words, a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived by means of an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference cannot be more stringent than the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the source from which it is derived. Consequently, on the basis of this <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference, it would have to be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as there, </span>in the source case, the double payment is required only when the guilty party took <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath, so too here, </span>when the thief himself pays double, it is only when he took <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>that he did not steal it.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">He derives </span>the obligation of a thief to pay double payment without having taken an oath from a third verse: “If the theft shall be found in his possession alive, whether it is an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:3). The double payment in this verse applies to all items, as is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from what the school of Ḥizkiyya taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As the school of Ḥizkiyya taught: Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” and “theft,” and all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">would be included. </span>Why was it necessary to also mention “donkey” and “sheep”?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse had been written <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have said: Just </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the item mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as </span>an item that <span class="gemarra-regular">is sacrificed on the altar, so too everything that is sacrificed on the altar </span>is subject to double payment, but other items are not. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">is there for you to include </span>in this category? <span class="gemarra-regular">Sheep, </span>which, like oxen, can be sacrificed on the altar. 

Daf 64a

<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states “sheep,” a sheep is thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the detail of “ox” cannot be written to include specifically items that can be sacrificed on the altar, e.g., a sheep. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues to analyze the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox,” “sheep,” and “theft,” and </span>in that manner <span class="gemarra-regular">everything </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">included. </span>Why is it necessary to write “donkey”? <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse been written in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, without “donkey,” <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have said: Just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox” and “sheep,” are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as items that are </span>subject to being <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred with </span>the sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, so too any item that is </span>subject to being <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred with </span>the sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is subject to double payment, but not other items.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is there for you to include </span>in this category? <span class="gemarra-regular">A donkey. When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">says “donkey,” a donkey is thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the details of “ox” and “sheep” cannot be written to include specifically items that are subject to being sacred with the sanctity of the firstborn, e.g., a donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues to analyze the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox,” and “donkey,” </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">“sheep,” and “theft,” and </span>in that manner <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">would be included. </span>Why is it necessary to write the word “alive”? <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse been written in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say: Just </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox,” “sheep,” and “donkey,” are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as </span>items that are <span class="gemarra-regular">animals, so too all animals </span>are subject to double payment, but not inanimate objects.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is there for you to include </span>in this category that is not already listed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Animals other </span>than oxen, sheep, and donkeys. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“alive,” animals are thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the details of “ox,” “sheep,” and “donkey” cannot be written to include animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment. This is the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
There are several puzzling elements of the halakhic exposition of the verse in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara now seeks to explain it in detail. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” and “theft.” </span>The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are “ox” and “theft”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written </span>in the verse in this order, as a generalization and a detail? No, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is “theft” and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” that is written. </span>Consequently, the verse contains a generalization and a detail, in which case the generalization is understood to refer only to that which is specified in the detail.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>that this would be the case <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>the words in this manner, i.e.: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated “ox” and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>all items would have been included; <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you </span>then proceed to <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Just as </span>the item mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox,” is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as </span>an item that can be sacrificed on the altar, so too everything that can be sacrificed on the altar is subject to double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">“Ox” is a detail and “theft” is a generalization, </span>and according to the rules of hermeneutics, in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">the generalization adds to the detail, and all items are included, </span>not just items that resemble the detailed item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>that the verse should be analyzed <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">written: </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft” and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox.” </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you </span>then proceed to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">would be included, or: Just as </span>the item mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail </span>is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>an item that can be sacrificed on the altar, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states? This analysis is applicable only when there is a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization. In this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft” is a generalization and “ox” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail. </span>The rules of hermeneutics state that when there is only <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a detail, there is nothing </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in the generalization other than what is </span>listed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the detail. </span>In this case, one would necessarily conclude that if one steals <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, yes, </span>he is liable to pay the double payment for stealing it, but if one steals <span class="gemarra-regular">anything else, no, </span>there is no double payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava stated </span>an explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> suggested: Let the verse say “ox” and “theft,” and similar suggestions, <span class="gemarra-regular">he was relying on </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“alive” </span>at the end of the phrase. He considered this word an additional generalization after the detailed items, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he was saying </span>that the phrase is to be treated as <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization. </span>Consequently, it should have been sufficient for the verse to state merely “theft,” followed by “ox,” followed by “alive.” Why does the Torah specify further items?
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the latter generalization is not similar to the first generalization. </span>The first generalization, “theft,” is so general that it includes all items, whereas the latter generalization, “alive,” includes only animals. Consequently, the rule of a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization should not apply. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the author of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is of the school of Rabbi Yishmael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who expounds generalizations and details in a case like this. </span>Even if the first generalization and the latter generalization are dissimilar, he interprets the verse as a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization.
Rava continues his explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> found <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>at the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the beginning of the verse to state: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> with the verb repeated? Rava now explains the entire <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, from the beginning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let</span> the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">say “ox” and “theft</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and “alive,” and all </span>items would be <span class="gemarra-regular">included, </span>in accordance with the rules of a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization. Why did the verse include other details?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers this by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse been written in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have said: Just as </span>the item mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox,” is clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as an item that is sacrificed on the altar, so too everything that is sacrificed on the altar </span>is subject to double payment, but not other items. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>else <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>for you <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>in this category? <span class="gemarra-regular">A sheep. When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states “sheep,” a sheep is thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the detail of “ox” cannot be written to include specifically items that can be sacrificed on the altar, e.g., a sheep. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” and “ox” and “sheep” and “alive,” and all </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">would be included. </span>Why is it necessary to write “donkey”? The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse been written in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, without “donkey,” <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have said: Just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox” and “sheep,” are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as items that are </span>subject to being <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred with </span>the sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, so too any item that is </span>subject to being <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred with </span>the sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> is subject to double payment, but not other items.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is there for you to include </span>in this category? <span class="gemarra-regular">A donkey. When</span> the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">says “donkey,” a donkey is thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the details of “ox” and “sheep” cannot be written to include specifically items that are subject to being sacred with the sanctity of the firstborn, e.g., a donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> then asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” and “ox,” and “sheep,” and “donkey” and “alive,” and </span>in that manner <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>items would be <span class="gemarra-regular">included. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse been written in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say: Just</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail, </span>“ox,” “sheep,” and “donkey,” are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as </span>items that are <span class="gemarra-regular">animals, so too all animals </span>are subject to double payment, but not inanimate objects.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is there for you to include </span>in this category that is not already listed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Animals other </span>than oxen, sheep, and donkeys. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states “alive,” animals are thereby stated </span>explicitly. Therefore, the details of “ox,” “sheep,” and “donkey” cannot be written to include animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft,” </span>i.e., what is the category of items derived from the detail and generalization? It must be that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>in the requirement of double payment. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“if </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”? </span>This is the conclusion of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as explained by Rava. 

Daf 64b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if this is how the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is to be understood, <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty </span>it posed <span class="gemarra-regular">is valid, </span>as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> ends with an unanswered question: Why do I need the phrase: “If the theft shall be found”?
The Gemara answers: This phrase is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is a refutation for </span>the derivation cited in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>that it means <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items? From the latter generalization </span>of “alive.” But in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>latter <span class="gemarra-regular">generalization itself </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“alive” is written. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">What does </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization accomplish, </span>i.e., what does it include in the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">items, </span>this cannot be, as the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“alive” is written </span>in the verse, indicating that if one steals <span class="gemarra-regular">animals, yes, </span>he is liable to pay double payment, but if he steals <span class="gemarra-regular">something else, </span>i.e., inanimate objects, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he is not liable to pay double payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to this </span>reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary </span>for the Torah to include the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>which includes all items, through the principle of a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But these </span>repeated verbs <span class="gemarra-regular">are two generalizations that are adjacent to each other </span>in the verse, and the details follow both of the generalizations. Consequently, it is not a case of a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, but rather of a generalization, a generalization, and a detail. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as they say in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any place </span>in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">where you find two generalizations adjacent to each other, place the detail between them and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">treat them as a generalization, and a detail, </span>and a generalization.
The Gemara applies this principle to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Place </span>the first detail, <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox,” between “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” and “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>and treat the verse as a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, so that other items that resemble the detail are included. <span class="gemarra-regular">To include what? If </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include animals, </span>this is not necessary, as animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are derived from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“alive” </span>later in the verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include an item that is not an animal, </span>i.e., inanimate objects, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this is how you should expound </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the items mentioned in <span class="gemarra-regular">the detail</span> are clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">defined as movable property and </span>are items that have <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too anything that is movable property and has intrinsic monetary </span>value is included, to the exclusion of land and financial documents.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>following this method, <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>the next detail, <span class="gemarra-regular">“donkey,” between </span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and treat it as a case of a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, so that other items that resemble the detail are included. <span class="gemarra-regular">To include what? If </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include an item that is not an animal, </span>this is not necessary, as it already was <span class="gemarra-regular">derived from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox.” Rather, </span>it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include an object that is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">delineated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to the exclusion of objects that are not clearly delineated in size or quantity.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>if this is the correct way to analyze the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the verse to state <span class="gemarra-regular">“sheep”? </span>There is nothing left to include. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this whole approach must be rejected, and a new method of analysis applied, as follows: It is not treated as a case of a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>treated as a verse that <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified, restricted, and amplified, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught, </span>concerning the verse: “These may you eat of all that are in the waters: Whatever has fins and scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers” (Leviticus 11:9), as follows: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In the waters,” “in the waters,” two times </span>and only afterward lists the details of seas and rivers. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not </span>expounded as <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, </span>and a generalization, because the detail does not appear between the generalizations. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">restricted, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified, </span>and thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified </span>the general category “waters” to include <span class="gemarra-regular">everything </span>except for “seas” and “rivers,” the specific matter excluded in the restriction, Here too, since the two generalizations are written before the details, it is expounded as an amplification, a restriction and an amplification.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What do </span>the generalizations <span class="it-text">himmatze</span> and <span class="it-text">timmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">include? </span>Do they <span class="gemarra-regular">include all items? If so, why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">all these details </span>of ox, sheep, and donkey? <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>detail serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude land, and one </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, and one </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">documents. </span>The words <span class="gemarra-regular">“theft” and “alive [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayyim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>do not serve to exclude further items from double payment, but <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>indicate the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says: </span>If one stole an item, and it deteriorated or its value decreased, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">revive [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aḥayah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the principal </span>to the value it had <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, i.e., he must repay the owner according to the value of the item at the time it was stolen.
§ Until this point, the Gemara has been discussing the source of the obligation of a thief to pay double payment according to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (63b) that maintains that both verses (Exodus 22:6–7) are referring to a bailee who falsely claims that a deposit was stolen from him. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the two verses <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about a thief and one </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he derives </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief himself</span> must pay double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“if the thief shall be found” </span>(Exodus 22:6), <span class="gemarra-regular">what does he derive from this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be found” </span>(Exodus 22:3)?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires </span>this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava bar Ahilai, as Rava bar Ahilai says: What is the reason </span>for the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, who says: </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>which indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it is found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] through witnesses </span>that he is liable to pay the fine of double payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">it will be found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>that the fine will be enforced <span class="gemarra-regular">by judges. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes </span>from double payment the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who incriminates himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> by admitting his liability before any witnesses testify concerning him, and the same is applied to all cases that involve fines.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both</span> verses are speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">who applies this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found,” to the thief himself, from where do we </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who incriminates himself </span>is exempt from paying double payment or any other fine? The Gemara answers: He derives it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The one whom the judges convict </span>shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8), which indicates that only one who is convicted by the judges on the basis of testimony must pay double, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not one who incriminates himself.</span>
The Gemara continues its line of questioning: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about a thief </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">who derives from: “If </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found” that one who incriminates himself </span>is exempt from payment of the fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does he expound from this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The one whom the judges convict </span>shall pay double to his neighbor”? He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: That </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary to </span>teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>his liability to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment if witnesses never come to testify against him. “If the theft shall be found” indicates that even if witnesses do come after he admitted his liability, he is exempt from paying the fine.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>verses <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thief </span>stole the deposit, and, as explained previously, derives from “if the theft shall be found” that a thief is required to pay double payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, and afterward witnesses came </span>and testified to his liability, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay the fine, contrary to the opinion of Rav.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>verse is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">who derives </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of double payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief from there, </span>i.e., from the verse “if the thief shall be found” (Exodus 22:6), there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“if </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found” </span>is required <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>teaching the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Ahilai. But why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">all these details, </span>“ox,” “donkey,” “sheep,” and “alive”? All the items excluded from double payment, such as land and slaves, are already derived from a different source.
The Gemara answers: This may be explained <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Any passage that was stated </span>in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">and was </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">repeated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was repeated only for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter that was introduced </span>for the first time in the repeated passage. That is, sometimes the Torah repeats an entire passage just for the sake of a single new detail. The single new detail derived from this passage is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one who admits that he is liable to pay a fine is exempt from paying the fine, which is derived from the words: “If the theft shall be found.”
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>since the two cases of a thief and a bailee who falsely claims the deposit was stolen are juxtaposed, as their obligations to pay double payment are expressed in consecutive verses, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief himself </span>is not obligated to pay double payment unless he falsely confirms his innocence <span class="gemarra-regular">with an oath, </span>just as a bailee is liable to pay double payment only under these circumstances.
The Gemara answers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says </span>that the phrase “if the theft shall be found…<span class="gemarra-regular">he shall pay double” </span>indicates that a thief pays double even <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Ya’akov elaborates: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>the verse obligates every thief, even <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>his taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath? Or </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>of a thief who falsely confirms his innocence <span class="gemarra-regular">with an oath? You </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">say: This </span>second possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>the Torah’s intent.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">This was not </span>the Torah’s intent? What is the proof that the Torah could not have meant that only a thief who falsely confirms his innocence with an oath pays double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>If this was the Torah’s intent, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One not write “he shall pay double” with regard to a thief </span>at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let it be derived through an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the case of a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, as follows: If, in the case of a bailee who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">for whom the </span>deposit initially <span class="gemarra-regular">came into his possession in a permitted </span>fashion, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states that he must pay double, </span>then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief himself, for whom </span>the stolen object <span class="gemarra-regular">came into his possession in a prohibited manner </span>from the start, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>that he must pay double payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the words <span class="gemarra-regular">“he shall pay double,” which the Merciful One wrote concerning a thief himself? </span>It must be that the verse adds to the requirement of double payment for a thief and indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he must pay double <span class="gemarra-regular">even without </span>having taken <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does this </span>verse, which states <span class="gemarra-regular">“if </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found” </span>and concludes “he shall pay double,” <span class="gemarra-regular">come for this </span>purpose? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it required for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “If the theft shall be found in his possession.” From the term “in <span class="gemarra-regular">his possession </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ado</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>

Daf 65a

<span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>a case where the stolen item is found in <span class="gemarra-regular">his hand </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ado</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> From where </span>do I derive that the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies if it is found on <span class="gemarra-regular">his roof, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">his yard, or </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">his enclosure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vekarpeifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The verse states </span>the repetitive phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“if </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be found [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>to indicate that the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case, </span>i.e., in any location that the stolen item is found.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if this is all the phrase is coming to teach, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse state </span>the identical word twice: <span class="gemarra-italic">Himmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">himmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Timmatze</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">timmatze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. From </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse varied </span>its wording, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude two </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from it: </span>That one is liable to pay double payment regardless of where the stolen item was found, and that a thief pays double payment even if he did not take an oath.
§ The Gemara returns to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Rav says: </span>When a thief makes his payments, the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal </span>is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, whereas the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>are calculated <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason, </span>i.e., the source, for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“If the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>shall be found in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">alive, </span>whether it is an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">Why is the Merciful One saying “alive [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayyim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” in </span>the context of this <span class="gemarra-regular">theft? </span>This juxtaposition serves to teach: When making payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">revive [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aḥayah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the principal </span>to the value it had <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav was sleepy and lying dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to rest, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Rav Sheshet meant that this is a careless ruling, as it is contrary to a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the animal was stolen when it was <span class="gemarra-regular">lean and </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">fattened it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment according to </span>the value of the animal as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it. This shows that the double payment and the fourfold and fivefold payment are applied in accordance with the value of the item at the time of the theft, not its value at the time of trial, as claimed by Rav.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not a refutation of Rav’s opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">could say to </span>the owner of the animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">I fattened </span>the animal myself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and will you take </span>for yourself  the added value from its fattening? In this particular case, Rav would agree that all payments are in accordance with the value of the item at the time of the theft.
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that apparently contradicts Rav’s ruling. If the animal was stolen when it was <span class="gemarra-regular">fat and the thief caused it to become lean</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the value of the animal as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it. The double and fourfold and fivefold payments are not paid in accordance with the value at the time of the trial, as claimed by Rav.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There too, </span>there is a reason for this exception, <span class="gemarra-regular">because we say of </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is it to me </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he killed it partially? </span>By causing the animal to become lean, the thief is considered to have started to put it to death. Consequently, when he ultimately kills the animal, he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment according to its value when he first began to weaken it, i.e., at the time of the theft. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav says </span>his ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is saying </span>it only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">appreciation </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">and depreciation </span>in value, not to changes in the animal’s physical state.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case referred to by Rav? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that initially </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">was worth one dinar and in the end it was worth four dinars, </span>and Rav teaches that the thief pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal according to </span>the value of the animal as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, which is one dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall we say that Rav disagrees with this </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba? As Rabba says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who robbed another of a barrel of wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially worth one dinar and ultimately it was worth four dinars, </span>and after its appreciation the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">broke </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">or drank </span>the wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays four </span>dinars. If the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">broke by itself, he pays one dinar. </span>Rabba holds that even the principal is paid according to the time when he broke the barrel. 
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response that Rav agrees with Rabba with regard to the above case. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> his <span class="it-text">halakha</span> he is referring to a case where, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>the item was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially worth four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately was worth one dinar. </span>In this situation, Rav maintains that the thief does not profit from the decrease in the value of the principal. Rather, he pays the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal according to </span>its value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina teaches </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in support of Rav: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a homeowner </span>acting as a bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the <span class="gemarra-regular">deposit, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>as to the truth of his claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>that he was lying and that he in fact took the item himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at some point <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified that the bailee himself had the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he admitted </span>his guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">before the witnesses came </span>and testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth, and </span>he must also bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if he admitted </span>his guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">after witnesses came </span>and testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering, and his </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth is covered by his double payment </span>that he pays; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the statement of Rabbi Ya’akov. </span>

Daf 65b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>It is written concerning a bailee who falsely claims innocence with regard to a deposit entrusted to him: “He shall restore it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to its principal, and </span>shall add <span class="gemarra-regular">its fifth part </span>to it” (Leviticus 5:24). This verse teaches that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is paid </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the principal, one adds one-fifth, </span>but for <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution that is not paid </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the principal, </span>as is the case here, where the bailee pays double the principal value, <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not add one-fifth. Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: </span>Neither the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth nor </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering is pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a case where there is double payment. </span>This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
Rabbi Ḥanina explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: His </span>payment of the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth is covered by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his double payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Ya’akov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>the stolen item was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially worth four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately, </span>at the time of trial, was still <span class="gemarra-regular">worth four </span>dinars, how could he say: <span class="gemarra-regular">His </span>payment of the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth is covered by his double payment?</span>
This statement is inaccurate in this case, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment, </span>i.e., the penalty included in the double payment, is <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth is one dinar. </span>When the Torah states “fifth” it means one-fifth of the total payment of the one-fifth and the principal together, i.e., one-quarter of the principal. For the additional one-fifth to be covered by the double payment, the two must be exactly equal, which is not the case here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a situation where <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and at the end </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one dinar, as the </span>penalty component of the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">one dinar and the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>is also <span class="gemarra-regular">one dinar?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal, </span>as well as the additional one-fifth, is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole, </span>whereas the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial, </span>as claimed by Rav.
The Gemara refutes this analysis. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> could be referring to a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and now, </span>at the time of trial, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">also worth four </span>dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">what is difficult </span>with this case, namely that <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">one dinar, </span>this problem can be resolved as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>that the deposit was stolen from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he again took </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and so on <span class="gemarra-regular">four times, and </span>after each oath <span class="gemarra-regular">he admitted </span>afterward that he had lied. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Torah said: “And </span>shall add <span class="gemarra-regular">its fifth part [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥamishitav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to it” (Leviticus 5:24).
Rava continues: The term <span class="it-text">ḥamishitav</span> is in the plural, which indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah included </span>the possibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">many </span>payments of an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a single principal. </span>In other words, each time the bailee takes a false oath he becomes obligated to pay an additional one-fifth, despite the fact that each oath concerns the same item. Since he did so four times, and the one-fifth is actually one-quarter of the principal, the total amount of payments of the additional one-fifth is equal to the principal, which is the same as the penalty component of the double payment.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Sages say: </span>“He shall restore it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to its principal, and </span>shall add <span class="gemarra-regular">its fifth part </span>to it” (Leviticus 5:24). This verse teaches that for <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution that is paid </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the principal, one adds one-fifth. </span>But for <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution that is not paid </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the principal, one does not add one-fifth. </span>The Gemara infers: He does not add one-fifth, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he </span>is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">bring a guilt-offering.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: </span>“He shall restore it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to its principal, and </span>shall add <span class="gemarra-regular">its fifth part </span>to it.” This indicates that the additional one-fifth is linked to the payment of the precise amount of the principal amount. If so, with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilt offering as well, </span>he should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay, </span>i.e., bring it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“He shall restore it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to its principal, and </span>shall add <span class="gemarra-regular">its fifth part </span>to it…<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his guilt-offering [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’et</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ashamo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>he shall bring to the Lord” (Leviticus 5:24–25). The verse links the guilt-offering to the payment of the precise amount of the principal, just like it does the additional one-fifth.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>in response: The superfluous word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> in the phrase “and his guilt offering [<span class="it-text">ve’et</span> <span class="it-text">ashamo</span>]” <span class="gemarra-regular">divides the verse. </span>Therefore, only the additional one-fifth payment, but not the guilt-offering, is linked to the payment of the precise amount of the principal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, </span>who maintains that this bailee is exempt from a guilt-offering as well, how would he respond to the Sages’ argument concerning “<span class="it-text">et</span>”? He would point out that the term in question is actually <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>consisting of the word <span class="it-text">et</span> preceded by the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span>, meaning “and.” The conjunction <span class="gemarra-regular">joins </span>the clauses of <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse. </span>Therefore, both the additional one-fifth payment and the guilt-offering are linked to the payment of the precise amount of the principal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis </span>would respond to Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai’s claim and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you: </span>If the Torah had intended that the two issues should be joined together, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write neither </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in response to this argument: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not possible</span> for the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">to have not written </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,”</span> as this term is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">to separate between property </span>belonging to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High, </span>i.e., the guilt-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">and non-sacred property, </span>i.e., that of a Jew. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>as the verse had to use “<span class="it-text">et</span>” to indicate this difference, the <span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> comes </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">joins </span>the clauses of the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse.</span>
§ The Gemara discusses other cases in which an object undergoes a change after it has been stolen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ile’a says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole a lamb and it </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">became a ram</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or if he stole <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf and it </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">became a bull, </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">has undergone a change </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, and he has </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it </span>as his own property. Consequently, his obligation of restitution consists of monetary payment rather than giving back the stolen item itself. If he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, it is in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters, </span>or it is <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells,</span> and he is not obligated in the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina raised an objection to Rabbi Ile’a </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole a lamb and it </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">became a ram, </span>of if he stole <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf and it </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">became a bull, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment according to </span>the animal’s value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that in a case of this kind the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>the animal as his own property <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>virtue of the physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>the animal underwent when it matured, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does he pay </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment? After all, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters, </span>or it is <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells.</span>
Rabbi Ile’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Rather, what </span>would you conclude from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">That</span> this physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>in the stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>serve to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it for the thief and render it his property? If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>should he <span class="gemarra-regular">pay according to </span>the animal’s value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him pay according to </span>the animal’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">now, </span>i.e., at the time of the slaughter or sale.
Rabbi Ḥanina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is the reason that he does not pay in accordance with </span>the animal’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">now: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the thief can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the animal’s owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did I steal a bull from you, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did I steal a ram from you? </span>No; I stole only a calf or a lamb, and therefore I will pay you the value of the animal when I stole it. Rabbi Ile’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Ḥanina: <span class="gemarra-regular">May the Merciful One save us from this opinion </span>of yours! Rabbi Ḥanina <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: On the contrary, may the Merciful</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One save us from your opinion!</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira objects to this: But </span>even if an animal’s natural growth is not considered a physical change, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the thief acquire it through </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">change in name, </span>i.e., its change of classification, as the animal was originally called a calf or a lamb and now it is considered a bull or ram.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>There is in fact no change in name here, as even <span class="gemarra-regular">a day-old bull is called a bull, </span>and even <span class="gemarra-regular">a day-old ram is called a ram. A day-old bull is called a bull, as it is written: “When a bull, or a sheep, or a goat is born” </span>(Leviticus 22:27).
<span class="gemarra-regular">A day-old ram</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is called a ram, </span>as can be derived from Jacob’s statement to Laban, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And the rams of your flock I have not eaten” </span>(Genesis 31:38). Now, did Jacob mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not eat </span>any of Laban’s <span class="gemarra-regular">rams, </span>but younger <span class="gemarra-regular">lambs he did eat? </span>This is certainly not the meaning of this verse, as this would mean he was a thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>this verse that <span class="gemarra-regular">a day-old ram is called a ram?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">In any case, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited earlier by Rabbi Ḥanina <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>for the opinion of Rabbi Ile’a, as it states that the thief must pay the fourfold or fivefold payment despite the fact that the slaughter or sale of the animal took place after it matured from a calf to a bull or from a lamb to a ram. To resolve the difficulty, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, who say: </span>An item, even if it has undergone a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change, remains in its place, </span>i.e., a stolen item remains in the possession of its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it even if it undergoes a change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If one gave wheat</span> to a prostitute <span class="gemarra-regular">for her payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the hire of her services, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">made </span>the wheat into <span class="gemarra-regular">flour; </span>or if he gave her <span class="gemarra-regular">olives and </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">made them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">oil; </span>or if he gave her <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes and </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">made them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to bring these products as an offering in the Temple, in accordance with the verse: “You shall not bring the hire of a harlot…into the house of the Lord your God for any vow” (Deuteronomy 23:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that these products are <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, </span>as the physical change renders them into new items. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Guryon of Asporak teaches </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai prohibit </span>these products <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>them. If so, these two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> reflect a dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel.
The Gemara clarifies the source of these two opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason of Beit Shammai </span>for prohibiting these products? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: </span>“You shall not bring the hire of a harlot, or the price of a dog, into the house of the Lord your God for any vow; for even both of these are an abomination to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19). The apparently superfluous word <span class="gemarra-regular">“even” </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include their changed </span>status. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel, </span>who permit these items after they have undergone a physical change, maintain that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“these” </span>in the phrase “both of these” teaches that this prohibition applies only to the original items, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">their changed </span>form.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Shammai </span>would reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">That</span> term, 

Daf 66a

<span class="gemarra-regular"> “these,” comes to </span>teach that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies only to the animals given as payment to the prostitute <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">their offspring. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>from where do <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel </span>derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? They would say that one should <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude two</span> conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“These” </span>items are disqualified, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>when they are in <span class="gemarra-regular">their changed </span>form, <span class="gemarra-regular">and “these” </span>are disqualified, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not their offspring. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, isn’t it written “even”? </span>Since Beit Hillel reject the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that Beit Shammai derive from this term, what do they learn from it? The Gemara states: Indeed, the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“even” is difficult according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel.</span>
In any event, they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree only with regard to</span> this particular issue: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>in a stolen item causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>in a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>of the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays according to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>value of the item, at the time of the theft, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above: <span class="gemarra-regular">He pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment according to </span>the animal’s value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> constitutes <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? As Rav says: </span>When a thief makes his payments, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal according to </span>the value as of the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, whereas the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>are calculated <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of standing trial. Rava said </span>in resolution of this difficulty: If one stole <span class="gemarra-regular">lambs </span>that subsequently became rams or were fattened, he pays the double payment and the fourfold or fivefold payment according to the <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>state of the animal, as claimed by both Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. If there was a change in the animal’s value due to fluctuation of the monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of animals, he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the animal’s worth <span class="gemarra-regular">now</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> at the time of standing trial.
