§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>The principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in a stolen item causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we learned </span>it in a mishna as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written </span>in the Torah: “Then it shall be, if he has sinned, and is guilty, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he shall restore the item that he robbed” </span>(Leviticus 5:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>the seemingly superfluous phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“that he robbed”? </span>This serves to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the item is the same <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stole </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must return </span>the stolen item itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the same as it was then, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay only money, </span>while the stolen item remains his to keep.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a mishna as well, as it is taught (93b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fashions it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, </span>or one who robs another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and fashions it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">garments, he pays </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value of the goods at the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of the robbery, </span>and keeps the altered materials for himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>another mishna can serve as the source for this principle (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 135a): <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one did not manage to giv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the first of the sheared wool of his sheep to a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">he dyed it </span>(see Deuteronomy 18:4), he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from giving it to the priest. This mishna indicates that an item that has undergone a change is no longer considered the same item as it had been. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>in a stolen item causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it.
§ Rabba continues to discuss the ways in which a thief acquires ownership of a stolen item: With regard to the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> over ever recovering the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages say that </span>this too causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the stolen item. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, we do not know if </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law or by rabbinic law.</span>
Rabba elaborates on the two possibilities he has just mentioned: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it is with regard to one who finds a lost item. </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who finds a lost item </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">once </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the item <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs </span>of recovering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">came into </span>the finder’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires it </span>and may keep it for himself? The same principle applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: Once the owner </span>of the item <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs </span>of recovering it, the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires it </span>for himself and need no longer return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>then, the despair of the owner causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the stolen item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the case of a stolen item is <span class="gemarra-regular">not comparable to </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a lost item, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item </span>that the owner’s despair enables the finder to acquire the item, because the item <span class="gemarra-regular">came into his possession in a permitted </span>manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">came into his possession in a prohibited </span>manner, this case cannot be derived from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a lost item. If so, the ruling that despair effects acquisition in a case of theft applies not by Torah law but <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law.</span>
Why would this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> have been instituted by rabbinic law? <span class="gemarra-regular">As, the Sages said that </span>a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">should acquire</span> the stolen item in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to an ordinance </span>instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the penitent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> To encourage thieves to repent and repay their victims, the Sages instituted that they need not return the stolen item after the owner despairs of recovering it. Rather, they can reimburse the owner for the monetary value of the item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef says: Despair </span>on the part of the owner over the possibility of recovering his item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that item at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even by rabbinic law. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef raised an objection to Rabba </span>from a mishna (96b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread and Passover elapse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the meantime, so that deriving benefit from it is prohibited, 

Daf 66b

the robber may nonetheless return the worthless bread to the owner and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: That which is yours</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is before you, </span>and no compensation is required. Rav Yosef states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">once the time of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>of leavened bread <span class="gemarra-regular">arrives, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly despairs </span>of recovering his now-worthless bread. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it enters your mind </span>to say that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>causes the robber to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">he say to him: That which is yours is before you? He should be required to pay </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">full-fledged money </span>rather than return the worthless food, as the bread now belongs to the robber.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>him in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I say </span>that the thief acquires the stolen item upon the owner’s despair of recovery it is when <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs, and that </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to acquire </span>the item. In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs but that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not wish to acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the worthless bread.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised an objection to Rabba </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The verse: “If his offering is a burnt-offering of the herd” (Leviticus 1:3), indicates that one’s offering must be <span class="gemarra-regular">“his offering,” but not </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">stole</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> from another. <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case referred to by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is dealing with a stolen animal that the robber consecrates and sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovery, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse </span>to teach this? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is disqualified, as one cannot even consecrate an animal that does not belong to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to one who seeks to consecrate and sacrifice a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair? </span>And yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that the animal cannot be consecrated by the thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> it, as if it belonged to him he would be able to consecrate and sacrifice it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Abaye in refutation of this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning,</span> consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written with regard to a <span class="it-text">zav</span>, a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge: “And whoever touches his bedding shall wash his clothes and bathe himself in water and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:5). This indicates that bedding on which a <span class="it-text">zav</span> lies can become ritually impure and impart impurity only if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">“his bedding,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but not </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen </span>bedding.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case discussed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that he robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and made it into bedding, is there anyone who says that </span>a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>that results from <span class="gemarra-regular">an action </span>performed to a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire it? Rather, what have you to say? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be speaking of a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the <span class="it-text">zav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">bedding</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> So too, </span>the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with one <span class="gemarra-regular">who robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering, </span>already consecrated. The reason this animal does not atone for the thief is that a consecrated animal cannot be stolen and become the thief’s property, as it belongs to the Temple treasury wherever it is located.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised an objection to Rav Yosef </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 26:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hides belonging to a homeowner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to </span>contracting <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Hides and leather are susceptible to contracting impurity only if they are in a finished state. If a private individual uses a piece of hide or leather for a certain purpose, e.g., as a cot or a table top, and decides that this will be its fixed purpose, it is considered a finished product and is susceptible to contracting impurity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to hides <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to a leatherworker, thought does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>Since this individual sells leather to others, when he uses a piece of leather for a household purpose and decides that this will be its fixed purpose, this is not considered a finished state, as he is likely to change his mind and sell the leather to one who will process it further and put it to a different use.
The mishna continues: If the hides are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a thief, </span>who has stolen them from another, the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>If they are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">thought does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity, </span>because he is not considered the owner of the hide. The difference is that unlike the case of a thief, who steals items stealthily, the identity of a robber, who takes the item openly, is known to the owner, and the owner harbors hope of finding the robber and getting the item back. Consequently, he does not despair of recovering his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the matters are reversed: </span>In the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a robber, </span>the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>If the hides are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a thief, thought does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity, because the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> owners have not despaired </span>of recovering them and the thief has not acquired the hide. Rabbi Shimon’s reasoning is that a robber, who seizes items brazenly, is a more difficult criminal to apprehend and bring to justice than a thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>although the two <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> of the mishna disagree as to which situation involves an owner’s despair of recovery, whether robbery or theft, in any event one can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>this mishna that the <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of the owner causes the thief or robber to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item, as otherwise the perpetrator’s thoughts about the hide would have no effect on its status with regard to ritual impurity. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here </span>in this mishna? It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief or robber <span class="gemarra-regular">trimme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the leather by cutting it. Although trimming a piece of leather is not a sufficient change to constitute an act of acquisition by itself, it is effective in conjunction with the owner’s despair.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan objects to this </span>answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case that <span class="gemarra-regular">they taught </span>this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>with regard to a leather table <span class="gemarra-regular">top [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">itzba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>a leather table <span class="gemarra-regular">top does not require trimming, </span>either due to the fact that its edges are not seen or because it is merely ornamental. Since it does not require trimming, this action should not be considered an act of acquisition at all.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in the previous mishna (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 26:7): <span class="gemarra-regular">Wherever there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no work lackin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> for an item to be considered finished, one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders it susceptible to ritual impurity; when there is </span>still some <span class="gemarra-regular">work lacking </span>for the item to be considered finished, <span class="gemarra-regular">thought does not render it susceptible to ritual impurity,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except for </span>the case of a leather table <span class="gemarra-regular">top</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although further work is required to smooth out the edges, one’s thought can render it susceptible to impurity because people do not care if this leather table top has uneven edges. It is with regard to this case of a table top that the mishna distinguishes between a homeowner and a leatherworker. Therefore, Rav Yosef’s explanation is rejected.
The Gemara suggests a different answer. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter was a difficulty </span>posed by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba to Rav Yosef for twenty-two years, and it was not resolved until Rav Yosef sat as the hea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> of the yeshiva <span class="gemarra-regular">and resolved it </span>in the following manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">A change in nam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of an item, representing a change in status, <span class="gemarra-regular">is similar to </span>a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>brought about by <span class="gemarra-regular">an action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">an action </span>causes the thief to acquire the item? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>the stolen items were <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels. </span>The same can be said for <span class="gemarra-regular">a change in name as well: Initially they called it a hide, and now </span>they call it a table <span class="gemarra-regular">top [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">abrazin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks a question with regard to changes in name: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what about the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where there is a change in name, as initially, </span>when it was stolen, it was called <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam, and now, </span>after it has been placed in a building, it is called <span class="gemarra-regular">a joist [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">telala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 55a): <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a stolen bea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>a robber <span class="gemarra-regular">had built</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into </span>a large <span class="gemarra-regular">building, </span>the court ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>receive <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>value in <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>rather than demand that the robber demolish the house to return the beam itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">because of an ordinance </span>instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the penitent,</span> i.e., to encourage robbers to admit their crime and reimburse the owner of the stolen item.
This mishna indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>the robber does not have to return the beam itself is <span class="gemarra-regular">because of </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance </span>instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the penitent. </span>

Daf 67a

One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if were <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>decree, the beam would have to be <span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>to the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">as is, </span>notwithstanding its change in name. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>This is not a genuine change in name, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam retains its name </span>even after it is inserted into a building. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to two obscure terms: The verse states: “And there were narrow windows and palm trees on the one side and on the other side, on the sides of the porch; there were also the <span class="it-text">tzalot</span> of the house, and the <span class="it-text">ubbim</span>” (Ezekiel 41:26). <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Tzalot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the house”; these are the casings [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hamaltetin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ubbim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”; these are the beams [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hamerishot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>This shows that a beam can retain its name even after it has been built into a house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said </span>a different answer: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change in name, a change </span>in which the item <span class="gemarra-regular">can revert to its original stat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span>considered enough of <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>for the thief to acquire the stolen item. Since the joist can be removed and revert to being called a beam, it is not considered a true change of name.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is a change in name </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not revert to its original state </span>really considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a change? But there is </span>the case of a water <span class="gemarra-regular">duct</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>called <span class="gemarra-regular">a log [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ketzitzta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and now </span>it is called <span class="gemarra-regular">a duct, and it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A duct that one hollowed ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and afterward attached </span>to the ground or to a building <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidates a ritual bath </span>through the water it channels to the bath. The water in a ritual bath must be gathered directly from rain or a stream, not drawn with vessels. If one hollowed out a log and used it to channel water into the bath, this is considered drawn water, as he used a vessel.
By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one attached it </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward hollowed it out, it does not invalidate the ritual bath. </span>Before the log was hollowed out, it was already attached to and considered part of the ground, and therefore the act of hollowing it out does not turn it into a vessel.
The Gemara states its question: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say that a change in name is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter </span>of significance, i.e., it is considered a real change in the item, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if one attached </span>the log first <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> afterward hollowed it out, </span>the ritual bath <span class="gemarra-regular">should also be invalid. </span>Since hollowing out the log leads to a change in name, it should be considered a new vessel at that point.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">drawn </span>water may not be used for a ritual bath <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as it </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and consequently the Sages were lenient in this case. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">even in the first clause, </span>where the log was hollowed out before being attached, it should be permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The Gemara answers: There is a difference between the two cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the first clause, the log <span class="gemarra-regular">had the status of a vessel while </span>it was still <span class="gemarra-regular">detached. Here, </span>in the second case, it did <span class="gemarra-regular">not have the status of a vessel while </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">detached, </span>but only after it became attached to the ground, and therefore the Sages were lenient.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against Rav Yosef’s opinion that the owner’s despair that he will recover his stolen items does not effect acquisition for the thief, from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, a robber, and one who forces </span>people to sell him items against their will, <span class="gemarra-regular">their consecration </span>of the items they obtained in these manners is a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">consecration</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that they separate </span>from the produce they obtained in these manners is valid <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the tithes that they separate </span>from those foods are valid <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes. </span>Consecrations, <span class="it-text">terumot</span>, and tithes must be performed by the owner of the item in question. Since there was no physical change in these items, this shows that the thief is considered the new owner merely by virtue of the owner’s despair of recovery.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>in answer to this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in those cases involving consecrations, <span class="it-text">terumot</span>, and tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a change in nam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">as initially </span>the stolen food was called <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., produce from which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes have not been separated, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now </span>it is called <span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> or tithe. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">consecration, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>called <span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now </span>it is called <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a change </span>in a stolen item causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “And he shall return the stolen item that he took by robbery” </span>(Leviticus 5:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>the seemingly superfluous phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“that he took by robbery”? </span>It teaches that only <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the item is in the same state <span class="gemarra-regular">as when he took it by robbery </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he must return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if not, he is required to pay only money; </span>the stolen item remains his to keep.
The Gemara asks with regard to this derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“That he took by robbery,” is required to exclude </span>the case of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen by one’s father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>when a son returns an item or money that his father had stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not add one-fifth to </span>the principal amount of that which <span class="gemarra-regular">his father stole. </span>The passage in question addresses one who stole and took a false oath. This individual is obligated to add one-fifth to the amount he stole (see Leviticus 5:21–24). The apparently redundant phrase “that he took by robbery,” teaches that the requirement to add one-fifth applies only to the sinner himself, not to his heirs (see 104b).
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the verse teaches only that <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write </span>merely: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he shall return his stolen item, </span>as from that phrase alone it could be derived that an heir does not have to add one-fifth. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">to write </span>the expression <span class="gemarra-regular">“that he took by robbery”? </span>One may therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude two </span>conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this verse: A son need not add one-fifth, and a change in a stolen item effects acquisition for the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of the above statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: From where </span>is it derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “And he shall return the stolen item that he took by robbery” </span>(Leviticus 5:23), from which it may be inferred that he must return it <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case, </span>even if it has undergone a change. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is written “that he took by robbery,” </span>which indicates that, on the contrary, the item need be returned only if it is in a similar state to when it was stolen. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is required </span>to teach another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One adds one-fifth upon</span> returning <span class="gemarra-regular">his own stolen </span>item concerning which he had taken a false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not add one-fifth upon </span>returning something <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen by his father.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering his stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated </span>in the criticism of the Jewish people for bringing inferior animals as offerings: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you have brought that which is stolen, and the lame, and the sick” </span>(Malachi 1:13). From the juxtaposition of these cases it may be derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">a stolen </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is similar to a lame </span>animal: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as a lame </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has no rectification at all </span>with regard to its disqualification as an offering, 

Daf 67b

<span class="gemarra-regular">so too a stolen </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has no rectification </span>for its disqualification. There is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference whether </span>one is dealing with a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. </span>In either case, it is disqualified. This shows that the owner’s despair does not effect acquisition for the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> may be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse: “If his offering is a burnt-offering of the herd” (Leviticus 1:3), indicates that one’s offering must be <span class="gemarra-regular">“his offering,” but not </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen </span>from another. <span class="gemarra-regular">When, </span>i.e., in which circumstances, is it necessary to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is dealing with a stolen animal that the robber consecrated and sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovery, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse </span>to teach this? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that it is disqualified, as one cannot even consecrate an animal that does not belong to him. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to one who seeks to consecrate and sacrifice a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair? </span>And yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that the animal cannot be consecrated by the thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it, as if it belonged to him he would be able to consecrate and sacrifice it. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is so.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rava was the one who said </span>that this proof can be refuted, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be interpreted as dealing with one <span class="gemarra-regular">who robbed another of an offering </span>that was already consecrated. Rava apparently contradicts himself. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">retracted </span>one of these two statements. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa, </span>not Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">said one of these </span>two statements.
§ The Gemara returns to the mishna, which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the principle of fourfold or fivefold payment </span>applies only to the theft of an ox or a sheep, as it is stated: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, and slaughter it or sell it, he shall pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep” (Exodus 21:37).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>is the fourfold and fivefold payment limited to oxen and sheep? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us derive </span>otherwise by a verbal analogy of the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” </span>in this verse and <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” from </span>a passage dealing with <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where it is stated: “And the seventh day is Sabbath to the Lord your God, you shall not perform any labor, you, your son, and your daughter, and your slave, and your maidservant, and your ox, and your donkey, and all your animals, and the gentile that is within your gates” (Deuteronomy 5:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>with regard to Shabbat, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated with regard to an ox is not limited to oxen, as <span class="gemarra-regular">undomesticated animals and fowl are similar to </span>oxen in that they too are included in this prohibition, as the verse states: “Nor any of your animals,” <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>in the case of theft, one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">undomesticated animals and fowl are similar to </span>oxen in that the fourfold or fivefold payment is incurred for their theft.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The verse </span>dealing with theft <span class="gemarra-regular">states “ox” and “sheep,” “ox” and “sheep” twice. </span>This repetition indicates that for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and a sheep, yes, </span>there is a fourfold or fivefold payment, and <span class="gemarra-regular">for other items, no, </span>there is no fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says, </span>with regard to Rava’s assertion that one of the instances of “ox” and “sheep” is superfluous: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>instance of the word “ox” or “sheep” <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">superfluous </span>one? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the instance of <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” and “sheep” at the end </span>of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is superfluous, due to </span>the following consideration: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Merciful One write: If one steal an ox or a sheep, and slaughter it or sell it, he shall pay five oxen for it and four sheep for it, </span>without repeating the words “ox” and “sheep,” this is not possible. <span class="gemarra-regular">If the Merciful One had written </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">like this, I would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to pay nine </span>animals, five oxen and four sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">for each and every </span>animal stolen.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that this interpretation is not possible, as the suggestion is that the verse would have <span class="gemarra-regular">written: For it, for it, </span>twice, whereas if a payment of nine animals were required for each stolen animal the verse would have written: For it, only once; then <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>mention of: <span class="gemarra-regular">For it, is superfluous, </span>to teach us that it is five for an ox and four for a sheep.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>repetition of: For it, <span class="gemarra-regular">is required for another interpretation, </span>and cannot teach that it is five for an ox and four for a sheep. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an expensive <span class="gemarra-regular">ox worth one hundred dinars he may pay </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for it </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">lean, </span>inferior <span class="gemarra-regular">animals [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">negidin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “For </span>the ox” and <span class="gemarra-regular">“for </span>the sheep,” which indicates that the oxen and sheep used for payment must be similar to the stolen animal in quality. Since one might have erred and understood that the thief is required to pay nine animals, five oxen and four sheep, for each and every animal stolen, that suggested version of the verse is not a possibility. The words “ox” and “sheep” at the end of the verse could not have been omitted, so they are not superfluous.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the words <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” and “sheep” in the first </span>part of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">are superfluous, due to </span>the following consideration: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Merciful One write: If a man steal, and slaughter it or sell it, he shall pay five oxen for the ox, and four sheep for the sheep, </span>without mentioning “ox” or “sheep” at the beginning of the verse.
The Gemara objects: It is not possible for the verse to have been written this way, as <span class="gemarra-regular">if the Merciful One had written </span>it in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say: </span>A thief is not required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he steals two </span>animals, an ox and a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughters them </span>both. The Gemara responds: One could not interpret the verse in this manner, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">is written: “And slaughter it.” </span>The singular pronoun “it” is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the slaughter of only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one could <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that a thief is not required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he steals both </span>of these animals, an ox and a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells them </span>both. The Gemara rejects this suggestion in a similar manner: This interpretation is also not possible, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “Or sell it,” </span>which is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the sale of only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>animal.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one could <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>a different interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that a thief is not required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">steals two </span>animals, an ox and a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughters one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one. </span>The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: This interpretation is impossible, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written:</span> “And slaughter it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sell it.” </span>The term “or” indicates that only one of these two actions results in paying the penalty.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But still, </span>had the verse been worded without mentioning an ox or sheep at the start, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say: </span>A thief does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he steals two </span>animals, an ox and a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughters one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">and leaves </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one, or sells one and leaves </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one. </span>It is therefore impossible to omit the words “ox” and “sheep” in the beginning of the verse, which means that these words are not superfluous.
The Gemara gives its final explanation of Rava’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, “ox” at the end </span>of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">and “sheep” in the first </span>part of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">are superfluous, due to </span>the following consideration: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the Merciful One write:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If a man steal an ox and slaughter it or sell it, he shall pay five oxen for it, and four sheep for a sheep. Why do I </span>need the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“ox” at the end </span>of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“sheep” in the first </span>part of the verse? <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>these apparently superfluous words that for <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox and a sheep, yes, </span>a thief is obligated to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, but for stealing <span class="gemarra-regular">other items, no, </span>he is not.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">after a thief </span>has already stolen it, i.e., one who steals a stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the thief or to the prior owner. Rather, he pays the principal amount alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where the second thief stole from the first thief <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering his item. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the second thief stole it <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, the first thief had acquired </span>the stolen item for himself as a result of the owner’s despair, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second thief pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment to the first thief, </span>who at the time of the second theft was its legal owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav was sleepy and lying down </span>to rest <span class="gemarra-regular">he said this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., he did not give it enough thought. This ruling is incorrect, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said: For what reason did the Torah say that </span>if a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>a stolen ox or sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>by selling or slaughtering the animal the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">deeply entrenched in sin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Sheshet analyzes Rabbi Akiva’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>did this sale of the stolen animal take place? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering his property, 

Daf 68a

<span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it possible to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>is any <span class="gemarra-regular">entrenchment </span>in sin? The sale does not take effect, as it occurred before the owner despaired, which means that the thief did not in fact deepen his sin by selling the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that the sale occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And if it enters your mind </span>that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does he pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment? </span>Since the animal belongs to him after the owner’s despair, in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters his own </span>animal or <span class="gemarra-regular">sells his own </span>animal.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>It is possible to explain the term: Entrenched in sin, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The thief is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because he repeated </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sin, </span>i.e., he sinned a second time by going through the motions of the sale, regardless of the fact the sale was not legally binding. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too,</span> one can say that the thief is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">because he repeated </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sin.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter it or sell it” </span>(Exodus 21:37). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as slaughter </span>is an act <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be undone, so too </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>referred to here is an act <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot be undone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Now, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>is a sale irreversible? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>this sale occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair</span> of recovering his stolen animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">why can it not be undone? </span>Since the thief’s sale of the animal before the owner’s despair is ineffective, the sale is easily undone. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be speaking about a case where the thief sold the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And if it enters your mind </span>that a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>a stolen item after the owner’s despair, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does he pay the fourfold or fivefold payment</span> for slaughtering or selling the animal at this point? <span class="gemarra-regular">He slaughters his own </span>animal or <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells his own</span> animal. Apparently, a thief does not acquire the stolen item after the owner’s despair.
The Gemara rejects this proof: The explanation for this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Naḥman said </span>in reference to a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. Rav Naḥman said that when that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> speaks of a sale that cannot be undone, this <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes one who transferred </span>ownership of the animal to another in a temporary manner, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">for thirty days. Here too, </span>one can answer in the same way, that it <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes one who transferred </span>ownership of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for thirty days</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Accordingly, if one sold the animal permanently, even if the sale was performed before the owner despaired and is therefore not legally binding, he is nevertheless required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole it </span>from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only the principal </span>to the first thief. This is because one who steals from a thief does not pay the double payment, as the mishna teaches.
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from the purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the purchaser, who has become the new owner of the animal. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered it, and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole </span>the slaughtered animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment but only the principal, </span>in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one who steals from a thief does not pay the double payment.
The Gemara analyzes this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle clause: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and stole it </span>from the purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the purchaser.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>did this sale occur? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, why does </span>the second thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the purchaser? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there anyone who says that a change in possession </span>of a stolen item, i.e., when it leaves the possession of the thief and enters the possession of another, <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>the additional factor of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, </span>causes the one who has it to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item? There is no such opinion. Therefore, the so-called purchaser of the animal does not become its owner, as the sale is invalid. This should be considered as a case of one who steals from a thief, and consequently there should be no double payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is obvious </span>that the sale occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And if it enters your mind </span>that a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>a stolen item after the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, why </span>should the first thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment? </span>After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his own </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that he sold, </span>having acquired it immediately upon the owner’s despair.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole it </span>from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only the principal </span>to the first thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Now, </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, </span>as the Gemara just established. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>causes the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">second</span> thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay only the principal? </span>After the owner has despaired of recovering his item, the thief becomes the owner of the item, and the second thief should have to pay him double payment for stealing his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: And </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>that the text of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is accurate? But </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole</span> an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and stole </span>the slaughtered animal, the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only the principal </span>to the first thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">And is there anyone who says that </span>a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>brought about by <span class="gemarra-regular">an action does not </span>cause the thief to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item? There is no such opinion; the thief certainly becomes the owner of the animal after slaughtering it. Consequently, the second thief should have to pay the double payment to the thief for stealing his slaughtered animal. It must therefore be concluded that the text of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> has been corrupted and must be reformulated.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, actually the entire</span> <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to the stage <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And </span>you must <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause with </span>that stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle clause, and </span>reverse the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle clause with </span>that stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause, and say like this: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and stole it </span>from the purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only the principal </span>to the purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a change in possession without </span>the additional factor of owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair does not </span>cause one to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the item.
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole</span> an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and stole </span>the slaughtered animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first</span> thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the second </span>thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the first thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the first thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it through the physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>brought about by <span class="gemarra-regular">an action, </span>i.e., slaughter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Actually, do not reverse </span>the middle and last clauses of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. With regard to the difficult <span class="gemarra-regular">last clause, it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, who say: </span>Even if an item has undergone a physical <span class="gemarra-regular">change, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place, </span>i.e., a stolen item remains the property of the owner. A thief never attains ownership of it, even if it undergoes a physical change.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not reversed, and if it is referring to the stage after the owner’s despair, then <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause and the middle clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> present <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, </span>who maintains that after the owner’s despair the item belongs entirely to the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: Actually, the entire </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with the stage <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And with what are we dealing here, </span>in the middle clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the owners despaired </span>of recovering the item when it was already <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the possession of the <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser, but they had not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>when the item was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the possession of the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief. </span>The purchaser is considered the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> after the despair occurred, <span class="gemarra-regular">there were </span>two factors in play, both the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair and a change in possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The combination of these two factors effects acquisition of the item on behalf of the purchaser.
Rav Zevid continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do not say </span>that in the middle clause the reason the owner’s item is acquired by another is only <span class="gemarra-regular">because we require </span>two factors, i.e., the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair and change of possession. Rather, even </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair by itself, </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">is acquired by the thief, </span>in accordance with Rav’s opinion that despair alone effects acquisition on behalf of the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Nevertheless, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> chose a case in which both of these factors are present <span class="gemarra-regular">because you will not find a case in which both of them, the first thief and the second thief, pay </span>a penalty <span class="gemarra-regular">except in such </span>a case. The first thief pays the fourfold or fivefold payment, and the second thief pays the double payment. Had the owner despaired before the sale, the first thief would have been considered the owner and would therefore be exempt from the additional payment.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells </span>a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, despite the fact that the sale is invalid. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from this payment. 
The two <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> explain the reasons for their respective rulings. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>with regard to the fourfold or fivefold payment: “And slaughter it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sell it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), <span class="gemarra-regular">and he has sold it. </span>There <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if the sale occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">before despair, </span>and there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if it takes place <span class="gemarra-regular">after despair.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Sheshet says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">his liability is </span>in effect only if he sells the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, when his action, </span>i.e., the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">is effective. But </span>if he sells it <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, when his action is not effective, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>that the sale be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the slaughter, </span>as they are mentioned together, and <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he slaughters the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">his action is effective.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say </span>he is exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said: For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did the Torah say that </span>a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who slaughtered or sold </span>a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the fourfold or fivefold payment? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he has become entrenched in sin </span>by slaughtering or selling the animal he stole.
Rav Sheshet analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When</span> did this sale, referred to by Rabbi Akiva, occur? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>it possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>is any <span class="gemarra-regular">entrenchment </span>in sin here? A sale before the owner’s despair is invalid, which means there is no deepening of his earlier sin. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not</span> the case that this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>referring to a sale <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair? Rava said: </span>This is not a proof, as one can explain that the thief is entrenched in sin <span class="gemarra-regular">because he repeated </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sin, </span>i.e. sinned a second time, by his act of sale, regardless of the fact that the sale is invalid.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof for the opinion of Rav Sheshet from a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And slaughter it or sell it” </span>(Exodus 21:37). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as slaughter </span>is an act <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot be undone, so too </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>referred to here is an act <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot be undone. </span>The Gemara analyzes this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>did this sale take place? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span> the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering his stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">why can it not be undone? </span>The thief’s sale of the animal is invalid before the owner’s despair, and therefore the sale is easily undone. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be referring to a sale that took place <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment only if the animal is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. Rav Naḥman </span>rejected this proof, as he <span class="gemarra-regular">interpreted </span>that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as serving to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude one who transferred </span>ownership of the animal temporarily, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">for thirty days.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar also holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the liability </span>of a thief to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment applies if he sells it <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering his stolen animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Elazar says: </span>

Daf 68b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Know that an ordinary </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft is </span>assumed to result in <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner’s despai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of recovering the stolen item. In other words, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, one may assume that the victim of theft has despaired of recovering his item.
The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Torah stated </span>that if a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal he had stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why is this so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>at the time the thief sold the animal, in which case the sale is invalid, and there should be no fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not because we say that an ordinary </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft is </span>assumed to result in <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner’s despair </span>of recovering the stolen item? This concludes the statement of Rabbi Elazar, which clearly indicates that there is no fourfold or fivefold payment if the animal is sold before the owner’s despair.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Rabbi Elazar’s assumption: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the Torah obligates the thief to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the owner has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>at the time of the sale, despite the fact that the sale is invalid, as Rav Naḥman stated.
In response to this question the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot enter your mind, </span>as Rabbi Elazar maintains that the juxtaposition of slaughtering and selling in the verse that states: “And slaughter it or sell it,” teaches that the thief’s sale of the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as slaughter </span>is a matter in <span class="gemarra-regular">which his action was effective, so too, </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>the animal is one in <span class="gemarra-regular">which his action was effective, </span>i.e., the sale is valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the sale occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>sense were his actions <span class="gemarra-regular">effective?</span>
The Gemara asks another question with regard to Rabbi Elazar’s reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the Torah requires the fourfold or fivefold payment only in the specific case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal is sold after <span class="gemarra-regular">we heard that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of its recovery. The Sages respond to this and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot enter your mind, </span>since, as explained above, the thief’s sale of the animal must be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of it. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the thief is liable to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering </span>the animal even if he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, so too, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>it applies even if he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, </span>before it is known that the owner has despaired of recovering the animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said to </span>Rabbi Elazar: The case of <span class="gemarra-regular">stealing a human being</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., kidnapping, <span class="gemarra-regular">proves </span>that your reasoning is incorrect. The Torah states: “And he who steals a man and sells him or if he is found in his hand, he shall be put to death” (Exodus 21:16). In this case <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no owner’s despair, </span>as no one ever despairs of his own freedom. Consequently, the thief’s sale of the person he kidnapped is invalid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet the Torah states that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to receive the death penalty for selling him.
