One can learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span>from this question <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds </span>that if the thief sells the stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
§ The Gemara asks: If the thief sells the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And Reish Lakish says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the animal is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span> the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair or after </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. Reish Lakish says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">liability is </span>in effect only if he sells the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, but after </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>there is no liability, because the thief has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the animal by virtue of the owner’s despair, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore it is <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and consecrated </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and subsequently slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the owner of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>The Torah states: “The one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8). The word “neighbor” excludes the case of one who steals a consecrated item from the Temple treasury. Since there is no double payment to the Temple treasury there can be no fourfold or fivefold payment either, as the fourfold or fivefold payment is considered an addition to, not a replacement of, of the double payment (see 75a). Therefore, a thief does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment to the Temple treasury for slaughtering one of its animals.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>did the events described in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> occur? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>they happened <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, is </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>at all? A thief cannot consecrate a stolen item before the owner despairs of recovering it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: “And <span class="gemarra-regular">when a man shall sanctify his house to be holy unto the Lord” </span>(Leviticus 27:14), from which it is derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one’s house belongs to him, so too, anything </span>that one consecrates must <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore a thief cannot consecrate a stolen item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious</span> that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with events that occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after</span> the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair. And </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason that he does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment is that he consecrated </span>the animal, on the grounds <span class="gemarra-regular">that when he slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered consecrated </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> consecrate </span>the animal before <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he would pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. And if it enters your mind that </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the animal for the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>would he have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay? </span>At that point it is <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters or his own </span>animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells.</span>
Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we dealing here? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case that occurred before the owner’s despair, and it is not the thief who consecrated the animal, as he cannot do so. Rather, we are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the owner consecrated the animal </span>while it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the thief’s possession.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>in this situation? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of recovering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither of them is able to consecrate </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the thief, cannot consecrate the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it does not belong to him; and that </span>one, the owner, cannot consecrate it, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not in his possession. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>an answer on behalf of Reish Lakish: <span class="gemarra-regular">He stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the pious ones [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzenuin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who acted not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 5:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">The pious ones would set aside </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">coin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and say: Anything that was picked from this </span>vine by passersby <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be desacralized onto these coins. </span>This mishna is referring to a grapevine in its fourth year after planting. The grapes on this vine must be either eaten in Jerusalem or redeemed with money that is then taken to Jerusalem and spent on food. The fruit may not be eaten outside Jerusalem without being redeemed. The pious ones were concerned that a passerby might help himself to some of their grapes, thereby transgressing a prohibition. Therefore, they would redeem any of their grapes that might be picked and eaten by passersby. Evidently, these pious ones were of the opinion that the owner of a stolen item can redeem it despite the fact that it is no longer in his possession. Likewise, they would say, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, that an owner of a stolen item can consecrate it even though it is no longer in his possession.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Reish Lakish’s explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that it is discussing a case where the owner of the animal consecrated it after it was stolen: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the principal </span>amount, i.e., the stolen animal itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">has returned to the owner. </span>By consecrating the animal, the owner has exercised his ownership of it, and it is therefore considered to have been returned to him at that point. The thief should therefore not be required to pay the double payment, as a thief is liable for double payment only when the stolen item is in his possession at the time of the trial, as it states: “The theft shall be found in his hand” (Exodus 22:3).
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stood in judgment </span>and was found guilty of theft before the owner consecrated the animal. Consequently, the liability to pay the double payment preceded the owner’s consecration of his property.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this trial of the thief? <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span> it refers to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the members of the court <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the animal back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> say that the thief is exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>because the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>the animal before it was slaughtered? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even if he did not consecrate it </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">should also not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara elaborates. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava says: </span>If the court tells a thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the stolen animal back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner and instead the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">has issued a definitive ruling in </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, and he </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is considered a robber, and a robber does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>The difference between a thief, concerning whom the Torah prescribes the double payment and the fourfold or fivefold payment, and a robber, who does not incur these obligations, is that a thief acts stealthily, whereas a robber brazenly uses force to take an item from its owner. Once a court has obligated a thief to make restitution and he has defied this sentence, he is considered a robber, and therefore the fourfold or fivefold payment and its atonement are not applicable to him. 

Daf 69a

Rava continues: But if the court says to the thief only: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are obligated to give </span>the stolen animal back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its owner, without actually ordering him to pay, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">has not issued a definitive ruling in </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, he is still </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>rather than a robber.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is not a challenge to the ruling of Reish Lakish. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they say to him </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are obligated to give </span>the stolen animal back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its owner. Consequently, he remains categorized as a thief.
§ The Gemara returns to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of recovering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither of them is able to consecrate </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the thief, cannot consecrate it <span class="gemarra-regular">because it does not belong to him, and that </span>one, the owner, cannot consecrate it <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not in his possession. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is invariably in accordance with the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed mishna, </span>i.e., a mishna that states a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> without citing it in the name of a particular Sage?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> there is a mishna of this kind (<span class="it-text">Ma’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 5:1) that contradicts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard in its fourth year, they would demarcate it with clods of earth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bikzozot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> placed around it on the ground, to alert people that they may not eat or derive any benefit from its grapes without redeeming them. The Gemara interrupts its quotation of the mishna to explain: This particular <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguishing mark </span>of earth is used because a vineyard in its fourth year is <span class="gemarra-regular">like earth: Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">earth there is </span>permission to derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from it </span>through its cultivation, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">when it has been redeemed </span>by means of coins, it is likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to benefit from it.</span>
The Gemara resumes its citation from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a grapevine <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span> is demarcated <span class="gemarra-regular">with potsherds [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥarsit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> placed around it, to alert people that its grapes may not be eaten nor may any benefit be derived from them at all (see Leviticus 19:23). The Gemara explains: This particular <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguishing mark </span>is used because <span class="it-text">orla</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">like potsherds: Just as no benefit </span>is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from potsherd, so too, no benefit </span>may be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span><span class="it-text">orla</span>.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">of graves </span>is demarcated <span class="gemarra-regular">with lime</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to notify people that the demarcated area is ritually impure and will impart impurity to those who pass over it. The Gemara explains: The reason this particular <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguishing mark </span>is used is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> lime is <span class="gemarra-regular">white, like bones. </span>The mishna further states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dissolves </span>the lime in water <span class="gemarra-regular">and pours </span>it out around the gravesite. The Gemara explains: This is performed <span class="gemarra-regular">in order that </span>the lime <span class="gemarra-regular">should be whiter </span>than in its non-dissolved form.
The Gemara resumes the citation from the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that vineyards of the fourth year and of <span class="it-text">orla</span> require demarcation, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? During the Sabbatical </span>Year. The Gemara explains: The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>all fruit that grows during that year may be taken by anyone (see Leviticus 25:5–6), as in that year all fruit is considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless </span>property.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But during the other years of </span>the Sabbatical <span class="gemarra-regular">cycle, </span>when anyone who takes the grapes of another is guilty of theft, there is no requirement to demarcate these vineyards. This is in accordance with the adage: <span class="gemarra-regular">Feed it to the wicked man and let him die. </span>That is, one is not required to take precautions to protect the wicked from the consequences of their own sins. Here too, there is no obligation to warn a thief that the grapes he is stealing are prohibited.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the pious ones would set aside </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">coin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and say: Anything that was picked from this</span> vine by passersby <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be desacralized onto these coins. </span>These pious ones maintain that the owner can desacralize the grapes despite the fact that they are no longer in his possession. Similarly, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, they would claim that an owner can consecrate a stolen item even though it is no longer in his possession. Since this opinion is cited in the mishna without being attributed to any particular Sage, Rabbi Yoḥanan should have accepted this ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Who</span> is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>this practice of the <span class="gemarra-regular">pious ones </span>in the mishna? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say </span>his principle that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is always in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed </span>mishna when it follows <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual </span>opinion; this suggestion does not alleviate the difficulty.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Wherever Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel taught </span>a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the corpus of <span class="gemarra-regular">our Mishna, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with his </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the case of the responsibility of the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantor </span>(see <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 173b), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the incident that occurred in the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tzaidan </span>(see <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 74a), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the dispute with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">evidence </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">final </span>disagreement (see <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 31a). Consequently, even if the opinion of the pious ones was cited by Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, Rabbi Yoḥanan should have accepted it as authoritative.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>in explanation of the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan: When quoting the declaration of the pious ones, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not say </span>in the past tense: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anything that was picked from this </span>vine by passersby shall be desacralized onto these coins. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say: Anything that will be picked from this </span>vine shall be desacralized onto these coins. In other words, the desacralizing is performed before the fruit is picked, while it is still in the full possession of the owner of the vine.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say such </span>a ruling? Could Rabbi Yoḥanan agree to this reformulation of the declaration of the pious ones? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: The pious ones and Rabbi Dosa said the same thing, </span>i.e., their opinions are equivalent? <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Dosa says </span>that this declaration is formulated in the past tense, as: Anything <span class="gemarra-regular">that was picked.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">morning the homeowner,</span> i.e., the owner of a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">stands and says: Anything that the poor will pick today </span>that is not rightfully theirs <span class="gemarra-regular">shall </span>hereby <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless </span>property. The poor are entitled to glean leftover grain from a field after it is harvested (Leviticus 23:22). Yet there are many <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> involved in determining what produce they are entitled to take, and not all poor people are learned enough to know these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. Consequently, there will inevitably be poor people who will take a certain amount of grain to which they are not entitled. For this reason, the owner of the field should relinquish, in advance, ownership over whatever the poor might unlawfully take.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa says: </span>This is not the correct practice. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">toward evenin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the owner should <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Anything that the poor picked </span>today that is not rightfully theirs <span class="gemarra-regular">shall </span>hereby <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless </span>property. Since Rabbi Yoḥanan stated that the opinions of the pious ones and Rabbi Dosa are the same, this indicates that the declaration of the pious ones was in the past tense, which means that they permitted redemption of fourth-year produce after it was already stolen. If so, the question remains: Why did Rabbi Yoḥanan not accept the ruling of the pious ones as authoritative? 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Dosa with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. </span>According to this new version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, Rabbi Dosa does not permit the owner of an item to exercise any control over it after it has been stolen from him. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do you reverse the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> to avoid a contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan? It is better to <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan</span> himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say </span>that he actually stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">The pious ones and Rabbi Yehuda said the same thing, </span>and leave the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> intact.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says: There is no alternative, as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>do otherwise than <span class="gemarra-regular">to reverse the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as </span>that would mean <span class="gemarra-regular">that in this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it teaches that Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that there is a principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And we have heard </span>elsewhere <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yehuda generally does not accept</span> the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Demai</span> 7:4): 

Daf 69b

In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from among the Samaritans [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Kutim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if there is reason to suspect that <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes were not separated, and he cannot separate them before the start of Shabbat, he acts as follows. If there are one hundred <span class="it-text">log</span> of wine in the barrels, he <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that I will separate in the future are </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as the mandated average measure of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is one-fiftieth; <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span><span class="it-text">log</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe; </span>and a tenth of the remainder, <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="it-text">log</span>, are <span class="gemarra-regular">second tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And he desacralize</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the second tithe that he will separate in the future by transferring its sanctity onto money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may drink </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, </span>relying on the separation that he will perform later. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Shimon prohibit </span>one from doing so. The objection of these three Sages is presumably that this arrangement relies on the principle of retroactive designation, as at the time of the declaration the identity of the particular portions of wine that will be <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes is unknown, and these Sages do not accept this principle. It is apparent from this mishna that Rabbi Yehuda does not accept retroactive designation, and therefore he cannot be the one who said that the owner of the field may issue his declaration of relinquishment in the morning.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Ultimately, why do you reverse the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> that contains the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Dosa? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>due to the contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda </span>and another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda. Now too, </span>although you have reversed the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, a similar problem remains, as there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>due to the contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>and another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As you said, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan: Do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that was picked </span>from this vine by passersby shall be desacralized onto these coins. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that will be picked from this </span>vine shall be desacralized onto these coins. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan here <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation. But </span>it is established that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan does not accept </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Brothers who divided </span>property received as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from each other, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as purchasers of land <span class="gemarra-regular">they must return </span>the portions <span class="gemarra-regular">to each other in the Jubilee </span>Year, at which point they may redistribute the property. This demonstrates that Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold that it is retroactively clarified that each brother’s portion was designated for him directly upon their father’s death, but rather all the land was considered joint property until the brothers traded or bought their respective portions from each other at the time of the distribution of the estate.
In light of this objection, the Gemara retracts its previous assertion that Rabbi Yoḥanan reformulated the declaration of the pious ones. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the pious ones <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>declared in the past tense: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anything that was picked </span>from this vine by passersby shall be desacralized onto these coins, i.e., the desacralizing took place after the grapes were stolen. If so, the question remains: Why did Rabbi Yoḥanan not accept the opinion of the pious ones, but instead ruled that the owner of an item cannot consecrate it after it has been stolen?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan found a different unattributed </span>mishna, which contradicts the opinion of the pious ones. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in the mishna here (62b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">after a thief </span>has already stolen it, i.e., one who steals a stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the thief or to the prior owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not pay to the first thief, as </span>the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it was stolen from the house of the man; </span>if the thief shall be found he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6), which indicates that the double payment applies in the case of an item “stolen from the house of the man,” i.e., from the owner’s jurisdiction, but <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>to an item stolen from <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief’s house. But let him pay </span>the double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner, </span>as it presumably still belonged to the owner when the second thief stole it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>this that a stolen item is not under the full jurisdiction of either the owner or the thief? It is not under the jurisdiction of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the first thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it does not belong to him, and </span>it is not under the jurisdiction of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not in his possession. </span>Therefore, neither of them can consecrate the stolen item.
The Gemara asks: Granted that this unattributed mishna disagrees with the mishna that cites the pious ones, <span class="gemarra-regular">but what did you see </span>that led you to <span class="gemarra-regular">follow that unattributed </span>mishna, the one that discusses the double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">act, </span>i.e., rule, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with this unattributed </span>mishna, which states the practice <span class="gemarra-regular">of the pious ones.</span> On what basis did he choose one mishna over the other?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan followed the mishna that discusses the double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">supports it: “And when a man shall sanctify his house to be holy to the Lord” </span>(Leviticus 27:14), from which it is derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as one’s house is in his possession, so too anything </span>that one consecrates must <span class="gemarra-regular">be in his possession, </span>excluding items that have been stolen from him.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: If Rabbi Yoḥanan had not said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the pious ones and Rabbi Dosa said the same thing, </span>i.e., their rulings are identical, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the pious ones accept </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Dosa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but Rabbi Dosa does not accept </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the pious ones.</span>
Abaye elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The pious ones accept </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Dosa, </span>for the following reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the Sages instituted an ordinance for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span>to prevent him from eating unredeemed fourth-year grapes, by allowing the owner to desacralize produce that is no longer in his possession, does it <span class="gemarra-regular">need to be said </span>that they did so for the sake of innocent <span class="gemarra-regular">poor people, </span>as Rabbi Dosa claimed? Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa does not accept </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the pious ones, </span>as he says: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>for the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">poor people that the Sages instituted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinance; but the Sages did not institute an ordinance for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span>in line with the aforementioned principle: Feed it to the wicked man and let him die.
In a similar vein, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: If Rabbi Yoḥanan had not said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the pious ones and Rabbi Dosa said the same thing, I would say </span>that there is a fundamental difference between the cases of fourth-year produce and gleanings taken by the poor, as one could claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the ruling of the <span class="gemarra-regular">pious ones? It is Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rabbi Meir say </span>that second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe is property </span>belonging to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> rather than the possession of the one who separated it from his produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even so, with regard to redemption </span>of the second tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One establishes it in his possession? As it is written </span>concerning the second tithe: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if a man will redeem any of his tithe, he shall add to it its fifth part” </span>(Leviticus 27:31). 
Although according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, second tithe does not belong to the owner of the produce from which it was separated, nevertheless, with regard to redemption <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One </span>does distinguish between a stranger and one who separated it from his produce, as the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">refers to </span>the second tithe as <span class="gemarra-regular">“his tithe” and </span>thereby decrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">he, </span>the owner of the crop from which it is separated, can redeem it by <span class="gemarra-regular">adding one-fift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> to its value, but no one else can do so. This indicates that although second-tithe produce is not in fact owned by the person, the Torah treats him as the owner of the produce.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fourth-year vineyard as well, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>many of its <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verbal analogy between <span class="gemarra-regular">second tithe </span>and fourth-year fruit, based on the use of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“holy” </span>in the context of fourth-year fruit and <span class="gemarra-regular">“holy” </span>in the context of second tithe. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written here, </span>concerning fourth-year fruit trees: “And in the fourth year all its fruit shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">holy, for giving praise </span>to the Lord” (Leviticus 19:24), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written with regard to second tithe: “And all the tithe of the land, whether of the seed of the land or of the fruit of the tree, is the Lord’s; it is holy” </span>(Leviticus 27:30).
From this analogy it is derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>in the case of the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“holy” that is written in connection to </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe, even though it is property </span>belonging to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High, with regard to redemption the Merciful One establishes it in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">jurisdiction </span>of the one who separated it, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>in the context of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“holy” that is written in connection to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth-year vineyard, even though it is not his property, </span>as it belongs to the Most High, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to desacralizing the Merciful One establishes it in </span>the vineyard owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">jurisdiction. </span>
The effect of this determination is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">is in his jurisdiction it is not his </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">he is able to desacralize it. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason the owner of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to desacralize </span>the fruit even after a thief has taken it. Even in normal circumstances when one desacralizes his fourth-year fruit he is desacralizing fruit that does not belong to him. Consequently, there is no novelty in the ruling that one can desacralize fruit even after it has been taken by a thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to gleanings </span>of the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the extra sheaves that the poor people inadvertently take <span class="gemarra-regular">are the property of </span>the owner of the field, it may be claimed that only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>those sheaves <span class="gemarra-regular">are in his possession, </span>i.e., they have not been taken by anyone else, <span class="gemarra-regular">can he relinquish </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>them, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession he cannot relinquish </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>them. Consequently, the pious ones, who permitted redemption of fourth-year produce after it had been stolen, would not necessarily agree with Rabbi Dosa, who allowed the relinquishment of stolen sheaves.
In a similar vein, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: If Rabbi Yoḥanan had not said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the pious ones and Rabbi Dosa said the same thing, I would say: Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">pious ones? It is Rabbi Dosa. </span>I would have said this <span class="gemarra-regular">so that an unattributed mishna should not </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan. And </span>the reason why this would have resolved the difficulty is that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan</span>

Daf 70a

<span class="gemarra-regular">did not say </span>to apply his principle, that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is always in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed </span>mishna, in a case where the mishna expresses the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">individual </span>Sage. According to this interpretation Rabbi Yoḥanan does not rule in accordance with the mishna, due to the fact that it represents the opinion of an individual Sage, Rabbi Dosa. Rather, he follows the majority opinion. Yet now that Rabbi Yoḥanan said that the pious ones and Rabbi Dosa said the same thing, it cannot be claimed that they are one and the same Sage. Consequently, the ruling of the mishna is evidently accepted by at least two Sages, and therefore the difficulty from the mishna cannot be resolved by assigning it to a single Sage.
§ The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: One cannot write a document of authorization [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">orakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to assign another to collect a debt or a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">of movable property </span>on his behalf. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: What is the reason </span>for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>a principle stated <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yoḥanan.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owners have not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of recovering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither of them is able to consecrate </span>it: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the thief, cannot consecrate the item <span class="gemarra-regular">because it does not belong to him, and that </span>one, the owner, cannot consecrate it <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not in his possession. </span>The granting of authority to collect a debt involves the transfer of ownership of the item or money from the owner to the collector; otherwise the debtor could refuse to convey it to the collector. In the case of movable property, as it is being held by another, it is not in the possession of the owner; just as the owner cannot consecrate this item he cannot transfer ownership of it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who state </span>a different version of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: One cannot write a document of authorization for </span>the collection of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property that </span>the bailee or debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has denied </span>owing. The Gemara infers: According to this version, the only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>the document cannot be written is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the bailee or debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has denied </span>owing the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>a document written under these circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">has the appearance of falsehood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the purported owner is transferring ownership of an item over which his own ownership is in doubt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> it can be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the bailee or debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">did not deny </span>owing the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">one can write </span>a document of authorization.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a state </span>another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to this kind of document: <span class="gemarra-regular">A document of authorization in which it is not written: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">take legal action </span>against so-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>possession of the owed property <span class="gemarra-regular">and collect it </span>from him <span class="gemarra-regular">for yourself, has no substance, </span>i.e., it is not a valid document. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the other </span>party, the bailee or debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">can say </span>to the collector who presents a document without this clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am not legally answerable to you; </span>I am willing to deal only with the person to whom the item is owed. To avoid this situation, the authorization document must transfer actual ownership of the item to the collector, who is now claiming it for himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: And if it is written </span>in the document that the owner transferred ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half</span> of the item to the collector, <span class="gemarra-regular">or a third or a quarter </span>of it, this is sufficient. The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the bailee or debtor must <span class="gemarra-regular">relate </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment, </span>i.e., engage in litigation with the collector, <span class="gemarra-regular">over </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> or third or quarter of the item that has been transferred to the collector, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">relate </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment concerning all of it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: If </span>the collector who is empowered by the authorization <span class="gemarra-regular">seized </span>the item he collected and kept it for himself, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take it away from him, </span>as the owner transferred ownership of the item to him in the document of authorization, as explained above. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>disagreed with Ameimar and <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Since </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote to </span>the collector: <span class="gemarra-regular">I accept upon myself anything that develops as a result of </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">legal process</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has </span>in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered </span>the collector <span class="gemarra-regular">an agen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to act on his behalf, and therefore the agent cannot seize the item for himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there is </span>another opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that states: </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">renders the </span>collector <span class="gemarra-regular">a partner </span>in the collected item, transferring ownership of half of it to him while maintaining ownership over the other half. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>between this opinion and that of Rav Ashi? The Gemara answers: The difference is whether the collector has the power <span class="gemarra-regular">to seize half </span>of the collected item for himself. If he is merely an agent of the owner, he cannot seize anything; if he is a partner he can seize up to half. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>the collector his <span class="gemarra-regular">agent, </span>and therefore this agent may not seize any portion of the collected item for himself.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna lists a series of cases in which a thief is required to pay the fourfold or fivefold penalty. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, also <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of the same witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">or based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two other </span>witnesses, he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for idol worship, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Yom Kippur, </span>he pay s the fourfold or fivefold payment. Although his sale or slaughter in these circumstances involved a sin, he is not liable to receive the death penalty for the sale and must consequently pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. 
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward his father died </span>and he inherited his father’s estate either on his own or in partnership with his brothers, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he consecrated </span>it, he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>
In the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered it, </span>not for the purpose of eating its meat, but to use it <span class="gemarra-regular">for medicinal purpose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to </span>feed the meat to <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs, </span>and likewise a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who slaughters </span>the animal to eat its meat <span class="gemarra-regular">but it was found to be an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who slaughters a non-sacred </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon exempts </span>the thief from the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">in these </span>last <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>cases, as he maintains that the legal status of an act of slaughter that is not fit for accomplishing its full ritual purpose is not considered an act of slaughter.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if two witnesses testify about the theft of an animal and two others testify about its slaughter or sale, the thief pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>in his exposition of the verse: “Based on the testimony of two witnesses or on the testimony of three witnesses shall a matter be established” (Deuteronomy 19:15).
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>the thief would be exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment, as <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this verse teaches that witnesses’ testimony must refer to an entire <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and not part of a matter? </span>In the case discussed by the mishna the second set of witnesses testifies only that this man slaughtered or sold an ox or sheep, not that he stole it, and therefore their testimony alone would not render the thief liable to pay anything. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 2:4) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When father Ḥalaft</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> went to study Torah with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, and some say </span>that he said: When <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri </span>went to study <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah with father </span>

Daf 70b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥalafta, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>the following in the course of their discussion of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of possession. 
If one has been in possession of real estate for three years, this serves as proof of his claim that he is the legal owner. One who is able to prove uninterrupted possession for the necessary period is not required to produce documentary evidence of his legal title to the property. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri or father Ḥalafta asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one harvested and <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>the produce of a field that he claims as his own the <span class="gemarra-regular">first yea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the three years required for establishing possession of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>witnesses, and subsequently ate the produce of the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>year <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>other witnesses, and finally ate the produce of the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>year <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>other witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Can the three testimonies combine to establish full testimony that he ate the produce of three years, thereby confirming his ownership of the field?
Rabbi Ḥalafta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, or vice versa: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>considered to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership </span>by the one who ate the produce. The other Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I too say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">so, but Rabbi Akiva disputes </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, as Rabbi Akiva would say: </span>The Torah requires that witnesses must testify with regard to a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">matter and not part of a matter. </span>Since there must be testimony concerning consumption of the produce over three years, and each set of witnesses establishes only that it took place for one year, their separate testimonies do not combine. If so, the mishna is apparently not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva.
The Gemara rejects this assertion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva. Doesn’t Rabbi Akiva concede </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothed </span>a certain woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two </span>other witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Someone else subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in sexual intercourse </span>with that same woman, this is proof that the act of intercourse was adulterous? 
The reason for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">that even though the witnesses </span>testifying about the <span class="gemarra-regular">intercourse require the witnesses </span>who testify about the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal, </span>i.e., the testimony of the second set of witnesses is meaningless without the testimony of the first witnesses, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the witnesses </span>testifying about the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal do not require the witnesses</span> who testify about the <span class="gemarra-regular">intercourse, </span>i.e., their testimony by itself establishes a halakhic status, <span class="gemarra-regular">we call </span>the testimony of each pair a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">matter.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>the same logic applies in the case of a thief who steals an animal and subsequently slaughters or sells it: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though the witnesses </span>who testify about the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter require the </span>testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>about the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>in order for their testimony to have any halakhic significance, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the witnesses </span>testifying about the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft do not require the </span>testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>who testify about the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, </span>as their testimony alone establishes that person as a thief who is liable to pay the double payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">we call </span>the testimony of each pair a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">matter.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis,</span> who disagree with Rabbi Akiva that the Torah stipulates that testimony must be about <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter and not half of a matter, </span>the term “matter” (Deuteronomy 19:15) serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what? </span>The Gemara answers: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case involving testimony that a girl has reached majority, in which <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he saw <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair on <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>lower <span class="gemarra-regular">back</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he saw <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair on <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>lower <span class="gemarra-regular">abdomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A girl is considered to have reached maturity when she has two pubic hairs. In this case, two witnesses separately testify that they have each seen one hair, and therefore each testimony is halakhically meaningless on its own. The Rabbis derive from the verse that these testimonies do not combine.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case each testimony is obviously invalid, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">half a matter and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">half a testimony. </span>Not only does each testimony refer to one hair, which is half a matter, it is submitted by one witness, which is half a testimony. Consequently, it is obvious that the girl is not considered of age in this case.
The Gemara therefore rejects this explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> the Rabbis maintain that the term “matter” serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that they saw <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair on a girl’s <span class="gemarra-regular">back, and two </span>other witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that they saw <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on her </span>lower <span class="gemarra-regular">abdomen. </span>In this case the testimony of either set of witnesses concerns only one hair, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>essentially <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor and those </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, each testimony concerns only half of a matter.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, </span>he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that in this case he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said: When it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pick off a fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for yourself from my fig tree </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>through performing this act <span class="gemarra-regular">your stolen </span>animal shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired by me. </span>Since the act of acquisition of the animal involved the type of Shabbat desecration for which one is liable to receive the death penalty, the thief is exempt from the monetary obligations he would ordinarily incur from this act, i.e., the fourfold or fivefold payment to the animal’s prior owner. This is in accordance with the principle that one who commits two or more transgressions by means of a single act, both of which entail punishment, is exempt from the lesser punishment.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>questioning this explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since, if </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">would bring a legal claim against </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">before us, </span>to force him to deliver the animal acquired by means of picking the fig, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">would not say to </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>him the animal you owe him, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty for his desecration of Shabbat, this shows that <span class="gemarra-regular">the sale is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>at all. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> would not call this exchange a sale and this interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cannot be correct.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Pappa said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Throw your stolen </span>animal from the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">into my </span>enclosed <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, and your stolen </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">be acquired by me. </span>One can acquire an item if it is placed on his property. In this case, when the thief places the animal on the purchaser’s property he moves it from the public domain into the private domain, which is a desecration of Shabbat that entails the death penalty. Consequently, he is exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara asks: If this is the correct explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with whose</span> opinion is the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says: </span>An item <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">airspace </span>of a certain area <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>as though it were <span class="gemarra-regular">at res</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in that area.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold that an item in the airspace of a certain area is not considered as though it were at rest in that area, <span class="gemarra-regular">once </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">reache</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>airspace <span class="gemarra-regular">of the courtyard </span>of the purchaser’s <span class="gemarra-regular">house </span>he has acquired it, as one can acquire items that are in the airspace of his courtyard just like those on its ground, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>moving an item from one domain to another on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for Shabbat desecration <span class="gemarra-regular">until it reaches the ground. </span>Since the thief’s monetary liability is not simultaneous with his incurring of the death penalty, he would not be exempt from payment.
The Gemara answers: It is possible that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis as well, as one can explain that it is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>which the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your stolen </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be acquired by me until it rests </span>on the ground. In that case, the acquisition of the animal and the Shabbat desecration are simultaneous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>it is possible to explain the <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rami bar Ḥama </span>did, that the animal was acquired through the picking of a fig on Shabbat. And the objection raised earlier, that this act should not be considered a sale at all, is incorrect. This can be demonstrated by the fact that the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah prohibits </span>one to bring as an offering an animal given as the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>to a prostitute for services rendered (Deuteronomy 23:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this prohibition applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in intercourse with his own mother, </span>which is a capital offense. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if she</span> would bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a legal claim before us, demanding </span>the payment of the animal that was agreed upon as her fee, <span class="gemarra-regular">would we say to him: Arise and pay her </span>the animal? The court would not say this, as the monetary liability was incurred simultaneously with the commission of a capital crime.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say that <span class="gemarra-regular">even though if she </span>brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a legal claim </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">him demanding </span>the payment of the animal that was agreed upon as her fee <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Go and pay her, </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to her it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">payment </span>to a prostitute, it cannot be used as an offering. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the case of the acquisition of the animal through picking a fig, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though with regard to payment, if </span>the purchaser would bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a legal claim before us </span>against the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">seeking </span>to force him to deliver the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">we would not say to him: Go pay, </span>

Daf 71a

and <span class="gemarra-regular">even so, since </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">transfers ownership to </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale, </span>and he is required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Yom Kippur </span>he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>questioning this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is he liable to pay it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Although there is no </span>penalty of <span class="gemarra-regular">execution </span>for slaughtering on Yom Kippur, <span class="gemarra-regular">nevertheless there is </span>the penalty of <span class="gemarra-regular">lashes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we maintain that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">flogged and </span>obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for the same act.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> in response: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna taught? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>taught in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: </span>One is sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">flogged and </span>obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for the same action.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, </span>which is a capital offense, he should be obligated to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, whereas the mishna (74b) states that in this case he is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that one is sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">flogged and</span> obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for the same act, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not hold </span>that one is sentenced to the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for the same act, this is incorrect.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it correct to say that Rabbi Meir does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>maintain that one can be sentenced to the death penalty and to pay for the same act? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for idol worship, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole an ox that is</span> sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">stoned, </span>from which it is prohibited to derive any benefit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he slaughtered it, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold </span>payment; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis exempt</span> him from this payment. Apparently Rabbi Meir maintains that one can be held liable for monetary payment and for capital punishment for the same act, e.g., slaughtering on Shabbat or slaughtering for idol worship.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Stand <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, i.e., this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should not be understood in a straightforward manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was stated concerning it: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Avin and Rabbi Ela and the entire grou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> of disciples of Rabbi Yoḥanan also <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>a thief who <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters </span>the stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the agency of <span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> person, i.e., he instructed another to slaughter it, and that agent did so on Shabbat or for idolatrous purposes. The thief pays the fourfold or fivefold payment because he himself did not commit a capital offense.
The Gemara asks: How can it be that a thief is liable to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment if another person slaughters the stolen animal for him? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">sin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes liable? </span>
