The Gemara provides several reasons why in the case of fourfold or fivefold payment it is possible for the thief to be liable for another’s actions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different here, as the verse states: “And slaughter it or sell it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), thereby juxtaposing the two acts of slaughtering and selling. It is derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>there is liability for the fourfold or fivefold payment through <span class="gemarra-regular">selling, </span>which by definition is performed <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of another </span>party, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>there is liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering </span>when it is performed <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of another </span>party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Rabbi Yishmael teaches: </span>The word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>in the phrase: “And slaughter it or sell it,” serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the agen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> slaughters or sells the animal at the behest of the thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Ḥizkiyya teaches: </span>The separate word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for” [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">taḥat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>in the phrase: “He shall pay five oxen for an ox, and four sheep for a sheep,” which could have been avoided by using the mere prefix of the letter <span class="it-text">beit</span>, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the agent </span>slaughters the animal on behalf of the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra objects to this </span>explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there anything </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">which if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">performs </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable, and </span>if his <span class="gemarra-regular">agent performs </span>it on his behalf one is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable? </span>How is it possible for an agent to have more power than the one who appointed him? Can it be that if the thief himself slaughtered the animal on Shabbat he would be exempt, whereas if he has it slaughtered by another he is liable?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to him: There, </span>in the case of the thief who slaughters a stolen animal on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not because he is not liable </span>that he does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>he is liable but he is excused from payment <span class="gemarra-regular">because he receives the greater of </span>the two punishments, i.e., execution, for desecrating Shabbat. When he appoints an agent he has no liability for desecrating Shabbat, and therefore he pays for the slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>a thief who <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through </span>the agency of <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason of the Rabbis, who exempt </span>the thief from payment? The thief did not himself do any act for which he is liable to receive the death penalty.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>are these <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who said: </span>The legal status of an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that is not fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for accomplishing its full ritual purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. </span>Since slaughtering on Shabbat or slaughtering for idolatrous purposes does not render the meat fit for consumption, Rabbi Shimon rules that there is no liability for the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>questioning this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>slaughtering for <span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship and </span>slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is </span>sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">stoned are </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that is not fit, </span>as in both of these cases it is prohibited to derive any benefit from the animal’s flesh. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>slaughtering on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat is a fit slaughter. As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 14a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or on Yom Kippur, although he is liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty for desecrating Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">his slaughter is valid </span>and the meat may be eaten.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who disagrees with that mishna and prohibits eating the meat of an animal slaughtered on Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 2:3): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who cooks </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly he may eat </span>the food, but if he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally he may not eat </span>it; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says:</span> If he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly he may eat </span>the food only <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the conclusion of Shabbat, </span>and if he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally he may not eat </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">ever, </span>although others may partake of it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar says: </span>If he cooked the food <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">may be eaten upon the conclusion of Shabbat by others </span>only, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not by him; </span>and if he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally it may not be eaten ever, neither by him nor by others. </span>Slaughter, like cooking, is a desecration of Shabbat that entails the death penalty. It follows that Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar maintains that the meat of an animal intentionally slaughtered on Shabbat may never be eaten. If so, this is a slaughter that does not render the meat fit for consumption, and therefore according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon there is no fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason for </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar? </span>The Gemara explains: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥiyya taught at the entrance to the house of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Nasi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall observe Shabbat, for it is holy [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kodesh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to you; </span>one who profanes it shall be put to death” (Exodus 31:14). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as it is prohibited to eat a sacred </span>item consecrated to the Temple [<span class="it-text">kodesh</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">so too is it prohibited to eat </span>food produced though <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>that desecrates <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>so, perhaps the analogy should be extended: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as it is prohibited to derive benefit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a sacred </span>item, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>should it be <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to derive benefit </span>from a product of <span class="gemarra-regular">an action </span>that desecrates <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“It is holy <span class="gemarra-regular">to you” </span>(Exodus 31:14), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">it shall be yours </span>for deriving benefit. Although food cooked on Shabbat may not be eaten, it is permitted to benefit from it in other ways.
The Gemara further asks: Based on the analogy between a sacred item and the product of an action that desecrates Shabbat, one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the action were performed <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly </span>it should be prohibited to consume the product, like a sacred item. To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “One who profanes it shall be put to death”</span> (Exodus 31:14), indicating that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who desecrates Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I said </span>this analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, </span>as the verse clearly is referring to one who is liable to receive the death penalty, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>one who desecrates Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly, </span>who is not executed.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to </span>this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">One said </span>that the product of <span class="gemarra-regular">an action </span>that constitutes a desecration of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, and one said </span>that the product of <span class="gemarra-regular">an action </span>that constitutes a desecration of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic </span>law.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>it is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law </span>explains <span class="gemarra-regular">as we said, </span>that the prohibition is based on the verse as interpreted by Rabbi Ḥiyya. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>it is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law </span>would say that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “It is holy,” </span>from which he infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It, </span>the day itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">is holy but </span>the products of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">actions are not holy, </span>and therefore they are not compared to sacred items and may be eaten by Torah law.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who said </span>that products of a prohibited act are prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, it is for </span>

Daf 71b

<span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis exempt </span>the thief from the fourfold or fivefold payment when he slaughters the animal on Shabbat, as slaughter on Shabbat does not render the meat permitted for consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that the product of a prohibited act on Shabbat may be eaten by Torah law but is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, why do the Rabbis exempt </span>the thief when he appoints an agent to slaughter the animal for him and the agent performs this action on Shabbat?
The Gemara answers: When the Rabbis exempt him from the fourfold or fivefold payment, they are not referring to the case where the thief’s agent slaughters the animal on Shabbat. Rather, they were speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of the rest </span>of the cases listed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, namely, an agent who slaughters the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for idol worship and </span>one who slaughters <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that is </span>sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">stoned.</span>
The Gemara asks another question with regard to the interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> presented above: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>granted he maintains that the legal status of an act of slaughter not fit for accomplishing its full ritual purpose is nevertheless considered an act of slaughter. But <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment when his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters</span> the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for idol worship?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Once he slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, </span>at the very start of the act of slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has prohibited </span>the animal, with regard to deriving benefit, as an animal sacrificed to idolatry. When he slaughters <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">deriving benefit, </span>which means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters. </span>Since deriving benefit from the animal is prohibited, it has no value; therefore, there is no ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who says </span>prior to the slaughter that only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the completion of the slaughter </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">he worship </span>the idolatry. Therefore, the prohibition does not take effect until that stage, which is also when the liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment is incurred.
The Gemara raises a question with regard to another of the cases of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">An ox that is </span>sentenced to be <span class="gemarra-regular">stoned is an item from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit is prohibited. </span>Consequently, when a thief or his agent slaughters this animal, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters. </span>Why does Rabbi Meir obligate him to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: With what are we dealing here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">entrusted </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to a bailee and </span>the ox fatally <span class="gemarra-regular">injured </span>someone while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the bailee’s house, and it was forewarned </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the bailee’s house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it was sentenced </span>to be stoned while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the bailee’s house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the thief then stole it from the bailee’s house and slaughtered it. Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Meir holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov, and he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov, who says: Even after </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was sentence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to be stoned, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee returned it to its owners </span>before it was killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">returned. </span>Although the ox is now worthless, as no benefit may be derived from it, since the bailee returned a physically intact ox, the owner has no claim against him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Meir also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says: An item </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>elimination <span class="gemarra-regular">causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary</span> value. With regard to an item that is otherwise worthless, if its elimination causes monetary loss due to the fact that it must be replaced, it is considered to be of value. In this case, although the ox is worthless in and of itself, when the thief slaughters it he prevents the bailee from returning it intact to the owner and causes him to be obligated to pay the owner the value of the ox before it was sentenced to be stoned. Consequently, the thief must reimburse the bailee, as the ox effectively has value for that bailee.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned</span> in a mishna (74b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibilit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to replace any of them with another animal if it is lost or it dies, the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment if he slaughters the animal. Although one is generally not liable to pay the double payment for stealing consecrated items, Rabbi Shimon maintains that this case is different, since as a result of the animal’s theft the owner sustains a loss by being required to substitute another animal for it. Since the animal’s loss has financial ramifications for the owner apart from any inherent value it has, it has value for him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Shimon holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item whose </span>elimination <span class="gemarra-regular">causes financial</span> loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: I recited </span>this <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>according to which the mishna follows the opinion of Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">in front of Rav Zevid of Neharde’a, </span>and I asked him: Is it correct to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">you can establish the mishna in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon? But isn’t it taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon exempts </span>the thief from the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">in these </span>last <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>cases. One can learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that in all the </span>rest of the cases in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna, </span>apart from these two, Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes </span>that the thief pays the fourfold or fivefold payment.
Rav Zevid <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No; </span>that is not the correct inference from the mishna. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span>one can learn only <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes </span>that the thief pays the fourfold or fivefold payment in the cases mentioned immediately prior to this one, specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal in order that it should be used <span class="gemarra-regular">for medicinal purposes or for </span>feeding to <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs. </span>Therefore, it can be correct to establish the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir and not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it, and afterward his father died, he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment to his father’s other heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole an ox </span>belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two partners and slaughtered it, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">to one of </span>the partners, which means that he is exempt from paying the fourfold or fivefold payment to that partner, in accordance with the principle that one who admits his own guilt is exempt from fines, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to payment to the other partner?
The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: “He shall pay <span class="gemarra-regular">five oxen </span>for an ox” (Exodus 21:37), which indicates five full oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not five</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> half-oxen. Or perhaps </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states “five oxen,” </span>this means that <span class="gemarra-regular">even five half-oxen </span>must be paid in a case of this kind. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states: “Five oxen,” </span>which means five full oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not five half-oxen.</span>
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to him </span>from the mishna: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward his father died, he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. But here, since his father died </span>and the thief has inherited part of the stolen animal himself, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the case of one who stole from two partners <span class="gemarra-regular">and went ahead and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">to one of them, </span>i.e., to himself. In the case of the mishna he is exempt from paying the portion of the fine that is for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the other heirs their portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? With </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where his father</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stood </span>against his son the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">trial, </span>and the son was convicted for the theft and slaughter of his father’s animal. In this case, the liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment was established before the father’s death, and at that time the payment was five full oxen.
Rava asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if the thief had <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>before the father’s death, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, according to your opinion? Would he <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> be required to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the fourfold or fivefold payment? If so, rather than teaching in the latter clause </span>of the mishna (74b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole his father’s </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and afterward he slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment; let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">make a distinction within the same </span>type of case, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>i.e., that the thief is required to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>in his father’s lifetime; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stand trial </span>in his father’s lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed, </span>the mishna could have mentioned that case. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna has to <span class="gemarra-regular">cite the first clause, </span>which discusses one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s and slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward his father died, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he cites the latter clause as well, </span>by means of a similar case: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole his father’s </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and his father died, and afterward he slaughtered or sold </span>the animal.
This discussion between Rava and Rav Naḥman occurred in the evening. <span class="gemarra-regular">On the </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">morning, </span>Rav Naḥman retracted his statement and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states: “Five oxen,” and </span>this means that <span class="gemarra-regular">even five half-oxe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> are included. Rav Naḥman explained his change of mind: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that I did not say </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>last <span class="gemarra-regular">night</span>

Daf 72a

is <span class="gemarra-regular">because I had not eaten ox meat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, I was fasting yesterday and was unable to concentrate properly.
Rava responded to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> if the Torah requires even a partial payment of the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>in which the son must pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>where he is exempt?
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>where the father’s animal was stolen and slaughtered in his lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">I read about </span>this case the verse: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), which indicates that the thief slaughtered the ox or the sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely in a prohibited </span>manner. In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>where the animal was slaughtered after the father’s death, <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not read about </span>this case the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And slaughter it,” </span>which describes a slaughter that was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely in a prohibited </span>manner, because the animal already partially belonged to him, and his own portion of the ox was slaughtered in a permitted manner.
§ The mishna teaches: A thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who slaughters </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">but it was found to be a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and likewise a thief who slaughters a non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard, pays the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥavivi of Meḥoza said to Rav Ashi: Conclude from </span>the mishna that the act <span class="gemarra-regular">of slaughtering </span>is considered to have been performed <span class="gemarra-regular">only at the end </span>of the slaughtering process.
Rav Ḥavivi of Meḥoza explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>you say that the act <span class="gemarra-regular">of slaughtering </span>lasts <span class="gemarra-regular">from beginning to end, </span>i.e., the halakhic ramifications of slaughtering are in effect throughout the process, one could raise a question with regard to the case of one who slaughters a non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">Once he slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, </span>at the very start of the act of slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has prohibited </span>the animal, with regard to deriving benefit, as a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard. When he slaughters <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>part, it is already prohibited with regard to deriving benefit, which means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters. </span>Since deriving benefit from the animal is prohibited, it has no value; therefore, there is no ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rava, said to </span>Rav Ḥavivi in response: It is possible to explain the mishna even if one maintains that the halakhic ramifications of slaughtering are in effect throughout the slaughter. As, <span class="gemarra-regular">when</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">become obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he performs <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">bit </span>of slaughter in the beginning, before the animal becomes forbidden. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not dismiss </span>Rav Ḥavivi’s objection with this explanation. The verse: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), indicates that to impose liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>that the thief slaughtered it <span class="gemarra-regular">completely, and </span>after having slaughtered it just a bit <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>complete slaughter yet.
Rav Huna said to Rav Ashi: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if you are correct, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>according to the one who maintains that the halakhic ramifications of slaughtering are in effect throughout the slaughter. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what Rav Gamda said in the name of Rava, </span>concerning this question: The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered, </span>i.e., severed, <span class="gemarra-regular">part </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">two organs that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must be severed in ritual slaughter, </span>i.e., the trachea and the esophagus <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">simanin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], outside </span>the Temple, and <span class="gemarra-regular">finished</span> slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">them inside </span>the Temple. Therefore, the animal became prohibited with regard to deriving benefit only at the final stage of slaughter, concomitant with the liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who teach </span>that the preceding exchange took place <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the following dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>ben Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">says in the name of Rabbi Levi the Elder: </span>The act of slaughtering is considered to have been <span class="gemarra-regular">performed only at the end </span>of the slaughtering process. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The act <span class="gemarra-regular">of slaughtering lasts from beginning to end</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ḥavivi of Meḥoza said to Rav Ashi: Shall we say that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds </span>that the prohibition against deriving benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">that were slaughtered in the Temple courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not by Torah law? </span>

Daf 72b

<span class="gemarra-regular">As, if it enters your mind </span>that it is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law </span>the mishna here would be difficult, for <span class="gemarra-regular">as soon as he slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, </span>at the very start of the act of slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has prohibited </span>the animal, with regard to deriving benefit, as a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard. When he slaughters <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>part it is already prohibited with regard to deriving benefit, which means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>an animal that belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to </span>Rav Ḥavivi: It is possible to explain the mishna even according to the opinion that the halakhic ramifications of slaughtering are in effect throughout the slaughter, and even if one maintains that it is prohibited by Torah law to benefit from a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple. As, <span class="gemarra-regular">when does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">become obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">as well? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he performs <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">bit </span>of slaughter in the beginning, before the animal becomes forbidden. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not dismiss </span>Rav Ḥavivi’s suggestion with this explanation. The verse: “If a man steal an ox or a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), indicates that in order to impose liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>that the thief slaughtered it <span class="gemarra-regular">completely, and </span>after having slaughtered it just a bit <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>complete slaughter yet.
Rav Huna said to Rav Ashi: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if you are correct, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult. </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Gamda said in the name of Rava: When </span>does the mishna state that the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated</span> to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment? It is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered part </span>of the <span class="gemarra-italic">simanim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> outside </span>the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> finished </span>slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">them inside </span>the Temple. Therefore, the animal became prohibited with regard to deriving benefit only at the final stage of slaughter, concomitant with the liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, also <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of the same witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses, these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay everything, </span>i.e., not only the principal amount but also the fourfold or fivefold payment. This is in accordance with the Torah’s decree with regard to conspiring witnesses: “You shall do to him as he had conspired to do to his brother” (Deuteronomy 19:19). Since these witnesses attempted to obligate the alleged thief to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, they themselves must pay that full amount.
With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two other </span>witnesses, if both <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">and those</span> witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>set of witnesses, who testified about the theft of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the alleged thief the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is what they had conspired to cause him to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the last </span>set of witnesses, who attested to the slaughter or sale of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the alleged thief a twofold payment for a sheep or <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> threefold payment </span>for an ox, which they had conspired to cause him to pay over and above the double payment.
If only the witnesses in the <span class="gemarra-regular">last </span>set <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses, while the testimony about the theft remains intact, the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>to the animal’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the second set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the alleged thief the twofold or <span class="gemarra-regular">threefold payment, </span>the amount over and above the double payment, which is what they had conspired to cause him to pay.
If only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">from the last </span>set of witnesses was found to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a conspiring </span>witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">the second testimony </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">nullified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it was not submitted by two valid witnesses, whereas the first testimony remains intact. If <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">from the first </span>set of witnesses is found to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a conspiring </span>witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire testimony </span>concerning the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">nullified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if there is no theft</span> established by reliable testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is no</span> liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">selling </span>it. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> One who is rendered a conspiring witness is barred from providing testimony in the future. The Gemara cites a fundamental dispute with regard to this disqualification. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a conspiring witness: Abaye says: He is disqualified retroactively, </span>from when he provided his testimony. Any testimony he may have provided after that point in time is retroactively nullified. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: He is disqualified </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from that point forward, </span>i.e., from when he was established to be a conspiring witness, but not retroactively from when he provided his testimony.
The Gemara explains the reasons for the two opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says he is disqualified retroactively </span>because it is <span class="gemarra-regular">from that time when he testified </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a wicked man, and the Torah said: “Do not put </span>your hand with <span class="gemarra-regular">the wicked </span>to be an unrighteous <span class="gemarra-regular">witness” </span>(Exodus 23:1), which is interpreted to mean: Do not allow a wicked man to serve as a witness.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is disqualified </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from that point forward </span>because the disqualification of <span class="gemarra-regular">a conspiring witness is a novelty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it is not based on logic. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>is a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">against two </span>other witnesses, in which case neither testimony should be accepted. <span class="gemarra-regular">What did you see that </span>causes <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">listen to </span>the second set of witnesses, who testify that the first set were not at the scene of the purported event? You could instead <span class="gemarra-regular">listen to </span>the first set of witnesses, who testify to the event, and disbelieve the second set. Yet the Torah teaches that the second set of witnesses is always deemed credible and the first set is subjected to punishment as conspiring witnesses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>as the disqualification of the conspiring witnesses is an anomaly, <span class="gemarra-regular">you have </span>the right to disqualify them <span class="gemarra-regular">only from the time of the novelty and onward, </span>i.e., this counterintuitive disqualification is not applied retroactively.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also holds like Abaye, who says </span>that by rights a conspiring witness <span class="gemarra-regular">should be disqualified retroactively </span>from when he provided his testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here this is Rava’s reason </span>for not disqualifying him retroactively: 

Daf 73a

It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the potential monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">loss for purchasers, </span>whose acquisitions had been validated by these witnesses between the time of the witnesses’ first testimony and when they were rendered conspiring witnesses. If the disqualification of the witnesses were applied retroactively, as by right it should, all these transactions would be nullified, which would cause a loss to these purchasers.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>these two explanations of Rava’s opinion? After all, according to both explanations Rava did not apply the disqualification of conspiring witnesses retroactively. The Gemara explains that there is a difference in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testify</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about one </span>of the witnesses that he was not at the scene of the supposed crime, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two </span>other witnesses testify <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> witness in a similar manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>there is a practical difference between the two explanations in a case where two witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>the first set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>testifying that they had once committed <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery </span>and are therefore unfit to give testimony. 
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to this version </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which you say </span>that Rava’s rejection of retroactive disqualification was <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a novelty, </span>in these two circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>novelty, and therefore he would agree that the disqualification should be retroactive. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to that version </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which you say </span>that Rava’s concern was <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>a potential <span class="gemarra-regular">loss for purchasers, </span>in these two circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a concern for a potential loss for purchasers. Consequently, in these circumstances as well Rava would reject retroactive disqualification.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti related: Rav Pappa </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">took action, </span>i.e., ruled in a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, </span>and rejected retroactive disqualification of conspiring witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Abay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with regard to retroactive disqualification of conspiring witnesses. The Gemara provides a principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in disputes between Abaye and Rava the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rava, except for six cases in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Abaye. </span>They are: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>the cases represented by the mnemonic <span class="gemarra-italic">yod-ayin-lamed</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kuf-gimmel-mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>These <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are the following: Unknown despair [<span class="it-text">ye’ush</span>]; conspiring witness [<span class="it-text">eidim</span>] who are disqualified retroactively; a side post [<span class="it-text">leḥi</span>] standing alone; betrothal [<span class="it-text">kiddushin</span>] that is not given to consummation; revealing intent with a bill of divorce [<span class="it-text">get</span>]; and an apostate [<span class="it-text">mumar</span>] who sins rebelliously. 
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Abaye’s opinion from that which <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, also <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of the same witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses, </span>these conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay everything, </span>including the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara explains the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the events occurred in the following sequence: The witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified concerning the theft </span>of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and then testified concerning the </span>animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. And </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">they were rendered conspiring witnesses </span>for their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the theft, and then they were rendered conspiring witnesses </span>for their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the slaughter.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say, in accordance with the opinion of Abaye, that a conspiring witness <span class="gemarra-regular">is disqualified retroactively </span>from the time he provided his testimony, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">once they are rendered conspiring witnesses concerning the theft, the matter becomes clarified retroactively that when they testified concerning the slaughter they were disqualified </span>to serve as witnesses. Consequently, that testimony should be rejected. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">must they pay </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment for their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the events did not happen in this sequence. Rather, the witnesses were <span class="gemarra-regular">first rendered conspiring witnesses </span>with regard to their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, </span>and only afterward were they rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the theft.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>in rejection of this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, when </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are subsequently rendered conspiring witnesses </span>with regard to their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the theft, the matter becomes clarified retroactively that when they testified concerning the slaughter they were disqualified </span>from providing testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">must they pay </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment for their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the </span>animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter?</span>
The Gemara gives its final answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Abaye, since the mishna can be explained as discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testified </span>concerning the theft of the animal and its slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">at the same time, and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">they were rendered conspiring witnesses </span>with regard to testimony about both matters. Therefore, even if the disqualification of these witnesses is established retroactively, they were not disqualified when they provided their single testimony concerning the theft and the slaughter.
The Gemara proposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the dispute between Abaye and Rava is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>As it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">there were two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testifying against </span>someone, claiming <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">testify against him that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they were rendered conspiring witnesses </span>only with regard to their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the theft, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated. </span>In other words, the testimony concerning the slaughter of the animal is null and void, as there is no longer any testimony that the animal was ever stolen. Therefore, the witnesses pay the double payment for having attempted to cause the alleged thief to pay that amount, while the accused is entirely exempt.
But <span class="gemarra-regular">if they were rendered conspiring witnesses </span>only with regard to their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the slaughter, </span>their testimony about the theft remains valid. Consequently, the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, and </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>a twofold or <span class="gemarra-regular">threefold payment </span>for having attempted to cause the thief to pay this amount, which is the fine for slaughter or sale beyond his double payment.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said when the theft and the slaughter were established <span class="gemarra-regular">by two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies. But </span>if these matters were established <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony, </span>then even if they were rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the testimony concerning the slaughter, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> When the testimony concerning the slaughter is invalidated the testimony concerning the theft is likewise negated, and the alleged thief is not required to pay the double payment. This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Yosei’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>did Rabbi Yosei mean when he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">By two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies, and what </span>did he mean when he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">By one </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony? If we say </span>that the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">By two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies, </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">literally by two </span>separate testimonies, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">by two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">sets </span>of witnesses, one of which testifies concerning the theft while the other testifies concerning the slaughter, this would mean that the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">By one </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony, </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">by one set </span>of witnesses that testifies to both the theft and the slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">after the other.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if so, when <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the facts are established <span class="gemarra-regular">by one testimony, </span>he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">one set </span>of witnesses testifying about both matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">after the other, </span>i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">that they testify concerning the theft and then testify concerning the slaughter. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">when they are rendered conspiring witnesses </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the slaughter, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is determined in accordance with the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that was partially invalidated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is entirely invalidated. And </span>consequently Rabbi Yosei would maintain that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>considered to have been <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered conspiring witnesses concerning the theft </span>as well. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where would this be derived? </span>Why should the earlier testimony about the theft be negated by their status as conspiring witnesses from the later testimony concerning the slaughter?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case that when Rabbi Yosei said: <span class="gemarra-regular">By two testimonies, </span>he meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">By a single testimony </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to two testimonies. And what is that? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">one set</span> of witnesses who testify about both the theft and the slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">after the other, </span>at two separate times. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if these matters were established <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony, </span>when the witnesses testified about both matters <span class="gemarra-regular">at the same time, </span>Rabbi Yosei concedes that these are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered two separate testimonies, despite the fact that they refer to two different events.
The Gemara continues to analyze the dispute between Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis: The <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> discussing this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed that </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone, </span>i.e., both Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis, if a witness pauses briefly in his testimony and then continues to testify, it is considered one long testimony. This is in accordance with the principle that the legal status of a pause or retraction <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking </span>a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the two testimonies, the one concerning the theft and the one concerning the slaughter, are considered a single testimony.
The Gemara asks with regard to the above: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not with regard to this </span>that Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? As the Rabbis maintain, </span>like Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a conspiring witness <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from here on, </span>i.e., from when he is rendered a conspiring witness. <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span>it was only <span class="gemarra-regular">from that time, </span>when the other witnesses testify about them, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are rendered conspiring witnesses, </span>it is only with regard to their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that they are rendered conspiring witnesses, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the theft </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not rendered conspiring witnesses.</span>
And <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei holds, </span>like Abaye, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a conspiring witness <span class="gemarra-regular">is disqualified retroactively, </span>from when he provided his testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they are disqualified immediately when they testify, if they are rendered conspiring witnesses concerning the slaughter they are rendered conspiring witnesses concerning the theft as well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the legal status of a pause or retraction <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> speaking </span>a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, </span>i.e., the two testimonies are considered one unit.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>in rejection of this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it were accepted that the legal status of a pause or retraction <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking</span> a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, everyone </span>would agree that the witnesses are <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified retroactively, </span>and their testimony with regard to the theft would also be negated. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here they disagree </span>about that very issue, i.e., whether the legal status of a pause or retraction <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking </span>a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like</span> that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech. The Rabbis maintain that </span>if the pause is <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking </span>a short phrase, then the two aspects of the testimony provided by the witnesses

Daf 73b

<span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not like </span>one testimony of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, </span>but are considered separate testimonies, and therefore the testimony concerning the theft remains valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei maintains that </span>the legal status of a pause <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking </span>a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, </span>and therefore the testimony about the theft is disqualified together with the testimony concerning the slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does Rabbi Yosei </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">maintain </span>that the legal status of a statement interrupted or retracted <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">required for speaking </span>a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech? But didn’t we learn </span>otherwise in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Temura</span> 25b): If one designates an animal by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is hereby a substitut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a burnt-offering, a substitute for a peace-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has issued two contradictory statements and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a substitute for a burnt-offering, </span>i.e., only the first part of his statement is accepted. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: If he intended this </span>outcome <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset, </span>that the animal should serve both as the substitute of a burnt-offering and as the substitute of a peace-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is impossible </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">to call it </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">two names at once, </span>i.e., the only way he can make his intent known is by issuing these two apparently contradictory declarations consecutively, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the animal has the status of both a substitute for a burnt-offering and a substitute for a peace-offering. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said: </span>This animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">a substitute for a burnt</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">changed his mind and said: A substitute for a peace-offering, it is a substitute for a burnt-offering.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we discussed </span>this ruling: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">changed his mind </span>before saying: A substitute for a peace-offering, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he cannot remove the status he already applied to the animal, and the animal certainly remains a substitute for a burnt-offering. Rabbi Yosei would not have issued such an obvious ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said </span>in response to this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are speaking </span>of a case where the individual <span class="gemarra-regular">changed his mind within the time required for speakin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a short phrase. Rabbi Yosei holds that when one adds to a statement after a pause, even if the addition was made within a short time, it is considered a separate statement, which does not reverse the initial declaration. This contradicts the explanation given for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above, according to which Rabbi Yosei maintains that when one adds to an existing statement within the time required for speaking a short phrase it is considered continuous speech.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">There are two </span>time frames that are referred to as being <span class="gemarra-regular">within the time required for speakin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a short phrase. <span class="gemarra-regular">One is the time required for a student to greet a rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one is the time required for the rabbi to greet a student. When does Rabbi Yosei hold </span>that a statement added within the time required for speaking a short phrase is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered continuous speech? When the words are added <span class="gemarra-regular">within the time required for a student to greet his rabbi </span>using the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Peace be upon you, my rabbi and teacher, as </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is a long </span>pause. By contrast, if the statement is added <span class="gemarra-regular">within the </span>shorter <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>frame <span class="gemarra-regular">required for the rabbi to greet his student: Peace be upon you, </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the added words constitute speech that is continuous with the original statement.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Witnesses </span>to a capital crime <span class="gemarra-regular">who were </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted </span>by two other witnesses, and <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately they, </span>the first set of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">were rendered conspiring witnesses, are killed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span>in accordance with the punishment for conspiring witnesses involved in a capital case, despite the fact that their testimony was already disqualified prior to the discovery of their conspiracy. The reason is that the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction</span> of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>the process <span class="gemarra-regular">has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">been completed </span>at the time of the contradiction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: From where do I say </span>that this is so? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 1:3) that if witnesses say: <span class="gemarra-regular">We testify with regard to so-and-so that he blinded his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave’s eye and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">knocked out his tooth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the master is obligated to pay him compensation for the value of his tooth, <span class="gemarra-regular">as that is what the master says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., this testimony is advantageous to the master, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">they were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses, they pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of an eye to the slave.</span>
Rava explains that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as written is problematic: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>it is exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is no other set </span>of witnesses other than those whose statement is quoted in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and the opposing set of witnesses who establish them as conspiring witnesses, several problems arise: First, why should they <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of an eye to the slave? After emancipating him </span>by testifying that his master has blinded him, should <span class="gemarra-regular">they be required to pay </span>him the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his eye?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, they should be required to pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the entire slave to the master, </span>as they intended to cause him to lose ownership of his slave through their false testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>why does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> say: <span class="gemarra-regular">As that is what the master says, </span>i.e., this testimony is advantageous to the master. <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">satisfactory to the master </span>that his slave be emancipated as a result of this testimony?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that this case involves another, competing, testimony that is not mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not </span>correct to say that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>prior to the testimonies mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>other witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">came and said: </span>The master first <span class="gemarra-regular">knocked out </span>the slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">tooth </span>and then <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his eye, in </span>which case <span class="gemarra-regular">the master is required </span>to emancipate the slave and also <span class="gemarra-regular">to give him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his eye; and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">an intermediate </span>set of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">came and said </span>the testimony quoted in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that first the master blinded the slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">eye and then </span>knocked out <span class="gemarra-regular">his tooth? </span>According to this account the master would still be required to emancipate the slave, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he would be required to give him only </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his tooth, </span>which is much less than the value of an eye. <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>this case the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicts </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">the intermediate ones.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this is </span>the meaning of the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">As that is what the master says, </span>i.e., this testimony is advantageous to the master. It means <span class="gemarra-regular">that what </span>the intermediate witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>i.e., that he owes the value of a tooth, <span class="gemarra-regular">is satisfactory to him, </span>as according to the claim of the first set, he owes the value of an eye. Since there are now contradictory testimonies, the testimony stating the claim of a loss of lesser value is accepted, and in that case the master would have to pay the slave only for the value of his tooth, in addition to emancipating him. This judgment corresponds exactly to the testimony of the intermediate set of witnesses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the intermediate </span>set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found to be conspiring witnesses, </span>as a third set of witnesses testified that the intermediate set was not at the scene of the incident at all. Therefore, the intermediate set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of an eye to the slave </span>less the value of a tooth, as this is the amount of monetary damage the slave stood to incur as a result of their testimony.
Rava concludes his proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction</span> of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony. Although the testimony of the intermediate set of witnesses had already been contradicted before it was shown to be conspiring testimony, nevertheless, they can still be established as conspiring witness at that later stage, which means that they must pay an amount equivalent to the loss they were attempting to cause through their testimony.
