<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: No. </span>There is another possible interpretation for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which answers the questions raised above and yet does not serve as proof for Rava’s opinion. According to this interpretation, the contradictory testimony was given after, not before, the testimony mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
It is possible that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a second set of witnesses both <span class="gemarra-regular">reversed </span>the order of events, by testifying that the tooth was knocked out before the blinding of the eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at the same time <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered </span>the first set witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">as conspiring witnesses, </span>by testifying that those original witnesses were not at the scene of the supposed events they claimed to have witnessed. It can be argued, albeit in a far-fetched manner, that the testimony of the first set of witnesses is considered to be to the master’s advantage even at this stage, because he knows what really happened, as reflected in the testimony of the later witnesses. Accordingly, Rava maintains that there are a total of three sets of witnesses in the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, while Abaye says that there are only two sets.
Abaye elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do I say that my interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is correct? 

Daf 74a

<span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case in which the second set witnesses both <span class="gemarra-regular">reverses </span>the order of events <span class="gemarra-regular">and renders </span>the first pair <span class="gemarra-regular">as conspiring witnesses, </span>it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first case as well, </span>in parallel fashion, states a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case in which the second set of witnesses both <span class="gemarra-regular">reverses </span>the order of events <span class="gemarra-regular">and renders </span>the first pair <span class="gemarra-regular">as conspiring witnesses.</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that if witnesses say: <span class="gemarra-regular">We testify </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so that he knocked out his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave’s tooth and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his eye, </span>which requires the master to emancipate him and compensate him for the value of his eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">as that is what the slave says, </span>i.e., this testimony is advantageous to the slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">they were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses, they pay the value of an eye to the master.</span>
Abaye analyzes this clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is speaking of a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where the latter </span>set of witnesses, who attested that the first set of witnesses were conspiring witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not concede that </span>there was any <span class="gemarra-regular">injury at all </span>inflicted on the slave by his master, then there is no testimony to confirm that those injuries were inflicted other than that given by the witnesses who were shown to be conspiring witnesses. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should be required to pay the entire value of the slave to the master, </span>as this is the amount of monetary damage the master stood to incur as a result of their false testimony.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is obvious that all of them, </span>i.e., both the first set of witnesses and the latter set, <span class="gemarra-regular">concede with regard to the injury </span>inflicted on the slave by the master. They both agree that the master both blinded the slave’s eye and knocked out his tooth and therefore is obligated to emancipate him. They disagree concerning only the order of events. The first set of witnesses said that the tooth injury occurred first and the eye injury occurred afterward. Consequently, they sought to require the master to emancipate the slave and compensate him for the eye injury.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the second set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">reversed </span>the order of events in their testimony, saying that the eye injury took place first, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the same testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">they rendered </span>the first pair <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> by testifying that they were not present when the events occurred. Since the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be interpreted in this manner, it stands to reason that the first case should be explained similarly.
The Gemara analyzes Abaye’s interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what are the circumstances</span> of the case? The second set of witnesses, who are deemed credible, have established that the injuries did not take place on the date reported by the first set of witnesses. According to their testimony, when did the injuries take place? <span class="gemarra-regular">If the latter </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">postdated </span>the events, by testifying that the injuries were actually inflicted at a later stage than that mentioned by the first set of witnesses, the first set of witnesses should <span class="gemarra-regular">still be required to pay the </span>full <span class="gemarra-regular">value of a slave to the master.</span>
The reason the first set of witnesses should be liable is <span class="gemarra-regular">that when they</span> sought to <span class="gemarra-regular">impose liability upon the man, </span>i.e., the master, this <span class="gemarra-regular">man was not yet </span>burdened with any <span class="gemarra-regular">liability. </span>When the first set of witnesses testified about the injuries, the master was not yet obligated to emancipate his slave or pay damages. Therefore, these conspiring witnesses should be required to pay these sums, which they had sought to impose on the master. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter </span>set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">predated </span>the time of the injuries, by testifying that they were inflicted at an earlier date than that attested to by the first set of witnesses.
The Gemara continues to analyze the case: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">had not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>for having injured his slave when the first set of witnesses submitted their testimony, those witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">should still be required to pay the entire value of the slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the master, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>at the time of their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">the man, </span>i.e., the master, was <span class="gemarra-regular">not yet liable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The first set of witnesses sought to render the master liable at a time when he was exempt from liability, and therefore they should be obligated to pay him the full value of the slave.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">stood tria</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> for having inflicted these injuries, and had been sentenced by the court to emancipate the slave for the first injury and pay him for the second injury. Then, the master evaded payment, and was subsequently brought before another court, where witnesses testified that the first court had established liability for knocking out the tooth first and then blinding the slave’s eye. This testimony was subsequently rendered conspiring testimony by a second set of witnesses, who testified both that the first set of witnesses was not at the scene of the first trial and that the results of the trial were actually reversed, i.e., the master’s liability was for blinding the eye first and then for knocking out the tooth. Since the first set of witnesses, who were rendered conspiring witnesses, sought to increase the master’s liability payment from that of the value of a tooth to that of an eye, they must pay the value of an eye to the master.
Rava sought to infer from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to his opinion that contradiction of testimony is the start of determining that testimony is conspiring testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said to Rav Ashi: From which </span>case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is the inference of Rava? If we say </span>that his inference is <span class="gemarra-regular">from the first clause, </span>this is difficult. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>if it involves three sets of witnesses, as claimed by Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">is the intermediate </span>set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted </span>and rejected before they are established as conspiring witnesses? The first set of witnesses testified that the eye injury took place after the tooth injury, whereas the intermediate set of witnesses reversed the order. If so, the intermediate set of witnesses sought to lower the master’s payment from the value of an eye to that of a tooth.
Rav Aḥa continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since if </span>the second set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">would not have been rendered conspiring witnesses, the testimony would </span>have been <span class="gemarra-regular">established in accordance with </span>their statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the judgment would have been decided in accordance with </span>their testimony. The reason their testimony would have determined the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">that one hundred dinars </span>is subsumed <span class="gemarra-regular">within two hundred, </span>i.e., testimony concerning a large sum includes testimony concerning a smaller sum.
Rav Aḥa continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, it is the first </span>set of witnesses, who testified that the eye injury occurred last, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>testimony would be considered <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted </span>and rejected, whereas the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">the intermediate </span>set of witnesses would <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> be considered <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted at all, </span>as it is accepted in full. If so, this is not a case of witnesses who were rejected due to contradiction and then subsequently rendered conspiring witnesses.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Aḥa in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">three sets </span>of witnesses, it is logical to assume that the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause is also </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>sets of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">infers </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause.</span>
Rava explains that the latter clause is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where two </span>witnesses, i.e., the ones mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">come and say: </span>The master <span class="gemarra-regular">knocked out </span>the slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">tooth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his eye, and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment in accordance with their statement, </span>obligating the master to emancipate his slave and compensate him for the value of his eye.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">two other </span>witnesses, who were not mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">come and say </span>that the events were reversed: First the master <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his </span>slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">eye and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he knocked out his tooth, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they contradict </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">those first </span>witnesses. At this point the master is obligated to emancipate his slave and pay him only the value of his tooth, as this much was required of him according to both sets of witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>then the first pair <span class="gemarra-regular">were found to be conspiring witnesses. </span>Therefore, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of an eye to the master, </span>less the value of a tooth.
Rava reaches his conclusion based on the following reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it enters your mind that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction </span>of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony, and witnesses who were first contradicted and then rendered conspiring witnesses are not punished as conspiring witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">why must </span>these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay? They were </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted from the outset, </span>before they were shown to be conspiring witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, conclude from </span>the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction </span>of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how could <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye,</span> who disagrees with Rava, refute this proof? He could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you: Granted, it is impossible </span>to interpret <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause without </span>the supposition <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">three sets </span>of witnesses involved. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>with regard to that first clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">As that is what the master says, </span>i.e., this testimony is satisfactory to the master. The only testimony recorded in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is that the master blinded the slave’s eye and then knocked out his tooth. Why would this be considered satisfactory to the master? It must therefore be assumed that this testimony was preceded by another one that was even less advantageous to the master. That testimony confirmed the injuries but placed the eye injury after the tooth injury, which involves greater liability for the master. Finally, a third set of witnesses must have arrived and rendered the intermediate set as conspiring witnesses, so that there are a total of three sets of witnesses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, why do I </span>need to explain it as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">three sets </span>of witnesses? If you say that it is because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states concerning this case: <span class="gemarra-regular">As that is what the slave says, </span>i.e., this testimony is satisfactory to the slave, this does not prove that there is another testimony, not mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that is less favorable to the slave than this one.
The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a slave would say anything, </span>i.e., any form of testimony would be favorable to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is satisfactory for him that he should be emancipated. </span>The court’s acceptance of testimony confirming either order of events would result in his emancipation from slavery, and therefore both testimonies are satisfactory to him. Although there is a compelling reason to posit the existence of three sets of witnesses in the first clause, there is no justification to do so in the second clause, and therefore it should be explained as did Abaye, as discussing only two sets of witnesses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira objects to </span>the basic assumption of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that when a master inflicts two injuries upon his Canaanite slave he must indemnify the slave for the second injury. One can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead that if the master <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his </span>slave’s <span class="gemarra-regular">eye, </span>

Daf 74b

the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">should go </span>free <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of his eye, </span>and if he <span class="gemarra-regular">knocked out his tooth </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">should go </span>free <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of his tooth, </span>and if the master both <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his eye and knocked out his tooth, </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">should go </span>free <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">his eye and his tooth, </span>without the master having to pay damages for the loss of his tooth.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>to him in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to your </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> “And if a man smites the eye of his slave or the eye of his maidservant and destroys it, he shall let him go free for his eye’s sake” (Exodus 21:26). The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“for his eye’s sake” </span>indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not for the sake of </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">his eye and his tooth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The same can be inferred from the subsequent verse: “And if he smites out his bondman’s tooth or his bondwoman’s tooth, he shall let him go free for his tooth’s sake” (Exodus 21:27). The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“for his tooth’s sake” </span>indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not for the sake of </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">his eye and his tooth.</span>
The Gemara returns to Rava’s opinion that the contradiction of testimony is the start of determining that testimony is conspiring testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: We too </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>from the mishna that Rava’s claim is correct, as it teaches (72b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, also <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of the same witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses, </span>these conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay everything, </span>i.e., not only the principal amount but also the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they testified concerning the theft and then testified concerning the slaughter, and they were </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the theft and then were rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the slaughter?</span>
Rav Idi bar Avin states his inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">But once they were rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the theft, </span>their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the slaughter </span>is in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted, </span>i.e., nullified, as testimony concerning the slaughter of an animal without prior testimony establishing that the animal was stolen is meaningless. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay everything. And if it enters your mind </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction </span>of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">why should they pay </span>a fine <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>lying about the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter? </span>Their testimony concerning the slaughter was rendered irrelevant before it was established as conspiring testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>this mishna that the <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction </span>of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is the start of determining that </span>testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>testimony?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in refutation of this inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the witnesses were <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered conspiring witnesses with regard to the slaughter first, </span>before they were rendered conspiring witnesses in their testimony concerning the theft itself. In this case, the testimony concerning the slaughter was not rendered irrelevant before it was rendered conspiring testimony.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is a matter <span class="gemarra-regular">in the dispute </span>between other <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>, before Rava and Abaye discussed it. As it was stated: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>to a capital crime <span class="gemarra-regular">who were </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted </span>by two other witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately were rendered conspiring witnesses, </span>this is a matter of dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar. One said: </span>These witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are killed, </span>like all conspiring witnesses in a capital case, as the contradiction of testimony is the start of determining that testimony is conspiring testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one said: They are not killed.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">It may be concluded </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says they are not killed. As Rabbi Elazar says: Witnesses who were contradicted in </span>a case involving the taking of <span class="gemarra-regular">a life, </span>i.e., a capital case, <span class="gemarra-regular">are flogge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for violating the prohibition: “You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor” (Exodus 20:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rabbi Elazar who says </span>that witnesses to a capital crime who were first contradicted and ultimately found to be conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are killed, why are they flogged </span>in this case? There is always the possibility that they might be rendered conspiring witnesses, which would render them liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment. Consequently, this is a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a prohibition given as warning </span>of liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for court</span>-imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">capital punishment, and </span>there is a principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">one is not flogged for </span>violating <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition given as warning </span>of liability <span class="gemarra-regular">for court</span>-imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">capital </span><span class="gemarra-regular">punishment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rabbi Elazar who says </span>that witnesses to a capital crime who were first contradicted and ultimately were found to be conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are not killed? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">It may be concluded </span>that this is so.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion that witnesses who were contradicted in a capital case are flogged. Why <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">flogged </span>simply because their testimony was contradicted? <span class="gemarra-regular">They are two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they are contradicted by <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>other witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">What did you see </span>in the testimony of the second set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>leads <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on those </span>witnesses to the extent that the first set of witnesses is flogged? You could just as well <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on these </span>witnesses, i.e., the first witnesses. How can the court ever determine with certainty that a given testimony is false based merely on contradictory testimony?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The contradiction to which Rabbi Elazar is referring involves a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the witnesses testified that they saw a certain person murdered, and subsequently the individual who was allegedly <span class="gemarra-regular">killed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came </span>to the court <span class="gemarra-regular">on his feet, </span>conclusively disproving their testimony.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtere</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>the stolen animal, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness or based on his own </span>admission, i.e., he himself admitted that he performed these acts, without there being any witness testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, but he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a capital offense, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole his father’s </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">his father died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and afterward he slaughtered or sold </span>it, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated </span>it as an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he slaughtered or sold </span>it, in all these cases the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, but he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to replace with another animal if one of the original animals that one stole is lost or dies, the thief is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>if he slaughters one of the animals. If it is a sacrificial animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">bears no </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility, </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if the fact that the thief slaughtered or sold the animal was established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness, </span>he is exempt from the fourfold of fivefold payment. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: By stating this case, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: The case of the thief slaughtering the animal established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness is similar to </span>a case where it is established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>in the case where the slaughter is established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness, if one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">witness comes </span>and corroborates the testimony of the first, he <span class="gemarra-regular">joins together with</span> the first witness and together their testimony is rendered a valid testimony of two, and the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>where the slaughter is established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">if witnesses come </span>after his admission he <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara comments: This interpretation of the mishna serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Huna </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says. As Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt </span>from payment, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses com</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and testify to his liability.
Since Rav Huna’s <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was mentioned, the Gemara discusses in detail <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt </span>from payment, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda raised an objection to Rav Huna </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving Rabban Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who blinded the eye of his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave Tavi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he experienced great jo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> as a result. Rabban Gamliel had long wanted to emancipate Tavi, but it is generally prohibited to emancipate a Canaanite slave. The injury provided a fortuitous opportunity for Rabban Gamliel to emancipate his slave, as blinding the eye of one’s slave results in his emancipation (see Exodus 21:27).
Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">encountered Rabbi Yehoshu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do you know that my slave Tavi was emancipated? </span>Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Why? </span>What circumstances enabled you to emancipate him? Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span> I was able to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I blinded his eye. </span>Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabban Gamliel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your statement is nothing, </span>and is not grounds for his emancipation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he has no witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who can testify that you did this to him. The principle is that one does not pay a fine based on his own admission. One pays a fine only based on the testimony of witnesses. The requirement to emancipate one’s slave after injuring his eye is a type of fine.
The Gemara infers from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if Tavi <span class="gemarra-regular">had witnesses </span>who could testify with regard to the injury, Rabban Gamliel would be <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to emancipate him, even if they testify after Rabban Gamliel’s admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>this that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liable, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify with regard to his liability.
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Ḥisda: This case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel is different, as he admitted </span>to his actions when he was <span class="gemarra-regular">not in the presence of a court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> An admission not in the presence of a court does not exempt the perpetrator from paying the relevant fine. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yehoshua was the president of the court, </span>so it is likely that the encounter took place in court. 

Daf 75a

The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">in court </span>when Rabban Gamliel encountered him.
The Gemara asks a question from a different source: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabban Gamliel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your statement is nothing, as you have already admitted </span>to inflicting the injury yourself? This indicates that even if witnesses would subsequently testify about the injury, Rabban Gamliel would not emancipate Tavi. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>the case that the difference between these two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua’s statement was: <span class="gemarra-regular">As you have no witnesses, holds </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is liable </span>to pay the fine if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua’s statement was: <span class="gemarra-regular">As you have already admitted, holds </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt </span>from payment, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>it is possible to understand the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> differently. <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone agrees </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt, </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree with regard to </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua said: <span class="gemarra-regular">As you have no witnesses, holds that </span>Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">was outside the court </span>when Rabban Gamliel encountered him, and therefore his admission is disregarded. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who says </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua said: <span class="gemarra-regular">As you have already admitted, holds </span>that Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">was in the court </span>when Rabban Gamliel met him, so Rabban Gamliel’s admission is a valid admission.
The Gemara analyzes in detail the dispute alluded to above: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, and afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and Shmuel says </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Ahilai said: What is the reason for </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? </span>With regard to theft, which is subject to a fine of double payment, the Torah states: “If the theft shall be found in his possession alive, whether it is an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:3). The verb for “shall be found” is doubled, as the verse states “<span class="it-text">himmatze</span> <span class="it-text">timmatze</span>.” Rav derives from the repetition that there are two matters that are found: The double payment is imposed only <span class="gemarra-regular">if it is found </span>[<span class="it-text">himmatze</span>], i.e., it is revealed that he stole the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>and the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>[<span class="it-text">timmatze</span>], as determined <span class="gemarra-regular">through judges. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes one who incriminates himself </span>through his own admission.
Rav asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the Torah to teach this here? This principle is already <span class="gemarra-regular">derived from </span>a different source: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The one whom the judges convict </span>shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8), which indicates that self-incrimination is insufficient to render one liable for double payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the fact that there are two verses to serve as the source for this principle that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>he is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine is exempt </span>from paying even if <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward witnesses come </span>and testify to his liability. The second verse teaches this additional novelty.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span>would explain the double expression differently. He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: That</span> verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary to </span>teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief himself </span>must pay double payment, i.e., the double payment is imposed not only upon a bailee who takes a false oath that the article entrusted to him was stolen, but it is also imposed upon a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the school of Ḥizkiyya taught </span>earlier in this chapter (63b).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav raised an objection to Shmuel </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">saw witnesses who were approaching </span>with the intent to testify against him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at that point <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span>I admit that <span class="gemarra-regular">I stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I did not slaughter or sell </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays only the principal. </span>This indicates that even if those witnesses subsequently testify, the thief remains exempt from the double payment as well as the fourfold or fivefold payment. Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? With a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the witnesses returned back</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., ultimately they did not testify.
Rav raised an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this interpretation is impossible, as can be seen <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: Let the witnesses come and testify. </span>This means that their testimony will be accepted and the thief will be required to pay the relevant fines. <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference </span>it may be deduced <span class="gemarra-regular">that the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>there is no point in the witnesses testifying, as the thief will be exempt in any case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said to </span>Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t there </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, which stands in accordance with my </span>opinion? When I said that one who admits that he is liable to pay a fine and afterward witnesses testified that he committed that act is deemed liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">I said </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Shmuel, </span>his opinion on this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly </span>subject to a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as he himself was forced to admit that his opinion is in accordance only with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, not that of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. But <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rav, shall we say </span>that his opinion too <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>necessarily subject to this dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I say </span>my opinion in accordance with the rulings of both <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says </span>that the testimony of the witnesses obligates the thief to pay a fine even after his admission <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>in that specific case, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>his guilt solely <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">fear </span>of the impending testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of the witnesses. But here, </span>in an ordinary case of admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> there is no impending testimony to incriminate him, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he admits </span>his guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">of his own </span>volition, <span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">concede </span>that the thief is exempt from payment even if witnesses subsequently testify that he is liable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna said: Rav’s statement is </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I stole </span>an item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole </span>that item. In that case it is logical that the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying the fine despite the witnesses’ testimony, because he at least <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated himself to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal </span>amount via his admission.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he says: I did not steal </span>anything, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did steal </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and subsequently </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Yes, I did steal the animal, and <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>I also <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he slaughtered or sold </span>it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. The reason he is liable is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> through his admission he sought to <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt himself from any </span>payment whatsoever. In order for an admission to exempt the perpetrator from a fine, it must include an admission that he is liable to pay some payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>In this case <span class="gemarra-regular">I have gotten the better [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kipaḥti</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the elders of the school of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a reference to Rav Hamnuna. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel </span>injuring his slave, he <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>seeking to <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt himself from any payment </span>whatsoever through his admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet earlier in the Gemara it was said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda stated </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Huna </span>to challenge Rav Huna’s opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">did not answer him </span>that Rabban Gamliel’s case was different because his admission served to exempt him entirely.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was also stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>the same opinion as Rav Hamnuna. If a thief says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I stole </span>an item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole </span>that item, the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying the fine despite the witnesses’ testimony, because he at least <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates himself, </span>through his admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he says: I did not steal </span>anything, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did steal </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and subsequently </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Yes, I did steal the animal, and <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>I also <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>it, and then <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he slaughtered or sold </span>it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>through his admission <span class="gemarra-regular">he was </span>seeking to <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt himself from any </span>payment whatsoever.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishna and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> that are <span class="gemarra-regular">also precisely </span>formulated in accordance with this opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>(74b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the stolen animal, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness or based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, but he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the mishna to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>in the beginning of this case: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an ox or a sheep, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the case more simply: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it, as established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness or based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays only the principal. </span>This would serve to teach the same principle in a less complicated manner, without the need for two additional witnesses. 

Daf 75b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>correct to say that by citing the more complicated case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: It is </span>only in this case, where it is established that the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is established that <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered </span>or sold it <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness or based on his own </span>admission, and <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not obligate himself </span>through his admission <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal, </span>that he is obligated to pay the fine.
The Gemara elaborates: In other words, it is only in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where the theft is established based on the testimony of two witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">that we say </span>that liability <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission <span class="gemarra-regular">is similar to the </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of one witness, </span>in that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as when </span>the slaughter is established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">witness </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">comes he joins together with </span>the first witness and together their testimony is rendered a valid testimony of two witnesses and the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes liable </span>to pay, so <span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>in a case when the slaughter is established <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his own </span>admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">if witnesses </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and testify, he <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes liable </span>to pay the fine, as his admission would not have rendered him liable to pay any payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it is established that the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered or sold </span>it, all <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness or based on his own </span>admission, in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>case through his admission <span class="gemarra-regular">he obligates himself to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal</span> amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that when witnesses testify subsequent <span class="gemarra-regular">to his own </span>admission it is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to when they arrive subsequent <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of one witness, </span>and he is liable to pay the fine in both cases. Rather, since in this case his admission would have rendered him liable to pay the principal due to the fact that the theft was not established based on the testimony of two witnesses, it is considered a proper admission, which exempts him from paying the fine.
The <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> that supports Rav Hamnuna’s opinion is the one cited earlier, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught: </span>If a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">saw witnesses who were approaching </span>with the intent to testify against him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at that point he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>I admit that <span class="gemarra-regular">I stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I did not slaughter or sell </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays only the principal. Why </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do I </span>need the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach: And </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>I admit that <span class="gemarra-regular">I stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">but I did not slaughter or sell </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let it teach </span>a simpler case, in which the thief said <span class="gemarra-regular">either: I stole </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: I slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: I sold </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>by choosing the more complicated case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: The </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason that </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>from payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is that he says: I stole </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">he obligated himself to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he says: I did not steal, and witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did steal </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and subsequently</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>changed his claim and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: I sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and confirmed <span class="gemarra-regular">that he slaughtered or sold </span>it, in which case the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">did not obligate himself to pay the principal </span>or any other payment, he would be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, an admission to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">admission, </span>as such an admission does not obligate the perpetrator to pay a fine.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says, </span>in rejection of this second proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is possible to explain the reason the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> chose to present this case in a different manner, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: That once </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I stole </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I did not slaughter or sell </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that he slaughtered or sold it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this exemption? 
The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a payment of four </span>sheep for a sheep and <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>oxen for an ox (see Exodus 21:37). This indicates that a thief can be rendered liable to pay, respectively, a fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not a fourfold payment </span>for an ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor a threefold payment </span>for a sheep. In other words, one should not view the fines as independent of each other, that if the thief is found with the animal he pays as a fine the double payment, and if he slaughtered or sold it he pays a different fine, i.e., the fourfold or fivefold payment. Rather, the fourfold or fivefold payment comprises the principle, the double payment, and an additional two or three times the principle. By admitting to his act of theft, the thief exempts himself from the double payment, and the remaining fine for slaughtering a sheep would be a threefold payment, or a fourfold payment for an ox, which are not mandated by the Torah.
The Gemara proposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the opinion of Rav Hamnuna and Rabbi Yoḥanan is the <span class="gemarra-regular">subject of </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>As it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testify that </span>some-one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">testify </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">him that he slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, and the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>who had testified concerning the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft were rendered conspiring witnesses, </span>the thief is exempt from all payment, as <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated. </span>If the testimony concerning the theft was undermined, the testimony concerning the slaughter or sale is thereby rendered irrelevant. Consequently, the alleged thief is exempt from any payment.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the witnesses </span>who testified concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">the slaughter </span>or sale <span class="gemarra-regular">were rendered conspiring witnesses, </span>but the testimony concerning the theft remains credible, the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, and </span>the conspiring witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a threefold payment, </span>as that is the loss they sought to impose on the thief. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said in the name of Sumakhos: </span>The witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, and </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays a threefold payment for an ox and a twofold </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for a ram. </span>This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara analyzes the statement of Sumakhos: <span class="gemarra-regular">To which </span>clause in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is Sumakhos referring? If we say </span>that he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the first clause, </span>in which the testimony concerning the theft is invalidated, this is impossible. <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Sumakhos </span>accept the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated, </span>in this case rendering the testimony concerning the slaughter or sale irrelevant if there is no testimony concerning the theft?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, </span>he must be referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, in which the testimony concerning the slaughter or sale is invalidated. This, too, is impossible, as in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">say well, </span>i.e., what they state is reasonable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay a threefold payment. </span>On what basis would Sumakhos dispute this ruling?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that Sumakhos is referring to a different case entirely, one that is not mentioned explicitly in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, and <span class="gemarra-regular">a different matter is </span>at the core of the dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">between them. </span>Sumakhos is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">You stole </span>an animal. The thief <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, I did steal </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">I slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: I sold </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But I did not steal </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in your presence, </span>and your testimony that you saw me steal it is false. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> subsequently the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses who rendered </span>the original witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses, </span>by testifying that they were in a different place at the time they claimed that the theft occurred, thereby proving <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">did not steal in their presence. And </span>finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses who testified that </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered or sold </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Sumakhos and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree over </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">an admission to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of a stolen animal is a valid admission, even though it does not lead to liability to pay any payment. Both parties to the dispute agree that the admission of a perpetrator only in response to the testimony of witnesses is not a valid admission.
The dispute between them is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Rabbis maintain that even though </span>the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">admission concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>itself is not a valid admission because it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the witnesses </span>who have testified against him that <span class="gemarra-regular">he admits </span>his guilt, nevertheless, his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">admission, </span>despite the fact it does not render the thief liable to pay a fine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment. The conspiring witnesses must pay the double payment to the thief, since this is the amount of financial damage they sought to impose on him, while the thief pays the double payment to the owner, as valid witnesses ultimately testified that he stole the animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Sumakhos maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">admission concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>itself is not a valid admission because it was <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses that he admits </span>his guilt, so too, the admission <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">admission, </span>because it does not obligate him to pay a fine, as stated by Rav Hamnuna and Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">those first witnesses </span>to the theft, <span class="gemarra-regular">who were rendered conspiring witnesses, pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, </span>as that is the amount of financial damage they sought to impose on him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the double payment to the owner of the animal, as valid witnesses ultimately testified that he stole it, and since his admission is invalid he must pay an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">threefold </span>payment, for a total of a fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for an ox, or a twofold </span>payment, for a total of a fourfold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">for a ram. </span>If this is their dispute, Sumakhos is in agreement with the opinion of Rav Hamnuna and Rabbi Yoḥanan, while the Rabbis disagree with this opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: No; </span>it is possible to explain the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> differently, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone, </span>i.e., both Sumakhos and the Rabbis, maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">an admission concerning </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of a stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">admission, </span>as it does not render the perpetrator liable to pay any payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, they disagree over </span>the concept of <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that you cannot render conspiratory </span>testimony. Sumakhos and the Rabbis disagree with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where witnesses come and say to </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">You stole </span>an animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did steal </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">I slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: I sold </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>you are false witnesses, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it was not in your presence that I stole </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in the presence of so-and-so and so-and-so. And </span>the thief subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">brought witnesses who established </span>the first set of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">as conspiring witnesses </span>by testifying that the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">did not steal </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in their presence. And </span>finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so and so-and-so, </span>the two people mentioned by the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">came and testified against </span>the thief, saying that <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>point that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, that the Rabbis maintain </span>that the testimony of so-and-so and so-and-so is <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that you cannot render conspiratory </span>testimony, as the thief himself admits that their testimony is true. <span class="gemarra-regular">And any testimony that you cannot render conspiratory </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered valid <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony. </span>Their testimony is therefore discounted, which leaves only the thief’s statement. The thief pays the money he admitted he owes, i.e., the principal of the theft, but he is exempt from paying a fine. Meanwhile, the first witnesses, who had been rendered conspiring witnesses, pay the thief the double payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Sumakhos maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony that you cannot render conspiratory </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>nevertheless considered valid <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony. </span>Therefore, the testimony of so-and-so and so-and-so is valid, and the thief must pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. Sumakhos states that the thief pays a threefold payment for an ox and a twofold payment for a ram. The reason is that the thief receives a double payment from the first, conspiring witnesses, which he gives to the owner of the animal, along with the remainder of the payment. This amounts to a threefold payment for an ox and twofold payment for a ram that he is required to pay from his own funds.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But do we not maintain </span>as an accepted principle <span class="gemarra-regular">that testimony that you cannot render conspiratory </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>valid <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony? </span>It is not reasonable to suggest that Sumakhos would disagree with that principle. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>witnesses say <span class="gemarra-regular">that they do not know on which day </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">at which time </span>of day the events in question occurred, in which case no one could ever say to them: You were in a different place at that time, thereby rendering them conspiring witnesses. With regard to such a case one can say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no testimony at all, </span>as the vague statement of the witnesses does not allow them to be prosecuted as conspiring witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">supporting</span> their testimony, which renders it more credible.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the Sages stated in the name of Sumakhos: The witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the thief admits that he stole </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to pay the principal </span>amount regardless of any subsequent testimony provided by witnesses. Why, then, should the conspiring witnesses be required to pay a double payment, which includes the principal amount? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says in the name of Rav: Teach </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> differently, and instead say that Sumakhos said that the witnesses are liable for 

Daf 76a

the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment of </span>the extra part of the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, </span>i.e., the amount that exceeds the principal.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it </span>as an offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he slaughtered or sold </span>it, the thief pays the double payment but he does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
