The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Granted, he is not liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for the slaughter </span>of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when he slaughtered </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to the Temple </span>treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not slaughter </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to its owner.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But let him be liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>having <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>the animal in the first place, as <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary </span>person, and <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it to Heaven </span>by consecrating it? Consecration should be considered tantamount to a sale, as in either case ownership of the animal is transferred to another party.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna taught? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to replace with another animal if one of the original animals is lost or dies <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">to be in the possession of their owne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> (see 74b). The mishna is referring a case where the thief consecrated the animal in such a manner that he is obligated to replace it if it is lost or damaged before being sacrificed. One consequence of this potential financial loss is that the animal is considered to be in the thief’s possession even after he consecrated it. Therefore, the animal’s consecration is not tantamount to a sale to another party.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>it follows that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna, which is stated before his opinion is introduced, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, with what are we dealing here </span>in the mishna? We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case where the thief consecrated the animal as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of lesser sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of lesser sanctity is the property of </span>its putative <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, and is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession. </span>Therefore, its consecration is not tantamount to a sale to another party.
The Gemara rejects this answer as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">But what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> had the thief consecrated the animal as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of the most sacred order? </span>Would he have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">rather than teaching </span>the following in <span class="gemarra-regular">the earlier clause </span>of the mishna (70a), in the case that stands in opposition to this one: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he consecrated </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">distinguish and teach</span> the opposing <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the same category <span class="gemarra-regular">itself.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> could have taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that the thief is exempt if he consecrated the stolen animal and then slaughtered or sold it, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said only if he consecrated the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of lesser sanctity; but </span>if he consecrated it <span class="gemarra-regular">as an offering of the most sacred order he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment, </span>as the consecration itself would be tantamount to a sale to another party.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually there is no difference </span>whether the thief consecrates the animal as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of the most sacred order </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no difference </span>whether he consecrates it as <span class="gemarra-regular">an offering of lesser sanctity. And as</span> for the matter that presented <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty for you, </span>namely: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary </span>person and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it to Heaven </span>by consecration, one can answer as follows: If someone, e.g., Reuven, <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary </span>person, e.g., Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven’s ox and now,</span> after the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Shimon’s ox. </span>By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it to Heaven, </span>i.e., he consecrated it as an offering, it is not considered to have been transferred into the possession of another party, as <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven’s ox and now, </span>after consecration, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven’s ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>In the case of sacrificial animals for which the owner bears financial responsibility to replace with another animal if one of the original animals that one stole is lost or dies, the thief is obligated to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment if he slaughters one of the animals. If it is a sacrificial animal for which the owner bears no financial responsibility, the thief is exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment. At this stage the Gemara assumes that Rabbi Shimon requires the fourfold or fivefold payment as a fine for the act of consecration itself rather than for the act of slaughtering the animal. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Although Rabbi Shimon holds </span>that there is a logic of: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary </span>person and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it to Heaven </span>via consecration, nevertheless, he <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>said <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: He should have said that if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which one bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying the fourfold or fivefold payment. In other words, if the thief stole a non-sacred animal and subsequently consecrated it as an offering in such a manner that he bears responsibility to replace it, he should be exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment for the act of consecration. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has not yet left his possession, </span>and therefore this act of consecration should not be considered a sale.
By contrast, if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which one does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility, </span>the thief should be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. If the thief stole a non-sacred animal and then consecrated it as an offering in such a way that he does not bear responsibility to replace it, he should be liable to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment for the act of consecration, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he has </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">removed </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from his possession.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>is not discussing the issue of whether the consecration of an animal is tantamount to its sale. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is referring to a different matter, </span>one that is not explicitly mentioned in the mishna. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this is what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: One who steals </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">after a thief </span>has already stolen it, i.e., he steals it from the thief, does not pay the double payment, and if he slaughtered or sold the animal he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. And similarly, one who steals consecrated </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the house of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> is exempt from the double payment, and if it was a sacrificial animal and the thief slaughtered or sold it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this last ruling? The reason is as it is written: “If a man gives his neighbor money or vessels to safeguard <span class="gemarra-regular">and it was stolen from the house of the man, </span>if the thief shall be found he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6). The phrase “from the house of the man” indicates that a thief is obligated to pay the double payment only when they are stolen from a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>if the item in question was stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">out of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">house of the Temple </span>treasury.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>If the stolen items were <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">for which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility, </span>the thief who steals them <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay the double payment, as well as the fourfold or fivefold payment if he slaughters or sells them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Since the owner must replace the animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">one applies </span>to this case the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“and it was stolen from the house of the man.” But </span>if the stolen animals are those for <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the double payment and from the fourfold and fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as one does not apply </span>to this case the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“and it was stolen from the house of the man.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Now, we have heard </span>elsewhere <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning Rabbi Shimon that he said: </span>An act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that is not fit </span>for accomplishing its full ritual purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>at all. And if the thief slaughtered the <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animal he stole, this <span class="gemarra-regular">is also </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that is not fit </span>for accomplishing its full ritual purpose, as it does not render the animal’s meat fit for consumption, in light of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that it is prohibited to eat a sacrificial animal slaughtered outside the Temple.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished, inside </span>the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner. </span>In this case, its meat may be eaten.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>by slaughtering and sacrificing the sacrificial animal on behalf of the owner, it is as though the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal, </span>i.e., the animal itself, has been <span class="gemarra-regular">returned to the owner, </span>and the fourfold or fivefold payment should no longer apply. The owner had designated the animal as his offering, and it was in fact used for that purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Avin said </span>in response: This is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where the </span>animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">blood was spilled </span>before it could be sprinkled on the altar. Consequently, the owner did not achieve atonement through this offering, which is why it is not considered as though the animal has been returned to the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he cited a different version of this answer, and said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished, inside </span>the Temple, but <span class="gemarra-regular">not for the sake of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case is that the animal’s meat may be eaten but the owner has not fulfilled his obligation with this offering. In such a case, the slaughter of the animal does render its meat fit for consumption. Yet, it is not considered as though the animal has been returned to the owner. 

Daf 76b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says </span>yet another explanation as to why the principal has not been returned to the owner: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters blemished </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>the Temple. A blemished animal may be slaughtered outside the Temple and its meat may be eaten, provided that it is redeemed with money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar wondered about this </span>discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the explanations attributed to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>which are based on the assumption that this is referring to slaughtering a sacrificial animal inside the Temple, is it the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering </span>of the animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for consumption? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinklin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> of the blood that <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted? </span>It is prohibited to eat sacrificial meat immediately after the slaughter; only after the sprinkling of the blood is it permitted to consume the meat. As the slaughter itself does not render the animal’s meat permitted, there should be no liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
Rabbi Elazar continues: And <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish, </span>who states that the case is referring to the slaughter of a consecrated blemished animal outside the Temple, is it the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering</span> of the animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for consumption? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption </span>of the animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted? </span>Since the thief slaughtered a sacrificial animal, it is prohibited to eat its meat until its sanctity is removed by redeeming it with money. Once again, the slaughter itself does not render the meat permitted, and here too, there should be no liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara comments: Apparently, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>following statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon escaped</span> Rabbi Elazar, who asked these questions. Rabbi Shimon holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>blood <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be sprinkled is considered </span>as though it had already been <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkled, and </span>likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be redeemed is considered </span>as if it had already been <span class="gemarra-regular">redeemed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara proves that Rabbi Shimon maintains these two opinions. Rabbi Shimon holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>blood <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be sprinkled is considered </span>as though it had already been <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkled, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: There are </span>cases involving <span class="gemarra-regular">leftover </span>sacrificial meat <span class="gemarra-regular">after the time allotted for its consumption [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">notar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the meat is susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food, and there are </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">leftover </span>sacrificial meat in which the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>If sacrificial meat was disqualified due to the fact that it <span class="gemarra-regular">remained overnight, </span>i.e., after the allotted time for that offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling </span>of its blood, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food, </span>as it was never fit for consumption. According to Rabbi Shimon, for an item to be susceptible to contracting ritual impurity of food it must have been permitted for consumption or benefit, either at present or at some point in the past. Sacrificial meat may not be consumed before the sprinkling of its blood, nor may it be consumed if it had been left over after a specific period of time, in most cases overnight. If it was disqualified by being left overnight before its blood had been sprinkled, there was never a time when the meat was permitted. By contrast, if the meat was disqualified by being left over <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling </span>of the blood, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food, </span>as it was permitted for consumption at some point after the sprinkling of the blood.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we maintain, </span>as a result of a discussion recorded in tractate <span class="it-text">Menaḥot</span> (101b): <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling </span>of the blood? It means <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit for sprinkling. </span>And what is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling </span>of the blood? This means <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit for sprinkling, </span>i.e., immediately subsequent to the slaughter.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the case in which the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">remained overnight before </span>the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit for sprinkling? </span>Since the blood is fit for sprinkling almost immediately after the animal’s slaughter, how is it possible for the meat to become <span class="it-text">notar</span> before that stage? The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there was not enough time in the day to sprinkle </span>the blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he slaughtered </span>the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately prior to sunset. </span>The blood was never fit for sprinkling, as the act of sprinkling must be performed before sunset. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this case the meat is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food, </span>as there was never a time when it was permitted for consumption.
What is the case where the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">remained overnight after </span>the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit for sprinkling? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">when there was </span>enough <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">in the day </span>after the slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">to sprinkle </span>the blood, and therefore the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food. </span>The Gemara states its conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Evidently, </span>Rabbi Shimon maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>blood <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be sprinkled is considered </span>as though it had already been <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkled.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Shimon holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be re-deemed is considered </span>as though it is already <span class="gemarra-regular">redeemed, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>

Daf 77a

The meat of the red <span class="gemarra-regular">heife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">contracting ritual impurity of food</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> despite the fact that it is prohibited to derive benefit from such meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it had a time when it was fit </span>for consumption. 

Daf 77b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says, </span>in explanation of Rabbi Shimon’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon would say</span> that the red <span class="gemarra-regular">heifer can be redeeme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with money even when it has already been slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">upon its pyre, </span>i.e., for the sake of purification. For this reason Rabbi Shimon claimed that the meat had a time when it was fit for consumption, as it can be rendered permitted for consumption through redemption. The Gemara states its conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Evidently, </span>Rabbi Shimon holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is ready to be redeemed is considered </span>as though it has already been <span class="gemarra-regular">redeemed.</span>
The Gemara discusses the relative merits of the answers provided by Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, Rabbi Yoḥanan did not state </span>an answer <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, </span>i.e., Reish Lakish, that the mishna is referring to a blemished animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he wants to interpret the mishna </span>as dealing with all kinds of sacrificial animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">even with unblemished </span>ones. <span class="gemarra-regular">But what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish did not state </span>an answer <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan?</span>
Reish Lakish could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that the verse states: “If a man steals an ox or a sheep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughters it or sells it” </span>(Exodus 21:37). This verse compares slaughtering to selling, thereby indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>of a particular animal <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>likewise applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, and anywhere that </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>of an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span> either. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">since when one sells sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale, </span>and no fourfold or fivefold payment is incurred, so too, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>fourfold or fivefold payment for their <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> these two Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">follow their </span>own lines of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning. As it was stated: According to the statement of Rabbi Shimon </span>that an act of slaughter that is not fit for accomplishing its full ritual purpose is not considered an act of slaughter at all and does not entail liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, in the case of a thief who <span class="gemarra-regular">sells </span>a stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">animal with a wound</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that will cause it to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment if he sells the animal rather than slaughters it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for the slaughter </span>of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, as its meat may not be eaten, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. And Reish Lakish says </span>that the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>as, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> according to Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>either.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., a sheep-goat hybrid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered it, </span>or if he stole <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sold it, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. What, is it not </span>correct to say that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which mentions the case of selling a stolen <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> but not slaughtering it, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon? Apparently, </span>according to Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>nevertheless applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">sale.</span>
Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not taught in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. Rather, it follows the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Shimon and maintain that a thief is liable for the fourfold or fivefold payment for slaughtering an animal even if the act of slaughter does not render its meat fit for consumption, as in the case of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> reflects the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>why does it mention the sale of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> but not its slaughter? According to the opinion of the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the fourfold or fivefold payment applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span> while <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter? </span>This is certainly not the case.
The Gemara responds with a counter-question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>would you say, that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> reflects the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon? </span>The same difficulty could be raised in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, </span>as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mentions the animal’s slaughter but not its sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is </span>the fourfold of fivefold payment applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of an animal of diverse kinds, while <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">sale? </span>There is certainly no difference between slaughtering and selling in this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one cannot make such inferences from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>liability with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>of diverse kinds, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. </span>If so, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis as well: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>liability with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. </span>Once the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is interpreted in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis and not that of Rabbi Shimon, it has no bearing on the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you: What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>comparison? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> reflects the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>and that is why it referred specifically to the sale of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it </span>necessarily <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> manner, that of selling, it maintained the same style of presentation and <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds in </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> manner, that of slaughtering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>there is no reason for it to present just one scenario in either case. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">combine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them and teach them </span>in a single sentence: <span class="gemarra-regular">If one stole </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds or a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span> and then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>either one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>The Gemara concludes: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>according to the opinion of Reish Lakish.
§ The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that a thief is liable to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment in the case of an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds. </span>The Gemara asks: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the Torah: “If a man steals an ox or <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> (Exodus 21:37), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rava says, </span>concerning the verse: “These are the animals that you may eat: The ox, the <span class="it-text">seh</span> of a sheep, and the <span class="it-text">seh</span> of a goat” (Deuteronomy 14:4), that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes a paradigm </span>for other cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">Wherever </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is stated </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude only </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds. </span>The Hebrew word <span class="it-text">seh</span> denotes either a sheep or a goat. A hybrid, which is neither a sheep nor a goat, does not qualify as a <span class="it-text">seh</span>. Why, then, is the fourfold or fivefold payment applicable to one who stole this kind of animal?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different here, </span>in the case of the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states “or” </span>(Exodus 21:37), a term that could have been avoided, as explained earlier (67b). This extra word serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, </span>i.e., the sheep-goat hybrid.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">every</span> instance of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>diverse kinds? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written: “When a bull or a sheep or a goat is born, it shall be seven days under its mother and from the eighth day onward it may be accepted as a fire-offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:27). The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“a bull or a sheep” </span>serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., an animal of diverse kinds may not be brought as an offering. The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“or a goat” </span>serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">resembles </span>another, i.e., a sheep that is the offspring of two sheep but that looks like a goat, or vice versa.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in response: The derivation from the word “or” depends on the verse in question. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>it is interpreted <span class="gemarra-regular">based on the context of the verse, and there, </span>it is also interpreted <span class="gemarra-regular">based on the context</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the verse. Here, with regard to theft, </span>the reason the word “or” serves as an inclusion is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written: “An ox or a sheep,” </span>which are two animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from which you cannot produce diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they cannot procreate together, and therefore the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to sacrificial </span>animals, the reason the word “or” serves as an exclusion is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written “sheep” and “goat,” </span>which are two animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from which you can produce diverse kinds. </span>Consequently, the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“or” </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>diverse kinds. 

Daf 78a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">it is also stated </span>in the first part of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A bull or a sheep” </span>(Leviticus 22:27), which are two animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you cannot produce diverse kinds. And </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us include </span>an animal of diverse kinds as being fit for sacrifice on the altar on that account. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the verse: “Or a goat,” serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a type of animal from being fit for sacrifice on the altar, it may be inferred that the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause: </span>“A bull or a sheep,” also serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a type of animal from being fit for sacrifice on the altar. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>one could equally argue that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the first clause </span>of the verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a type of animal as being fit for sacrifice on the altar, the <span class="gemarra-regular">latter clause</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>a type of animal as being fit for sacrifice on the altar.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>comparison? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that both expressions serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>types of animals from being fit for sacrifice on the altar, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">two exclusions were necessary: </span>One exclusion is referring to diverse kinds and the other is referring to an animal that resembles another species, <span class="gemarra-regular">as even though </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds is excluded, it was </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary to exclude </span>an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">resembles </span>another. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that both phrases serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>types of animals as being fit for sacrifice on the altar, <span class="gemarra-regular">why are two inclusions </span>required? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds has been included, </span>in the first inclusion, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to say that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">resembles </span>another is also included? There is more justification for including an animal that resembles another, whose parentage is entirely of one species, than for including an animal of diverse kinds.
The Gemara has established that when the Torah uses the word <span class="it-text">seh</span> (Exodus 21:37) in the context of theft it does not serve to exclude animals of diverse kinds. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>what is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rava says </span>with regard to the verse: “The ox, the <span class="it-text">seh</span> of a sheep, and the <span class="it-text">seh</span> of a goat” (Deuteronomy 14:4), that <span class="gemarra-regular">this establishes a paradigm </span>for other cases, teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">wherever </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is stated</span> in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude only </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds. With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> did Rava state this principle? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this principle is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written explicitly with regard to them: “A bull or a sheep” </span>(Leviticus 22:27), which, as taught in the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude diverse kinds.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this principle is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">animal tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> concerning which it is written: “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock [<span class="it-text">tzon</span>], any one that passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred unto the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32), this principle is not necessary either. The reason is that the exclusion of diverse kinds can be <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>by means of a verbal analogy <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“under” </span>in this verse, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“under” </span>in a verse that deals with <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals: “When a bull, or a sheep, or a goat is born, it shall be seven days under its mother” (Leviticus 22:27). This verbal analogy, from which many <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of animal tithe are derived, indicates that diverse kinds are not subject to animal tithe, just as they cannot be used for an offering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If</span> this principle is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to firstborn </span>animals, concerning which it is written: “However, the firstborn among animals, which is born as a firstling to the Lord, no man shall sanctify it; whether it be ox or <span class="it-text">seh</span>, it is the Lord’s” (Leviticus 27:26), it is not necessary in that context either. The reason is that this can be <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>by a verbal analogy between the term <span class="gemarra-regular">passing, </span>in the verse: “And you shall cause to pass to the Lord all that open the womb” (Exodus 13:12), and the same term <span class="gemarra-regular">passing, from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">animal tithe: </span>“And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, any one that passes under the rod, the tenth shall be sacred unto the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This verbal analogy teaches that if the firstborn of a ewe or a she-goat is an animal of diverse kinds it is not considered a firstborn with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of firstborn animals, which means that Rava’s principle is not necessary here.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, you </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that an animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">resembles </span>another is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “But the firstborn of a bull, </span>or the firstborn of a sheep, or the firstborn of a goat, you shall not redeem; they are holy” (Numbers 18:17). This indicates that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the firstborn are not applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the fathering animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is a bull </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">its firstborn is also a bull. </span>This excludes an animal that resembles another species, rather than its father. Once it is established that an animal that resembles another is not subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a firstborn, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the Torah to state the same with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds? </span>Since it is evident that firstborn status does not apply to diverse kinds, Rava’s principle is not required here either.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava’s </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to </span>the redemption of <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn donkey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> concerning which it is written: “And every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a <span class="it-text">seh</span>” (Exodus 13:13), <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 12a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not redeem </span>a firstborn donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">neither with a calf, nor with a non-domesticated animal, nor with a slaughtered </span>animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span> animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with diverse kinds, </span>i.e., a sheep-goat hybrid, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rava’s principle is referring to the source for the prohibition against using an animal of diverse kinds for the redemption of a firstborn donkey.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what about <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, who</span> disagrees with this ruling and <span class="gemarra-regular">permits </span>the use <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>an animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds </span>for the redemption of a firstborn donkey? <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in the same mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar permits diverse kinds </span>for use in the redemption of a firstborn donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is Rava’s principle relevant?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Rava’s </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to a non-kosher </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that was born from a kosher </span>mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose impregnation was from a non-kosher </span>animal. Rava is saying that this animal is not kosher. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua, as, if </span>it were in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua,</span> although he would agree with this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he derives </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> (see <span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 7a) <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of sheep [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kevasim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">seh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of goats [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">izzim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”</span> (Deuteronomy 14:4). The plural forms “<span class="it-text">kevasim</span>” and “<span class="it-text">izzim</span>” indicate that a lamb is not kosher <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">its father is a sheep and its mother is a ewe, </span>and the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies to a kid.
The Gemara asks with regard to the case under discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But can a kosher</span> animal <span class="gemarra-regular">become impregnated by a non-kosher </span>animal in the first place? Is it even possible for this to occur? Why did Rabbi Yehoshua and Rava have to find a biblical source to deem this offspring as non-kosher? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>it is possible. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we maintain </span>elsewhere (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 7a) 

Daf 78b

<span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mother animal <span class="gemarra-regular">became impregnated from </span>an animal with <span class="gemarra-regular">non-cloven </span>hooves that was born from a kosher mother and father. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who maintains that the offspring resulting from this, which does not have cloven hooves, is not kosher. Since the animal’s father is not kosher according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, the offspring is also not kosher, in accordance with Rava’s principle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a burnt</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside a bull </span>for this purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole </span>the bull, <span class="gemarra-regular">can the thief exempt himself </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>repaying the owner with <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, or by </span>repaying him with a bird to be used as <span class="gemarra-regular">a bird burnt-offering, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Menaḥot</span> 107a): If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a burnt</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering, he must bring </span>a bull or <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep </span>as a burnt-offering to fulfill his vow. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: He may </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">bring a turtledove or a young pigeon </span>as a burnt-offering.
Rava elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted upon himself </span>to sacrifice an animal with the <span class="gemarra-regular">status of a burnt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case any animal that fulfills this requirement will suffice? If so, the thief may compensate the owner with a sheep or bird, as the owner can sacrifice that animal as a burnt-offering. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">I want to perform </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the optimal manner, </span>which is by sacrificing a bull. Therefore, you must pay me back with a bull.
<span class="gemarra-regular">After he raised the dilemma, </span>Rava himself <span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently resolved it: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">thief can exempt himself </span>from liability by repaying the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>repaying him with a bird to be used as <span class="gemarra-regular">a bird burnt-offering, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, teaches </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">explicitly, </span>i.e., without the question-and-answer format: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a burnt</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering, and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a bull </span>for this purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came and stole </span>the bull, the thief can <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt himself </span>from liability <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>repaying the owner with <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, or by </span>repaying him with a bird to be used as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bird burnt-offering, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>a stolen animal in a partial fashion, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">one-hundredth of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which he kept for himself; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he had a partnership in </span>owning the animal before stealing it; or in the case of a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who slaughtered </span>the stolen animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and it became</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> non-kosher </span>meat <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">han</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> because he slaughtered it improperly; or in the case of a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who ripped open </span>the animal rather than slaughtering it halakhically; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>in the case of a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who tore loose </span>the gullet or windpipe of the animal as he slaughtered it, rendering the slaughter invalid, in all these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment but does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>The fourfold or five-fold payment applies only if the animal is entirely sold or if it is slaughtered in accordance with the halakhic definition of animal slaughter.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the mishna mean when it states that the thief sold the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">one-hundredt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of it? </span>Which part of the animal must the thief keep for himself for him to be exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The mishna means that he sold it <span class="gemarra-regular">except for some </span>part of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that becomes permitted through </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. </span>This does not apply to horns or a sheep’s fleece, which do not require slaughter in order to be used. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Levi says: </span>The mishna’s statement applies even if the thief sold the entire animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fleece. And it is likewise taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The thief is exempt even if he sells the whole animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fleece.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the opinion of Rav from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the whole animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its foreleg, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its hind leg, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its horn, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fleece, he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>If the thief sells the animal except for some <span class="gemarra-regular">part </span>of it whose absence <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidates </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he leaves out from the sale a part of the animal whose absence <span class="gemarra-regular">does not invalidate the slaughter, he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>If an animal is missing one of its vital organs, e.g., its liver, one of its intestines, its gullet, or its windpipe, it is considered already dead and its slaughter at this stage would be invalid. For the thief to be exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment on the grounds of an incomplete sale, he must retain one of these organs for himself.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>If the thief sells the whole animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its horn, he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>If he sells the whole animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fleece, he does pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
The Gemara explains the objection from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not present a difficulty, as his ruling is exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>it does present a difficulty, as in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion does his ruling accord? None of the three opinions expressed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> correlate with that of Rav.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the entire animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its foreleg or except for its hind leg, he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>If he sold the entire animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its horn </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fleece, he does pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the four opinions of the <span class="it-text">tanna</span><span class="it-text">’im</span> presented in these <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that when the Torah states: “If a man steals an ox or a sheep, and slaughters it or sells it, he shall pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep” (Exodus 21:37), the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“and slaughters it” </span>indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>him to slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">all of it</span> for him to incur liability to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. Likewise, the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“or sells it” </span>teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require</span> him to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">all of it, </span>not leaving any portion at all for himself, even the fleece.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“and slaughters it” </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">parts </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>affected <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, </span>which serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude parts </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not </span>affected <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter. </span>When the Torah immediately adds the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“or sells it,” </span>this indicates that selling is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to slaughter. </span>Consequently, if the sale excludes the animal’s fleece or horns, i.e., those parts that are not affected by slaughter, there is no fourfold or fivefold payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds, </span>according to the first version of his opinion, that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">horn, which is not meant to be cut off </span>in the animal’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding </span>if the thief keeps that part for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">fleece, which is meant to be cut off </span>in the animal’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding </span>if the thief keeps it for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he must pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the other </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the school of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds </span>that the animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">forelegs and hind legs, which require slaughter </span>for them to be put to their usual use, i.e., for eating, <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span> considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding </span>if the thief keeps one of them for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">its horns and its fleece, which do not require slaughter</span> in order to be used, <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding </span>if the thief keeps them for himself.
The Gemara asks: This presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty, </span>as there is a contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar and </span>another opinion presented in the name <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. </span>The Gemara answers: The two rulings represent the reports of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>they disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">missing a limb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">lame, or </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">blind, </span>and he subsequently sold it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and similarly, one who steals an animal </span>belonging to several <span class="gemarra-regular">partner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and he subsequently sold it, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">partners </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who stole </span>an animal together and sell it are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the fourfold or fivefold payment. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to the contrary, that several <span class="gemarra-regular">partners who stole </span>an animal together and sell it are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment?
The Gemara resolves the contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that he is exempt, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">partner who stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from another </span>partner. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that he is liable, it is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a partner, who, </span>together with other thieves, <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>someone else <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>their group.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman </span>from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">a partner who stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from another </span>partner and slaughtered it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">partners who </span>jointly <span class="gemarra-regular">stol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> an animal and one of them slaughtered it, <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. To counter this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And slaughters it,” </span>which indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>liability for slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">all of it, and </span>in these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>so. One who steals an animal that he partly owns is not liable for slaughtering his own portion. Likewise, when several partners steal an animal, the one who slaughters it is not liable for slaughtering the portions of his fellow thieves.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman said </span>a different resolution of the contradiction: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>Both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> are speaking of partners who together stole an animal from someone else. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the thief is liable, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a partner who slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">with the knowledge </span>and consent <span class="gemarra-regular">of another </span>partner. In such a case the one slaughtering is acting as the agent of the partner as well and is fully liable for the slaughter. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the thief is exempt, it is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of a partner who slaughtered </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">without the knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another </span>partner in the theft. Consequently, the one slaughtering is acting solely on his own and is not liable for the slaughter of his partner’s share, which is why he is exempt from any payment.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raises </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemmas: </span>If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">except for thirty days, </span>i.e., the thief reserved the right to use the animal himself for thirty days before the sale takes effect, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he sold it <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its work</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he stipulated with the buyer that any work the animal performs would be for the thief’s own benefit and profit, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he stole a pregnant animal and sold it <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fetus, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
The Gemara elaborates on the last dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the one who says that a fetus is </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">its mother’s thigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a part of its mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">you should not raise the dilemma, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is clear that the thief, by retaining the fetus, <span class="gemarra-regular">has withheld </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">When you should raise the dilemma, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says that a fetus is not </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">its mother’s thigh, </span>i.e., it has the status of an independent being. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say that since it is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to the mother, if the thief keeps the fetus for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding? Or perhaps, since it stands to become detached from </span>the mother <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who state </span>a different analysis of this dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>a fetus is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">its mother’s thigh, it is not </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">withholding, or perhaps, since </span>it needs its mother <span class="gemarra-regular">to be rendered permitted </span>for consumption <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the mother’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, it is considered as though </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">has withheld a part of the </span>mother’s <span class="gemarra-regular">body. </span>The Gemara concludes: All these dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
