<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">severed </span>one of its limbs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that the essential factor is that part of <span class="gemarra-regular">what he stole he has not sold, </span>as the missing limb was not sold, and therefore he is exempt from the fourfold or fivefold payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the essential factor is that with regard to that <span class="gemarra-regular">which he sold he has not withheld </span>any part for himself. Once again, the Gemara states that this dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave it to another and </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it </span>for him, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave it to another and </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it </span>for him, the thief is liable to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, as performing these actions through an agent is equivalent to performing them by oneself. 

Daf 79a

The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and consecrated </span>it, or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on credit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., without receiving any money for it at the time, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and exchanged </span>it for another item, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave it </span>to another <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>used it to <span class="gemarra-regular">repay his debt, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal and used it to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>for an item <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>purchased on <span class="gemarra-regular">credit, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and sent it in </span>the form of <span class="gemarra-regular">presents </span>to his betrothed <span class="gemarra-regular">in his father-in-law’s house,</span> in all of these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment, </span>as these acts are all considered forms of selling. This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>All of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> it states are obvious. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first clause teaches us, </span>through the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave it to another and </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>or sold it on his behalf, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">there is agency for transgression. Even though in the entire Torah </span>there is a principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no agency for transgression</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here there is agency for transgression</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Torah’s principle is that a transgression committed by an agent who was appointed by another person is not considered the act of the one who appointed the agent, but the independent act of the agent himself. The case discussed by this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is an exception to the rule, as here, the agent’s slaughter or sale of the animal is legally considered the action of the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that this case is an exception to the principle? It is because the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And slaughters it or sells it” </span>(Exodus 21:37), which juxtaposes the two acts of slaughtering and selling. This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>one becomes liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">selling, which</span> by definition <span class="gemarra-regular">is impossible without another </span>party, i.e., the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too one becomes liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering </span>even when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of another </span>party, i.e., when the thief instructs another person to slaughter the animal on his behalf.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>a novelty in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>it. The novelty is that this is considered a sale despite the fact that there is no purchaser. This is due to the following argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary </span>person, and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is it to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold it to Heaven </span>by consecrating it? If the animal changes ownership, it is considered a sale, and it does not matter if the new owner is an ordinary person or the Temple treasury.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owner’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he took hold of it or established control over it but had not yet removed it from the owner’s premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain; or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain; or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or sold </span>it, and all of this occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain, </span>in all of these cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughtered or sold </span>it, and all of this occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from any of the fines for theft, as it is not considered theft until the stolen object is actually removed from the owner’s premises.
If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>in the process of <span class="gemarra-regular">leading </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and leavin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the owner’s premises, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it died </span>while it was still <span class="gemarra-regular">in the owner’s domain, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he lifted it up or led it out of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain and </span>then the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for his theft. For an act to be considered theft, the thief must acquire the item by pulling it or moving it, which are ineffective forms of acquisition on the owner’s premises; or by lifting it up, which is effective even when performed in the owner’s domain.
If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the animal as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for the redemption of his firstborn son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to a creditor, </span>or conveyed it for safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee, </span>or lent it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a borrower,</span> or conveyed it for safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">to a paid bailee, or </span>leased it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a renter, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and he was leading out </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and it died in the owner’s domain, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment. If that individual, following the thief’s instructions, <span class="gemarra-regular">lifted up </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or led it out of the owner’s domain, and it </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for the theft. The thief is liable for instructing another to remove the animal for the purposes of payment of a debt, safekeeping, borrowing, or rental, as this is tantamount to the thief taking it with his own hands.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar raises a dilemma: </span>Did the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">institute </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pullin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> or leading an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to bailees, or not? </span>When an animal or other item is purchased, the parties to the sale are not bound by the deal until the purchaser performs an act of acquisition, one of which is pulling the animal or leads it along. Did the Sages institute an ordinance that the same applies to bailees? In other words, does the bailee’s obligation to safeguard the animal or item begin as soon as he consents to watch it, or only after he has taken the animal and moved it even minimally?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the animal as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for the redemption of his firstborn son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to a creditor,</span> or conveyed it for safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">to an unpaid bailee, </span>or lent it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a borrower, </span>or conveyed it for safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">to a paid bailee, or </span>rented it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a renter, and he was leading out </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and it died in the owner’s domain, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>talking about the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee </span>leading out the animal, when it states that the thief is exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>this mishna that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling with regard to bailees. </span>If the bailee’s obligation begins immediately upon his consent to watch over the item, it would be considered stolen by the thief at that stage, even before the bailee moves it.
Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yeimar: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is not necessarily the correct interpretation of the mishna. The mishna may mean that the owner gave the animal to his creditor or to a bailee, and subsequently a thief came to steal it from the house of the creditor or the bailee, and it was the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief </span>who was leading the animal out of those premises when it died.
Rav Yeimar asked: How can that clause of the mishna refer to an animal that died as the thief was leading it out? The mishna already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause. </span>Ameimar answered: Nevertheless, it is possible that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from its owner’s house, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>it again with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief who stole </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">from a bailee’s house.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to </span>Ameimar: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not reject</span> Rav Yeimar’s argument by means of this alternative interpretation of the mishna. It is not reasonable to assert that the mishna taught this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> twice, as <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief stole </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the bailee’s house </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief stole </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the owner’s house? </span>There is no halakhic distinction between these two cases. Therefore, the mishna would not have discussed both of them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>more reasonable to say that the mishna should be interpreted as meaning that the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee</span> was leading the animal out of the owner’s house at the behest of the thief, as Rav Yeimar claimed? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, one should <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to bailees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that they did. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was also stated </span>explicitly that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Just as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling with regard to purchasers, so too </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling with regard to bailees.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling with regard to purchasers, so too </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling with regard to bailees. And just as land is acquired by </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>the writing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed </span>of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">or by </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of the land through working it, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too a rental</span> deal is finalized <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>the writing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed </span>of rent, <span class="gemarra-regular">or by </span>the renter <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of the land. This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara asks: When the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> speaks of rental, it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">rental of what </span>kind of property? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say</span>

Daf 79b

it is speaking of <span class="gemarra-regular">the rental of movable property, is movable property </span>subject to the writing of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the rental of land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>If people <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">who was hiding in the wood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> near a herd of grazing animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that individual emerged and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>one of the animals from the herd, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is the thief liable to the fourfold or fivefold payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">But he did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pull </span>the animal. Rabbi Elazar is apparently describing a case where the thief emerged from the forest and slaughtered one of the animals without first moving it, and there is no fourfold or fivefold payment unless the thief first steals the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he hit </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">with a stick, </span>causing it to move.
With regard to Rabbi Elazar’s statement, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: But since </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">saw him </span>doing all this, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is a robber, </span>not a thief, and the fourfold or fivefold payment applies only to thieves. A thief is one who sneaks into a house or other private property; one who commits his act brazenly, in public, is classified as a robber. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he was hiding from them, he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, </span>despite the fact that they saw him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if so, what are the circumstances </span>of a <span class="gemarra-regular">robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Abbahu said: </span>Robbers are <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Benaiah ben Jehoiada, as it is stated </span>concerning him: “He slew an Egyptian, a goodly man; and the Egyptian had a spear in his hand; but he went down to him with a staff, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he robbed the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand, and slew him with his own spear” </span>(II Samuel 23:21).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>A different example of a robber is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the men of Shechem, as it is stated: “And the men of Shechem set ambushers for him on the tops of the mountains, and they robbed all that came along that way by them” </span>(Judges 9:25).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu did not say </span>the example <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>verse, which discusses the men of Shechem? He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Since </span>the men of Shechem <span class="gemarra-regular">were hiding </span>in ambush, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> but thieves. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>respond to this claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they were hiding </span>was not because they were hesitant to steal in view of the public. Rather, they acted in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>the travelers <span class="gemarra-regular">should not see them </span>in advance <span class="gemarra-regular">and flee from them.</span>
§ The Gemara concludes its discussion of theft with several aggadic statements. <span class="gemarra-regular">His students asked Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai: For what reason was the Torah stricter with a thief than with a robber? </span>Only a thief is required to pay the double, fourfold, or fivefold payment, not a robber. Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">This one, </span>the robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">equated the honor of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">servant to the honor of his Master, and that one, </span>the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not equate the honor of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">servant to the honor of his Master. </span>The robber fears neither God nor people, as he is not afraid to rob in public. The thief does not fear God but he does fear other people, which demonstrates that he is more concerned about humans than God.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it were, </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes the eye below, </span>i.e., God’s eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">as though it does not see, and the ear below, </span>i.e., God’s ear, <span class="gemarra-regular">as though it does not hear. </span>The Gemara cites verses that describe people who imagine that God does not see their actions, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Woe to them who seek deeply to hide their counsel from the Lord, and their works are in the dark, </span>and they say: Who sees us, and who knows us?” (Isaiah 29:15). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “And they say: The Lord will not see, neither will the God of Jacob give heed” </span>(Psalms 94:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “For they say: The Lord has forsaken the land, and the Lord does not see” </span>(Ezekiel 9:9).
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir said: </span>To illustrate the severity of a thief over a robber, as per Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai’s explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">they stated a parable in the name of Rabban Gamliel. To what is this matter comparable? To two people who were </span>living <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">city, and </span>both of them <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared a feast. One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">invited the people of the city </span>to his feast <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not invite the king’s sons. And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">did not invite the people of the city and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">did not invite the king’s sons. Which of them </span>deserves <span class="gemarra-regular">a greater punishment? You must say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who invited the people of the city but did not invite the king’s sons. </span>Likewise, both the thief and the robber show disdain for God, but the robber does not display more respect for people.
The Gemara discusses why there is a fourfold payment for a sheep but a fivefold payment for an ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir said: Come and see how great the power of labor is. </span>The theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, which </span>was forced <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">to cease its labor, </span>leads to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fivefold </span>payment; whereas the theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sheep, which </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>forced <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">to cease its labor, </span>as a sheep performs no labor, leads to only <span class="gemarra-regular">a fourfold</span> payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said: Come and see how great human dignity is. </span>The theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox, which walked on its own legs </span>as the thief stole it, leads to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fivefold </span>payment, whereas the theft of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheep, which </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">carried on his shoulder </span>as he walked, thereby causing himself embarrassment, leads to only <span class="gemarra-regular">a fourfold </span>payment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not raise small domesticated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animals</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., sheep and goats, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>settled areas of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yisrael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they graze on people’s crops. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may raise </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in Syria, </span>despite the fact that with regard to many other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> Syria is treated like Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wildernes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Eretz Yisrael.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">One may not raise chickens in Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to the sacrificial meat </span>that is common there. There is a concern that chickens will pick up garbage that imparts ritual impurity and bring it into contact with sacrificial meat, thereby rendering it ritually impure. <span class="gemarra-regular">And priests may not </span>raise chickens anywhere <span class="gemarra-regular">in Eretz Yisrael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because of the </span>many foods in a priest’s possession that must be kept <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure, </span>e.g., <span class="it-text">teruma</span>.
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not raise pig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anywhere, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not raise a do</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unless it is tied with chains. One may spread out traps [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nishovim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for pigeons only if </span>this was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">at a distance of</span> at least <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ris</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is 8,000 cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">settled area, </span>to ensure that privately owned pigeons are not caught in the traps.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not raise small domesticated animals, </span>i.e., sheep and goats, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>settled areas of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael. But one may raise </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the forests of Eretz Yisrael. In Syria, </span>it is permitted to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">even in a settled area. And, needless to say, </span>it is permitted to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not raise small domesticated animals in </span>settled areas of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael. But one may raise </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the wilderness that is in Jude</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in the wilderness that is on the border near Akko</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And even though </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said that one may not raise small domesticated animals, nevertheless, one may raise large, domesticated animals, </span>i.e., cattle, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">issue a decree upon the public onl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if a majority of the public is able to abide by it.</span>
This difference is that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>for someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring small domesticated animals from outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael in the event that they are needed. But it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not possible </span>for someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring large, domesticated animals from outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael whenever he needs one, since there is a constant need for them as beasts of burden. Therefore, the Sages did not issue a decree with regard to these types of animals.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though they said that one may not raise small domesticated animals, however, one may keep </span>these animals on his premises for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days before a pilgrimage Festival, and thirty days before the </span>wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">feast of one’s son, </span>when many animals are needed for food, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he does not leave the last </span>one, i.e., the animal which he purchased immediately before the Festival, for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the final line of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> needs to state this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say that if the pilgrimage Festival has passed and thirty days have not yet elapsed from </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he bought </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">until now, </span>he may keep the animal until thirty days have elapsed. To counter this, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say: It is permitted to keep it for </span>a total of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days. Rather, once the pilgrimage Festival has passed, he should not keep it </span>any longer. 

Daf 80a

The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a butcher may bu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> small domesticated animals <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter </span>them, and again <span class="gemarra-regular">buy </span>small domesticated animals <span class="gemarra-regular">and keep </span>them for a while, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he does not keep the last one of them </span>that he bought beyond <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">His students asked Rabban Gamliel: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to raising </span>small domesticated animals in Eretz Yisrael? Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: It is permitted. </span>The Gemara interrupts its citation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to pose a question: How could Rabban Gamliel say this? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not raise </span>small domesticated animals in Eretz Yisrael?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the text of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be emended, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">raised this dilemma before him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> keeping </span>them for a while? The Gemara resumes the quotation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, provided that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">does not go out and graze among the flock. Rather, </span>one should <span class="gemarra-regular">tie it to the legs of the bed </span>in his house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain pious man who was groaning, </span>i.e., suffering, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>a pain in <span class="gemarra-regular">his heart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Those caring for the man <span class="gemarra-regular">asked the physicians </span>what to do for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they said: There is no other remedy for him but that he should suckle warm milk every morning. And they brought him a she-goat and tied it to the leg of the bed for him, and he would suckle </span>milk <span class="gemarra-regular">from it every morning.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Days later, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his friends came in to visit him. When they saw that she-goat tied to the legs of the bed, they turned back, saying: </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit in this </span>man’s <span class="gemarra-regular">house, and we are going in to </span>visit <span class="gemarra-regular">him? </span>They referred to the goat in this manner because small animals habitually graze on the vegetation of others, thereby stealing their crops.
His friends <span class="gemarra-regular">sat down and investigated </span>this pious man’s behavior, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they could not find </span>any sin attributable <span class="gemarra-regular">to him except that si</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span> keeping <span class="gemarra-regular">that she-goat </span>in his house. That man <span class="gemarra-regular">himself also said at the time of his death: I know </span>for a fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that I have no sin </span>attributable <span class="gemarra-regular">to me except </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sin of </span>keeping <span class="gemarra-regular">that she-goat </span>in my house, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I transgressed the statement of my colleagues, </span>the Sages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael said: </span>The members of my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s family were among the wealthy property holders in the upper Galilee. And for what reason were they destroyed? </span>It was due to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they would graze </span>flocks <span class="gemarra-regular">in the forests, and </span>also because they would <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a single </span>judge. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though there were forests close to their houses, </span>and therefore there should have been no problem for them to take their animals to graze in these forests, <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a small, </span>private <span class="gemarra-regular">field and they would convey </span>the animals on <span class="gemarra-regular">a path through it.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a shepherd </span>of small domesticated animals <span class="gemarra-regular">who repented</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him to sell </span>all his animals <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, he may sell </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">gradually. And likewise, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert who came into </span>possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs and pigs </span>(see 83a) <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>part of <span class="gemarra-regular">his inheritance, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him to sell </span>all of them <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately. Rather, he may sell </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">gradually.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who vowed to purchase a hous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to marry a woman in Eretz Yisrael, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him to acquire </span>the first house or marry the first woman he sees <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately </span>upon his arrival in Eretz Yisrael. Instead, he may wait <span class="gemarra-regular">until he finds </span>the house or wife <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriate for him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain </span>unmarried <span class="gemarra-regular">woman who had a son who was distressing her, and she jumped up and took an oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> impulsively: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who comes </span>to marry me and will discipline my son, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will not turn him away. And unworthy men jumped at </span>the opportunity to marry <span class="gemarra-regular">her. And when the matter came before the Sages, they said: </span>She need not marry one of these men, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intention </span>in her oath was certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>marry <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">who is appropriate for her.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as</span> the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not raise small domesticated animals, </span>i.e., sheep and goats, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not raise small undomesticated animals</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yishmael says: One may raise village dogs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cats, monkeys, and genets</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because they serve to clean the house </span>of mice and other vermin.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are</span> these <span class="gemarra-regular">genets? Rav Yehuda said: </span>These are known in Aramaic as <span class="gemarra-italic">shartza</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥartza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that in Aramaic this animal is called <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥarza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This creature <span class="gemarra-regular">has short thighs and it grazes among the thorn bushes. And what </span>is the reason that they are called <span class="gemarra-italic">shartza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a term that generally refers to creeping creatures that slither [<span class="it-text">shoretz</span>] rather than walk? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because its thighs are </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">short </span>that it appears to slither instead of walking on legs.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: We in Babylonia have rendered ourselve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like </span>the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrae</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the prohibition of the Sages against raising <span class="gemarra-regular">small domesticated animals. Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rav Huna: What of your </span>sheep and goats? How can you raise these animals in Babylonia?
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Ḥova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> my wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">watches </span>the animals to ensure that they do not graze on land belonging to others. Rav Adda bar Ahava cursed Rav Huna and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: May Ḥova bury her son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">!</span> In <span class="gemarra-regular">all the years of Rav Adda bar Ahava, no children of Rav Huna from Ḥova survived, </span>due to this curse. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of the above statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: We in Babylonia rendered ourselves like </span>those of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>raising <span class="gemarra-regular">small domesticated animals, from </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav came to Babylonia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel and Rav Asi </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">happened to be </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">at a house </span>where a celebration was being held marking the passage <span class="gemarra-regular">of a week of </span>a newborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son, </span>i.e., a circumcision. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say it was a house </span>where a celebration was being held marking the <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption of </span>a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son. Rav </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter before Shmuel, </span>for reasons the Gemara will explain; 

Daf 80b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel would not enter before Rav Asi, </span>as he considered Rav Asi to be greater than he; and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi would not enter before Rav, </span>as Rav was his teacher. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said: Which </span>of us <span class="gemarra-regular">should stay behind </span>and let the other two come in before him? They decided: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let Shmuel stay behind, and let Rav and Rav Asi come </span>inside in that order. Afterward, Shmuel himself would enter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why didn’t they decide to <span class="gemarra-regular">let Rav or Rav Asi stay behind? </span>The Gemara explains: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">a mere gesture that Rav performed for Shmuel </span>in initially stating that Shmuel should precede him, as Rav did not really feel that Shmuel was superior to him. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of that incident </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>he inadvertently <span class="gemarra-regular">cursed </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav took upon himself </span>to treat Shmuel with deference.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In the meantime, </span>while all this was going on, <span class="gemarra-regular">a cat [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shunara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came and severed the hand of the baby. Rav emerged </span>from the house <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cat, it is permitted to kill i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> even if it is privately owned; <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is prohibited to maintain it </span>in one’s possession; <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is not subject to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>if one takes it from its owner; <span class="gemarra-regular">and, </span>in the case of a lost cat, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not subject to </span>the obligation of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning a lost item to its owner. </span>
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Rav’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And since you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to kill it, what is </span>the need to state <span class="gemarra-regular">further </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to maintain it </span>in one’s possession? If a cat is considered such a dangerous animal that it is permitted to kill it, of course one cannot keep it in his possession. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that although Rav ruled that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to kill it, </span>he concedes that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no prohibition </span>in keeping it, Rav therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that it is also prohibited to keep it in one’s possession.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>further questioning Rav’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And since you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not subject to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>if one takes it from its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the need to state <span class="gemarra-regular">further </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not subject to </span>the obligation of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning a lost item to its owner </span>in the case of a lost cat? If one may actively steal a cat, certainly there is no obligation to return it when found. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said </span>in response: Rav was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hide</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> against Rav’s ruling that it is prohibited to keep a cat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One may raise village dogs, cats, monkeys, and genets, because they serve to clean the house </span>of mice and other vermin. The Gemara resolves the apparent contradiction: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a black </span>cat, which is harmless, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> ruling of Rav is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a white </span>cat, which is dangerous.
The Gemara raises a difficulty against this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the incident of Rav </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was a black </span>cat. Since this cat severed the baby’s hand, it was obviously a vicious, dangerous animal. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There it was a black </span>cat, but it was <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">white </span>one. The offspring of a white cat is dangerous, even if it itself is black. The Gemara further objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Ravina raise this </span>very issue <span class="gemarra-regular">as a dilemma?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Ravina raised a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a black </span>cat that is <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a white </span>one? Is it also dangerous like its parent? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravina raised the dilemma, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a black </span>cat that is <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a white </span>cat that itself is <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a black </span>cat. By contrast, in <span class="gemarra-regular">the incident with Rav </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was a black</span> cat that was <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a white </span>one, which was itself <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring of a white </span>cat. That animal is definitely dangerous.
§ The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the distinguishing letters in the various names of the sons of Rav Pappa in the ensuing list: <span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥet</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">dalet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yod</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥet</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Aḥa bar Pappa says </span>the following three statements <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Abba bar Pappa, </span>who said them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Adda bar Pappa. And some say Rabbi Abba bar Pappa says </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Pappa, </span>who said them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Aḥa bar Pappa. And some say Rabbi Abba bar Pappa says </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Aḥa bar Pappa, </span>who said them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The three statements are as follows: The court <span class="gemarra-regular">sounds the alar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat over </span>a breakout of <span class="gemarra-regular">sores</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a door that is locked will not be opened quickly; and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a house in Eretz Yisrael, one writes a bill of sale for </span>this transaction <span class="gemarra-regular">even on Shabbat.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: After explaining how the public engages in prayer when there is a drought, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all other types of calamities that break out upon the community, </span>other than drought, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sores, </span>a plague of <span class="gemarra-regular">locusts, flies, hornets</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or mosquitoes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or infestations of snakes or scorpions</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">would not sound the alarm </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the people would <span class="gemarra-regular">cry out. </span>This indicates that it is not proper to sound the alarm on Shabbat for an epidemic of sores.
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to moist </span>sores; whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to dry </span>sores, which are more dangerous than moist ones. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">boils that the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought upon the Egyptians </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">moist on the outside and dry on the inside, as it is stated: “And it became a boil breaking out with oozing upon man and upon beast” </span>(Exodus 9:10). The phrase “breaking out” is referring to the exterior of the wound. Since the verse specifies that the outside was oozing with secretions, it can be inferred that the inside was dry. This indicates that the sores can be of either type.
The Gemara analyzes the second of the three statements: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a door that is locked will not be opened quickly. </span>This is clearly a metaphor, but to <span class="gemarra-regular">what is it </span>referring? <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>It is a metaphor for rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">ordination</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If one meets with resistance in his quest to receive ordination, he should take it as a sign that this opportunity will not soon open up for him again. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who is treated poorly will not soon be treated well. Rav Aḥa of Difti said: He will never be treated well. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so; Rav Aḥa of Difti was saying </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter </span>that reflected what had occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara turns its attention to the third statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a house in Eretz Yisrael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one writes a bill of sale for </span>this transaction <span class="gemarra-regular">even on Shabbat. </span>The Gemara asks: Can it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>that one may write this bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat? </span>Writing on Shabbat is a prohibited labor for which one is liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava said there, </span>with regard to a similar issue, that one <span class="gemarra-regular">tells a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to do it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does </span>so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too, </span>it is referring to a situation where he <span class="gemarra-regular">tells a gentile </span>to write a bill of sale for the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though telling a gentile </span>to perform an action that is prohibited for a Jew on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>generally a violation of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rabbinic decree, </span>as the Sages prohibited telling a gentile to perform prohibited labor on behalf of a Jew on Shabbat, here <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not </span>impose this <span class="gemarra-regular">decree, due to </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">settling Eretz Yisrael. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a city in Eretz Yisrael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">forces him to purchase a path to </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">its sides, due to </span>the importance of <span class="gemarra-regular">settling Eretz Yisrael.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua stipulated ten conditions </span>when he apportioned Eretz Yisrael among the tribes: 

Daf 81a

The conditions are <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall </span>have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">graze </span>their animals <span class="gemarra-regular">in forests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even on private property; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">gather wood from </span>each other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, </span>to be used as animal fodder; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">gather </span>wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetation </span>for animal fodder in any place <span class="gemarra-regular">except for</span> a field of <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek; and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">pluck off a shoot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere </span>for propagation and planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for olive shoots; and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">take supplies </span>of water from a spring on private property, even <span class="gemarra-regular">from a spring that emerges for the first time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">fish in the Sea of Tiberias, </span>i.e., the Sea of Galilee, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that </span>the fisherman <span class="gemarra-regular">does not build an </span>underwater <span class="gemarra-regular">fenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to catch fish, thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">causing an impediment to boats</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues the list of Joshua’s ten conditions: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>people shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">relieve themselves </span>outdoors <span class="gemarra-regular">behind a fence, even in a field </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">full of saffron [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karkom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">walk in permitted paths, </span>i.e., those paths that cut through a private field, throughout the summer <span class="gemarra-regular">until the second rainfall,</span> when crops begin to sprout; <span class="gemarra-regular">and they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">veer off to the sides of the roads </span>onto private property <span class="gemarra-regular">because of hard protrusions </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yeteidot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the road; and one who becomes lost among the vineyards</span> shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down branches and enter </span>an area of the vineyard, or <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down branches and exit </span>an area of the vineyard, until he finds his way back to the road; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse with no one to bury it [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">met</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] acquires its place </span>and is buried where it was found.
The first condition mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">graze </span>their animals <span class="gemarra-regular">in forests. Rav Pappa said: We said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>domesticated animals, i.e., sheep or goats, that graze <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a forest of <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>trees. Small animals grazing in a forest of this kind would not destroy it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>animals grazing <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a forest with <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>growth, or <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>animals, e.g., oxen, grazing <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a forest of <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>trees, these practices are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted, as in either of these scenarios the practice would destroy the forest. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, all the more so, </span>it is understood <span class="gemarra-regular">that large </span>animals grazing <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a forest with <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>growth is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted.
The Gemara discusses the next condition mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">gather wood from </span>each other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fields</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to be used as animal fodder. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">We said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to </span>twigs of <span class="gemarra-regular">thorns and shrubs, </span>as the field’s owner does not care about these. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even with regard to </span>twigs of <span class="gemarra-regular">thorn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and shrubs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when </span>they have been <span class="gemarra-regular">detached </span>by the owner it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted, as he has already claimed them for himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And even when</span> they are <span class="gemarra-regular">attached we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the twigs are still <span class="gemarra-regular">moist, but when </span>they are completely <span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted, as the owner requires these for firewood. Moreover, it is permitted only <span class="gemarra-regular">provided</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one does not uproot </span>the thorn bush or shrub from the ground, but it is prohibited to pull them out with their roots.
The Gemara further discusses Joshua’s conditions: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">gather </span>wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for animal fodder in any place <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>a field of <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: Is this <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetation is good for fenugreek, </span>and therefore the owner wants it to be left in his field? The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a mishna that deals with diverse kinds (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 2:5): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek that sproute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> alongside </span>various <span class="gemarra-regular">types of </span>wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetation,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one is not required to uproot </span>the vegetation. Although it is generally prohibited to grow different species of vegetables together in one patch, if the species have a negative impact on each other’s growth, it is not prohibited. In this case the wild vegetation may be left alongside the fenugreek because it is harmful to it, and the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of diverse kinds do not apply in a case of this kind.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>the mishna is referring to a case where the fenugreek was planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds; there, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that lists Joshua’s conditions is referring to fenugreek planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks. </span>When it is planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, </span>wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetation is bad for it, as it weakens </span>the fenugreek and lowers its yield. But when it is planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks, </span>wild vegetation is <span class="gemarra-regular">good for it, as when it is situated among vegetation it climbs on it </span>and thereby grows to a larger size.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead another answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the mishna is referring to a case where the fenugreek was planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for human </span>consumption; and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to fenugreek planted <span class="gemarra-regular">for animal </span>consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sowed </span>the fenugreek <span class="gemarra-regular">for animal</span> consumption, the wild <span class="gemarra-regular">vegetation is also required by him, </span>as this too can be used for animal fodder. <span class="gemarra-regular">And how can we know </span>if a particular fenugreek field was planted for human or animal consumption, and thereby know whether the vegetation may be picked and taken? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>If he planted it <span class="gemarra-regular">in rows [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mesharei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for human </span>consumption; if he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>plant <span class="gemarra-regular">in rows </span>but planted haphazardly, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for animal </span>consumption.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">pluck off a shoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anywhere </span>for propagation and planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for olive shoots, </span>as this would cause damage to the olive tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tanḥum and Rabbi Berayes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> explained </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of a certain elder: With regard to olive </span>trees, one must distance himself by <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of an eg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> from the trunk before detaching a shoot; in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of reeds and grape vines, </span>he may take shoots only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>place of the first <span class="gemarra-regular">knot and above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all other trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> shoots may be taken only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the thick </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where there are many branches growing, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not from the thin </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tree.</span>
Furthermore, one may take <span class="gemarra-regular">from a new </span>branch, <span class="gemarra-regular">which does not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">produce fruit, but not from old </span>branches, <span class="gemarra-regular">which do produce fruit; </span>and one may take <span class="gemarra-regular">from a place that does not face the sun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 81b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but not from a place that faces the sun, </span>where the fruits grow copiously, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And for the precious things of the fruits of the sun” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:14).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the people of the city </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">take supplies </span>of water from a spring on private property, even <span class="gemarra-regular">from a spring that emerges for the first time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba bar Rav Huna says: And </span>although one may draw water from that spring, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give money to </span>reimburse the owner of the property. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with his </span>opinion, as the water may be taken without payment.
The next of Joshua’s conditions is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">fish in the Sea of Tiberias</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> provided that </span>the fisherman <span class="gemarra-regular">does not build an </span>underwater <span class="gemarra-regular">fence </span>to catch fish, thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">causing an impediment to boats. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may fish with nets and with traps. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, the tribes stipulated with each other that one may not build </span>an underwater <span class="gemarra-regular">fence </span>to catch fish, thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">causing an impediment to boats, but one may fish with nets and with traps</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sea of Tiberias was </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">in the portion of </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Naphtali. Moreover, </span>the tribe of Naphtali <span class="gemarra-regular">received </span>in addition a small stretch of land equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>length of the <span class="gemarra-regular">rope of </span>a fish <span class="gemarra-regular">trap. </span>This stretch of land was located <span class="gemarra-regular">to the south </span>of the sea, where the members of this tribe could spread out their fishing nets, <span class="gemarra-regular">to fulfill that which is stated: </span>“And of Naphtali he said: O Naphtali, satisfied with favor, and full with the blessing of the Lord; <span class="gemarra-regular">possess the sea and the south” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:23).
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Detached </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mountains </span>at the time of conquest <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of all the tribes </span>equally, as spoils of war; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">attached, </span>e.g., trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>sole <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of that tribe </span>that would receive the land where the tree was found.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And you do not have a single tribe of Israel that did not have </span>in its portion at least some land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mountains, and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">in the lowland, and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">in the countryside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">in the valley, as it is stated: “Turn and take your journey, and go to the hill-country of the Amorites and to all their neighbors, in the Arabah, in the hill-country, and in the lowland, and in the countryside, and by the seashore” </span>(Deuteronomy 1:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">And you find similarly with regard to the Canaanites and Perizzites and Amorites who </span>inhabited the land <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the Jews, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it stated </span>in the above verse: “The Amorites <span class="gemarra-regular">and to all their neighbors.” Apparently, </span>the Amorites and <span class="gemarra-regular">their neighbors </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">had this </span>variety of types of land in their respective territories.
§ The Gemara discusses the next of Joshua’s conditions: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>people shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">relieve themselves </span>outdoors <span class="gemarra-regular">behind a fence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even in a field </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">full of saffron. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: </span>It goes without saying that one may relieve himself when necessary; this stipulation <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only </span>to permit the one relieving himself <span class="gemarra-regular">to take a stone out of </span>a wall in the field with which to clean himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: And </span>it is permitted to remove a stone from a wall for this purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">even on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Mar Zutra the Pious would take </span>a stone in this manner on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">and replace </span>it in the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to his attendant </span>after Shabbat: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go and plaster it over, </span>so that it would fit securely back in the wall.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they</span> shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">walk in permitted paths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., those paths that cut through a private field, throughout the summer <span class="gemarra-regular">until the second rainfall, </span>when crops begin to sprout. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>fields that we have in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">even dew </span>that settled the previous night <span class="gemarra-regular">is bad for them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Even after a night of dew, the field is sufficiently moistened that trampling on it will cause damage, and therefore this condition does not apply if there was dew the previous night.
