The next item on the list of conditions is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they </span>shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">veer off to the sides of the road</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> onto private property <span class="gemarra-regular">because of hard protrusions of the road. </span>The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel and Rav Yehuda, </span>who lived in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">walking along the road, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel veered off to the sides of the road </span>onto private property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said to him: </span>Do the <span class="gemarra-regular">conditions that Joshua stipulated </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">even in Babylonia? </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Indeed so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I say </span>that they apply <span class="gemarra-regular">even outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Ḥiyya were </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">walking along the road, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">they veered off to the sides of the road. Rabbi Yehuda ben Kanos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was taking broad steps </span>on the road, to avoid the protrusions without going off to the side of the road, <span class="gemarra-regular">while walking in front of them. Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rabbi Ḥiyya: Who is this </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who is showing off </span>his supposed <span class="gemarra-regular">greatness in our presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> By acting more stringently than required by <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, he is displaying insolence.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya said to </span>Rabbi Yehuda: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps it is my student Rabbi Yehuda ben Kanosa. And </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his actions are </span>undertaken <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of Heaven; </span>he is not acting out of haughtiness. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they reached him </span>and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">saw him, he said to him: If you were not Yehuda ben Kanosa I would have cut off your legs with iron shears</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., I would have excommunicated you for your impudence.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who becomes lost among the vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> shall have the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mefaseig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> branches and enter </span>an area of the vineyard, or <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down branches and exit </span>an area of the vineyard, until he finds his way back to the road. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this stipulation extends further: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sees another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">lost among the vineyards, he may cut down branches and enter </span>an area of the vineyard, or <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down branches and exit </span>an area of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">until he </span>reaches him and <span class="gemarra-regular">brings him </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">up to the city or to the road. And similarly, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself is the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who is lost among the vineyards, he may cut down branches and enter </span>an area of the vineyard, or <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down branches and exit</span> an area of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">until he comes </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">up to the city or to the road.</span>
The Gemara asks a question with regard to this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the point of the clause that begins with: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly? </span>It is obvious that a lost individual himself has the same right to cut down branches as one who assists him to find his way out. The Gemara answers: That is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person who is permitted to cut down branches, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, </span>having seen the lost party, <span class="gemarra-regular">he knows </span>exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is going </span>to rescue the other and help him leave the vineyard, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is why <span class="gemarra-regular">he may cut down branches; but </span>with regard to the lost person himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">who does not know where he is going, </span>one might have said that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not cut down branches </span>but must <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>all the way <span class="gemarra-regular">back to the boundary </span>of the vineyard. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that one who is lost may cut down branches in his quest to find his own way to the nearby town or road.
The Gemara asks a further question: Why was it necessary for Joshua to stipulate that one may find his way out in this manner? After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law. </span>When one is lost, whoever can assist in helping him find his way must do so by Torah law, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There is a mitzva to return lost items to their owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived that the requirement applies even to <span class="gemarra-regular">returning his body</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., helping a lost person find his way? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “And you shall restore it </span>to him” (Deuteronomy 22:2), which can also be translated as: And you shall restore himself to him. If this is required by Torah law, why did Joshua stipulate a condition to this effect?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">By Torah law </span>one is required only to walk in a roundabout path <span class="gemarra-regular">along the boundaries, </span>without damaging another’s vines by cutting off branches. Joshua <span class="gemarra-regular">came and instituted </span>the stipulation <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may </span>go even further and <span class="gemarra-regular">cut off branches and ascend </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">cut off branches and descend, </span>thereby leaving through the most direct route.
The Gemara addresses the last stipulation in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse with no one to bury it [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">met</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] acquires its plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and is buried where it was found. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who finds a corpse laid out on a main street [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">isratya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> evacuates it </span>for burial either <span class="gemarra-regular">to the right of the street or to the left of the street, </span>but it may not be buried under the main street itself. If one can move the corpse either to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fallow field or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a plowed field, he evacuates it to the fallow field.</span>
If the choice is between <span class="gemarra-regular">a plowed field and a sown field, he evacuates it to the plowed field. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>fields <span class="gemarra-regular">were fallow, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">sown, he evacuates it to any side where he wishes </span>to move it. According to this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, a <span class="it-text">met</span> <span class="it-text">mitzva</span> is not necessarily buried where it is found. It may be moved elsewhere.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai said: </span>The ruling of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a corpse<span class="gemarra-regular"> laid out on the pathway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Were the corpse buried there, it would prohibit passage by priests. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since permission was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">granted to evacuate it </span>from there, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may evacuate it to any place he wishes. </span>If, however, the corpse was in a field, it would be prohibited to move it.
§ The Gemara returns to the opening statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that Joshua stipulated ten conditions. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Are there really only <span class="gemarra-regular">ten? These </span>conditions enumerated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">eleven. </span>The Gemara answers: The condition that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may walk in permitted paths </span>that cut through a private field in the summer was not instituted by Joshua; rather, King <span class="gemarra-regular">Solomon said it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s produce was completely </span>harvested <span class="gemarra-regular">from the field, but he does not allow people to enter into his field </span>to shorten their route, <span class="gemarra-regular">what do people say about him? </span>They say: <span class="gemarra-regular">What benefit does so-and-so have </span>by denying entry into his field? <span class="gemarra-regular">And what harm are people causing him </span>by traversing his field? <span class="gemarra-regular">Concerning him, the verse says: Do not be called wicked </span>by refraining <span class="gemarra-regular">from being good. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">written: Do not be called wicked </span>by refraining <span class="gemarra-regular">from being good? </span>There is no such verse in the Bible. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>an idea <span class="gemarra-regular">like this </span>is found in the Bible, albeit in a slightly different form, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written like this: “Withhold not good from him to whom it is due, when it is in the power of your hand to do it” </span>(Proverbs 3:27).
The Gemara further questions the statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that Joshua instituted ten stipulations: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is there nothing more </span>that Joshua instituted? <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is </span>also the stipulation mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yehuda. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: During the time of manure removal, a person may remove his manur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from his property <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public thoroughfare and pile it up </span>there for <span class="gemarra-regular">a full thirty </span>days, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that it should be trodden by the feet of people and by the feet of animals, </span>thereby improving its quality, as it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on this condition </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua apportioned </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people.</span>
The Gemara continues this line of questioning: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>the stipulations mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: It is a stipulation of the court, </span>i.e., it is an automatic right even when not explicitly granted, <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>owner of a bee colony <span class="gemarra-regular">may enter the field of another and chop of</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the other’s branch </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to save his </span>bee <span class="gemarra-regular">colony, and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the other’s </span>severed <span class="gemarra-regular">branch. </span>That is, if a beekeeper finds that one of his colonies has relocated to a tree in a neighboring field, he may bring it back to his own property together with the branch, provided that he later reimburses the owner of the tree.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court that this </span>bearer of wine <span class="gemarra-regular">pours out his win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from his barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>uses the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">to save another’s </span>spilling <span class="gemarra-regular">honey, </span>which is more valuable than the wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wine from the </span>saved <span class="gemarra-regular">honey of the other, </span>as reimbursement. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court that this </span>owner of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">unloads his wood </span>from his donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">and loads another’s flax, </span>which is more valuable than wood, if the load of flax is stranded on the road due to a mishap, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wood from the </span>saved <span class="gemarra-regular">flax of that other </span>individual. Once again, the reason is that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on this condition </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua apportioned Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people.</span>
The Gemara explains why the stipulations mentioned by Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yishmael are omitted by the earlier <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are not speaking of individual </span>opinions, but only of those that are accepted by all the Sages. 

Daf 82a

The Gemara further questions the number of Joshua’s stipulations: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when Rabbi Avin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">both a tree that lean</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into the field of anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a tree that is close to a boundary </span>with another field, the owner of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>the first fruits of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites </span>the accompanying declaration, as described in Deuteronomy 26:5–10, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on this condition </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua apportioned Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people. </span>This is an additional stipulation by Joshua, which means that there are more than ten.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, who </span>is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that deals with the <span class="gemarra-regular">ten conditions that Joshua stipulated? It is Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, </span>an <span class="it-text">amora</span>. Therefore, Rabbi Yoḥanan, another <span class="it-text">amora</span>, can disagree with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Geviha from Bei Kati</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">explicitly </span>in his version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tanḥum and Rabbi Beraye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say in the name of a certain elder, and who is that </span>elder? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: Joshua stipulated ten conditions.</span>
§ The Sages taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ezra </span>the Scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted ten ordinances: </span>He instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>communities <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat in the afternoon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday and Thursday; and </span>the courts convene and <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday and Thursday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one does laundry on Thursday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one eats garlic on Shabbat eve. And </span>Ezra further instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">that a woman should rise early and bak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> bread on those days when she wants to bake; <span class="gemarra-regular">and that a woman should don a breechcloth; and that a woman should </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">comb </span>her hair <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only then <span class="gemarra-regular">immerse </span>in a ritual bath after being ritually impure; <span class="gemarra-regular">and that peddlers </span>of cosmetics and perfumes <span class="gemarra-regular">should travel around through </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the towns. And </span>Ezra further <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">immersion for those who experienced a seminal emission.</span>
The Gemara analyzes these ordinances, the first of which is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>communities <span class="gemarra-regular">shall read </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat afternoon. </span>This Gemara explains that this ordinance was instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">due to those who sit </span>idly on street <span class="gemarra-regular">corners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who do not attend the synagogue during the week.
The Gemara discusses the second of Ezra’s ordinances: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that they should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> read </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday and Thursday. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did Ezra institute </span>this practice? <span class="gemarra-regular">But it was instituted from the beginning, </span>i.e., long before his time. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the verse: “And Moses led Israel onward from the Red Sea, and they went out into the wilderness of Shur; <span class="gemarra-regular">and they went three days in the wilderness, and found no water” </span>(Exodus 15:22). <span class="gemarra-regular">Those who interpret verses</span> metaphorically <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>here is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing other than Torah, as it is stated </span>metaphorically, concerning those who desire wisdom: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Ho, everyone who thirsts, come for water” </span>(Isaiah 55:1).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: The verse means that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">traveled for three days without </span>hearing any <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah they became weary, </span>and therefore the <span class="gemarra-regular">prophets among them arose and instituted for them that they should read </span>from the Torah each <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, and pause </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Sunday, and read </span>again on <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday, and pause </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Tuesday and Wednesday, and read </span>again on <span class="gemarra-regular">Thursday, and pause </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat eve, so they would not tarry three days without </span>hearing the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah. </span>Evidently this practice predates Ezra.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially they instituted </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one man </span>read <span class="gemarra-regular">three verses; </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">alternatively, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">three men </span>read <span class="gemarra-regular">three verses. </span>Either way, the number three <span class="gemarra-regular">corresponds to </span>the three types of Jews: <span class="gemarra-regular">Priests, Levites, and Israelites. </span>Ezra later <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">three men </span>always read, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ten verses </span>altogether be read by them, <span class="gemarra-regular">corresponding to the ten idlers </span>in a city, i.e., the ten men who are paid to spend their time dealing with synagogue and communal matters.
The next ordinance of Ezra is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the courts convene and <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday and Thursday. </span>The Gemara explains that the reason for this ordinance is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>many people are <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>in a city on these days, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they come </span>from the countryside <span class="gemarra-regular">for the reading of the </span>holy <span class="gemarra-regular">book, </span>the Torah, which is performed on Mondays and Thursdays, as stated above.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that one should do laundry</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Thursday. </span>This was instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the need to have clean garments in <span class="gemarra-regular">deference to Shabbat.</span>
The Gemara explains the next listed ordinance: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that one should eat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> garli</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat eve. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that garlic enhances sexual potency, and Friday night is an appropriate time for <span class="gemarra-regular">conjugal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">relations. As it is written </span>concerning the righteous: “And he shall be like a tree planted by streams of water, <span class="gemarra-regular">who brings forth his fruit in his season” </span>(Psalms 1:3); <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yehuda says, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who engages in sexual intercours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every Shabbat eve.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">five matters were stated with regard to garlic: It satisfies; it warms </span>the body; <span class="gemarra-regular">it causes </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">countenance to shine; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it increases </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sperm, and it kills lice that are in the intestines. And some say </span>that it also <span class="gemarra-regular">instills love </span>into those who eat it <span class="gemarra-regular">and removes jealousy </span>from them.
The next ordinance is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that a woman should rise earl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and bake </span>bread on those days when she bakes. This Gemara explains that this was instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">so that bread should be available for poor people, </span>who go begging for bread in the mornings.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that a woman should don a breechcloth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This ordinance was instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>reasons of <span class="gemarra-regular">modesty.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that a woman should </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">comb </span>her hair <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only then <span class="gemarra-regular">immerse </span>in a ritual bath. This is to ensure that there is no dirt or other substance in the hair that would invalidate the immersion. The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, </span>Ezra did not institute this.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, concerning a verse that discusses one who must undergo ritual immersion: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall bathe his flesh [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">besaro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in water” </span>(Leviticus 14:9). This verse teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that no substance should interpose between his flesh and the water. </span>When the verse states this in the expanded form of <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his flesh,” </span>using the term “<span class="it-text">et</span>,” this teaches that the water must come into contact even with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is subordinate to his flesh. And what is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that? </span>It is one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hair. </span>Accordingly, the Torah itself states that there may not be any interposing substance in the hair at the time of immersion. What, then, did Ezra add?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">By Torah law </span>one is required <span class="gemarra-regular">to inspec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> his or her hair before immersion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>some hairs are <span class="gemarra-regular">knotted </span>together, preventing contact with water at that spot, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>perhaps there is some <span class="gemarra-regular">repulsive substance </span>in his hair. One must perform this inspection <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>these would constitute <span class="gemarra-regular">an interposition. </span>

Daf 82b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Ezra <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and added to the Torah’s minimal obligation. He <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">combing </span>the hair even when it is known that it is not knotted and contains no repulsive substance.
The Gemara discusses the next of Ezra’s ordinances: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that peddlers shoul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> circulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the towns. </span>This Gemara explains that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>peddlers supply <span class="gemarra-regular">women’s cosmetics</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore Ezra instituted this practice <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>women <span class="gemarra-regular">should not become unattractive to their husbands.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the last of the ten ordinances: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he instituted </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">immersio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for those who experienced a seminal emission. </span>The Gemara asks: But this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is written: “And if the flow of seed go out from a man, then he shall bathe </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">his flesh in water”</span> (Leviticus 15:16). The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">By Torah law </span>immersion <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>required only if one wishes to partake <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or sacrificial </span>meat. Ezra <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and further <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>that immersion is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">even for </span>reciting or studying <span class="gemarra-regular">matters of Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that one may not raise chickens in Jerusalem. The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that contains a list of other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> that are unique to Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ten matters were state</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A house </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>Jerusalem does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>become <span class="gemarra-regular">irredeemabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> one year after its sale. Those who sell houses in other walled cities have the right to buy back their property for one year after the transaction. If they fail to do so, the house becomes the permanent possession of the buyer (see Leviticus 25:29–30). This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does not apply to houses in Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>its Elders do <span class="gemarra-regular">not bring a heifer whose neck is broke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> as required when a murder victim is found near a city and the murderer is unknown (see Deuteronomy 21:1–9); <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot become an idolatrous city </span>(see Deuteronomy 13:13–19).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues its list: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> a house in Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot become ritually impure </span>with the impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">of leprous sores</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one may not build out projections or balconies </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gezuztraot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> from houses that are <span class="gemarra-regular">in it; and one may not establish garbage dumps in </span>Jerusalem; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may not build kilns in it; and one may not plant gardens and orchards </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pardesot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in it, except for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">rose garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that were </span>already there <span class="gemarra-regular">from the times of the early prophets; and one may not raise chickens in it; and </span>finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not leave a corpse overnight in </span>Jerusalem.
The Gemara discusses these ten <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> pertaining to Jerusalem, one by one: <span class="gemarra-regular">A house </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>become <span class="gemarra-regular">irredeemable </span>one year after its sale. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written: </span>“And if it is not redeemed within the space of a full year, then <span class="gemarra-regular">the house </span>that is in the <span class="gemarra-regular">walled </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be made sure in perpetuity to him who bought it, throughout his generations” </span>(Leviticus 25:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who taught this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem was not apportioned to </span>any single one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tribes </span>of Israel; rather, it is considered common property. Since no one has ancestral ownership of any house in Jerusalem, its houses cannot be sold permanently.
The Gemara analyzes the next <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>its inhabitants do <span class="gemarra-regular">not bring a heifer whose neck is broken. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written: “If one is found slain in the land that the Lord your God gives you to possess it” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">And,</span> again, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who taught this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem was not apportioned to </span>any one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tribe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of Israel. Therefore, it is not included in the description: “The land that the Lord your God gives you to possess it.”
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot become an idolatrous city. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written, </span>in the introduction of the passage dealing with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of an idolatrous city: “If you shall hear tell concerning one of <span class="gemarra-regular">your cities, </span>which the Lord your God gives you to dwell there” (Deuteronomy 13:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who taught this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem was not apportioned to </span>any one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribes </span>of Israel. It is therefore not included in the description “one of your cities, which the Lord your God gives you to dwell there.”
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a house in Jerusalem does <span class="gemarra-regular">not become ritually impure </span>with the impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">of leprous sores. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written: “And I put the plague of leprosy in a house of the land of your possession” </span>(Leviticus 14:34). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who taught this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem was not apportioned to </span>any one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tribes </span>of Israel. It is there-fore not included in the description “a house of the land of your possession.”
The Gemara discusses the next <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not build out projections or balconies </span>from houses that are <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>Jerusalem. The Gemara provides two reasons for this prohibition. First, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the danger of contracting <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity </span>by being in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">tent </span>as a corpse, i.e., under the same roof, in which case the impurity spreads to all items under the roof. If even a small part of a corpse is under a balcony, everyone who passes under that balcony is rendered impure. Many people come to Jerusalem to sacrifice offerings, and they must maintain a state of ritual purity. The other reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that those </span>great crowds of <span class="gemarra-regular">pilgrims not be injured </span>by colliding with the projections.
The next <span class="it-text">halakha</span> pertaining to Jerusalem is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not establish garbage dumps in it. </span>The Gemara explains that the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">repugnant creatures </span>that are attracted to such heaps and impart ritual impurity upon their death.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not build kilns in </span>Jerusalem. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span>unsightly <span class="gemarra-regular">smoke </span>produced by kilns. The Sages sought to preserve the beauty of Jerusalem and the Temple.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not plant gardens and orchards in it. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the odor </span>emitted by these places, either from discarded weeds or from fertilizer.
The next <span class="it-text">halakha</span> on the list is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not raise chickens in </span>Jerusalem. The Gemara explains that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sacrificial </span>meat that is consumed in Jerusalem. Since chickens peck in the garbage, they are likely to pick up items that impart ritual impurity and bring them into contact with the consecrated food, which may not be eaten in an impure state.
The Gemara discusses the last <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not leave a corpse overnight in it. </span>The Gemara notes that this prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> there is no known explanation for it.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not raise pig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anywhere. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> the background for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the members of <span class="gemarra-regular">the house of Hasmonean</span> monarchy <span class="gemarra-regular">were at war with each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hyrcanus, </span>one of the parties to this war, <span class="gemarra-regular">was inside </span>the besieged Jerusalem, <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>his brother <span class="gemarra-regular">Aristobulus, </span>the other contender to the throne, was <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside. And every day </span>the people inside <span class="gemarra-regular">would lower down money in a box </span>from the Temple walls, to purchase sheep to sacrifice, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>those on other side <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span>take the money and <span class="gemarra-regular">send up </span>sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>over the wall for the <span class="gemarra-regular">daily offerings.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There was a certain elder there who was familiar with Greek wisdom, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said </span>to those besieging Jerusalem: <span class="gemarra-regular">As long as they occupy themselves with the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service, they will not be delivered into your hands. The next day they lowered down money in a box </span>as usual, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>this time <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent up to them a pig. When the pig reached to the midpoint of the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">wall it stuck its hooves into the wall, and Eretz Yisrael quaked </span>over an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">four hundred parasangs by four hundred parasangs.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">At that time </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Cursed be the man who raises pigs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cursed be the man who teaches his son Greek wisdom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning that time </span>of siege that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident </span>in which the barley for the <span class="gemarra-italic">omer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came from the gardens of Tzerifin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> far from Jerusalem, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wheat for <span class="gemarra-regular">the two loaves </span>of <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span> was brought <span class="gemarra-regular">from the valley of Ein Sokher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Barley and wheat could not be brought from any nearer because the besiegers had destroyed all the produce around Jerusalem. This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>it really <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to study <span class="gemarra-regular">Greek wisdom? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: In Eretz Yisrael, </span>

Daf 83a

<span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>would one speak the <span class="gemarra-regular">Syriac [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sursi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> language? </span>One should speak <span class="gemarra-regular">either the sacred tongue, </span>Hebrew, <span class="gemarra-regular">or the Greek language</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And Rabbi Yosei said </span>similarly: In <span class="gemarra-regular">Babylonia, why </span>would one speak the <span class="gemarra-regular">Aramaic language? </span>One should speak <span class="gemarra-regular">either the sacred tongue or the Persian language</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> At any rate, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement indicates that there is nothing wrong with learning and speaking Greek. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Greek language </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">discrete, and Greek wisdom </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">discrete. </span>In other words, these are two separate issues; only Greek wisdom is prohibited, not the Greek language.
The Gemara further pursues this line of inquiry: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is Greek wisdom </span>itself actually <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says in the name of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: </span>It is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“My eye affected my soul, because of all the daughters of my city” </span>(Lamentations 3:51). Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel applied this verse to a personal tragedy: <span class="gemarra-regular">There were a thousand children in the household of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>Rabban Gamliel; <span class="gemarra-regular">five hundred of them studied </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah, and five hundred of them studied Greek wisdom. </span>All of them were killed by the Romans; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the only </span>ones that <span class="gemarra-regular">remain of them </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">I, </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">here, and the son of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s brother, </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">in Asia Minor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[Asya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span>. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement indicates that it is permitted to study Greek wisdom.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The household of Rabban Gamliel is different, as they </span>held <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>ties <span class="gemarra-regular">with the government. </span>Since knowledge of Greek wisdom was crucial for the members of this family, the Sages exempted them from the general decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts his hair </span>in the fashion of <span class="gemarra-italic">komi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a certain haircut favored by the Romans, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered one <span class="gemarra-regular">of the ways of the Amorites</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a gentile practice prohibited by the Torah (Leviticus 18:3). Despite this, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted Avtolmos bar Reuve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to cut his hair </span>in the fashion of <span class="gemarra-italic">komi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, because he </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>ties <span class="gemarra-regular">with the government</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Like-wise, <span class="gemarra-regular">they permitted </span>the members <span class="gemarra-regular">of the household of Rabban </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to discuss </span>matters <span class="gemarra-regular">of Greek wisdom, because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>ties <span class="gemarra-regular">with the government.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not raise a dog unless it is tied with chains. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not raise a dog unless it is tied with a chain. But he may raise </span>a dog <span class="gemarra-regular">in a city that is close to the borde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the country, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">tie it during the day but may release it at night.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: One who raises dogs is like one who raises pigs. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">significance </span>of this statement? Since both are prohibited, what is the point of this comparison? The Gemara answers: The significance is with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to determining when one is liable </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">curse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for it. </span>Rabbi Eliezer is saying that the same curse meted out to one who raises pigs also applies to one who raises dogs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: Babylonia is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a city close to the border, </span>and therefore it is permitted to raise dogs there. The Gemara qualifies this statement, and in this context, Babylonia is <span class="gemarra-regular">interpreted </span>as referring only to <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a city that was close to the border.
With regard to raising dogs, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dostai from Biri expounded: </span>It is written in connection to the Ark of the Covenant: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And when it rested, he said: Return, O Lord, to the myriads of the thousands of Israel” </span>(Numbers 10:36). This verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach you that the Divine Presence does not rest upon the Jewish people </span>if they number <span class="gemarra-regular">fewer than two thousand and two myriads</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where one myriad is equal to ten thousand. The plural form of “myriads” and “thousands” indicates at least two of each. If they are <span class="gemarra-regular">lacking one </span>individual from this total, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there was a pregnant woman among them, who was fit to complete </span>the number by giving birth, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a dog barked at her and she miscarried </span>as a result of the fright, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner of the dog <span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">caused the Divine Presence to depart from the Jewish people.</span>
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who entered a certain building to bake. A dog barked at her. Its owner said to her: Do not be afraid of it; its canine teet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have been removed. She said to him: </span>It is too late for your reassurances. <span class="gemarra-regular">Take your favors and throw them on the thorns! </span>I have felt that <span class="gemarra-regular">the baby has already moved </span>from its place in the womb and will not be born alive.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may spread out traps for pigeons only </span>if this was performed at a distance of at least thirty <span class="it-text">ris</span>, which is eight thousand cubits, from any settled area, to ensure that privately owned pigeons are not caught in the traps. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do </span>pigeons really <span class="gemarra-regular">travel that </span>far from their established places? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 23a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fifty cubits from the city, </span>so that the pigeons that settle in the cotes do not eat the crops that grow in the gardens of the city. This shows that the range of a pigeon is only fifty cubits, whereas four <span class="it-text">mil</span> is eight thousand cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>Pigeons <span class="gemarra-regular">fl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> much <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>than fifty cubits away from their cotes, but <span class="gemarra-regular">their stomachs become full </span>from the food they find <span class="gemarra-regular">within fifty cubits, </span>and therefore they do not eat any more beyond that range.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">flying, </span>is their range only <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ris</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and no more? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In a settled area, one may not spread out </span>a trap for pigeons <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mil</span> from the settlement? This indicates that a privately owned pigeon might be trapped even one hundred <span class="it-text">mil</span> away from a settled area. Why, then, does the mishna permit trapping beyond four <span class="it-text">mil</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not talking about an ordinary city but <span class="gemarra-regular">about a settled area </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">vineyards </span>are grown. Since the pigeons rest in the vineyards as they travel, they are able to traverse great distances. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba stated </span>a different answer: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a settled area </span>where there are many <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in which they can rest from their flight.
The Gemara asks: If there are many dovecotes along the way, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the prohibition against setting pigeon traps <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the dovecotes themselves. </span>Since the mishna teaches that it is prohibited to trap pigeons within four <span class="it-text">mil</span> of privately owned dovecotes, it should be irrelevant that there is a city one hundred <span class="it-text">mil</span> away. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with dovecotes <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>belong <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the prohibition against trapping pigeons from private dovecotes applies only to birds owned by Jews. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or if you wish, say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>abandoned dovecotes <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless. Or if you wish, say </span>that it is referring to dovecotes <span class="gemarra-regular">that are his, </span>i.e., they belong to the same individual who is setting the pigeon trap.


Daf 83b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for that </span>injury <span class="gemarra-regular">due to five types </span>of indemnity: He must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage, for pain, for medical costs, for loss of livelihood, and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for damag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> assessed? If <span class="gemarra-regular">one blinded </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">eye, severed his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hand, broke his leg, </span>or caused any other injury, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a slave </span>being <span class="gemarra-regular">sold in the </span>slave <span class="gemarra-regular">market, and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises how much he was worth </span>before the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">and how much he is wort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> after the injury. The difference between these two sums is the amount that one must pay for causing damage.
How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> assessed? If <span class="gemarra-regular">one burned </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with a skewer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beshapud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or with </span>a hot <span class="gemarra-regular">nail, or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if one burned another <span class="gemarra-regular">on his fingernail, </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where he does not cause a bruise </span>that would affect the victim’s value on the slave market, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates how much </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a similar </span>threshold for pain <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is willing to take </span>in order to be made <span class="gemarra-regular">to suffer in this way. </span>The one who burned the victim must then pay this amount. 
How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical cost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> assessed? If one <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>another, then he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to heal him </span>by paying for his medical costs. In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">growths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., blisters or rashes, <span class="gemarra-regular">appeared on </span>the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the growths are <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the blow, </span>the one who struck him is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable; </span>if the growths are <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to the blow, </span>the one who struck him is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>In a case where the wound <span class="gemarra-regular">healed, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">reopened, </span>and again <span class="gemarra-regular">healed, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">reopened, </span>the one who struck him remains <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to heal </span>the injured party by paying for his medical costs, as it is apparent that the current wound resulted from the original injury. If the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">healed fully, </span>the one who struck him <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable to heal him </span>by paying for any subsequent medical costs.
How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> assessed? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a watchman of cucumbers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the one who caused him injury must compensate him based on that pay scale for the income that he lost during his convalescence. This indemnity does not take into account the value of the standard wages of the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">already gave him compensation for his hand or compensation for his leg, </span>and that compensation took into account his professional skills.
How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> assessed? <span class="gemarra-regular">It all depends on </span>the stature of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who humiliates </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who is humiliated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>does the mishna take for granted the fact that one who caused injury is liable to pay compensation to the injured party? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“An eye for an eye” </span>(Exodus 21:24). You might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this means that the one who caused injury shall lose <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual eye </span>rather than pay money.
The Gemara responds: That interpretation should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind. </span>The principle implicit in the mishna is derived from a verbal analogy in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Based on the verse: “An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot” (Exodus 21:24), one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded the eye of </span>another, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">blinds his eye </span>as punishment; or if one <span class="gemarra-regular">severed the hand of </span>another, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">severs his hand; </span>or if one <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the leg of </span>another, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">breaks his leg. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “One who strikes a person,” </span>and the verse also states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And one who strikes an animal,” </span>to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as one who strikes an animal </span>is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation, so too, one who strikes a person </span>is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is your wish to sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that there is an objection to this derivation, there is an alternative derivation: The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall not take ransom for the life of a murderer, who is guilty of death, </span>for he shall die” (Numbers 35:31). This indicates that it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">for the life of a murderer </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall not take ransom; but you </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">take ransom for </span>one who severed another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">extremities</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is analogous to the death of a limb, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>severed limbs <span class="gemarra-regular">do not regenerate. </span>
The Gemara asks: To <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>verse is the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> referring when it quotes: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes </span>a person” and: “One who strikes an animal”? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes an animal shall pay its compensation, and one who strikes a person shall be put to death” </span>(Leviticus 24:21), this cannot be, as <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is written with regard to killing, </span>not injury, and there is no monetary compensation for killing. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> references the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “One who strikes an animal mortally shall pay its compensation, a life for a life” </span>(Leviticus 24:18); <span class="gemarra-regular">and juxtaposed to that</span> is the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if a man maims his neighbor, as he has done, so shall it be done to him” </span>(Leviticus 24:19). The Gemara challenges: But <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>latter verse <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>use the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes,” </span>which is the basis for the comparison in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are stating </span>an analogy from <span class="gemarra-regular">striking </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">striking </span>that is based not upon the exact phrasing of the verse but upon the details of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the act of <span class="gemarra-regular">striking that is stated with regard to an animal </span>renders one liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation, so too, </span>the act of <span class="gemarra-regular">striking that is stated with regard to a person </span>renders one liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written </span>in the verses discussing one who injures another: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And a man who strikes any person mortally shall be put to death” </span>(Leviticus 24:17), which presumably means that in the case of one who severs another’s extremity the same injury, i.e., death of a limb, is done to the one who caused the injury, and he does not pay monetary compensation? The Gemara answers: The verse does not mean that his limb shall be put to death, i.e., removed, but rather, that he should pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">with money. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the verse is referring to paying compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">with money? </span>Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he is punished <span class="gemarra-regular">with actual death </span>i.e., loss of a limb?
The Gemara answers: That interpretation should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind </span>for two reasons. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>reason is that this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is juxtaposed to </span>the following verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes an animal mortally shall pay its compensation”</span> (Leviticus 24:18). <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, it is written after it: </span>“A fracture for a fracture, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth; <span class="gemarra-regular">as he has given a blemish to a person, so shall it be given unto him” </span>(Leviticus 24:20); <span class="gemarra-regular">and learn from </span>the use of the word “given” that the verse is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">money.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>potential difficulty with the first derivation did the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refer to when it prefaced its second derivation with the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is your wish to say? </span>The Gemara explains: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that <span class="gemarra-regular">a further difficulty </span>was troubling <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: What did you see that </span>led <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the principle of monetary payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“one who strikes an animal”? </span>Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes a person </span>shall be put to death” (Leviticus 24:21), and learn that causing an injury renders one liable to receive physical retribution, which is analogous to death, and not monetary payment? 
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: The <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">damages are derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">damages are not derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>The Gemara questions this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>why not say that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person are derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person are not derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">animals?</span>
To deflect this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>the second derivation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If it is your wish to say </span>that there is an objection to this derivation, there is an alternative derivation, as the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: </span>“And <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall not take ransom for the life of a murderer, who is guilty of death, for he shall die” </span>(Numbers 35:31). This indicates that it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">for the life of a murderer </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall not take ransom; but you </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">take ransom for </span>one who severed another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">extremities, </span>which is analogous to the death of a limb, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>severed limbs <span class="gemarra-regular">do not regenerate.</span>
The Gemara challenges this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall not take ransom for the life of a murderer,” coming to exclude </span>the case of one who severs another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">extremities </span>from the prohibition against taking ransom? Isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">which the Merciful One states: You shall not mete out two </span>punishments <span class="gemarra-regular">to him; </span>i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">do not take money from him </span>as ransom <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">kill him? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived from </span>the verse: “Then it shall be, if the guilty deserves to be lashed, that the judge shall lie him down and flog him before him, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the measure of his evildoing” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:2). From the fact that “evildoing” is singular, the Gemara homiletically infers: For <span class="gemarra-regular">one evildoing, you can render him liable, but you cannot render him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">two evildoings, </span>i.e., one cannot receive two punishments for the same act. 
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the verse: “You shall not take ransom for the life of a murderer, for one who is guilty of death” <span class="gemarra-regular">is still necessary </span>to teach the primary <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught in that verse, in <span class="gemarra-regular">which the Merciful One states: You shall not take money and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>the guilty from being put to death. The verse does not serve to exclude liability to pay damages from the prohibition against paying restitution. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>i.e., if the Torah desires to teach only that the court cannot take ransom to spare the murderer from being put to death, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall not take ransom” </span>and follow it immediately with the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“for one who is guilty of death.” Why do I </span>need the Torah to also state: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For the life of a murderer”? Learn from </span>the addition of that phrase that it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">for a murderer </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">not take ransom; but you </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">take ransom for </span>one who severed another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">extremities, which do not regenerate </span>once severed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And once it is written: “You shall not take ransom,” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the first derivation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which juxtaposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes </span>a person” to: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One who strikes </span>an animal”? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> were to be derived only <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>verse which states: “You shall not take ransom” (Numbers 35:31), <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say: If </span>the one who caused the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">desires</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>may choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">give his eye, and if he desires, he </span>may choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of his eye. </span>Therefore, the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>to derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal: Just as one who strikes an animal </span>is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation </span>and does not receive corporal punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, one who strikes a person </span>is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation </span>and does not receive corporal punishment.
§ The Gemara presents a series of derivations for the principle that one who injures another is liable to pay monetary compensation. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dostai ben Yehud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>The phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“An eye for an eye” </span>(Leviticus 24:20), means <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution. </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that he must pay the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution, or is it only </span>teaching that the one who caused the injury must lose <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual eye? You say: </span>There may be a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the eye of </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is large and the eye of </span>the injured party is <span class="gemarra-regular">small. How can I read </span>and literally apply the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“an eye for an eye” in this </span>case? 
The Gemara continues the derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in all cases like this, </span>where their eyes are different sizes, the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">takes monetary restitution </span>from the one who caused him injury, but in a case where their eyes are the same size, the one who caused injury is punished by actually having his eye removed, this cannot be, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah said: “You shall have one manner of law” </span>(Leviticus 24:22), teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">law </span>shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">equal for all of you. </span>
The Sages object to this derivation and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty </span>in saying that his eye should be blinded? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps, </span>as the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the injured party’s eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>that the court should <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sight from </span>his eye as well, no matter the size of the eye. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since, if you do not say so, </span>then by the same logic, 

Daf 84a
