in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who killed a large </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">or a large </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who killed a small </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">how do we kill </span>the murderer? If one suggests that in such a case a monetary penalty will be imposed, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah stated: “You shall have one manner of law” </span>(Leviticus 24:22), teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">law </span>shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">equal for all of you, </span>so the punishment must be the same for all murderers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>explain that since the murderer <span class="gemarra-regular">took the life of </span>the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states that </span>the court should likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">take the life from him. So too, </span>since the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sight from </span>the eye of the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>that the court should likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sight from </span>his eye. Therefore, the Gemara does not accept the derivation of Rabbi Dostai ben Yehuda, in accordance with the objection of the Sages.
The Gemara presents another derivation: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: “An eye for an eye” </span>(Leviticus 24:20), is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution. </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that this is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution, or is it only </span>teaching that the one who caused the injury must lose <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual eye? </span>There may be a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a blind person and he blinded </span>another, or there was <span class="gemarra-regular">one with a severed limb and he severed </span>the limb of another, or there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a lame person and he caused </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">to be lame. In this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can I fulfill “an eye for an eye” </span>literally, when he is already lacking the limb that must be injured? If one will suggest that in that case, a monetary penalty will be imposed, that can be refuted: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Torah stated: “You shall have one manner of law” </span>(Leviticus 24:22), which teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law </span>shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">equal for all of you.</span>
The Sages object to this derivation and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: And what </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty? Perhaps </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is possible </span>to render the guilty party liable according to the punishment listed in the Torah, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>and the court does so; but in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is not possible </span>to enact such a punishment, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not possible, and we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exempt him. As if you do not say so, </span>that punishing one and exempting another is not counter to the principle of: “One manner of law,” then by the same logic, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who has a wound that will cause him to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">who killed a healthy person, what do we do to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is possible </span>to render the guilty party liable according to the punishment listed in the Torah, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>and the court does so; but in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is not possible </span>to do so, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not possible, and we exempt him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the Gemara does not accept the derivation of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, in accordance with the objection of the Sages.
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: </span>“A fracture for a fracture, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth; as he has given a blemish to a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">so shall it be given unto him” </span>(Leviticus 24:20), <span class="gemarra-regular">and giving can </span>refer <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> to a payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">money. </span>The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if that is so, </span>then when the same verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As he has given </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yitten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a blemish to a person,” </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>word, “<span class="it-text">yitten</span>,” <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>refer <span class="gemarra-regular">to money? </span>The word “<span class="it-text">yitten</span>” means that he caused an actual injury, even though it employs a term whose literal meaning is give.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: The rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Rabbi Yishmael are interpreting a superfluous verse. Now, it is written: “And if a man gives a blemish to his neighbor; as he has done, so shall it be done to him” </span>(Leviticus 24:19), so <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall it be given unto him” </span>(Leviticus 24:20)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the repetition that the verse is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution. </span>The Gemara asks: But if this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As he has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> given </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yitten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a blemish to a person” </span>(Leviticus 24:20)? What does the usage of the term “<span class="it-text">yitten</span>” teach? The Gemara answers: In fact, it does not teach anything, but rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the Merciful One <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to write </span>at the end of that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall it be given unto him,” </span>where the employment of a term of giving is accurate, the Merciful One <span class="gemarra-regular">also wrote </span>earlier in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As he has given </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yitten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a blemish to a person.”</span>
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Rabbi Ḥiyya taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to conspiring witnesses: “And your eye shall not pity; a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, <span class="gemarra-regular">a hand for a hand, </span>a foot for a foot” (Deuteronomy 19:21). This teaches that the witnesses pay compensation with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is given from hand to hand. And what </span>type of compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">is that? Monetary restitution. </span>The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is so, is </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A foot for a foot” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:21), <span class="gemarra-regular">also like that, </span>i.e., is it teaching that the witnesses pay compensation with an item passed from foot to foot? 
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The rabbis of <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya are interpreting a superfluous </span>phrase in the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse. Now, it is written: “And you shall do to him as he purposed to do to his brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">If it enters your mind </span>to say that the verse means this <span class="gemarra-regular">literally, why do I </span>need the Torah to specify: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A hand for a hand” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:21)? The punishment will be whatever he purported to do to his brother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the extra phrase that the punishment is <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A foot for a foot” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:21)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it is written: “A hand for a hand,” </span>the Merciful One <span class="gemarra-regular">also wrote </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A foot for a foot.”</span>
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says </span>that this principle is <span class="gemarra-regular">derived from </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Ḥizkiyya, as the school of Ḥizkiyya taught </span>that the Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“An eye for an eye” </span>(Exodus 21:24), and: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A life for a life” </span>(Exodus 21:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">but not an eye and a life for an eye. And if it enters your mind </span>to say that the verse means this <span class="gemarra-regular">literally, </span>there could be <span class="gemarra-regular">times when you find </span>a case where both <span class="gemarra-regular">an eye and a life </span>are taken <span class="gemarra-regular">for an eye, </span>i.e., when the one who caused the damage is so weak <span class="gemarra-regular">that as </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">blinds </span>his eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">his soul departs </span>from his body.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty? Perhaps we evaluate </span>the physical condition <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the guilty party; <span class="gemarra-regular">if he can withstand </span>this punishment, then <span class="gemarra-regular">we do </span>blind his eye; <span class="gemarra-regular">if he cannot withstand </span>this punishment, then <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not </span>do so and he goes unpunished. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if we evaluate </span>him and determine <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">can withstand </span>this punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we do so to him </span>and blind his eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">his soul departs </span>his body as a result, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he dies, he will die. Didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to lashes </span>(<span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 22b): If one was sentenced to be flogged, and the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluated him </span>and determined that he could withstand a certain number of lashes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he dies at the han</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> of the officer tasked with administering the lashes, then the officer is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>even though the one who was flogged was not sentenced to the death penalty? Therefore, the Gemara does not accept the derivation of Abaye. 
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rabba </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “A wound for a wound” </span>(Exodus 21:25), to teach that one who injures another must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case </span>where he pays compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And if it enters your mind </span>that the phrase: “An eye for an eye” (Exodus 21:24), refers to the removal of <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual </span>eye from the one who injured the other, then <span class="gemarra-regular">just as</span> it is so that the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">has pain </span>from the loss of his eye, the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">also has pain </span>when the court removes his eye; why then does the Torah require that he pay compensation for pain as well?
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty? Perhaps there is a person who is delicate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so <span class="gemarra-regular">he has more pain, and there is a person who is not delicate, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have </span>the same amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">pain. </span>Therefore, even if the court actually removes an eye for an eye, the one who caused the injury might still need to compensate the injured party for pain. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>when the Torah states: “A wound for a wound” (Exodus 21:25)? It renders the one who caused the injury liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>the injured party compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">the difference between </span>them in pain tolerance. Therefore, the Gemara does not accept the derivation of Rav Zevid. 
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava </span>that concerning one who was injured by another, who must pay for damage, the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“If he rises again, and walks outside upon his staff, then he that struck him shall be absolved; only he shall pay for his loss of livelihood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed” </span>(Exodus 21:19), which teaches that one who injures another must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case </span>where he pays compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And if it enters your mind </span>that the phrase: “An eye for an eye” (Exodus 21:24), is referring to an <span class="gemarra-regular">actual </span>eye, then <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">needs healing, </span>the one who caused him the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">also needs healing </span>after the court removes his eye; why, then, does the Torah require that he pay compensation for medical costs as well?
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the difficulty? Perhaps there is </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">whose flesh heals quickly</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there is </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">whose flesh does not heal quickly. </span>Therefore, even if the court actually removes an eye for an eye, the one who caused the injury might still need to compensate the injured party for medical costs. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>when the Torah states: “And shall cause him to be thoroughly healed” (Exodus 21:19)? It renders the one who caused the injury liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>the injured party compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">the difference between </span>their respective medical costs.
The Gemara presents another derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>that the fact that one who injures another pays monetary restitution <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived </span>from a verbal analogy of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for,” </span>as written with regard to injuries caused to people <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for,” </span>as written with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that gored another ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written here: “An eye for an eye” </span>(Exodus 21:24), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there, </span>with regard to a forewarned ox that gored the ox of another: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall pay an ox for an ox” </span>(Exodus 21:36). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>the verse does not mean that the owner pays compensation with an actual ox, but rather pays <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution, so too here, </span>one who injures another pays <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did you see that </span>led <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from a verbal analogy of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for” </span>as stated in the verse with regard to injuries to a person <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for” </span>as stated with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox? Let us learn </span>a verbal analogy of the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for” </span>as stated in the verse with regard to injuries to a person <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“for” </span>as stated with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, as it is written </span>about one who kills another: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall give a life for a life” </span>(Exodus 21:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>the court punishes the guilty party by taking his <span class="gemarra-regular">actual </span>life, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>why not say that the court should take his <span class="gemarra-regular">actual </span>eye?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages is derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages is not derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>say that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is not derived from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">animals.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi </span>retracted his original statement and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>a different derivation: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">derived from </span>a verbal analogy of the word “for” as written with regard to injuries from the word “for” as written with regard to a man who rapes a woman, who must pay monetary compensation. The verse states: “Then the man that lay with her shall give to the girl’s father fifty shekels of silver, and she shall be his wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">for he has afflicted her; </span>he may not send her away all his days” (Deuteronomy 22:29). Based on this verbal analogy, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a person, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages </span>is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a verse concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">damages. </span>
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>The verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“An eye for an eye” </span>(Exodus 21:24), is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual</span> eye. The Gemara asks: Can it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>that the verse is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual </span>eye? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rabbi Eliezer </span>understand the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">like all these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who explained that this verse is referring to monetary payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said </span>in response: Rabbi Eliezer means <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as a slave </span>to assess the compensation for the injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, like whom </span>does the court appraise the injured party? If you say that the court appraises him <span class="gemarra-regular">like a freeman, does a freeman have monetary </span>value? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said: </span>Rabbi Eliezer means <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appraise the injured </span>party as if he were going to be sold as a slave, but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>they appraise <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who caused </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The court appraises how much the latter’s value would be reduced were he to sustain the same injury he caused to the injured party, and he pays this amount as indemnity.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain donkey that severed the hand of a child</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Pappa bar Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He said </span>to the officers of the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go appraise the four types </span>of indemnity <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the child. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>in the mishna that there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>types of indemnity? Rav Pappa bar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was saying </span>to include the indemnities the responsible party is liable to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">other than damage. Abaye said to him: But </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that caused this injury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that causes injury <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage?</span> Rav Pappa bar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the officers of the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go appraise for </span>the child the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">his damage. </span>They said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>doesn’t the child <span class="gemarra-regular">need to be appraised as a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He said to them: Go appraise him as a slave. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The father of the child said to them: I do not want </span>my child to be appraised as a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">because this matter </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">demean him. They said to </span>the father: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>you are <span class="gemarra-regular">acting to the detriment of the child, </span>as he will not receive compensation for his injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: When he matures, I will appease him with my own </span>money, rather than see him demeaned now. 
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain ox that chewed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">da’alas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the hand of a child, </span>injuring him. The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava. He said to </span>the officers of the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go appraise him as a slave. They said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it </span>you, <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, who said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who is appraised as a slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in order to determine the amount of a monetary penalty, that penalty <span class="gemarra-regular">is not collected </span>by courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia? </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is not necessary </span>to appraise his value in order to force the guilty party to pay restitution, but it is nevertheless necessary to determine his value. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">seize</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> property from the one who caused him injury, and that property is equal in value to what the payment should be, the court will not compel him to return it. 
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava says: </span>Compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by an ox and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a person is collected </span>by courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia, </span>but compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a person and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by an ox is not collected </span>by courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia. </span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by a person and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by an ox, </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>collected in Babylonia? If you say that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require ordained judges </span>to collect damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there are not </span>any ordained judges in Babylonia, then <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox to an ox, and </span>damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">a person to an ox, </span>

Daf 84b

say that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require ordained judges [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">elohim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and there are no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> any ordained judges in Babylonia.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what is different </span>about damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by an ox and </span>damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a man, </span>so that Babylonian judges can rule in these cases even though they are not ordained? The difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we, </span>the judges of Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">perform the agenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>we do <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">admissions and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">loans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as we are permitted to rule in those cases as agents of the ordained judges in Eretz Yisrael. If so, then in cases of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by a perso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>cases of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by an ox as well, </span>why not say that the judges of Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it is with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">admissions and loans?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state, </span>with regard to the distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we, </span>the judges of Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, we do so <span class="gemarra-regular">in matters where </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is clear to us</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">in matters where </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is not clear to us</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such as in the case of an injury to a person, which requires an appraisal, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>an objection: In cases of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox by an ox, and </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox by a man, </span>cases that we do judge in Babylonia, the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is also not clear to us, </span>as the damage must be appraised. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>how is the judgment assessed in those cases? We say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see how </span>much <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox is sold </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">in the marketplace, </span>and thereby assess the value of the damages, without a detailed appraisal. If so, in the case of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by a person, and </span>damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by an ox, </span>say <span class="gemarra-regular">too: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see how a slave is sold in the </span>slave <span class="gemarra-regular">market. </span>Why, then, are these latter cases not judged in Babylonia?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">payment of double </span>the principal incurred by a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment </span>incurred by a thief who stole a sheep or ox and then slaughtered or sold the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the payments <span class="gemarra-regular">are fixed </span>and there is no need for an appraisal, <span class="gemarra-regular">we should perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state, </span>with regard to the distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, we do so only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>cases where the guilty party pays <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution </span>for a loss he caused. But <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a penalty, </span>such as the double, fourfold, or fivefold payments of a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not perfor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael. 
The Gemara asks: In cases of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by a person, where </span>the liable party pays <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should we perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, we do so only <span class="gemarra-regular">in cases that are common. </span>Therefore, in cases of damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by a person, </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">that are uncommon, we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara challenges: But accordingly, for indemnities paid to a woman for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation and degradatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> after being raped or seduced, a case <span class="gemarra-regular">that is common</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we should perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed, </span>we do collect compensation for humiliation and degradation in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Pappa collected four hundred dinars </span>as compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for humiliation </span>when he judged these cases. The Gemara questions this explanation: But the other Sages do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>agree <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>that ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Pappa, as Rav Ḥisda sent </span>this question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Naḥman, </span>asking if he should collect compensation for humiliation and degradation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him </span>the following reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥisda, Ḥisda, do you collect a penalty in Babylonia?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>explain the distinction this way: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, we do so only <span class="gemarra-regular">in a matter that is common and involves, </span>i.e., the payment is for, <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary loss. But in a matter that is common but does not involve a monetary loss, or in an uncommon matter which does involve a monetary loss, we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>in a case of an injury caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a person, even though it involves a monetary loss, since it is uncommon, we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael. In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, even though it is common, since it does not involve a monetary loss, we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara challenges the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> itself: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it in fact the case that the courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia collect </span>restitution for damage caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox by an ox? But doesn’t Rava say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox caused damage, </span>the courts <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia do not collect </span>the compensation. The Gemara clarifies: To <span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span>did the ox cause <span class="gemarra-regular">damage? If we say that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged a person, why </span>did Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>state his <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that damaged a person? Even </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person who damaged a person, </span>which is more common, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not collect </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia. Rather, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is obvious </span>that Rava meant that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">damaged an ox. And </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not collect </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia. </span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>Rava stated his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an innocuous </span>ox, i.e., an ox that was not forewarned, whose owner pays for the damage as a penalty; and penalties are not collected in Babylonia. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>Rava states his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to a forewarned </span>ox, and payment for damage it causes is not a penalty, but rather serves as compensation. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rava say: There are no forewarned </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia, </span>as an ox can be forewarned only by ordained judges? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>an ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was forewarned there, </span>in Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then its owners <span class="gemarra-regular">brought it here, </span>to Babylonia. 
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But this is an uncommon matter, </span>as forewarned oxen are not frequently transported from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon matter, did you not say that we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael? The Gemara answers: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the Rabbis from there, </span>i.e., Eretz Yisrael, who are ordained, <span class="gemarra-regular">came and declared </span>this ox <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned, here, </span>i.e., in Babylonia. The Gemara challenges this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon matter, and you say </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon matter </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not perform the agency of </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rava says </span>that courts in Babylonia collect restitution for damage caused by an ox, he means <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>damage in the categories of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eating and Trampling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which are forewarned from the outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> All agree that since these are common forms of damage and involve monetary loss, the judges of Babylonia perform the agency of the judges of Eretz Yisrael and collect compensation for the damage.
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion of the mishna, which states: How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain </span>assessed? If <span class="gemarra-regular">one burned </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with a skewer or with a </span>hot <span class="gemarra-regular">nail, </span>or even if he burned him on his fingernail, where he would not cause a bruise that would affect the victim’s value on the slave market, the court evaluates how much money a person with a similar threshold for pain as the victim is willing to take in order to be made to suffer in this way. The Gemara comments: This teaches that even when the <span class="gemarra-regular">pain </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place </span>that causes <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to the injured party, the one who caused the injury must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>compensation. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>this statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: This is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to the verse: “<span class="it-text">Keviyya</span> for <span class="it-text">keviyya</span>, a wound for a wound, <span class="it-text">ḥabura</span> for <span class="it-text">ḥabura</span>” (Exodus 21:25), <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: A burn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is the first </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>in the verse, and <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai says: A bruise [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is the first </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>in the verse. 
The Gemara explains the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Ben Azzai certainly agrees that the first term in the verse, “<span class="it-text">keviyya</span>,” means a burn. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds that “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” indicates </span>an injury <span class="gemarra-regular">with no bruise, </span>and that one would be liable to pay for injuring another even in that manner; therefore, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to reveal about </span>the meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">of “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>that if the burn also <span class="gemarra-regular">has a bruise, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>the one who caused the injury must pay compensation for pain; but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the burn has <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>bruise, then <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>the one who caused the injury does not pay compensation for pain alone. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And ben Azzai holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” indicates </span>a burn <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">has a bruise, </span>and that one would be liable to pay for injuring another only in that manner; therefore, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to reveal about </span>the meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">of “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>that even if it is a burn <span class="gemarra-regular">with no bruise, </span>the one who caused the injury must pay compensation for pain alone, even though there is no damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to </span>Rava’s explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, the opposite stands to reason, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: A burn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is the first </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>in the verse, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” indicates </span>a burn <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">has a bruise, </span>and one would be liable to pay for injuring another only in that manner. Therefore, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to reveal about </span>the meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">of “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>that even if it is a burn <span class="gemarra-regular">with no bruise, </span>the one who caused the injury must pay compensation for pain alone, even though there is no damage. 
Rav Pappa continues: And <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a bruise [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is the first </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>in the verse, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” indicates </span>an injury <span class="gemarra-regular">with no bruise, </span>and that one would be liable to pay for injuring another even in that manner. Therefore, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One writes </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥabura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to reveal about </span>the meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">of “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>that if the burn also <span class="gemarra-regular">has a bruise, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>the one who caused the injury must pay compensation for pain; but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the burn has <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>bruise, then <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>the one who caused the injury does not pay compensation for pain alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to this explanation, the statements of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and ben Azzai with regard to the meaning of the terms in the verse are <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">final understanding </span>of the verse. The term: The first term stated, is referring to the understanding of the first term after the second term has been written, not what the understanding of the first term would have been if not for the addition of the second term. According to the explanation of Rav Pappa, the mishna here is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara offers another explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and ben Azzai: <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, everyone </span>agrees is that <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” indicates </span>an injury <span class="gemarra-regular">whether there is a bruise or whether there is not a bruise. And here,</span>

Daf 85a

Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and ben Azzai <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>over whether the hermeneutical principle of a generalization and a detail is applied <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a generalization and a detail that are distant from each other.</span> When a generalization is followed by a detail, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies only in the case specified in the detail. The verse states: “<span class="it-text">Keviyya</span> for <span class="it-text">keviyya</span>, a wound for a wound, <span class="it-text">ḥabura</span> for <span class="it-text">ḥabura</span>” (Exodus 21:25). The word “<span class="it-text">keviyya</span>,” as stated in the beginning of the verse, is a generalization that includes burns not accompanied by bruises as well as burns accompanied by bruises. “<span class="it-text">Ḥabura</span>,” as stated at the end of the verse, is a detail of a burn that is accompanied by a bruise. The Torah distances the detail, “<span class="it-text">ḥabura</span>,” from the generalization, “<span class="it-text">keviyya</span>,” by stating the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: “A wound for a wound” between them. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that since there is an intervening phrase between the generalization and the detail, one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from the verse concerning burns and bruises by <span class="gemarra-regular">employing </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a detail. </span>Therefore, the one who caused the injury is liable to pay compensation for pain in all cases of burns, even those that are not accompanied by bruises. <span class="gemarra-regular">And ben Azzai holds </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">does derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from the verse concerning burns and bruises by <span class="gemarra-regular">employing </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization and a detail, </span>and therefore the one who caused the injury is liable to pay compensation for pain only if the burn is accompanied by a bruise. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the Torah to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabura</span> for <span class="it-text">ḥabura</span>,” as that is included as a subset of “<span class="it-text">keviyya</span>”? The phrase mentioning “<span class="it-text">ḥabura</span>” is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">additional money, </span>i.e., in a case where someone caused a burn with a bruise, he pays additional compensation for the bruise beyond that for the burn.
§ The mishna teaches: How is the payment for pain assessed? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates how much </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a similar </span>threshold for pain <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is willing to take </span>in order to be made to suffer in this way. The one who burned the victim must then pay this amount. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How do we appraise pain in a case </span>where the injured party also suffered personal <span class="gemarra-regular">injury? </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s father says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates how much </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is willing to take </span>to allow someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to sever his hand. </span>The Gemara objects: Do you really mean <span class="gemarra-regular">to sever his hand? </span>Wouldn’t this evaluation <span class="gemarra-regular">be not just for pain, but </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">include all five types </span>of indemnity? <span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, are we dealing with fools, </span>who would accept money to have their hands severed? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court evaluates how much money a person would accept to allow someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to sever his</span> already <span class="gemarra-regular">severed hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is of no use. The Gemara objects: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">his severed hand also, there is not pain alone, but there is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">pain and humiliation, because it is an embarrassing matter for him </span>if someone were <span class="gemarra-regular">to take </span>a part <span class="gemarra-regular">of his flesh to throw it to dogs. </span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates how much a person is willing to take </span>to allow someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to sever his hand, which is </span>already condemned by <span class="gemarra-regular">a written </span>decree <span class="gemarra-regular">from the government</span> to be severed, changing the decree <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>having it severed by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a drug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is not accompanied by pain, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>having it severed by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sword, </span>which is accompanied by pain. The amount of money he would accept to have his hand severed by a sword instead of by the drug is his compensation. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>one would <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">and cause himself pain </span>in this way, so there is no indemnity to evaluate. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates how much a person would giv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>have someone <span class="gemarra-regular">sever his hand, which is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">condemned </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">a written </span>decree <span class="gemarra-regular">from the government </span>to be severed, changing the decree <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>having it be severed by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sword, </span>which is accompanied by pain, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>having it be severed by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a drug, </span>which is not accompanied by pain. 
The Gemara objects: If this is the case, then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>wording of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">To take, </span>is imprecise; <span class="gemarra-regular">it should have </span>said: <span class="gemarra-regular">To give. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>The mishna means that the court evaluates how much <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">will take from that </span>one, i.e., the one who caused the injury, based on <span class="gemarra-regular">what this </span>man, the injured party, would have <span class="gemarra-regular">given </span>to the government to have his hand severed by a drug rather than with a sword.
§ The mishna teaches: How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs </span>assessed? If one <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>another, then he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to heal him </span>by paying for his medical costs. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:4): If <span class="gemarra-regular">growths appeare</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>the injured area <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the injury, and the wound reopened, </span>then the one who caused the injury is again <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to heal him </span>by covering his medical costs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and is liable to give him the value of his loss of livelihood </span>while he recovers from the reopened wound. But if the growths that appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">are not due to the injury, he is not liable to heal him </span>by covering his medical costs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is not liable to give him the value of his loss of livelihood.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the growths appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the injury, he is liable to heal him </span>by covering his medical costs, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he is not liable to give him the </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of his loss of livelihood. And the Rabbis say: </span>The one who caused the injury is not liable at all, because the Torah states the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his medical costs </span>together. This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who is liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for loss of livelihood is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs, and </span>anyone <span class="gemarra-regular">who is not liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for loss of livelihood is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable to </span>pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they disagree? Rabba said: I found the Sages in the study hall of Rav when they were sitting and were stating </span>an explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree about </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound may be </span>wrapped in a <span class="gemarra-regular">bandage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., whether one is permitted to bandage his wound to lessen the pain, at the risk of causing damaging side effects. 
Rabba explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound may be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bandage. </span>Consequently, if the bandage causes side effects which lead the injured party to incur additional medical expenses, those expenses are considered to have resulted from the original injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound may not be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bandage. </span>Therefore, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse repeated </span>the obligation to pay them, by stating: “And shall cause him to be thoroughly healed [<span class="it-text">verappo</span> <span class="it-text">yerappe</span>]” (Exodus 21:19), the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay compensation. But for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse did not repeat </span>the obligation to pay it, the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not liable </span>to pay compensation.
Rabba continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I said to them </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>Rabbi Yehuda were to hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound may not be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bandage, </span>then the one who caused the injury should <span class="gemarra-regular">also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not be liable </span>to pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs, </span>as he is not liable to compensate the injured party for damage resulting from his own irresponsible behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the disagreement is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound may be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bandage, but may not be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> excessive bandage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
He explains the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>a wound <span class="gemarra-regular">may not be </span>wrapped <span class="gemarra-regular">in an excessive bandage, </span>then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse repeated </span>the obligation to pay them, by stating: “<span class="it-text">Verappo</span> <span class="it-text">yerappe</span>” (Exodus 21:19), the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay compensation. But for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">which the verse did not repeat </span>the obligation to pay, the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable </span>to pay compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold: Since the verse repeated </span>the obligation to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs, one is also liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for loss of livelihood, which is juxtaposed to </span>the obligation to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs, </span>as the verse states: “Only he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed.” 
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that even though medical costs and loss of livelihood are juxtaposed, the one who caused the injury is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liable </span>to pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">because the Merciful One restricted it </span>in the Torah, as the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Only </span>he shall pay for his loss of livelihood, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed” (Exodus 21:19). “Only” is a restricting term. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis, </span>who hold that one must pay for loss of livelihood in this case as well, hold that the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“only” is coming </span>to exclude growths <span class="gemarra-regular">that were not due to the injury, </span>with regard to which the one who caused the injury is exempt from liability. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter Rabbis </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: Anyone who is liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for loss of livelihood is liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs, and anyone who is not liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for loss of livelihood is not liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs, why do I </span>need, i.e., how do I account for, the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> repeated </span>the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is necessary for that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Yishmael says: </span>When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And shall cause him to be thoroughly healed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">verappo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 21:19), it is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here that permission is granted to a doctor to heal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is not considered to be an intervention counter to the will of God.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if growths appeared due to the injury, and the wound reopened, </span>then the one who caused the injury is again <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to heal him </span>by covering his medical costs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and is liable to give him </span>the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of his loss of livelihood </span>while he recovers from the reopened wound? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “And he shall cause him to be thoroughly healed” </span>(Exodus 21:19). One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the growths <span class="gemarra-regular">were not due to the injury. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Only</span> he shall pay for his loss of livelihood,” in order to exclude this case. This is in accordance with the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says: Even </span>if the growths appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the injury, </span>the one who caused the injury is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: “Only.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if the growths appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the injury, </span>the one who caused the injury is <span class="gemarra-regular">completely exempt </span>from paying compensation, both for medical costs and loss of livelihood. And this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter Rabbis </span>in the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if the growths appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the injury, </span>the one who caused the injury is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood, but is liable </span>to pay compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for medical costs. In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this statement? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">his father, </span>Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara analyzes the statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the growths <span class="gemarra-regular">were not due to the injury. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Only </span>he shall pay for his loss of livelihood,” to teach that he is exempt in this case. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there a need </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>to teach that he is exempt in the case of growths <span class="gemarra-regular">that were not due to the injury? </span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: What </span>did the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it said that the growths <span class="gemarra-regular">were not due to the injury? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who violated </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">doctor’s instruction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and ate honey or any type of sweet </span>food, which the doctor had instructed him not to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>of the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that honey or any type of sweet </span>foods <span class="gemarra-regular">are detrimental to </span>the recovery from <span class="gemarra-regular">the injury</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his injury developed </span><span class="gemarra-italic">garguteni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable to heal him </span>by covering his medical costs. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Only,” </span>to teach that he is exempt in this case. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">garguteni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Abaye said: Necrosis. What is its remedy? Crystalline ice plant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and wax, and wine dregs.</span>
§ The Gemara presents several <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> concerning compensation for medical costs: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will heal yo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">u</span> myself, as I am a doctor; the injured party may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You are to me as a predatory lion, </span>in that I fear you and do not trust you to heal me. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will bring a doctor who heals for no cost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that I will not need to pay for your medical costs; the injured party may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: A doctor who heals for no cost </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">worth nothing. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the injured party: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will bring you a doctor </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a distant </span>place, the injured party may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: A doctor </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> distant </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">blinds the eye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A local doctor has an incentive to ensure that the patient fully heals, while a doctor from a distant place has no incentive to monitor the patient once he has received his fee. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that one, </span>the injured party, <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the one who caused him injury: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and I will </span>take responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">healing myself; </span>the one who caused him the injury may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You will be negligent with yourself and you will take more from me </span>than was originally necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the one who caused him injury: <span class="gemarra-regular">Settle a fixed </span>sum <span class="gemarra-regular">for me </span>to cover my medical costs, and I will take care of my own recovery; the one who caused him the injury may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: All the more so </span>with this proposal is there a concern <span class="gemarra-regular">that you will be negligent with yourself, </span>as you will wish to profit and you will not spend the money on your recovery, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will call me: An</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ox that causes damage, </span>because I caused an injury from which you did not recover.
§ With regard to compensation for pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And all of these </span>types of indemnity <span class="gemarra-regular">are pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a case </span>where the one who caused injury must also pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: The verse states: “A wound for a wound” </span>(Exodus 21:25), to teach that the one who caused injury is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain in a case of damage.</span>
The Gemara asks: But isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach an additional <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: 

Daf 85b

This serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>in the category of those liable to pay compensation one who causes injury <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> just as </span>one who causes injury <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally </span>is liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one who causes injury <span class="gemarra-regular">due to circumstances beyond his control just as </span>one who causes injury <span class="gemarra-regular">willingly. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>and the verse teaches only this, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse write </span>the more succinct phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">A wound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">petza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for a wound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">befatza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; what </span>is taught by the expanded phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A wound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">petza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for a wound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">taḥat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">patza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”? Conclude two </span>conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the verse, that the one who caused the injury is liable to pay compensation regardless of how he caused the injury, and that he must pay compensation for pain in addition to compensation for damage.
With regard to compensation for medical costs in a case where one pays compensation for damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “He shall cause him to be thoroughly healed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">verappo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 21:19), and the doubled term teaches that the one who caused the injury is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>monetary compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs in a case of </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. </span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary for </span>teaching a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: </span>When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Verappo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” from here </span>it is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that permission is granted to a doctor to heal. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, let the verse write: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Verofeh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning: And a doctor shall heal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the phrase employed that the one who caused the injury is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>monetary compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs in a case of damage.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">still necessary for</span> the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that we stated </span>previously, i.e., it was necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for the verse to repeat </span>the language <span class="gemarra-regular">of healing, </span>as the Gemara explained.
