The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, let the verse say </span>one of the two words twice, <span class="gemarra-regular">either: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Rappo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rappo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Yerappe</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. What </span>is taught by repeating the language with a change: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Verappo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">yerappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”? Learn from </span>this wording that the one who caused the injury is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>monetary compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs in a case of damage.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> stated that compensation for pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation are paid even where the one who caused the injury pays compensation for damage. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">that you find these </span>examples of cases where the one who caused an injury must pay compensation for these indemnities <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not in a case of damage. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">you find </span>examples of <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not in a case of damage? </span>
The Gemara answers: An example of a case where one must pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain </span>alone is <span class="gemarra-regular">as that </span>which the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>explicitly: How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain </span>assessed? If <span class="gemarra-regular">he burned </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with a skewe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or with a </span>hot <span class="gemarra-regular">nail, or even </span>if he burned him <span class="gemarra-regular">on his fingernail, </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where he does not cause a bruise, </span>i.e., there was no personal injury, only pain, the court evaluates the monetary value of the pain. An example of a case where one must pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs </span>alone is <span class="gemarra-regular">where some </span>body part <span class="gemarra-regular">was hurting and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">came and brought him a strong drug, and it whitened his flesh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the second person <span class="gemarra-regular">must give him </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">drug to restore the color to his flesh, </span>even though he caused no damage, i.e., loss of function.
An example of a case where one must pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>alone is a case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who locked </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">in a room [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’inderona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and forced him to be idle, </span>but did not cause him any personal injury. An example of a case where one must pay compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation </span>alone is a case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spit in the fac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>another, without causing any personal injury.
§ The mishna teaches: How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>assessed? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a watchman of cucumbers. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:2): How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>assessed? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a watchman of cucumbers. And if you say: </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">the standard of justice was compromised. </span>The Gemara interjects to clarify this statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It appears to be compromised, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when this man will recover</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">not collect the wage of a watchman of cucumbers, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">carry buckets and collect </span>a higher <span class="gemarra-regular">wage, or </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">travel as an agent and collect </span>an even higher <span class="gemarra-regular">wage. </span>The assessment of loss of livelihood should also account for one of these types of labor.
The Gemara returns to quoting the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The standard of justice was not compromised, because </span>the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">already gave him the value of his han</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or the value of his leg, </span>and that compensation took into account the professional opportunities he lost due to the injury.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">severed the hand of </span>another, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him the value of his hand </span>as compensation for damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a watchman of cucumbers. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the leg of </span>another, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him the value of his leg </span>as compensation for damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he were a watchman at the opening </span>to a courtyard, because he cannot work even as a watchman of cucumbers, as that requires walking around the cucumber field. 
Rava continues: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded the eye of </span>another, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him the </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">of his eye </span>as compensation for damage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">as though </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">caused him to grind with a mill</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as even a blind person can do this. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">deafened </span>another, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him his entire valu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> as compensation for damage, because one lacking the ability to hear is not fit for any form of employment. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">severed the hand </span>of another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluate hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to determine the compensation, and then he <span class="gemarra-regular">broke his leg, and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluate him </span>for this additional injury, and then he <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded his eye, and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluate him </span>for this further injury; <span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">deafened him, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say: Since </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">did not evaluate him </span>each time, <span class="gemarra-regular">one evaluation is sufficient for </span>the court to determine his compensation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the one who caused him injury must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him his entire value at once, </span>as that is the compensation for deafening him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say: <span class="gemarra-regular">We evaluate </span>each injury <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one, and we </span>obligate the one who caused him injury to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>compensation for each.
Rava explains the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">The difference is </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the one who caused the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">must give him </span>monetary compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain and humiliation for each and every one </span>of the injuries. <span class="gemarra-regular">Although he does not give him </span>monetary compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage, medical costs, and loss of livelihood for each and every one </span>of the injuries, <span class="gemarra-regular">since, </span>ultimately, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is giving him his entire value </span>after deafening him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is like someone who killed him, and therefore he gives him his entire value </span>and no more; <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event, </span>must he <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">pain and humiliation for each and every one </span>of the injuries, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">had pain and humiliation </span>each time?
Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>as a resolution to this dilemma that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the fact is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">had not evaluated him </span>after each injury, the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">pays him his entire value all together, </span>then there is another dilemma: If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">had evaluated him </span>after each injury but the one who caused the injury had not paid the compensation before he deafened him, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say: Since </span>it is so that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluated him, </span>the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to give him </span>the compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every one </span>of the injuries? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, since </span>the one who caused him injury <span class="gemarra-regular">had not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>those compensations before deafening him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him his entire value. </span>The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raises a dilemma: </span>If one injured another, causing him <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood that diminishes his monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he struck him on his hand and his hand became weakened </span>so that he could not work, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>his hand <span class="gemarra-regular">will ultimately return</span> to its original health, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Should one say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>his hand <span class="gemarra-regular">will ultimately return </span>to its original health, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not need to give him any </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">whatsoever </span>for the damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, in any event, he has diminished </span>his value for <span class="gemarra-regular">now.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this dilemma from a mishna (87a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who strikes his father or his mothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and did not cause them </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">a bruise, </span>and who therefore is not liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment, which is the penalty for one who causes his parent a bruise, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who injures another on Yom Kippur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore is liable for excision from the World-to-Come [<span class="it-text">karet</span>] and not liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment, 

Daf 86a

is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the five types of indemnity.
The Gemara explains: In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of one who injured his parent but <span class="gemarra-regular">did not bruise him, what are the circumstances? </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he struck him on his hand, and it will eventually return </span>to its original health? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to this case that mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the five types of indemnity. If so, this resolves Rabba’s dilemma.
The Sages object and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he deafened </span>his parent by striking him, <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not bruise him. </span>Since his father’s hearing loss is permanent, he is liable to pay all five types of indemnity, and this is not relevant to Rabba’s dilemma. The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabba </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">say: One who deafens his fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is executed, </span>even though no bruise is visible, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is impossible for deafening </span>to occur <span class="gemarra-regular">without a bruise</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is certain that <span class="gemarra-regular">a drop of blood fell into his ear </span>from the blow, even if it is not visible from the outside.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he shaved his </span>father’s hair without causing a bruise. In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he shaved him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his hair <span class="gemarra-regular">will return, and this is </span>an example of <span class="gemarra-regular">our dilemma, </span>i.e., of an injury to a limb that will return to its original health. If so, this resolves Rabba’s dilemma.
The Sages object and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>It is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he smeared </span>his father with a <span class="gemarra-regular">depilatory </span>agent <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nasha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that caused his hair to fall out, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his hair <span class="gemarra-regular">will not return. </span>
The Gemara explains how one could be liable for each of the five types of indemnity by smearing a depilatory agent: The father experiences <span class="gemarra-regular">pain </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has fissures on his head and has pain from those fissures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He incurs <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs because he requires healing </span>for the fissures. He incurs <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he would dance in taverns </span>to earn money, <span class="gemarra-regular">which requires </span>him to <span class="gemarra-regular">make various gestures with his head </span>and his hair while dancing; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">he cannot gesture </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">of those fissures </span>on his head. He experiences <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no humiliation greater than </span>losing one’s hair.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the matter that is a dilemma for Rabba is obvious to Abaye on this side </span>of the dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">and to Rava on that side </span>of the dilemma; they each resolved the dilemma but with opposing conclusions. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it was stated: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">on his hand and </span>the hand was <span class="gemarra-regular">weakened</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but it will ultimately return </span>to its original health, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: He gives him </span>compensation for his <span class="gemarra-regular">major loss of livelihood, </span>i.e., the decrease in his value, due to his temporary paralysis, as measured by his price on the slave market; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">minor loss of livelihood, </span>i.e., the money he would have earned while idle during his recovery. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: He gives him only the value of his loss of livelihood for each and every day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he does not give him the full value of his hand.
§ The Gemara presents another dispute between Abaye and Rava. It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who severs the hand of a Hebrew slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to another, Abaye says: He gives </span>compensation for the <span class="gemarra-regular">major loss of livelihood to the slave, and </span>compensation for the <span class="gemarra-regular">minor loss of livelihood to the master. Rava says: All </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be given to the slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and land shall be purchased with </span>the money; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the master garners the profits </span>from the land for the duration of the slave’s term of slavery.
The Gemara comments: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one injured a slave and thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced </span>the slave’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but he did not reduce </span>the slave’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">for his master; </span>the Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where this is possible? This is possible in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he split the tip of his ear or the tip of his nostril, </span>which does not impact the slave’s ability to perform labor. The Gemara returns to continue the statement: In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the compensation goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">himself. </span>If the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced </span>the slave’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">for his master</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then this is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye and Rava.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: How is payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation </span>assessed? <span class="gemarra-regular">It all depends on </span>the stature of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who humiliates </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who is humiliated. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. Rather, it is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon. </span>
These opinions are <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">all of those </span>cases of Jews who were humiliated, regardless of their individual stature, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are viewed as though they were freemen who lost their property </span>and were impoverished, and their humiliation is calculated according to this status, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they are the sons of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, </span>and are all of prominent lineage. Humiliation is assessed according to a standard formula, regardless of who was humiliated. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The court views each person according to his stature, <span class="gemarra-regular">the great </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">according to his greatness, and the small </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">according to his smallness. Rabbi Shimon says: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>people, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">views them as though they were freeme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who lost their property; </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">poor </span>people, the court views them <span class="gemarra-regular">as the least among </span>the poor. This lessens the payment of compensation for the one who caused humiliation. 
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, if </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, the mishna teaches: It all depends on </span>the stature of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who humiliates </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who is humiliated, and Rabbi Meir </span>holds in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of those </span>who were humiliated <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered alike to <span class="gemarra-regular">one another. And if </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, a mishna teaches </span>(86b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who humiliates a blind person is liable, whereas Rabbi Yehuda says </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A blind person does not have humiliation. Rather, is </span>the opinion expressed in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon?</span>
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna expresses the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. When Rabbi Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a blind person does not have humiliation, </span>he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">taking </span>compensation for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">from him. </span>A blind person is not fully aware of what he does, and one can be rendered liable for causing humiliation only if he intended to humiliate the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to giving him </span>compensation for humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is given</span> compensation. 
The Gemara challenges this explanation of the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from the fact that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">latter clause </span>of that mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who humiliates a sleeping person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable but a sleeping person who humiliates </span>another is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and does not teach </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a blind person who humiliates </span>another is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, by inference, </span>the mishna teaches that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference this </span>way, <span class="gemarra-regular">and no difference that </span>way; whether a blind person humiliates another or is humiliated, the one who causes humiliation is liable to pay compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is clear </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
§ The Gemara analyzes a related <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in light of the three opinions cited earlier. <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Sages taught: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to humiliate a small </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated a great </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">adol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives the money </span>he would have owed <span class="gemarra-regular">for the small </span>man’s <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation to the great </span>man. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to humiliate a slave and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated a freeman, he gives the money </span>he would have owed <span class="gemarra-regular">for the slave’s humiliation to the freeman. Whose </span>opinion is this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon. </span>
The Gemara explains why this is not in accordance with the opinion of any of these <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span>: It <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to say that when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">small in </span>terms of his <span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>i.e., he is poor; and when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gadol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">great in </span>terms of his <span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>i.e., he is wealthy. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stating the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, doesn’t he say </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of those </span>who were humiliated <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered similar to <span class="gemarra-regular">one another? And if </span>it is stating the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, doesn’t he say: Slaves have no humiliation; </span>whereas the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses the compensation owed to a slave. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is stating the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, doesn’t he say: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to humiliate this </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated that </span>one, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt?</span>
The Gemara explains Rabbi Shimon’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for exempting one who humiliated a person whom he did not intend to humiliate? The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of humiliation is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">killing. Just as </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">killing, </span>the murderer is not executed <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he intended </span>to kill the victim specifically, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And he lies in wait for him, and rises up against him” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:11), which means he is not liable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">intended </span>to kill <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>specifically, so <span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>the one who humiliated is not liable <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">intended </span>to humiliate <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>specifically, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And she put forth her hand, and took him by his genitals” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:11); this teaches that one is not liable for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">intended </span>to humiliate <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>specifically.
The Gemara returns to analyzing the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and when Rabbi Yehuda said: Slaves have no humiliation, </span>he meant that one would not be liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to give them </span>compensation for humiliation; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the court needs <span class="gemarra-regular">to appraise </span>compensation for the humiliation of others <span class="gemarra-regular">according to their </span>humiliation, and thereby determine the compensation one owes to a freeman when he intended to humiliate a slave, then <span class="gemarra-regular">we do appraise according to their </span>humiliation. 
The Gemara presents an alternative explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir. Do you maintain </span>that when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gadol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means he is <span class="gemarra-regular">great in </span>terms of his <span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>and when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means he is <span class="gemarra-regular">small in </span>terms of his <span class="gemarra-regular">property? No, </span>rather, when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gadol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual adult </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">adol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; and </span>when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">an actual minor [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">katan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a minor subject to humiliation? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, as Rav Pappa said </span>with regard to another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: The case involves a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached a stage in which when <span class="gemarra-regular">others humiliate him he feels humiliation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here, too, </span>

Daf 86b

say that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case involving a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached a stage in which when <span class="gemarra-regular">others humiliate him he feels humiliation.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who humiliates a naked person, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one who humiliates a blind person, or one who humiliates a sleeping </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, but a sleeping person who humiliates </span>another is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from the roof </span>onto another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">damage and humiliated </span>him, then the one who fell is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the </span>indemnity of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>since a person is always considered forewarned, <span class="gemarra-regular">and exempt from the </span>indemnity of <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>since a person is not liable for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">intend</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to humiliate the other person.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:12): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another who was <span class="gemarra-regular">naked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, but </span>the magnitude of humiliation felt when he <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated him </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">naked is not comparable to </span>the magnitude of humiliation felt had he <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated him </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">clothed, </span>since one who chooses to be naked is less sensitive to humiliation. Similarly, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bathhouse, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, but </span>the magnitude of humiliation felt when he <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated him in a bathhouse is not comparable to </span>the magnitude of humiliation felt had he <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated him in the marketplace.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another who was <span class="gemarra-regular">naked, </span>the one who humiliated him is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is a naked person subject to humiliation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Is it possible to humiliate him in this state? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Naked? </span>It means a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a gust </span>of wind <span class="gemarra-regular">cam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and lifted his clothes, and </span>then this one <span class="gemarra-regular">came and raised them higher and humiliated him.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bathhouse, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is </span>one in <span class="gemarra-regular">a bathhouse subject to humiliation? </span>In a place where people stand naked, can a person be humiliated by having his clothes removed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he humiliated him </span>not in an actual bathhouse, but <span class="gemarra-regular">on the bank of the river, </span>which is a place where people behave more discreetly when they undress.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel raises a dilemma: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another who was <span class="gemarra-regular">asleep, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> before he awoke, so he never knew of his humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is his dilemma? Rav Zevid said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is his dilemma: </span>Is the compensation for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">due to embarrassment, </span>i.e., that his feelings suffer because of what he experienced, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">died and does not have </span>that feeling of <span class="gemarra-regular">embarrassment? Or perhaps </span>the compensation for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">is due to disgrace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., lessening of his honor in front of other people, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">disgraced him. </span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to the dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: A deaf-mute and a minor have </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation; an imbecile does not have </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to disgrace, this </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor, </span>who can be disgraced; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if you say </span>that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to embarrassment, is a minor subject to humiliation? </span>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>do you mean by stating that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to disgrace? </span>If compensation is granted due to disgrace, then <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile </span>should receive compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">have no greater humiliation than this. </span>It is impossible to degrade him further.
The Gemara returns to the original suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any case, resolve from this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">is due to disgrace, as, if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to embarrassment, is a minor subject to embarrassment? </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Pappa said </span>with regard to a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, cited later by the Gemara: The case involves a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached an age in which when <span class="gemarra-regular">others humiliate him he feels humiliation; here, too, </span>say that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case involving a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached an age in which when <span class="gemarra-regular">others humiliate him he feels humiliation. </span>This is how Rav Zevid understands the dilemma of Rabbi Abba bar Memel.
Rav Pappa explains Rabbi Abba bar Memel’s dilemma differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is his dilemma: </span>Is the compensation for humiliation <span class="gemarra-regular">due to his own embarrassment, and </span>this one <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>and was not embarrassed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the compensation for humiliation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family’s humiliation, </span>and therefore the one who humiliated him must pay compensation to his family?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from the same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A deaf-mute and a minor have </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an imbecile does not have </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family’s humiliation, this </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor, </span>whose family can experience humiliation based on what was done to their relative; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if you say </span>that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to his own embarrassment, is a minor subject to humiliation?</span>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>do you mean by stating that the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the humiliation of members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family? </span>If this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile </span>should receive compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The Sages say in response: If one is <span class="gemarra-regular">an imbecile, you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">have no greater humiliation than this. </span>
The Gemara returns to the original suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any case, resolve from this that </span>the compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family’s humiliation, as, if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to embarrassment, is a minor subject to embarrassment? Rav Pappa said: Yes, </span>he is subject to embarrassment, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case involving a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached an age in which when <span class="gemarra-regular">others humiliate him he feels humiliation.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this distinction <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: A deaf-mute has </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an imbecile does not have </span>the right to receive compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor, sometimes he ha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the right to receive compensation for humiliation, and <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes he does not have </span>the right. Why is this so? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>case where he has the right to receive compensation for humiliation is one involving a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has reached the stage in which <span class="gemarra-regular">when others humiliate him he feels humiliation; that </span>case where he does not have the right to receive compensation for humiliation is one involving a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>reached the stage in which <span class="gemarra-regular">when others humiliate him he feels humiliation. </span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who humiliates a blind person </span>is liable to pay compensation. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A blind person </span>who humiliated another <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation. And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this way Rabbi Yehuda deemed </span>a blind person <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable to be exile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for killing unintentionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">and from </span>being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">lashes, and from </span>being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">court</span>-imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">capital punishment, </span>if he transgresses a prohibition for which the Torah mandates one of these punishments.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">derives </span>a verbal analogy to: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Your eye </span>shall not pity” (Deuteronomy 25:12), stated with regard to humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">from: “Your eye </span>shall not pity” (Deuteronomy 19:21), stated with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses. </span>The analogy teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as there, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of conspiring witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">blind people </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>included, as blind people cannot see events occur in order to testify, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of compensation for humiliation, <span class="gemarra-regular">blind people </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>included.
The Gemara continues its explanation: Why did Rabbi Yehuda deem a blind person exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable to be exiled </span>for killing unintentionally? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verse states with regard to an unintentional killing: “Or with any stone, whereby one may die, <span class="gemarra-regular">seeing him not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> (Numbers 35:23),this formulation serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude a blind person; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: </span>The verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include a blind person.</span>
The Gemara explains the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? </span>He would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you: </span>The verse states with regard to an unintentional killing, without any further limiting clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As when one goes into the forest with his neighbor to hew wood” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:5), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this includes <span class="gemarra-regular">even a blind person; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One wrote </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Seeing him not” </span>(Numbers 35:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a blind person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what is the reasoning of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir? The Merciful One wrote </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Seeing him not” </span>(Numbers 35:23), apparently <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>one who happened to not see the one he killed; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Merciful One wrote </span>in the Torah: “Who kills his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">unawares”</span> (Deuteronomy 19:4), apparently <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a blind person, who is not aware of where others are standing. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is a restriction following a restriction, and </span>there is a hermeneutical principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">a restriction following a restriction </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">only to amplif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and include additional cases. Therefore, a blind person is included in the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of those liable to be exiled for unintentional killing.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>respond to this reasoning? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>verse: “Who kills his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">unawares,” </span>does not exclude one who could not see, but rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it comes to exclude </span>one who was <span class="gemarra-regular">intending </span>to kill a particular person and unintentionally killed someone else. That killer is not exiled.
The Gemara continues to explain the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. Why did he deem a blind person exempt from being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">court</span>-imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">capital punishment? </span>That <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>by means of a verbal analogy to: “But if he smote him with an instrument of iron so that he died, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">a killer; </span>the killer shall be put to death” (Numbers 36:15), written with regard to capital punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">from: </span>“You shall appoint for yourselves cities, to be cities of refuge for you, that <span class="gemarra-regular">a killer</span> who killed any person unintentionally may flee there” (Numbers 35:11), written with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable to be exiled. </span>
Why did Rabbi Yehuda deem a blind person exempt from being among <span class="gemarra-regular">those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">lashes? </span>That <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>by means of a verbal analogy to: “Then it shall be, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilty </span>one deserves to be beaten” (Deuteronomy 25:2), written with regard to lashes, <span class="gemarra-regular">from: </span>“Moreover you shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer, that is <span class="gemarra-regular">guilty </span>of death” (Numbers 35:31), written with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those liable </span>to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">court</span>-imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">capital punishment. </span>
The Gemara presents another statement of Rabbi Yehuda: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A blind person does not have humiliation, </span>

Daf 87a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and so did Rabbi Yehuda exempt </span>a blind person <span class="gemarra-regular">from all judgments </span>of civil law <span class="gemarra-regular">that are in the Torah. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? The verse states </span>with regard to an unintentional killing: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then the congregation shall judge between the smiter and the avenger of blood, according to these laws” </span>(Numbers 35:24), to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who is subject to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a smiter and to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">an avenger of blood is subject to </span>civil <span class="gemarra-regular">laws, and anyone who is not subject to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a smiter or to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">an avenger of blood, </span>including a blind person, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to </span>civil <span class="gemarra-regular">laws.</span>
The Gemara presents another statement of Rabbi Yehuda. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A blind person does not have, </span>i.e., receive, compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, and so did Rabbi Yehuda exempt </span>a blind person <span class="gemarra-regular">from all mitzvo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that are stated in the Torah. Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? The verse states: “And this is the commandment, statutes, and laws” </span>(Deuteronomy 6:1), to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who is subject to </span>civil <span class="gemarra-regular">laws is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">subject to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">commandments and statutes, and anyone who is not subject to </span>civil <span class="gemarra-regular">laws, </span>including a blind person, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">not subject to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">commandments and statutes.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef, </span>who was blind, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: At first, I would say: </span>If I hear <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says: A blind person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from the mitzvot, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will host a festive day for the Sages. What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that I am not commanded and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">I perform mitzvot. </span>
Rav Yosef continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">But now that I heard this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina says: </span>One who is <span class="gemarra-regular">commanded and performs </span>a mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">is greate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">is not commanded and performs </span>it, I say: If I hear <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to me </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will host a festive day for the Sages. What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that as I am commanded, I have more reward.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is a stringency with regard to a person </span>who caused injury, <span class="gemarra-regular">compared to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an ox </span>that caused injury: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the person pays </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation; and </span>if he caused a woman to miscarry he also <span class="gemarra-regular">pays compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring, </span>as the verse states (see Exodus 21:22). <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox </span>that caused injury, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays only </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for </span>miscarried <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who strikes his father or his mothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but did not cause them </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">a bruise, </span>and therefore is not liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who injures another on Yom Kippur, </span>the punishment for which is not court-imposed capital punishment, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for all of </span>the five types of indemnity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures a Hebrew slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for all of </span>the five types of indemnity. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>suffered <span class="gemarra-regular">during the time that </span>the injured slave <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to </span>the one that injured him. Since the right to the slave’s labor belongs to his master, his inability to work is his master’s loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures a Canaanite slave belonging to other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for all of </span>the five types of indemnity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves do not have humiliation, </span>so the one who injures the slave pays only the other four types of indemnity.
The mishna continues: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an encounter with them is disadvantageous. </span>In other words, no favorable outcome is possible for someone involved in an incident with one of these people, since <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures them </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they were </span>the ones <span class="gemarra-regular">who injured others, they </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is because they lack awareness and are not responsible for their actions. 
Similarly, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave and </span>a married <span class="gemarra-regular">woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an encounter with them is disadvantageous, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures them </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>were the ones <span class="gemarra-regular">who injured others, they </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because they do not have money with which to pay compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they pay </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">at a later time. </span>The exemption is only temporary, as, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman becomes divorced </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">the slave becomes emancipated, </span>and they then have their own money, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>compensation. 
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who strikes his father or his mothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and causes them </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">a bruise, or one who injures another on Shabbat, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the five types of indemnity, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he is judged with </span>losing <span class="gemarra-regular">his life. </span>The court imposes capital punishment for these acts, so there is no additional monetary punishment. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one who injures his own Canaanite slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the five types of indemnity, because his slave is his property. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara discusses a case of compensation for injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma before Rav: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures the minor daughter of others, to whom </span>does he pay compensation for the <span class="gemarra-regular">injury?</span>
Rabbi Elazar explains the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since the Merciful One granted the profits of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">youth to the father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he receives her betrothal money, compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">injury also belongs to her father? What is the reason </span>that he should receive it? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one who injured her <span class="gemarra-regular">lowered her monetary </span>value, resulting in her father receiving gifts of lesser value when she is betrothed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the profits of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">youth that the Merciful One grante</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to</span> her father, <span class="gemarra-regular">because if he desires to give her </span>in marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">afflicted with boils</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he can give </span>her to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">injury, since if he desires to injure her he may not injure her, </span>just as he may not injure any other person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One did not grant him </span>the right to receive the compensation when she is injured. 

Daf 87b

Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Elazar in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Torah granted the father only the profits of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">youth </span>and nothing else. Therefore, compensation for the injury goes to the daughter. Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rav’s statement based on the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures a Hebrew slave </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for all of </span>the five types of indemnity. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>occurring <span class="gemarra-regular">during the time that </span>the injured slave <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to </span>the one that injured him. This should be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a minor daughter as well, that since the father has the right to the earnings of his minor daughter, he should receive the compensation for her loss of livelihood. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav concedes with regard to </span>compensation for her <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>that it is paid to the father, <span class="gemarra-regular">since her earnings belong to her father until the time of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">adulthood, </span>and therefore her inability to work is her father’s loss.
Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rav’s statement based on a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures his adult son </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>his compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately. </span>If one injured <span class="gemarra-regular">his minor son he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">make a safe investment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">segulla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> with the compensation money. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures his minor daughter </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and moreover, </span>if there were <span class="gemarra-regular">others who injured her, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to give </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">to her father. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">So too </span>here, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the daughter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of livelihood </span>alone, which is paid to the father. The other types of indemnity are paid to the daughter.
The Gemara questions the first ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that if a father injured <span class="gemarra-regular">his adult son he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>his compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately? And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from that which is taught in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures the sons or daughters of others</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">adults he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give them </span>their compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately; </span>if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">minors he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">make a safe investment for them. </span>If one injures <span class="gemarra-regular">his own sons or daughters, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying them compensation. 
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the father is exempt, it is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are dependent on </span>their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">tabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for support. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the father is liable, it is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are not dependent on his table.</span>
The Gemara challenges this resolution of the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">did you interpret the first </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? You interpreted it as dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are not dependent on his table? If so, say the latter clause </span>of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures his minor daughter </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, and moreover, </span>if there were <span class="gemarra-regular">others who injured her, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to give </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">to her father. </span>If this is a case where the daughter is not dependent upon her father for support, then the one who injured her would be <span class="gemarra-regular">required to give </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">to her, because she needs </span>to provide her own <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance.</span>
The Gemara continues its challenge. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a master can say to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">slave: Work for me but I will not feed you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a master is not legally obligated to provide sustenance for his slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to a Canaanite slave, as </span>the master can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Work </span>for me <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire day, and at night go aroun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>beg, <span class="gemarra-regular">and eat. But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Hebrew slave, as it is written </span>with regard to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Because he fares well with you” </span>(Deuteronomy 15:16), indicating that the Hebrew slave must be <span class="gemarra-regular">“with you” in foo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">“with you” in drink, </span>i.e., the Hebrew slave is entitled to live with his master as an equal, the master may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>compel the slave to serve him unless he feeds him. <span class="gemarra-regular">All the more so </span>is it not the case with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his daughter, </span>that she is not required to beg for her sustenance and should receive the compensation herself?
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava, son of Rav Ulla, said </span>concerning a similar matter (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 43a): This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary only for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">surplus, </span>i.e., money that a woman earns beyond what she needs for her essential sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary only for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">surplus. </span>If the compensation for injury is more than the daughter requires for her sustenance, the additional sum is paid to her father.
The Gemara again challenges the resolution of the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">did you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interpret the latter </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> discussing one who injures the children of another? You interpreted it as dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sons <span class="gemarra-regular">are dependent on </span>their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">table. </span>But the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also stated: If they are <span class="gemarra-regular">adults, he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give them </span>their compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately; </span>if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">minors, he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">make a safe investment for them. Why </span>does he make a safe investment for them? Shouldn’t he be <span class="gemarra-regular">required to give </span>the compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">to their father?</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular </span>about receiving money that would go to his child is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in a matter that causes </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">a loss, </span>as in a case where the father himself injured his child and would need to pay compensation. But <span class="gemarra-regular">in a matter that comes from elsewhere, </span>as in a case where someone else injured his child, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not particular </span>about receiving the money, and it is paid to the child.
The Gemara challenges that response: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">a found </span>item a matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes to </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">from elsewhere, and </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular </span>about receiving it? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">profit that comes to </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">from elsewhere, and they do not </span>suffer <span class="gemarra-regular">physical pain in </span>obtaining <span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular </span>about receiving the money, as he does not feel that the children deserve it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an injury, where they </span>suffer <span class="gemarra-regular">physical pain and it comes to them from elsewhere, </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is not particular </span>about receiving the compensation paid to his child.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there, </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, isn’t it discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the daughter suffers <span class="gemarra-regular">physical pain, and </span>it is a matter that <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to her from elsewhere, and </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular </span>about receiving the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches: And moreover, </span>if there were <span class="gemarra-regular">others who injured her, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to give </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">to her father? </span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is a captious man, </span>which is evident from the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>his children <span class="gemarra-regular">are not dependent on his table. </span>A man like this <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular even about matters that come to them from elsewhere. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the latter <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it discusses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a captious man, </span>which is evident from the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>his children <span class="gemarra-regular">are dependent on his table.
