When he is particular </span>about receiving the money, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in a matter that causes him a loss, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">in a matter that comes to them from elsewhere, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not particular. </span>
The two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> stated that the father makes a safe investment for his minor children with the compensation paid to them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">a safe investment? Rav Ḥisda says: </span>The father should purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scroll </span>for his child. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna, says: </span>The father should purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">a date palm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from which </span>the child <span class="gemarra-regular">will consume dates.</span>
The Gemara comments that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> of Eretz Yisrael discussed the same issue as did those in Babylonia. <span class="gemarra-regular">And so says Reish Lakish: The Torah granted the father only the profits of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">youth, </span>and nothing else. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The father receives <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the compensation for his daughter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wound. </span>
The Gemara objects: Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>that the father receives compensation for his daughter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wound, </span>which, unlike an injury, does not diminish his daughter’s value? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even Rabbi Elazar raised his dilemma only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an injury, </span>

Daf 88a

by <span class="gemarra-regular">which he lowered her monetary </span>value, diminishing the amount of money that her father will receive for her betrothal. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a wound, </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">which he did not lower her monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar did not </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">raise a dilemma.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">wounded her on her face, and he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">lowered her monetary </span>value, as this affects the amount of money that her father will receive for her betrothal. 
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures a Canaanite slave belonging to others </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for all of the five types of indemnity. Rabbi Yehuda says: Canaanite slaves do not have humiliation, so one who injures a slave pays only the other four types of indemnity. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? </span>The Gemara explains: The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states</span> with regard to the indemnity of humiliation: <span class="gemarra-regular">“When men strive together, a man and his brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:11). The formulation “and his brother” teaches that the payment of compensation for humiliation is applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to someone who has </span>a relationship of <span class="gemarra-regular">brotherhood </span>with a Jew. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding </span>a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, who does not have </span>a relationship of <span class="gemarra-regular">brotherhoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with Jews. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Sages, </span>who hold that a Canaanite slave is included in the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of compensation for humiliation, maintain that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>the Jews’ <span class="gemarra-regular">brother with regard to</span> the observance of <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot, </span>as a Canaanite slave is obligated to observe most mitzvot. 
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who holds that slaves are not in the category of brothers, <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring witnesses </span>who testify that a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave </span>committed a sin punishable by capital punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be put to death </span>by the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “You shall do unto him as he conspired to do unto his brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:19), and the slave is not considered a brother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: The </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states </span>with regard to conspiring witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall put away the evil from your midst,” </span>indicating that the punishment for conspiring witnesses should be applied <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case, </span>including when they testified about a slave.
The Gemara raises another challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Sages, </span>who hold that slaves are in the category of brothers, a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave should be fit for kingship, </span>as it is written: “One from among your brothers shall you set a king over you” (Deuteronomy 17:15). The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to your reasoning, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> disqualifying <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert </span>from being king <span class="gemarra-regular">should pose a difficulty for you according to all </span>opinions, both according to the opinion of the Sages and of Rabbi Yehuda: Why is a convert not fit to be a king, as he is certainly in the category of brother? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, the verse states: “One from among your brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> shall you set a king over you,” which indicates that the king must be <span class="gemarra-regular">from the choicest among your brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which disqualifies both converts and slaves.
The Gemara challenges further: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Sages, </span>who hold that slaves are in the category of brothers, a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave should be fit to bear witness, as it is written: “And behold, the witness is a false witness, and has testified falsely against his brother” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:18). If a slave is considered a brother, why is he not eligible to testify in court?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: You cannot say </span>that a slave is fit to bear <span class="gemarra-regular">witness, </span>because the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>of a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived by an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And just as a woman, who is fit to enter into the congregation, </span>i.e., to marry a Jew of fit lineage, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from bearing witness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so too, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, who is not fit to enter the congregation, is it not logical that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from bearing witness? </span>
The Gemara counters this derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about a woman? </span>She is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that she is not fit to </span>undergo the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">circumcision. </span>Would <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that from the fact that a woman is disqualified from bearing witness one can derive that the same is true <span class="gemarra-regular">for a slave, who is fit to </span>undergo <span class="gemarra-regular">circumcision? </span>The Gemara responds: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor shall prove </span>that one’s fitness to undergo circumcision is not germane to one’s qualification to bear witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the mitzva to undergo <span class="gemarra-regular">circumcision, and </span>yet he <span class="gemarra-regular">is disqualified from bearing witness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
This is countered: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about a minor? </span>He is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that he is not </span>obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot. </span>Would <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that from the fact that a minor is disqualified from bearing witness one can derive that the same is true <span class="gemarra-regular">for a slave, who is </span>obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot? </span>The Gemara responds: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman shall prove </span>the matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as she is </span>obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot and is disqualified from bearing witness. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the derivation has reverted </span>to its starting point. <span class="gemarra-regular">The aspect of this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is not like the aspect of that </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">aspect of that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is not like the aspect of this </span>case, as each case has its own unique <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Their common denominator </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>both a woman and a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">all the mitzvot and are disqualified from bearing witness. I will also bring </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the slave </span>for inclusion in this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">all the mitzvo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and is disqualified from bearing witness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
This derivation is rejected: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about their common denominator? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>a woman or a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a man, </span>and this is why they are disqualified from bearing witness. Would <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that from the fact that they are disqualified from bearing witness one can derive that the same is true <span class="gemarra-regular">for a slave, who is a man? </span>
The Gemara offers a different derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a slave is disqualified from bearing witness <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, </span>who is disqualified from bearing witness. The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about a robber? </span>He is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that his actions caused him </span>to be disqualified. Would <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that from the fact that a robber is disqualified from bearing witness one can derive that the same is true <span class="gemarra-regular">for a slave, whose actions did not cause him </span>to be unfit?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from a robber and from one of these </span>other two, either a woman or a minor. Their common denominator is that they do not observe all the mitzvot and are disqualified from bearing witness. So too, a slave does not observe all the mitzvot and is disqualified from bearing witness. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar, son of Ravina, said </span>another derivation. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Fathers shall not be put to death for children” </span>(Deuteronomy 24:16), meaning that people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥayis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">children. </span>This is referring to Canaanite slaves, whose children are not considered to be related to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">For if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to interpret the verse according to its straightforward meaning, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we say: “Fathers shall not be put to death for children,” </span>meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">by the testimony of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">children, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write: Fathers shall not be put to death for their children. What </span>does the verse teach by stating only: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Children,” </span>without the word their? <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>this formulation <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage with </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">children.</span>
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>when the end of the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Nor shall children be put to death for fathers” </span>(Deuteronomy 24:16), does this <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>mean that people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">children who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage with </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers? But </span>if that were the case, it would <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be the case that <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from bearing witness, </span>as one who converts no longer shares common lineage with his parents. 
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert, although he has no </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with those <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>him, i.e., his parents, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him, i.e., his children. This serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude a slave, who has no </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage either </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him.
The Sages prove that a convert is fit to bear witness: <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert is disqualified from bearing witness, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One write: Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, according to </span>the interpretation <span class="gemarra-regular">that we say: </span>Fathers <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on the testimony of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">children; and let the Merciful One </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">write: “Nor shall children be put to death for fathers,” from which you learn two </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">children shall not be put to death by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers, and another, </span>that people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">children who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage with </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers, </span>i.e., converts.
The Gemara continues the statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave </span>being disqualified from bearing witness <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived by an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert: And just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert, that it is </span>the case concerning those <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he has no </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage, but </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage, </span>and he is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from bearing witness, </span>then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, who has no </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him, all the more so <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not logical that he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified from bearing witness? </span>
The Gemara continues the statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Merciful One </span>did not write the verse that way, but instead <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote: “Fathers shall not be put to death for children,” which indicates </span>that people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage with </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">children, learn from </span>this formulation that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave, who has no </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>is the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who is disqualified from bearing witness. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert, since he has </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage </span>with those <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>him, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to bear witness.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Let the Merciful One write: Nor shall children be put to death for their fathers, why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One wrote: “Nor shall children be put to death for fathers,” which indicates </span>that people <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not be put to death based on </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">children who do not have </span>common <span class="gemarra-regular">lineage </span>with their <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the Merciful One <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote: “Fathers shall not be put to death for children,” </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">also wrote </span>in the same manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Nor shall children be put to death for fathers.”</span>
§ The mishna (87a) teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, an encounter with them is disadvantageous, </span>since one who injures them is liable. But if they were the ones who injured, they are exempt. The Gemara relates an incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mother of Rav Shmuel bar Abba from </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Hagroneya was married to Rabbi Abba. She wrote, </span>i.e., signed over, her <span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rav Shmuel bar Abba, her son. After she died, </span>

Daf 88b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Abba went before Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba </span>to claim his mother’s property. Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">established him </span>as the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property, </span>in accordance with what was written in the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba, </span>the mother’s husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>a report of <span class="gemarra-regular">the matter before Rav Hoshaya. Rav Hoshaya went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>a report of the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Yehuda. </span>Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Hoshaya: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who sold her usufruct property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which belongs to her but whose profits her husband garners, <span class="gemarra-regular">in her husband’s lifetime, and </span>then she <span class="gemarra-regular">died, the husband repossesses </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchasers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The granting of her property by means of the document is analogous to a sale, and Rabbi Abba can repossess the property from Rav Shmuel bar Abba.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba, </span>who had ruled that the property belongs to Rav Shmuel bar Abba. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: I know the mishna </span>that supports my opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span> 136a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">writes </span>a document transferring ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> stating that the transfer should take effect immediately but the son will have use of it only <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death, the son cannot sell </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">in the father’s possession. And the father, </span>even though he retained the right to use the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot sell </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written </span>as belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to the son. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the father sold </span>the property, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sold </span>to the extent that the purchaser may use it <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">dies. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the son sold </span>the property during his father’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser does not have </span>the right to use the property <span class="gemarra-regular">until the father dies. </span>
Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>if the son sold the property during his father’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">when the father dies the purchaser has </span>rights to the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this would be so <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the son died in the father’s lifetime, where </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">never came into the son’s possession. </span>
Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba’s analysis is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who says: </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son died in the father’s lifetime, where </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">never came into the son’s possession, </span>and there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the father died in the son’s lifetime, where the </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">came into the son’s possession. </span>In any event, <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser acquired </span>the property. 
The Gemara records a dispute between the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> with regard to this point. <span class="gemarra-regular">As was stated: </span>In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the son sold </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">in the father’s lifetime, and the son died in the father’s lifetime, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The purchaser did not acquire </span>the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: The purchaser acquired </span>the property. 
The Gemara explains the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The purchaser did not acquire </span>the property, because he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: When the mishna teaches </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son sold </span>the property during his father’s lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser does not acquire </span>any rights to use the property <span class="gemarra-regular">until the father dies, and </span>one could infer that <span class="gemarra-regular">when the father dies the purchaser has </span>rights to the property, the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the son did not die during the father’s lifetime, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">came into the son’s possession </span>upon the father’s death, before the purchaser acquired it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son died in the father’s lifetime, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come into the son’s possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">even when the father dies the purchaser does not have </span>rights to the property.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is considered to be like ownership of the item itself. </span>Even though the property itself did not belong to the father, it is as though the father owned the property, because all of the produce belonged to him in practice. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that did not belong to him. </span>
The Gemara explains the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser acquired </span>the property based on this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the mishna teaches </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son sold </span>the property during his father’s lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser does not have </span>any right to use the property <span class="gemarra-regular">until the father dies, </span>and one could infer that <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event, when the father dies the purchaser has </span>rights to the property, the mishna means that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son did not die in the father’s lifetime, where the </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">came into the son’s possession, and </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no difference </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the son died in the father’s lifetime, where the </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come into the son’s possession. </span>In either case, the <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser acquired </span>the property.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce is not considered to be like ownership of the item itself. And </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that belonged to him.</span>
The Gemara returns to the discussion of the opinion of Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba. <span class="gemarra-regular">And now </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">us, whether </span>if one discusses the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba and whether </span>one discusses the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda, they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, </span>that ownership of the rights to use an item and to its produce is not considered to be like ownership of the item itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says: If </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce is considered to be like ownership of the item itself, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">when the father dies and the son </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">died in the father’s lifetime, why does the purchaser have </span>rights to the property? <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t he sell </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that did not belong to him? </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of</span> the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce is not considered to be like ownership of the item</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself? </span>Therefore, Rav Shmuel bar Abba should receive the property transferred to him by his mother, as the fact that the husband owned the rights to its produce does not limit her ability to transfer her property to her son.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">brought back </span>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba’s reply <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Yehuda. </span>Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, that a husband can repossess the property that his wife sold before she died, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna </span>concerning a father who transfers his property to his son while retaining the right to garner the profits.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning </span>for distinguishing between the two cases? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: Granted, if </span>the mishna had <span class="gemarra-regular">taught the opposite </span>and stated that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes </span>a document transferring ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to his father </span>after his death, with the son retaining the right to garner the profits until then, and the father sold the property during his son’s lifetime, the purchaser has rights to the property after the son dies, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>possible <span class="gemarra-regular">to resolve from </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that ownership of</span> the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce is not considered to be like ownership of the item</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself. </span>
Rav Yosef continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But now that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>specifically: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who writes </span>a document transferring ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to his son, </span>the ability of the son to sell the property is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">is fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> and already has a right to the property, and not just due to the existence of the document. In the case of Rav Shmuel bar Abba as well, the woman’s property is inherited by her husband, not her son, so she cannot transfer it to Rav Shmuel bar Abba.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that a son inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a father, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">a father does not inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> There is no difference between their rights to inherit from one another. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>even if the mishna taught a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning a son transferring his property to his father, the son’s reason for doing so could have been that <span class="gemarra-regular">he comes to hide his property from his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>and wants his father to inherit from him instead. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>when a father transfers his property to his son, <span class="gemarra-regular">he comes to hide his property from </span>the son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, </span>as the father has other sons but does not want them to inherit from him. Therefore, the mishna’s choice of case cannot serve as a basis for inference.
Abaye continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>was Shmuel’s reason for saying that the right of a husband to the property that his wife sold before she died <span class="gemarra-regular">is not similar to our mishna</span> that states that a father does not have rights to property sold by his son? The difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Usha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an ordinance instituted with regard to a husband’s rights to his wife’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: In </span>the town of <span class="gemarra-regular">Usha </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who sold her usufruct property in her husband’s lifetime and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, the husband repossesses </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchasers. </span>This ordinance was instituted only for the benefit of a husband, but not for the benefit of a father or son. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: We too learn </span>of the ordinance of Usha in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If witnesses said: <span class="gemarra-regular">We testify about so-and-so that he divorced his wife and gave </span>her the full value of the obligations recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 89a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and she is under hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and serves him, </span>i.e., she was in fact still married to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then these witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">were found to be conspiring </span>witnesses who were attempting to deny this woman the ability to ever collect payment of her marriage contract, then the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say </span>that the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">shall pay the entire </span>value of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract. Rather, </span>the court says that they shall pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage of her marriage contract. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the financial advantage of her marriage contract? </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> how much a person </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">want to give </span>to purchase the rights <span class="gemarra-regular">of this </span>woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract, </span>taking into account the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that if she becomes widowed or divorced </span>the purchaser will receive its full value, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if she dies </span>during her husband’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband will inherit her </span>property and the purchaser will receive nothing. 
Rav Idi bar Avin continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no ordinance of Usha, why would her husband inherit </span>from<span class="gemarra-regular"> her? </span>Let the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">sell her marriage contract entirely</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>This is not a proof for the existence of the ordinance of Usha, because even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>there is no ordinance, and the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the woman retains the right to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct property, </span>would they also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the woman retains the right to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to guaranteed property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is listed among the possessions she brought into the marriage but is entirely under her husband’s authority? In any event, there is property that she does not have the right to sell and that the husband would inherit if she dies, regardless of whether or not there is an ordinance of Usha, so the marriage contract could not be sold for its full value.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage, since </span>discussion of this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">came to us, let us say something about it. </span>The money received for selling the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage is </span>given only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> For if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to say that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the conspiring <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>who have been rendered liable to pay a penalty to the wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">say to her: What loss have we caused you </span>by testifying that you had received payment of your marriage contract? Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you were to sell it for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage,</span> your <span class="gemarra-regular">husband would have taken </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from you. Rav Shalman said </span>in response: She still would incur a loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is a gain </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the household. </span>Even if the husband were to be the one to receive the payment from the sale, the financial situation of the household would be improved, leading to a concrete benefit for the wife as well. This offsets the wife’s potential loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the money received for selling the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage </span>of the marriage contract is given only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wife, and the husband does not </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">garner the profits </span>from that money or from property the wife would purchase with that money. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? The Sages instituted </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the profits </span>of her property are <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the husband, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not institute </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the profits of the profits </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">for him.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came from the study hall of Rav they said: We learned </span>a source <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Usha </span>in the mishna (87a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave or </span>a married <span class="gemarra-regular">woman, an encounter with them is disadvantageous, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures them </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>were the ones who <span class="gemarra-regular">injured others they </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>because they do not have money with which to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no ordinance of Usha, </span>there would be a method by which a married woman can obtain money with which to pay, as the court can have <span class="gemarra-regular">her sell </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct property and give </span>the money received <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the one she injured. It can therefore be inferred from the mishna that a woman cannot sell her usufruct property, in accordance with the ordinance of Usha.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, though indeed there is an ordinance of Usha, and she cannot fully sell </span>her usufruct property, <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>should nevertheless be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">sell </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct property for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage,</span> i.e., the purchaser will pay her for the future rights to the property in the event that she gets divorced or is widowed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she will give </span>that money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the one she injured. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she does not have </span>usufruct property of which she can sell the future rights. <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, </span>there is no source from the mishna for the ordinance of Usha, as the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she does not have </span>usufruct property to sell.
The Gemara questions the ruling of the mishna: Why does the mishna assert that a married woman will not have money with which to pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">but she should sell </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract and give </span>the money received <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the one she injured? The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>ruling of the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited for a man to remain </span>living together <span class="gemarra-regular">with his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">even one hour without </span>her having <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract. </span>Therefore, the woman cannot sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>for the ruling of Rabbi Meir? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that she will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not be demeaned in his eyes such that </span>he will easily <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce her, </span>as he would not suffer any adverse financial consequences by divorcing her. The Gemara asks: If that is the reason, then <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>when she sold her marriage contract to others, the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">will not </span>easily <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce her, as, if he would divorce her, those who purchased </span>her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">will come</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract from </span>the husband. It makes no difference to the husband whether he will have to pay the marriage contract to her or to the purchasers. Therefore, the reason for the ruling of the mishna cannot be based upon the statement of Rabbi Meir. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> the reason she is not required to sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract to pay the one she injured is that the <span class="gemarra-regular">financial advantage </span>of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">words, </span>i.e., not a specific possession, but a legal entity that simply creates the possibility to collect its value at a later date. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">words are not mortgaged </span>for the payment of debts, in this case her debt to the injured party. 
The Gemara questions this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why not? </span>Why is financial advantage not mortgaged? <span class="gemarra-regular">They are words that are sold for dinars. </span>Since the financial advantage of her marriage contract has a market value, it is mortgaged to pay the debt to the injured party. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>she is not required to sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>of the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, as Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a promissory not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">went back and forgave </span>the debtor his debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is forgiven, </span>and the promissory note is left valueless, since the debtor essentially had a non-transferable obligation to the creditor alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heir can forgive </span>the debt. Since there is a concern that the woman will forgive the debt of her marriage contract after having sold it, causing a loss to the purchaser, she is not required to sell it.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Let her <span class="gemarra-regular">sell </span>the financial advantage of the marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the one she injured, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if she </span>happens to <span class="gemarra-regular">forgive </span>the debt of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband, she will forgive it. </span>Just as it is generally permitted for one to sell a promissory note despite the fact that he could then forgive the debt, the same should hold true in this case as well.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>matter that will engender a benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband, she </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly forgive </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>so that he will not have to pay the marriage contract. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">causing </span>a definite <span class="gemarra-regular">loss to that purchaser</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>by having the woman sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract in a case where she will certainly forgive the debt, the Sages will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be willing to <span class="gemarra-regular">cause a </span>definite <span class="gemarra-regular">loss to </span>the purchaser. 
The Gemara offers another suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that she should <span class="gemarra-regular">sell </span>her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">to that one whom she injured </span>in order to receive the money <span class="gemarra-regular">for the financial advantage, </span>

Daf 89b

so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if she </span>were to <span class="gemarra-regular">forgive </span>the debt of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband, </span>the one she injured <span class="gemarra-regular">would not lose </span>anything, <span class="gemarra-regular">as now as well she is not giving him any </span>payment, one could respond that <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>matter that will engender a benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband, she will certainly forgive </span>the debt with regard to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we do not trouble the courts </span>to supervise the sale of the financial advantage <span class="gemarra-regular">without cause</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the reason she does not sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract to obtain money with which to pay the injured party is that she would then forgive the debt of the marriage contract, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:22): <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly,</span> in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>was the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who injured her husban</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">she has not lost her marriage contract </span>as a result, as he does not collect compensation from the properties she brought into the marriage that are enumerated in the marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does she not lose it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let her sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract to her husband </span>in order to obtain the money to compensate him <span class="gemarra-regular">for that injury </span>that she caused him, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if she will forgive </span>the debt of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to her husband there will be no loss </span>for the purchaser, i.e., her husband. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited for a man to remain </span>living together <span class="gemarra-regular">with his wife </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">even one hour </span><span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>her having <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract. </span>Therefore, the woman cannot sell the financial advantage of her marriage contract to her husband. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>for the ruling of Rabbi Meir? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that she will not be demeaned </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in his eyes such that </span>he will easily <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>if she were to sell the marriage contract to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce her and collect </span>the properties listed in the marriage contract as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for his injuries from her. If that is so, even now, </span>where she does not sell her marriage contract to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will divorce her, and </span>once she is divorced, he will <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the properties listed in the marriage contract as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for his injuries </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from her. </span>Preventing her from selling the marriage contract to him will not serve as an impediment to his divorcing her. 
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a large </span>sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that because </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">that slight </span>sum due him as compensation for his injuries, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would not </span>be willing to <span class="gemarra-regular">lose </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>sum that he would have to pay were he to divorce her. Therefore, the marriage contract does serve as an impediment to his divorcing her. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>in fact the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">larger than </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let them establish </span>her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the other, </span>additional, sum, <span class="gemarra-regular">let her sell it to</span> her husband as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for his injuries. </span>Since she will be left with a marriage contract of standard value, they would be allowed to remain living together.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not larger than </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah </span>law, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">his injury was </span>assessed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">four dinars, and because </span>of a gain of <span class="gemarra-regular">four dinars, </span>the husband would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be willing to <span class="gemarra-regular">lose twenty-fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> dinars, which is the value of a marriage contract required by Torah law. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in the latter case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as she does not sell </span>her marriage contract to obtain money to pay damages <span class="gemarra-regular">while she is under him, </span>i.e., married to her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, she does not lose</span> the value of her marriage contract to pay damages <span class="gemarra-regular">while she is under him.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">she will be found to have lost </span>the value of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what are the circumstances? </span>It would be a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">larger than </span>the sum recorded in <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract</span> required <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law. </span>In that case she would be obligated to sell the portion of the marriage contract representing the additional amount in order to obtain money with which to compensate the one she injured.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in response: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the stipulation in the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">male offspring </span>inherit payment of their mother’s marriage contract, and it is not discussing the sale of a marriage contract in general. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: Just as </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stipulates <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells her marriage contract to others does not lose </span>the future implementation of the stipulation in the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">male offspring </span>inherit payment of their mother’s marriage contract, and Rava clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The need for <span class="gemarra-regular">money is what </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>to sell it under <span class="gemarra-regular">duress</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and she did not intend to abrogate her sons’ rights to inherit the property in the future. Rava continues his explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, </span>a woman who <span class="gemarra-regular">sells her marriage contract to her husband does not lose </span>the future implementation of the stipulation in the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">male offspring </span>inherit payment of their mother’s marriage contract, and Rava clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The need for <span class="gemarra-regular">money is what </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>to sell it under <span class="gemarra-regular">duress.</span>
§ The Gemara returns to the earlier discussion and suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that the issue whether or not there was <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinance of Usha </span>instituting that the wife cannot sell her usufruct property <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves </span>that the woman brought into the marriage as <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">are emancipated by </span>having <span class="gemarra-regular">a tooth </span>knocked out <span class="gemarra-regular">or an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eye </span>blinded <span class="gemarra-regular">by the woman, </span>i.e., the wife, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when the owner of a slave knocks out the slave’s tooth or blinds his eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>emancipated by having a tooth knocked out or an eye blinded <span class="gemarra-regular">by the man, </span>i.e., the husband, as he is not their owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another</span> <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The slave is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>emancipated if his tooth was knocked out or his eye was blinded, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor by the man nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by the woman. </span>
The Gemara continues its analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">They assumed that everyone </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce, </span>which the husband has with regard to usufruct property, is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like ownership </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the item itself, </span>which is why the husband is not considered the owner of the slaves. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>so that the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to this: That the one who says </span>that the slave is emancipated if he was struck <span class="gemarra-regular">by the woman </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Usha? </span>Since she retains the right to sell her usufruct property, she is considered the full owner of the slaves with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of their being emancipated. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that the slave is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>emancipated if he was struck <span class="gemarra-regular">by the man and not </span>if he was struck <span class="gemarra-regular">by the woman </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an ordinance of Usha. </span>Since she cannot sell her usufruct property, she is not considered to be the full owner of the slaves with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of their being emancipated. 
The Gemara offers an alternative explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>perhaps it is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an ordinance of Usha. But here, </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is referring to the time <span class="gemarra-regular">before the ordinance </span>was instituted, and since the wife had the right to sell her usufruct property, she is considered the full owner of the slaves with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of their being emancipated, while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is referring to the time <span class="gemarra-regular">after the ordinance </span>was instituted, and since she could no longer sell her usufruct property, she is not considered to be the full owner of the slaves with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of their being emancipated. 
The Gemara offers an alternative explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are referring to the time <span class="gemarra-regular">after the ordinance </span>was instituted, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in each <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an ordinance of Usha. Rather, according to the one who says </span>that the slave is emancipated if he is struck <span class="gemarra-regular">by the woman but not </span>if he is struck <span class="gemarra-regular">by the man, what is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, as Rava said: </span>

Daf 90a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Consecratio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of an item to the Temple, the advent of the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened brea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> taking effect upon a leavened food, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">emancipatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">abrogate </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">lien </span>that exists upon them. Therefore, the emancipation of a slave resulting from the knocking out of his tooth or the blinding of his eye abrogates the lien that the husband has on the slave as usufruct property, leaving the woman as the solitary owner.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>According to this explanation, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that the slave is not emancipated when he is struck by the woman holds that the lien of the husband is not abrogated, which would run counter to the statement of Rava. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No;</span> it is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that agrees with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>that a lien is abrogated, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here </span>the reason why the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds that the husband’s lien on the slave is not abrogated is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages strengthened the lien of a husban</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on his wife’s property, and it is only this type of lien that is not abrogated by emancipation. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> of the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">hold that there is n</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ordinance of Usha, and here, they disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the question whether <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of the item itself. </span>In this case, the husband enjoys the usage of the slave while the wife owns the slave himself. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that rules that the slave is not emancipated when struck by the woman holds that the husband is also considered to be an owner, and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that rules that the slave is emancipated when struck by the woman holds that the husband is not considered to be an owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the dispute with regard to the question whether ownership of the rights to use an item and to its produce is like ownership of the item itself is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dispute between these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells his</span> Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave to another, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">contracte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with him </span>that the sale is effected <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">will serve </span>the seller for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days </span>before he is transferred to the purchaser, the outcome of this sale is that during those thirty days, the original master enjoys the usage of the slave and the purchaser is the owner of the slave. 
As detailed in the Torah (Exodus 21:18–21), if one strikes another and the injury leads directly to the victim’s death, the one who struck him is liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment. This ruling does not apply in the case where a master strikes his Canaanite slave and the slave lingers with his injuries for more than a day or two and then dies, in which case the master is exempt from court-imposed capital punishment. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> addresses who is considered the owner of the slave with regard to this latter <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says </span>that during those thirty days, only the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: <span class="gemarra-regular">A day or two days. </span>Rabbi Meir holds that in this case, the first owner is included in this exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is under his </span>authority, as he enjoys the usage of the slave, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of the item itself. </span>The status of the first owner as the owner also negates the possibility that the second owner would be regarded as the owner with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and he would not be included in the exemption.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that only the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>owner <span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: <span class="gemarra-regular">A day or two days, because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is his money,</span> i.e., property, but the first owner is not included in the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: A day or two days, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its produce </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like ownership of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> item itself. </span>Therefore, the first owner does not have the status of an owner with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: <span class="gemarra-regular">A day or two days. This </span>one, the first owner, is included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is under his </span>authority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the second owner, is included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is his money. </span>The Gemara explains the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is uncertain, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and to <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> produce, if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of the item itself, </span>in which case only the first owner would be exempt, or <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ownership of the item itself, </span>in which case only the second owner would be exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>where there is an <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital </span>law, the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">to be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lenient</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, neither of them would receive court-imposed capital punishment in this case. 
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are not </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: <span class="gemarra-regular">A day or two days, </span>and both would receive court-imposed capital punishment. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the second owner, would be liable to receive it <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not under his </span>authority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the first owner, would receive it <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not his money. </span>Rabbi Eliezer holds that one is required both to own the slave himself and enjoy the usage of the slave to be included in the exemption. 
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer?</span> The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“Notwithstanding if he continue a day or two, he shall not be punished; <span class="gemarra-regular">for he is his money” </span>(Exodus 21:21), and Rabbi Eliezer understands this to be referring to a slave that is <span class="gemarra-regular">his money </span>alone, a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">that is unique to him, </span>and therefore this exemption does not apply to one who does not have total ownership of the slave.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose</span> opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is that which Ameimar says: </span>If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman, </span>i.e., a husband or a wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">who sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the wife’s <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is owned by the wife but used by the husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not accomplish anything, </span>as the sale does not take effect? <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is his statement? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, </span>who holds that one is considered to be an owner only if he both owns the item itself and enjoys the usage of that item.
