The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught that which the Sages taught: One who is a half-slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> half-freeman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and similarly, a slave belonging to two partners, are not emancipated </span>when injured by one of their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>one of their <span class="gemarra-regular">extremities that do not regenerate, </span>i.e., the twenty-four extremities whose injury by an owner emancipates a slave? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This is what </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say in the name of Rava: It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer. </span>
He explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Rabbi Eliezer say </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“his money” </span>indicates a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">that is unique to him? Here too, </span>since the verse states with regard to the emancipation of a slave resulting from his master striking him: “And if a man smite the eye of <span class="gemarra-regular">his slave” </span>(Exodus 21:26), this is referring to his slave <span class="gemarra-regular">that is unique to him. </span>Therefore, this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of emancipation would not apply to a slave not fully owned by one master. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">strike</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili </span>that he must give him <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">slapped </span>another on the cheek, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him two hundred dinars. </span>If he slapped him on the cheek with <span class="gemarra-regular">the back of his hand, </span>which is more degrading than a slap with the palm, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him four hundred dinars.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">he pulled his ear, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">pulled out his hair, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">spat </span>at him <span class="gemarra-regular">and his spittle reached him, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he removed </span>the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak from him, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he uncovered the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">head of a woman in the marketplace, </span>in all of these cases, he must <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">four hundred dinars. </span>

Daf 90b

<span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle </span>of assessing payment for humiliation caused to another: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>evaluated <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the honor of </span>the one who was humiliated, as the Gemara will explain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said: Even </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor among the Jewish people, they are viewed as though they were freemen who lost their property </span>and were impoverished. And their humiliation is calculated according to this status, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, </span>and are all of prominent lineage.
The mishna relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">And an incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving one who uncovered the head of a woman in the marketplace, </span>and the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Akiva </span>to request that he render the assailant liable to pay for the humiliation that she suffered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to give her four hundred dinars. </span>The man <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">My teacher, give me time </span>to pay the penalty, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">gave him time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The man then <span class="gemarra-regular">waited for her </span>until <span class="gemarra-regular">she was standing by the opening of her courtyard, and he broke a jug in front of her, and </span>there was the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">about an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">issa</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of oil inside </span>the jug. The woman then <span class="gemarra-regular">exposed her </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">head and she was wettin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">metapaḥat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>her hand in the oil, <span class="gemarra-regular">and placing her hand on her hea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to make use of the oil. 
The man <span class="gemarra-regular">set up witnesses </span>to observe <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>actions, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he came before Rabbi Akiva, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to him: Will I give four hundred dinars to this </span>woman for having uncovered her head? By uncovering her head for a minimal benefit, she has demonstrated that this does not cause her humiliation. 
Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You did not say anything, </span>i.e., this claim will not exempt you. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who injures himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> although it is not permitted for him </span>to do so, is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from any sort of penalty, but <span class="gemarra-regular">others who injured him </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay him. In this case as well, the man was liable to compensate the woman for shaming her, despite the fact that she did the same to herself. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who cuts </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">saplings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> although it is not permitted for him </span>to do so, as this violates the prohibition of: “You shall not destroy” (see Deuteronomy 20:19), is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from any penalty, but <span class="gemarra-regular">others </span>who cut down his saplings are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay him. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, one who strikes another must pay him one hundred dinars. The Gemara clarifies this opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Did <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>in the mishna that he must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>in the mishna that he must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>coinage, which is worth one-eighth of Tyrian coinage, i.e., twelve and a half dinars of Tyrian coinage?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof: It happened <span class="gemarra-regular">that there was a certain man who struck another </span>man, and the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yehuda Nesia </span>to request an assessment for the humiliation he suffered. Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the assailant: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is I, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Give him one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the incident that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna he must pay <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>it that it is so. 
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> did Rabbi Yehuda Nesia mean when he stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is I, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the assailant: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is I, who saw you </span>strike the man, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says </span>that the penalty for this act is <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage; therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give him one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage, <span class="gemarra-regular">is this to say that a witness can become a judge, </span>i.e., that one who witnessed an event can himself serve as a judge concerning the matter, and consequently Rabbi Yehuda Nesia was able to act as both witness and judge in the same case?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a Sanhedrin that saw one kill </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">person, some of them have become witnesses </span>and testify before the others, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some of them have become judges </span>to issue a verdict; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Tarfon. Rabbi Akiva says: They are all witnesses </span>to the act, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a witness cannot become a judge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara infers from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that even <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon says </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where some of </span>the members of the Sanhedrin <span class="gemarra-regular">have become witnesses and some of them have become judges, but he did not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a witness becomes a judge </span>without anyone else testifying. All the more so according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva would it not be permitted for Rabbi Yehuda Nesia to act as a judge as well as serving as a witness. 
The Gemara rejects this: One could say that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>it is taught in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the Sanhedrin <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>the murder <span class="gemarra-regular">at night</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> at which time <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">for them to practice judgment, </span>since cases of capital law may be judged only during the daytime. They were therefore not functioning as judges at that time. On the following day, testimony must be heard from some, now acting as witnesses, in front of the others, now acting as judges. By contrast, in the case of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia, he was able to serve as both the witness and the judge, as he witnessed the event while functioning as a judge. 
The Gemara offers an alternative explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say</span> instead that Rabbi Yehuda Nesia did not witness the incident, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the assailant: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is I, that I hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage must be paid; <span class="gemarra-regular">and these are witnesses who testify concerning you </span>that you struck the other. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give him one hundred dinars </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tyrian </span>coinage. 
§ The Gemara discusses the previously mentioned opinion of Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does Rabbi Akiva hold that a witness cannot become a judge?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 12:3) with regard to what is stated in the Torah concerning injuries: “And if men contend, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one smite the other with a stone, or with his fist” </span>(Exodus 21:18), that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon HaTimni says: Just as a fist is unique </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is submitted to the assembly </span>of judges to assess its ability to injure <span class="gemarra-regular">and to the witnesses </span>who attest that it was the fist used to strike, as a fist remains attached to the assailant, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>a ruling can be issued in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that is submitted to the assembly </span>of judges to assess its ability to injure <span class="gemarra-regular">and to the witnesses </span>who attest that this was the item used to strike? This serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the stone that injured <span class="gemarra-regular">left the possession of the witnesses </span>and is not available to be inspected by the court to assess if it is capable of causing the purported injury.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to him: But </span>is it the case that in all incidents of injury the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">struck him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the presence of the court, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that they know </span>exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>hard <span class="gemarra-regular">he struck him and on what </span>part of the body <span class="gemarra-regular">he struck him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he struck him <span class="gemarra-regular">on his thigh </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he struck him on <span class="gemarra-regular">the lobe of his heart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rather, the court relies on witnesses to testify about the injury. Therefore, the witnesses should be able to testify about the item used as well. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>was one <span class="gemarra-regular">who pushed another from the top of the roof or from the top of a building, and </span>the one who was pushed <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>as a result of the fall, do the members of <span class="gemarra-regular">the court go to the building </span>to inspect how high it is, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>does the <span class="gemarra-regular">building go to the court? </span>Obviously neither, and the court relies upon the testimony of witnesses who state how tall the building is. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the building <span class="gemarra-regular">collapsed, </span>must the court <span class="gemarra-regular">rebuild it </span>in order to assess its height? The witnesses should then be able to testify about the item used as well. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Akiva interprets the verse differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as a fist is unique </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is submitted to the witnesses </span>for them to testify about it, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>a ruling can be issued in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that is submitted to the witnesses </span>to testify about, despite the item’s not being available for the court to assess. 
This serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stone </span>that injured <span class="gemarra-regular">left the possession of the assailant </span>and cannot be found, and even the witnesses were unable to see it. In such a case the assailant is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment, since even the witnesses cannot testify about whether the stone was capable of inflicting the purported injuries.
The Gemara states its question: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to </span>Shimon HaTimni: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are </span>all cases of injury such that the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">struck him in the presence of the court </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that they know </span>exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>hard <span class="gemarra-regular">he struck him?</span> It can be inferred from this <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">strike him in front of them, </span>Rabbi Akiva would agree that <span class="gemarra-regular">a witness can become a judge. </span>This contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Akiva in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that a witness cannot become a judge.
The Gemara answers that there is no proof as to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, since it may be that he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>his refutation <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Shimon HaTimni, but he himself does not hold accordingly. </span>Perhaps Rabbi Akiva himself holds that if the court had witnessed the act, they would not be able to render judgment concerning it.
The Gemara quotes a related <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous ox that killed </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently went and <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">judges it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law </span>and the ox is killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not judge it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> despite the damage that it caused. 
By contrast, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">that killed </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently went and <span class="gemarra-regular">caused damage, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">judges it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law, </span>and the owner is liable to pay for the damage it caused, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the court <span class="gemarra-regular">goes back and judges it </span>again as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law, </span>and the ox is killed. But if the court <span class="gemarra-regular">proceeded and judged it </span>first as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not go back and judge it </span>again as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law, </span>since it has already been sentenced to be killed. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if they proceeded and judged it </span>first as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law, what of it? Let them go back and judge it </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>law.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: I found the Sages of the school of Rav who were sitting and saying </span>to explain this: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this? It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon HaTimni, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a fist is unique </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is submitted to the assembly </span>of judges to assess its ability to injure <span class="gemarra-regular">and to the witnesses </span>to attest that this was the fist used to strike, so too, a ruling can be issued in the case of any item that is submitted to the assembly of judges to assess its ability to injure and to the witnesses to attest that this was the item used to strike. 

Daf 91a

Rava continues the report in their name: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, we require the evaluation of the court </span>in order to render him liable to pay for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ox that killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">once the verdict </span>was given that it to be put <span class="gemarra-regular">to death, we do not delay </span>the implementation of the verdict in order to wait <span class="gemarra-regular">for the evaluation of the court, and we do not delay its judgment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the monetary case is not judged. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And I, </span>Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the Sages of the school of Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>who does not require assessment by the court, one could explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">fled</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the court cannot judge his case in his absence and cannot render him liable to pay for the damage caused by his ox. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case where the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">fled, </span>then in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">judge i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law, how does </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">judge it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law without </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the ox being present? The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>in the presence of the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fled.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, from where </span>are the damages <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>in a situation where the owner fled, as he is not here to pay the damages? The Gemara answers: They are paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from plowing. </span>The ox is rented out to plow fields, and the fees generated are used to pay the damages. Afterward, the ox is judged for the killing as a case of capital law. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an innocuous </span>ox, why did the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rule that the court does not judge it as a case of monetary law? The court <span class="gemarra-regular">should judge it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law first, and </span>the damages <span class="gemarra-regular">will be paid from </span>fees generated from renting out the animal for <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing, and then </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">should judge it </span>as a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital law.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said </span>in answer to this last question: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is to say </span>that the money gained from <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is </span>considered like the <span class="gemarra-regular">superior-quality </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of its owner. </span>In other words, that money is like the rest of the owner’s estate, and is not considered to be part of the value of the ox itself. Since payment for damage caused by an innocuous ox is taken only from the value of the ox itself, it follows that money received from renting out the ox to plow cannot be used to pay damages.
§ In connection with the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the court must assess whether the death can be attributed directly to the action of the assailant, the Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there an evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage </span>as well, to determine whether the act was sufficient to inflict that damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is there <span class="gemarra-regular">no evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage? </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that specifically in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of killing is where we perform an evaluation? </span>The assessment is to determine whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a soul departs with this </span>assault and the assailant will be held liable or whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a soul doesn’t depart with this </span>assault and the death is attributed to other factors. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>perhaps we say that he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever </span>caused the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>between the two, and with regard to damage as well, the court evaluates whether the act was sufficient to inflict that damage, and if it was not, he will be exempt. 
The Gemara says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what was taught in a mishna (50b) concerning the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a pit: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as a pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that has sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death </span>when falling into it is at least <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, any </span>other excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">that have sufficient </span>depth <span class="gemarra-regular">to cause death</span> may be no less than <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths. </span>If any of the types of excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">were less than ten handbreadths </span>deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an ox or a donkey fell into </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them and died, </span>the digger of the excavation is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>But if it <span class="gemarra-regular">was injured in it </span>but did not die he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay damages.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>the case that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is counting </span>the handbreadths from <span class="gemarra-regular">below to above, and this </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: From </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth </span>deep <span class="gemarra-regular">until ten </span>handbreadths deep, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage? Apparently, with regard to damage </span>he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever </span>caused the damage, even a fall into an excavation having the depth of one handbreadth. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the mishna that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>perform <span class="gemarra-regular">an evaluation with regard to damage. </span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is counting</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from above to below, and this </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If the excavation is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths deep then <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>If the excavation is <span class="gemarra-regular">slightly less than ten, there is </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">death. And actually, I will say to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage, and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every </span>circumstance, <span class="gemarra-regular">we require that </span>there be conditions <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby </span>the injured party <span class="gemarra-regular">could </span>reasonably <span class="gemarra-regular">be damaged by </span>whatever caused the damage.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:26): If a slave owner <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>his Canaanite slave <span class="gemarra-regular">on his ey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and blinded him, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">on his ear and deafened him, the slave is emancipated by means of these </span>wounds. If he struck <span class="gemarra-regular">near his eye and </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not see, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">near his ear and he does not hear, the slave is not emancipated by means of these </span>wounds. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the slave is not emancipated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that we require an evaluation </span>of the damage, and in such a case the assumption is that the owner’s action did not suffice to cause the injury? <span class="gemarra-regular">And learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage. </span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>the slave is not emancipated, <span class="gemarra-regular">because we say </span>that it is possible that it was the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">who frightened himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> resulting in his blindness or deafness, but it was not the actual strike that caused it. An injury can result from being frightened, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 6:16): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who frightens anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and thereby causes him injury is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. How so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one shouted into </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ear and deafened him, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he held him and shouted into his ea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and deafened him, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>according to human laws as well, as he physically took hold of him.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:3): With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">five types of indemnity </span>that one who injures another must pay, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluates </span>the victim as to the value of the damage that he suffered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>this payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to him immediately. </span>Payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">medical costs and loss of livelihood</span> is evaluated from the moment of injury <span class="gemarra-regular">until he is healed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">evaluated </span>that a certain sum would be needed to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>medical costs and loss of livelihood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently the victim’s condition began <span class="gemarra-regular">progressively deterioratin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> and the sum proved to be inadequate, <span class="gemarra-regular">they give him </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">only as they had evaluated him. </span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If <span class="gemarra-regular">they evaluated him </span>as requiring a certain sum for medical costs and loss of livelihood <span class="gemarra-regular">and he healed </span>sooner than expected, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>sum <span class="gemarra-regular">as they had evaluated him. Learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to evaluating </span>an injured <span class="gemarra-regular">man </span>to determine <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>long <span class="gemarra-regular">he will suffer from this injury </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>long <span class="gemarra-regular">he will not suffer, we do not raise a dilemma, </span>since it is obvious <span class="gemarra-regular">that we certainly evaluate </span>this element. <span class="gemarra-regular">When we raise the dilemma </span>of whether the court performs an evaluation or not, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to evaluating an item, </span>i.e., determining <span class="gemarra-regular">if it </span>is capable of <span class="gemarra-regular">causing this damage or </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>capable of causing this damage. With regard to this issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta,</span> <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 12:3): <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon HaTimni says: Just as a fist is unique </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is submitted to the assembly </span>of judges to assess its ability to injure <span class="gemarra-regular">and to the witnesses </span>who attest that this was the fist used to strike, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>a ruling can be issued in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that is submitted to the assembly </span>of judges to identify its ability to injure <span class="gemarra-regular">and to the witnesses </span>who attest that this was the item used to strike. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an evaluation </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>above: If <span class="gemarra-regular">they evaluated him </span>as requiring a certain sum for medical costs and loss of livelihood <span class="gemarra-regular">and he healed </span>sooner than expected, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>sum <span class="gemarra-regular">as they had evaluated him. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, as Rava said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this man whom they evaluated, </span>concluding that he would not be able to perform labor <span class="gemarra-regular">for the entire day, and </span>his wounds <span class="gemarra-regular">healed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’itpaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at midday and he was performing labor, we give him </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for the entire day. </span>The injury was one that would generally cause a man to not be able to perform labor for an entire day, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it was from Heaven that they had compassion on him </span>and healed him sooner. This does not affect the liability of the one who caused the damage.
§ The mishna teaches (90a): If he <span class="gemarra-regular">spat </span>at him <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">spittle reached him, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he removed </span>another’s cloak, he must give the injured party four hundred dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where the spittle reached <span class="gemarra-regular">him. But </span>if the spittle landed <span class="gemarra-regular">on his clothing </span>without touching him, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to pay him. The Gemara asks: Why not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let it be like </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliated </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with words. </span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">they say in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Avin: That is to say </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he humiliated </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with words </span>alone, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">anything, </span>although he will be held accountable by Heaven for his sin.
The mishna teaches with regard to the assessment of payment for humiliation: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>assessed <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">honor of </span>the one who was humiliated. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Does <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as a leniency, or </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">he say </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as a stringency? </span>The Gemara explains the two possibilities: <span class="gemarra-regular">He says </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as a leniency, </span>teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is a poor </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">who doesn’t need to take so much </span>payment for humiliation, as detailed in the fixed sums of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he says </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as a stringency, </span>teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is a rich </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to give him more </span>than those fixed sums. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor of the Jewish people, they are viewed as though they were freemen who lost their property </span>and were impoverished, and their humiliation is calculated according to this status, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they are the sons of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, </span>and are all of prominent lineage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>Rabbi Akiva’s statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">as a leniency</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that while the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> states the principle that payment for humiliation is in accordance with the honor of the one who was humiliated, and therefore a poor person will receive less than the fixed sums listed in the mishna, Rabbi Akiva responds that even a poor man is deserving of those fixed sums by virtue of his esteemed lineage. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that this is so.
§ The mishna relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving one who uncovered the head of a woman </span>in the marketplace. The woman came before Rabbi Akiva to request that he assess payment for the humiliation that she suffered, and Rabbi Akiva obligated the assailant to give her four hundred dinars. The man said to Rabbi Akiva: My teacher, give me time to pay the penalty, and Rabbi Akiva gave him time. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But do we give time </span>for an assailant to pay compensation? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥanina say: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>to provide payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for injuries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he must pay compensation immediately. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we do not give him time </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation </span>it is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to injury, as he caused a monetary loss </span>by inflicting physical damage on the victim. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to humiliation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where he did not cause him a monetary loss, we do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> give </span>him time to pay compensation.
The mishna relates that the man then <span class="gemarra-regular">waited for her </span>until <span class="gemarra-regular">she was standing by the opening of her courtyard, </span>and caused her to uncover her own head. Rabbi Akiva said that although she caused injury to herself, which is not permitted, this does not negate the man’s requirement to pay her compensation. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to him: You plunged into mighty water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and you raised </span>nothing more than worthless <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware in your hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted for a person to injure himself. </span>This contradicts the mishna’s account of Rabbi Akiva’s opinion. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the mishna, where it states that one may not injure himself, it is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>inflicting actual physical <span class="gemarra-regular">injury, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where it states that it is permitted for one to injure himself, it is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation </span>to oneself. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the ruling of Rabbi Akiva in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>causing <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, </span>

Daf 91b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and it teaches: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who injures himself, although it is not permitted for him </span>to do so, he is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from any sort of penalty, indicating that the prohibition is in effect even with regard to humiliation. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the man: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not necessary </span>to say with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">humiliation, where it is permitted for a person to humiliate himself, </span>that someone else who humiliated him is liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But even </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">injury</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where it is not permitted for a person to injure himself, others who injured him are liable.</span>
§ The Gemara discusses whether it is permitted to injure oneself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And is a person not permitted to injure himself? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath to do evil to himself and did not do evil he will be exempt </span>from bringing an offering for having transgressed this oath. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: </span>“Or if anyone swear clearly with his lips <span class="gemarra-regular">to do evil or to do good” </span>(Leviticus 5:4), which teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>taking an oath to <span class="gemarra-regular">do good </span>for which one is liable is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an optional </span>activity, as opposed to taking an oath to perform a mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>taking an oath to <span class="gemarra-regular">do evil </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">optional </span>activity, as opposed to taking an oath to transgress. <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>can therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">include </span>within the category of one who is liable if he transgressed his oath the person who <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath to do evi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to himself and did not do evil</span>. It is clear from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that doing evil to oneself is permitted.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not referring to one who takes an oath to injure himself but is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who takes an oath stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will sit in </span>observance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fast, </span>which it is permitted to do. 
Earlier in this same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it states that one who takes an oath to do evil to others is not liable for violating his oath if he does not do evil, as it is prohibited to do evil to others. If the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to one who takes an oath to fast, then <span class="gemarra-regular">in the corresponding </span>situation <span class="gemarra-regular">in the context of doing evil to others, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must also then be referring to one who takes an oath <span class="gemarra-regular">to have </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">sit in </span>observance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fast. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Can </span>one compel <span class="gemarra-regular">others </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">sit in </span>observance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fast? </span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes; </span>it is possible, as by preventing others from accessing food he can impose a fast on them, e.g., in a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he confined them in a room. </span>
The Gemara questions the assertion that this is the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>considered taking an oath to <span class="gemarra-regular">do evil </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">others? </span>It is considered such if one takes an oath stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will strike so-and-so and I will injure his brain. </span>Accordingly, in the corresponding situation of doing evil to oneself it is necessary to explain that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to causing injury as well, and the inference that this is permitted remains. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as there is </span>a <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not permitted for a person to injure himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there is </span>a <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted for a person to injure himself.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that you heard that says: It is not permitted for a person to injure himself? If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And surely your blood of your souls will I require” </span>(Genesis 9:5), and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: From the hand of your souls, </span>i.e., from yourself, <span class="gemarra-regular">will I requir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your blood, </span>meaning one is liable even for taking his own life, that is not a correct inference.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps killing is different. </span>While Rabbi Elazar holds that it is prohibited to take one’s own life, it cannot be inferred from here that he holds that one is liable for injuring himself. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may ren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> garments in anguish <span class="gemarra-regular">over one who died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">of the ways of the Amorites, </span>but a Jewish custom. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: I heard that one who rends </span>his garments <span class="gemarra-regular">excessivel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over one who died is flogged for </span>having transgressed the prohibition of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not destroy </span>(see Deuteronomy 20:19). The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And all the more so </span>it is the case that according to Rabbi Elazar one who injures <span class="gemarra-regular">his body </span>in anguish transgresses this prohibition. 
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps garments are different, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>tearing them <span class="gemarra-regular">is a loss that is irreversible, like that </span>practice <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>who would <span class="gemarra-regular">refer to his garments as: My honor, and </span>like that practice of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, </span>who, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he would walk among thorns and shrubs, </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">raise his clothing </span>despite the fact that his skin would get scratched by the thorns. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said </span>in explanation of his actions: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>flesh <span class="gemarra-regular">will heal </span>if scratched, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that </span>garment <span class="gemarra-regular">will not heal </span>if torn. Similarly, perhaps it is prohibited to rend one’s garments, but it is permitted to injure oneself. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar HaKappar the Distinguished said: What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to a nazirite: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall atone for him for sinning by the soul” </span>(Numbers 6:11)? <span class="gemarra-regular">And with which soul did this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">sin </span>by becoming a nazirite? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he afflicted himself </span>by abstaining <span class="gemarra-regular">from win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> he is considered to have sinned with his own soul, and he must bring a sin-offering for the naziriteship itself, for causing his body to suffer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And are </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">matters not </span>inferred <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: And just as this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who afflicted himself </span>by abstaining <span class="gemarra-regular">only from wine is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">called a sinner, one who afflicts himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> by abstaining <span class="gemarra-regular">from everything</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> through fasting or other acts of mortification, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>is he described as a sinner? Consequently, Rabbi Elazar HaKappar holds that one may not harm himself in any manner.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who cuts </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">saplings, </span>although it is not permitted for him to do so, is exempt from payment. Nevertheless, others who cut down his saplings are liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav:</span> If one charged another: <span class="gemarra-regular">You killed my ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You cut </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">my saplings, </span>and you are liable to pay for them, and the other responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">You told me to kill </span>the ox, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You told me to cut </span>down the saplings, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, you let no creature exist. Is it in his </span>power to assert that because the other instructed him to cause damage he is exempt? With this claim, anyone who causes damage can exempt himself.
Rabba bar bar Ḥana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall I erase this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> from the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> that I teach? Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">interpret </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an ox that is ready to be killed, </span>e.g., it had gored, and the owner decided to have it killed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a tree that is ready to be cu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> down for whatever reason, e.g., it was worshipped as part of an idolatrous rite or it is situated in a manner that poses a danger to the public. In such a case there is reason to believe that he was in fact instructed to cut it down. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>that the owner of the ox or tree acknowledges that it would be killed or cut down in any event, <span class="gemarra-regular">what claim is he stating to him, </span>as there was no loss resulting from the action of the other? The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him: I desire to perform this mitzva </span>of removing a danger or destroying idolatry by myself, and therefore I am demanding payment from you for having prevented me from doing so.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states with regard to one who slaughters an undomesticated animal or a bird: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall pour </span>out the blood thereof, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he shall cover </span>it with dust” (Leviticus 17:13). This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who poured </span>the blood, i.e., the one who slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall cove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">An incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving one who slaughtered </span>an undomesticated animal or bird, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another preempted </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">and covered </span>the blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Gamliel deemed him liable to give ten golden coin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the one who slaughtered the animal, as he prevented him from performing the mitzva. 
§ In connection with the prohibition against cutting down trees the Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree that </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">produces </span>fruit in the amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to cut it </span>down due to the prohibition of: “When you shall besiege a city…you shall not destroy the trees” (Deuteronomy 20:19). 
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the statement of Rav from what was taught in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 4:10): <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>fruit must <span class="gemarra-regular">be on an olive tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so </span>that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut it </span>down? <span class="gemarra-regular">A quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span>. Why did Rav say that it must produce a full <span class="it-text">kav</span>? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Olive trees are different, since they are significant. </span>Therefore, even a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> is valuable. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina said: My son Shivḥa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not di</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for any reason <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>than <span class="gemarra-regular">that he cut </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">a fig tree before its time. Ravina says: But if </span>the lumber <span class="gemarra-regular">was greate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in monetary </span>value than its fruits, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to chop it down, and this does not violate the prohibition against destroying a tree.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The verse states: “Only the trees of which you know that they are not trees for food, them you may destroy and cut down” (Deuteronomy 20:20). <span class="gemarra-regular">“Only the trees of which you know”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree </span>that bears fruit used for <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>and it is permitted to cut down this type of tree under certain circumstances. <span class="gemarra-regular">“That they are not trees for food”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a barren tree. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">will ultimately include all types</span> of trees, so that even a tree that produces fruit may be cut down, <span class="gemarra-regular">what, </span>then, is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “That </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not trees for food,” </span>which indicates that it is permitted to cut down only a barren tree? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to give precedence </span>to cutting down <span class="gemarra-regular">a barren </span>tree <span class="gemarra-regular">over</span> a tree whose fruit is used for <span class="gemarra-regular">food. </span>

Daf 92a

One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that he must give precedence to the cutting down of a barren tree <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the barren tree is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater in monetary </span>value than the fruit-bearing tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> states: “Only,” </span>which teaches that there is an exception to the rule. Similarly, if the fruit-bearing tree itself would be worth more as lumber than for its fruits, it would be permitted for one to cut it down. 
The Gemara relates: The <span class="gemarra-regular">sharecropper of Shmuel brought him dates. </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>them, and <span class="gemarra-regular">tasted the taste of wine in them. He said to </span>his sharecropper: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is this? </span>The sharecropper <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The date palms <span class="gemarra-regular">stand among the grapevines </span>and therefore contain a taste of wine from the grapes. Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">they weaken the wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the grapevines, <span class="gemarra-regular">so much </span>that it is possible to taste the wine in the dates? <span class="gemarra-regular">Tomorrow, </span>cut down the date palms and <span class="gemarra-regular">bring me from their marro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> to eat. 
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda saw date palms </span>growing <span class="gemarra-regular">among grapevines </span>on his estate. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to his sharecropper: Uproot the </span>date palms, since one can <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase date palms </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">grapevines</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as grapevines are more valuable, while one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot purchase grapevines </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">date palms. </span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Despite </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the assailant who caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">gives to </span>the victim all of the required payments for the injury, his transgression is <span class="gemarra-regular">not forgiven for him </span>in the heavenly court <span class="gemarra-regular">until he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">request</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> forgiveness <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>that God told Abimelech after he had taken Sarah from Abraham: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Now therefore restore the wife </span>of the man; for he is a prophet, and he shall pray for you, and you shall live” (Genesis 20:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where</span> is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forgiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">him that he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cruel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “And Abraham prayed to God; and God healed Abimelech, </span>and his wife, and his maidservants; and they bore children” (Genesis 20:17).
The mishna continues: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Blind my eye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or: <span class="gemarra-regular">cut off my hand, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">break my leg, </span>and he does so, the one who performed these actions is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage, despite having been instructed to do so. Even if he explicitly instructed him: Do so <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>you will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment, he is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
With regard to one who says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Tear my garment, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">break my jug, </span>and he does so, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage. But if he instructed him explicitly: Do so <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>you will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment. If one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do so, </span>i.e., cause damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-s</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the condition that </span>you will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment, and he did so, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, whether </span>the instructions were <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">himself, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the instructions were <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his property. </span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: All these </span>sums <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in the previous mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>one is liable to pay for humiliating another are the <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for his humiliation, </span>for which there is a set amount. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>for the victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> caused by the assailant, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the assailant <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>as offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">all the rams of Nebaioth </span>(see Isaiah 60:7) <span class="gemarra-regular">that are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the world, </span>which are of the best quality, his transgression <span class="gemarra-regular">is not forgiven for him </span>in the heavenly court <span class="gemarra-regular">until he requests </span>forgiveness <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Restore the wife of the man; for he is a prophet, and he shall pray for you”</span> (Genesis 20:7).
Having quoted the verse, the Gemara asks: Shall one infer from here <span class="gemarra-regular">that the wife of a prophet needs to be returned, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the wife of another </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">need not be returned? </span>
The Gemara answers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: </span>This is how the verse should be understood: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Restore the wife of the man” in any case, </span>since she is his wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to that <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you, </span>Abimelech, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: “Will you slay even a righteous nation? Did he not say himself to me: She is my sister, and she, even she herself, said: He is my brother?” </span>(Genesis 20:4–5), the answer is that you, Abimelech, are not so righteous, since the reason Abraham said that Sarah was his sister is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is a prophet, and he already learne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> how to conduct himself based on your behavior. As with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a guest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akhsenai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who comes to town, does one ask him about matters concerning eating and drinking, or does one ask him about matters concerning his wife? </span>Does one ask a guest: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is she your wife? Is she your sister? </span>Abimelech was to be blamed, since Abraham thought that he intended to steal his wife.
The Gemara remarks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From here </span>it can be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is executed </span>for having transgressed a prohibition without awareness that the act was prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he should have learne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he did not learn.</span>
Having mentioned the verses concerning the incident of Abraham and Abimelech, the Gemara explains other related verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">“For the Lord had obstructe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atzor</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">atzar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>all the wombs of the house of Abimelech” (Genesis 20:18). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Why </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">these two obstructions [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atzor</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">atzar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>both stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a man, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">semen </span>will not be discharged, and <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a woman, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">semen </span>will not be discharged from her, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that she will not give <span class="gemarra-regular">birth.</span>
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Two </span>are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a man: Semen and urine, </span>i.e., that the men were unable to both urinate and discharge semen; <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a woman: Semen, and urine, and birth.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: Three </span>are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a man: Semen, and urine, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">anal sphincter, </span>i.e., that they were unable to discharge stool as well. Consequently, they would be unable to relieve themselves at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Four </span>are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a woman: Semen, and birth, and urine, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">anal sphincter.</span>
The verse states: “For the Lord had obstructed <span class="gemarra-regular">all the wombs</span> of the house of Abimelech.” The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Rabbi Yannai say: Even a hen of the house of Abimelech did not lay her egg </span>during that time.
§ The Gemara cites a series of questions that Rava asked Rabba bar Mari, the first one being related to the previous topic of discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages stated: Anyone who asks </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">compassion </span>from Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>behalf of <span class="gemarra-regular">another, and he requires </span>compassion from Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning that same matter, he is answered first? </span>Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And the Lord changed the fortune of Job, when he prayed for his friends” </span>(Job 42:10).
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You said </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from a verse in the Writings, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from a verse in the Torah. As it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Abraham prayed to God; and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maidservants, </span>and they bore children” (Genesis 20:17), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written </span>immediately following that: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Lord remembered Sarah, as He had said” </span>(Genesis 21:1), with the pronoun interpreted homiletically: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Abraham sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to Abimelech. </span>Because Abraham prayed for Abimelech that the women of his household should give birth, Abraham himself was answered concerning that matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The cabbage is damaged together with the thorn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the cabbage is sometimes harmed when the thorn is removed? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “Why will you contend with Me?
