You all have transgressed against Me, says the Lord” </span>(Jeremiah 2:29). The term “you all” includes even those who have not sinned.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You said </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from a verse in the Prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from a verse in the Torah. The Lord said to Moses after some of the people collected the manna on Shabbat: <span class="gemarra-regular">“How long do you refuse [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">me’antem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to keep My commandments and My laws?” </span>(Exodus 16:28). The term “you refuse [<span class="it-text">me’antem</span>]” is written in the plural, indicating that even Moses was included, although he did not sin.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: It is written </span>with regard to Joseph: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And from among his brothers he took five men, </span>and presented them to Pharaoh” (Genesis 47:2). <span class="gemarra-regular">Who are these fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> men? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Those whose names were repeate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the blessings with which Moses later blessed the twelve tribes. They are Dan, Zebulun, Gad, Asher, and Naftali (see Deuteronomy 35). Since they were weak, Joseph brought them before Pharaoh. 
Rava said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Judah also </span>had his name <span class="gemarra-regular">repeated </span>in the blessings, and he was strong.
Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: His </span>name <span class="gemarra-regular">was repeated for his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, as Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan said: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written </span>concerning Reuben and Judah in Moses’ blessing of the tribes at the end of his life: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Let Reuben live and not die in that his men become few” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:6), and immediately afterward in the following verse it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And this for Judah, </span>and he said: Hear Lord, the voice of Judah, and bring him in unto his people; may his hands fight on his behalf, and You shall be a help against his adversaries” (Deuteronomy 33:7)? What is the connection between the blessing of Reuben and that of Judah, juxtaposed with the conjunction “and”?
Rabbi Yoḥanan said: <span class="gemarra-regular">All those forty years that the Jewish people were in the desert, the bones of Judah, </span>which the Jewish people took with them from Egypt along with the bones of his brothers, <span class="gemarra-regular">were rollin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> around <span class="gemarra-regular">in the coffin, until Moses came and asked for mercy </span>on Judah’s behalf. Moses <span class="gemarra-regular">said before </span>God: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of the Universe, who </span>served as the <span class="gemarra-regular">impetus for Reuben that he should confess </span>his sin, through which he merited a blessing and was not excluded from the count of the twelve sons of Jacob (see Genesis 35:22)? It was <span class="gemarra-regular">Judah, </span>as Reuben saw him confess his sin, and thereby did the same. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Immediately </span>after Moses prayed, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Hear, Lord, the voice of Judah” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">His bones </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">entered </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">sockets [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leshafa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and his skeleton became attached. The angels still <span class="gemarra-regular">did not elevate </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">into the heavenly study hall. </span>Moses then prayed: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And bring him in unto his people”</span> (Deuteronomy 33:7), i.e., bring him to those in the heavenly study hall. This prayer was accepted, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">did not kno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what the sages were saying, and </span>he was unable <span class="gemarra-regular">to deliberate </span>in Torah matters <span class="gemarra-regular">with the sages. </span>Moses then prayed: <span class="gemarra-regular">“May his hands fight on his behalf” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:7), meaning that he should have the ability to contend with them in study. But still <span class="gemarra-regular">he was unable to draw </span>conclusions from <span class="gemarra-regular">his discussion in accordance with the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Moses then prayed: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And You shall be a help against his adversaries” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:7).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Poverty follows the poor? </span>Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> 3:8): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rich </span>people would <span class="gemarra-regular">bring first fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in baskets of gold and of silver, and poor </span>people would bring first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">in wicker baskets </span>made <span class="gemarra-regular">of peeled willow, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">they would give the baskets and the first fruits to the priests. </span>The rich would have their baskets returned to them, while the poor would not. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You said </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from a mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from a verse in the Torah: 

Daf 92b

The verse states with regard to one diagnosed with leprosy: “And the leper in whom the plague is, his clothes shall be rent, and the hair of his head shall go loose, and he shall cover his upper lip, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he shall cry: Unclean, unclean” </span>(Leviticus 13:45). Not only must the leper suffer from the leprosy itself; he must undergo further embarrassment by publicizing his condition. This is akin to the aphorism that poverty follows the poor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby the Sages stated: Awaken early and eat, in the summer due to the heat and in the winter due to the cold. And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">people say: Sixty runners run and do not reach the man who ate in the morning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabba bar Mari said to him that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “They shall not hunger nor thirst, neither shall the heat nor the sun smite them” </span>(Isaiah 49:10), indicating that one who is not hungry or thirsty will not be affected by the weather. 
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You said </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from a verse in the Prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from a verse in the Torah. The verse states: “And you shall serve the Lord your God, and He will bless your bread and your water; and I will take sickness away from the midst of you” (Exodus 23:25). Rava explicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall serve the Lord your God”; this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">recitation of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shema</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and prayer. “And He will bless your bread and your water”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>dipped <span class="gemarra-regular">in salt, and a flask of water </span>drunk after the bread, in the mornings. <span class="gemarra-regular">From this</span> point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward </span>the remainder of the verse applies: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And I will take sickness away from the midst of you.”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Sickness”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">bile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And why is its name called sickness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">maḥala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]? </span>It is called this <span class="gemarra-regular">since there are eighty-three sicknesses in </span>bile. The letters spelling the word <span class="gemarra-italic">maḥala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., <span class="it-text">mem</span>, <span class="it-text">ḥet</span>, <span class="it-text">lamed</span>, <span class="it-text">heh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">have that numerical value </span>of eighty-three. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all of those </span>sicknesses, eating <span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>dipped <span class="gemarra-regular">in salt </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">morning and </span>drinking <span class="gemarra-regular">a flask of water </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">negates them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby the Sages stated: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">your friend calls you a donkey, prepare a saddle for your back</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., do not contest his statement? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>in the conversation between the angel and Hagar: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he said: Hagar, maidservant of Sarai, from where did you come and to where are you going? And she said: I am fleeing from the face of my mistress Sarai” </span>(Genesis 16:8). Though Hagar was no longer the maidservant of Sarai, since the angel referred to her as such, she responded in kind. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: </span>If you are aware of <span class="gemarra-regular">a derogatory matter that is </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">in you, say it first </span>before others say it about you? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to Eliezer: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he said: I am Abraham’s servant”</span> (Genesis 24:34), immediately proclaiming that he is a servant. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: The goose stoops </span>its head <span class="gemarra-regular">as it goe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> along, <span class="gemarra-regular">but its eyes </span>look <span class="gemarra-regular">afar</span> to find food for itself? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to Abigail’s statement to David: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And when the Lord shall have dealt well with my lord, then remember your maidservant” </span>(I Samuel 25:31). Although Abigail spoke with humility in her request that David spare her husband’s life, she made reference to deriving future benefit from David. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: Sixty discomforts come to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the teeth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lekhakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who hears the sound of another </span>eating <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not eat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to what Nathan the prophet said concerning the coronation banquet of Adonijah, to which he was not invited: “For he is gone down this day, and has slain oxen and fatlings and sheep in abundance, and has called all the king’s sons…<span class="gemarra-regular">But me, even me your servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and your servant Solomon he has not called” </span>(I Kings 1:25–26).
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You said </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from a verse in the Prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say </span>the proof <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from a verse in the Torah. As it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Isaac brought her into his mother Sarah’s tent, and took Rebekah, and she became his wife; and he loved her, and Isaac was comforted for his mother” </span>(Genesis 24:67). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward: “And Abraham took another wife, and her name was Keturah” </span>(Genesis 25:1). After seeing his son marry, Abraham was disquieted by the fact he was not married. This is akin to one who sees another eating and does not eat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: </span>While <span class="gemarra-regular">the wine </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner, the gratitude </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the one who pours it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to God commanding Moses to transfer his authority to Joshua: “And the Lord said unto Moses: Take you Joshua the son of Nun, a man in whom is spirit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and lay your hand upon him…that all the congregation of the children of Israel may hearken” </span>(Numbers 27:18–20). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “And Joshua the son of Nun was full of the spirit of wisdom; for Moses had laid his hands upon him; and the children of Israel hearkened unto him, </span>and did as the Lord commanded Moses” (Deuteronomy 34:9). Although the spirit of God was not given to Joshua by Moses, as Moses was only a conduit, he was given credit for it. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: A dog, in its hunger, swallows </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">dung</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabba bar Mari said to him that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“The full soul loathes a honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet” </span>(Proverbs 27:7).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: A bad palm tree strolls and goes </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among a grove of barren trees, </span>i.e., bad people seek out other bad people? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This matter is written in the Torah, repeated in the Prophets, and triplicated in the Writings, and we learned </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a mishna, and we learned </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
Rabba bar Mari explains each of the sources. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is written in the Torah, as it is written: “And so Esau went to Ishmael” </span>(Genesis 28:9). It <span class="gemarra-regular">is repeated in the Prophets, as it is written: “And there were gathered vain fellows to Yiftah, and they went out with him” </span>(Judges 11:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is triplicated in the Writings, as it is written: All fowl will live with its kind, and men with those like him </span>(Book of Ben Sira 13:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a mishna </span>(<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 12:2): <span class="gemarra-regular">All that is attached to </span>that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all that is attached to </span>that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure. And we learned </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Rabbi Eliezer says: Not for naught </span>did the <span class="gemarra-regular">starling go to the rave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but because it is its kind, </span>as it too is a non-kosher bird. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">you called </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">your frien</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he did not answer you, throw a large wall </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cast it at him, </span>i.e., do not attempt to help him anymore? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is as it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Because I have purged you and you were not purged, you shall not be purged from your impurity anymore, </span>until I have satisfied My fury upon you” (Ezekiel 24:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a well that you drank from, do not throw a stone into it? </span>Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “You shall not abhor an Edomite, for he is your brother; you shall not abhor an Egyptian, because you were a stranger in his land” </span>(Deuteronomy 23:8). Since you dwelled in their lands, you may not cause them harm. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: If you lift the load </span>with me <span class="gemarra-regular">I will lift </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span>you will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>lift it with me <span class="gemarra-regular">I won’t lift </span>it? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to Barak and Deborah concerning the war of Sisera: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Barak said to her: If you will go with me, then I will go; but if you will not go with me, I will not go” </span>(Judges 4:8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: When we were small, </span>we were considered <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">men; now that we are old, </span>we are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">children [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ledardekei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is that <span class="gemarra-regular">initially, it is written </span>with regard to the Jewish people traveling in the wilderness: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Lord went before them by day in a pillar of cloud, to lead them the way; and by night in a pillar of fire, to give them light” </span>(Exodus 13:21). God Himself guarded over the Jewish people. <span class="gemarra-regular">But at the end, </span>after some time passed and it would be expected that the Jewish people were considered more important, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: </span>

Daf 93a

<span class="gemarra-regular"> “Behold, I send an angel before you, to keep you by the way” </span>(Exodus 23:20), indicating that an angel was sent in place of God to guard the Jewish people. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: From where is this matter </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">whereby people say: Drag woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after a property owner. </span>In other words, help out a wealthy man even in a small way, as this may lead to your benefiting from him. Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And Lot also, who went with Abram, had flocks, and herds, and tents” </span>(Genesis 13:5).
§ In connection with the incident of Abraham and Abimelech mentioned in the mishna, the Gemara quotes a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanan says: One who passes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment of anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">is punished first, as it is stated: “And Sarai said to Abram: My wrong be upon you, </span>I gave my handmaid into your bosom; and when she saw that she had conceived, I was despised in her eyes: The Lord judge between me and you” (Genesis 16:5). Sarai stated that God should judge Abram for his actions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “And Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her” </span>(Genesis 23:2), as Sarah died first. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter applies </span>only in a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has </span>someone to do <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">on eart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> and has no need to appeal to the heavenly court.
Concerning this, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says: Woe to he who cries </span>out to Heaven <span class="gemarra-regular">more than the one about whom </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">crying </span>out. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>concept <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Both the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who crie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> out <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one about whom </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">crying </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">are included </span>in the verse discussing the cries of an orphan who is mistreated: “If you afflict them, for if they cry at all to Me, I will surely hear their cry. My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword” (Exodus 22:22–23). <span class="gemarra-regular">But they are quicker </span>to punish <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who cries </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">than the one about whom </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">crying </span>out, as in the incident with Sarai. 
The Gemara provides another lesson from the story of Abraham and Abimelech. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yitzḥak says: The curse of an ordinary person should never be </span>regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">light in your eyes, for Abimelech cursed Sarah and it was fulfilled in her descendant. </span>The curse on Sarah is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “Behold, it is to you a covering of the eyes” </span>(Genesis 20:16), meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to her: Since you concealed </span>your status <span class="gemarra-regular">from me and you did not reveal that </span>Abraham <span class="gemarra-regular">is your husband, and you caused me this suffering, may it be </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">will that you should have children with covered eyes. And </span>this curse <span class="gemarra-regular">was fulfilled in her descendant, as it is written: “And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, and his eyes were dim, so that he could not see” </span>(Genesis 27:1). 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says: A person should always be among those who are pursue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and not among the pursuers. </span>One can prove that this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as none among birds are pursue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more than doves and pigeons, </span>as all predators hunt them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>from all birds <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse deemed them fit to</span> be sacrificed on the <span class="gemarra-regular">altar. </span>
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Blind my eye, </span>or: Cut off my hand, or: Break my leg, and he does so, the latter is liable to pay for the damage, even if the injured party explicitly instructed him to do so on the condition that he will be exempt from payment. But if one instructs another to damage his property on the condition that he will be exempt from payment, he is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi bar Ḥama said to Rava: What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause and what is different</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause? </span>
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>he is liable, despite the fact that he was instructed to carry out the injury on the condition that he would be exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">because a person does not forgo </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage to his <span class="gemarra-regular">extremitie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> such as his eyes, hands, and feet, mentioned in the mishna (92a). Consequently, when he told the assailant that he would be exempt, the presumption is that he was not sincere. 
Rav Asi bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But does a person forgo </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for his pain </span>when he doesn’t lose a limb? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to one who said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Strike me, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">wound me, on the condition that </span>you will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>According to Rava’s reasoning, he should be liable in this case as well, as the presumption should be that he was not sincere. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">was silent, </span>as he did not have a response. 
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Have you heard anything with regard to this </span>matter? Rav Asi bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what Rav Sheshet said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>loss of a limb may result in <span class="gemarra-regular">a family flaw, </span>i.e., it may cause harm to the family name. One who loses a limb not only suffers pain; his family suffers as well. He is not in a position to forgive the assailant for the harm caused to his family, but he may forgo compensation for his own pain. Consequently, if he instructed another merely to injure him, without causing loss of limb, on condition that the assailant will be exempt from payment, the assailant will be exempt. 
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed concerning the explanation for the ruling of the first clause of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>loss of a limb may result in <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">family flaw. Rava says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because a person does not forgo </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage to <span class="gemarra-regular">his extremities.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is a yes that, </span>based on other factors, <span class="gemarra-regular">is like a no </span>and is not viewed as giving consent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a no that, </span>based on other factors, <span class="gemarra-regular">is like a yes, </span>and although one said no it is as though he gave consent. In this case as well, where he said: On condition to be exempt, he was not sincere. 
The Gemara comments that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. With regard to one who said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Strike me, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">wound me; </span>and the other asks: Is this <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>I will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the first one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him, </span>in the tone of a question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>this is an example of the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is a yes that is like a no. </span>It is as if the victim asked: Even if I give you permission to do it, do you think that I would forgo the compensation? By contrast, if one said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Tear my garment, </span>and the other asks: Is this <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>I will <span class="gemarra-regular">be exempt </span>from payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">And he said to him, </span>in the tone of a question: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, this </span>is an example of <span class="gemarra-regular">a no that is like a yes, </span>since he meant to say that if he did not want to exempt him from payment he would not ask him to do it. 
§ The mishna teaches that if one instructed another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Break my jug, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Tear my garment, </span>and the other did so, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verses state with regard to bailees: “If a man delivers to his neighbor money or vessels to safeguard” (Exodus 22:6), and: “If a man delivers to his neighbor an ass, or an ox, or a sheep, or any beast, to safeguard” (Exodus 22:9). The Sages derived from these verses that the bailee is liable if the item was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to safeguard, but not </span>where it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to destroy; </span>if it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to safeguard, but not </span>where it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to tear; </span>if it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to safeguard, but not </span>where it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to distribute to the poor. </span>This indicates that a bailee is not liable for damage to an item if he was told to tear it, even if the owner did not state that it is on condition to be exempt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>mishna that obligates him to pay for the damage is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it came into his possession, </span>and he was responsible for it before the owner instructed him to tear it. Therefore, even if he was instructed to tear it, he is liable. And <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which exempts him from paying, is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it did not come into his possession, </span>but he simply tore it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said to </span>Rav Huna: But the phrase in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“to safeguard,” </span>which obligates a bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates that it came into his possession </span>already, and this is the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that rules he is exempt. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba said: This and that </span>are discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it came into his possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it came into his possession as </span>an item given for <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding, </span>and he is exempt if the owner stated explicitly that this will be the case, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it came into his possession as </span>an item given for <span class="gemarra-regular">tearing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain purse </span>full <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> charity </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">that came to </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pumbedita. Rav Yosef deposited i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a certain man. </span>That man <span class="gemarra-regular">was negligent in </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">thieves came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">stole it. Rav Yosef deemed </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">To safeguard, but not </span>where it was given to him <span class="gemarra-regular">to distribute to the poor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> This seems to teach that with regard to money that is distributed to the poor, there is no <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of safeguarding.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The poor of Pumbedita </span>have an amount that is <span class="gemarra-regular">set for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to receive. Each poor person already had a specific sum designated for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>accordingly <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in the category of: <span class="gemarra-regular">To safeguard. </span>Therefore, he is liable.


Daf 93b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fashions it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, </span>or one who robs another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and fashions it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">garments, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value of the goods at the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of the robbery, </span>but he need not return the vessels or garments. He has acquired the stolen items because they had undergone a change.
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pregnant cow and it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth </span>while in his possession, or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ewe </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">laden </span>with wool <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the robber then <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared it, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of a cow that is ready to give birt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of a ewe that is ready to be shorn. </span>He pays the value of the animal at the time of the robbery, and the calf or the wool remains his.
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow, and it became pregnant in his </span>possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth; </span>or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ewe, and it became laden </span>with wool <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared it, </span>then the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays according to </span>the value of the animal at the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of the robbery. This is the principle: All robbers pay according to </span>the value of the stolen item at the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of the robbery.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>It can be inferred from the mishna that if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and fashioned it into vessels, yes, </span>the robber acquires the wood due to the change. If he merely <span class="gemarra-regular">sanded it, no, </span>the robber does not acquire it, as this is not a significant change. Similarly, if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and fashioned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">garments, yes, </span>he has acquired the wool due to the change. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">washed it, no, </span>he has not acquired it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and sanded it, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">stones and smoothed them, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and washed it, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">flax and cleaned it, he pays according to </span>the value of the stolen item at the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of the robbery. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that even a change such as sanding wood is regarded as a significant change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>This does not contradict the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic </span>law, which is not deemed significant by Torah law, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is reversible. And all the more so, </span>if the robber effects <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah </span>law, i.e., an irreversible change, he acquires the stolen item due to the change.
The Gemara explains: Accordingly, it must be that the case in the mishna, where the change is reversible, where one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and fashioned it into vessels, </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">sanded wood. And what are they? Boards </span>that the robber used to construct a vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is a change </span>in which the item <span class="gemarra-regular">can revert to its original state, as, if </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">desires, he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">disassemble them. </span>Similarly, the case of one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and fashioned it into garments </span>refers <span class="gemarra-regular">to wool </span>that was already <span class="gemarra-regular">spun, as </span>fashioning them into garments <span class="gemarra-regular">is a change </span>in which the item <span class="gemarra-regular">can revert to its original state, as, if </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">desires, he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">unravel them. </span>The mishna teaches that the robber acquires the stolen item by making these changes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and all the more so </span>the robber acquires the stolen item through <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law.</span>
Abaye continues his explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but he does not teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law. </span>It is possible that he maintains that the robber does not acquire the stolen item due to such a change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi stated </span>another answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also teaching </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>deemed significant <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law. </span>The case in the mishna of one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and fashioned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span>is referring to one who constructed <span class="gemarra-regular">pestles [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bukhanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span>analogous to the case mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> where <span class="gemarra-regular">one sanded them,</span> since a pestle is formed by trimming the wood in an irreversible manner. Similarly, the case in the mishna of one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and fashioned it into garments </span>is referring to one who fashioned the wool into pieces of <span class="gemarra-regular">felt [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">namtei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which is an irreversible change.</span>
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does washing </span>effect a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">change, </span>so that one who robs another of wool and washes it acquires the wool and pays its value at the time of robbery? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a mishna that discusses the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the first of the sheared wool, which one must give to a priest (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 135a): If the owner of the sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">did not manage to giv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the sheared wool <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">before he dyed it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from giving it to the priest, as the obligation is in effect only with regard to wool remaining in its original state. By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he washed it but did not dye it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to give it to the priest. This indicates that washing does not effect a significant change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the first of the sheared wool: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared it, spun it, and wove it, </span>the sheared wool <span class="gemarra-regular">does not combin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with the wool from other sheep to constitute the minimum quantity of wool for which one is obligated to give the first of the sheared wool to the priest. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">washed it, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not combine </span>with the wool of other sheep, as washing effects a significant change, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">combines </span>with the wool of other sheep, as washing does not effect a significant change. Their opinions correspond to the opinions in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and mishna previously quoted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava stated </span>another answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">This and that, </span>i.e., both the mishna and the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, are in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one untangled </span>the strands of wool by hand before washing it. In this case, the washing is not fully effective, and does not effect a significant change. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one combed it </span>before washing it. The washing is more effective and consequently effects a significant change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated </span>another answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one merely <span class="gemarra-regular">whitened it, </span>which is not a significant change. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one bleached i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with sulfur, which is a significant change.
Having demonstrated that, according to Rabbi Shimon, washing effects a significant change, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it can be said </span>that, according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Shimon, dye does not </span>effect a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">change, </span>as the Gemara will prove, can it be said that <span class="gemarra-regular">washing </span>effects a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">change? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared </span>sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one and dyed </span>the wool of each sheep before shearing the next sheep, or sheared them <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one and spun </span>the wool, or sheared them <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one and wove </span>the wool, then the wool sheared from the different sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">does not combine </span>to constitute the minimum quantity of wool for which one is obligated to give the first of the sheared wool to the priest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: </span>Even if he <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed it, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">combines </span>with the other wool. This indicates that, according to Rabbi Shimon, even dyeing the wool is not a significant change, so how could he maintain that washing it is?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>statement, that washed wool does not combine with other wool, is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement, that even dyed wool combines with other wool, is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon. </span>There is a dispute as to what Rabbi Shimon rules with regard to this issue.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, the Rabbis do not disagree with Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, </span>and they are also of the opinion that Rabbi Shimon holds that washing effects a significant change. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the apparent contradiction, <span class="gemarra-regular">dye is differen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and it does not effect a significant change, <span class="gemarra-regular">since one is able to remove it with soap [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzafon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and return the wool to its previous state. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when it is taught there, </span>in the mishna cited above, that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one did not manage to give </span>the sheared wool <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">before he dyed it he is exempt, and </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">was established in accordance with all opinions, </span>it was not stated with regard to ordinary dye but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> indigo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which cannot be removed </span>with soap and therefore effects a permanent and therefore significant change.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, and Beit Shammai, and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, and Rabbi Yishmael all hold </span>that despite <span class="gemarra-regular">a change, </span>the changed item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place, </span>i.e., the changed item is still considered to have the status it had before the change. The Gemara proceeds to prove that each of these <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> holds this way: The opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">said. </span>He says that, according to Rabbi Shimon, even if the wool is dyed it still combines with the wool of other animals to constitute the minimum quantity of wool for which one is obligated to give the first of the sheared wool to the priest.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the source that indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span> maintain that an item that undergoes a change is considered to have the same status that it had before the change? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>a prostitute <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat as her payment, and she </span>ground it and <span class="gemarra-regular">converted it into flour; </span>or if he gave her <span class="gemarra-regular">olives, and she </span>squeezed them and <span class="gemarra-regular">converted them into oil; </span>or if he gave her <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes, and she </span>squeezed them and <span class="gemarra-regular">converted them into wine; </span>and if, in any of these cases, she subsequently consecrated the final product, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to sacrifice them upon the altar as a meal-offering or libation, as the Torah states: “You shall not bring the hire of a harlot or the price of a dog into the House of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, </span>as the Gemara will explain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef says: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">Guryon</span>

Daf 94a

<span class="gemarra-regular">of Asporak: Beit Shammai prohibit </span>sacrificing these items <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>doing so. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason of Beit Shammai? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“You shall not bring the hire of a harlot or the price of a dog into the House of the Lord your God for any vow; for <span class="gemarra-regular">even both of these </span>are an abomination unto the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19). The word “even” is an amplification, which serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>in the prohibition these items in <span class="gemarra-regular">their changed </span>form. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what is the reason of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel? The verse states “these” </span>to emphasize that the prohibition applies only to these items in their initial form, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">their changed </span>form.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, isn’t </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“these” written </span>in the verse, indicating an exclusion? The Gemara responds: Beit Shammai <span class="gemarra-regular">requires that </span>word to indicate that <span class="gemarra-regular">“these” </span>items are forbidden, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring </span>of animals given as payment to the prostitute. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, </span>what is the source of that <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara answers: According to Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">you learn two </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from this</span> word, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“These” </span>items are forbidden in their initial form <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">their changed </span>form, and <span class="gemarra-regular">“these” </span>items are forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">but not their offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel as well, isn’t </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“even” written </span>in the verse, indicating an amplification? The Gemara answers: Indeed, the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“even” is difficult for Beit Hillel. </span>It is not clear how they would interpret that word.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the source that indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov </span>holds that an item that undergoes a change is still considered to have the same status that it had before the change?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: </span>In the case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of wheat, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">ground it, kneaded it, and baked it, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">separate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it, </span>i.e., he separated the portion of the dough that one is required to separate and then give to a priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>can he <span class="gemarra-regular">recite the blessing </span>over the separation of <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>individual is <span class="gemarra-regular">not reciting a blessing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">blaspheming</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And with regard to this it is stated: “The robber who recites a blessing blasphemes the Lord” </span>(Psalms 10:3), which is referring to a robber who recites a blessing upon performing a mitzva with an item he stole. According to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, although this wheat has been significantly changed, it is still considered a stolen item.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the source that indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar </span>holds that an item that undergoes a change is still considered to have the same status that it had before the change? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:2) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated this principle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any enhancement </span>to the stolen animal in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was enhanced </span>by the actions of the <span class="gemarra-regular">robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has the advantage </span>when repaying the owner. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he desires, he takes his enhancement, </span>i.e., when he returns the animal, the robbery victim must pay the difference between its value at the time of the robbery and its current value, and <span class="gemarra-regular">if he desires </span>he can return it to the owner and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: That which is yours is before you.</span>
The Gemara expresses surprise: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is he saying? </span>If the robber has a right to demand compensation for the enhancement to the animal, why would he ever return it without stating this demand? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced it, he takes his enhancement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">weakened, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: That which is yours is before you, </span>and no further compensation is required. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>despite <span class="gemarra-regular">a change, </span>the changed item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place. </span>Since the robber has not acquired it, he simply returns the item to the robbery victim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>i.e., if the robber has not acquired it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he enhanced it </span>that should be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The item should still belong to the robbery victim and the robber should not be entitled to compensation. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: The fact that the robber has a right to demand compensation for the enhancement is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to an ordinance </span>instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the penitent. </span>In order to ease the burden of one who desires to repent, the Sages instituted that the robber be reimbursed for the increase in the value of the animal. Otherwise, a robber might refrain from returning a stolen item.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the source that indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael </span>holds that an item that undergoes a change is still considered to have the same status that it had before the change? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The ideal way to fulfill the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva of produce in the corner of the field, which is given to the poor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">e’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to separat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the standing </span>grain, i.e., grain that has not been harvested. If <span class="gemarra-regular">one did not separate </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the standing </span>grain, he <span class="gemarra-regular">separates </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sheaves </span>of grain that have already been harvested. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not separate </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sheaves, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">separates </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the pile </span>of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">smoothed </span>the pile.
If he <span class="gemarra-regular">smoothed </span>the pile of grain, activating the obligation to tithe the produce, he first <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes </span>the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>a portion of the tithed produce <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the poor as <span class="it-text">pe’a</span>, so that the poor will not have to tithe what they receive. Additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">they said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: </span>If he did not separate <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> during any of the aforementioned stages and he made a dough from the grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">he separates </span><span class="it-text">pe’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even from the doug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gives it to </span>the poor. This indicates that even if the grain was changed, one is not exempt from the obligation of <span class="it-text">pe’a</span>.
The Gemara has now clarified the sources Abaye alluded to when he listed all the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> who hold that despite a change, the changed item remains in its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Did all these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> go to </span>so much trouble in <span class="gemarra-regular">an effort [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ikhpal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to teach us </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, </span>which is presumably not accepted as normative? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Pappa: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what they are saying: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not engage in a dispute with regard to this matter. </span>All of the aforementioned <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> hold that even Beit Hillel agree that a change in the form of an item does not impact its status.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: From where </span>can it be proven that all of the aforementioned <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> hold that an item that undergoes a change is still considered to have the same status that it had before the change? One can say that the reasons for their statements are due to other factors. <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda states </span>his opinion, that it is not a significant change, <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of the first of the sheared wool, <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to dye, </span>which is a reversible change, <span class="gemarra-regular">since one is able to remove it with soap.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai state </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of a harlot, <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Most High, because </span>of the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">has become repugnant,</span> in being used as payment for the services of a prostitute, and therefore it cannot be used for an offering even if its form has changed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>where one robbed another of wheat, <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to a blessing, because this is a mitzva </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is performed through </span>commission of <span class="gemarra-regular">a transgression, </span>but this does not indicate that a change is insignificant with regard to other matters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>where the condition of the animal changed, <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to weakening </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is reversible. </span>Since the animal’s value can be restored by fattening it, the weakening is not deemed a significant change.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>where one separated <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> at a late stage, <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, because it is written: “You shall leave </span>them for the poor” <span class="gemarra-regular">an additional </span>time. It is mentioned twice, in Leviticus 19:10 and Leviticus 23:22. One of these terms is superfluous, indicating that <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> must be given to the poor under all circumstances, even if the grain was changed and made into dough. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Let us derive from </span><span class="it-text">pe’a</span> that in other halakhic domains the status of an item is not affected by its undergoing a change, <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> cannot function as a source because <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts to the poor are different </span>from other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>.
The Gemara notes: Rava’s claim that no definitive conclusion with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael concerning a changed item is supported by the statement of another <span class="it-text">amora</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the dilemma raised by Rabbi Yonatan, as Rabbi Yonatan raises a dilemma: What is the reason </span>for the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yishmael? </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">change does not </span>cause one to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>an item? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he generally holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">change </span>does cause one to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>an item, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here,</span> in the case of <span class="it-text">pe’a</span>, it is different <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall leave” is written an additional </span>time.
Having quoted Rabbi Yonatan’s dilemma, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>for the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yishmael is that he holds that change does not </span>cause one to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>an item, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the <span class="gemarra-regular">additional </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall leave,” which the Merciful One writes </span>in the Torah? <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold that <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> may not be taken from dough, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">the additional </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall leave” that the Merciful One writes?</span>
The Gemara responds: This additional term <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who renounced ownership of his vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and arose earl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the morning </span>before anyone else took possession of it <span class="gemarra-regular">and harvested it is obligated in</span> the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">individual fallen </span>grapes left for the poor <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eret</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">incompletely formed clusters </span>of grapes left for the poor <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">olelot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">forgotten </span>clusters of grapes left for the poor <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> These are the four gifts to the poor that the Torah requires one to give from a vineyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he is exempt from the </span>mitzva to <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>his produce, because this requirement does not apply to an ownerless field. The obligation to give gifts to the poor in this case is derived from the additional mention of the term “You shall leave.”
§ The Gemara returns to the discussion of a stolen item that underwent a change. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</span> who says that even if the stolen animal deteriorated, it is returned to the owner in its current state.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Shmuel </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Shmuel say: One does not appraise </span>the change in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for a thief nor for a robber. Rather, </span>they keep the stolen animal and pay back the victim with their own money; one appraises the change only for one obligated to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, who said </span>earlier in response to Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>he stated it only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to weakening </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is reversible, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: When </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, </span>who holds <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>despite <span class="gemarra-regular">a change, </span>the changed item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place, </span>he stated this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to weakening </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">which is reversible, </span>in which case the change is insignificant. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when Shmuel says there: One does not appraise </span>the change in value, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for a thief nor for a robber, </span>but rather one appraises the change <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>for one obligated to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">for damage, </span>he stated this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to weakening </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">that is irreversible.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Abaye, who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar states </span>his opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">he states it </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to weakening </span>of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">which is irreversible, what can be said?</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye taught </span>the statement of Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">like this: Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>

Daf 94b

Some <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, but </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">himself does not hold accordingly.</span>
The Gemara continues the discussion of acquisition of a stolen item due to a change it underwent. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law, a stolen item that has changed is returned as is, as it is stated: “And he shall restore that which he took by robbery” </span>(Leviticus 5:23). This indicates that he shall return it <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case, </span>even if it has been changed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna </span>it is stated that if the stolen item is changed the robber gives monetary compensation rather than returning the item, that policy was instituted by the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the ordinance </span>instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the penitent.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say that? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with an unattributed mishna, and we learned </span>in a mishna with regard to first of the sheared wool (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 135a): If the owner of the sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">did not manage to give </span>the sheared wool <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">before he dyed it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from giving it to the priest. This indicates that dyeing the wool is a significant change.
