<span class="gemarra-regular">One of the Rabbis, whose name </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov, said to them: It was explained to me </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>that he was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">sanded wood and fashioned it into vessels, which is a change </span>in which the item <span class="gemarra-regular">can revert to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its original state</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Consequently, the robber does not acquire the item by Torah law, but rather due to the ordinance instituted for the penitent.
§ Having mentioned the ordinance instituted for the penitent, the Gemara discusses other details of this ordinance. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 8:11): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers or usurer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that returned </span>either the stolen item or the interest to the one from whom they took it, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who does accept</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, the Sages are displeased with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since by doing so he discourages those who wish to repent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This mishna, </span>i.e., the statement of the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught in the days of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident with regard to one man</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who desired to repent </span>after having been a thief for many years. <span class="gemarra-regular">His wife said to him: Empty one [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">reika</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if you repent </span>you will have to return all the stolen items to their rightful owners, and <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">belt </span>that you are wearing <span class="gemarra-regular">is not yours, and he refrained and did not repent. At that time, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers or usurers that returned </span>either the stolen item or the interest to the one from whom they took it, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. And </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">one who does accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, the Sages are displeased with him.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objectio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to children whose deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">father left the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money </span>paid <span class="gemarra-regular">as interest, although they know that it is interest, they are not obligated to return </span>it. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They,</span> the children, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>the ones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not </span>obligated to return it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but their father </span>would have been <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to return </span>it, and his victims may accept his money.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">By right, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should have taught <span class="gemarra-regular">that their father also </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have been <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span> this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the children is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>of the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to teach </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">father left them a cow, or a garment, or any </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">specific item </span>he had stolen or taken as interest, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are obligated to return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the honor of their father, </span>so that the item not serve as a reminder to all that their father transgressed. Since this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> needs to be stated specifically with regard to the children, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught with regard to them.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it true that <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the honor of their father they are obligated to return </span>the item or money? <span class="gemarra-regular">I will read here </span>the verse: “You shall not revile God, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor curse a ruler of your people” </span>(Exodus 22:27), from which the Sages inferred that the prohibition against cursing a ruler is in effect only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a ruler that <span class="gemarra-regular">acts as </span>a member of <span class="gemarra-regular">your people, </span>i.e., in accordance with Torah law. One who curses a wicked ruler does not violate this prohibition. Similarly, if one’s father is wicked, the mitzva to honor him should not apply. Why would his children have to return items that he stole due to his honor?
The Gemara responds: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pineḥas said </span>concerning a different case: This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he repented. Here too, </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">repented, </span>and since he is no longer wicked, his children are obligated to honor him. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he repented, what was </span>the stolen item or interest <span class="gemarra-regular">doing with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He should have returned it </span>while he was still alive. The Gemara responds: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not manage to return it before he died. </span>Consequently, the children must return the items in order to uphold their father’s honor.
The Gemara raises another contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the statement of another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers and usurers, although they collected </span>the stolen item or interest, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it.
The Gemara first clarifies the meaning of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers, what collection is there, </span>i.e., why did the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> use the term: Collected, in this context? <span class="gemarra-regular">If they robbed, they robbed </span>and did not collect anything; <span class="gemarra-regular">and if they did not rob, they did not rob </span>and cannot be called robbers at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>emend the text of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers, and who are they, </span>i.e., what is meant by the term: Robbers? It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">usurers. </span>The Gemara resumes its citation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Although they collected </span>the interest, <span class="gemarra-regular">they must return </span>it. This is contrary to the ruling of the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> that if robbers and usurers return what they have taken, it is not accepted. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one does not accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why do they return </span>it if it will not be accepted? The Gemara responds: In order <span class="gemarra-regular">to fulfill </span>their obligation to <span class="gemarra-regular">Heaven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In order to fully repent, they must at least offer to return to the debtors the interest they took unlawfully.
The Gemara raises a contradiction from another source. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the statement of another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">shepherds </span>who allow their animals to graze in other people’s fields, thereby stealing from the owners; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>tax <span class="gemarra-regular">collector</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who are hired to collect taxes on behalf of the government and collect excessive sums; <span class="gemarra-regular">or tax collector</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who purchase the right to collect taxes themselves and collect unlawfully, <span class="gemarra-regular">their repentance is difficult, </span>since they steal from the public. It is difficult for them to find every one of their victims in order to pay them restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>what they have stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">to whomever they recognize </span>as victims of their theft. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that thieves do return what they have stolen.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one does not accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why do they return </span>it if it will not be accepted? The Gemara responds: In order <span class="gemarra-regular">to fulfill </span>their obligation to <span class="gemarra-regular">Heaven. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if they are not actually obligated to return what they have stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">why is their repentance difficult?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, say the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the money belonging to those <span class="gemarra-regular">that they do not recognize </span>as their victims, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should use </span>that money for <span class="gemarra-regular">community needs. And Rav Ḥisda says: </span>This means providing <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, ditches, and caves, </span>which benefit the general public. This indicates that a thief actually does pay back what he has stolen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this contradiction must be resolved differently. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: Here, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that he must actually return what he has stolen, it is referring to a time <span class="gemarra-regular">before the ordinance </span>for the penitent was instituted. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that one does not accept the repayment from a robber, it is referring to a time <span class="gemarra-regular">after the ordinance </span>was instituted.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And now that Rav Naḥman says </span>that when the Sages say that he does not return what he has stolen, they refer only to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the stolen item does not exist </span>in its initial form, and <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that, </span>both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, are referring to a time <span class="gemarra-regular">after the ordinance </span>was instituted, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>

Daf 95a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that rules that one may accept the stolen item is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the stolen item </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">exists. There, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that rules not to accept it even if the robber seeks only to fulfill his obligation to Heaven is referring to a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item does not </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">exist. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the incident in which the robber’s wife told him that he would have to return even the <span class="gemarra-regular">belt, </span>which was the impetus for instituting the ordinance for the penitents, was a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">exists, </span>in which case the robber would be obligated to return it even after the ordinance was instituted. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: Even the <span class="gemarra-regular">belt? </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the belt, </span>but the actual belt was no longer in his possession.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not institute an ordinance </span>for the penitent <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">exists? But there is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which is a stolen item that </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">exists, and we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 55a): <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a stolen beam that </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">built into a building, </span>the Sages instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">should take its monetary </span>value and not the actual beam <span class="gemarra-regular">because of the ordinance </span>instituted for <span class="gemarra-regular">the penitent, </span>i.e., so that the penitent not be required to destroy his house. This indicates that the ordinance instituted for the penitent is in effect even when the stolen item still exists. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There it is different. Since </span>in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">there is the loss of the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">building</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Sages treat </span>the beam <span class="gemarra-regular">as though it were not </span>in existence.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pregnant cow, and it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth </span>while in the robber’s possession, or if one robbed another of a ewe that was laden with wool and the robber then sheared it, he pays the owner the value of a cow that is ready to give birth, or the value of a ewe that is ready to be shorn. In connection with this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who robs </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ewe and sheared it, </span>and similarly, one who robs another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow and it gave birth, </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay it and its sheared </span>wool <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>it and <span class="gemarra-regular">its offspring; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: A stolen item is returned as is. Rabbi Shimon says: </span>A stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">is viewed as though it had been monetarily appraised </span>at the time of the robbery, and the robber pays only that amount.
The Gemara clarifies the different opinions in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rabbi Meir, </span>who holds that the robber returns the animal and its sheared wool or the animal and its offspring? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he holds </span>that despite <span class="gemarra-regular">a change, </span>the changed item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place? </span>Despite its changes, the animal always remained in the possession of the robbery victims, and consequently any increase in value belongs to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, perhaps </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">generally </span>holds that one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in it, and therefore the wool or offspring should belong to the robber by right, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here it is a penalty that he imposes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which forces the robber to return items that are technically his.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case does the reasoning of Rabbi Meir make a practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference? In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the stolen item was <span class="gemarra-regular">devalued </span>since the time of the robbery. If Rabbi Meir’s reason is that despite a change, the changed item remains in its place, it is returned as is, even if its current value is less than what its value had been at the time of the robbery. But if he requires the robber to return the item itself because of a penalty, and by right the robber acquired the animal due to the change, then in this case, where the value decreased, the robber would be required to return what its value had been at the time of the robbery.
The Gemara attempts to find a solution to this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was taught in the mishna (96b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal and it aged </span>while in his possession, consequently diminishing its value, or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves and they aged, he pays according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. Rabbi Meir says: With regard to slaves, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this indicates that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>that aged while in the possession of the robber Rabbi Meir concedes to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, and he too holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays according to </span>what its value had been at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery.</span>
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds </span>that despite <span class="gemarra-regular">a change, </span>the changed item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains in its place, </span>then the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal </span>should be returned as it is in the case of the animal that aged, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, </span>in the case of a stolen animal that subsequently was shorn or gave birth, the payment of wool or offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">is a penalty </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">which he penalizes </span>the robber, so that the robber will not benefit from the increased value of the stolen item?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Rabbi Meir’s reasoning cannot be proven from the mishna, since it is possible to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir is speaking to </span>the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the Rabbis’ </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">statement. </span>His statement should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to my own </span>opinion, one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an animal </span>that was stolen and then aged should be returned as it is now, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. But according to you, who say </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in it, <span class="gemarra-regular">agree with me in any event </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a slave, </span>he is returned as is. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because his legal status is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">real estate, and real estate cannot be stolen. And the Rabbis say to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>for the purpose of robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">the legal status of a slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property.</span>
The Gemara again attempts to find a solution to the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was taught in the mishna (100b): If one gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye it red for him and he dyed it black, </span>or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner of the wool the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool,</span> since the dyer violated the owner’s wishes. It can be inferred from this mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool, yes, </span>he must give it; but the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and its enhancement,</span> i.e., the amount by which the value of the wool increased because it was dyed, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he need not give it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in the item, the dyer should be <span class="gemarra-regular">required to return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and its enhancement to </span>the owner, as it never left the owner’s possession.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here,</span> in the case of a stolen animal that was subsequently shorn or gave birth, the payment of wool or offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">is a penalty </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">which he penalizes </span>the robber, so that the robber will not benefit from the increased value of the stolen item? The Gemara affirms this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the mishna that this is indeed the reasoning of Rabbi Meir.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: This, </span>i.e., Rabbi Meir’s reasoning, <span class="gemarra-regular">was never in question for us. </span>Why not? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav reversed </span>the opinions in the mishna on 96b <span class="gemarra-regular">and taught </span>it as follows: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal and it aged, </span>or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves and they aged, he pays according to </span>what their value had been at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: With regard to slaves, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. Certainly, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>an item due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>in the item, which is why the robber pays according to what its value had been at the time of the robbery. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of the cow that gave birth or the ewe that was shorn, the payment of offspring or wool <span class="gemarra-regular">is a penalty </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">which he penalizes </span>the robber.
The Gemara continues the alternative explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">When we asked </span>the question, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is how we asked </span>it: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">penalizes </span>the robber, is it only for one who robbed <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, but </span>if one took an item from its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally, </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">does not penalize </span>the robber? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he penalizes even </span>one who took an item from its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally.</span>
The Gemara tries to resolve this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> types of monetary claims <span class="gemarra-regular">are collected </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥorarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>property, i.e., property that is still in possession of its owner and has not been sold in the meantime.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And these are they: Produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>value of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Even if one has the right to the produce of a particular property, or the gain accrued from that produce, he cannot claim this payment from liened property. The Gemara continues with the list of monetary claims collected from unsold property: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who accepts upon himself </span>at the time of his betrothal the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to provide sustenance for his wife’s so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or his wife’s daughter </span>from a previous marriage; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a promissory note that has no </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee,</span> i.e., a document that does not explicitly state that all of the properties of the debtor will serve to guarantee payment of the debt; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman’s marriage contract that has no </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whom did you hear that says </span>that omission of the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee </span>of the sale from the document <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a scribal error</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir. </span>There is a dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis with regard to a promissory note that does not contain a property guarantee. According to the Rabbis, it was omitted in error and is always considered as having been written in the document. Rabbi Meir holds that a promissory note that does not contain a property guarantee cannot be used to collect property that has been liened or sold; it can be used to collect only unsold property. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is therefore in accordance with Rabbi Meir’s opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>value of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>are collected only from unsold property.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which he collects the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>value of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce? </span>It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it to another, and </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced it, and it is now leaving the possession </span>of the purchaser because the robbery victim has proved in court that this field is his. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>from the robber who sold him this field, in order to recoup what he had paid, 

Daf 95b

he can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect the principal, </span>i.e., what he paid for the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">liened property </span>that has been sold. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he can collect <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhanced </span>value, i.e., the value of the improvements made to the field, only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property. </span>Why are both of these collected from the robber? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because the owner of the field came and took </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">his land and its enhanced </span>value.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>a purchaser who is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ignoramus, who does not know whether property can be stolen or cannot be stolen, </span>and when he purchased stolen land from the robber, he did so unintentionally, since he was under the mistaken impression that this land belonged to the robber who sold it? <span class="gemarra-regular">And even so, the owner of the land can come and take the land and its enhanced </span>value. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if so, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">penalizes even </span>one who acquires stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is speaking <span class="gemarra-regular">of a purchaser </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scholar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he knew </span>that the robber had no right to sell this land. The purchaser is therefore penalized and is required to return the enhanced value of the land as well.
The Gemara again tries to determine the scope of the penalty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was taught in a mishna (100b): If one gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye it red for him and he dyed it black, </span>or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner of the wool the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool, </span>since the dyer violated the owner’s instructions. It can be inferred from the mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool, yes, </span>he must give; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and its enhanced </span>value, i.e., the amount by which the value of the wool increased because it was dyed, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he is not required to give.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">penalizes </span>one who acquires a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally as well, </span>the dyer should be <span class="gemarra-regular">required to return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and its enhancement to him. Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>the mishna that if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">penalizes </span>the robber, but if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">unintentionally he does not penalize </span>him? The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the mishna that this indeed is the reasoning of Rabbi Meir.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A stolen item is returned as is. Rabbi Shimon says: </span>The stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">is viewed as though it had been monetarily appraised </span>at the time of the robbery. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, </span>since ostensibly they agree that the robber does not return the value of the enhancement to the robbery victim?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: They disagree with regard to enhancement that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the stolen item</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The disagreement concerns a case where the enhancement occurred while the stolen item was in the possession of the robber, and when he returned the item it was still enhanced. Therefore, he did not keep any of the enhancement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that the enhancement <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the one who was robbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shimon holds that it belongs to the robber.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said </span>that the disagreement between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon can be explained differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone </span>agrees that the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the stolen item belongs to the robber, and here they disagree </span>with regard to whether the robber can keep <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third, or one-fourth</span> of the value of the enhancement, and the remainder is kept by the owner of the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the stolen item belongs entirely to the robber, and Rabbi Shimon holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the robber takes one-half, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third, or one-fourth </span>of the value of the enhancement. In other words, he is treated as a shepherd or rancher and receives the share of the enhancement that local custom dictates be paid to that type of laborer.
The Gemara cites a proof for Rav Zevid’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna (93b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow, and it became pregnant in his </span>possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth; </span>or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ewe, and it became laden </span>with wool <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared it, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays according to </span>the value of the animal at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. </span>The Gemara infers from the mishna: If the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth, yes, </span>he pays the value of the animal at the time of the theft, but if the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give birth </span>and is still pregnant, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">returned as is.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, enhancement that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the stolen item belongs to the one who was robbed, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>as the pregnant cow is returned as is. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa, who says </span>that everyone agrees that the enhancement <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the robber, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>is it in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the robber does not retain any of the enhanced value.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that the inference is incorrect: <span class="gemarra-regular">The same is true </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even if it did not give birth, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays according to </span>the value of the animal at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery, </span>and the enhanced value due to the pregnancy is returned to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which the mishna teaches: It </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth, </span>cannot serve as the basis for an inference pertaining to this discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> needs to <span class="gemarra-regular">cite </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it gave birth </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna, since in that case he acquires the animal due to the change in its condition, therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he cites</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">it gave birth </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause as well, </span>but it need not have given birth. It cannot be inferred from this mishna that an animal that has not given birth is returned as is.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Pappa. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>The stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">is viewed as though it had been monetarily appraised </span>at the time of the theft, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of keeping <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third, or one-fourth </span>of the value of the enhancement.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When we were </span>studying <span class="gemarra-regular">in the study hall of Rav Kahana, we were asked </span>a question: <span class="gemarra-regular">According </span>to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says that the robber takes one-half, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third, or one-fourth </span>of the value of the enhancement; <span class="gemarra-regular">when we remove </span>the robber, taking the stolen animal from him and paying him a portion of the enhanced value, do <span class="gemarra-regular">we remove him </span>by paying him his share <span class="gemarra-regular">with money? Or, perhaps he takes </span>his portion <span class="gemarra-regular">from the meat </span>of the animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we resolved the </span>dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from that which Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>cases, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises the enhanced </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the parties involved in enhancing a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are paid in money </span>rather than by being given a portion of the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and these are they: A firstborn </span>son who makes payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to a regular </span>son. This is a case where two sons, one firstborn and the other not, inherit a field from their father. Before it is divided, they both work and enhance the field. When the time comes to divide the field, the firstborn son, who receives a double portion, must pay his brother for the enhancement that the latter contributed to the former’s portion. This payment is given in money rather than land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the second case is that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>who is obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">to a purchaser, </span>i.e., a creditor who collects the debt from lands that were sold by the debtor. He pays money to the purchaser for the enhancements generated by the purchaser but does not pay him in land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the third case is that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor </span>who is obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">to orphans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a creditor who collects land from the orphans of his debtor. He must pay them for any enhancements done by the orphans after their father’s death. This payment is also given in money rather than land.
The Gemara discusses Shmuel’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Did Shmuel </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor gives the purchaser </span>any of the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>value at all? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Shmuel say: A creditor collects </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhanced </span>value? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>where Shmuel stated that a creditor does not collect the enhanced value, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where there was <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement that reaches shoulders [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevaḥ</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hammaggia</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">likhtefayim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the produce that grew due to the improvements made by the purchaser is fully grown and ripened and can now be harvested and carried upon one’s shoulders. <span class="gemarra-regular">But there, </span>where Shmuel stated that a creditor does collect the enhanced value, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where there was <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement that does not reach shoulders, </span>i.e., its growth is not complete.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But </span>there were <span class="gemarra-regular">daily incidents </span>of this type, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel would collect </span>from purchasers <span class="gemarra-regular">even enhancement that reached shoulders. </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>

Daf 96a

<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>ruling, that Shmuel would collect the enhanced value, is for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is owe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">the amount of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the land and the enhanced value. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>ruling, that Shmuel would not collect the value of the enhancement, is for a case where the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is owed by </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">only the amount of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the land.</span>
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This works out well according to the one who says: If the purchaser </span>of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">has money, he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot remove the creditor </span>from the land, i.e., the creditor has the right to collect the land. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">well. But according to the one who says: If the purchaser </span>of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">has money, he can remove the creditor </span>from the land, i.e., the purchaser can choose to pay him money instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">say: If I had money, I would remove you from all of the land; now </span>that I do not have sufficient money to pay what you are owed, <span class="gemarra-regular">give me </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">riva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of land, </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">the amount of my enhancement.</span>
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>this field as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repayment for him, as he said to him: You shall not be repaid from anything but this, </span>in which case he clearly has a lien on this field and nothing else.
§ The Gemara continues the discussion of a stolen item that has been enhanced. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and enhanced </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> it to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and enhanced </span>it and then died <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeathed </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold that which he enhanced and bequeathed that which he enhanced. </span>And the robbery victim, should he wish to recover the stolen item, must pay the purchaser or heir for the enhanced value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma </span>related to the aforementioned <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser enhance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the stolen item? Must the robbery victim pay the purchaser for the enhanced value or not? <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemma, he then resolved it: What has the first </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to the second </span>in any sale? He has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">any rights that will come into his possession. </span>Since the robber had the rights to the value of his enhancements to the stolen item, he sold those rights to the purchaser as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile </span>robber <span class="gemarra-regular">enhance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the value of a stolen item? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Shall we arise and institute an ordinance for </span>the benefit of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile? </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This question <span class="gemarra-regular">is not necessary </span>except <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it was the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it to a Jew. </span>Rava was asking if the Jew needs to return the enhanced value. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, one who comes </span>to possess an item <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>purchasing it from <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is like a gentile </span>himself because, as stated previously, in any sale the purchaser’s rights are identical to the seller’s. Since the Sages did not institute ordinances for the benefit of gentiles, the Jewish purchaser does not have those rights either.
The Gemara explains: This question <span class="gemarra-regular">is not necessary </span>except <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it was the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that a Jew robbed </span>another of the item <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold it to </span>a gentile, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the gentile enhanced it, and </span>then the <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile went back and sold it to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">Jew</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say: Since it was initially </span>stolen by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew and </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">then </span>acquired by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew, the Sages did institute an ordinance? Or, perhaps since there is </span>the ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile intervening, the Sages did not institute an ordinance. </span>The Gemara comments: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that if one robbed another of wood and fashioned it into vessels, he acquired the wood due to the change. The Gemara discusses what qualifies as a change. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who robbed another of a palm tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cut it </span>down, <span class="gemarra-regular">although he threw it from the land </span>of the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">to his own land, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The tree was <span class="gemarra-regular">initially called a palm tree, and now, </span>although it has been cut down, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is also called a palm tree, </span>so the change to the item is not sufficiently significant for the robber to acquire it. Moreover, if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree and made </span>it into <span class="gemarra-regular">logs, he did not acquire it, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">now, in any event, they are called palm tree logs.</span>
By contrast, if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">logs and fashioned them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">beams, he has acquired </span>them, since this change is significant. If one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">large beams and fashioned them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">small beams, he did not acquire them, </span>since they are still called beams. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">fashioned them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">boards, he did acquire </span>them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: This one who robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm fron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fashioned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hutzei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he removed the leaves from the spine, <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">since initially it was called a palm frond and now </span>it is called <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves. </span>One who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves and fashioned them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a broom has acquired them, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>they were called <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves, and now </span>they are called <span class="gemarra-regular">a broom. </span>One who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a broom</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">fashioned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a rope has not acquired it. What is the reason </span>for this? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">go back </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">unravel it, and it will </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">be a broom.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>central <span class="gemarra-regular">twin-leaf became split</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., is this considered a change through which a stolen <span class="it-text">lulav</span> would be acquired? The Gemara cites a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Matun says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>central <span class="gemarra-regular">twin-leaf was removed, </span>the <span class="it-text">lulav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is unfit. </span>

Daf 96b

<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true for </span>a case where the central twin-leaf <span class="gemarra-regular">became split, </span>i.e., that this <span class="it-text">lulav</span> has been rendered unfit to be used for the mitzva, and the robber has acquired the <span class="it-text">lulav</span> as a result of this change? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the case where it <span class="gemarra-regular">was removed is different, as </span>the result is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is lacking, </span>and an incomplete <span class="it-text">lulav</span> is certainly unfit. But if the leaf remains in place, albeit split, it does not necessarily render the <span class="it-text">lulav</span> unfit. The <span class="it-text">lulav</span> has not been changed and therefore the robber does not acquire it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the question was resolved as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Matun says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>central <span class="gemarra-regular">twin-leaf became split</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it becomes like </span>a <span class="it-text">lulav</span> whose central <span class="gemarra-regular">twin-leaf was </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">removed, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">unfit. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>his statement that if the central twin-leaf became split, the robber has acquired the <span class="it-text">lulav</span> as a result of the change.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: This one who robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">eart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fashioned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a bric</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not acquired </span>it due to the change. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and convert it </span>back into <span class="gemarra-regular">earth. </span>By contrast, if he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a brick, and </span>by crushing it <span class="gemarra-regular">turned it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has acquired it </span>due to the change. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say: Perhaps </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and fashion it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a brick? This is a different brick, and a new entity has arrived, </span>i.e., entered into existence, <span class="gemarra-regular">here.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: This one who robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bar of silver [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">naskha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fashioned </span>it into <span class="gemarra-regular">coin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not acquired it </span>due to the change. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? He can <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>it and by melting the coins <span class="gemarra-regular">turn them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a bar of silver. </span>By contrast, if he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">coins and fashioned them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a bar of silver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has acquired them </span>due to the change. <span class="gemarra-regular">What do you say </span>in response to this, that perhaps he will <span class="gemarra-regular">return and fashion them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">coins? </span>These are new coins, and <span class="gemarra-regular">a new entity has arrived here.</span>
Rav Pappa continues: If the stolen coins were <span class="gemarra-regular">black [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheḥimei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., old and used, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he made them </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">ne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> by cleaning them thoroughly, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired </span>them. By contrast, if however, they were <span class="gemarra-regular">new, and he made them black, he has acquired </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What do you say </span>in response to this, that perhaps he will <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">make them new </span>by cleaning them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Their blackness is already known, </span>and therefore the coins have been changed irreversibly.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: All robbers pay according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is added </span>by the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle? </span>The Gemara replies: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add that which Rabbi Ela says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole a lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">b</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>during the time that it was in the thief’s possession it <span class="gemarra-regular">became a ram, </span>or if one stole <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">became an ox, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">a change occurred </span>while the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession, and he has acquired it </span>due to the change. If he then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters his own </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sells his own </span>animal, and he does not become liable to pay the penalty of four or five times the value of the animal.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who robbed another </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pair </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">padna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of oxen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He then <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed </span>his field <span class="gemarra-regular">with them, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sowed seeds with them, and eventually returned them to their owner. </span>The robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>to claim payment from the robber. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the robbery victim and the robber: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go estimate </span>the amount by <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the value of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">was enhanced </span>during the time that the pair of oxen was in the possession of the robber, and the robber must pay that amount.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rav Naḥman: Did <span class="gemarra-regular">the oxen </span>alone <span class="gemarra-regular">enhance </span>the value of the land? <span class="gemarra-regular">Did the land not </span>become <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>in and of itself? Perhaps not all of the enhanced value of the land was due to the labor performed by the oxen. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Did I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they should estimate </span>and give him <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the enhanced value? <span class="gemarra-regular">I said </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">half. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Ultimately, it is a stolen item and is returned as it was </span>at the time of the robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">All robbers pay according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. </span>Why should the robber also pay the owner half the value of the enhancement?
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tell you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when I am sitting in judgment, do not say anything to me, </span>i.e., do not question or comment upon my rulings. An indication that my rulings should not be questioned is <span class="gemarra-regular">as our friend Huna has said about me, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">King Shapu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and I are brothers with regard to </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">laws, </span>i.e., with regard to monetary laws, my opinion is equal to that of Shmuel. <span class="gemarra-regular">This man is an experienced robber, and I wish to penalize him. </span>Therefore, I compelled him to pay the enhanced value, although by right he is not obligated to do so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal and it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">age</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> while in his possession, consequently diminishing its value, or if one robbed another of Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves and they aged </span>while in his possession, they have been changed. The robber therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">pays according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. Rabbi Meir says: With regard to </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, he says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you.</span>
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a coin and it cracked, </span>thereby reducing its value; or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and it rotted; </span>or if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and it fermented, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery.</span>
If he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a coin and it was invalidated </span>by the government; or if he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it became ritually impure; </span>or if he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread and Passover elapsed over it, </span>and therefore it is prohibited to derive benefit from it; or if he robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal and a sin was performed with it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> thereby disqualifying it for use as an offering; <span class="gemarra-regular">or if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was disqualifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>being sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the altar </span>for some other reason; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was going out to be stoned </span>because it gored and killed a person at some point after the robbery, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>In all of these cases, although the value of the stolen item has been diminished or altogether lost, since the change is not externally discernible, the robber returns the item in its current state.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s statement that one who robbed another of an animal that aged pays what its value was at the time of the robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">aged </span>means that it <span class="gemarra-regular">actually aged. But even </span>if the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">weakened, </span>which is a less significant change, it is still considered changed, and the robber has acquired the animal. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that it <span class="gemarra-regular">aged, </span>indicating that a lesser change, e.g., weakening, is not significant? The Gemara responds: Rav Pappa was speaking of <span class="gemarra-regular">weakening </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">like aging, </span>i.e., the animal became so weak <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">will not return </span>to its former <span class="gemarra-regular">health.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Kashisha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: This is what they say in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Even if one stole a lamb and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">became a ram, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">became an ox, </span>it is considered that <span class="gemarra-regular">a change occurred </span>while the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, and he has acquired it </span>due to this change. If he then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughters his own </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sells his own </span>animal, and he does not become liable to pay the penalty of four or five times the value of the animal. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Didn’t I say to you: Do not exchange </span>the names of the <span class="gemarra-regular">men</span> in whose name you are transmitting words of Torah? <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated in the name of Rabbi Ela, </span>not in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: With regard to </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, he says to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanina bar Avdimi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav set aside </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who are the majority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and practice </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir? </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> in the <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span>manner, i.e., with the opinions reversed, so that the Rabbis, rather than Rabbi Meir, hold that with regard to slaves the robber says: That which is yours is before you. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav set aside the mishna and practice </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav also teaches the mishna </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span>manner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reasoning of Rav, who reversed </span>the opinions in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna in light of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? On the contrary, let him reverse </span>the opinions in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in light of the mishna. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav also learned the mishna </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span>manner. Rav did not decide to reverse the opinions in the mishna. In the text of the mishna that he utilized, the opinions were the same as in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that Rav did in fact decide to reverse the opinions in the mishna, based upon the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">When he does not reverse </span>a mishna due to a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>mishna that he will not reverse <span class="gemarra-regular">in light of one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>. But <span class="gemarra-regular">he would reverse one </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in light of two </span><span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, and in this case there is a second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in which the opinions are the reverse of those found in the mishna.
The second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 8:23–24): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who exchanges a cow for a donkey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>in the meantime the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth; and similarly, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservant, and </span>in the meantime <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth, </span>if in either of these cases the purchaser and seller have a dispute as to when the birth took place, where <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: She gave birth </span>at the time that she was <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession </span>and therefore the offspring is mine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the other is silent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the one who stated definitively that she gave birth while in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>the offspring. If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I do not know, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I do not know</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">they shall divide </span>the value of the offspring.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>She gave birth while <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>She gave birth while <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller must take an oath that she gave birth </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession, as anyone who </span>is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath that is </span>enumerated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Tora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes an oath and does not pay; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span>In this case, since the seller initially had possession of the animal or the maidservant, he is considered the defendant, and therefore it is sufficient for him to take an oath to exempt himself from payment and maintain possession of the offspring.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not take an oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concerning either </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves or concerning land. </span>This indicates that according to the opinion of the Rabbis, Canaanite slaves have the legal status of land, whereas according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, they do not. It follows, then, that in the mishna here as well, it is the Rabbis, and not Rabbi Meir, who maintain that, with regard to slaves, one says: That which is yours is before you, as one does with regard to land.
