The Gemara asks: If it is true that the opinion that the mishna attributed to Rabbi Meir was attributed by Rav to the Rabbis, then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>is imprecise. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>said that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: According to </span>the way <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you have reversed </span>the opinions in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you taught </span>that Rabbi Meir says that the robber says to the robbery victim: That which is yours is before you, then the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>despite the fact that according to Rav, this is the opinion of the Rabbis. 

Daf 97a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rav </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the legal status of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">real estate? But doesn’t Rav Daniel bar Rav Ketina say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One who seizes another’s </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and performs labor with him is exempt </span>from paying the master for the labor of the slave? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that, in Rav’s opinion, the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">real estate, why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying? A slave, like real estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of his owner, </span>wherever he might be. Therefore, the one who seized him did not steal the slave, in which case he could simply return him. Rather, he made use of a slave belonging to another and should be liable to pay for the master’s loss of the slave’s labor.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case where the one who seized the slave forced him to perform labor when it was <span class="gemarra-regular">not during </span>regular <span class="gemarra-regular">working hours. </span>Consequently, he did not prevent the slave from performing labor for his master. Since the owner did not incur any loss, the one who seized the slave is not obligated to pay for the benefit that he derived from the slave. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>message <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Abba sent to Mari bar Mar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ask Rav Huna </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">one who resides in another’s courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge: Does he need to pay him rent, or does he not need to pay him rent? And they sent to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">He does not need to pay him rent, </span>since the owner of the property did not incur any monetary loss.
The Gemara rejects this comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? Granted, there, </span>in the case of a courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the reasoning for that <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says: An inhabited hous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> remains <span class="gemarra-regular">habitable, </span>and it is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">satisfactory for </span>the owner of the property to have someone residing in his courtyard, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the reasoning is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that since the verse states: “In the city is left desolation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the gate is smitten unto ruin” </span>(Isaiah 24:12), which indicates that a desolate house will fall into ruin but an inhabited house will be maintained, either way it is satisfactory <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the owner that one stay in his courtyard. Consequently, the one who resides there need not pay rent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of a slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it satisfactory for him that his slave be weakened </span>by performing labor for another? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Indeed, it is satisfactory for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him that </span>the work habits of <span class="gemarra-regular">his slave not be undone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara records a related incident. Members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">house of Rav Yosef bar Ḥam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would, </span>with his approval, <span class="gemarra-regular">seize the slaves of people who owed him money, and they would work them </span>against the will of the owners. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son of</span> Rav Yosef bar Ḥama, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is the reason that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master does this, </span>i.e., seizes and uses these slaves? Rav Yosef bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As Rav Naḥman says: A slave is not worth </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">the bread in his stomach. </span>When the slaves work for me and eat in my home, I am not causing the owners any monetary loss. Rav Yosef bar Ḥama’s son <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will say that Rav Naḥman said </span>this with regard to specific slaves, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as his slave Daru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">dances among </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">barrels [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kuvei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and does not perform any labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">All </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves perform labor, </span>and their labor is worth more than their board.
Rav Yosef bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Daniel, as Rav Daniel bar Rav Ketina says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One who seizes another’s slave and performs labor with him is exempt </span>from paying the master for the labor of the slave. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">satisfactory for </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the work habits of <span class="gemarra-regular">his slave not be undone.</span>
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This statement </span>of Rav Daniel applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the one who seizes the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not owed money </span>by the owner of the slave. But <span class="gemarra-regular">since the Master is owed money b</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the owner of the slave, this <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">appearance of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: Although </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who resides in another’s courtyard without his knowledge does not need to pay him rent, </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">lent </span>money to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">resided in the courtyard of another, </span>i.e., that of his creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">he needs to pay him rent, </span>to avoid the appearance of interest. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">bar Ḥama said to him: I retract </span>my opinion, and will no longer seize the slaves of my debtors.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who seizes another’s shi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and performs labor with it, </span>what payment can the ship’s owner claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that he may choose: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the cost of the ship’s <span class="gemarra-regular">rent, </span>and if he <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the amount by which the value of the ship was <span class="gemarra-regular">diminished </span>by being used for this labor, whichever amount is larger. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: He </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">take only</span> the amount by which the value of the ship was <span class="gemarra-regular">diminished.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>They <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree. </span>They were addressing different cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">This, </span>i.e., Rav’s statement, is referring to a ship <span class="gemarra-regular">that is commonly </span>available <span class="gemarra-regular">for rental. That, </span>i.e., Shmuel’s statement, is referring to a ship that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not commonly </span>available <span class="gemarra-regular">for rental. And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">This and that </span>statement are both referring to a ship <span class="gemarra-regular">that is commonly </span>available <span class="gemarra-regular">for rental. This, </span>Rav’s statement, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who seized the ship <span class="gemarra-regular">descended, </span>i.e., took possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">with the intention of renting </span>the ship. He pays for the rental. <span class="gemarra-regular">That, </span>Shmuel’s statement, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who seized the ship <span class="gemarra-regular">descended with the intention of robbery, </span>to use it without paying. He is regarded as a robber and pays only the amount by which its value was diminished.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a coin and it cracked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he pays the value of the coin at the time of the robbery, as he has acquired it due to its change. But if the coin was invalidated, he says: That which is yours is before you. Since this is not a significant change, he has not acquired it. The Sages disagree with regard to the explanation of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>When the mishna states that the coin <span class="gemarra-regular">cracked, </span>it means that it <span class="gemarra-regular">actually cracked; </span>when it says that the coin was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated, </span>it means that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated by the governmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and is therefore unfit for use.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: </span>A coin <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated by the government is </span>the same as a coin that is <span class="gemarra-regular">cracked, </span>because its complete loss of value is a significant change. <span class="gemarra-regular">But what are the circumstances </span>of the mishna, in which a coin that was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated </span>is not considered changed? It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a coin <span class="gemarra-regular">was invalidated </span>by the government in <span class="gemarra-regular">this province</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the residents there can no longer use it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the coin still <span class="gemarra-regular">circulates </span>and is in use <span class="gemarra-regular">in another province.</span>
The Gemara clarifies Rav Huna’s opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Huna: According to your </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">that you said </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated </span>means that the coin was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated </span>by the <span class="gemarra-regular">government, </span>and the mishna rules that in that case the robber can return it as is, there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what of the cases in the mishna of one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and it rotted </span>or one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and it fermented, which are similar to </span>a coin that was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated by the government, </span>since none of these items are fit for use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>their value at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery </span>because they underwent a change? Why would the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> be different in the case of a coin that was invalidated by the government?
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There, </span>in the cases of produce and wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">its taste and its smell changed. Here, </span>in the case of the coin that was invalidated, the coin itself <span class="gemarra-regular">did not change.</span>
The Gemara clarifies Rav Yehuda’s opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Yehuda: According to your </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">that you said </span>that a coin that was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated by the government is </span>the same as one that <span class="gemarra-regular">cracked, </span>and the mishna rules that in that case the robber pays according to its value at the time of the robbery, there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what of the case in the mishna of one who robbed another of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it became impure, which is similar to </span>a coin that was <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidated by the government, and </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you.</span>
Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There, </span>in the case of <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is not evident, </span>since it is impossible to tell the difference between pure and impure items. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of the coin, <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage is evident, </span>since one can tell by looking at it that it is the type of coin that was invalidated.
§ With regard to a coin that was invalidated, it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that there was a dispute concerning the question: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who lends </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">another on </span>the condition that he repay the loan using a particular kind of <span class="gemarra-regular">coin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that coin becomes invalidated, Rav says: </span>

Daf 97b

The debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him a coin that is in circulation at that time </span>with which he repays the loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>that the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the creditor: I am giving you a coin like the one you gave me, although you cannot utilize it here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Go spend it in Meishan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a distant place where this coin is still in circulation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: Shmuel’s statement is reasonable when </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">has a way to go to Meishan, </span>i.e., he intends to travel there, and therefore the debtor can tell him to spend the coin when he arrives at his destination. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he has no way </span>to go to Meishan, i.e., he does not intend to go there, the debtor may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>give him these coins. Rather, he must give him coins that are in circulation in their current location.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ma’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 1:6): <span class="gemarra-regular">One cannot desacraliz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> second-tithe produce by transferring its sanctity <span class="gemarra-regular">onto coins that are not in circulation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> How so? If one had coins of bar Kokheva [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Kozeviyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> coins <span class="gemarra-regular">of Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>coins <span class="gemarra-regular">of earlier kings, </span>all of which are no longer in use, one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot desacralize </span>second<span class="gemarra-regular">-</span>tithe produce by transferring its sanctity onto them. Rava infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if one had coins <span class="gemarra-regular">of later, </span>i.e., current, kings, that are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the coins of the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier </span>kings in that they have been invalidated in his location, since they are still valid elsewhere, one <span class="gemarra-regular">can desacralize </span>the second-tithe produce by transferring its sanctity onto them. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not make a distinction as to whether the owner of the produce intends to travel to the location where those coins are in use or not.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With what are we dealing here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">kingdoms are not particular with one another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> They allow a coin that has been invalidated in their province to be taken out of their borders and spent in a province where it is valid. Since these coins can be given to those planning to travel to the location where it is valid, it is considered to be a valid coin even in the location of the one desacralizing the second-tithe produce.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But, </span>according to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">when Shmuel said </span>that the debtor can repay his debt with invalidated coins only if the creditor intends to travel to a location where they are valid, he is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">kingdoms are particula</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with each other. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can he bring </span>these coins to Meishan without the authorities confiscating them? The Gemara responds: Shmuel is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">bring them with difficulty, </span>as in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the authorities <span class="gemarra-regular">do not search, but if they find </span>any invalid coins <span class="gemarra-regular">they are particular </span>to confiscate them. It is therefore possible to bring these coins into the other kingdom. Nevertheless, since the authorities are particular, one who does not plan to travel there will not be able to exchange these coins with anyone in his location.
The Gemara questions Shmuel’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ma’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 1:6): <span class="gemarra-regular">One cannot desacralize </span>second-tithe produce by transferring its sanctity <span class="gemarra-regular">onto money of </span>Eretz Yisrael, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">they, </span>the coins and their owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">are in Babylonia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>one cannot do so onto money <span class="gemarra-regular">of Babylonia when they, </span>the coins and their owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">are here </span>in Eretz Yisrael. If one uses money <span class="gemarra-regular">of Babylonia and they are in Babylonia, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">can desacralize </span>the second-tithe produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> desacralize </span>second-tithe produce by transferring its sanctity <span class="gemarra-regular">onto money of </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia. </span>And this is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they will ultimately ascend to there, </span>Eretz Yisrael, as the very purpose of transferring the sanctity to the coins is to spend them in Jerusalem.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">kingdoms are </span>especially <span class="gemarra-regular">particular with one another, </span>and it is impossible to transport coins from one location to the other. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the kingdoms are especially particular with one another, then with regard to the case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, in which sanctity is transferred onto money <span class="gemarra-regular">of Babylonia and they are in Babylonia, for what are these </span>coins <span class="gemarra-regular">fit? </span>In any case they cannot be brought to Jerusalem. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">They are fit for purchasing an animal with them </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">that will be brought up to Jerusalem.</span>
With regard to the statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that one cannot desacralize second-tithe produce by transferring its sanctity onto Babylonian money when in Eretz Yisrael, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted that </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">money shall circulate in Jerusalem because of this reason, </span>i.e., so that Jews from all locations will be able to use their local currencies? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that all money is valid in Jerusalem is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a time when the authority of the Jewish people is dominan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over the nations of the world </span>and could enforce the rabbinic enactments. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that sanctity may not be transferred onto Babylonian money when in Eretz Yisrael, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a time when the authority of the nations of the world is dominant over them, </span>i.e., the Jews, at which time foreign currency was not usable in Jerusalem.
Having mentioned the coins of Jerusalem, the Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: What is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">coin of </span>ancient <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The names <span class="gemarra-regular">David and Solomo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> were inscribed <span class="gemarra-regular">on one side, and Jerusalem the Holy City </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">other side. And what is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">coin of Abraham our forefather? An old man and an old woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> representing Abraham and Sarah, were inscribed <span class="gemarra-regular">on one side, and a young man and a young woman, </span>representing Isaac and Rebecca, were <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">other side.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava inquired of Rav Ḥisda: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who lends </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>the condition that he repay the loan in <span class="gemarra-regular">coin, </span>i.e., with the specific denomination of a currency, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the government <span class="gemarra-regular">added t</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> the size of the coin, so that a coin of the same denomination now weighs more? Is the debtor obligated to return the newly adjusted coin, or can he repay the debt according to the prior weight of the coin that he borrowed? Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: He gives him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">coin that is in circulation at the time </span>of the payment. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And </span>is this the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the new coin is as large <span class="gemarra-regular">as a sieve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>And is this the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is as large <span class="gemarra-regular">as a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tartiya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes.</span>
Rava challenged: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>by increasing the weight of this coin, the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce has decreased in price, </span>and since more produce can be purchased with this coin, giving it to the creditor as repayment is a form of interest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: We examine </span>the situation: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">decreased in price due to </span>the change in the weight of <span class="gemarra-regular">the coin, </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">is reduced for </span>the debtor and the creditor is repaid with coins that equal the prior value of the loan. 

Daf 98a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">decreased in price due to the market </span>value, the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">is not reduced for him.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the value of the coin <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>been <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced for the purpose of </span>melting it down into <span class="gemarra-regular">a bar of metal. </span>Since this coin now contains a larger quantity of metal, if it were to be melted it would be worth more than an earlier coin of the same type, so it should be considered interest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>in this case one must act <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with how Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>acted when they <span class="gemarra-regular">performed an action with the dinars of Agardami</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Arab merchant [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tayya’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> They considered <span class="gemarra-regular">up to ten </span>old coins to be the equivalent <span class="gemarra-regular">of eigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> new coins. Since ten old coins were equivalent in value to eight new coins, they paid eight new coins in exchange for ten old ones.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: One who throws another’s coi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into the Great Sea is exempt </span>from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? He can <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The coin <span class="gemarra-regular">is resting before you; if you wish, take it. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies only if the coin is <span class="gemarra-regular">in translucent </span>water, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the coin <span class="gemarra-regular">can see </span>the coin, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">turbid </span>water, <span class="gemarra-regular">where he cannot see </span>the coin, it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply, and the one that threw it will be liable to compensate the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when he rolled </span>the coin into the sea without picking it up, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the coin <span class="gemarra-regular">with his hands </span>and threw it into the sea, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has robbed </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">it, and </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to perform </span>the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning </span>the coin to its owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>to the statement of Rabba from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ma’aser</span> <span class="it-text">Sheni</span> 1:6): One <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot desacralize </span>second tithe by transferring its sanctity <span class="gemarra-regular">onto money that is not in his possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> How so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he had money in a fortress [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kastera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in the King’s Mountain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Har</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">HaMelekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or if his purse fell into the Great Sea, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not desacralize </span>second tithe by transferring its sanctity onto that money. This indicates that money that fell into the Great Sea is considered lost. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>This is not difficult; it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different with regard to </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe, since it is necessary </span>that the money be <span class="gemarra-regular">found in the hand </span>of the one who wishes to desacralize the tithe, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: “Then you shall turn it into money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and bind up the money in your hand, </span>and shall go to the place that the Lord your God shall choose” (Deuteronomy 14:25), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if it is in the Great Sea, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>in his hand, but nevertheless it is not considered lost.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: One who effaces </span>the image of <span class="gemarra-regular">another’s coi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is exempt </span>from paying damages, even though he caused the coin to lose value. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As he did not do anything, </span>the coin remains the same size as before. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this statement </span>applies only in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he struck it with a hammer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kurnesa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and flattened it; but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he filed it with a file [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shofina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> he must pay the amount of the reduction in value, since <span class="gemarra-regular">he caused it to diminis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> in size.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>to the statement of Rabba from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:26): If a master <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>his slave <span class="gemarra-regular">on his eye and blinded it, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">on his ear and deafened it, the slave is emancipated by means of these </span>injuries. If he struck the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">near his eye and </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not see, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">near his ear and he does not hear, the slave is not emancipated by means of these </span>injuries. The first clause indicates that one is liable for damage caused even if it is not visible damage.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rabba says: One who deafens his father is put to death, </span>even though no bruise is visible, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is impossible for deafening </span>to occur <span class="gemarra-regular">without a bruise, </span>as it is certain <span class="gemarra-regular">that a drop of blood fell into his ear </span>from the blow, even if it is not visible from the outside. Striking someone in the ear in a manner that causes deafness results in a significant physical change, while striking a coin with a hammer does not detract from the actual size of the coin.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: One who slits the ear of another’s co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is exempt </span>from paying damages, even though this cow is no longer fit to be sacrificed as an offering due to the injury. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow was available </span>for many uses until now, so <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">available </span>for those uses now, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the one who slit its ear <span class="gemarra-regular">did not do anything </span>to damage the cow in a substantial way. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>concerning the fact that it is rendered disqualified from being sacrificed as an offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">not all oxen stand near the altar, </span>i.e., most animals are not sacrificed as offerings anyway, so it is not considered a loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection</span> from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who performs a task with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">water of purification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the water that is mixed with the ashes of the red heifer and sprinkled upon one who has become impure as part of the purification ritual, <span class="gemarra-regular">or with </span>the red <span class="gemarra-regular">heifer of purification, </span>whose ashes are mixed with springwater and sprinkled on those who have contracted impurity imparted by a corpse on the third and seventh days of their impurity, is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt according to human laws, </span>since he has not caused any discernible damage, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable according to the laws of Heaven. </span>It may be inferred from here that one is exempt from liability according to human laws only if he performed <span class="gemarra-regular">a task </span>with those items, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the damage </span>that he caused <span class="gemarra-regular">is not evident, but </span>in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">slits </span>the ear, <span class="gemarra-regular">where the damage is evident, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed liable according to human laws.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The same is true that even one who slits </span>the ear <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt </span>according to human laws, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that specified cases where the damage is not evident <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: That even </span>one who performs <span class="gemarra-regular">a task </span>with the water of purification or the red heifer, <span class="gemarra-regular">where the damage is not evident, is liable according to the laws of Heaven.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: One who burns another’s </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is exempt, as </span>the one who burned it can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I have burned </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">your paper, </span>and he is not held liable for the fact that the creditor will no longer be able to prove that he had provided the loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama objects to this: What are the circumstances? </span>

Daf 98b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If there are witnesses who know what was </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, they should write a </span>new, <span class="gemarra-regular">proper, </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for him, </span>and there will not be any loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there are no witnesses, how do we know </span>what was written in the promissory note in order to assess liability? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Let it </span>refer to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who burned the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">trust</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the creditor with regard to the details of the promissory note. Despite the concession of the one who burned the promissory note with regard to the amount of the debt, Rabba holds that he is exempt, since the value of the debt is not inherent in the actual paper.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi bar Ḥanina said: This </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba is </span>the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis. According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value, the one who burned the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable. According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable. </span>Rabba holds in accordance with the Rabbis, and therefore rules that one who burns a promissory note is exempt from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, objects to this: Say that you heard </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where he damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba. As Rabba says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread before Passover</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and another came and burned it during the festival </span>of Passover, when the leavened bread had already become forbidden, the one who burned it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying the robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">as all are commanded to destroy </span>the leavened bread, and he therefore performed a mitzva. If he burned it <span class="gemarra-regular">after Passover, </span>that is the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis.</span>
Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value, the one who burned it is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>and he must pay the robber. Although it is prohibited to derive benefit from leavened bread, the robber could have returned it to the victim and been exempt from liability. Now that it has been burned, the robber will have to pay the monetary value of the leavened bread at the time of the theft. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial </span>loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an item </span>such as a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">no intrinsic monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we say </span>that in Rabbi Shimon’s opinion it too is considered to have monetary value?
The Gemara cites a ruling for the case where one burns the promissory note of another. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: The one who rules </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action <span class="gemarra-regular">collects, in this </span>case, the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of a proper </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>i.e., the amount of the debt, from the one who burned the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who rules </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no liability </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action <span class="gemarra-regular">collects, in this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the paper. </span>The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">there was an incident </span>like this one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rafram forced Rav Ashi, </span>who had burned a document in his youth, to pay damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he collected </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>if he had damaged <span class="gemarra-regular">a beam </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>crafting <span class="gemarra-regular">a sculpture</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he paid him the value of the debt listed in the promissory note.
§ The mishna teaches that if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, and Passover elapsed over it, </span>and it is therefore prohibited to derive benefit from it, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>his victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to items from which benefit is forbidden </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: That which is yours is before you? Rav Ḥisda said: It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 5:4): If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that killed </span>a person and is consequently liable to be stoned, and <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">sentenced it </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the ox, the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>is valid; if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">consecration </span>is valid; if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it, its flesh is permitted; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee returned it to its owner, it is returned.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">from when it was sentenced </span>to be stoned it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, and if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>valid; if <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrated it, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">consecration </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>valid; if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered it, its flesh is forbidden; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee returned it to its owner, it is not returned, </span>as once it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, the ox is worthless. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says: Even after it was sentenced, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee returned it to its owner, it is returned.</span>
Rav Ḥisda completes his analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not that they disagree about this </span>issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Ya’akov holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to items from which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> benefit is forbidden </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say: That which is yours is before you, and the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to items from which benefit is forbidden </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot say: That which is yours is before you?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No. </span>It may be <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> items from which benefit is forbidden </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say: That which is yours is before you, </span>and the ruling of the mishna is also in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis. <span class="gemarra-regular">As if so, </span>i.e., if it were true that the dispute in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> between the Rabbis and Rabbi Ya’akov concerns the general question of returning an item from which benefit is forbidden, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should disagree with regard to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread on Passover </span>and whether it can be returned as is, since this is a clear case of an item from which benefit is forbidden. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba said: Here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree with regard to </span>a different issue: Can <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox be sentenced in its absence?</span>
Rabba explains the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox may not be sentenced in its absence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the bailee is liable to pay. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>when the ox is returned after its sentencing, the owner may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had you brought </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>before sentencing, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have chased it away into the marsh, </span>preventing the sentencing from taking place. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, </span>since you did not return it to me before it was given to the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">you have given it to one with whom I cannot litigate, </span>as the court was sure to sentence it. Therefore you must pay me and not return the ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ya’akov holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox may be sentenced </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in its absence, </span>and the claim of the owner of the ox is not accepted. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the bailee may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did I do </span>to the ox? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately it would have been sentenced in its absence </span>and rendered forbidden.
The Gemara relates an incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, </span>who stated that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Ya’akov and not the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">found Rabba bar Shmuel </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Did you learn anything </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of returning stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">items from which benefit is forbidden? </span>Rabba bar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes, we learned </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “Then it shall be, if he has sinned, and is guilty, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he shall restore the item </span>that he robbed” (Leviticus 5:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “That he robbed”? </span>It means that the robber must <span class="gemarra-regular">return the same </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that he robbed.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">From here </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a coin and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was invalidated, </span>or of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted, </span>or of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fermented, </span>or of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">became ritually impure, </span>or of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread and Passover elapsed over it, </span>or of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal and a sin was performed with it, or </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that had not been sentenced, he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who did you hear say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">before the ox was sentenced </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">can be </span>returned, but <span class="gemarra-regular">after it was sentenced it cannot? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Ya’akov in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread and Passover elapsed over it, he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>This disproves the analysis of Rav Ḥisda, as even the Rabbis agree that an item from which benefit is forbidden is returned as is. Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabba bar Shmuel: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you find </span>the Sages, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not say anything to them,</span> i.e., do not publicize that I erred.
§ The Gemara discusses the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that if one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and it rotted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the robbery victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna (96b): If one robbed another of <span class="gemarra-regular">produce and it rotted, he pays </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery? Rav Pappa said: Here, </span>the mishna is referring to a case where the stolen produce <span class="gemarra-regular">all rotted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which constitutes a significant change. The robber acquires the produce and must pay what its value was at the time of the robbery. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">part of </span>the stolen produce <span class="gemarra-regular">rotted.</span> In such a case the robber may return it and say: That which is yours is before you.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">to craftsmen to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and they damaged </span>them, the craftsmen are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>for the damage. For example, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave a chest, a box, or a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cabine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to a carpenter to fix, and he damaged </span>it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay. And a builder who committed to demolish a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>while demolishing it he <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the stones, or who damaged </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he was demolishing on this side </span>of the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">fell from another side </span>and caused damage, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>a stone fell and caused damage <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the force of <span class="gemarra-regular">the blow, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one gave a carpenter a chest, a box, or a cabinet to fix, and he damaged it, the carpenter is liable to pay for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that a carpenter is liable to pay damages <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the carpenter a chest, a box, or a cabinet to drive a nail into them, </span>i.e., he gave the carpenter complete vessels to repair, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he drove the nail into them and broke them. But </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave wood to a carpenter to build a chest, a box, or a cabinet, and he built a chest, a box, or a cabinet from </span>the wood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>before giving it to the owner the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">broke them, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the damage caused to these vessels, and must pay only for the damage caused to the wood.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The craftsman is considered to have acquired the vessel through his work, which enhances its value, and it remains in his possession until he returns it to the owners. Consequently, if he damages the vessel in any way, he is damaging his own item, and must return only the value of the raw materials to the owners.
The Gemara attempts to contradict Rav Asi’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">to craftsmen </span>to fix <span class="gemarra-regular">and they damaged </span>them, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>for the damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gave them wood, </span>and they nevertheless pay the owner the value of a vessel? The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to a case where he gave them <span class="gemarra-regular">a chest, a box, or a cabinet </span>to repair.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">a chest, a box, or a cabinet, it may be inferred that the first clause </span>of the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">wood. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: The latter clause <span class="gemarra-regular">is explaining </span>the first clause. After stating that the craftsmen are liable to pay damages, the mishna explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case is it so that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">to craftsmen to fix, and they damaged </span>them, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay? </span>It is with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">gave a carpenter a chest, a box, or a cabinet.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so too, it is reasonable </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the latter clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches in what </span>case the first clause deems them liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if it enters your mind </span>to think that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is referring to a case where he gave <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>one could ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">told us </span>that if one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable to pay </span>the value of a vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of vessels, is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to tell us that if one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">a chest, a box, or a cabinet, </span>the craftsman is liable to pay damages?
The Gemara dismisses this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is due to that </span>reason, i.e., if that is the manner in which the explanation of the mishna is refuted, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>conclusive <span class="gemarra-regular">argument, </span>because that claim can be refuted by saying that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause, so that you would not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is referring to a case where one gave the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">a chest, a box, or a cabinet, but </span>had he given <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>the carpenter would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the case of one who gave a carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">a chest, a box, or a cabinet </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>and it follows <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that the first clause </span>discusses one who gave the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, and even so </span>the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable to pay </span>damages. It is therefore impossible to prove Rav Asi’s statement from the mishna.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that a mishna (100b) <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of Rav Asi: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives wool to a dyer</span>

Daf 99a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and it was burned in the cauldro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in which it was dyed, the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool. </span>The Gemara infers: The <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool, yes, </span>the dyer must pay that amount, but the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the wool and its enhanced </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he need not pay. The Gemara suggests: Is this <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring to a case where the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">was burned after falling </span>into the cauldron and the dye had taken hold, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is enhanced </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel, </span>and therefore the dyer need not pay the enhanced value?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>This is not a proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">was burned at the moment of falling </span>into the cauldron, before the dye had taken hold, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is no enhancement. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> be if <span class="gemarra-regular">it was burned after falling </span>into the cauldron, when the dye had taken hold? Would the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the owner the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and its enhancement? Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel does not accept </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Asi, </span>and holds that a craftsman does not acquire ownership rights through the enhancement of the vessel?
The Gemara rejects this statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: With what are we dealing here </span>in the mishna? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the wool and herbs </span>used in the dye both <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to the homeowner, and the dyer is taking </span>only the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment of his hand, </span>i.e., the wages for his labor, and nothing else. In this case, the craftsman does not acquire ownership rights through the enhancement of the vessel, but in a case where the craftsman provides the materials, he does acquire such rights.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>i.e., if the homeowner’s herbs were also ruined by the dyer, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>said that the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool and herbs, </span>not just the value of his wool. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Shmuel is </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">dismissing </span>the Gemara’s proof with regard to the statement of Rav Asi that a craftsman acquires a vessel through its enhancement, by saying that the mishna could be understood otherwise. He does not, however, state his own opinion on this matter.
The Gemara offers another suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gave his garment to a craftsman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">concluded </span>the work <span class="gemarra-regular">and notified </span>the owner that the work was complete, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the owner delays paying the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">from now until ten days </span>henceforth, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not violate, for this </span>delay, the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">of: </span>“You shall not oppress your neighbor, nor rob him; the wages of a hired worker <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not abide with you all night </span>until the morning” (Leviticus 19:13). If the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the garment <span class="gemarra-regular">to him at midday, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">once the sun has set </span>and the owner has not paid him, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does violate, for this </span>delay, the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">against delaying </span>the payment of wages.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel, why does </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">violate </span>the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">against delaying </span>the payment of wages? It is as if the craftsman acquired the garment, and the payment is considered to be a purchase of the garment by the owner, rather than a wage.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stating the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the laundering of a thick garment, where there is no enhancement </span>of the garment. Therefore, the craftsman does not acquire it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, to what </span>end <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the owner of the garment <span class="gemarra-regular">give it to </span>the craftsman? He gave it to him in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to soften </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once he has softened it, that is its enhancement, </span>and the craftsman has therefore acquired it. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No;</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">hired </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for treading</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., to forcefully tread on the garment in water until it softens, with the owner paying the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’a</span> coin <span class="gemarra-regular">for each tread. </span>The difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">that this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">hired </span>labor, where the craftsman is paid based on the amount of times he performed an action, and not contractual labor, where he is paid based on the outcome, in this case, a softened garment.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to what entered our minds initially, that </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not hire </span>the worker <span class="gemarra-regular">for treading </span>but rather he hired him like a craftsman based on the assumption that the garment would be returned laundered, this <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Sheshet. As they asked Rav Sheshet: </span>If one hires <span class="gemarra-regular">a contractor, </span>who is not paid an hourly wage but is paid upon the completion of his task, and the one who hired him does not pay him on the day that he completes the work, does he <span class="gemarra-regular">violate, for this </span>delay, the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition against delaying </span>the payment of wages, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>does he <span class="gemarra-regular">not violate </span>the prohibition? <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Sheshet said to them: </span>He does <span class="gemarra-regular">violate </span>the prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>based on this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Sheshet disagrees with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Asi, </span>who holds that a craftsman acquires ownership rights through the enhancement of the vessel, and his payment is not considered to be a wage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel bar Aḥa said: </span>Rav Sheshet is discussing a specific type of contractor, and he stated his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an agent </span>tasked with the delivery <span class="gemarra-regular">of a letter, </span>in which case, since the contractor’s only task is to deliver the letter, there is no enhancement through which he might acquire ownership rights. Consequently the prohibition against delaying the payment of wages applies.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the statement of Rav Asi, that a craftsman acquires ownership rights through the enhancement of the vessel, is the <span class="gemarra-regular">subject of </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>As it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a woman gave gold to a goldsmith, instructing him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fashion bracelets, earrings, or rings for me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and I will be betrothed to you </span>as payment for your work, then <span class="gemarra-regular">once he has fashioned them she is betrothed; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: She is not betrothed until money enters her possession.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>mentioned by the Rabbis? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>i.e., the rings she ordered, then <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference Rabbi Meir </span><span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">money is not </span>required in order for the betrothal to take effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with what </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">he betroth her? </span>He has given her nothing but the jewelry. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is obvious. </span>To <span class="gemarra-regular">what money </span>are the Rabbis referring? They must be referring to when he betroths her via <span class="gemarra-regular">other money, </span>i.e., the payment she owes him for his service. According to the opinion of the Rabbis, in order for the betrothal to take effect he must give her additional money, while according to Rabbi Meir the betrothal takes effect when he gives her the jewelry.
The Gemara prefaces its explanation of the connection to the issue at hand by delineating two assumptions: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>those who say that Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis are engaging in a dispute with regard to the issue of a craftsman acquiring ownership rights through the enhancement of a vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>agrees that the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a wag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is incurred continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the beginning </span>of the period he was hired <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">end, </span>i.e., the obligation to pay for a service begins when the hired party commences work, and the sum owed increases as he proceeds. The fact that he is not paid from the time he commences work establishes the wages as a debt. Consequently, the wages now have the status of a loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>they also assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>agrees that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who betroths </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a loa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">she is not betrothed. </span>She therefore cannot be betrothed to him by not having to pay the wages for his work.
Based on these assumptions, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not that they disagree with regard to</span> whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel? As Rabbi Meir holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman acquires </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel, </span>and since he owns the enhanced value of the vessel, when he gives the jewelry to her he is giving her something valuable of his own, and she is betrothed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman does not acquire </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel, </span>and since a craftsman, in this case, the goldsmith, does not own the jewelry, he cannot betroth a woman with it.
