The Gemara rejects this explanation of the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman does not acquire </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel, but here they disagree with regard to </span>the issue of whether the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a wage </span>is incurred continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the beginning </span>of the period he was hired <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">end.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds </span>that the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a wage </span>is incurred <span class="gemarra-regular">only at</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the end </span>of the period for which he was hired, i.e., the owner is obligated to pay only when the work is complete, and therefore the goldsmith’s wages do not have the status of a loan, but of a sum of money that she becomes obligated to give him at that time. If he gives her the jewelry without asking for that money, it is as though he gave the money from his wages to her, and she may be betrothed with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a wage </span>is incurred continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">from the beginning </span>of the period he was hired <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">end, </span>and therefore his wages have the status of a loan, and she cannot be betrothed with them and must be given additional money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>agrees that the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a wage is </span>incurred continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">from the beginning </span>of the period he was hired <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> its <span class="gemarra-regular">end, and here they disagree with regard to one who betroths </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a loan. As Rabbi Meir holds </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who betroths </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a loan, she is betrothed. And the Rabbis hold </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> betroths </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a loan, she is not betrothed. </span>

Daf 99b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>another interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone </span>agrees that the obligation to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wage </span>is incurred continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">from the beginning </span>of the period a craftsman is hired <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">end; and everyone </span>agrees that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who betroths</span> a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a loan, she is not betrothed; and everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman does not acquire </span>ownership rights <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the vessel.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But with what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he added a jewel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nofekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of his own for her. Rabbi Meir holds </span>that if a man betroths a woman with <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan and one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her mind is </span>focused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Therefore, in this case the jewel serves as the betrothal money. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that if a man betroths a woman with <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan and one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her mind is </span>focused <span class="gemarra-regular">on the loan, </span>so the loan serves as the betrothal money, and if one betroths a woman with a loan, she is not betrothed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">in the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 3:4): If one says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <span class="gemarra-regular">with the payment for which I have worked for you, she is not betrothed, </span>as the payment is a loan, since she already owes him this money. But if he says: Be betrothed to me <span class="gemarra-regular">with the payment for which I will work for you, she is betrothed, </span>as from the moment he is entitled to the money, he gives it to her for her betrothal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: </span>If he says: Be betrothed to me <span class="gemarra-regular">with the payment for which I will work for you, she is not betrothed, </span>as Rabbi Natan holds that the obligation to pay a wage is incurred continuously from the beginning of the period he was hired to its end, which means that upon the completion of the labor it is a loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">and all the more so </span>if he says: Be betrothed to me <span class="gemarra-regular">with the payment for which I have worked for you.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cites a third opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: Actually they said </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">With the payment for which I have worke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for you, or whether </span>he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">With the payment for which I will work for you, she is not betrothed. But if he added a jewel of his own for her, she is betrothed.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is there between the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Natan? </span>The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them</span> is with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a wage: </span>Is the obligation incurred continuously or only upon the completion of the work? The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi </span>is the issue of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan and one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Rabbi Natan holds that if a man betroths a woman with a loan and one <span class="it-text">peruta</span> her mind is focused on the loan, and in this case his jewel is disregarded; and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that her mind is focused on the <span class="it-text">peruta</span>, in this case the jewel, and she is betrothed with the jewel.
§ The Gemara now returns to the topic of a craftsman who damages the item with which he is working. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: An expert butcher who damaged </span>an animal by slaughtering it incorrectly, thereby rendering it non-kosher, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>the owner of the animal for the damage. Why? <span class="gemarra-regular">He is one who causes damage; he is negligent; he is like one who is told </span>by the animal’s owner to <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it from here, </span>i.e., the area of the throat where ritual slaughter is performed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he slaughtered it from there, </span>i.e., a different area of the throat, in violation of the owner’s wishes.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why must he say </span>both that the butcher <span class="gemarra-regular">is one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who causes damage </span>and that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is negligent? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>Shmuel had <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>only that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is one who causes damage, I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only in a case where the butcher slaughtered the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for pay, </span>in which case, due to the extra responsibility that he bears, he is considered to be one who caused damage and is liable to pay even in a case where the damage was unintentional; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does </span>the work <span class="gemarra-regular">for free, </span>I would say <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he is exempt from liability in a case where the damage was unintentional. Shmuel therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the butcher <span class="gemarra-regular">is negligent, </span>and one who works without pay is analogous to an unpaid bailee, who is liable to pay for damage caused by negligence.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama bar Gurya raised an objection to Shmuel </span>from the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (10:10): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives an animal to a butcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the butcher killed it in a way that <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered it an animal carcass, </span>if the butcher is <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert, </span>then he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from liability; if he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>person, without particular expertise in the act of ritual slaughter, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And if </span>the owner of the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>the butcher, then regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>person or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert, </span>the butcher is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage. This indicates that an expert butcher who slaughtered the animal improperly is exempt if he slaughtered it without pay. Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: May your mind be muddle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for raising a ridiculous objection.
<span class="gemarra-regular">One of the Sages came and raised </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">objection to </span>Shmuel. Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Now you shall receive what your friend received </span>from me, since <span class="gemarra-regular">I say to you </span>my statement in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and you say to me, </span>i.e., you raise an objection, based upon the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. Why were you not precise </span>in your consideration of <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>choice of <span class="gemarra-regular">words? As I say: He is one who causes damage; he is negligent; he is like one who is told </span>by the animal’s owner to <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it from here, and he slaughtered it from there. Who accepts this reasoning? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: He should have taken upon himself </span>the responsibility to perform his task properly, and if he did not, he is liable to pay for the damage that he caused. The other <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, who exempt him from liability.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span>is Shmuel referring to? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>that is difficult. Parenthetically, the Gemara states that the letters <span class="gemarra-italic">kuf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">lamed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span> serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the three statements of Rabbi Meir that will be cited. It stands for: He tied it [<span class="it-text">kesharo</span>], to dye [<span class="it-text">litzboa</span>], and broke [<span class="it-text">nishbera</span>].
The Gemara returns to the matter at hand: <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (45b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>ox’s <span class="gemarra-regular">owner tied it with reins </span>to a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">or locked </span>the gate <span class="gemarra-regular">before it in an appropriate manner, but </span>nevertheless the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged and caused damage, whether </span>the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">innocuous or forewarned </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>since this is not considered sufficient precaution to prevent damage; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span>As the Gemara explains on 45b, Rabbi Meir holds that a forewarned ox requires a heightened level of safeguarding, and since the owner did not safeguard it, he is liable. The same would apply here, that one who agrees to perform a task must exercise care in executing it. Otherwise, he will be held liable to pay for damage.
The Gemara explains why this cannot be the statement of Rabbi Meir that Shmuel was referring to: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in that mishna, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the interpretation of biblical <span class="gemarra-regular">verses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> not logical reasoning, as the Gemara explains there, and conclusions cannot be drawn from that <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to this one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span>that Shmuel is referring to, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (100b): If one gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">red for him, and he dyed it black, </span>or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black, and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of his wool, </span>indicating that he is liable to pay for the damage. The Gemara rejects this opinion: This statement also does not prove that according to Rabbi Meir a worker is liable to pay for a job performed improperly, since <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>the wool, thereby removing it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span>that Shmuel is referring to, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">jug broke </span>on the road <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not remove it, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">his camel fell </span>on the road <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not stand it up, Rabbi Meir says: He is liable for the damage </span>that they cause, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say: He is exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. </span>The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we maintain </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the question of whether <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stumbles is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligent. </span>According to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, one who stumbles is considered negligent, since he should have paid attention while walking. He is therefore liable for whatever damage he causes. In the case of an expert butcher as well, Rabbi Meir holds that he is considered negligent when damaging the animal he slaughtered, and the Rabbis hold that he is not negligent and therefore exempt from liability.
The Gemara discusses Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion concerning the case of an expert butcher. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: An expert butcher who damaged </span>an animal by slaughtering it incorrectly, thereby rendering it non-kosher, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the owner of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even if he is as expert as the butchers of Tzippori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is not considered an accident, and he is considered to be at fault. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there was an incident </span>in which a butcher who damaged an animal was brought to court <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yoḥanan in the synagogue of </span>the town <span class="gemarra-regular">Maon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the butcher: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go bring proof that you are an exper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">chickens, and I will exempt you </span>from payment.
The Gemara responds: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the aforementioned incident, the butcher slaughtered the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for free, </span>and he is therefore exempt, while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in Rabba bar bar Ḥana’s previous statement, he slaughtered the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">for pay, </span>and is therefore liable to pay for the damage. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with that which Rabbi Zeira says: One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wants a butcher to be liable to </span>pay <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>in the event that he damages the animal during slaughter should <span class="gemarra-regular">advance him a dinar, </span>so that he is paid for his services, and he is consequently liable to pay damages.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (10:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who brought wheat </span>to another <span class="gemarra-regular">to grind </span>for him, and the miller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not wet </span>the grains sufficiently for the grinding to be performed effectively, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he converted </span>the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">into bra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or coarse bran; </span>or if one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">flour to the baker and he made bread </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">underbake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and tends to crumble; or if one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal to a butcher and </span>the butcher killed it in a way that <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered it </span>an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass, </span>the worker is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, because he is like a paid bailee. </span>This indicates that even if the work was done for free, the worker has the legal status of one who is paid, and he is liable to pay for the damage. The Gemara answers by emending the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because he is a paid bailee </span>and actually receives payment.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>animal that was <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>with an incision <span class="gemarra-regular">not in the nec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was brought before Rav. </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">declared it non-kosher, and exempted the butcher from paying its value. Rav Kahana and Rav Asi encountered that man, </span>i.e., the owner of the animal, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they said to him: Rav did two for you.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>are the <span class="gemarra-regular">two? If we say </span>there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two unfavorable </span>rulings, what are they? One is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have declared </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">kosher, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who says that an animal that has been slaughtered in this manner is kosher, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>instead he <span class="gemarra-regular">declared it non-kosher, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold that it is not kosher. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the second is that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, he should have </span>ruled that <span class="gemarra-regular">the butcher </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the damage. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if these are the two that Rav Kahana and Rav Asi are referring to, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it permitted </span>for them <span class="gemarra-regular">to say this type </span>of statement to the owner of the animal?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>a judge <span class="gemarra-regular">leaves </span>the courthouse, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not say </span>to the litigant: <span class="gemarra-regular">I found you innocen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and my colleagues found you liable, but what can I do, since my colleagues outnumber me? And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>a circumstance such as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “He that goes about as a talebearer reveals secrets; </span>but he that is of a faithful spirit conceals a matter” (Proverbs 11:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the intention is that they told him that there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two favorable </span>rulings: First, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>by declaring the animal to be non-kosher, <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not allow you to eat </span>an item about which there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>as to whether it is <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden, and </span>second, by exempting the butcher from paying you, <span class="gemarra-regular">he prevented you </span>from being in a situation where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>as to whether receiving payment from the butcher constitutes <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, </span>since you would have been given the butcher’s money when he may be exempt, as the animal may in fact be kosher.
§ The Gemara continues the discussion of an expert who erred, thereby causing a loss. It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who presents a dinar to a money change</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to assess its value or authenticity and the money changer declares it valid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, </span>i.e., invalid, causing its owner a monetary loss, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the money changer is <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> while if he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>person he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that irrespective of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>person, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay for the owner’s loss.
To reconcile the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: When </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert is exempt </span>from liability, it is referring to renowned experts <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>the money changers <span class="gemarra-regular">Dankhu and Issur, </span>whose expertise is so great <span class="gemarra-regular">that they do not need to learn </span>about assessing currency <span class="gemarra-regular">at all. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if they are so proficient, <span class="gemarra-regular">in what did they err? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They erred with regard to </span>a coin from <span class="gemarra-regular">a new press</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which at that time was leaving the press, </span>and they did not know its value.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who presented a dinar to Rabbi Ḥiyya </span>to assess its authenticity. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to her: It is a proper </span>coin. <span class="gemarra-regular">The next day she came before him and said to him: I presented it </span>to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they told me </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a bad </span>dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I am not </span>able to <span class="gemarra-regular">spend it. </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav: Go exchange it for her, and write on my tablet </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apinkasi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This </span>was a <span class="gemarra-regular">bad transaction, </span>as I should not have assessed the coin.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Dankhu and Issur, who are exempt due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they do not need to learn </span>about assessing currency? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya too did not need to learn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he was also an expert. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya </span>was not actually required to return a dinar to this woman, but when he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">he acted beyond the letter of the law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef taught </span>concerning the verse: “And you shall show them the way wherein they must walk, and the work that they must do” (Exodus 18:20): <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall show them”; this </span>is referring to

Daf 100a

<span class="gemarra-regular">the core of their existence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Torah study, which is the source of life. <span class="gemarra-regular">“The way”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">acts of kindness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “They must walk”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">visiting the sick. “Wherein”; this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">burial </span>of the dead. <span class="gemarra-regular">“The work”; this </span>is referring to conducting oneself in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the law. “That they must do”; this </span>is referring to conducting oneself <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the letter of the law. </span>This indicates that the Torah mandates that people conduct themselves beyond the letter of the law.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish presented a dinar to Rabbi Elazar </span>so that the latter would assess it. Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">said: It is a proper </span>coin. Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Realize that I am relying on you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What </span>is the purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">of stating that you are relying on me? </span>Is it so <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>this dinar <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, I will be required to exchange it for you </span>with a good dinar? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">you who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rabbi Meir </span>who is of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">liability</span> for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action, even if he did not directly cause damage to the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that you intended to say: This is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, but we do not hold in accordance with his </span>opinion?
Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>I intended to say that this is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and we </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">hold in accordance with his </span>opinion.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span>is Rabbi Elazar referring to? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>that is difficult. Parenthetically, the Gemara states that the letters <span class="gemarra-italic">dalet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">lamed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peh</span> serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the four statements of Rabbi Meir that will be cited. It stands for: Judged [<span class="it-text">dan</span>], to dye [<span class="it-text">litzboa</span>], covers [<span class="it-text">mesakekh</span>], and broke open [<span class="it-text">pirtza</span>].
The Gemara returns to the matter at hand. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 28b): If a judge <span class="gemarra-regular">issued a judgmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and erred, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquitted </span>one who was in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed liable </span>one who should have in fact been <span class="gemarra-regular">acquitted, </span>or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a pure </span>item is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> impure </span>item is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure, </span>and by doing so he caused a litigant a monetary loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">what he did is done, </span>i.e., the judgment stands, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the judge <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from his home, </span>i.e., from his personal funds. He is therefore liable to pay the damages even though he caused the loss indirectly.
The Gemara explains why this cannot be the statement of Rabbi Meir that Shmuel was referring to: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated with regard to that</span> mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ile’a says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: And this </span>mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the judge not only issued a ruling, but actively <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the money from the one whom he found liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave </span>it to the other party <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is not a case of causation but of direct action.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Elazar must be referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Meir, as we learned </span>in a mishna (100b): If one gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">red for him, and he dyed it black, </span>or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black, and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of his wool. </span>The Gemara responds: This too does not prove that according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir one is liable even if the loss was brought about by causation, since <span class="gemarra-regular">there he does </span>cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Elazar must be referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 7:4): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">drapes his grapevin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> atop another’s grain has rendered </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> due to the prohibition against growing diverse kinds in a vineyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to pay the owner of the grain for the damage. The Gemara responds: This too does not prove that according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir one is liable even if the loss was brought about by causation, since <span class="gemarra-regular">there too he does </span>cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 3:3): If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition of a vineyard </span>that is adjacent to a wheat field, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>partition <span class="gemarra-regular">broke open, </span>

Daf 100b

the owner of the wheat field may <span class="gemarra-regular">tell</span> the owner of the vineyard to <span class="gemarra-regular">repair </span>the breach before the vines intermingle with the grain and cause it to become forbidden. If the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">broke open </span>again, he may again <span class="gemarra-regular">tell him </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">repair </span>it. If the owner of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">abandoned </span>the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not repair it, he has rendered </span>the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and is obligated </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">restitution </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This demonstrates that one is liable to pay damages even if he did not perform any action at all, and consequently proves that Rabbi Meir rules there is liability for damage caused by indirect action.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to a dyer and it was burned in the cauldron </span>during the dyeing process, thereby completely ruining the wool so that there is no enhancement, only loss, the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of his wool. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed it unattractively [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka’ur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> so that the dye is not absorbed well by the wool, <span class="gemarra-regular">if the enhancement, </span>i.e., the amount that the value of the wool has increased by being dyed, <span class="gemarra-regular">exceeds the </span>dyer’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">the expenses. And if the expenses exceed the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement, he gives him </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement.</span>
If the owner gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">red for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">he dyed it black</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives</span> the owner of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of his wool. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>Here too, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement exceeds the </span>dyer’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses, </span>the owner of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">the expenses. And if the expenses exceed the enhancement, he gives him </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the mishna mean by <span class="gemarra-regular">unattractively? Rav Naḥman said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Kelabus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does <span class="gemarra-italic">kelabus</span> mean? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Shmuel said: </span>

Daf 101a

<span class="gemarra-regular">The sediments </span>of dye in <span class="gemarra-regular">the cauldrons, </span>that is, the dyer took the dye remaining in the cauldron from previous use, and used that dye for this garment, leading to an inferior result.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives wood to a carpente</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to fashion a chair from it and he fashioned a bench from it </span>instead, or one who gives him wood to fashion <span class="gemarra-regular">a bench and he fashioned a chair from it </span>instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>The carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him the value of his wood </span>and keeps the chair or bench, as he has acquired it due to the change. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>He does not acquire the item. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the value of the wood’s <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement exceeds the </span>carpenter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">the expenses, and if the expenses exceed the enhancement </span>of the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives him </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement. </span>Since the carpenter deviated from the customer’s order, he is entitled to either his expenses or the enhancement, the smaller amount of the two.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Meir concedes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he gave wood to a carpenter to fashion a beautiful chair from it and he fashioned an ugly chair from it, </span>or to fashion <span class="gemarra-regular">a beautiful bench </span>from it <span class="gemarra-regular">and he fashioned an ugly bench </span>from it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the value of the wood’s <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement exceeds the </span>carpenter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the carpenter <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the expenses, and if the expenses exceed the enhancement he gives him the value of the enhancement. </span>Since the carpenter did not deviate significantly from the customer’s instructions, Rabbi Meir concedes that the carpenter does not acquire the item due to the change.
§ In connection with the discussion of the halakhic implications of the enhancement of a garment quoted above, the Gemara records that <span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: What is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? That <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to the woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">substantive, </span>i.e., the dye is considered a separate entity from the wool it dyed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wool </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not substantive, </span>i.e., the dye does not remain an independent entity, and it is viewed as if there is only colored wool?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which this dilemma is relevant? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>the dilemma arises <span class="gemarra-regular">where one robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">pigments, and ground them </span>up <span class="gemarra-regular">and soaked them </span>in water, converting them into dye, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed </span>wool <span class="gemarra-regular">with them, </span>then the dilemma would be concerning how the robber returns the pigments. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the pigments <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a change </span>of form, which occurred when he ground the pigments, and in any event will be obligated to return the value of the pigments at the time of the robbery.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to resolve the dilemma in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">pigments </span>that had already been <span class="gemarra-regular">soaked </span>in water, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed </span>wool <span class="gemarra-regular">with them. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> here? Is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool substantive, </span>i.e., a separate entity, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the robber: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my dyes that you took? Or perhaps the enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wool </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not substantive, </span>but becomes one with the wool, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the robber can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have nothing at all of yours, </span>since the dyes are no longer considered extant.
The Gemara rejects this understanding of the application of the dilemma. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool is not substantive, can </span>the robber really <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I have nothing at all of yours? Let </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Give me my dyes that you have </span>caused to be <span class="gemarra-regular">lost. </span>Even if the dyes are no longer considered extant, the owner is still entitled to monetary compensation for the robbery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the dilemma is relevant <span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">side </span>of the question: Is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wool is not substantive, and </span>therefore the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">needs </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay him? Or perhaps </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool is substantive, and </span>the robber can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>The dyes absorbed into the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">lie before you; take them. </span>The Gemara rejects this as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">Take them? With what </span>should he <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the dyes, <span class="gemarra-regular">with soap?</span> While <span class="gemarra-regular">soap does remove </span>dye from the wool, <span class="gemarra-regular">it does not return </span>the dye to the robbery victim, as the dye cannot be recovered.
The Gemara suggests another scenario: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, with what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he robbed one </span>person of <span class="gemarra-regular">wool and dyes, and dyed that wool with those dyes, and he is returning the </span>dyed <span class="gemarra-regular">wool to him. </span>The dilemma is: Is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wool is substantive, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">returning </span>both the <span class="gemarra-regular">dye and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool to him? Or perhaps enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool is not substantive, and </span>it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">the wool </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is returning to him, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not returning the dye to him, </span>since it is no longer extant.
The Gemara rejects this understanding of the application of the dilemma as well. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case based on the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he increased the value </span>of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>as dyed wool is more expensive than undyed wool. Consequently, even if the robber has not returned the dye, he reimburses the owner for it when he returns the appreciated wool. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to resolve the dilemma in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dye has depreciated. </span>If the dye is viewed as an independent entity the robber is returning both the wool and the dye. If it is not, he must reimburse the robbery victim for the value of the dye at the time of the robbery. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: The dilemma is relevant in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he robbed another of dye and a basket, and <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">basket with </span>the dye, in which case the dye does not increase the value of the dyed item.
The Gemara presents an alternative understanding of the case where the dilemma applies. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">wool that </span>belonged to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and dyes that </span>belonged to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a monkey came and dyed that wool with those dyes. </span>The dilemma is as follows: Is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye </span>provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool is substantive, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of the dye can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the wool: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my dyes that are with you? Or perhaps enhancement </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">dye</span> provides <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wool is not substantive and </span>the owner of the wool can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the dye: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is nothing </span>of yours <span class="gemarra-regular">with me, </span>and he is exempt from liability because the dyes are no longer extant.
Having determined the scenario in which the dilemma is relevant, the Gemara proceeds to resolve the dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Orla</span> 3:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">A garment that one dyed with </span>dye extracted from <span class="gemarra-regular">peels of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., fruit that grows on a tree during its first three years, <span class="gemarra-regular">must be burned, </span>as it is prohibited to derive benefit from <span class="it-text">orla</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the enhancement of an item’s <span class="gemarra-regular">appearance is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span>and the dye therefore remains an independent substance even after having been absorbed by the wool.
The Gemara rejects this resolution. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The reason the garment must be burned is not because the dye remains an independent substance. Rather, it is because <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah prohibited benefit that is visible to the eye, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: “And shall have planted all manner of trees for food, then you shall count the fruit thereof as forbidden; three years shall it be as <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">areilim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to you; <span class="gemarra-regular">it shall not be eaten” </span>(Leviticus 19:23). From this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a prohibition </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">eating </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is it derived that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not</span> even derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not dye with </span>dyes extracted from the fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not light a lamp with </span>oil extracted from the fruit? 
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Then you shall count the fruit thereof [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">orlato</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] as forbidden [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">araltem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>Three years shall it be as <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">areilim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to you; <span class="gemarra-regular">it shall not be eaten” </span>(Leviticus 19:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">to include all these </span>types of benefit in the prohibition. Consequently, there is an explicit derivation that an item dyed with <span class="it-text">orla</span> dye is forbidden.
The Gemara attempts another resolution of the dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from that which was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A garment that one dyed with </span>dye extracted from <span class="gemarra-regular">the peels of </span>produce from the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year must be <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>when the time for the elimination of Sabbatical Year produce arrives. This indicates that the dye evidently remains an independent substance. The Gemara rejects this proof: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, as the verse states: “Shall </span>all the increase thereof <span class="gemarra-regular">be” </span>(Leviticus 25:7), and the phrase: “Shall be,” teaches that it <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">remain as it is, </span>i.e., it retains its status as Sabbatical Year produce despite any change to its form. 

Daf 101b

The Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a contradiction: We learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Orla</span> 3:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">A garment that one dyed with </span>dye extracted from <span class="gemarra-regular">peels of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must be burned. Apparently, </span>the change in <span class="gemarra-regular">appearance </span>precipitated by the <span class="it-text">orla</span> peels <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span>and the dye retains its status as <span class="it-text">orla</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raise a contradiction </span>from another mishna (<span class="it-text">Oholot</span> 3:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">log</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of bloo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from a corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">that was absorbed in </span>the floor of <span class="gemarra-regular">a house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> every vessel in <span class="gemarra-regular">the house is ritually impure </span>by virtue of being under the same roof as the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>that any vessel in <span class="gemarra-regular">the house is ritually pure. And </span>these two statements <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> first statement was <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to vessels that were </span>in the house <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset, </span>before the blood was absorbed; and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>second statement was <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to vessels that came </span>into the house <span class="gemarra-regular">at the end, </span>after the blood had already been absorbed.
The mishna continues: If the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">was absorbed in a garment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">examined, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if the garment is washed and a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">log</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of blood emerges from it, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is ritually impure, </span>and the garment imparts ritual impurity to the vessels in the house as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if not, </span>i.e., if less than a quarter-<span class="it-text">log</span> of blood emerges, then it <span class="gemarra-regular">is pure, </span>and it does not impart impurity. Apparently, only the blood that can be removed from the garment is considered blood, while the blood absorbed in the garment is insignificant. If this is the case, the change in appearance precipitated by the blood is not considered a significant matter, and the blood absorbed in the garment does not remain an independent substance.
The Gemara presents an answer. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: </span>A <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>among <span class="gemarra-regular">the leniencies </span>applied to the measurements <span class="gemarra-regular">of a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">log</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">taught here, </span>as the mishna is written <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to the blood of submissio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that is discharged from a body at the time of death, and such blood is ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, </span>but in general, a change in appearance precipitated by blood is significant.
§ Having cited a contradiction raised by Rava, the Gemara proceeds to cite another. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction. We learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 7:1): Concerning plants <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>among <span class="gemarra-regular">the species that </span>are used as <span class="gemarra-regular">dyes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for example the <span class="gemarra-italic">sefiḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., produce that grew without being intentionally planted, <span class="gemarra-regular">of woa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and safflower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they have </span>sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">and money </span>exchanged for <span class="gemarra-regular">them has </span>sanctity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year. Additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">eradication</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and money </span>exchanged for <span class="gemarra-regular">them is </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">eradication. Apparently, wood, </span>a type of inedible growth, <span class="gemarra-regular">is subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical </span>Year despite the fact that it is not edible.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And raise a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">reed leave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and vine leaves that one piled for storag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon the field, </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">gathered them for eating, they are subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical </span>Year; if he gathered them <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>use as <span class="gemarra-regular">wood, </span>e.g., for kindling a fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical </span>Year. Apparently, wood or any other non-food product is not subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">answers </span>the contradiction, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: </span>“And the Sabbath produce of the land shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">for food </span>for you” (Leviticus 25:6), indicating that the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year takes effect only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to those </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">whose benefit and whose consumption coincide, </span>as is the case with regard to food. <span class="gemarra-regular">Wood is excluded, as its benefit follows its consumption.</span> The primary purpose of kindling wood is not accomplished with the burning of the wood; rather, it is with the charcoal that heats the oven. Therefore, wood is not subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there wood </span>that is used to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">heat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose benefit coincides with its consumption,</span> as one enjoys the warmth provided by the fire while the wood is burned?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>

Daf 102a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Unspecified wood exists for fuel, </span>i.e., charcoal, so its benefit follows its consumption.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says: And </span>the matter of whether <span class="gemarra-regular">kindling wood, </span>whose benefit follows its consumption, is subject to the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute among the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 6:25): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not transfer Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., wine, to another person; <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for soaking </span>flax to prepare it for spinning, as the benefit derived from the flax follows its soaking, when the soaked and spun thread is woven into a garment; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor or for launderin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> with it, as the benefit derived follows the laundering when one wears the clean clothes. Soaking the flax or laundering the garment in wine is considered the consumption of the wine, as it is no longer potable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: One may transfer </span>to another <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">produce for soaking and for laundering.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning </span>for the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis? The verse states </span>with regard to Sabbatical Year produce: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For food” </span>(Leviticus 25:6), from which it is inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not for soaking; “for food,” but not for laundering. And Rabbi Yosei says </span>that it is permitted, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “For you,”</span> from which it is inferred: For you, <span class="gemarra-regular">for all your needs, </span>even for soaking and for laundering.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis as well, isn’t it written: “For you”? </span>How do they explain that term? The Gemara answers: From that term “for you” it is derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For you,” similar to “for food,” </span>i.e., the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year takes effect <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to those </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">whose benefit and whose consumption coincide, </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes soaking and laundering, where </span>the items’ <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit follows their consumption.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei as well, isn’t it written: “For food”? </span>Rabbi Yosei could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: That </span>term <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For food,” but not for a poultice [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">melogema</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say “for food” but not for a poultice, or </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">it is only “for food” but not for laundering? When </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">says: “For you,” laundering is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>as permitted since it includes all of one’s bodily needs. <span class="gemarra-regular">How do I realize </span>the meaning of that which the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For food”? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">“for food” but not for a poultice.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. Should one ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what did you see </span>that led you <span class="gemarra-regular">to include the </span>use of Sabbatical Year produce for <span class="gemarra-regular">laundering and to exclude the </span>use of Sabbatical Year produce as <span class="gemarra-regular">a poultice? </span>Perhaps the opposite should be said. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">I include the </span>use for <span class="gemarra-regular">laundering, which </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">equally to every person, </span>as everyone needs clean clothes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I exclude the </span>use as <span class="gemarra-regular">a poultice, which </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">equally to every person; </span>it is only for the ill wounded.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to Sabbatical Year produce: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For food,” but not for a poultice; “for food,” but not for sprinklin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> wine in one’s house to provide a pleasant fragrance; <span class="gemarra-regular">“for food,” but not to make an emetic [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apiktevizin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it </span>to induce vomiting? <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, as, if </span>it were <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, is there </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">also soaking and laundering </span>that should have been excluded from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as in the Rabbis’ opinion the use of Sabbatical Year produce for those purposes is forbidden?
§ The mishna (100b) teaches that if the owner gave wool to a dyer to dye it red and instead he dyed it black, Rabbi Meir says: The dyer gives the owner of the wool the value of his wool. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: If </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span>exceeds the dyer’s expenses, the owner of the wool gives the dyer the expenses. If the expenses exceed the enhancement, he gives him the value of the enhancement. The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device, the acrostic <span class="gemarra-italic">saban</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>for the names of the Sages involved in the following incident; each letter in the acrostic represents the middle letter of one of the names: <span class="it-text">Samekh</span>, Rav Yosef; <span class="it-text">beit</span>, Rabbi Abba; <span class="it-text">nun</span>, Rav Huna. 
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef was sitting behind Rabbi Abba, </span>and they were both sitting <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Huna. And Rav Huna was sitting and saying: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef turned his face </span>in disdain of Rav Huna’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said: Granted, </span>stating that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa is necessary, </span>as it would <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that there is a principle that when there is a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">many, </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the many. </span>Rav Huna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in this case the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa, despite the fact that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual.</span>
The Gemara interrupts Rav Yosef’s remark and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span> the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa </span>to which Rav Huna is referring? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, one may not collec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>gentiles near the time of their holidays, but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>agreement, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may collect from </span>gentiles even near the time of their holidays, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the creditor is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as one who salvages </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from their possession.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to the statement that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, why do I </span>need it? This <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>an example of the Mishna recording <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute, and afterward </span>recording only one side of that dispute as <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed opinion. And </span>the principle is that when the Mishna records <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute, and afterward </span>records only one side of that dispute as <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed opinion, </span>then the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</span>
The Gemara identifies the dispute and the unattributed mishna. The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>is found <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Bava</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Kamma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If one gave wool to a dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to dye </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">red for him and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">he dyed it black, </span>or to dye it <span class="gemarra-regular">black and he dyed it red, Rabbi Meir says: </span>The dyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the owner of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of his wool. Rabbi Yehuda says: If </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement exceeds the expenses, </span>the owner of the wool <span class="gemarra-regular">gives the expenses to </span>the dyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the expenses exceed the enhancement, he gives him </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement. And the unattributed </span>mishna appears <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Bava</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Metzia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as we learned </span>in a mishna there (76a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Whoever changes </span>from the terms of an agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">is at a disadvantage, and whoever renege</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>an agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">is at a disadvantage. </span>This unattributed mishna accords with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that a craftsman who deviates from his assignment receives either the expenses or the enhancement, whichever is of lesser value.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>being that this is a dispute and afterward an unattributed opinion, why did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>find it necessary to state that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> follows the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is necessary, </span>as it would <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Mishna is not sequential and, </span>in fact, this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">followed by a dispute. And </span>why does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>disagree? He disagrees because <span class="gemarra-regular">if that is so, </span>then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">every </span>case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute </span>is recorded <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward an unattributed </span>opinion is recorded, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say: The Mishna is not sequential, and </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">followed by a dispute.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna </span>would respond: The situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Mishna is not sequential, </span>i.e., where we say that the Mishna is sequential, is only when both <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> appear <span class="gemarra-regular">in one tractate, but </span>when they appear <span class="gemarra-regular">in two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">tractates we say </span>that the Mishna is not sequential.
