Since these <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> are found in two different tractates, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> and <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span>, the assumption is that the Mishna is not sequential. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef </span>would respond: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Nezikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span>, and <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Batra</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is one tractate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>that even if <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> and <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> are to be considered two separate tractates, Rav Yosef would still hold that Rav Huna’s statement was unnecessary <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>as one of a pair <span class="gemarra-regular">of established </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Whoever changes</span> from the terms of an agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">is at a disadvantage, and whoever reneges </span>on an agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">is at a disadvantage. </span>Since this ruling was taught with another, established <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, it is apparent that this is also an established <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
§ The Gemara notes another dispute concerning one who deviates from the terms of an agreement. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 4:20): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who gives money to his agent</span>

Daf 102b

<span class="gemarra-regular">to purchase wheat for him, </span>which he plans to sell at a profit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>instead the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased barley with </span>the money, or if he gave his agent money to purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">barley and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">he purchased wheat with </span>the money, two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> issue discordant rulings with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there was a loss</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the loss is for </span>the agent, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if there was a profit, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">profit is for </span>the agent as well, as he is considered to have abrogated his status as an agent by deviating from the instructions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 4:20) that if there was an agreement that both parties would split the profits from the transaction, <span class="gemarra-regular">if there was a loss, the loss is for </span>the agent, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if there was a profit, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">profit </span>goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middle,</span> i.e., the agent and the investor split the profit.
To reconcile the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and this </span>second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains his rationale: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>by an agent that deviates from the terms of his assignment means that the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the item in question for himself, as in the case of one who was paid to dye wool red but dyed it black. In this case as well, when the agent purchases wheat instead of barley, or vice versa, he acquires the grain for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a change </span>by an agent which deviates from the terms of his assignment does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>mean that the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the item in question for himself. It is acquired by the one who appointed the agent, and they split the profits as agreed. But the agent is held responsible for any loss incurred, due to his deviation from the instructions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar objects to this </span>explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you say that the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda extends to the case of these <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rabbi Meir says </span>that a change by an agent from the terms of his assignment results in the acquisition of the item by the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to an item that is fit for </span>use by the one who appointed the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">himself, </span>such as wool dyed the wrong color, which is now not usable for its intended purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say </span>his ruling with regard to an item purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>subsequent sale as <span class="gemarra-regular">merchandise, </span>since it is intended to be sold for a profit in any event, and the transaction would take effect as agreed upon initially, with the agent held responsible for any loss incurred.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: </span>Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are written in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is discussing grain purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">for eating, </span>and since the one who appointed the agent desired wheat, he does not acquire the barley. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is discussing grain purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>subsequent sale as <span class="gemarra-regular">merchandise, </span>and the transaction takes effect as agreed upon initially, with the agent held responsible for any loss incurred.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">they laughed at it in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, at the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>who said that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda, </span>a deviation by an agent from the terms of his assignment does not result in the acquisition of the item for the agent himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">And who informed the owner of the wheat, </span>i.e., the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he should transfer the wheat to the owner of the money? </span>If the seller was unaware that the agent was acting on someone else’s behalf, how would the one who appointed the agent acquire the wheat? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Sasrati objects to this </span>rationale: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case where the agent was sent to purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and </span>he purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the one who appointed the agent should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquire the wheat, since the seller was unaware that the agent was acting on someone else’s behalf.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu said: </span>The case of an agent who was assigned to purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and </span>purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat is different, as </span>the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">is performing his assignment and, </span>as such, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is like the customer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the one who appointed him, and it is as though the latter has purchased the grain himself.
Rabbi Abbahu further explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that the agent is viewed as an extension of the one who appointed him, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 24a): Concerning both <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrates his propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one who valuates himself </span>by donating his fixed value to the Temple, the Temple treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> any rights <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the donor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife’s clothing; and not with regard to his children’s clothing; and not with regard to </span>new clothes colored with <span class="gemarra-regular">dye that the </span>donor <span class="gemarra-regular">dyed for </span>his wife or children; <span class="gemarra-regular">and not with regard to new sandal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that</span> the donor <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased for </span>his wife or children. Presumably, the treasurer has no right to these items because they are for the personal use of the donor’s wife and children, and are considered as if owned by them.
Rabbi Abbahu continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>is it so, i.e., why is it that the wife is considered the owner of the dyed clothing for which the husband paid? <span class="gemarra-regular">Here also, let </span>us <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Who informed the dyer that he should transfer his dye to the wife? Rather, is it not because we say that </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">is performing his assignment and, </span>as such, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>an extension of <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife’s hand? Here also, </span>in the case of one who purchases grain for another, the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">is performing his assignment, and is like </span>an extension of the <span class="gemarra-regular">customer’s hand.</span>
The Gemara rejects this explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said: No, </span>the reason for the ruling of the mishna is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the intention of anyone who consecrates his property is not upon the clothing of his wife and his children, </span>i.e., he does not intend to consecrate those items.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira objects to </span>Rabbi Abba’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is it the intention of a person </span>who consecrates his property to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">upon his phylacteries? </span>Presumably not. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 23b) that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrates </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries are evaluated for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> and consecrated. Apparently, lack of intent to consecrate a particular item does not prevent its consecration. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rabbi Zeira: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, the intention of a person </span>who consecrates his property <span class="gemarra-regular">is upon </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrates his property thinks </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am performing a mitzva, </span>and he therefore intends to include his phylacteries; <span class="gemarra-regular">but the intention of a person is not upon the clothing of his wife and his children, due to the enmity </span>that would be engendered if he consecrated their clothing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Oshaya </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to </span>Rabbi Abba’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is it not </span>so that the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">those who are obligated in valuations was taught here </span>in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 21a): Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">those who are obligated in valuations, </span>the Temple treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">seizes collateral from them </span>to force them to fulfill their vow. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And is the intention of a person upon himself </span>to allow the treasurer <span class="gemarra-regular">to seize collateral from him? </span>Presumably not. Nevertheless, collateral is seized from him, proving that one’s intention does not prevent consecration. Accordingly, even if it is assumed that he does not intend to consecrate the clothing of his wife or children, the clothing should nevertheless be consecrated. Why, then, is the clothing of his wife or children not consecrated?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Abba </span>also holds that the reason the clothing is not consecrated is not due to his intent, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>a different explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anyone who consecrates his property becomes as one who transferred his wife’s and his children’s clothing to them at the outset. </span>Therefore, the clothing did not belong to him at the time that he consecrated his property.
§ The Gemara presents another situation in which one makes a purchase involving a third party. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field in the name of another, he is not compelled to sell </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to him </span>at the time of the sale: I will purchase the field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that he will sell it to me, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is compelled to sell </span>it.
Noting the ambiguity of this statement, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> saying? Rav Sheshet said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field from another, </span>claiming that he is acting <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of the Exilarc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> or another dominant figure, so that others will be discouraged from contesting the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Exilarch is not compelled to sell </span>it to him, i.e., the Exilarch is not required to provide the purchaser with documentation that the field belongs to the purchaser. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the seller: I will purchase the field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that the Exilarch will provide me with that documentation, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Exilarch is compelled to sell </span>it to him, i.e., to provide him with the documentation.
The Gemara questions Rav Sheshet’s interpretation. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field in the name of the Exilarch, the Exilarch is not compelled to sell </span>it to him. Since the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches only that the Exilarch is not required to provide the purchaser with documentation that the field is his, it can be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Let us say that </span>this interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: And who informed the owner of the wheat that he should transfer the wheat to the customer? </span>Since the seller assumed he was selling the field to the Exilarch, the Sages of Eretz Yisrael would hold that the sale does not take effect. 
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to this </span>inference that it is surmised that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in conflict with the opinion of the Sages of Eretz Yisrael, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as it can be said that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">informed the owner of the field and informed the witnesses </span>that he intends to purchase the field for himself.
The Gemara rejects Rav Sheshet’s interpretation for a different reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>is difficult, as it states that if the purchaser said to the seller: I will purchase the field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that the Exilarch will sell it to me, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Exilarch is compelled to sell </span>it to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why</span> should the Exilarch be compelled to provide the purchaser with documentation? <span class="gemarra-regular">But let the Exilarch say: I do not desire your esteem nor do I desire your disgrace, </span>i.e., I am not involved in your affairs. Since the Exilarch had not been party to the negotiations, how can a stipulation stated by the purchaser render him obligated?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye said: This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field in the name of his friend, the Exilarch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 103a

<span class="gemarra-regular">the seller is not compelle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to sell </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">another time, </span>i.e., to provide the purchaser with a document denoting him as the owner of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to him: </span>I will purchase the field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the conditio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that you will provide a deed in my name, <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller is compelled to sell </span>the field again, i.e., to provide the purchaser with a document denoting him as the owner.
The Gemara clarifies the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field in the name of another, the seller is not compelled to sell </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">another time. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the seller: <span class="gemarra-regular">You knew that I took, </span>i.e., purchased, the field <span class="gemarra-regular">for myself, and it was merely </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">protection [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ufanaḥya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that I desired </span>to obtain ownership by claiming to purchase it in the name of the other person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I do not throw </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">money for naught. Rather, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with the intention that you will write another document for him, </span>i.e., the seller, stating that I purchased the field. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the seller can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I have performed a matter for you together with the one in whose name you purchased</span> the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him write you another document.</span>
The Gemara discusses Abaye’s interpretation of the latter clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to him: </span>I will purchase the field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that you will provide a deed in my name, <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller is compelled to sell </span>the field again. Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">said to the witnesses in front of </span>the seller: You can <span class="gemarra-regular">see that I require another document. Lest you say </span>that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I thought </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a document from the one in whose name you purchased </span>the field that <span class="gemarra-regular">you were saying </span>you required, and not from me. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the purchaser can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I took the trouble and said to the witnesses, in front of you, </span>that I require another document, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is from you that I require </span>the document.
§ The Gemara mentions a related incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana gave money </span>to a salesman in exchange <span class="gemarra-regular">for flax, </span>and temporarily left the flax in the possession of the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">flax appreciated </span>in value and the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the flax sold it </span>for a greater profit on behalf of Rav Kahana, intending to give him all of the money. Rav Kahana then <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What should I do? Should I go and take my money, </span>or would doing so have the appearance of collecting interest for a loan? Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: <span class="gemarra-regular">If, when they sold </span>the flax, <span class="gemarra-regular">they said: This flax is Kahana’s, go take </span>the money, as in such a case it is as though the flax was purchased directly from you. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say this, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not take </span>the money, since you would be receiving a greater sum of money than you provided, and this would appear to be a loan repaid with interest.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion was Rav’s ruling? Was it only <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: Who informed the owner of the wheat that he should transfer the wheat to the owner of the money? </span>As the Gemara taught earlier, the Sages of Eretz Yisrael hold that the sale can be performed on another’s behalf only if such an arrangement is explicitly stated at the time of the transaction. In this case as well, if the seller did not explicitly state that the money would belong to Rav Kahana, all the money from the sale would be acquired by the seller, who would then be prohibited to give it to Rav Kahana due to the appearance of paying interest. 
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say that Rav Kahana gave four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and took eight </span>in return? He did not lend money to the seller. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">the flax appreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>and when the seller sold it <span class="gemarra-regular">he robbed </span>Rav Kahana of his flax, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we learned </span>in a mishna (93b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">all robbers pay </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the value of the stolen item at <span class="gemarra-regular">the time of the robbery. </span>Therefore, according to all opinions the seller owes Rav Kahana the value of the flax at the time the seller sold it for its appreciated value, and Rav Kahana’s accepting the money would not constitute collecting interest for a loan.
Having rejected the previous explanation of Rav’s ruling, the Gemara presents an alternative understanding of the case. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: There, it was </span>a matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust, </span>as the seller was paid in advance <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Kahana did not pull the flax </span>as an act of acquisition, or perform any other formal act of acquisition. Consequently, at the time of the second sale the flax belonged to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rav says: One may make </span>an arrangement of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust with regard to </span>the delivery of items such as <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one may pay the money in advance with the agreement that he will receive the produce at a later date, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not make </span>an arrangement of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust with regard to money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one may not pay the money in advance with the agreement that he will receive the value of the produce at a later date, as this has the appearance of collecting interest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who robs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of an item having <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and takes </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath to </span>the robbery victim claiming his innocence, and then later wishes to repent, must <span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>the money, which includes the principal together with an additional one-fifth payment, to the robbery victim, even if this necessitates following <span class="gemarra-regular">after him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a distant place like <span class="gemarra-regular">Medea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">may not give </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robbery victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to return it to the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and neither </span>may he give it <span class="gemarra-regular">to his agent, but he may give </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to an agent of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, he returns it to his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">the principa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> value of the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not give him </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth</span> payment, or if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">forgave him concerning the principal but did not forgive him concerning </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth</span> payment, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he forgave him concerning this and concerning that, with the exception of the value of less than one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the principal, he need not pursue him </span>to repay the remaining debt. By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>the robbery victim the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not give him the principal, </span>or if the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">forgave him concerning </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not forgive him concerning the principal, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he forgave him concerning this and concerning that, with the exception of the value of one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the principal, he must pursue him </span>to repay the remaining debt.
If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal and took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath to him concerning </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, asserting that he had already paid it, 

Daf 103b

then the additional one-fifth is considered a new principal obligation. The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> payment about which he had taken a false oath. If he then takes a false oath concerning the second one-fifth payment, he is assessed an additional one-fifth payment for that oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">until the principal, </span>i.e., the additional one-fifth payment about which he has most recently taken the false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">is reduced to less than the value of one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And such </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a deposit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: </span>“If anyone sins, and commits a trespass against the Lord, and he defrauds his counterpart <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a deposit, or with regard to a pledge, or with regard to a robbery, or if he exploited his counterpart; or he has found that which was lost, and deals falsely with it, and swears to a lie</span>…he shall restore it in full, and shall add the fifth part more to it” (Leviticus 5:21–24). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if a robber took a false oath that he did not rob, he must travel even as far as Medea in order to repay the robbery victim. This indicates that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes an oath to </span>the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he is required to go to any length to repay his obligation, but if he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not take an oath to him, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he does not have to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon and not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Yevamot</span> 118b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed one of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> people <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does not know which of them </span>he robbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and each one </span>of the five <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He robbed me, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">places </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and withdraws </span>from them; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Tarfon. Rabbi Akiva says: This is not </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">way to spare him from transgression. </span>He is not considered to have returned the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pays </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item to each and every one </span>of the five.
The Gemara clarifies: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is the mishna written? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, </span>it is not so, because <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>that he did not rob, Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He places </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item between them and withdraws; </span>it is not his responsibility to ensure that it reaches the robbery victim. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>it is also not so, because <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>necessarily <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>He is not considered to have returned the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pays </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item to each and every one </span>of the five, while the mishna rules that his obligation is contingent upon his having taken the false oath.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, and when Rabbi Akiva says </span>that the robber is not considered to have returned the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pays </span>the value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item to each and every one </span>of the five, it is only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath that </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>this. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? As the verse states </span>with regard to one who takes a false oath concerning a financial obligation: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Unto him to whom it appertains shall he give it, on the day of his being guilty” </span>(Leviticus 5:24). The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the guilty party must make a rigorous effort to return what he owes is stated in the case of one who took a false oath, and Rabbi Akiva would state his ruling only in that case.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon </span>rule that a robber who took a false oath is not required to pay all claimants, being that the verse indicates otherwise? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though he took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>and by Torah law is obligated to return the stolen item to the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages instituted an ordinance </span>allowing him to place it between the five possible victims, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted a great ordinanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that if the expense </span>required to return a stolen item to the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is greater than the principal, </span>the robber may <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to the court, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">brings his guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and achieves atonement for himself. </span>This ordinance would apply here as well, as the expense required to pay all five claimants is greater than the principal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva </span>agree that the Sages instituted this ordinance? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Akiva holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Sages instituted the ordinance, </span>they did so only for cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">knows whom he robbed, as </span>in such cases <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>definitely <span class="gemarra-regular">returning the money to its owner </span>by depositing it with the court, who will convey it to the robbery victim. But in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed one of five </span>people, <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not know whom he robbed, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>by merely placing the stolen item between the five of them <span class="gemarra-regular">the money is not returned to its owner, the Sages did not institute an ordinance.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Yehuda raises an objection </span>to the explanation that Rabbi Akiva stated his opinion specifically in a case where the robber took an oath. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Yevamot</span> 14:2) states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva did not disagree with regard to one who purchased </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> people <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not know from which of them he purchased </span>it, as both agree <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">he places the money of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">purchase between them and withdraws. </span>Since the purchaser has not transgressed, he is not penalized by being required to suffer the loss of paying each of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what did they disagree? </span>They disagree with regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who robbed one of five people, and he does not know from which of them he robbed </span>the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Tarfon says: He places the stolen item between them and withdraws, and Rabbi Akiva says: He has no remedy, </span>i.e., he has not fulfilled his obligation to return the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pays </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the stolen item to each and every one </span>of them.
Rav Huna bar Yehuda states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind that </span>Rabbi Akiva stated his ruling specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>an item from another, and <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> him? In either case he has transgressed the prohibition against taking a false oath denying his obligation, and he should be penalized by being required to ensure that the one to whom he owes the money receives it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava raises another objection </span>to the explanation that Rabbi Akiva stated his opinion specifically in a case where the robber took an oath. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain pious </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who purchased </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">two people, and he did not know from which of them he purchased </span>the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he came before Rabbi Tarfon </span>for a ruling. Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Place the money of your purchase between them and withdraw. He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Akiva, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have no remedy until you pay each and every one, </span>i.e., both of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that Rabbi Akiva stated his ruling specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, does a pious </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">take a false oath? </span>It seems from this incident that Rabbi Akiva rules he must pay all potential owners regardless of whether or not he took a false oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say that </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">he took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath and later became a pious </span>man, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>isn’t there a tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that we say: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain pious </span>man, the pious man is <span class="gemarra-regular">either Rabbi Yehuda ben Bav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Elai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava and Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Elai, were </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">pious </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">from the beginning.</span>
Due to these objections, the Gemara offers an alternative explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna here <span class="gemarra-regular">is actually </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, and Rabbi Tarfon concedes </span>that a robber must pay every potential owner in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span>as is the case in the mishna here. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? As the verse states: “Unto him to whom it appertains shall he give it, in the day of his being guilty” </span>(Leviticus 5:24). This verse, which requires one to go to any length to return money owed, is referring specifically to one who takes a false oath concerning his financial obligation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva, who said </span>in the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Yevamot</span> that a robber must pay all potential owners <span class="gemarra-regular">even though he did not take </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span>agrees that the verse is referring specifically to one who takes a false oath, but holds that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">penalize </span>the robber by obligating him to pay them all in any event.
The Gemara questions this explanation of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon, after all, </span>the mere fact that it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath is not sufficient </span>to obligate him to pay the additional one-fifth and to bring a guilt-offering if it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">admi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that he took a false oath and owes the money. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>would the mishna here <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>state: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even without </span>taking the false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span>the robber should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be obligated to pursue the owner as a result of his having admitted his obligation. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tarfon concedes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where a robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to two </span>people: <span class="gemarra-regular">I robbed one of you </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and I do not know which of you </span>it was, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives one hundred dinars to this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dinars to that </span>person, 

Daf 104a

<span class="gemarra-regular">as he has already admitted </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">on his own</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Tarfon concedes that a robber who wishes to repent must go to any length to return the stolen item to its owner. If the mishna here is in accordance with his opinion, it should not have stated its ruling specifically in a case where the robber took a false oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>The case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated here could be in accordance with the opinions of both Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva. <span class="gemarra-regular">For as </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">knows whom he robbed and admitted to him </span>that he robbed him, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is possible to return the money to its owner, </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">is as the one who says to </span>the robber: The money you owe me <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span>kept <span class="gemarra-regular">in your possession </span>as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">for me. Therefore, </span>in a case where the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the owner is considered to have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The money you owe me <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span>kept <span class="gemarra-regular">in your possession </span>as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, since </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">requires atonement </span>for his false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not possible </span>for him to achieve atonement <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">reaches the possession of </span>the robbery victim. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case where the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not take </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the money <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered as a <span class="gemarra-regular">deposit </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and takes it.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that if the robber wishes to return the stolen item, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not give </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robbery victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>to return it to the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor to his agent. </span>The Gemara comments: It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an agent who was appointed in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to collect a debt from another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>Such an agent <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent, </span>so that the debtor is considered to have repaid his debt as soon as he transfers the money to the agent, and the debtor will not be held responsible if an accident occurs causing the loss of the money before the agent gives it to the creditor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>Such an agent <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent, </span>and the debtor remains responsible until the money reaches the creditor’s possession.
The Gemara explains their respective opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">is an agent </span>because it was <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>reason that the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">took the trouble and appointed </span>the agent <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, in order to place </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">under </span>the agent’s <span class="gemarra-regular">domain. Rabba said </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not an agent </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>assumed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>to the debtor: This individual <span class="gemarra-regular">is a trustworthy person. If you </span>are willing to <span class="gemarra-regular">rely </span>on him, then <span class="gemarra-regular">rely </span>on him to convey the payment to me. Similarly: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish to send </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">send </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession.</span>
The Gemara cites a mishna that poses a difficulty to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 98b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>enters into an agreement to <span class="gemarra-regular">borrow a co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> from another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sent it </span>to the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">son, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">agent, or </span>if he sent it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the borrower’s son, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">agent, and </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the borrower is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the cow, as it never entered his possession.
The Gemara explains the case of the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this agent of </span>the borrower, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances </span>surrounding his appointment? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not appoint </span>him as his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, how do we know </span>that he was appointed as an agent? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he appointed </span>him as his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, and </span>yet the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the borrower is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>This poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, </span>who holds that one acquires property through his agent. According to his reasoning, the borrower should be held responsible for the cow once it reaches the possession of the agent.
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>concerning a different mishna: This is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his hired </span>hand <span class="gemarra-regular">or his </span>regular <span class="gemarra-regular">harvester</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here also </span>the mishna in <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his hired </span>hand <span class="gemarra-regular">or his </span>regular <span class="gemarra-regular">harvester. </span>The mishna discusses a case where there were no witnesses to the appointment of the agent, and therefore it does not pose a difficulty to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda. Yet, since it is well known that this person is constantly in the owner’s service, he is assumed to be acting as his agent.
The Gemara poses a difficulty to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda from the mishna here. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: If the robber wishes to return the stolen item, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not give </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robbery victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>to return it to the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor to his agent. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this agent of </span>the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances </span>surrounding his appointment? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">did not appoint him </span>as his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, how do we know </span>that he was appointed as an agent? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">appointed him </span>as his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>and the robber nevertheless does not fulfill his obligation to return the stolen item by giving it to this agent? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda interpreted </span>the ruling of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his hired </span>hand <span class="gemarra-regular">or his </span>regular <span class="gemarra-regular">harvester, </span>who do not require witnesses to validate their appointment as his agent.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an agent who </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">appointed in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would one say that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, </span>one appointed before witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent? </span>If that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">instead of teaching </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause: But he may give </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to an agent of the court, </span>which indicates that this is the only agent to whom he may give it, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">make a distinction within </span>the case of an agent appointed by the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">itself and teach: An agent who </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">appointed in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses is indeed </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent. </span>If an agent appointed in the presence of witnesses is a legally recognized agent, why does the mishna shift to discuss an agent of the court?
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Although the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna could have stated the case of an agent appointed by the robbery victim in the presence of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have stated this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">definitively, </span>as with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an agent of the court, </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>whether the <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery victim appointed him </span>as an agent, i.e., the court appointed him at the behest of the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>whether the <span class="gemarra-regular">robber appointed him </span>as an agent, i.e., the court appointed him at the behest of the robber. In both cases <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>could state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning an agent of the court <span class="gemarra-regular">definitively. </span>By contrast, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an agent who was appointed in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, that </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery victim appointed him </span>as an agent <span class="gemarra-regular">he is an agent, </span>but when the <span class="gemarra-regular">robber appointed him </span>as an agent, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not an agent, </span>as the robber cannot appoint an agent to receive payment on behalf of the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have stated this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">definitively.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this mishna, which rules that an agent of the court is an agent even if appointed only by the robber, serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>following <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (10:11) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">an agent of the court who was appointed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery victim but not appointed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">robber, or </span>an agent who <span class="gemarra-regular">was appointed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">robber, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the other, </span>i.e., the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">and took his </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the agent’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, </span>the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for any accidental damage to the payment during the delivery. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar states that the robber is exempt from paying for any accidental damage when he gave the payment to a court agent he appointed only if the robbery victim sent for and took possession of the payment. This is in opposition to the ruling of the mishna that the robber is exempt whenever he gives the payment to an agent of the court.
The Gemara cites the opinion of two other <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> with regard to the status of an agent appointed in the presence of witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar both say: An agent who was appointed in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses is </span>a legally recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">agent. And if you say: Our mishna </span>contradicts this assertion, as it rules that the stolen item is not considered returned if given to an agent of the robbery victim, this is of no concern.
The Gemara explains: The mishna does not mean to disqualify an agent appointed by the robbery victim in the presence of witnesses, but rather is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">provides </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">with an agen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> without appointing him in the presence of witnesses, in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he says to </span>someone: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have money </span>owed to me that is currently <span class="gemarra-regular">with so-and-so, and he is not sending it. Present yourself to him, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>he wishes to return it but <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot find a person with whom to send it. </span>
The Gemara offers a second explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>that the mishna is not discussing a case where he appointed the agent in the presence of witnesses, but it is still known that the agent acts on behalf of the robbery victim, as the ruling of the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the victim’s hired </span>hand <span class="gemarra-regular">or his </span>regular <span class="gemarra-regular">harvester. </span>That is why the robber is still liable after having given the payment to the agent.
§ The Gemara discusses another matter relating to the appointment of an agent. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>

Daf 104b

One who owes a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">may not send money </span>with another to the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of a figure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">deyokani</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> or sign used in place of a signature that is associated with the creditor. The possession of this sign on the part of the other is not sufficient proof that he has been appointed as an agent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even if witnesses </span>verifying that this is the creditor’s sign <span class="gemarra-regular">are signed on it. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: If </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses signed on it, one may send </span>the money with the other.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: According to Shmuel, what is the rectification, </span>i.e., what recourse is available to one who wishes to collect a debt without traveling to the debtor’s location? The Gemara answers: One may act <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>course of action <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abba, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">was owed mone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by Rav Yosef bar Ḥama. </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Safra: When you come </span>back from Rabbi Yosef bar Ḥama’s locale, <span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>my money <span class="gemarra-regular">to me. When </span>Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">went there, Rava, </span>Rav Yosef bar Ḥama’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son, said to him: Did </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">write you </span>a document stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have received </span>payment, so that my father will have proof that he has absolved himself of the debt? Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No. </span>Rava responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, first go </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him write you </span>a document stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have received </span>payment, and then my father will pay you.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Even if he writes you </span>a document stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have received </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is nothing, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps by </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">you arrive </span>back here, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba will have died and the money will fall before </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans </span>as an inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the document stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have received </span>payment, that was written <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Abba, will be nothing, </span>as the debt is no longer owed to him, but rather, to his heirs. Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Rather, what is the rectification? </span>Rava replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go, </span>and Rabbi Abba will <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer to yo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">u</span> the rights to the money owed to him <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>acquisition of <span class="gemarra-regular">lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">write for us </span>a document stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have received </span>payment. Then, we will pay you.
The Gemara notes: And this is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>course of action <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Pappa, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">was owed twelve thousand dinars </span>by a resident of <span class="gemarra-regular">Bei Ḥozai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred </span>his claim to the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Shmuel bar Abba by means of </span>the acquisition of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">threshold of his house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When </span>Rav Shmuel bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>from Bei Ḥozai with the money in hand, Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">went out as far as Tavak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> toward him </span>in his excitement to receive the money.
§ The mishna teaches that if the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal </span>value of the stolen item, but did not give him the additional one-fifth payment required of a robber, he is not required to pursue the robbery victim in order to return the additional one-fifth payment. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitutio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> rather than a fine. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs </span>of the robber must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay it </span>to the robbery victim. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we also learned </span>in the mishna that if the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal and takes </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, asserting that he had already paid it, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">adds </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment about which he had taken a false oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is monetary restitution, </span>as one is obligated to pay an additional one-fifth for taking a false oath only with regard to monetary restitution, not with regard to fines.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs another and takes </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>that he did not rob him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs pay the principal and </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payments to the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">but are exempt from </span>the obligation to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">the guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs obligated </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">of their father, </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is monetary restitution, and </span>therefore the <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs must pay </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one could <span class="gemarra-regular">raise a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. After having stated that one is required to add the additional one-fifth payment only for a robbery he commits himself, and not for a robbery committed by his father, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">still say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when does </span>an heir <span class="gemarra-regular">not pay </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for his father’s robbery</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is only <span class="gemarra-regular">when neither he nor his father took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath. </span>
But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>took a false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not his father; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">his father </span>took a false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not he; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he and his father </span>both took false oaths; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is the heir’s exemption derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“He shall restore the item <span class="gemarra-regular">that he robbed,” and </span>“the item <span class="gemarra-regular">that he has acquired through exploitation” </span>(Leviticus 5:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in this case the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">did not rob and did not exploit. </span>Since the verse states the obligation to pay the additional one-fifth payment when discussing one who robbed or exploited another, and the heir has done neither, he is exempt from payment. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that heirs are not obligated to pay the additional one-fifth payment.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the mishna and the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, they discuss a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>his obligation and therefore was required to pay the additional one-fifth payment, and this obligation is transferred to his heir; <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the latter <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it discusses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not admit </span>his obligation and was never required to pay the additional one-fifth payment.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the latter <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not admit </span>his obligation, then the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would be that the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">would not pay even the principal, </span>as the obligation is not known by anyone. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not pay </span>the principal, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>isn’t it understood <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">searches for </span>a source to teach the heir’s exemption from only the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that he does pay the principal.</span>
The Gemara also proves that the heir must pay the principal from the continuation of the same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And further, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">still say: When does </span>the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the principal for his father’s robbery? </span>It is only <span class="gemarra-regular">when he and his father </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>false <span class="gemarra-regular">oaths. </span>But if <span class="gemarra-regular">his father </span>took a false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not he; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>took a false oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not his father; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">neither he nor his father </span>took false oaths; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is the heir’s obligation to pay the principal derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>the following terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Robbery,” and “exploitation,” “lost item,” and “deposit” </span>(Leviticus 5:23); and <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a derivation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yesh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">talmud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>here to derive that the heir is obligated to pay the principal in all of these cases.
