The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna sat and stated this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, his son, said to him: </span>Was <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a derivation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yesh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">talmud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], or </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they will be paid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yishtalmu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am saying: There is a derivation, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">from the additional </span>expressions in the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">I say </span>it can be derived. It is apparent that an heir is obligated to pay the principal, and this refutes Rav Naḥman’s attempted resolution.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>did Rav Naḥman mean when he suggested that the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not admit </span>his obligation and exempts his heir from paying the additional one-fifth but obligates him to pay the principal? The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">father did not admit, but his son did admit, </span>and therefore he is obligated to pay the principal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">his son be liable </span>to pay the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for his own </span>false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: In </span>the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">extant. </span>Although the false oath was taken, it is not the type of obligation for which one must pay an additional one-fifth payment. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If in </span>the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">extant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should be that the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pay even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that while heirs must return an item stolen by their father, they are not obligated to compensate the owner if the item is no longer extant. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is guaranteed </span>property, i.e., land, which the heirs inherited from the robber. Heirs are obligated to compensate the owner of a stolen item with inherited land, even if the stolen item itself is no longer extant.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">when there i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> guaranteed property, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? </span>After all, such a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>legally considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral</span> agreement, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the creditor of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect from the heirs </span>of the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>can he collect <span class="gemarra-regular">from those who purchased </span>land from the debtor.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: 

Daf 105a

The reference here is to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>the father had already <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>and was obligated to pay. In such a case, the debt is considered like a loan with a promissory note, which a creditor may collect from the debtor’s heirs. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>the father had already <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>and was obligated to pay, then the heir, who took a false oath and later confessed, would have to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay even </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>as this would be akin to any monetary obligation; but the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rules that he is obligated to pay only the principal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>The heir is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">because one does not pay </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for the denial of </span>a debt that is secured by <span class="gemarra-regular">a lien on land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>a different explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the stolen item is still extant, yet the heir is exempt because <span class="gemarra-regular">his father’s sack [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">disakaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> containing the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">was deposited in the possession of others. </span>Accordingly, the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">pays the principal, since </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>extant, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not pay </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">because when he took an oath </span>that it was not in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">he took an oath truthfully, as he did not know </span>that his father had stolen the item.
§ The mishna teaches that if the robbery victim forgave the robber concerning both payments, <span class="gemarra-regular">excepting less than </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the principal, </span>he need not pursue him in order to return the remaining debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: They taught </span>that the robber is not obligated to pursue the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is not extant, but </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">extant, he must pursue him </span>to return it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">will appreciate </span>in value, and the debt he owes will exceed the value of one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is not different </span>when the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is extant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not different when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is not extant. </span>In either case <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not need to pursue him </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">we are not concerned that perhaps</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it will appreciate </span>in value.
The Gemara cites another ruling with regard to a stolen item worth less than one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">three bundle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of goods that <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span> in total, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they depreciated </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>their value <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at two </span><span class="it-text">perutot</span>, even <span class="gemarra-regular">if he returned two </span>bundles <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robbery victim he <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated to return the other </span>bundle. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna also <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>(96b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, and Passover elapsed over it, </span>and it is therefore prohibited to derive benefit from it, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you, </span>and he is not required to pay compensation, despite the fact that the robbery victim has suffered a monetary loss.
The Gemara explains the proof from the mishna: It may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that he is not required to pay compensation is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">there in its unadulterated </span>form; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not there in its unadulterated </span>form, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though now it is not </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">money, since it was </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">money initially, </span>at the time of the robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to pay. Here too, even though </span>the third bundle is <span class="gemarra-regular">not worth one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> now, since initially it was worth one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he is required to pay.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">two bundles </span>of goods that <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perut</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> in total, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he returned one of them to </span>the robbery victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">now there is no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">a stolen item </span>in the possession of the robber, as the remaining bundle is worth less than one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>, and he has therefore fulfilled his obligation to return the stolen item; <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>we say that since the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item that was in his possession </span>in its entirety, he is obligated to return the second bundle?
Rava himself <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolves </span>the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no stolen item here, </span>as the remaining bundle is worth less than one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no returning </span>of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">here. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise at this expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">If there is no stolen item here, </span>as what remains is insignificant, it follows that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>fulfillment of the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">returning </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>and the robber ought to be exempt, as he is no longer considered to be in possession of a stolen item. The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even though </span>the robber is exempt from returning the second bundle, as <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no stolen item here, there is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>fulfillment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva of returning </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the returned bundle was worth less than one <span class="it-text">peruta</span> as well.
§ Following Rava’s previous dilemma, the Gemara cites a similar dilemma raised by Rava. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a nazirite who shave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> his head as required <span class="gemarra-regular">but left two hair</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> uncut <span class="gemarra-regular">has done nothing, </span>and his obligation to shave his head has not been fulfilled. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If a nazirite shaved and left two hairs, and afterward he <span class="gemarra-regular">shaved one </span>of them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one fell ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of its own accord, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this considered shaving one’s entire head or not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Is Rava raising a dilemma </span>as to whether one can <span class="gemarra-regular">shave </span>his head <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>hair? How does this case differ from that of one who shaves his entire head one hair at a time, which is a fulfillment of his obligation?
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>a resolution to Rava’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one of </span>the hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">fell out </span>first, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he shaved </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one. Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">now, in any event, there is no measur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of hair left on his head that requires shaving, as one remaining hair is not significant, and he has therefore fulfilled his obligation; <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">shaving, as initially he left </span>the significant amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">two hairs </span>uncut, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now when he shaves </span>a second time, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are not two hairs </span>left for him to shave, and this does not qualify as shaving?
Rava himself <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolves </span>the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no hair here; there is no shaving here. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise at this expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">If there is no hair here, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">there is shaving here, </span>as no hair remains. The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even though there is no hair here, </span>as only one hair remains, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no mitzva of shaving here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he failed to shave it all on the first attempt, and the second time he shaved less than the required amount.
§ The Gemara cites another dilemma raised by Rava. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>(<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 10:6) that with regard to a sealed earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel that was puncture</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and was </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed by sediment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from its contents, the sediments have effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">saved </span>the contents of the barrel from contracting ritual impurity if the barrel were to come into contact with an impure item, as it is once again considered a sealed barrel. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed half of </span>the hole, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Do we say that since the hole is not currently large enough to allow ritual impurity to penetrate, the barrel is considered sealed; or perhaps we say that since the hole was initially large enough to allow impurity to penetrate, and it has not yet been sealed completely, the barrel retains its status and is not considered sealed?
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: Isn’t this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated explicitly in <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna, </span>quoted by Rava above? <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned</span> in the continuation of that mishna: With regard to an earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel that was punctured and was </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed by sediments, </span>the sediments have effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">saved </span>the contents of the barrel from contracting ritual impurity. If it was not sealed by sediments and instead one <span class="gemarra-regular">plugged </span>the hole <span class="gemarra-regular">with a vine, </span>its contents remain susceptible to contracting ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">until he smears </span>clay around the uncovered parts of the hole. If <span class="gemarra-regular">there were two </span>vines placed in the hole in order to plug it, its contents remain susceptible to contracting ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">until he smears </span>clay <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sides </span>of the hole inward, <span class="gemarra-regular">and between one vine and the other.</span>
Rav Yeimar explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>its contents become impervious to contracting ritual impurity is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he smeared </span>clay over the uncovered sections of the hole, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not smear </span>clay over the uncovered sections, the contents would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be impervious to contracting ritual impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>should this not be like the case in Rava’s dilemma? <span class="gemarra-regular">But let it be </span>considered, when one plugs the hole with the vine, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>though <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed half of </span>the hole, since there is no apparent difference between a hole that is half-sealed and a hole that is partially plugged with a vine. Accordingly, Rava should not have stated his dilemma, as it is clear from the mishna that if the hole is only partially covered, the contents of the barrel are susceptible to contracting ritual impurity.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, if he does not smear </span>clay around the vines, the vine <span class="gemarra-regular">will not remain </span>in place. By contrast, in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he sealed half of it with a substance that remains </span>in place, as in Rava’s dilemma, the seal <span class="gemarra-regular">remains </span>in place and could be considered a seal. Rava’s dilemma remains unresolved. 
§ The Gemara cites another dilemma raised by Rava. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, and Passover elapsed over it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is therefore prohibited to derive benefit from it, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">may say to </span>the victim: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you. Rava raises a dilemma: </span>

Daf 105b

If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath concerning </span>the robbery of the leavened bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, if it </span>were to be <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen </span>from the robber, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">would need to pay </span>the initial value of the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robbery victim, as he can no longer say: That which is yours is before you, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he has denied </span>a claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary matter to </span>the robbery victim and must consequently pay the additional one-fifth payment and bring a guilt-offering? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">now, in any event, it is resting </span>in the robber’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">mere dust, </span>since it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, and as such <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not denied </span>a claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary matter, </span>and the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> concerning a false oath do not apply.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The matter that was a dilemma for Rava is obvious to Rabba, as Rabba says </span>that in a scenario where one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">You stole my ox</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I did not steal </span>it. 
The first asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">nature of its </span>presence <span class="gemarra-regular">in your </span>possession? The second responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am an unpaid baile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the defendant then takes a false oath to that effect, after which he confesses that he stole the ox, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring a guilt-offering for denying a claim of a monetary matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he exempted himself from </span>liability in cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft and loss.</span>
If he responds instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am a paid bailee over it, </span>and takes a false oath to that effect, after which he confesses that he stole the ox, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring a guilt-offering for denying a claim of a monetary matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he exempted himself from </span>liability in cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">breakage and death.</span>
If he responds instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am a borrower of it, </span>and takes a false oath to that effect, after which he confesses that he stole the ox, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring a guilt-offering for denying a claim of a monetary matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he exempted himself from </span>liability in cases where the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">died due to </span>ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">labor.</span>
In all of these cases, the ox is in the possession of the one who took the false oath, and he admits that it belongs to the other. The Gemara analyzes Rabba’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabba holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the ox is now <span class="gemarra-regular">extant </span>and can be returned to its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">since, if it were to be stolen, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span>be found to <span class="gemarra-regular">be denying </span>a claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary matter, </span>as according to his claim he would then be exempt from paying, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>considered to <span class="gemarra-regular">be denying </span>a claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary matter as well. Here, </span>in the case of the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">also, even though it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">mere dust, since, if it were to be stolen, he would be required to pay </span>the robbery victim <span class="gemarra-regular">full-fledged monetary restitution, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>considered to <span class="gemarra-regular">be denying </span>a claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary matter as well.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava sat and said this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that one who protected himself from potential liability for payment by taking a false oath that he is a bailee is liable to pay the additional one-fifth payment and bring a guilt-offering. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Amram raised an objection to Rava </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states concerning one who is liable for taking a false oath concerning a monetary matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And deals falsely with it” </span>(Leviticus 5:22); this serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude one who admits to the primary </span>feature of a claim. 
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">so? </span>In a scenario where one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">You stole my ox, and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I did not steal </span>it. 
The first asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">nature of its </span>presence <span class="gemarra-regular">in your </span>possession? The second responds with any of the following replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">You sold it to me; you gave it to me as a gift; your father sold it to me; your father gave it to me as a gift; it chased after my cow </span>and entered my domain; <span class="gemarra-regular">it came to me on its own; I found it straying on the road </span>and I brought it home; <span class="gemarra-regular">I am an unpaid bailee over it; I am a paid bailee over it; </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">I am a borrower of it; and </span>the second <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>that he had done so; one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that he <span class="gemarra-regular">should be liable. The verse states: “And deals falsely with it,” </span>which serves to <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude one who admits to the primary </span>feature of a claim. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states explicitly that one who takes a false oath that he is a bailee is not liable; how can Rava state otherwise?
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Fool, when that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here you are</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and presented the ox to him immediately, so that he did not profit by claiming that he was a bailee. <span class="gemarra-regular">When I spoke, </span>I was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">was standing in </span>a different place, such as <span class="gemarra-regular">a swamp, </span>and was not returned to the owner.
Several examples of an oath in which the robber admits to the primary feature of a claim were cited in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above. The Gemara analyzes some of these examples. When the robber says: <span class="gemarra-regular">You sold </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">to me, </span>he has asserted that it belongs to him, so <span class="gemarra-regular">what admission to the primary </span>feature of the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">is there? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him: </span>You sold the animal to me, but <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not give you </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take your ox and go.</span>
When the robber says: <span class="gemarra-regular">You gave it to me, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your father gave it to me, </span>he has asserted that it belongs to him, so <span class="gemarra-regular">what admission to the primary </span>feature of the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">is there? </span>The Gemara explains: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him: </span>It was given to me <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that I will afford you satisfaction, and I did not do </span>anything <span class="gemarra-regular">for you; take your ox and go.</span>
When the robber says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I found it straying on the road </span>and I brought it home, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should have returned i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to me. Shmuel’s father said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">he says: </span>I take <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I found </span>the ox as <span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item, and I did not know that it was yours so that I could return it to you.</span>
§ After discussing a false oath taken by a robber in which he admits to the primary feature of a claim, the Gemara discusses a false oath taken by witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When a witness takes an oath that he has no knowledge of the status of a lost item, <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there are three </span>possible false <span class="gemarra-regular">oaths, </span>i.e., the oath may be false for one of three reasons: The witness may have <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized </span>the lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>recognize <span class="gemarra-regular">its finder, </span>or he may have recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">its finder but </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>recognize the item, or he may have recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">nor its finder. </span>In each of these cases, the witness took a false oath that he had no knowledge of the lost item, when in fact he had limited knowledge of it.
The Gemara asks: In the third case cited above, where the witnesses recognized <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">nor its finder, he took his oath in truth </span>when he claimed that he did not have knowledge of the lost item. Why is this cited as an example of a false oath? The Gemara emends the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the reference here is to a case where he recognized both the item <span class="gemarra-regular">and its finder.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">For which </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> did ben Azzai cite these examples? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ami says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina </span>says: They were cited <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> teach that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">exemptio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in these cases from bringing an offering for taking a false oath of testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>that these examples were cited <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach that the witness incurs <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>to bring an offering in these cases.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rav Ami and Shmuel disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who administers an oath </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a single witnes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and the witness takes a false oath that he has no awareness of the monetary matter at hand, the witness is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from bringing a sin-offering; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, deems </span>the witness <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring a sin-offering.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they disagree? </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that causes financial</span> loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value. Similarly, the potential monetary benefit that the witness can generate by causing the defendant to admit to the debt and pay the owner is considered to have monetary value. Therefore, the witness is considered to have taken a false oath with regard to a monetary matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that an item that causes financial loss <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not considered </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value. Similarly, the potential monetary benefit that the witness can generate by causing the defendant to admit to the debt and pay the owner is not considered to have monetary value. Therefore, the witness is not considered to have taken a false oath with regard to a monetary matter.
§ The Gemara discusses the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning a bailee who denies having a deposit in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>A bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">denies </span>a claim <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning a deposi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> becomes </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber with regard to it, and </span>he is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay even <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> damage that is the result of <span class="gemarra-regular">accidents. </span>The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And deals falsely with it” </span>(Leviticus 5:22–24), and <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>from this verse the <span class="gemarra-regular">punishment </span>for one who denies having a deposit. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>itself derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Neither shall you deal falsely” </span>(Leviticus 19:11). The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">punishment of </span>having to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>due to his denial even for accidental damage, in accordance with the statement of Rav Sheshet?
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">punishment </span>for taking a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the additional one-fifth payment and the bringing of the offering. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he took an oath, it may be inferred that the first clause </span>teaches a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not take an oath, </span>and the punishment referred to by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is the imposition of liability for accidental damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the latter clause teaches </span>that the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And swear to a lie” </span>(Leviticus 5:22), and <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>from this that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a punishment </span>for taking a false oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>itself derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Nor lie” </span>(Leviticus 19:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>teaches the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">where he took an oath, the first clause </span>must be teaching the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not take an oath.</span>
The Gemara answers: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>clause <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>clause are referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he took an oath, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the latter clause, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>his false oath, while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the first clause, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where witnesses came </span>and testified that the deposit is in his possession. Where <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>damage that is a result of <span class="gemarra-regular">accidents, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">where he admitted </span>his false oath, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay for the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering. </span>Since the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring in both clauses to a case where the bailee took an oath, it offers no support for Rav Sheshet’s statement.
After dismissing the attempted proof for Rav Sheshet’s statement that a bailee who denies possession of a deposit is considered a robber even without having taken a false oath, the Gemara now attempts to disprove the statement itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama raises an objection </span>to Rav Sheshet’s statement: Though it is usually the defendant who is required to take an oath in order to avoid having to pay a claim, there are cases in which the plaintiff takes an oath to receive payment. The mishna in <span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> (44b) lists these cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one such case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the plaintiff’s <span class="gemarra-regular">opponent, </span>i.e., the defendant, <span class="gemarra-regular">is suspect with regard to an oath, </span>i.e., there is reason for the court to believe that he would take a false oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>would the defendant have become suspect? It would be by having taken a false oath with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">either an oath of testimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or an oath on a deposit, or even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>taken in <span class="gemarra-regular">vain.</span>
The Gemara comments: Since the mishna states that he becomes suspect only as a result of having taken a false oath, it can be inferred that he does not become suspect by virtue of denial of a claim alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that a bailee who denies having taken the deposit is considered a robber even without having taken an oath, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">denial that he </span>ought to be <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified, </span>as a robber does not have the credibility to take an oath.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in defense of Rav Sheshet’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here, </span>in the case of the mishna in <span class="it-text">Shevuot</span>? We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">stands in </span>a place not in the bailee’s possession, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">a swamp, as </span>in this case his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">denial, because he thinks </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will evade </span>the owner by claiming that I never took the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">until I go and bring it to him. </span>Therefore, he is not considered to be a robber. By contrast, Rav Sheshet is referring to a case where the bailee denied responsibility for the item while it was in his possession, as he intended to keep it for himself.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that one who denies possession of an item only so that he may later return it is not considered a robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Idi bar Avin says: One who denies </span>a claim <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>having taken <span class="gemarra-regular">a loa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is fit to bear witness, </span>

Daf 106a

but one who denies a claim <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>having taken <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is disqualified from bearing witness,</span> because if it is clear that the deposit is in his possession, yet he denies it, he must be lying.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty with regard to Rav Sheshet’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Ilfa say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath effects acquisition, </span>meaning that once he testified falsely that he did not become a bailee, the item in question becomes his property, rendering him liable as a robber even for damage or loss resulting from accidents? The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the taking of <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath that effects acquisition, but </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">denial </span>of having become a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">does not effect acquisition. </span>The Gemara rejects this distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>Ilfa must be referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">stands in </span>a place not in the bailee’s possession, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">a swamp,</span> and as long as he does not take an oath, it can be assumed that his intention is simply to be evasive. But if the animal was standing in his house, then he acquires it as soon as he denies the claim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of Ilfa’s statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath effects acquisition? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said </span>that if one party says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hundred dinars in your possession, and the other </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: You do not </span>have any money <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and later, witnesses cam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and testified that his oath was false, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: </span>“The oath of the Lord shall be between them both, to see whether he has not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owner thereof shall accept it, and he shall not make restitution” </span>(Exodus 22:10); teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">once the owner received an oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the one who took the oath <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer pays monetary restitution.</span> Ilfa’s statement that an oath effects acquisition means that the bailee will no longer have to pay monetary restitution, and it does not relate to Rav Sheshet’s statement that the bailee becomes responsible for damage resulting from accidents as soon as he denies the claim.
§ Having mentioned Rav’s ruling, the Gemara addresses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that if one party says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession, and the other </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">says: You do not </span>have any money <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and later, witnesses came </span>and testified that his oath was false, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as it is stated: “And the owner thereof shall accept it, and he shall not make restitution” </span>(Exodus 22:10); teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">once the owner received an oath, </span>the one who took the oath <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer pays monetary restitution.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Rav’s statement is reasonable in </span>the case of one who denies having taken <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan, which is intended for expenditure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the money is no longer in his possession, the Torah exempts him from monetary restitution once he takes an oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of one who denies having accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposit, it remains in the owner’s possession </span>and must be returned intact, and it is not considered to be monetary restitution. Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But, by God, Rav said </span>his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>the case of one who denies having accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposit, as when </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>exempting him from payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is written, it is written in </span>the case of one who denies having accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposit.</span>
§ The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman was sitting and saying this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rav Aḥa bar Minyumi raised an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> objection to Rav Naḥman </span>from that which was taught in a mishna (108b): If the owner asked the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my deposit, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">lost, </span>and the owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>thereby accepting the oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he consumed </span>the deposit, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the principal. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted of his own </span>accord that he had taken a false oath, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering. </span>This indicates that one is required to pay monetary restitution for a deposit even after taking an oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to him: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one takes an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">oath outside of court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which does not exempt him from paying restitution. Rav Aḥa bar Minyumi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If so, say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: If the owner asked the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my deposit, </span>and the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen, </span>and the owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>thereby accepting the oath; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole it, </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment of double </span>the principal. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted of his own </span>accord that he had taken a false oath, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering. And if it enters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your mind </span>that this oath was taken <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of court, is there </span>an obligation of <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>in such a circumstance?
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am able to answer you </span>by saying that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna is referring to one who took an oath <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of court, and the latter clause </span>of the mishna is referring to one who took an oath <span class="gemarra-regular">in court, but we will not answer you with a forced answer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Instead, I will explain it this manner: Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>clause <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>clause are referring to an oath taken <span class="gemarra-regular">in court, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>the ruling of the first clause is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">leape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to take an oath as soon as the other litigant stated his claim, even though the court had not yet required him to do so, which is not considered a full-fledged oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the ruling of the latter clause is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who did not leap </span>but took an oath only when required by the court.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said to Rav Naḥman: After all, you do not hold </span>in accordance with the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav; why are you pledging yourself to </span>explain the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav </span>so that it not be contradicted by the mishna? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I said this not to justify Rav’s ruling but <span class="gemarra-regular">to clarify </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, as Rav </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">explain the mishna in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>manner, as I did. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rav quoted a verse,</span> so how could Rav Naḥman not agree with his statement? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> in response: This <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>was not written to teach the ruling of Rav; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it comes to </span>teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">all those </span>discussed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Torah </span>who are required to <span class="gemarra-regular">take oaths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take oaths and do not pay; </span>as the verse should be interpreted as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the owner thereof shall accept it, and he shall not make restitution”</span> (Exodus 22:10), teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who has </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to pa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath, </span>and not the one demanding payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna raises an objection </span>to Rav’s statement from a different mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> 36b), which states: If an owner requested the return of his deposit and the purported bailee denied having received it, and the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">administered an oath </span>to the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">five times</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether before the court or not before the court, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">denied </span>the claim each time, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable for each and every one </span>of the oaths and must pay the additional one-fifth payment and bring a guilt-offering for each one. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon says: What is the reason? Since he is able to retract and admit </span>after each oath, at which point he would be liable to pay, therefore each subsequent false oath is a denial of that liability. It can be seen from this mishna that one who admits liability after having taken a false oath is liable to pay, counter to the statement of Rav.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And here, you cannot say </span>that the mishna in <span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> is referring to a case where the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">leaped </span>to volunteer his oath, because it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>explicitly that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">administered an oath </span>to the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the deposit. And <span class="gemarra-regular">you cannot say </span>that the mishna in <span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> is referring to a case where the bailee took his oath <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of court, </span>because it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>explicitly that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies whether the oath was taken <span class="gemarra-regular">before the court </span>or not before the court.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He, </span>Rav Hamnuna, <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the objection and he resolved it: </span>The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches it disjunctively, </span>i.e., the rulings of the mishna are stated with regard to different circumstances. Where it teaches that the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">administered an oath </span>to the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the deposit, that is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of court,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>when it discusses an oath taken <span class="gemarra-regular">before the court, </span>it is referring to a case where the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">leaped </span>and volunteered his oath. Therefore, the mishna does not discuss the case with regard to which Rav issued his ruling, where the bailee was forced to take an oath before the court.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>to Rav’s statement from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a homeowner </span>acting as a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">claimed, with regard to a deposit, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he took an oath </span>to that effect <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>that he was lying and that in fact he took the item himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses came </span>and testified that the bailee himself indeed took the item, then <span class="gemarra-regular">if he admitted </span>his guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal </span>value of the item <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he must also bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering. But if he admitted </span>his guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment and </span>brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rules that one who takes an oath is not exempt from payment, counter to the statement of Rav.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And here, </span>in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">you cannot say that </span>it is referring to an oath taken <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of court or </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">leaped </span>and volunteered his oath, because <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, and one is obligated to pay double payment only when the accused has an oath administered to him before the court.
The Gemara cites a new version of Rava’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>to having taken a false oath, there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>whether one falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> claim </span>that the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost, and </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>whether one falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">as well; </span>in these cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav did not say </span>that taking an oath exempts the bailee from restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is written </span>in the Torah portion discussing a false oath taken with regard to a deposit: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they shall confess </span>the sin that they performed, and he shall return the principal for his guilt, and he shall add to it one-fifth, and he gives it to the one with regard to whom is guilty” (Numbers 5:7), teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>anyone who admits to a false oath concerning a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to pay the principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment.
The Gemara continues the new version of Rava’s statement: Additionally, in a case where one falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief</span> stole the deposit and takes an oath to that effect <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses come </span>and say that he had stolen it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav did not say </span>that taking an oath exempts the bailee from restitution, <span class="gemarra-regular">because double payment is written </span>in the Torah (see Exodus 22:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">When he says </span>that taking an oath exempts the bailee from restitution, it is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim that </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not admit it, and witnesses come </span>and testify that he had stolen it.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Gamda went and said that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rav Ashi. </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Now </span>consider: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even Rav Hamnuna, </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav’s student and knew that Rav says </span>that one who takes a false oath is exempt from paying restitution even in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rav Hamnuna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">challenged </span>him from a mishna that teaches that one is not exempt in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav did not say </span>his <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>that he took a false oath? Presumably, Rav Hamnuna, as Rav’s student, was aware of the scope of his teacher’s ruling. How, then, can you limit it as being narrower than Rav Hamnuna’s interpretation? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa the Elder said to Rav Ashi: Rav Hamnuna </span>did not raise a difficulty against Rav with regard to the case of one admitting to having taken a false oath, rather, with regard to the case where witnesses came after he took the oath, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult for him: </span>

Daf 106b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that when <span class="gemarra-regular">one takes </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">then witnesses come, he is liable </span>to pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is why we hold him liable </span>for a guilt-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering for the final oath, since he can </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">retract and admi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> his liability and incur an obligation to pay. Consequently, the fact that he took another false oath constitutes an additional false denial of his monetary liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say, </span>as Rav did, that even <span class="gemarra-regular">when witnesses come he is exempt </span>from paying, then the mishna’s ruling is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">is there any </span>similar case <span class="gemarra-regular">where if witnesses come and testify with regard to it, he would be exempt, and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we would stand and obligate him </span>to bring a guilt-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering for a </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">oath, </span>for no reason other than <span class="gemarra-regular">since he can </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">retract and admit </span>his liability? As of <span class="gemarra-regular">now, in any event, he has not admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to any liability and has no extant debt, and any further oaths that he takes are not denials of monetary liability. It follows, then, that Rava’s explanation of Rav’s opinion cannot be undermined by Rav Hamnuna’s challenge.
§ The Gemara cites another ruling concerning the topic of a bailee who claims that a deposit in his possession was stolen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim, with regard to a deposit, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> stole it, and it becomes clear that he stole it himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. If he slaughtered or sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
He explains his ruling by means of a comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since a thief pays double payment, and </span>one who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit also <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment, </span>it follows that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a thief, who </span>ordinarily <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment, </span>and if he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>an animal he stole <span class="gemarra-regular">pays fourfold or fivefold payment, so too, </span>one who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposit, who </span>ordinarily <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment, </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the animal he received as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">pays fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>having taken a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath; will you say </span>that this stringency should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">who pays double payment only upon </span>taking a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath? </span>Therefore, one cannot derive from the obligation of a thief to pay fourfold or fivefold payment to the case of one who falsely states the claim that the deposit was stolen.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Rabbi Yoḥanan did not base his ruling on a logical inference; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a derivation based upon <span class="gemarra-regular">a juxtaposition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the verses discussing a thief and one who falsely states the claim that a deposit was stolen are juxtaposed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one cannot refute </span>through analysis a derivation based upon <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposition.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>verse is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a thief and one </span>verse is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit. According to him, there is a juxtaposition, and one can <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>derive one from the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span>verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If the thief shall be found, </span>he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6), <span class="gemarra-regular">and: “If the thief shall not be found” </span>(Exodus 22:7), are referring to one who falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit, and neither verse is referring to a thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling is derived from an amplification indicated by the verse not employing the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“thief </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gannav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>and instead employing the expanded term <span class="gemarra-regular">“the thief [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hagannav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].” </span>This teaches that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the fourfold and fivefold payment applies to one who falsely states the claim that the deposit was stolen, as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba raised an objection to </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a scenario where one said to an unpaid bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my ox? </span>Then the bailee responded: It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen. </span>And the owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen. And the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he ate it, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. But here, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is impossible to </span>eat even <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk of meat without slaughtering </span>the animal first, indicating that it must have been slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">pays double payment. </span>It can be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment, yes, </span>he pays; but <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment, no, </span>he does not pay.
Rabbi Yoḥanan answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he ate it </span>as an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass. </span>Since it was not killed according to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual slaughter, the thief does not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let</span> Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">answer </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba by saying that it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as where he ate it </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal with a wound that will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cause it to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>in accordance with Rabbi Shimon’s opinion that the legal status of an act of slaughter that is not fit for accomplishing its full ritual purpose is not considered an act of slaughter for which the thief must pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. The Gemara responds that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that the legal status of an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter that is not fit </span>for accomplishing its full ritual purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, </span>and the thief would pay the fourfold or fivefold payment.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">answer </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba by saying that the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an animal removed from its mother’s womb after the mother was ritually slaughtered [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ben</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">pekua</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is permitted for consumption without slaughter, so that there is a possibility that the thief ate it without first slaughtering it. The Gemara responds that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ben</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">pekua</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> requires slaughter.</span>
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">answer </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba by saying that it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">stood in judgment </span>in court, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>the stolen animal, and he did not do so, and subsequently slaughtered or sold it? In this case he would not pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as doesn’t Rava say </span>that if the judges instruct a thief: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>the stolen animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt</span> from paying the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Once </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled on his matter, </span>requiring him to give the animal to the owner, and he did not heed the court’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">but slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, </span>and not a thief; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a robber does not pay fourfold or fivefold payment.</span>
Rava continues: But if the judges say only: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are obligated to give </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>and he did not heed the court’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">but slaughtered or sold </span>the animal, then he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay the fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">has not issued a definitive ruling in </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, he is still </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>rather than a robber.
