The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, let </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">answer </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba by saying that the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a partner who slaughtered </span>an animal stolen by him and his partner <span class="gemarra-regular">without the other </span>partner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that in such a case, the thief, i.e., the partner who slaughtered the animal, does not pay fourfold or fivefold payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">selected one of two or three </span>possible answers but did not mean to say that it was the only possible answer.
§ The Gemara cites a related ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span> falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim, with regard to a lost item, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> stole it, i.e., he found a lost item, and when the owner requested its return, he claimed that it had been stolen from him, and it became known that he lied and had taken the item himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays double payment. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written </span>in the verse concerning double payment for a thief: “For any matter of trespass, from an ox, for a donkey, for a sheep, for a garment, or <span class="gemarra-regular">for any lost item about which one shall say: </span>This is it, the claims of both of them shall come before the judges; the one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor” (Exodus 22:8). It can be seen from here that double payment applies to a false claim of theft even with regard to a lost item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel raised an objection to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man gives </span>his neighbor money or vessels to safeguard, and it was stolen from the house of the man, if the thief shall be found, he shall pay double” (Exodus 22:6). The use of the word “man” indicates that the <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>of a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">by a minor is nothing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gives </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">when he is a minor and lodges the claim </span>concerning it <span class="gemarra-regular">against </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">when he is </span>still a <span class="gemarra-regular">minor. From where </span>is it derived that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would be the same in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">when he is a minor and lodges the claim </span>concerning it <span class="gemarra-regular">against </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">when he is an adult? The verse states: “The claims of both of them shall come before the judges” </span>(Exodus 22:8), i.e., the claim is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>of the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">claim are equal, </span>both done when he is an adult.
Based on the ruling of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, Rabbi Abba bar Memel raises his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that even one who finds a lost item pays double payment for claiming falsely that it was stolen, indicating that the giving of the item as a deposit by the owner is not an essential condition to render the thief liable for double payment, then the claim of a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">should be like a lost item</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well, </span>and one who received a deposit from a minor should be liable for double payment. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor, </span>so that at the time it was consumed, the owner had no legal standing. Therefore, the bailee is not obligated to pay.
Rabbi Abba bar Memel questions this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>had the bailee consumed it <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the owner was already <span class="gemarra-regular">an adult, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed, </span>would the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> be <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">pays? If so, rather than teaching: </span>The claim is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>of the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">claim are equal, let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>The claim is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">consumption </span>of the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">claim are equal, </span>which would be a more precise ruling. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Emend the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>The claim is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">consumption </span>of the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">claim are equal.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>a different answer to Rabbi Abba bar Memel’s objection: The two cases <span class="gemarra-regular">are not comparable, </span>so an objection to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba’s statement concerning a lost item cannot be derived from the case of a minor giving a deposit, because the <span class="gemarra-regular">lost item came </span>into the possession of the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">power of one </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent, </span>as the one who lost it is presumed to be an adult, though he did not personally give it to the finder; <span class="gemarra-regular">but this </span>deposit given by a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come </span>into his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">power of one </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">mentally competent, </span>as from a halakhic perspective, a minor is not considered mentally competent. Therefore, he has no grounds for a claim.
§ The Gemara quotes a related ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim, with regard to a deposit, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not obligated </span>to take an oath, nor to pay double payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">until he denies part of </span>the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and admits to part of </span>the claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As the verse states: </span>“About which one shall say: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is it” </span>(Exodus 22:8), indicating an admittance of only this part, but no more. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees </span>with the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says: </span>

Daf 107a

<span class="gemarra-regular">A merging of </span>Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">portions is written here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> written in this passage is in fact meant to be applied to a different passage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when it is written: “This is it,” </span>from which the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a partial admission is derived, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written concerning a loan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> not a deposit. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">a loa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would apply only there?
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba, as Rabba says: For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did the Torah say </span>that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits to a part of the claim must take an oath? </span>It is because there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a presumption </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person does not exhibit insolenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> by lying <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of his creditor, </span>who had done him a favor by lending money to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>person who denies part of the claim actually <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to deny all of </span>the debt, so as to be exempt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not deny </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">because a person does not exhibit insolence.</span>
Rabba continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in order not to exhibit insolence, he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to admit to </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all of </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he denies </span>owing <span class="gemarra-regular">him in part </span>is because he <span class="gemarra-regular">reasons: If I admit to him with regard to all of </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will lodge a claim against me with regard to all of it, </span>and right now I do not have the money to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">I will evade him at least </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">now until I have money, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will pay </span>him all of it. This rationalization enables one to falsely deny part of a claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, the Merciful One imposes an oath on him, in order </span>to ensure <span class="gemarra-regular">that he will admit to him with regard to all of </span>the debt.
The Gemara completes its answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is with regard to a loan that this can be said, </span>as the basis for this explanation is that one will not exhibit insolence before his creditor, who did him a favor by lending him money; <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to a deposit, one will certainly exhibit insolence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the claimant did him no favor. Therefore, there is no reason to say that one who completely denies a claim concerning a deposit is deemed credible any more than one who admitted to part of it, and he is obligated to take an oath in either case. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama teaches </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: All <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">bailees</span>

Daf 107b

<span class="gemarra-regular">require denial of a par</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and admittance of a part of </span>the claim in order to be obligated to take an oath when someone claims to have given them an item as a deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and these are they: An unpaid bailee, and a borrower</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a paid bailee, and a renter. </span>
The Gemara quotes the source for this statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: What is the reasoning </span>for the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rami bar Ḥama? </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee, it is explicitly written with regard to him: “This is it,” </span>as explained earlier. Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a paid bailee, </span>Rami bar Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">learns </span>by means of a verbal analogy to the term <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>used with regard to a paid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>used with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee, </span>since the verses about both a paid and an unpaid bailee begin: “If a man gives his neighbor” (Exodus 22:6, 9).
Rava continues: Rami bar Ḥama learns the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a borrower </span>from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vekhi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a man borrow” </span>(Exodus 22:13). There is a principle that the conjunction “and,” represented by the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, adds to the previous topic. </span>Based on this principle, the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a borrower are connected to those of the subject of the previous verse, the bailee. Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a renter, if </span>Rami bar Ḥama is stating his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that a renter is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a paid bailee, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">a paid bailee; if </span>he is stating his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that a renter is <span class="gemarra-regular">like an unpaid bailee, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says: </span>With regard to an unpaid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim, with regard to a deposit, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole it, and is discovered to have lied, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not liable </span>to pay double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he misappropriates it, </span>i.e., uses it for his own needs, before taking his oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The verse states: “If the thief shall not be found, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the house shall approach the judges to determine if he misappropriated his neighbor’s goods” </span>(Exodus 22:7), and the following verse concludes: “The one whom the judges convict shall pay double to his neighbor.” <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>one can learn <span class="gemarra-regular">that if he misappropriated it, he is liable </span>for double payment; <span class="gemarra-regular">that is to say that we are dealing </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he misappropriates it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said to </span>his students: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one who falsely claims that the deposit was stolen is liable for double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an animal still <span class="gemarra-regular">standing over its </span>feeding <span class="gemarra-regular">trough, </span>i.e., the bailee is still safeguarding it for its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Is he stating </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically with regard to </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">standing over its </span>feeding <span class="gemarra-regular">trough, but if the </span>bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">misappropriated it </span>before taking an oath, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an oath is not effective for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at all, </span>not even to cause him to be liable to pay double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he is stating </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even with regard to </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">standing over its </span>feeding <span class="gemarra-regular">trough, </span>in addition to an animal that the bailee misappropriated?
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I did not hear this </span>ruling, so I cannot transmit Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, but <span class="gemarra-regular">I did hear </span>something <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to it, as Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to an unpaid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and retracted and </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses came </span>and testified that he lied, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from double payment for the second claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason; is it not due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he already <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the second oath is disregarded, which is why he is not liable for double payment for a false claim of theft? So too, one who misappropriates the deposit thereby acquires it and is no longer obligated to take an oath.
Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>there is no proof from there, because one could argue that the reason is not because he acquired the item with the first oath; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it left the owner’s possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the bailee taking the <span class="gemarra-regular">first oath, </span>he is exempt from taking an additional oath with regard to the same claim, but his oath will be significant even after having misappropriated the item.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was also stated: Rabbi Avin says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ile’a says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the claim, with regard to a deposit, that </span>it is now <span class="gemarra-regular">lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and retracts and </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim that </span>the deposit was taken through <span class="gemarra-regular">theft and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses come </span>and testify that he lied with regard to the claim of theft, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from double payment for the second claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it left the owner’s possession with </span>the bailee taking the <span class="gemarra-regular">first oath.</span>
The Gemara cites an <span class="it-text">amora</span> who disputes the ruling of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>With regard to an unpaid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim, with regard to a deposit, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole it, and is discovered to have lied, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he misappropriated i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> before he took an oath he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is saying, </span>i.e., this is how the verse is to be understood: “If the thief shall not be found, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the house shall approach the judges if he has not misappropriated</span> his neighbor’s goods” (Exodus 22:7), indicating that this verse speaks specifically with regard to a case where he did not misappropriate the deposit; <span class="gemarra-regular">consequently, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he misappropriated it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from double payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to </span>Rav Sheshet: <span class="gemarra-regular">But aren’t three oaths administere</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by the court <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>any unpaid bailee who claims that the deposit was stolen from him? The first is: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I was not negligent in </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> thereby enabling it to be stolen; the second is: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I did not misappropriate it; </span>the third is: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that it is not in my possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What, is it not </span>so that: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I did not misappropriate it, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to: An </span><span class="gemarra-regular">oath that it is not in my possession, </span>in the following manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that it is not in my possession, when the matter becomes revealed that it is in his possession, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, so too, </span>with regard to: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I did not misappropriate it, when the matter becomes revealed that he did misappropriate it, </span>he should be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable?</span>
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>there is no proof from there, because one could say that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I did not misappropriate it, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: An oath <span class="gemarra-regular">that I was not negligent in </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>in the following manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I was not negligent in </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">it, when the matter becomes revealed that he was negligent in </span>safeguarding <span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from double payment, so too, </span>with regard to: <span class="gemarra-regular">An oath that I did not misappropriate it, when the matter becomes revealed that he did misappropriate it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from double payment. </span>Since the comparison can be made between different pairings of the oaths to suggest opposite conclusions, none of these comparisons are definitive.
§ The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> quoted earlier (65b) teaches that a bailee who would be liable for double payment if witnesses were to testify that he had in fact stolen a deposit about which he had taken an oath attesting to its theft does not pay the additional one-fifth payment normally imposed upon one who takes a false oath with regard to a monetary claim. The Gemara explores the reason for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: </span>Is it the <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">that renders him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>is it the taking of the <span class="gemarra-regular">oath that renders him liable for double payment </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment? 
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which there is a practical difference between these possibilities? It is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thief </span>stole the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and retracts and </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">states the claim </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost and takes an oath </span>to that effect, 

Daf 108a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and witnesses come </span>and testify <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>claim that at the time he took an oath that the deposit had been stolen, it was actually in his possession; <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admits with regard to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>claim that it had been a lie and that it had not actually been lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: Is he obligated to pay the additional one-fifth payment?
The Gemara explains the two possibilities: Is it being obligated in <span class="gemarra-regular">a monetary </span>obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">that renders him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">double paymen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">he is liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment for </span>the deposit due to the witness testimony and would therefore be exempt from the additional one-fifth payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>is it admitting to a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that renders him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this latter oath </span>that the item was lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it does not render him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment, </span>as he took an oath that it had been lost, not stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">will it render him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to this dilemma from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> 49b): In a scenario where one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to someone from the marketplace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Where is my ox that you stole? And </span>the accused <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not steal</span> it; whereupon the owner of the ox said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> administer an oath to you, and </span>the accused <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>accepting the oath; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify about </span>the accused <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole it, </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay double payment. And if he admitted of his own </span>accord that he stole it, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering.</span>
Rava explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses who render him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment, </span>as since the accused was not a bailee, the oath does not render him liable, and yet the mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he admitted of his own </span>accord that he stole it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he must pay the additional one-fifth payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he admitted after witnesses </span>testified, then <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he is not required to pay the additional one-fifth.
Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath that renders him liable </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>pay the additional one-fifth payment if <span class="gemarra-regular">he admitted </span>that it was a false oath <span class="gemarra-regular">after witnesses </span>testified? <span class="gemarra-regular">After all, this oath does not render him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the double payment, </span>as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one who falsely takes an oath that the item was stolen pays double payment applies only in the case of a bailee; therefore, the oath <span class="gemarra-regular">should render him liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, as does any false oath taken with regard to a monetary claim.
Rava completes the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>this mishna that it is the <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">that renders him liable </span>to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts him from the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment? The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that the additional one-fifth payment is dependent upon the type of monetary obligation, and not an oath, resolving Rami bar Ḥama’s dilemma.
§ Concerning the additional one-fifth payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina raises a dilemma: </span>If the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">and the double payment </span>are split <span class="gemarra-regular">among two men, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred his ox to two peopl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to safeguard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they stated the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>from them; <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>that it had been stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>of his own accord that he had lied, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>that it had been stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified that he had lied. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case?
Ravina clarifies the possibilities: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is particular with regard to one man that he does not pay </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">and the double payment, </span>whereas in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">this one </span>about whom the witnesses testified <span class="gemarra-regular">will pay the double payment and that one </span>who admitted of his own accord <span class="gemarra-regular">will pay the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps the Merciful One is particular that the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">and the double payment will not be paid for one monetary </span>obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here too, it is one monetary </span>obligation? The Gemara comments: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ Concerning the additional one-fifth payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payments <span class="gemarra-regular">or two double payments with regard to one man, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>; must he pay twice for the same monetary obligation? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the claim </span>that the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost and took an oath and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that it was not lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">and returned and </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the claim </span>that the same deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost, and took </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>supporting this claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>that it was not lost. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and took an oath and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and testified that he had taken it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he returned and </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the claim </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>stole the same deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses came </span>and again testified that he had taken it; <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
Rav Pappa clarifies the possibilities: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">two types of monetary restitution, </span>e.g., double payment and the additional one-fifth payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">that they will not be paid for one monetary </span>obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one type, </span>merely doubled; <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps the Merciful One states </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution that they will not be paid for one monetary </span>obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here too, they are two </span>payments of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whether in the case of two additional one-fifth payments or two double payments?
The Gemara suggests resolution to Rav Pappa’s dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as Rava says: </span>The verse states: “Or anything about which he has sworn falsely, he shall restore it in full, <span class="gemarra-regular">and shall add the fifth part [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥamishitav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] more thereto” </span>(Leviticus 5:24). By employing a plural term, <span class="it-text">ḥamishitav</span>, and not the singular <span class="it-text">ḥamishito</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah added many </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifths for one principal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that one can become obligated in multiple one-fifth payments for the same principal. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>Rava’s statement that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
§ The Gemara discusses an amoraic dispute concerning a similar case: If <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">owner demanded of </span>an unpaid <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee </span>that he return a deposit, and he claimed that it had been stolen from him <span class="gemarra-regular">and took an oath </span>to that effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>despite being exempt from payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">he paid</span> of his own volition, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief was identified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to whom </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>paid, the owner or the bailee? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: To the owner of the deposit. Rava says: To the one in whose </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">the deposit </span>was when it was stolen, i.e., the bailee.
The Gemara explains their opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says </span>that the double payment is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the deposit; since </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">troubled him by </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>instead of paying immediately, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>willing to <span class="gemarra-regular">grant acquisition of the double payment to </span>the bailee, so it is paid to the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that the double payment is paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to the one in whose </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">the deposit </span>was when it was stolen; <span class="gemarra-regular">once he paid, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">grants acquisition of the double payment to </span>the bailee.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they disagree with regard to the </span>deductive <span class="gemarra-regular">inference </span>to be drawn from the wording <span class="gemarra-regular">of the mishna, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 33b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deposits with another, </span>i.e., an unpaid bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal or vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and they were stolen or lost, </span>and the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not wish to take an oath,</span> which he may decide to do, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee takes an oath </span>that he is exempt <span class="gemarra-regular">and is released </span>from the obligation to pay the owner, but may also opt to pay; in such a case the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief was found he pays double payment, </span>or if the deposited item was a sheep or an ox and the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment. To whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>those payments? He pays them <span class="gemarra-regular">to the one in whose </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">the deposit </span>was when it was stolen or lost. When the bailee paid the owner for the stolen item, he acquired it and therefore is entitled to any payment of principal or fine paid by the thief.
The mishna continues: If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath and did not wish to pay, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief was </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>and was required to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay double payment, </span>or he <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered or sold </span>the sheep or ox and was required to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourfold or fivefold payment, to whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the money? He pays it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the deposit, </span>not to the bailee.
The Gemara explains the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye inferred </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava inferred </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause. Abaye inferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, as it teaches: </span>If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not wish to take an oath, </span>the thief pays the double, fourfold, or fivefold payment to the bailee. Abaye infers from here that <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> reason </span>the thief pays the bailee is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not wish to take an oath, </span>

Daf 108b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath, even though he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">paid, to whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">To the owner of the deposit.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava inferred </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause. </span>It teaches: If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath and did not want to pay, </span>the thief must pay the penalty to the owner of the deposit. Rava infers from here that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the thief pays the owner is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not want to pay, but </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">did pay, even though </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath </span>previously, <span class="gemarra-regular">to whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">To the one in whose </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">the deposit </span>was when it was lost.
The Gemara notes: The inference from <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause is difficult for </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye. </span>The Gemara explains. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you: This is what </span>the latter clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: </span>If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath and did not want to pay </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">the oath, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>wanted to pay only <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>having taken <span class="gemarra-regular">the oath, </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">To the owner of the deposit. </span>Similarly, the Gemara notes: The inference from <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause is difficult for </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava. </span>The Gemara explains. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: This is what </span>the first clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">paid, </span>meaning he had taken an oath <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not want to stand by his oath, but </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">paid </span>in order to nullify the oath he had taken, <span class="gemarra-regular">to whom does </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>double payment? <span class="gemarra-regular">To the one in whose </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">the deposit </span>was when it was lost.
§ The Gemara relates another dilemma concerning the status of a bailee and stolen deposits. If the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">demanded from a bailee </span>that he return their deposit, and he claimed that it had been stolen from him <span class="gemarra-regular">and took an oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> to that effect; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief was recognized, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the bailee demanded of </span>the thief to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admitted </span>to having stolen it; and then the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner demanded of </span>the thief to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">and he denied </span>the claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">brought witnesses </span>that he had stolen it, <span class="gemarra-regular">did the thief become exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee, </span>as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when one admits liability to a penalty? Does the bailee have standing vis-à-vis the thief despite having exempted himself by taking an oath to the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">or did the thief not become exempt through </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: If </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath truthfully</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if it now becomes clear through the testimony of witnesses that the bailee’s oath was true, he is assumed to be someone the owner would rely on to collect the stolen item for him, and he remains a bailee. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief became exempt through </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee. If </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">taken falsely, </span>e.g., he took an oath that the animal given as a deposit died naturally and it is now clear that his oath was false, he is assumed to be someone whom the owner would not rely on to collect the stolen item for them, and he is no longer a bailee. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief did not become exempt through </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma</span> concerning the previous ruling: If a bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">rose to take a false oath but </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not let him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Should he be considered as one who had taken a false oath, as that was his intention, and he is no longer a bailee; or, since he never actually took the false oath, he is still a bailee? The Gemara comments: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved. The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>Rava’s question <span class="gemarra-regular">like this, </span>as quoted above. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tavyumei </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>Rava’s question differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If he actually <span class="gemarra-regular">took a false oath, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is he still a bailee or not? The Gemara comments: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stand </span>unresolved.
The Gemara relates another dilemma concerning the status of a bailee and stolen deposits: If the <span class="gemarra-regular">owners </span>of a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">demanded from a bailee </span>that he return their deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">pai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> them instead of taking an oath, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief was recognized, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the owners demanded of </span>the thief to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admitted </span>to having stolen it; and then the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee demanded of </span>the thief to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">and he denied </span>the claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">brought witnesses </span>that he had stolen it, did <span class="gemarra-regular">the thief become exempt</span> from double payment <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">owners, </span>as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when one admits liability to a penalty, <span class="gemarra-regular">or not?</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">bailee can say to the owners: Once you took your money </span>from me <span class="gemarra-regular">you removed yourselves from here </span>and have no further connection to this deposit. Therefore, I am now considered the owner of the stolen item and the right to the double payment is mine, and the thief’s admission to you is meaningless. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: Just as you performed a service for us </span>by paying us when you were not obligated, <span class="gemarra-regular">we performed </span>a service <span class="gemarra-regular">for you as well. </span>Instead of granting acquisition of the double payment to you, to enable you to be repaid <span class="gemarra-regular">we took the trouble </span>to search <span class="gemarra-regular">after the thief. We will take </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">ours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you take </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">yours, </span>the money you paid us. The Gemara comments: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>If an animal given as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen in circumstances beyond the control </span>of the bailee, who is therefore exempt from liability regardless of whether he was paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the thief was recognized</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abaye says: If he is an unpaid bailee, </span>then if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief, i.e., the bailee will pay the owner and then get reimbursed by the thief; and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath </span>that he was not responsible and the owner can demand his money from the thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he is a paid bailee he enters </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief  <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not </span>have the option to <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath</span> to become exempt, as the responsibility to collect payment from the thief is part of his duty as a paid bailee. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Whether this </span>unpaid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">or that </span>paid bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">enters </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not </span>have the option to <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees with </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna bar Avin? As Rav Huna bar Avin sent </span>this ruling: If an animal given as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen in circumstances beyond the control </span>of the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">and the thief was recognized, if he is an unpaid bailee, </span>then if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief; and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath </span>that he was not responsible, and the owner can demand his money from the thief. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he is a paid bailee, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he enters </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not </span>have the option to <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath.</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">that first </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">took an oath, </span>before the thief was recognized. The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>Rav Huna bar Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief; and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">take an oath </span>that he was not responsible, indicating that the bailee had not yet taken an oath. The Gemara answers: Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what Rav Huna bar Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>Having first taken an oath before the thief was recognized, if <span class="gemarra-regular">an unpaid bailee </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">remain with his oath </span>and not pay the owner, and if he so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span>he can choose to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment with </span>the thief.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba Zut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raises the dilemma like this: </span>If an animal given as a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">was stolen in circumstances beyond the control </span>of the bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">thief returne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the animal to the place from where he had stolen it, and it is now <span class="gemarra-regular">in the house of the bailee, and it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died through </span>the bailee’s <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">once it was stolen in circumstances beyond </span>the bailee’s <span class="gemarra-regular">control his guardianship is completed </span>and he has no more responsibility for the animal, even for subsequent negligence? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps once it </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">returned, it returned to his guardianship, </span>and an unpaid bailee is liable for loss resulting from negligence? The Gemara comments: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the owner asked the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> deposit? </span>And the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> And the owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>therefore accepting the oath; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he consumed it, </span>then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal. </span>If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted on his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that he had taken a false oath, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If the owner asked the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is my deposit, </span>and the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It was stolen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> and the owner said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I administer an oath to you, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Amen, </span>therefore accepting the oath; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify about </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stole it, </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment of double </span>the principal. If the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted on his own </span>that he had taken a false oath, then he must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the principal, </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering.</span>
The mishna continues: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs his fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and the father demands that he return the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he takes an oath to</span> his father that he did not rob him; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the father <span class="gemarra-regular">dies</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> and then the son admits that he robbed him and took a false oath, necessitating the return of the principal and the giving of the additional one-fifth payment to his father’s heirs, of which he is either one of several or the only one; what should he do? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>son <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal and </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons or brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering </span>and does not keep his own share. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he does not want </span>to forfeit his share <span class="gemarra-regular">or where he does not have </span>sufficient funds to pay the other heirs while forfeiting his share, he <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows </span>money in the amount of the value of the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">and the creditors com</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and are repaid </span>in part from his share in the stolen item.
In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to his son </span>in a vow: It is forbidden <span class="gemarra-regular">like an offering [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">konam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and for that reason <span class="gemarra-regular">you may not derive benefit from my property, if </span>the father then <span class="gemarra-regular">dies </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>because it is no longer the father’s property once he dies. 

Daf 109a

The mishna continues: If the father stated in his vow that his son may not derive benefit from his property <span class="gemarra-regular">in his life and in his death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the father then <span class="gemarra-regular">dies </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">does not inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the prohibition is still in effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>instead of taking his inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">he returns</span> his portion in the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to his brothers. And if he does not hav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> sufficient funds to subsist without his inheritance, he <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows </span>money in the amount of the value of his share in the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditors come and are repai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from his share.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> written in the mishna that one who robs his father pays the principal and the additional one-fifth payment to the father’s heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says: </span>One may <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>put this money <span class="gemarra-regular">in a charity </span><span class="gemarra-regular">purs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> if he so chooses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: And </span>when giving the money <span class="gemarra-regular">he must say: This </span>is what was <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">my father.</span>
§ The Gemara questions the mishna’s ruling that one who robs his father must return the stolen item to others even if he is the sole heir. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>must he do this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him forgive </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself; </span>as the heir, to whom payment is due, he should be able to forgive it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (103a) that in the case of a robber who took a false oath claiming to be innocent and later admitted his liability: If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">forgave him concerning </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the principal, but did not forgive him concerning the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, he need not pursue him to repay the remaining debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>even the principal <span class="gemarra-regular">is subject to forgiveness, </span>so why doesn’t he forgive the obligation to himself?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. That </span>mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, </span>who says that this obligation can be forgiven, while <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>mishna, ruling that a son who robbed his father and is his sole heir cannot forgive the obligation to himself, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>who holds that this obligation cannot be forgiven.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:16) that the verse states with regard to one who steals from one who then died: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But if the man has no kinsman </span>to whom <span class="gemarra-regular">restitution may be made for the guilt, </span>the restitution for guilt that is made shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s” (Numbers 5:8). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is there </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">Jewish person who has no kinsmen? </span>Since every Jew descends from Jacob our forefather, all Jews have relatives to inherit from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse is speaking of robbery of a convert </span>who never married or had children as a Jew, and in any case is no longer legally related to his gentile family; he has no heirs. In this situation the Torah instructs one who robbed from a now-deceased convert to return the stolen item to a priest.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: In the case of one <span class="gemarra-regular">who robbed a convert and took </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath to him </span>saying that he did not rob him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">heard that the convert died; and he was bringing his money, </span>for the principal and the additional one-fifth payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his guilt-offering up to Jerusalem </span>to pay his debt to the priests and sacrifice his offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he encountered that same convert, </span>who in fact had not died; <span class="gemarra-regular">and, </span>instead of having the robber pay the money right away the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">established it as a loan for </span>the robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> leaving his property ownerless, as he had no heirs; <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>robber <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession, </span>as it is now a loan, not money to pay back the theft; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">has no remedy until he will remove his stolen item from his possession.</span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains their respective opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if the one to whom payment is due forgives the return of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself, </span>such as in this case of a convert who died or in the case of the mishna where a son robbed his father who then died, and there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if he forgives the return of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to others. </span>In either case, he <span class="gemarra-regular">can forgive </span>payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if the one to whom payment is due forgives the return of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to others </span>and there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if he forgives the return of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself. </span>In either case, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>payment.
Rabbi Yoḥanan continues his analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei </span>HaGelili, <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would also be, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>no liability would remain in the case of the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">even had he not established</span> the robbery debt <span class="gemarra-regular">as a loan, </span>as the robber could forgive the obligation to himself once the convert died. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>its <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">established it as a loan for </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">is to convey to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you the far-reaching nature of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva: That even </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">established it as a loan for him, </span>in which case it could be considered as though the robber had returned the stolen item and now has a standard loan debt, nevertheless, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">has no remedy until he will remove his stolen item from his possession, </span>so as to not benefit from his act of robbery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet objects to this </span>interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, let </span>the mishna on 103a, which indicates that one can forgive the principal payment of a robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us </span>instead that the robbery victim can forgive the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself, and </span>it would be understood that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>one can forgive the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to others. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>which Rabbi Yoḥanan explains to be the opinion stated in the mishna here, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it teach us that one cannot forgive </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to others, and </span>it would be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>with regard to the robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Sheshet said: That </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>mishna are both in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. When </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili is saying that one can forgive </span>the return of a stolen item, he meant specifically forgiving the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to others, but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">why did this </span>one who robbed a convert who subsequently died <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession? Because </span>the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">established it as a loan for him, </span>and henceforth it is no longer considered stolen property, but a standard loan debt.
The Gemara offers a different explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: That </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>mishna are both in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva. When Rabbi Akiva says that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>the return of a stolen item he meant specifically forgiving the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself, </span>as in the case of the convert, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">can forgive </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to others. </span>

Daf 109b

The Gemara questions Rava’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference </span>does it follow <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">can forgive </span>the return of the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">even to himself? But </span>if so, payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a convert </span>who dies without heirs, about <span class="gemarra-regular">which the Merciful One says </span>that it requires <span class="gemarra-regular">giving </span>repayment <span class="gemarra-regular">to the priests, how can you find these</span> circumstances if in every case where one robs a convert and the convert dies the robber can forgive the return of the item to himself?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: With what are we dealing here? </span>With a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one robbed the convert and took an oath to him </span>that he did not rob him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the convert died, and </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>his false oath <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the convert’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such <span class="gemarra-regular">that at the time that he admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Name, </span>i.e., God, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the principal and the additional one-fifth payment <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave it to the priests. </span>Once the right to the payment is transferred to the priests the robber can no longer forgive it. By contrast, if he admitted his false oath while the convert was still alive and then the convert dies, the convert can forgive the obligation to himself, since he already took ownership of it.
