§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a female convert, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: “But if the <span class="gemarra-regular">man </span>has no kinsman” (Numbers 5:8), indicating that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies to a male convert, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, </span>i.e., a female convert; if she dies after being robbed, payment is not given to the priests. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps it is the manner of the verse </span>to employ masculine wording, but the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies in the case of a female convert as well?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aharon said to Ravina: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to your dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verse states in its entirety: “But if the <span class="gemarra-regular">man </span>has no kinsman to whom restitution may be made for the guilt, the restitution for guilt that is made shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s; besides the ram of the atonement, whereby atonement shall be made for him.” <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a man; from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>is it derived that this applies equally to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman? When it states: </span>“The restitution for guilt <span class="gemarra-regular">that is made,” there are two </span>instances of the phrase “that is made” <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>as the verse mentions making restitution twice, to include a female convert in this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, what </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> states </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">“man”? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explains: To pay a convert who is <span class="gemarra-regular">a man, you need to investigat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concerning him </span>to determine <span class="gemarra-regular">if he has a kinsman or not, </span>but to pay a convert who is <span class="gemarra-regular">a minor you do not need to investigate concerning him. It is known that he has no kinsman, </span>since as a convert he has no kin among his birth family, and as a minor he does not have children.
§ With regard to the payment to priests in the case of one who robbed a convert who then died without heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>The verse states: “Restitution for guilt that is made <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s” </span>(Numbers 5:8), teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Name, </span>i.e., God, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it and gave it to the priest who is in that priestly watch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that it is given only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the priest who is on that priestly watch? Or </span>perhaps that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case, and <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>he may give it <span class="gemarra-regular">to any priest that he wishes? When it says </span>in that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Besides the ram of the atonement, whereby atonement shall be made for him,” </span>this teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse speaks of </span>giving it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the priest who is on that priestly watch. </span>Just as the ram that the robber brings is given only to the priest on duty who sacrifices it, so too, the money is also given only to the priest on duty.
Concerning this payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">robs </span>the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">was a priest, from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that he shall not say: Since </span>the payment usually <span class="gemarra-regular">is removed </span>from the robber and given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the priests and it is </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, it should be mine. And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a logical derivation </span>to support this reasoning, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">has the right to acquire </span>the payment <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to others </span>who stole from a convert, then with regard to payment <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to himself, </span>which is already in his possession, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>that he should keep it?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan states </span>this logical inference <span class="gemarra-regular">with different wording: And just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter in which </span>a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">has no portio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until it enters his possession, </span>e.g., <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, which can be given to any priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">once it enters his possession </span>another priest <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot remove it from his possession; </span>so too, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">has a portion </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">before it enters his possession, </span>e.g., an item stolen from a convert, in which he has a portion as one of the priests on the priestly watch, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it logical that another </span>priest <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot remove it from his possession </span>once it is in his possession?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues, countering that this logical inference is not correct: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, if you said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning a matter in which </span>a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">has no portion, </span>where the reason why once it enters his possession another priest cannot remove it from his possession is <span class="gemarra-regular">that just as he has no portion in it, so too, others have no portion in it; would you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>from a convert? As there it could be said <span class="gemarra-regular">that just as </span>the priest who robbed him <span class="gemarra-regular">has a portion in it </span>as one of the priests on the priestly watch, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, other </span>priests on that watch <span class="gemarra-regular">have a portion in it. Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the item he stole is removed from his possession and is distribute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to all of his brethren, the priests.</span>
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: “And every man’s hallowed thing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall be his; </span>whatsoever any man gives to the priest, it shall be his” (Numbers 5:10), indicating that a priest is not required to give to the other priests the offerings he sacrifices? Therefore, just as he has the right to the flesh of the guilt-offering that he brings to atone for robbing the convert, shouldn’t he also have the right to the payment? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here, </span>in this case? We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a ritually impure priest, </span>who is unfit to sacrifice the guilt-offering and therefore does not have rights to the flesh of the offering. In this case, he will not be able to keep the payment for himself.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states its ruling specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an impure priest, </span>how can it describe the payment as <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter in which </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">has a portion? Does he have </span>a portion in it? Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must not be referring to an impure priest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>there is another reason why he has no right to the payment. This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">derived </span>through a verbal analogy between the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“even the priest’s [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lakohen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Numbers 5:8) written in this context, and the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“to the priest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lakohen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 27:21) <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the verse stated concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an ancestral field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which, if consecrated and then redeemed by another does not revert to its original owner in the Jubilee Year, but is given to the priests, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> will now explain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verse states: “But the field, when it goes out in the Jubilee, shall be holy unto the Lord, as a field dedicated; the possession thereof shall be to the priest” (Leviticus 27:21). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The possession thereof”? From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that goes out to the priests in the Jubilee </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">and one of the priests redeemed it </span>before the Jubilee Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not say: Since </span>a field that is redeemed by another <span class="gemarra-regular">goes out to the priests in the Jubilee </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the field that I redeemed <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, it should be mine, </span>and not be given to the priests in general?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a logical derivation </span>to support this reasoning, as follows: If <span class="gemarra-regular">I acquire </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to others, </span>who consecrated it and it was then redeemed, then with regard to a field <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to me, </span>which is already in my possession, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>that I should keep it?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues, countering that this logical inference is not correct. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “As a field dedicated; the possession thereof shall be to the priest” </span>(Leviticus 27:21), indicating that a field of which the priest has <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>from his ancestors <span class="gemarra-regular">is his, but this </span>field that he redeemed <span class="gemarra-regular">is not his. How so? </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is removed from his possession and is distributed to all of his brethren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">the priests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara records another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning the rights of a priest to offerings he sacrifices. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Menaḥot</span> 13:17): <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a priest </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">come and sacrifice his offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at any time and at any hour that he wishes </span>and does not have to wait for his priestly watch to serve in the Temple? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“And if a Levite comes from any of your gates out of all Israel, where he sojourns, <span class="gemarra-regular">and comes with all the desire of his soul </span>unto the place that the Lord shall choose; <span class="gemarra-regular">then he shall minister </span>in the name of the Lord his God” (Deuteronomy 18:6–7).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the performance of </span>the offering’s <span class="gemarra-regular">service, </span>i.e., eating the meat of the animal he sacrifices, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the offering’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hide, belong to him? The verse states: “And every man’s hallowed things shall be his” </span>(Numbers 5:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? If </span>this priest <span class="gemarra-regular">was blemished</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he gives </span>his offering <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">priest that is on the same priestly watch </span>as him to sacrifice it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the performance of its service and its hide belong to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 110a

The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he was old or sick</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that he cannot perform the Temple service or eat from the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives it to any priest he wishes </span>to sacrifice it, even to one not on his priestly watch, <span class="gemarra-regular">and performance of its service and its hide </span>are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> members of the priestly watch.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this old or sick </span>priest? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he is in a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is able to perform </span>the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">performance of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its service and its hide should be his as well, </span>as the priest that sacrificed it was acting as his agent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he is in a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is not able to perform </span>the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service, how can he appoint an agent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> stated that he may give it to any priest he wishes, indicating that he chooses which priest he will appoint as his agent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is able to do </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficulty. </span>With regard to the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service, where </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he performs it with difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is </span>still considered performance of the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service, </span>he is therefore able to <span class="gemarra-regular">appoint an agent </span>to do it for him. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">eating </span>the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> says that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he eats </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficulty it is excessive eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and excessive eating is nothing, </span>i.e., he does not thereby fulfill the mitzva to eat the sacrificial portion, he is not able to appoint an agent to eat it for him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to that </span>reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">performance of its service and its hide </span>are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">members of the priestly watch.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: If a priest </span>of the priestly watch <span class="gemarra-regular">was ritually impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a communal offerin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives it to any </span>priest <span class="gemarra-regular">he wishes, and performance of its service and its hide </span>are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the members of the priestly watch. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies? <span class="gemarra-regular">If there are ritually pure </span>priests available, then <span class="gemarra-regular">can impure ones perform </span>the Temple service, and by extension appoint an agent to perform it in their stead? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there are no ritually pure </span>priests there, as all members of the priestly watch are impure, is the <span class="gemarra-regular">performance of its service and its hide </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the members of the priestly watch? </span>Even though communal offerings are sacrificed in such a circumstance, the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">are impure and are not able </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">eat </span>the offering, even though they may sacrifice it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that they are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to blemished </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>priests <span class="gemarra-regular">who are on that priestly watch. </span>Even though blemished priests are disqualified from performing the Temple service and therefore the offering must be sacrificed by impure priests, the blemished priests are permitted to eat the sacrifice, as they are ritually pure.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: If a High Priest was an acute mourner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one whose immediate relative died on that day but had yet to be buried, and he had an offering to sacrifice on his own behalf, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">to any priest that he wishes </span>to sacrifice it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and performance of its service and its hide </span>are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the members of the priestly watch. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rav Ashi’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Zevaḥim</span> 11:3): <span class="gemarra-regular">A High Priest may sacrifice </span>an offering even when he is <span class="gemarra-regular">an acute mourner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but he does not eat </span>it during that day while he is an acute mourner <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not </span>receive <span class="gemarra-regular">a portion </span>of the sacrifice <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat at nigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> after his acute mourning is finished. It follows from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that since he sacrifices it by himself he is able to appoint another priest in his stead, and since he may not eat it, it is given to the priestly watch to eat. What, then, was the novelty of Rav Ashi’s statement?
The Gemara answers: It might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Merciful One had compassion on the High Priest, </span>permitting him to continue serving in the Temple even while in a state of acute mourning, it was for <span class="gemarra-regular">him to sacrifice; but </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to appointing an agent, he is not able </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">appoint </span>one. Therefore, Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he is able to appoint an agent, since he himself is permitted to perform the Temple service.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs a convert and takes a </span>false <span class="gemarra-regular">oath </span>denying having done so, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>the robber, in order to achieve repentance, <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal, </span>i.e., the stolen item or, if it is no longer extant, its monetary value, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>of its value <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">priests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering to the altar, as it is stated: “But if the man has no kinsman to whom restitution may be made for the guilt, the restitution for guilt that is made shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s; besides the ram of the atonement, whereby atonement shall be made for him” </span>(Numbers 5:8).
The mishna continues: If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">was bringing the money and the guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> up </span>to Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">and he die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> before paying the priests and bringing his offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">the money shall be given to </span>the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span>animal designated for the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering shall graze until it becomes blemished </span>and consequently disqualified from being sacrificed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">shall </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">be sold and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>received <span class="gemarra-regular">for it shall be allocated for </span>communal <span class="gemarra-regular">gift </span>offerings. If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the money to the members of the priestly watc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>before they sacrificed his guilt-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">the heirs cannot remove </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the priests’ <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, as it is stated: </span>“And every man’s hallowed things shall be his; <span class="gemarra-regular">whatsoever any man gives to the priest, it shall be his” </span>(Numbers 5:10).
The mishna continues: If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the money to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiari</span><span class="gemarra-regular">b</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then gave the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, </span>the following priestly watch, to sacrifice on his behalf, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>his obligation. By contrast, if he first gave the <span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib and </span>then gave the <span class="gemarra-regular">money to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, if </span>the animal designated for <span class="gemarra-regular">the guilt-offering </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">extant, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, </span>who received the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">should sacrifice it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>longer extant because the priestly watch of Joiarib had already sacrificed it, he <span class="gemarra-regular">should return and bring another guilt-offering; for one who brings his stolen item </span>to the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">brings his guilt-offering </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>his obligation, but one who <span class="gemarra-regular">brings his guilt-offering before </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">brings his stolen ite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> has <span class="gemarra-regular">not fulfilled </span>his obligation.
Although he cannot sacrifice the offering before paying the principal, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave the principal but did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">give the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, the lack of having given <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">does not preclude </span>sacrificing the offering.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in explanation of the verse cited in the mishna: “But if the man has no kinsman…the restitution for guilt that is made shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s” (Numbers 5:8): With regard to the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal, </span>i.e., the stolen item itself or its equivalent value; <span class="gemarra-regular">“the restitution…that is made,” this </span>is referring to the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>perhaps this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the proper interpretation of the verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it should be interpreted: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Guilt,” this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">ram </span>of the guilt-offering.
Before continuing the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> the Gemara interrupts to clarify: <span class="gemarra-regular">And for what purpose</span> does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> distinguish between the two interpretations of guilt, as in any event, both the principal and the guilt-offering must be brought? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">To exclude that which Rava </span>holds, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava says: </span>With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item of a convert that </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">returned at night</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fulfill </span>his obligation. And similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he returned it to him </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">halves, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fulfill </span>his obligation. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? The Merciful One labeled </span>the stolen item with the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” </span>teaching that just as a guilt-offering cannot be offered at night or in halves, so too, the stolen item cannot be returned at night or in halves.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">When it says </span>in that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Besides the ram of the atonement” </span>(Numbers 5:8), referring to the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">you must say </span>concerning the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt” </span>written earlier in the verse that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal; “the restitution…that is made,” this </span>is referring to the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>perhaps this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the proper interpretation of the verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it should be interpreted: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Guilt,” this </span>is referring to the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment. Before continuing the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara interrupts to clarify: <span class="gemarra-regular">For what purpose </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> distinguish between the two interpretations? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">To</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exclude </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>teaches, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the mishna: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">gave him the principal but did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">give him the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, the lack of having given <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">does not preclude </span>sacrificing the offering. If “guilt” is referring to the additional one-fifth payment, then, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the contrary, </span>it would follow that the lack of having given the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">precludes </span>sacrificing the offering.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">When it says </span>in the previous verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall make restitution for his guilt in full, and </span>add unto it <span class="gemarra-regular">the fifth part thereof” </span>(Numbers 5:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">you must say </span>concerning the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt” </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal; “the restitution…that is made,” this </span>is referring to the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the verse is speaking of robbery of a convert. Or </span>perhaps this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the proper interpretation of the verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it should be interpreted: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The restitution…that is made,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">double payment </span>that a thief must pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the verse is speaking of theft from a convert. When it says </span>in the previous verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall make restitution for his guilt in full, and </span>add unto it <span class="gemarra-regular">the fifth part thereof” </span>(Numbers 5:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse is speaking of money that is paid </span>exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the principal, </span>and not double payment.
§ Having quoted Rava’s statement, the Gemara returns to discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Rava says: </span>With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item of a convert that </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">returned at night, </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fulfill </span>his obligation. And similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he returned it to him </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">halves, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fulfill </span>his obligation. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? The Merciful One labeled </span>the stolen item with the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” </span>teaching that just as a guilt-offering cannot be offered at night or in halves, so too, the stolen item cannot be returned at night or in halves.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item of a convert that does not have the value of one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perut</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for each and every pries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on the priestly watch, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not fulfill his obligation </span>by giving it to the priestly watch. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? As it is written: “The restitution for guilt that is made,” </span>meaning that the robber has not fulfilled his obligation to return the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">until there will be </span>halakhically significant <span class="gemarra-regular">restitution made to each and every priest, </span>minimally one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>. If the stolen item was of less value than can be distributed with each priest in the watch receiving at least one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>, the robber must add to the payment so that each priest receives one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>.
Based on this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>If the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>the value of one <span class="it-text">peruta</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>each priest on <span class="gemarra-regular">the priestly watch of Joiarib, </span>which had many priests, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it has</span>

Daf 110b

the value of one <span class="it-text">peruta</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>each priest on the <span class="gemarra-regular">priestly watch of Jedaiah, </span>which had fewer priests, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>with regard to which Rava raised his dilemma? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the dilemma is raised in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gave </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, during </span>the time of the Temple service of the <span class="gemarra-regular">priestly watch of Jedaiah, </span>there would be no dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">There is in </span>this payment enough value for each priest to receive one <span class="it-text">peruta</span>.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to raise the dilemma in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gave it to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah </span>priestly watch <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>the time of the Temple service of the <span class="gemarra-regular">priestly watch of Joiarib; </span>in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains the two possibilities: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is not </span>during Jedaiah’s <span class="gemarra-regular">priestly watch, it is nothing, </span>i.e., it is not a fulfillment of the mitzva to return the stolen item? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it was not fit for </span>the Joiarib priestly watch, as it was of insufficient value, <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset it stands </span>ready <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah </span>priestly watch, and by giving it to them he fulfilled the mitzva? The Gemara comments: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">priests, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they may divide </span>among themselves the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a convert, </span>with some priests taking a larger share <span class="gemarra-regular">in exchange for </span>taking a smaller share in the restitution for another <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert? </span>In other words, can the priests arrange that one priest or several priests will receive the restitution for one robbery and another priest or several priests will receive the restitution for a different robbery another time?
He explains the two possibilities: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One labeled </span>the stolen item with the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” </span>and therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering </span>the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">may not divide </span>portions of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with some priests taking a larger share <span class="gemarra-regular">in exchange for </span>taking a smaller share in other portions of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering, </span>but rather all priests of the watch share in the sacrificial flesh, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>with the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery: </span>The priests <span class="gemarra-regular">may not divide </span>the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert, </span>with some priests taking a larger share <span class="gemarra-regular">in exchange for </span>taking a smaller share in the restitution for another <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert? Or perhaps </span>the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert </span>paid to priests is not in fact an offering, but it <span class="gemarra-regular">is monetary restitution, </span>and monetary restitution may be divided in this manner among the priests?
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolves it </span>himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One labeled </span>the stolen item with the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt,” </span>so it may not be divided in this manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, teaches it explicitly </span>as a ruling, and not as a dilemma and solution, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Priests may not divide </span>the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a conver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with some priests taking a larger share <span class="gemarra-regular">in exchange for </span>taking a smaller share in the restitution for another <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert. What is the reason? The Merciful One labeled </span>the stolen item with the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt.”</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>What is the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">priests with regard to </span>the restitution for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert? Are they </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs </span>of the convert <span class="gemarra-regular">or are they recipients of gifts?</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference? </span>The Gemara answers: The difference would be in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one robbed </span>a convert of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">Passover elapsed over it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> rendering it an item from which one is prohibited to derive benefit and therefore valueless. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">are heirs, this is what they inherit: </span>Only that which the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to them, and the priests receive the valueless leavened bread as is. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are recipients of gifts, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift that the Merciful One is saying that </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">should give to them, and this </span>robber <span class="gemarra-regular">is not giving them anything, for it is merely dust. </span>Therefore, the robber should have to pay the priests what the value of the bread had been at the time of the robbery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zeira raises the dilemma like this: Even if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are recipients of gifts, this </span>question, i.e., whether a robber of leavened bread over which Passover then elapsed fulfills the mitzva to return the stolen item even in this devalued state, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not our dilemma, </span>as this is certainly a fulfillment of the obligation. <span class="gemarra-regular">For this </span>stolen item is the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift </span>with regard to which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states </span>in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">should give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priests.
Rav Zeira continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, when we have a dilemma </span>whether the priests are considered as heirs or as recipients of gifts, the practical difference arises in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where ten animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came into </span>the priest’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert. </span>The dilemma is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are they obligated to separate tithe from them, or not?</span>
The Gemara explains the two possibilities: Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">they are heirs, </span>in which case they will be obligated, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Master said </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 56b) that if heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the jointly <span class="gemarra-regular">held </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the estate,</span> i.e., the heirs jointly owned the animals as the inheritance had yet to be divided, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are obligated </span>to separate tithes from animals born to those animals, and the same will apply to the priests. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps they are recipients of gifts, and we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 55b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who purchases </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">or one who </span>has an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">given to him as a gift </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from </span>the obligation to separate the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the same will apply to the priests. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ḥalla</span> 2:7–10): <span class="gemarra-regular">Twenty-four priestly gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were given to Aaron and to his sons, and all of them were given with </span>a derivation from <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization; and </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a covenant of salt. </span>The verses in the book of Numbers, chapter 18, detail the gifts of the priesthood. The first verse (18:8) is written in general terms, followed by verses listing the actual gifts (9–18), followed by a final verse written in general terms. The method of interpreting verses written in this manner is one of the thirteen hermeneutical principles. Additionally, the phrase: “Covenant of salt,” is written in the final verse (18:19), and is referring to all of the gifts of the priesthood.
This serves to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who fulfills </span>the mitzva of giving the gifts of the priesthood is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as if he fulfills </span>the entire Torah, which is interpreted using the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a detail, and a generalization; and </span>as if he has brought all of the offerings, concerning which there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a covenant of salt. And anyone who violates </span>the mitzva of giving the gifts of the priesthood is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as if he violates </span>the entire Torah, which is interpreted using the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization; and </span>as if he has not brought all of the offerings, concerning which there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a covenant of salt.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And these are </span>the twenty-four gifts: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">ten in the Temple</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and four in Jerusalem, and ten in the boundaries</span> of Eretz Yisrael. The <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>gifts that the priests consume only <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Temple </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal sin-offering; and a bird sin-offering; and a definite guilt-offering; and a provisional guilt-offering; and communal peace-offerings, </span>i.e., lambs offered on <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of oil </span>that accompanies the guilt-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>a recovered <span class="gemarra-regular">leper; and the surplus of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">omer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., what remains of the measure of barley brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the two loaves, </span>i.e., the public offering of two loaves from the new wheat offered on <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the shewbread; and the leftovers of grain-offerings, </span>after the priests have offered the required handful.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>gifts that the priests consume anywhere <span class="gemarra-regular">in Jerusalem: The firstbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of kosher animals; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the first fruits; and the </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">separated </span>for the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">from the thanks-offerin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the nazirite’s ram; and hides of consecrated </span>animals.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And ten </span>gifts that the priests consume anywhere <span class="gemarra-regular">in the boundaries </span>of Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-italic">Teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the portion of the produce designated for the priest; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe, </span>which the Levite separates from the tithe he receives and gives to a priest; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the portion of dough of the five main grains designated for the priest; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the first of the sheared </span>wool; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the gifts </span>of non-sacrificial, slaughtered animals, namely, the right foreleg, the cheeks, and the maw; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>money given for the <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption of </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son; and </span>a sheep or goat given as <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption of the firstborn donkey; and </span>a consecrated <span class="gemarra-regular">ancestral field </span>the priests receive in the Jubilee Year; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a dedicated field; and </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery of a convert </span>who died without heirs.
The Gemara infers from the wording of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event, labels </span>the payment for robbery of a convert <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift. </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the priests who receive it <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">recipients of gifts, </span>and not heirs. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the money to the members of the priestly watch </span>and then died before they sacrificed his guilt-offering, the heirs cannot remove the money from the priests’ possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Learn from </span>this mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary restitution</span> for the robbery <span class="gemarra-regular">atones </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> of the sin, <span class="gemarra-regular">for if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not atone </span>at all, and atonement is not achieved until the guilt-offering is sacrificed, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that in the case of robbery of a convert, if the guilt-offering is not brought the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs. What is the reason </span>I would say this? Because <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not give </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">with this intention </span>of giving the money and not achieving atonement at all, and it would be a mistaken transaction.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>it would follow that <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering whose owners have died, </span>leaving no one to bring the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">should be transferred to non-sacred </span>status, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">did not separate</span> the animal as an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">with this intention </span>of its not being sacrificed to atone for his sin. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>in response: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering whose owners have died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">learned this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through traditio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is left to die.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, a guilt-offering whose owner has die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should be transferred to non-sacred </span>status, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not separate </span>the animal as an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">with this intention </span>of it not being sacrificed to atone for his sin. The Gemara answers: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a guilt-offering, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">also learned this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through tradition: Any </span>occurrence <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>if it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a sin-offering </span>the animal is placed in isolation for it to <span class="gemarra-regular">die, </span>if it occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a guilt-offering </span>the animal is left to <span class="gemarra-regular">graze </span>until it develops a blemish precluding its use as an offering, at which point it can be redeemed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman whose husband died childless</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yevama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], who happened before </span>her late husband’s brother who was <span class="gemarra-regular">afflicted with boil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to enter levirate marriage with him, <span class="gemarra-regular">should go out </span>free to marry <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>being required to perform <span class="gemarra-regular">the ritual through which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yavam</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> frees the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yevama</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of her levirate bonds [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. For she did not betroth herself </span>to this man’s deceased brother <span class="gemarra-regular">with this intention </span>of having a levirate bond with a man afflicted with boils. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, it is clear to us</span>

Daf 111a

<span class="gemarra-regular">that it is satisfactory for her to </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>kind of marital arrangement, and even had she taken into consideration the possibility of entering a levirate bond with this <span class="it-text">yavam</span> who is afflicted with boils she still would have accepted betrothal to her husband. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish says </span>that women have a saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is better to sit </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">two bodies [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tan</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">du</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., to be married, <span class="gemarra-regular">than to sit </span>lonely like <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the money to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib </span>and then gave the guilt-offering to the priestly watch of Jedaiah, the following priestly watch, to sacrifice on his behalf, he has fulfilled his obligation. By contrast, if he first gave the guilt-offering to the priestly watch of Joiarib and then gave the money to the priestly watch of Jedaiah, if the guilt-offering is extant, then members of the priestly watch of Jedaiah, who received the money, should sacrifice it. The Gemara quotes a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that records a dispute between <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> concerning this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:18): If the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">gave the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">guilt-offering to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib and </span>then gave <span class="gemarra-regular">the money</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">should return the money </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., with the priestly watch of Joiarib; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say </span>the opposite: They <span class="gemarra-regular">should return the guilt-offering </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the money, </span>and the priestly watch of Jedaiah will sacrifice it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this dispute? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that he gave the guilt-offering to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib during the priestly watch of Joiarib and the money to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah during the priestly watch of Jedaiah, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired that which belongs to it and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired that which belongs to it. </span>Why would the court remove what was given lawfully to the priestly watch?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gave the guilt-offering to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib during the priestly watch of Joiarib and the money to </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">during the priestly watch of Joiarib, </span>and the dispute is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since this is not the priestly watch of Jedaiah, we penalize Jedaiah; therefore, </span>the priestly watch of Jedaiah must <span class="gemarra-regular">return the money </span>in their possession <span class="gemarra-regular">to be with the guilt-offering </span>held by the Joiarib watch. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the members of </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib acted unlawfully when they accepted the guilt-offering before </span>the robber paid <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>since payment for the robbery must be given before the guilt-offering can be offered. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, we penalize them, and the guilt-offering </span>in their possession <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the money </span>held by the Jedaiah watch.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> on this topic (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:18): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, </span>that if during the Joiarib watch the robber gave the guilt-offering to the Joiarib watch and the money to the Jedaiah watch, the money should return to the priestly watch of Joiarib, <span class="gemarra-regular">if the members of </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib went first and sacrificed the guilt-offering </span>before receiving the money from the priestly watch of Jedaiah, then the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">should go back and bring another guilt-offering,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the members of </span>the priestly watch of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jedaiah, </span>who are already in possession of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">should offer it, and those </span>members of the priestly watch of Joiarib <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired that </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">that is in their possession.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: For what </span>purpose is that offering <span class="gemarra-regular">useful? It is a disqualified guilt-offering, </span>since it was sacrificed before the payment for the robbery was given, and had to be entirely burned on the altar. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>acquiring <span class="gemarra-regular">its hide, </span>which the members of the priestly watch of Joiarib keep.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, if the guilt-offering is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">extant, </span>i.e., if the priestly watch of Joiarib did not already sacri-fice it, then the priestly watch of Joiarib <span class="gemarra-regular">should return the guilt-offering </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the money, </span>and the priestly watch of Jedaiah will sacrifice it.
The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">should return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the guilt-offering. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>With a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">that the priestly watch of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Joiarib exited </span>at the close of their Temple service <span class="gemarra-regular">and they did not demand </span>the money from the priestly watch of Jedaiah. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: That </span>by doing so, the members of the priestly watch of Joiarib <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>their rights to the money <span class="gemarra-regular">in favor of </span>the priestly watch of Jedaiah. Consequently, they are required to give the guilt-offering to the priestly watch of Jedaiah to sacrifice.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, if the guilt-offering is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">extant,</span> i.e., if the priestly watch of Joiarib did not already sacrifice it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the money </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">with the guilt-offering. </span>The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? This is </span>what Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>explicitly; what novelty did Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi teach?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>With a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it happened <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the priestly watch of these and of those, </span>i.e., both Joiarib and Jedaiah, <span class="gemarra-regular">exited </span>at the end of their Temple service, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they did not demand </span>of the other the item in possession of the other watch. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they waived </span>their rights <span class="gemarra-regular">in favor of each other, </span>so that the money stays in possession of the Jedaiah watch, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that we say: Since </span>the Jedaiah watch <span class="gemarra-regular">did not demand </span>the guilt-offering from the Joiarib watch after the latter exited, <span class="gemarra-regular">let them go back to the first, </span>standard scenario, returning the money to Joiarib to be with the guilt-offering.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">For one who brings his stolen item </span>to the priests <span class="gemarra-regular">before he brings his guilt-offering </span>has fulfilled his obligation, but one who brings his guilt-offering before he brings his stolen item has not fulfilled his obligation. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: </span>“But if the man has no kinsman to whom restitution may be made for the guilt, <span class="gemarra-regular">the restitution for guilt that is made shall be the Lord’s, even the priest’s; besides the ram of the atonement, whereby atonement shall be made for him” </span>(Numbers 5:8). Learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money </span>must be returned <span class="gemarra-regular">first, </span>before the guilt-offering is brought.
Having understood that the inference is that the wording “besides the ram of the atonement” indicates that the ram must be brought after the money is given, <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the Sages said to Rava: If that is so, </span>then in a different verse, which states concerning the additional offerings sacrificed on the first day of Passover: “You shall offer these <span class="gemarra-regular">besides the burnt-offering of the morning, </span>which is for a continual burnt-offering” (Numbers 28:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>should one learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that the additional offerings </span>are brought <span class="gemarra-regular">first, </span>before the morning burnt-offering?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that no </span>sacrifice <span class="gemarra-regular">shall precede the daily morning offering? The verse states: </span>“And the fire on the altar shall be kept burning on it, it shall not be extinguished; and the priest shall kindle wood upon it every morning, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall prepare the burnt-offering upon it </span>and shall cause the fats of the peace-offerings to go up in smoke upon it” (Leviticus 6:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: “The burnt-offering,” </span>with the definite article, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the first burnt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the daily morning offering, which is first both chronologically and in terms of importance.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I do not hold that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> derives this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from the wording of: “Besides the ram of the atonement,” but <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span> hold that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derives it from </span>the phrase in the same verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Whereby atonement shall be made for him” </span>(Numbers 5:8), which is written in the future tense, indicating that he will achieve atonement in the future by bringing the ram of atonement, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>as of now, when he is giving payment for the robbery, the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">did not yet atone </span>for his sin.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave the principal to him </span>but did not yet give the additional one-fifth payment, his not giving it does not preclude sacrificing the offering. The Gemara now clarifies the source of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> on the topic of the guilt-offering brought by one who misuses consecrated property, which is accompanied by repayment of the value of the item and an additional fifth of its value: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if he brought his </span>payment for his benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not bring his guilt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or if he brought <span class="gemarra-regular">his guilt-offering but did not bring his </span>payment for his benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">misus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of consecrated property, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not fulfill </span>his obligation?
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “With the ram of the guilt-offering [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ha’asham</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and he shall be forgiven” </span>(Leviticus 5:16). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> interprets the phrase: “The ram of the guilt-offering,” to be referring to two entities: The ram, i.e., the offering, and the payment, represented by the words “the guilt-offering”; this teaches that forgiveness and atonement are achieved only after both the ram of the guilt-offering is sacrificed and the restitution of the monetary payment is given.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if he brought his guilt-offering before bringing his </span>payment for his benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not fulfill </span>his obligation? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “With the ram of the guilt-offering,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">the guilt-offering </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was already </span>brought.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as the ram and guilt-offering, </span>i.e., payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">preclude </span>his achieving atonement, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>payment of the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>of the value <span class="gemarra-regular">precludes </span>his achieving it. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “With the ram of the guilt-offering, and he shall be forgiven,” </span>which teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ram and guilt-offering, </span>i.e., payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">preclude </span>his achieving atonement <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to consecrated </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the payment of the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth does not preclude </span>his achieving it.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of misuse of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">be learned from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>money, i.e., payment for robbery of a convert who died without heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>let the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>money be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of misuse of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property.
In what manner? The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of misuse of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property can be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>money as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt” that is </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the context of robbery of a convert, is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal,</span> i.e., the payment itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“guilt” that is </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the context of misuse of consecrated property, is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">principal. And </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>money can be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of misuse of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of misuse of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>property the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">does not preclude </span>his achieving atonement, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth </span>payment <span class="gemarra-regular">does not preclude </span>his achieving atonement.


Daf 111b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his children, or </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>and then died, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the victim of the robbery after their father’s death. But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">was something that serves </span>as a legal <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee </span>of a loan, the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to pay.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed </span>another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the owners </span>of the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">have not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">came, </span>took it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">and ate </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes he may collect from this one, </span>i.e., the first robber, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he wishes he may collect from that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the second robber. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that he may collect from whomever he chooses? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as the owners did not despair </span>of retrieving it, <span class="gemarra-regular">it remains the possession of its owner, </span>so that when the second robber stole it from the first, he was in fact stealing from the original owner. Nevertheless, since the first robber was already obligated to return the item, his obligation remains in force and the owner may demand payment from him if he wishes.
The Gemara questions this opinion based on what <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to his children, or </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the victim of the robbery after their father’s death.
