This appears to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, </span>who holds that one who steals from a thief is obligated to pay the owner. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: When that </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>it is addressing a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owners had already <span class="gemarra-regular">despaire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> of retrieving the item, whereas Rav Ḥisda was referring to a case where the owners had not yet despaired.
§ The mishna stated that <span class="gemarra-regular">if one left </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his children as an inheritance, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the domain of an heir is comparable to the domain of a purchaser. </span>Just as an item that is purchased leaves the domain of the seller, an item that is inherited leaves the domain of the deceased and is considered the property of the heir. Since the owner has despaired of retrieving the item and the item has changed domains, it is entirely the property of the new owner, and he is exempt from payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the domain of an hei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not comparable to the domain of a purchaser. </span>Consequently, the item has not undergone a complete change of ownership and the heir would be required to return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the explanation of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span>had already <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed </span>the stolen goods, so there is nothing to return to the owner.
The Gemara questions the opinion of Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the fact </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause teaches: If it was something that serves </span>as a legal <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>and is, therefore, an existing commodity, the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to pay, it may be inferred that </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause we are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">dealing with a stolen item that is extant. </span>This is contrary to Rava’s statement that the mishna is discussing stolen goods that have been consumed. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: If their father left them guaranteed property, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are obligated to pay </span>from that property, even if the stolen item is not extant.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">teach Rabbi Shimon, his son, </span>that this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring only to <span class="gemarra-regular">something that may actually serve </span>as a legal <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>i.e., land? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he plows with, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he drives </span>by directing it from <span class="gemarra-regular">behind, </span>which the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to return because of the honor of their father. </span>This indicates that the mishna is referring to stolen property that is extant, and not to land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When I die, Rabbi Oshay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will come toward me </span>from his place in heaven in order to greet me, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I explain the mishna in accordance with his </span>opinion and thereby honor him. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Oshaya taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>the stolen goods to <span class="gemarra-regular">his children, </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the owner. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the stolen item is extant, </span>the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated </span>to return it to the owner; if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not extant, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them guaranteed property, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are obligated to pay </span>the owner. Rava explains the mishna as being consistent with the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rabbi Oshaya, although this explanation is not consistent with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s interpretation.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rabbi Oshaya. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is not extant, </span>the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt </span>from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda, </span>who says that heirs are obligated to pay for stolen goods that they consumed. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>it is referring to a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the owners had already <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving the item, whereas Rav Ḥisda was referring to a case in which the owners had not yet despaired.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen item is extant, </span>the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to pay. Let us say that </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rami bar Ḥama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since according to his understanding, the heirs should be exempt from payment because the stolen item is considered to have changed ownership when they inherited it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>

Daf 112a

it is referring to a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the owners have <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving their property. Consequently, the heirs have not acquired the stolen property, and it must be returned.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava teaches that </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rami bar Ḥama </span>cited above <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them money </span>that he obtained by taking <span class="gemarra-regular">interest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if they are aware that </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">interest, they are not obligated to return </span>the money to the debtor who paid it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the domain of an heir is comparable to the domain of a purchaser, </span>and because the money has changed domains, the heirs have acquired it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, I will say to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the domain of an heir is not comparable to the domain of a purchaser. And </span>the reason they do not have to return the money is because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is different here, as the verse states: “Take no interest of him or increase, </span>but fear your God, that your brother may live with you” (Leviticus 25:36), which teaches that you must <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>the interest <span class="gemarra-regular">to him so that he may live with you. </span>Since the interest is returned for this reason and not because it is considered stolen goods, it is apparent that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is cautioning him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the lender, to return it, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One is not cautioning his son </span>to return it.
The Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who teaches </span>Rami bar Ḥama’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., Rav Adda bar Ahava, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>would apply it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, </span>since there is no other explanation for why the heirs are exempt from payment. Conversely, according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who teaches </span>Rami bar Ḥama’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the mishna, </span>it is limited to that case. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama teaches it as </span>explained by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, </span>that the heirs are not exempt from payment because the domain of an heir is comparable to the domain of a purchaser, but rather because heirs are never required to return interest.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:21): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his children, </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the owner. In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>the stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance, if the heirs are <span class="gemarra-regular">adults they are obligated to pay, </span>and if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">minors they are exempt from paying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If the adult </span>heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">said: We do not know </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">calculations our father made with you </span>and whether he paid you for the stolen goods, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are exempt.</span>
The Gemara expresses surprise: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because they say: We do not know, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt? </span>Since it is clear that they are in possession of stolen property, how can they be exempt due to the uncertain claim that perhaps their father repaid the owner after the theft? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that the heirs are certain about their claim and that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be formulated differently, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">adult </span>heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">who sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">We know the calculations our father made with you and there is nothing of yours left with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he paid his debt to you, they <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt.</span>
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his children, </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">and they consumed them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether they are adults or minors, they are obligated </span>to pay the owner. The Gemara asks: Are <span class="gemarra-regular">minors obligated </span>to pay? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be only </span>like a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one caused damage, </span>and a minor who causes damage is exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be formulated differently, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>the stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">and they did not yet consume them, whether they are adults or minors, they are obligated </span>to return the stolen items, since the items are still extant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>In the case of children whose <span class="gemarra-regular">father </span>died and <span class="gemarra-regular">left them a cow </span>that he had <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they may use it for the entire duration of its loan. </span>Nevertheless, if it <span class="gemarra-regular">died, they are not liable </span>to pay if its death was caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">an unavoidable accident</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> despite the fact that a borrower is liable for damage caused by an unavoidable accident. This is because liability for accidental damage pertains only to the actual borrower, i.e., the deceased father. If the children <span class="gemarra-regular">thought that it </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to their father and they slaughtered it and ate it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they </span>are liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of inexpensive meat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rava adds: If <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them guaranteed property, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are liable to pay.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Some teach this </span>final statement of Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the first clause, </span>which states that the heirs are exempt from payment for accidental damage. According to this interpretation, if the father left them land, they are obligated to pay for the cow if it dies due to unavoidable accident. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some teach it with regard to the latter clause, </span>which states that heirs who slaughter and consume a cow must pay the owner the value of inexpensive meat. According to this interpretation, if the father left them land, they must pay for the full value of the cow.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The one who teaches it with regard to the first clause </span>holds it to be true <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so with regard to the latter clause, </span>where the heirs actually consumed the meat themselves. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, </span>accordingly, this understanding <span class="gemarra-regular">differs </span>with the forthcoming opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Pappa. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who teaches it with regard to the latter claus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> holds it to be true in that clause exclusively, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to the first clause, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>true. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is </span>consistent with the forthcoming opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Pappa says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he had a stolen co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he slaughtered it on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">because he was already rendered liable </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft before he came to </span>transgress the <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat prohibition </span>of slaughtering an animal on Shabbat. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he had a borrowed co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> in his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">and he slaughtered it on Shabbat, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the transgression of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Shabbat prohibition </span>of slaughtering an animal on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">and the prohibition against theft </span>occur <span class="gemarra-regular">as one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the act of slaughter is tantamount to the theft of the animal. This indicates that according to Rav Pappa, a borrower’s liability to pay for accidental damage is initiated only when the damage is inflicted. Accordingly, in the case discussed by Rava, since the damage was not inflicted during the father’s lifetime, the deceased’s property was never liened to the cow’s owner, and consequently the heirs are not obligated to pay for any accidental damage.
After having cited two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> that express different opinions with regard to the obligation of heirs to pay for property stolen by their deceased father, the Gemara cites a third <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that presents both opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>with regard to the verse: “Then it shall be, if he has sinned, and is guilty, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he shall restore the item that he robbed”</span> (Leviticus 5:23); <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states “that he robbed”? </span>It means that the robber must <span class="gemarra-regular">return the same </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">that he robbed.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">From here, </span>based on this exposition, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feeds </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the children are <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying </span>the owner. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>stolen goods <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they are adults or minors, they are obligated </span>to return the stolen goods. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said in the name of Sumakhos: </span>If the heirs are <span class="gemarra-regular">adults </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated, </span>but if they are <span class="gemarra-regular">minors </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt.</span>
The Gemara recounts a related incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">The son of Rabbi Yirmeya’s father-in-law, </span>i.e., his wife’s brother, who was a minor, <span class="gemarra-regular">shut the doors </span>of his father’s house <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yirmeya </span>in order to prevent Rabbi Yirmeya from establishing legal possession of the house or a chamber that he claimed belonged to him. Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Avin </span>to file a legal claim against his brother-in-law.
Rabbi Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to Rabbi Yirmeya: Your brother-in-law is <span class="gemarra-regular">claiming </span>ownership of that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since he retains the presumptive ownership of his father’s house upon his father’s death. Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I can bring witnesses who can testify that I took possession of it during his father’s lifetime. </span>Rabbi Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But does </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">accept witnesses</span>

Daf 112b

who testify <span class="gemarra-regular">in the absence of a litigant? </span>Since the defendant is a minor his presence is not legally recognized, and the court does not accept testimony against him. Rabbi Yirmeya questioned this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>accept such testimony? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>that if a robber leaves stolen goods to his children, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they are adults or minors, they are obligated </span>to pay the owner? If the court obligates minors to pay, it must accept testimony about them. Rabbi Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos’s dispute is at your side, </span>i.e., Sumakhos disagrees with this ruling and holds that the minors are exempt from paying. Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did the whole world go to the effort to hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to seize what is mine?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">In the meantime, the matter circulated and </span>eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Abbahu, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Did you not hear that which Rav Yosef bar Ḥama says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya </span>says? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Yosef bar Ḥama says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a child who took his slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and descended into the field of another and said: It is mine, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say: Let us wait until he matures </span>before we assess his claims. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">removes it from his possession immediately, and when he matures he may bring witnesses </span>to attest to his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and we will see </span>how to judge the case. Similarly, Rabbi Yirmeya should be awarded the disputed property until his minor brother-in-law may litigate in court.
The Gemara rejects Rabbi Abbahu’s assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is </span>the case that Rav Yosef bar Ḥama discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable </span>to the case of Rabbi Yirmeya? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is there, </span>in Rav Yosef bar Ḥama’s case, <span class="gemarra-regular">that we seize </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, because there is no presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">from his father; but where he does have a presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">from his father, no, </span>we do not seize his property. Since Rabbi Yirmeya’s brother-in-law has a presumption of ownership due to the fact that the property belonged to his father, he retains control of the property.
§ Having mentioned the issue of testimony in the absence of a litigant, the Gemara discusses this matter in greater detail. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shabbtai says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> The court <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts witnesses </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in the absence of a litigant. Rabbi Yoḥanan wondered at this </span>statement of Rav Ashi, and said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does </span>the court in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">accept witnesses in the absence of a litigant?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina received </span>the following guideline <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan: The court accepts testimony in the absence of the defendant only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the plaintiff <span class="gemarra-regular">was ill</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or his witnesses were ill, or his witnesses wished to travel overseas and </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>for the defendant <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not come</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since there is a concern that the plaintiff will not be able to present his claims at a later date, the testimony is accepted even in the absence of the defendant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts witnesses in the absence of a litigant. Mar Ukva said: </span>This statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was explained to me </span>personally <span class="gemarra-regular">by Shmuel himself, </span>and he said that it applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">opened his case and sent for him, but he did not appear. But </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">open the case for him, he may say to </span>the plaintiff: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am going to the High Cour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to resolve this case and will not appear in the local court.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then even <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the court already <span class="gemarra-regular">opened </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">able </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">say to them: I am going to the High Court </span>to resolve this case. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>The defendant may not defer an opened case to the High Court if, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>the local court <span class="gemarra-regular">obtained a license from the High Court </span>authorizing it to adjudicate the case.
§ Having discussed testimony in the absence of a litigant, the Gemara addresses a similar matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">ratifies a documen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the absence of a litigant. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not ratify a document in the absence of a litigant. Rav Sheshet said to Rabbi Yosei bar Abbahu: I will explain Rabbi Yoḥanan’s reasonin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to you. The verse states </span>with regard to an ox that gored: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And warning has been given to its owner and he has not secured it” </span>(Exodus 21:29). <span class="gemarra-regular">The Torah </span>means to <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Let <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the ox come and stand by his ox </span>when the testimony about the ox is provided. Similarly, a document may be ratified only in the presence of the individual it implicates.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">ratifies a document in the absence of a litigant, and </span>this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the other litigant <span class="gemarra-regular">stands and screams </span>in protest that the document is a forgery. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said: Give me tim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until I bring witnesses and disqualify the document, we give him </span>time before forcing him to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he has come </span>with witnesses within the time allotted to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has come, </span>and the court reviews the case accordingly. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he does not com</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> within the time allotted to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">we give him </span>an additional three days on which to bring witnesses, when the court is in session: <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday, Thursday, and Monday.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">has not come, we write a document of ostracis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against him </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">ninety days. </span>During <span class="gemarra-regular">the first thirty </span>days <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not descend to his property </span>to collect his debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">he is occupied </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowing money </span>to pay his debt. During <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle </span>period of thirty days <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, we do not descend to his property, as </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Perhaps he did not find </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">to borrow </span>from and <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">occupied with selling </span>his property in order to pay his debt. During the <span class="gemarra-regular">final </span>thirty days <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, we do not descend to his property, as </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Perhaps the debtor has found a purchaser and <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser himself is occupied with </span>obtaining the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>so that he can pay the debtor for the sale, and the debtor will then pay his debt.
If the debtor still <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come </span>to pay his debt after ninety days, <span class="gemarra-regular">we write </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">adrakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> allowing the creditor to collect his due from any <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>belonging to the debtor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I am comin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to pay and then he does not actually make an appearance. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: I am not coming, we immediately write </span>a document of authorization without waiting for ninety days to pass.
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>of a ninety-day waiting period applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a loan, </span>as the debtor requires time in order to obtain the money to pay it back. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to a deposit </span>that the owner demands back from a bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">we write </span>a document of authorization <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately. </span>Since a bailee should have immediate access to the deposit, there is no reason to grant him an extension.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we write </span>a document of authorization, the document applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">land, but </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to movable property, </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>draft such a document. The reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps the creditor will seize and consume </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and when the borrower </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and brings witnesses and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidates the </span>creditor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">document, he will not find anything to collect </span>in order to retrieve his money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if the creditor </span>owns <span class="gemarra-regular">land, we write </span>a document authorizing the creditor to collect from any property that belongs to the borrower, including movable property. Since the creditor owns land, there is no concern that if the borrower manages to overturn the ruling he will have nothing from which to collect. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not draft </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization with regard to movable propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">has land. </span>This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned lest </span>the creditor’s land <span class="gemarra-regular">depreciate </span>in value and the borrower will be unable to retrieve his money.
The Gemara teaches another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to this matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we write </span>the document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization, we inform </span>the party that is liable to pay, as a final warning before authorizing a creditor to locate and take possession of his property in repayment of the debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when he is nearby, but </span>if he is <span class="gemarra-regular">distant, </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>notify him before authorizing the creditor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if he is distant but there are relatives </span>of his nearby, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there are caravans that go </span>to the borrower’s current location <span class="gemarra-regular">and return, we delay </span>issuing <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>document of authorization for the <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve months </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the year, until the caravan goes and returns, </span>so that if he wishes to make a claim, he can do so. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">where Ravina delayed </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve months </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the year </span>before issuing a document of authorization <span class="gemarra-regular">for Mar Aḥa, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">until a caravan went </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">and returned from Bei Ḥozai.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. There, </span>Ravina delayed issuing the document because the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">was a violent man, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization would come into his possession, it would not be possible to take it from him </span>if the borrower would prove that the original document was invalid. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>i.e., in general, <span class="gemarra-regular">we wait for </span>the defendant to be informed <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if he is close enough to be informed within a day. Consequently, if the court decided the issue on Monday, <span class="gemarra-regular">a messenger </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>inform the defendant <span class="gemarra-regular">on Tuesday, and he </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>from his location to the court <span class="gemarra-regular">on Wednesday and stand trial on Thursday. </span>If a debtor is more than a day’s travel away, however, the court does not trouble itself to notify him.
§ Apropos the Gemara’s discussion of summoning an individual to court by means of a messenger, the Gemara discusses this issue in a more general manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: We deem the agent of the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who was sent to summon an individual to court, as <span class="gemarra-regular">credible as two </span>witnesses if he says that the defendant refuses to come to court. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies only with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to excommunication, but </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>issuing <span class="gemarra-regular">a document of ostracism, since it causes </span>the defendant <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of money, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as he must give money to the scrib</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for drafting the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>the agent is not deemed credible.
Additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: We may give </span>a defendant a particular <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>to appear in court by informing him of the trial <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>word of <span class="gemarra-regular">mouth from a woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or from his neighbors, </span>as these people are trusted to notify the defendant of the court’s summons. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the defendant is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in the city. </span>

Daf 113a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the defendant <span class="gemarra-regular">is in the city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>ostracize him for failing to respond to a summons conveyed through a woman or a neighbor, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we say: </span>Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not tell him </span>of the court’s summons, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they said </span>to themselves: Since the defendant is in the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">a court agent </span>has already <span class="gemarra-regular">found him and told him. </span>As a result, these unofficial messengers will not deliver the court’s summons to the defendant at all.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that the court will ostracize one who does not respond to a summons conveyed through a woman or a neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not pass by the court’s entrance </span>on his way home, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he does <span class="gemarra-regular">pass by the court’s entrance, </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>ostracize him. This is because it is possible that the unofficial messengers will <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to themselves: Since he passes by the courthouse, <span class="gemarra-regular">the court </span>has already <span class="gemarra-regular">found him and told him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that the court will ostracize one who does not respond to a summons <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he comes </span>home <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>that the woman or neighbor is sent to deliver the court summons. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not come </span>home <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>ostracized, because it is possible to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they forgot </span>to notify him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who had <span class="gemarra-regular">a document of ostracism written about hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not come to court, we do not tear up the document for him until he </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to court, </span>and it is not enough for him to simply commit to appearing. Similarly, if the document of ostracism was written <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not obey </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">the court, we do not tear it up for him until he </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">obeys </span>the ruling. The Gemara comments: This second statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he </span>has acquiesced and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I will obey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">tear up the document for him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">sets a date </span>for an individual to appear in court on the upcoming <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>if he does not appear, they set a date for that <span class="gemarra-regular">Thursday, and </span>if he does not appear, they set a date for the following <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday, </span>so that he has a second <span class="gemarra-regular">date and </span>then a third <span class="gemarra-regular">date after </span>the first <span class="gemarra-regular">date. And </span>if he does not appear in court by the third date, then <span class="gemarra-regular">on the next day we write </span>a document of ostracism.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi happened </span>to come to <span class="gemarra-regular">the house of Rav Kahana. He saw </span>that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman whom </span>Rav Kahana had <span class="gemarra-regular">summoned to </span>appear in <span class="gemarra-regular">court in the evening, </span>but she did not appear, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in the morning </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote a document of ostracism concerning her. </span>Rav Asi said <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master not hold </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which Rav Ḥisda says, </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">sets a date </span>for the coming <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">Thursday, and </span>then the following <span class="gemarra-regular">Monday </span>before it issues a document of ostracism?
Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: That matter </span>applies only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a man, as he is a victim of circumstance and is not </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">in the city </span>due to his vocational activities. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since she is </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">in the city, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">she does not come </span>to court the first time <span class="gemarra-regular">she is </span>immediately considered <span class="gemarra-regular">rebellious, </span>and the court may issue a document of ostracism right away.
Continuing the discussion of court dates, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not set a date for </span>legal proceedings <span class="gemarra-regular">during the days of Nisan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor during the days of Tishrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and also <span class="gemarra-regular">not on the eve of a Festival nor the eve of Shabbat </span>because these are busy times. <span class="gemarra-regular">But during Nisan we may set </span>a court date to take place <span class="gemarra-regular">after Nisan, and </span>likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">during Tishrei </span>we may set a court date to take place <span class="gemarra-regular">after Tishrei. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of Shabbat we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span>set a court date to take place <span class="gemarra-regular">after the eve of Shabbat. What is the reason </span>for this? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">one is preoccupied with his work </span>in preparation <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat </span>and it is possible that he will forget about the court summons.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: We do not set </span>a court <span class="gemarra-regular">date for participants in the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the gatherings for Torah study during Elul and Adar, <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>the months of the <span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor for participants in </span>the public discourses prior to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival during the </span>period leading up to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival. </span>The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">would come before Rav Naḥman </span>during the <span class="it-text">kalla</span> period in order to make legal claims against others, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say to them: Did I gather you </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">for your </span>own needs? No, I gathered you to participate in Torah study. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But now that there are scoundrels, </span>who do not come to study Torah but rather to avoid trial, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned </span>that they will continue to evade prosecution, and therefore we summon them to court even during these time periods.
§ The mishna teaches, with regard to one who left a stolen item to his children, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">was something that may serve </span>as a legal <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee </span>of a loan, the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to pay </span>the owner. The Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi would <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>this mishna to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, his son, </span>and explain that it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>refer only to <span class="gemarra-regular">something that can actually </span>serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantee </span>for a loan, i.e., land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it refers <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he plows with, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he drives </span>by directing it from <span class="gemarra-regular">behind, </span>which the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to return because of the honor of their father, </span>so that people will not continually point out that the inheritance was stolen and thereby disgrace their deceased parent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana raises a dilemma before Rav: </span>If the robber left his heirs a stolen item that is used in relative privacy, such as <span class="gemarra-regular">a bed that he lies on </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a table upon which he eats,</span> rather than something as conspicuous as a large animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Are the heirs obligated to return it to its owner? Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: “Give to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser” </span>(Proverbs 9:9), meaning that from the fact that the heirs must return a cow and a donkey, one can infer that they must also return a bed and a table.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exchang</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> larger coins for smaller ones <span class="gemarra-regular">from the trunk of customs collectors nor from the purse of tax </span><span class="gemarra-regular">collectors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may not take charity from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they are assumed to have obtained their funds illegally. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may take </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the collector’s <span class="gemarra-regular">house or from </span>money he has with him in <span class="gemarra-regular">the market </span>that he did not take from his collection trunk or purse.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It was <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the prohibition against exchanging money from the trunk of a customs collector: <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may give </span>the customs collector <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> as payment for a debt that amounts to less than a dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>when the collector <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him change, </span>he may accept it.
It was taught in the mishna that one may not exchange money from the trunks of <span class="gemarra-regular">customs collectors, </span>which are assumed to include stolen funds. The Gemara questions this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doesn’t Shmuel say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law of the kingdom is the law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., <span class="it-text">halakha</span> requires Jews to obey the laws of the state in which they live. Accordingly, the customs are collected legally and it should be permitted to make use of the funds.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina bar Kahana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The mishna is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">a customs collector who does not have a limitatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> placed by the governor on the amount he may collect, and he collects as he pleases. Alternatively, the Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Yannai said: </span>The mishna is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">a customs collector who stands on his own, </span>i.e., he was not appointed by the government but, on his own, he forces people to give him money.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who teach </span>the statements of Rabbi Ḥanina bar Kahana and the Sages of the school of Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>following mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 9:2) and its attendant discussion. The customs collectors would not levy a duty for the garments one was wearing. In light of this, the mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not wear </span>a garment made of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a combination of wool and linen, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he wears it <span class="gemarra-regular">on top of ten garments, </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to avoid </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">customs. </span>It was noted that this <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is prohibited to avoid </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">customs </span>by wearing a garment of diverse kinds. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says in the name of Rabbi Akiva: It is permitted to avoid </span>paying <span class="gemarra-regular">customs </span>in this manner.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, with regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, they disagree about this: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., Rabbi Akiva, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional act is permitted. </span>In this case, the prohibition is to benefit from wearing the garment, and that is not his intent, as his intention is merely to avoid paying the customs duties. Therefore, it is permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional act is prohibited. But is </span>it ever <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to avoid customs? Doesn’t Shmuel say: The law of the kingdom is the law?</span>
In answer to this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina bar Kahana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The dispute in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a customs collector who does not have a limitation </span>placed on the amount he may collect. Alternatively, Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Yannai said: </span>The dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a customs collector who stands on his own, </span>i.e., who is self-appointed.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who teach </span>the statements of Rabbi Ḥanina bar Kahana and the Sages of the school of Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 27b): One <span class="gemarra-regular">may vow before murderers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plunderers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and customs collectors </span>in order to reinforce the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a certain item that is being commandeered <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or that <span class="gemarra-regular">it belongs to the king’s house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and thereby avoid its seizure, <span class="gemarra-regular">despite </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is not </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">that it does not belong to the king’s house. </span>It was asked: Can it be that it is permitted to pronounce such a vow <span class="gemarra-regular">before customs collectors? But doesn’t Shmuel say: The law of the kingdom is the law? </span>It should therefore be prohibited to state such a vow before the customs collectors.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina bar Kahana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The mishna in <span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> issues its ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a customs collector who does not have a limitation </span>placed on the amount he may collect. Alternatively, the Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi Yannai say: </span>The mishna issues its ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a customs collector who stands on his own.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>The mishna issues its ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a gentile customs collector, </span>whom one may deceive, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew and a gentile who approach </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">for judgmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in a legal dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you can vindicate </span>the Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">under Jewish law, vindicate him, and say to </span>the gentile: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is our law. </span>If he can be vindicated <span class="gemarra-regular">under gentile law, vindicate him, and say to </span>the gentile: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is your law. And if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>possible to vindicate him under either system of law, <span class="gemarra-regular">one approaches </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">circuitously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> seeking a justification to vindicate the Jew. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: One does not approach </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">circuitously </span>in order to vindicate the Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sanctification of God’s name, </span>as God’s name will be desecrated if the Jewish judge employs dishonest means.
The Gemara infers from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, the reason </span>that the court does not employ trickery in order to vindicate the Jew is only <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is </span>the consideration of <span class="gemarra-regular">the sanctification of God’s name. Consequently, </span>if there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>consideration of <span class="gemarra-regular">the sanctification of God’s name, </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">approach </span>the case circuitously. Apparently, it is permitted to deceive a gentile.
The Gemara challenges this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is robbery </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted? Isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva taught this matter when he came from Zephirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> From where </span>is it derived that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">rob a gentile? </span>It is from the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>with regard to a Jew who has been sold as a slave to a gentile: <span class="gemarra-regular">“After he is sold he may be redeemed” </span>(Leviticus 25:48), 

Daf 113b

indicating <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one should <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>a Hebrew slave by force <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby allow him to <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>the gentile’s jurisdiction. Rather, the Jew must be freed by legal means. <span class="gemarra-regular">One might have thought </span>that it is permitted to <span class="gemarra-regular">deceive him </span>in order to free the Jew. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, the verse states: “And he shall reckon with him that bought him” </span>(Leviticus 25:50), in order to teach that one must <span class="gemarra-regular">be precise </span>in the financial dealings <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser </span>of a Hebrew slave, and one must pay him the appropriate sum without employing any form of deception. This indicates that it is prohibited to steal from a gentile.
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling that permits the court to deceive a gentile is issued <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a regular <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>verse, which teaches that it is prohibited to deceive a gentile, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a gentile who resides in Eretz Yisrael and observes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the seven Noahide mitzvot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ger</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">toshav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: How is it possible to differentiate between a gentile and a <span class="it-text">ger</span> <span class="it-text">toshav</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Aren’t both of them written next to each other, </span>indicating that the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> pertains to both? As it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One who violates the prohibitions of the Sabbatical Year will be punished by having to resort to selling himself as a slave. And he will sell himself <span class="gemarra-regular">not to you, but to a stranger, as it is stated: </span>“And sell himself unto <span class="gemarra-regular">the stranger” </span>(Leviticus 25:47), <span class="gemarra-regular">and not to a stranger </span>who is a convert, <span class="gemarra-regular">but to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ger</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">toshav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is stated: </span>“And sell himself unto <span class="gemarra-regular">the stranger who is a settler </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ger</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">toshav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>with you” (Leviticus 25:47).
The verse continues and states: “Or to the offshoot of a stranger’s family.” When it says <span class="gemarra-regular">“a stranger’s family,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the gentile </span>family members of a <span class="it-text">ger</span> <span class="it-text">toshav</span>, who are idolaters. <span class="gemarra-regular">When it says “or to the offshoot,” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to a Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">who is sold to idol worship, </span>i.e., to work in a temple dedicated to idolatry. Since it is subsequently stated: “He shall reckon with him that bought him” (Leviticus 25:50), it is apparent that this reckoning applies equally to each of the above, including the gentile. This contradicts Rav Yosef’s answer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of the slave, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an actual act of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery </span>committed against a gentile, <span class="gemarra-regular">but there, </span>in the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where it would be permitted to employ deception if not for the desecration of God’s name, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to abrogating his loan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Abrogating a loan owed to a gentile is permitted because it does not entail actually taking money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rava: The release of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Hebrew slave </span>from his gentile master <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>akin to the <span class="gemarra-regular">abrogation of his loan.</span> The purchase price paid by the master is considered as a loan that the slave pays back over the years of his servitude until he goes free at the Jubilee. Consequently, deceptively bringing about his early release is akin to abrogating a loan, yet Rabbi Akiva derives from the verse that it is prohibited to do so. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava says: The body of a Hebrew slave is owne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by his master, and retaking him from the gentile by deceptive means would therefore constitute actual robbery.
The Gemara cites another statement related to stealing from a gentile. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai bar Giddel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">rob a gentile, </span>but it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to retain <span class="gemarra-regular">his lost item</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one is not required to return it to him. The Gemara examines the basis for each of these rulings: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">rob a gentile, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">rob a gentile? </span>It is derived from a verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And you shall consume all the peoples that the Lord your God shall deliver unto you” </span>(Deuteronomy 7:16), indicating that it is permitted to consume the other nations’ property only <span class="gemarra-regular">when they are delivered into your hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., in times of war, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not when they are not delivered into your hand.</span>
It is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted</span> to retain <span class="gemarra-regular">his lost item, as Rav Ḥama bar Gurya says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: From where </span>is it derived that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to retain <span class="gemarra-regular">the lost item of a gentile? </span>It is derived from a verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>with regard to the mitzva of returning a lost item: <span class="gemarra-regular">“With every lost thing of your brother’s” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:3), indicating that it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">to your brother </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you return </span>a lost item, <span class="gemarra-regular">but you do not return </span>a lost item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile.</span>
The Gemara questions this derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">has not yet come into </span>the Jew’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hand, as he is not obligated to pursue it </span>in an effort to find the lost item and return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the item had </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">come into his hand, say </span>that he must <span class="gemarra-regular">return it </span>to the gentile. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>It is understood from the verse itself, as it states: “And so shall you do with every lost thing of your brother’s, which he has lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you have found” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:3), which <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates </span>that the verse refers even to an item <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>has already <span class="gemarra-regular">come into one’s hand. </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir says: In a case where there is </span>a concern that retention of an article lost by a gentile will result in the <span class="gemarra-regular">desecration of </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">name, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited even </span>to retain a gentile’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lost item.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to financially benefit from a business <span class="gemarra-regular">error </span>of a gentile, i.e., it need not be returned. The Gemara notes that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">where Shmuel purchased a golden bowl [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lakna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from a gentile in exchange [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bemar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for</span> the price <span class="gemarra-regular">of an iron </span>bowl, which was <span class="gemarra-regular">four dinars, and </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">included one </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">dina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in the payment so that the gentile would not realize his mistake.
The Gemara relates another incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana purchased one hundred and twenty barrels from a gentile for </span>the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span>barrels, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he included one </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar </span>in the payment. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Take note that I am relying upon yo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">u</span> to check that the transaction has been carried out properly. The Gemara records a third episode: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina and a gentile purchased a palm tree </span>together in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to chop it up </span>and split the wood between them. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to his attendant: Hurry and precede </span>the gentile so that you can bring my share of the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from the trunk</span> of the tree, which is thicker than the upper part of the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the gentile knows </span>only the <span class="gemarra-regular">number </span>of logs that he is due to receive and will not realize that you are taking thicker pieces.
The Gemara relates a final anecdote: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi was traveling on the road </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he saw a branch of a grapevin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in an orchard,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>there were <span class="gemarra-regular">clusters of grapes hanging on it. He said to his attendant: Go see </span>to whom these clusters belong. <span class="gemarra-regular">If they are </span>owned by <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile, bring </span>some to me, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if they are </span>owned by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew, do not bring me </span>any. <span class="gemarra-regular">A certain gentile who was sitting in the orchard overheard </span>Rav Ashi’s instructions. The gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to steal the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentile? </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: A gentile takes money </span>for his grapes, and I intended to pay for them, but <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew does not take money </span>for his grapes and I did not want to take them without paying for them.
§ The Gemara relates to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter of civil law <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Shmuel says: The law of the kingdom is the law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the halakhic principle is that Jews must obey the laws of the state in which they reside. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Know </span>that this principle is true from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the municipal authorities <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> without the consent of their owners <span class="gemarra-regular">and construct bridges </span>from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we cross over them. </span>Evidently, the wood is not considered stolen property, which one is prohibited from using, because the law of the kingdom is the law.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the reason the bridges may be used is <span class="gemarra-regular">because their owners despaired of retrieving them </span>and not because the law of the kingdom is the law. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">If not </span>for the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law of the kingdom is the law, how </span>would the <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of the owners of the trees allow us to use the bridges? The fact that the owners have despaired of retrieving their wood does not effect a transfer of property, and it therefore still belongs to them.
The Gemara questions Rava’s understanding: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the municipal authorities <span class="gemarra-regular">do not act as the king said. The king said: Go and cut </span>down a bit of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from all the valleys</span> in the area so that each individual loses only a small amount of wood. <span class="gemarra-regular">They, </span>however, disobey the king and <span class="gemarra-regular">go and cut </span>down all the wood needed for the bridge <span class="gemarra-regular">from one valley. </span>Therefore, even if the law of the kingdom is the law, this cannot be the reason that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> permits Jews to cross over such bridges, as the authorities are not enforcing the law of the kingdom, but rather their own unlawful inclinations.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">An agent of a king </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the king </span>himself, and he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>expected to <span class="gemarra-regular">trouble </span>himself to collect wood proportionally from each valley. <span class="gemarra-regular">They, </span>the owners of the land where the wood is cut, <span class="gemarra-regular">cause themselves a loss, as they should collect </span>compensation <span class="gemarra-regular">from all </span>the other residents <span class="gemarra-regular">of the valleys </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and take money </span>from them for this purpose. Since the land owners whose wood was used have permission to collect compensation from all the residents in the area, the authorities are acting within their rights by confiscating wood from a single location.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>When the king’s agents come to collect the king’s share of the grain from a field owned by several partners, the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is found in the granar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay the king’s share </span>for the entire property, as the agents are not expected to locate and exact payment from each individual proprietor separately. The partner who paid may later claim reimbursement from the other owners for covering their share of the tax. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies only to <span class="gemarra-regular">partners </span>who share ownership of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sharecropper collects his portion </span>from the crop but does not own a share of the land.
