Consequently, the tax may not be collected from his produce, and doing so would constitute robbery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>Property that belongs to <span class="gemarra-regular">a town dweller may be taken as security for </span>the tax owed by another <span class="gemarra-regular">town dweller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And this statement applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the property tax and head tax of that year, but </span>with regard to taxes from <span class="gemarra-regular">the previous year, since the king has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">been appeased, </span>the ability to take property belonging to someone else has <span class="gemarra-regular">passed. </span>The tax collector has already paid the entire amount he must pay the king for the previous year, and everything else he collects is his own profit. Although he has the right to collect this extra amount, he may not take property for one person as security for the taxes of someone else.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">who construct pen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for their animals <span class="gemarra-regular">inside the </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">limits </span>and charge a fee to bring their animals through the fields around the city to fertilize the fields, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to purchase </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the livestock of the </span>Jewish residents of the <span class="gemarra-regular">town become intermingled with their </span>livestock, and it is possible that the animal one would buy is actually stolen property.
Rava adds: If the pens were <span class="gemarra-regular">outside the </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">limits, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to purchase </span>livestock <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, </span>as it is unlikely that a Jew’s livestock became intermingled with the seller’s livestock. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: If the owners </span>of the livestock <span class="gemarra-regular">were pursuing </span>the animals, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the pens were <span class="gemarra-regular">outside the </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">limits, it is prohibited </span>to purchase livestock from the owners of the pens.
§ Apropos the discussion of legal dealings between Jews and gentiles, the Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava declared, and some say </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>who declared: All <span class="gemarra-regular">who ascend upward </span>to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>all who <span class="gemarra-regular">descend downward </span>to Babylonia agree that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew who knows </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">evidenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concerning </span>the legal claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile, and </span>the gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">did not demand from him </span>that he testify, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the Jew nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">went and testified for him in a gentile court, against his fellow Jew, we excommunicate him. What is the reason </span>that we excommunicate him? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because they, </span>the gentile courts, <span class="gemarra-regular">expropriate money</span>

Daf 114a

based <span class="gemarra-regular">on the word of one </span>witness, which is insufficient evidence according to Jewish law. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>that this is so <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> individual testifies alone against his fellow Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">but when two </span>witnesses testify against a Jew, we do <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> excommunicate them, as their testimony is sufficient evidence according to Jewish law as well, and they have not caused the defendant any unjustified financial loss even according to <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a single </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">also, we said </span>that we excommunicate him <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if he testified <span class="gemarra-regular">in a court of villagers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">demagista</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>if he testified in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>official government <span class="gemarra-regular">courthouse [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">davar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is not excommunicated. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">they also prescribe an oath to </span>the defendant based on the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">a single </span>witness, but they do not expropriate money, in accordance with Jewish law.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When I was in the academy of Rav Huna, </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma was raised before us: </span>What is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an <span class="gemarra-regular">important person, </span>whose testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is relied upon </span>by the gentile courts <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>if it were the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses? Since the gentile court will <span class="gemarra-regular">expropriate money </span>based <span class="gemarra-regular">on his word, </span>should the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> be that <span class="gemarra-regular">he should not testify? Or perhaps, since he is an important person, he cannot escape </span>the authorities who demand his testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">testify. </span>The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The Gemara cites another situation where a Jew is excommunicated for causing harm to another Jew. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish man who sells a gentile </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">on the border of </span>the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">his fellow Jew, we excommunicate him. What is the reason? If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he has ignored <span class="gemarra-regular">the right of one </span>whose field <span class="gemarra-regular">borders </span>the field of his neighbor to be the first one offered the purchase of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but doesn’t the Master say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">from a gentile, and one who sells </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is no right of one </span>whose field <span class="gemarra-regular">borders </span>the field of his neighbor to be the first one offered the purchase of the field?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because we say to him </span>on behalf of the owner of the adjacent field: <span class="gemarra-regular">You have placed a lion, </span>i.e., a dangerous individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">on my border, </span>as the gentile might now cause me harm. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">we excommunicate hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until he accepts upon himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">all harm that comes </span>upon the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the gentile’s activities.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">customs collectors took one’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">donke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave him a different donkey </span>that was taken from another Jew in its stead, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">bandits took his garment and gave him a different garment </span>that was taken from a Jew in its stead, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">his because the owners despaired of </span>retrieving <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>when they were stolen, and they may therefore be acquired by another. In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who salvages </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">river</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or from a troop [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hagayis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of soldiers, <span class="gemarra-regular">or from bandits, if the owners </span>of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are his, </span>i.e., they belong to the one who salvaged them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">swar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of bees, if </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving the bees, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are his, </span>i.e., they belong to the one who found them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka said: A woman or a minor, </span>whose testimony is not generally accepted by the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">is deemed credible to say: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">from here that this swarm emerged</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it therefore belongs to a certain individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may walk into another’s fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to salvage his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">swarm </span>of bees that has relocated there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he damaged </span>some property in the process, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must pay </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what he has damaged. But </span>if the bees settled on a branch of a tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not cut </span>off the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">branch </span>in order to take the bees, even <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that he will later <span class="gemarra-regular">give him the money </span>for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: He may even cut </span>off the branch <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">the money </span>for it as compensation.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one who is given an item by a customs collector or a bandit may keep the item. It was <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he took </span>a donkey from the customs collector, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the original owners. </span>The Gemara explains: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">despair alone does not effect </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition. </span>Consequently, the customs collector did not acquire the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it initially came into the possession </span>of the individual to whom the customs collector gave it <span class="gemarra-regular">illegally, </span>and he is therefore required to return it to the original owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he </span>wants to act beyond the letter of the law and <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to return it </span>voluntarily, he should <span class="gemarra-regular">return it to the original owners, </span>but he is not required to return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that he is not required to return it? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">despair alone effects </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition </span>and the donkey was, therefore, acquired by the Jew when the customs collector gave it to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nevertheless, if he said: I do not want </span>to accept <span class="gemarra-regular">money that is not mine, he returns </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the original owners.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that if customs collectors or bandits replaced one’s item with one taken from another Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">his because the owners </span>despaired of retrieving them when they were stolen. In this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: They taught </span>that the owners certainly despaired of recovering their property <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when it was stolen by <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile bandit, but </span>if it was taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish bandit, no, </span>the owner did not necessarily despair of recovering it. This is because the victim of the theft might <span class="gemarra-regular">reason: Tomorrow, I will take him to court </span>and force him to return what he stole.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef objects to this: On the contrary, the opposite is </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable: </span>When dealing with <span class="gemarra-regular">gentiles, who judge </span>a case and impose their verdicts <span class="gemarra-regular">with force, he does not despair </span>because he realizes that the gentile court will enforce the law. By contrast, when dealing with <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew, since </span>Jewish courts merely <span class="gemarra-regular">pronounce a verbal </span>decision but do not have the authority to enforce it, the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs</span> of recovering his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>Rav Ashi’s distinction <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was stated with regard to the latter clause </span>of the mishna, which states: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who salvages </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">from gentiles or from bandits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the owners despaired of retrieving it, the one who finds it may keep it. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is known that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owners despaired </span>of retreating it, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>the finder may keep the item; but in <span class="gemarra-regular">an unspecified </span>situation, where it is not known whether the owners despaired, the finder may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>keep the item.
Concerning this, Rav Ashi said: <span class="gemarra-regular">They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when the item was stolen by <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile </span>bandit, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the gentile court <span class="gemarra-regular">judges </span>a case and imposes its verdict <span class="gemarra-regular">with force, </span>and therefore it cannot be assumed that the owners despair. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the robbery was committed by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish bandit, since </span>Jewish courts merely <span class="gemarra-regular">pronounce a verbal </span>decision but do not have the authority to enforce it, the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs </span>of recovering his property.
§ Apropos the discussion with regard to an owner’s despair of retrieving a lost or stolen item, the Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 26:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">hides </span>that are tanned by the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity. </span>Hides and leather are susceptible to contracting impurity only if they are in a finished state. If a private individual uses a piece of hide or leather for a certain purpose, e.g., as a cot or a table top, and decides that this will be its fixed purpose, it is considered a finished product and is susceptible to contracting impurity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to hides <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to a leatherworker, thought does not render them susceptible </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to ritual impurity. </span>Since this individual sells leather to others, when he uses a piece of leather for a household purpose and decides that this will be its fixed purpose, it is not considered a finished state, as he is likely to change his mind and sell the leather to one who will process it further and put it to a different use.
The mishna continues: If the hides are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a thief, </span>who has stolen them from another, the thief’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>If they are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a robber, </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">thought does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity, </span>because he is not considered the owner of the hide. The difference is that unlike the case of a thief, who steals items stealthily, the identity of a robber, who takes the item openly, is known to the owner, and he harbors hope of finding him and getting the item back. Consequently, he does not despair of recovering his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the matters are reversed: </span>In the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a robber, </span>the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">thought renders them susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>If the hides are those <span class="gemarra-regular">of a thief, thought does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity, because the owners have not despaired </span>of recovering them and the thief has not acquired the hide. Rabbi Shimon’s reasoning is that a robber, who seizes items brazenly, is a more difficult criminal to apprehend and bring to justice than a thief.
The Gemara analyzes the scope of the dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: The dispute </span>is only with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to an unspecified </span>case, where it is unknown whether or not the owners despaired, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where it is known </span>that the owners despaired, <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>that their <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>effects legal <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>Even in cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is known </span>that the owners despaired, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">also a dispute, </span>because although the owner may have expressed despair verbally, he may still hope to retrieve the item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rabba: Do not disagree with Ulla, as </span>the formulation of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned in the mishna </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his </span>opinion. The mishna states that according to Rabbi Shimon, thought does not render the hides of a thief susceptible to ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because the owners did not despair </span>of retrieving them, and therefore the hides do not belong to the thief. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the thought of the thief does not render the hides susceptible to ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">is that the owners did not despair </span>of retrieving them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the owners </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of retrieving them, then <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items would be <span class="gemarra-regular">his, </span>and his thoughts would render the hides susceptible to ritual impurity.
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We learned </span>the mishna as saying: A thief cannot render the hides susceptible to ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is no </span>true <span class="gemarra-regular">despair for owners </span>of stolen goods, even if they state they have despaired.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna here that if <span class="gemarra-regular">customs collectors took one’s donkey </span>and replaced it with a donkey taken from another Jew, or if bandits took his garment and replaced it with a garment taken from another Jew, he may keep these items because the owners despaired of retrieving them when they were stolen. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in this mishna?
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who hold that the owner despairs only in the case of a thief who steals secretly, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult, </span>because the mishna indicates that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>also despairs of retrieving his property, as in the case of a customs collector. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the owner despairs only in the case of a robber, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult, </span>because the mishna indicates that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thief </span>also despairs of retrieving his property, as in the case of bandits.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to Ulla, who says </span>that all agree that if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known </span>that the owners despaired, the individual in possession of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too </span>it is possible to explain that the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is known </span>that the owners despaired, <span class="gemarra-regular">and all agree </span>that the recipient of the stolen property may keep it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rabba, who says </span>that even in cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is known </span>that the owners despaired, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">also a dispute, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna written? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and it is not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon. </span>The Gemara answers that the mishna is discussing a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who is similar to a robber in that he steals using force and aggression. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the victim of a robber despairs of recovering his property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, this is </span>identical to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, </span>i.e., the customs collector, and there is no reason for the mishna to teach the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> twice. The Gemara answers that the mishna in fact teaches the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers, </span>the customs collector and the armed bandit.
The Gemara suggests another proof with regard to the dispute between Ulla and Rabba. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, a robber, and one who forces </span>another to sell him some-thing, <span class="gemarra-regular">their consecrated items are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, and their </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and their tithes are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> assumes that even the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber</span> despairs of retrieving his property, as seen from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the robber’s act of consecration or separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> or tithes is valid. This contradicts the opinion of the Rabbis, who hold that the thoughts of a robber do not render the hides susceptible to ritual impurity, because he is not considered the owner of the hides. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> assumes that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>despairs of retrieving his property, as seen from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the robber’s act of consecration or separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> or tithes is valid. This contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, as he holds that the thoughts of a thief do not render the hides susceptible to ritual impurity, because he is not considered the owner of the hides.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to Ulla, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known </span>that the owners despaired of recovering their property, the individual in possession of the items <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>it is possible to explain that the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is known </span>that the owners despaired. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rabba, who says </span>that even in cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is known </span>that the owners despaired, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">also a dispute, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> written? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>written in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mentions a thief it is actually referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit, </span>who is considered a robber because he steals using force and aggression. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the victim of a robber despairs of recovering his property. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>identical to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, </span>and there is no reason for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to teach the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> twice. The Gemara answers that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> wishes to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers.</span>
The Gemara offers an alternative explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> is referring to an actual thief, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>written in accordance the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: A thief </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a robber. </span>

Daf 114b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And we maintain, </span>as the Gemara concludes below, that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi means that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the owner despairs of recovering his item once it is stolen by a robber.
§ The Gemara examines <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I say </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber. A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Was Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>who hold that the owners do not despair of recovering their item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a thief therefore does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the items he steals? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he was saying </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the owners despair of recovering their property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a thief therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the stolen items.
The Gemara attempts to resolve the dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">customs collectors took </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey </span>and gave him a different donkey that was taken from another Jew in its stead, or if bandits took his garment and gave him a different garment that was taken from a Jew in its stead, these items are now his because the owners despaired of retrieving them when they were stolen. It is therefore apparent that despair is assumed both in the case of a robber, i.e., the customs collector, and in the case of a thief, i.e., the bandits.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in this mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who assume that the owners despair only in the case of a thief, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the mishna assumes that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>also despairs of retrieving his property. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who assumes that the owners despair only in the case of a robber, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the mishna assumes that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>also despairs of retrieving his property.
The Gemara presents the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the owners despair of recovering their property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a thief therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the stolen items, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason that a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the stolen goods.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying</span> that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, and </span>a thief therefore does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the stolen goods, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? Since the mishna rules that the owners have presumably despaired with regard to both a thief and a robber, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, and it is not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with an armed bandit, </span>who is considered a robber because he steals using force and aggression, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that despair is assumed in the case of a robber. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, this is </span>identical to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, </span>i.e., the mishna’s first case of the customs collector, and there is no reason for the mishna to teach the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> twice. The Gemara answers: The mishna wishes to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof based upon the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief, a robber, and one who forces </span>another to sell him something, <span class="gemarra-regular">their consecrated items are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated, and their </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and their tithes are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> assumes that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>also despairs of retrieving his property, and therefore the robber’s act of consecration or separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> or tithes is valid. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> assumes that the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thief </span>despairs of retrieving his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that the owner despairs of recovering his property, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason that a thief therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the stolen items. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> written?
The Gemara responds: When the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers to a thief, it is actually referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit, </span>who is legally considered a robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who holds that victims of a robber despair of recovering their property. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, this is </span>identical to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>that is mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> wishes to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Rabba: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s own interpretation of the mishna (111b) that states that children who inherit an item that was stolen by their father are obligated to return it to the owner if it is something that serves as a legal guarantee of a loan, e.g., land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">would teach Rabbi Shimon, his son, </span>that the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring only to <span class="gemarra-regular">something that may actually serve </span>as a legal <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>i.e., land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he plows with, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he drives </span>by directing it from <span class="gemarra-regular">behind, </span>which the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">are obligated to return because of the honor of their father.</span>
The Gemara infers: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that the heirs must return the stolen item is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the honor of their father. But </span>if it were <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the honor of their father, </span>they would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be required to return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to a thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber </span>according to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon. </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a swarm of bees, </span>if the owners despaired of retrieving the bees, they belong to the one who found them. The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the reason that the mishna includes the case of the bees, which begins with the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so too?</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is saying: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated by the mishna applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a swarm of bees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which is </span>the property of the owners via <span class="gemarra-regular">a rabbinic </span>form of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisitio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> due to the fact that one cannot effect a legal acquisition of bees by Torah law. It might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">since one acquires </span>the swarm of bees <span class="gemarra-regular">only by rabbinic law, even </span>where the owners’ response is <span class="gemarra-regular">unspecified </span>it can be assumed that they <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of recovering the bees, and the finder may keep them. To counter this, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is known that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owners </span>of the bees <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired</span> of recovering them, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>the finder may keep the bees; <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>despair, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he may not keep them.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka said: A woman or a mino</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is deemed credible </span>to say: It was from here that this swarm emerged, and it therefore belongs to a certain individual.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are a woman and a minor eligible for testimony? </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that women and minors cannot present testimony in court, so how can Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka rule that they are deemed credible? The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: Here, we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the owners were pursuing </span>the bees, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the woman and the minor were speaking offhandedly and saying: </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">from here that this swarm emerged. </span>In this context, it can be assumed that the individual identified as the owner is the real owner of the bees, even in the absence of formal testimony in court.
Having mentioned a case of offhand remarks, the Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: </span>Information gleaned from <span class="gemarra-regular">one who speaks offhandedly is valid only with regard to testimony </span>enabling <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>to remarry, as the Sages were lenient and decreed that the incidental remarks of certain individuals who are not eligible to serve as witnesses may be relied upon in such a case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And </span>is it so that one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>rely upon offhand remarks in other situations? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the case in the mishna of <span class="gemarra-regular">a swarm of bees is</span> a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">speaks offhandedly, </span>and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that he is deemed credible. Rav Ashi answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">A swarm of bees is different, as it is </span>the property of its owners via <span class="gemarra-regular">a rabbinic </span>form of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition. </span>Consequently, the Sages relied on offhand remarks.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is there <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>case where offhand remarks expressed by those who are ineligible to testify in court would be accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Torah law? But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain person who was speaking offhandedly and saying: I remember when I was a child and I </span>would still <span class="gemarra-regular">ride on father’s shoulder. And they took me from schoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and removed my tunic, and immersed me </span>in a ritual bath so that I would be able <span class="gemarra-regular">to partake of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that evening.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ḥanina </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude</span> his retelling of the incident <span class="gemarra-regular">as follows: </span>That individual then went on to say: <span class="gemarra-regular">And my friends </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">separate </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">from me, and they would call me: Yoḥanan, eater of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥallot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a reference to the portion of dough given to the priests, which has the same status as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>after hearing this anecdote, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">elevated him to the priesthoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and granted him the right to partake of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on his statement. </span>Since it is prohibited for non-priests to consume <span class="it-text">teruma</span> by Torah law, it is apparent that offhand remarks may be relied upon even with regard to Torah law, even in cases unrelated to enabling a woman to remarry.
Rav Ashi answers: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi granted him the right to partake of produce that is <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic law, </span>as he holds that the requirement to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> after the destruction of the Temple is by rabbinic law. One can still posit that offhand remarks made by individuals who are ineligible to testify in court are not deemed credible with regard to Torah law.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And still, </span>is there <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>other case where offhand remarks made by those who are ineligible to testify in court would be accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law? But when Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, didn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">he say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥana of Carthage [Kartigna]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and some say </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Carthage, related: An incident came before Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, and some say </span>that this <span class="gemarra-regular">incident came before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a certain child who was speaking offhandedly and said: My mother and I were captured </span>and held <span class="gemarra-regular">among the gentiles. </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">I would go out to draw water, my mind </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">on my mother, </span>and when I would go out <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gather wood, my mind </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">on my mother. </span>Since the child was always conscious of his mother, he was aware that she was not violated by her captors.
The Gemara concludes the statement of Rav Dimi and explains the challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">married her to a priest </span>based <span class="gemarra-regular">on his statement. </span>Since it is prohibited by Torah law for a priest to marry a woman who has engaged in sexual intercourse with a man forbidden to her by Torah law and with whom she cannot establish a marital bond, e.g., a gentile, it is clear that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi relied on an offhand remark even with regard to a prohibition by Torah law.
The Gemara answers: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">were lenient with regard to a captured woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> By Torah law, a woman taken captive may be presumed to remain permitted to a priest, and it is the Sages who decreed that she is forbidden due to the concern that she was raped. It is this rabbinic decree that may be disregarded on the basis of offhand remarks.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the bees settled on a branch of a tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not cut </span>off the other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">branch </span>in order to take the bees, even <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that he will later <span class="gemarra-regular">give him the money </span>for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: It is a stipulation of the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which takes effect even without being confirmed by individuals, <span class="gemarra-regular">that one will</span> be permitted to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter another’s field and cut off another’s branch </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to salvage his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">swarm </span>of bees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the owner of the field then <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the value of his branch from his fellow’s swarm.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court that </span>one who sees another’s honey barrel break <span class="gemarra-regular">should pour out his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and </span>then use the empty wine barrel to <span class="gemarra-regular">salvage the other’s honey, </span>which is more expensive than wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the owner of the wine then <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the value of his wine from the other’s honey. And it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court that one </span>who sees that another’s donkey has fallen <span class="gemarra-regular">should unload his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">wood </span>from his own donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">and load the other’s flax, </span>which is more expensive than wood, in its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the owner of the wood then <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the value of his wood from the other’s flax. </span>These stipulations take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on this condition </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua apportioned Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who recognizes his </span>stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in another’s possession, and a rumor had spread in the city </span>that the former had been the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft, the purchaser, </span>i.e., the one in possession of these items, <span class="gemarra-regular">must take an oath to </span>the victim as to <span class="gemarra-regular">how much </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">he spent </span>on the purchase, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>that sum of money in exchange for returning the items. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if no </span>such rumor had spread, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not in </span>the purported victim’s <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>to assert that the items were stolen, and he is not entitled to demand their return, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The items were never stolen; rather, the purported victim <span class="gemarra-regular">sold them to another, and this </span>individual who currently possesses the item <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased them from </span>that other person.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if a rumor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spread in the city </span>that he had been the victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft, what of it? Let us suspect </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he sold the items and he himself is spreading the rumor </span>that they were stolen so that he will be able to buy them back.
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where people, </span>i.e., guests, <span class="gemarra-regular">cam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into his house, and he arose at night and shouted [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehifgin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and said: My vessels have been stolen, </span>in which case it seems clear that he was the victim of theft. The Gemara rejects this rationale: On the contrary, the suspicion that he is lying should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he has found a pretext </span>for claiming that his property was stolen, and it should be suspected that he is taking advantage of the situation dishonestly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> by stating <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rav: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a group of people spent the night in his house. And <span class="gemarra-regular">there was a tunnel </span>that had been <span class="gemarra-regular">burrowed into his house, and the people that stayed overnight </span>as guests <span class="gemarra-regular">in his house left with bundles of vessels on their shoulders, and everyone says: So-and-so’s vessels were stolen. </span>In such a case, there is clear evidence that the homeowner was the victim of theft.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels were </span>stolen but <span class="gemarra-regular">scrolls were not. </span>Why must the purchaser return the scrolls as well as the vessels? The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>everyone <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">scrolls </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>stolen.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us suspect </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>scrolls were taken, while <span class="gemarra-regular">he is claiming </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>scrolls were stolen. If this is the case, he is claiming scrolls that do not belong to him. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case where people <span class="gemarra-regular">are saying: Such and such a scroll and such and such </span>a scroll were stolen, i.e., it is known which scrolls were taken from the homeowner.
The Gemara questions this as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the scrolls that were stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">were old </span>and had therefore depreciated in value, while <span class="gemarra-regular">he is claiming </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">new </span>scrolls were taken. If so, he is claiming scrolls that do not belong to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>The mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">These are so-and-so’s vessels </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">these are so-and-so’s scrolls. </span>In this case it is known exactly which items were stolen.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rav </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Rav </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a burglar </span>who came in <span class="gemarra-regular">and took vessels and left is exempt </span>from paying for those items? <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this exemption? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">he purchases them with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">blood. </span>Since a homeowner is allowed to kill a burglar, a burglar is exempt from returning the stolen items, based on the principle: One receives the greater punishment. Consequently, if the burglar himself is exempt, how can one who purchases an item from the burglar be required to return it?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter, that </span>one who steals <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>what he stole, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to a burglar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as he initially subjected himself to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>when he broke into the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>thieves, who stayed overnight as guests of the homeowner, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>break into the house and thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">subject themselves to </span>being <span class="gemarra-regular">killed, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>exempt from returning the stolen item.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: We taught </span>that all of these conditions must be met before the purchaser can be forced to return the item <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a homeowner who is wont to sell his vessels, but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a homeowner who is not wont to sell his vessels, </span>

Daf 115a

one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need to pursue </span>the matter in <span class="gemarra-regular">all this </span>detail.
The Gemara questions this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he needed money, and he </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the items despite the fact that he does not generally sell his personal belongings. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: A rumor spread in the city </span>that he had been a victim of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft. </span>It is reasonable to assume that he is the rightful owner, as he does not usually sell his belongings and it is common knowledge that he was the victim of theft.
§ Having assessed the mishna’s ruling with regard to a case where the thief remained unidentified, the Gemara discusses a case where the thief was found. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>In a case where a thief <span class="gemarra-regular">stole </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and later the thief was identified, Rav says in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: </span>The homeowner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>can be pursued only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the first </span>one, i.e., the thief, but he has no claim against the purchaser. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yannai: </span>The homeowner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>can also be pursued <span class="gemarra-regular">with the second </span>one, i.e., with the purchaser.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree. Here, </span>in the case about which Rabbi Yoḥanan issues his ruling, the item was purchased from the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the victim of the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired </span>of recovering the stolen item. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>can be pursued even <span class="gemarra-regular">with the second </span>one, i.e., the purchaser. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case about which Rav issues his ruling, the item was purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the victim <span class="gemarra-regular">despaired, </span>and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>can be pursued only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the first </span>one, i.e., the thief.
Rav Yosef continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And both </span>Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan have accepted as <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the ruling of Rav Ḥisda </span>(111b), that if the owner had not yet despaired of retrieving his item, he can press his claim against either the thief or the purchaser.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree? Isn’t </span>a case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts </span>to which members <span class="gemarra-regular">of the priesthood </span>are entitled <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable </span>to a case of a stolen item that was sold <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the onset of the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">despair, </span>as the priest still hopes to receive the gifts, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>with regard to their legal status? This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 132a): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one said to </span>a butcher: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sell me the innards of a cow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the gifts of the priesthood were in them, </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">must give </span>the gifts <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not deduct </span>the value of the gifts <span class="gemarra-regular">from the money </span>he agreed to pay the butcher. By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he purchased </span>the innards <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the butcher <span class="gemarra-regular">by weight, he must give </span>the gifts <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may deduct </span>the value of the gifts <span class="gemarra-regular">from the money </span>he agreed to pay the butcher.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">weighed </span>the innards <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the butcher weighed </span>the innards <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, the </span>priest’s <span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>may be pursued only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the butcher. </span>The butcher is comparable to a thief when he sells the gifts of the priesthood to a non-priest, and Rav holds that the priest can press his claim only against the butcher. Similarly, in the case of the mishna he would hold that the owner can press his claim only against the thief and not against the purchaser.
The Gemara refutes Abaye’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that Rav meant that the priest can <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>pursue his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim with the butcher, </span>although he is certainly able to claim the gifts from the purchaser. And Rav had to teach this <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts of the priesthood are not </span>considered to have been <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen </span>even if the butcher sells them, because wherever they are they remain the legal property of the priests. Rav therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that they are considered to have been stolen in this case, and therefore the priest can press his claim against the butcher.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Abaye, who said </span>that Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree, with regard to what </span>do they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? </span>The Gemara answers: They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda. </span>Rav disagrees with Rav Ḥisda and rules that one is entitled to collect only from the thief, while Rabbi Yoḥanan accepts the ruling of Rav Ḥisda and allows one to collect from either the thief or the purchaser.
The Gemara presents another explanation of the dispute between Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said </span>that both agree that if the owner has not yet despaired of retrieving his item, he can press his claim against either party. They disagree in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the owners despaired </span>of retrieving it only after the item was already <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the purchaser, but they did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>when it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the thief.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is with regard to this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>on the part of the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a change in possession </span>of a stolen item, e.g., it leaves the possession of the thief and enters the possession of a purchaser, the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the item. By contrast, if there is first <span class="gemarra-regular">a change in possession </span>of a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>on the part of the owner, then the purchaser does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the item. Since in this case the owner did not despair until after the change of possession from the thief to the purchaser, the purchaser did not legally acquire the item, and the owner can press his claim against him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no differenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> whether the despair or change of possession came first. As long as the owner has despaired of recovering his item, it becomes the property of the purchaser, and the owner cannot demand that he return it.
The Gemara presents a third explanation of the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that it </span>must be <span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>by the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner. But here, it is with regard to </span>whether the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case that Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>can be pursued only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the first </span>one, i.e., the thief, meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law with regard to the purchaser </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>after returning the item to its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can collect money </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the thief,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yannai </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the claim </span>of the purchaser can be pursued <span class="gemarra-regular">with the second one, </span>meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law with regard to the purchaser </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he can </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money from the owne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> when he returns the item to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case.
The Gemara questions this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rav hold </span>that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case? <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t Rav Huna a student of Rav, and </span>yet when a certain thief known as <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanan the Wicke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stole a cloak and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it, </span>and the case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Huna, he said to that man </span>from whom the cloak was stolen: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go redeem your pledge </span>from the purchaser, i.e., reimburse the purchaser for the garment that he returned to you. Evidently, Rav’s own student held that the Sages did allow a purchaser to claim reimbursement from the owner.
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanan the Wicked is different. Since </span>he has no money, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>way for the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">to collect payment from him, </span>and the case is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable </span>to a case where the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">was not identified, </span>with regard to which case the Sages implemented the provision ensuring the integrity of the marketplace.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: If he is a well-known thief</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case. The purchaser should have been aware that the item may be stolen and should not have purchased it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t Ḥanan the Wicked well known, and </span>yet, according to Rav Huna, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Although </span>he was <span class="gemarra-regular">well known for villainy, </span>he was <span class="gemarra-regular">not well known for theft.</span>
§ The Gemara continues to examine the provision ensuring the integrity of the marketplace. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his deb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with the stolen item, or one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his </span>debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">credit </span>that was extended to him with the stolen item, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they say </span>to the creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was not with the expectation of </span>receiving <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">that you gave </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">anything.</span>
With regard to the integrity of the marketplace, it was also stated that if a thief provided a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">worth two hundred </span>dinars as <span class="gemarra-regular">collatera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>a loan of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span>dinars, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case. Consequently, the creditor is entitled to reimbursement from the owner for returning the collateral. If the collateral and the loan were <span class="gemarra-regular">of equal value</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ameimar said: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case, while <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case.
