The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Mar Zutra that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case.
The Gemara examines other applications of this provision: In <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if the stolen item was purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">for an amount equal </span>to its actual market value, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case. If a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one hundred </span>dinars was purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sheshet says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case, while <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did implement the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case.
The Gemara states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">in all these </span>cases the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace, except </span>with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his debt </span>with the stolen item and one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his </span>debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">credit </span>that was extended to him with the stolen item.
The Gemara recounts a related incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Avimi bar Nazi, the father-in-law of Ravina, was owed four dinars by a certain man, </span>who then <span class="gemarra-regular">stole a cloak and brought it to </span>Avimi as repayment for the loan. Avimi then <span class="gemarra-regular">lent him four additional dinars. In the end, the thief was identified </span>as the debtor, and the case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Ravina </span>to determine whether or not the owner would have to pay Avimi for returning the cloak.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to Avimi: With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>four dinars that were lent, the thief is viewed as one who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his debt, and </span>the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">not required to give anything </span>in exchange for the garment’s return as the Sages’ ordinance ensuring the integrity of the marketplace does not apply in such a case. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those four additional dinars, take your money </span>from the owner of the cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">and return the cloak </span>to him. Since Avimi lent the second set of dinars only because he had received the cloak, Ravina ruled that the Sages’ ordinance applied to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kohen objects to this: But perhaps the cloak was given </span>to Avimi only in payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for these first </span>four <span class="gemarra-regular">dinars, </span>and it was a case of a thief who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his debt </span>or who <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and repaid his </span>debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">credit </span>that was extended to him with the stolen item. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the latter four dinars </span>were loaned because Avimi <span class="gemarra-regular">trusted the debtor, just as he trusted him initially, </span>when he lent the first four dinars. The cloak was not collateral for the second loan, and therefore the Sages’ ordinance should not apply. <span class="gemarra-regular">The matter circulated </span>until <span class="gemarra-regular">it came before Rabbi Abbahu, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kohen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara recounts another incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">A resident of Naresh stole a scroll </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it to a resident of Pappunya for eighty dinars. The resident of Pappunya </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">went and sold it to a resident of Meḥoza for one hundred and twenty dinars. In the end, the thief was identified </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: The </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the scroll should go and give the resident of Meḥoza eighty dinars and take his scroll </span>in return. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>afterward, <span class="gemarra-regular">the resident of Meḥoza should go and take </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">forty </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">from the resident of Pappunya.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava objects to this: Now </span>that it has been established that with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">purchases from a thief, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">implemented the provision </span>ensuring <span class="gemarra-regular">the integrity of the marketplace in this </span>case despite the fact that he dealt with the thief directly, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> to teach that the same would apply to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">from a purchaser? </span>Accordingly, the final purchaser is entitled to receive from the original owner the full amount that he paid for the item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the scroll should go and give the resident of Meḥoza one hundred and twenty dinars and take his scroll </span>in return. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the scroll should g</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and collect forty</span> dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">from the resident of Pappunya and eighty </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">from the resident of Naresh, </span>as each profited from the sale in these amounts, respectively.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a situation where <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">came with his barrel of wine, and that </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">came with his jug of honey, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel of honey cracked and this </span>first individual <span class="gemarra-regular">poured </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">his wine and salvaged the </span>other’s <span class="gemarra-regular">honey, </span>which is worth more than the wine, by collecting it <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>his wine barrel, 

Daf 115b

the owner of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">only his wage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., compensation for the effort he put into salvaging the honey. He is not, however, entitled to compensation for the wine itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the owner of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I will salvag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">and you will pay me the value of my </span>wine, the owner of the honey is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to pay him </span>compensation for the wine.
Similarly, if <span class="gemarra-regular">a river washed away his donke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the donkey of another, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>donkey was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one hundred dinars and </span>the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">of the other </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth two hundred, and </span>the individual with the less valuable donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">abandoned his </span>donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">salvaged </span>the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">of the other, he has </span>the right to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">only his wage, </span>i.e., compensation for the effort he put into salvaging his fellow’s donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to </span>the owner of the more valuable donkey: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will salvage your </span>donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">and you will pay me the </span>monetary value <span class="gemarra-regular">of mine </span>in exchange, the owner of the more valuable donkey is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to pay </span>the rescuer compensation for his donkey.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>does one who pours out wine have the right to collect only this wage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him say to </span>the owner of the honey: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have acquired </span>your honey <span class="gemarra-regular">from ownerless </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who was laden </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of wine and jugs of oil and saw that they were breaking </span>and their contents were leaking out should <span class="gemarra-regular">not say: This is hereby </span>separated as <span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and tithe for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce that I have in my house. And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if he said </span>this, it is as though <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say anything. </span>The fact that one cannot separate produce that is about to be lost as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> or tithe indicates that such property is considered ownerless.
The Gemara answers that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yirmeya says </span>in a different context, that the ruling discussed there is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the basket of the olive pres</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">wrapped around it </span>so that the barrel would not break completely, and some of the contents would remain inside. <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, </span>here, the mishna issued its ruling only <span class="gemarra-regular">when the basket of the olive press </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">wrapped around </span>the honey barrel so that it would not break completely, and the contents are therefore not rendered ownerless.
The Gemara challenges the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if he said </span>that the wine or oil is separated as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> or tithe, it is as though <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say anything. But isn’t it taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was traveling on the road and had money in his possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>he saw <span class="gemarra-regular">a ruffian </span>moving <span class="gemarra-regular">toward him, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">should not say: The </span>second-tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">produce that I have in my hous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is hereby desacralized onto these coins, </span>i.e., the sanctity of the produce is hereby transferred to the coins. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said </span>so, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands, </span>and the produce is desacralized while the coins attain the sanctity of the second tithe.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is capable of saving </span>his money from the ruffian and that is why he may transfer the sanctity of the second tithe to the coins. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is capable of saving </span>the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">why should he not say </span>that the produce should be desacralized <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is capable of saving </span>the money only <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficulty. </span>Consequently, he should not transfer the sanctity of the second tithe to the coins, as it may be lost; but if he does so, the transfer takes effect, as it is not certain that the money will be lost.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">wherever there is </span>a potential <span class="gemarra-regular">loss one should not say </span>that the sanctity is transferred to the money <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But isn’t it taught </span>otherwise in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one had ten barrels of ritually impure, untithed </span>wine, i.e., first-tithe wine from which the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe had not yet been separated, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he saw that one of them had broken </span>and that its contents were leaking out, <span class="gemarra-regular">or that it had been expose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and is forbidden for consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may say: This </span>barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">is hereby </span>separated as <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe for the other nine </span>barrels. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to oil, he should not do so due to the priest’s loss</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> issued its ruling only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">basket of the olive press </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">wrapped around </span>the barrel so that some of its contents would remain inside. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>this rationale applies to a barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">that was broken, </span>as the remaining contents are still <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>for use, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to a barrel that was <span class="gemarra-regular">exposed, for what </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">is it fit?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the exposed wine is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for sprinkling, </span>in order to spread its pleasant aroma, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>otherwise in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">water that was exposed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not pour it </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, nor mix clay with it, nor settle </span>dust <span class="gemarra-regular">with it </span>by sprinkling it in <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, nor give it to his animal to drink</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor </span>give it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the animal of another. </span>This proves that exposed liquids may not be used even for sprinkling.
The Gemara answers: The wine is fit for use <span class="gemarra-regular">because he passed it through a strainer, </span>and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A vessel covered with <span class="gemarra-regular">a strainer is subject to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">exposure </span>if the vessel is left unsupervised. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya said: When </span>is this so? It is so <span class="gemarra-regular">when the lower vessel, </span>in which the liquid collects after passing through the strainer, <span class="gemarra-regular">is exposed. But when the lower vessel is covered, even if the upper vessel is exposed, it is not subject to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">exposure, because the venom of a snake is like a sponge </span>in that <span class="gemarra-regular">it floats and stays in place.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Wasn’t it stated with regard to </span>Rabbi Neḥemya’s ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Simon says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: They taught </span>Rabbi Neḥemya’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">only where one did not mix it, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one mixed </span>the wine, any venom found in it becomes capable of penetrating the strainer? Consequently, the wine remains <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden </span>even if it is passed through a strainer.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, too, it is possible </span>to prevent the venom from mixing with the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">by placing something upon the mouth of a barrel that will filter it </span>slowly so that the venom will not penetrate the strainer, and the wine may therefore be used.
It has now been established that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that if one’s barrel of untithed, impure wine is breaking, he may separate it as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe for other barrels of untithed, impure wine, may be explained in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Neḥemya. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya, may we separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> from impure produce for other impure produce?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure for </span>other produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, and from </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure for </span>other produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure, and from </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure for </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, but not from </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure for </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Neḥemya says: Even </span>with regard to separating <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure for </span>produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted one to separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">only in the case of doubtfully tithed produce [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">demai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Consequently, how can the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span> unequivocally permit one to separate impure wine as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe for other impure wine? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">a case of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">demai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara discusses the continuation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited previously: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to oil, he should not do so, due to the priest’s loss. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about a leaking barrel of impure <span class="gemarra-regular">oil, </span>which one may not separate as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, because if he does so the priest will suffer a loss? That case is different <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the impure <span class="it-text">teruma</span> oil <span class="gemarra-regular">is fit </span>to be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to kindle </span>a fire, and the priest will now not receive that oil. The Gemara challenges: But <span class="gemarra-regular">wine is also fit </span>to be used, as the priest is able <span class="gemarra-regular">to sprinkle </span>it in order to impart a pleasant aroma. Why is there is no concern that the priest will suffer a loss? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling is nothing, </span>i.e., it is insignificant, <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t Shmuel say in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One drinks from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span> of wine worth one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and one sprinkles from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span> of wine worth <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which indicates that there is greater benefit in sprinkling wine than in drinking it?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with new </span>wine that has not yet developed an aroma and is therefore not fit for sprinkling. The Gemara counters: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it fit to </span>allow it to <span class="gemarra-regular">age </span>so that it will become fit for sprinkling? The Gemara responds: If one waits for it to age, he might <span class="gemarra-regular">come to </span>experience <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishap with it, </span>as he will forget that it is impure <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, which is forbidden for consumption.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Oil </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be subject to the concern that one might <span class="gemarra-regular">come to experience a mishap with it, </span>as he might forget that it is forbidden and mistakenly drink it. The Gemara explains: The halakha is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the priest must <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>the oil <span class="gemarra-regular">in a foul vessel, </span>and there is no concern that he will consume it, as such oil is used only for kindling. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the wine also be placed in a foul vessel, </span>in which case there would be no concern that he would drink it. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that he desires </span>to use <span class="gemarra-regular">it for sprinkling, would he place it in a foul vessel? </span>This would ruin its aroma. Consequently, the wine may not be kept due to concern over a possible mishap, while the oil may be kept.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the concern with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishap itself is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a barrel of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wine that became impure </span>and is therefore forbidden for consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: </span>

Daf 116a

The wine must <span class="gemarra-regular">all be poured ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in order to prevent a possible mishap. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>Let the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">be used </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling. Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: I will decide </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> by proposing an intermediate opinion: If the wine became impure <span class="gemarra-regular">in a house, it may be used </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling, </span>as it can be used immediately, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it became impure <span class="gemarra-regular">in the field, it must all be poured out, </span>as it is possible that by the time it is brought to the house and used for sprinkling, someone may drink it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that he decided the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to aged </span>wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">it may be used </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkling, </span>as it is fit to be sprinkled immediately, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to new </span>wine, which does not yet have a pleasant aroma, <span class="gemarra-regular">it must</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all be poured out </span>in order to prevent a possible mishap. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to </span>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei: <span class="gemarra-regular">A decision </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">a third </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>conclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">decide </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the owner of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the honey: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will salvage your </span>honey and you will pay me the value of my wine, the owner of the honey is obligated to give him compensation for the wine. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is the stipulation binding? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the owner of the honey <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: I was </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">fooling with you </span>when I accepted your condition, and I did not agree to it at all.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one was fleein</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from prison and there was a ferry before him, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to </span>the ferryman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Take </span>this entire <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar and take me across </span>the river, the ferryman <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">only his </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">wage, </span>but not the entire dinar. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the prisoner could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">fooling with you </span>and never intended to pay you a full dinar. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here also, let</span> the owner of the honey <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the wine: <span class="gemarra-regular">I was </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">fooling with you.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>case in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is not comparable </span>to the case cited above; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>it is comparable <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter clause </span>of that same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said to </span>the ferryman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Take this dinar as your wage and take me across </span>the river, the prisoner must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him his wage in the full amount, </span>i.e., the entire dinar.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>which states that the ferryman receives only his regular wage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>which states that he receives the full dinar? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said: </span>The latter clause deals <span class="gemarra-regular">with a trapper who scoops fish from the sea, </span>i.e., a fisherman, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the prisoner: <span class="gemarra-regular">You have caused me a los</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">fish [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kavrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar, </span>which I would have caught had I not taken you across the river. Similarly, in the case in the mishna, the owner of the wine sustains a financial loss in order to save the honey, and therefore he is entitled to the compensation that the owner of the honey agreed to pay.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a river washed away his donkey and the donkey of the other </span>man, and <span class="gemarra-regular">his donkey is worth one hundred dinars, </span>etc. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach both the case of the barrels of wine and honey and the case of the donkeys, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if it </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>case, that of the wine and honey, it might be said that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">that when </span>the owner of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>his stipulation, the owner of the honey <span class="gemarra-regular">gives him the value of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>loss. Why is this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">is lost through </span>the direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>of its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of the donkeys, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the donkey is lost <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself </span>in the river, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say: </span>The one who salvages the donkey of his fellow <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">only his wage, </span>i.e., compensation for his labor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the mishna had <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>only the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>it might be said: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is here, </span>in the case of the donkeys, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if the intention of the one who saved the donkey was <span class="gemarra-regular">unspecified, </span>i.e., he did not stipulate that the owner of the other donkey would compensate him for the loss of his own donkey, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">only his wage, because </span>the donkey is lost <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself. But there, </span>where the barrel of wine is lost <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>of its owner, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Even in </span>a case where the intention of the owner of the wine was <span class="gemarra-regular">unspecified, </span>the owner of the honey must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him the value of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>barrel of wine. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, both cases are <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary.</span>
The Gemara cites a relevant discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana raised a dilemma before Rav: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">descended </span>into the river <span class="gemarra-regular">to rescue </span>another’s donkey instead of his own after stipulating that he would be compensated for the loss of his own donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his </span>own donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from the river <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is the rescuer still entitled to payment from the owner of the donkey that he saved, despite the fact that he did not suffer a monetary loss? Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The rescuer is still compensated because it was <span class="gemarra-regular">from Heaven </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">mercy was bestowed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon him, </span>and his good fortune does not affect the stipulation.
This <span class="gemarra-regular">is like that </span>case where <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra was traveling in a caravan, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain lion </span>followed them, <span class="gemarra-regular">accompanying the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> along the way. <span class="gemarra-regular">Every night, </span>the travelers <span class="gemarra-regular">would send one of their donkeys to </span>the lion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the lion <span class="gemarra-regular">would eat </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Safra’s time arrived </span>to provide the lion with prey, <span class="gemarra-regular">he sent it </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey but </span>the lion <span class="gemarra-regular">did not eat it. Rav Safra went ahead and acquired it </span>back, as his donkey had become ownerless when he presented it to the lion. Although Rav Safra did not lose his donkey, he had fulfilled his obligation to provide the lion with a donkey, and his good fortune did not affect his obligation vis-à-vis the other travelers.
With regard to this episode, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Why </span>was it necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for him to acquire </span>the donkey again? <span class="gemarra-regular">Although </span>Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">made it ownerless </span>by sending it to the lion, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">made ownerless </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with the intention that the lion </span>would consume it, but <span class="gemarra-regular">it was not made ownerless with the intention that everyone </span>else could acquire it. Accordingly, no one else could have acquired the donkey. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Rav Safra did </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">as an added precaution.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav raised a dilemma before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">descended </span>into the river in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to rescue </span>another’s donkey instead of his own, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span>manage to <span class="gemarra-regular">rescue </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does the stipulation still apply so that the owner of the donkey he attempted to rescue must compensate him for the loss of his own donkey? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And is this a question? </span>It is clear that <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>the right to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">only his wage, </span>but he is not entitled to the value of his own donkey.
Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who hires a laborer</span>

Daf 116b

<span class="gemarra-regular">to bring cabbage and plum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to an ill </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he went and found that </span>the patient had already <span class="gemarra-regular">died or recovered, </span>the employer nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the worker <span class="gemarra-regular">his entire wage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Evidently, one is paid for his efforts even if the desired result is not accomplished. Accordingly, the rescuer’s stipulation should apply, and one should be obligated to pay another for attempting to salvage his donkey even if he did not actually succeed in doing so.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Are </span>those two cases <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, </span>in the case of the ill person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the agent performed his assignment, </span>as he procured and delivered the foods to the ill person, but <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of the donkeys, <span class="gemarra-regular">the agent did not perform his assignment, </span>as he was unable to rescue the animal from the river.
§ Apropos the episode involving Rav Safra, the Gemara discusses the division of expenses among travelers in a caravan. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a caravan that was traveling in the deser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a troop </span>of bandits <span class="gemarra-regular">stood over it </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>attack and <span class="gemarra-regular">pillage </span>it, and the members of the caravan agreed to pay ransom to the bandits, they <span class="gemarra-regular">calculate </span>each traveler’s contribution <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>he is carrying, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not calculate according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">souls </span>in the caravan, i.e., the expense is not divided equally among the travelers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if they hired a scout who travels in front of them </span>and leads them safely through the desert, the travelers <span class="gemarra-regular">calculate </span>each one’s contribution to paying the scout’s wages <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">souls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And they should not differ from the </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">custom of donkey drivers, </span>who often have set procedures for such situations.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The donkey drivers are permitted to stipulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone whose donkey becomes lost, </span>the caravan <span class="gemarra-regular">will provide him </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a different donkey. </span>If the donkey was lost <span class="gemarra-regular">through negligence, they do not provide him </span>with another donkey, but if it was lost <span class="gemarra-regular">not through negligence, they provide him </span>with another donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the individual whose donkey became lost <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Give me </span>money instead of the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will guard </span>the caravan along with everyone else, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not listen to him.</span>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">has another donkey, lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he will guard </span>the caravan <span class="gemarra-regular">for its </span>sake. Since he still owns one donkey, he never lost his incentive to guard the caravan, and the other drivers should therefore give him money if he wishes. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">guarding one </span>donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from guarding two </span>donkeys, and the driver will be more likely to guard the caravan properly if they supply him with another donkey.
§ The Gemara cites another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses the division of expenses among a group. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a boat that was traveling on the se</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> when <span class="gemarra-regular">a gale arose </span>and threatened <span class="gemarra-regular">to sink it, and </span>the sailors <span class="gemarra-regular">lightened its load </span>by throwing some of their belongings overboard, the sailors <span class="gemarra-regular">calculate </span>the amount that each must throw out <span class="gemarra-regular">according to weight, but </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not calculate </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>how much <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>the items are worth. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they should not differ from the </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">custom of sailors.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if a number of boats are traveling together, <span class="gemarra-regular">the sailors are permitted to stipulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone whose boat was lost, </span>the others <span class="gemarra-regular">will provide him </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a different boat. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>boat <span class="gemarra-regular">was lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through negligence, </span>the other sailors <span class="gemarra-regular">do not provide </span>him with another boat, but if it was lost <span class="gemarra-regular">not through negligence, </span>the sailors <span class="gemarra-regular">provide him </span>with another boat. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the boat <span class="gemarra-regular">sailed to a place where the boats do not travel, </span>the other sailors <span class="gemarra-regular">do not provide </span>him with a different boat.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary because in </span>the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Nisan, </span>the boats <span class="gemarra-regular">distance </span>themselves from the shore by <span class="gemarra-regular">one rope </span>length, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tishrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">distance </span>themselves by <span class="gemarra-regular">two rope </span>lengths. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this case, the boat <span class="gemarra-regular">was traveling during Nisan </span>and sailed <span class="gemarra-regular">to the place </span>where boats sail during <span class="gemarra-regular">Tishrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lest you say </span>that the sailor is not considered negligent because he <span class="gemarra-regular">is taking his </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">route and traveling </span>as he is accustomed to, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that his actions are considered negligent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a caravan that was traveling in the desert and a troop </span>of bandits <span class="gemarra-regular">stood </span>over it <span class="gemarra-regular">and pillaged it, and one of </span>the travelers <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and rescue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the caravan from the bandits, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has rescued </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for the common </span>good, i.e., each member of the caravan receives back his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he stated: I will rescue </span>the property from the bandits <span class="gemarra-regular">for myself, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">rescued </span>the items <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>and he is now the legal owner of all the property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>each member of the caravan is <span class="gemarra-regular">able to rescue </span>his property, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">latter clause, </span>where the rescuer states that he is saving the property for himself, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be that the possessions are rescued <span class="gemarra-regular">for the common </span>good, as the other members of the caravan did not despair of retrieving their property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>each member of the caravan is <span class="gemarra-regular">unable to rescue </span>his property, they despair of retrieving their property and relinquish ownership of it. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be that the possessions are saved <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>so that he is their legal owner. Why is there a discrepancy between the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the first clause and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the latter clause?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said: Here, </span>in the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a caravan whose members are <span class="gemarra-regular">partner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and jointly own the confiscated property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, a partner may divide </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">without the other </span>partner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">consent. </span>Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he said </span>that he intends to save the property for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has</span> dissolved the partnership and <span class="gemarra-regular">divided </span>the property so that if he is able to rescue only some of the property, the property he rescues is his share of the joint property. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>that he intends to save the property for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not divided </span>the property, and whatever he rescues is jointly owned by the partners.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava stated </span>a different answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with laborer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who were hired to protect the caravan, and one of these guards saved the travelers’ property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, as Rav says: A laborer may retract </span>his commitment to his employer <span class="gemarra-regular">even in the middle of the day.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As long as he did not retract </span>his commitment, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">considered </span>to be under the <span class="gemarra-regular">jurisdiction of the employer, </span>so that anything he saves automatically belongs to the employer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when he retracts </span>his commitment, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a different reason </span>that he is able to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “For unto Me the children of Israel are servants” </span>(Leviticus 25:55), indicating that Jews are servants of God, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not servants of servants, </span>i.e., of other Jews. Consequently, it is permitted for a laborer to conclude his term of employment whenever he wants. Once he does so, if he saves property that the members of the caravan are unable to rescue, the property belongs to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi stated </span>another answer: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the other members of the caravan are <span class="gemarra-regular">able to rescue </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficulty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he revealed his intention </span>to rescue the property for himself and the other travelers did not protest, it is clear that they have despaired of recovering their property, and the rescuer has secured the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not reveal his intention </span>to rescue the property for himself, the status quo remains and the property has been rescued <span class="gemarra-regular">for the common </span>good.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs a field from an-other and thugs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">massikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the field from the robber, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is dependent upon the circumstances: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is a regional disaster </span>in which the thugs seize all the property in the region, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the owner of the field: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">yours is before you, </span>i.e., it is your prerogative to try to reclaim it from the thugs. No compensation is required since the thugs would have seized the property in any event. But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the thugs took that field alone <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the robber, </span>the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to provide </span>the owner with <span class="gemarra-regular">a different field.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: One who teaches </span>the mishna using the term <span class="gemarra-italic">massikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not err, and one who teaches </span>the mishna using the term <span class="gemarra-italic">matzikin</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">does not err, </span>as both terms may be used to refer to thugs. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who teaches</span> the mishna using the term <span class="gemarra-italic">matzikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not err, as it is written: “In the siege and in the distress [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">matzok</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>with which your enemies shall distress you” (Deuteronomy 28:55). Consequently, <span class="it-text">matzikin</span> are individuals who cause distress to others.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one who teaches</span> the mishna using the term <span class="gemarra-italic">massikin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not err, as it is written: </span>“All your trees and the fruit of your land <span class="gemarra-regular">shall the locust consume” </span>(Deuteronomy 28:42), <span class="gemarra-regular">and, </span>in the standard Aramaic translation, <span class="gemarra-regular">we translate </span>this phrase as: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall the locust [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sakke’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] consume. </span>Consequently, <span class="it-text">massikin</span> are those who consume the property of others.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the thugs took the field <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the robber, </span>the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to provide the owner with a different field. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case in the latter clause of the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they seized </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">his land, </span>i.e., the robber’s land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not seize all </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">lands </span>in the region, <span class="gemarra-regular">you already learned this from the first clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is a regional disaster </span>in which the thugs seize all the property in the region, the robber is not obligated to compensate the owner of the field, which indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it is not </span>a regional disaster, the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>exempt from payment. What novelty does the latter clause teach?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the individual did not actually take control of the property before it was seized by the thugs, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">showed </span>the field to the thugs and thereby facilitated their occupation of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">A different version </span>of this answer is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>A case <span class="gemarra-regular">where gentiles coerced </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">and told him to show them his lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for them to seize, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he showed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>field belonging to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">along with </span>his own fields, and the thugs then seized all the land he showed them.
The Gemara recounts a related incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who showed piles of wheat, </span>belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Exilarch’s household, </span>to thugs, who seized them. The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>for judgment, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman deemed </span>that man <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>the Exilarch for the stolen wheat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef was sitting behind Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya, and Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya was sitting before Rav Naḥman. Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said to Rav Naḥman: </span>Did you deem him liable to pay because that is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or </span>was it <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine?</span>
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This individual’s liability <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>written explicitly in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, </span>i.e., it is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>thugs took the field <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the robber, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to provide </span>the owner with a different <span class="gemarra-regular">field. And it was established </span>that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">showed </span>the field to thugs, who later seized it. So too, in this case, the one who showed the Exilarch’s wheat pile to the thugs is obligated to pay for them. <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">left, Rav Yosef said to Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya: What difference does it make to you</span>

Daf 117a

<span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine? </span>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, we learn from it </span>and apply this ruling to other cases, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, we do not learn from it, </span>as it is possible that Rav Naḥman had a specific reason to impose a fine in this case.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do you say that we do not learn from </span>the imposition of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine </span>in one case and apply the ruling in other cases? The Gemara answers that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renders </span>another’s food <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure, </span>thereby rendering it unfit for him to consume, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who pours </span>another’s wine as <span class="gemarra-regular">a libatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for idol worship, thereby rendering it an item from which deriving benefit is prohibited, are liable to pay the owner for the financial loss they caused despite the fact that the fact that damage is not evident. <span class="gemarra-regular">Subsequently, </span>they added to this list, <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even one who intermingles </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span>, the portion of the produce designated for the priest, with another’s non-sacred produce, thereby rendering the non-sacred food forbidden to non-priests, is liable to compensate the owner for the loss of value of the produce, as fewer people will be willing to buy it from him.
The Gemara comments: It may be inferred from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is only because the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently </span>added to the list that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>one who intermingles <span class="it-text">teruma</span> with another’s non-sacred produce must compensate him. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">they had not subsequently </span>added to the list, he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that we do not learn that he is liable from the cases of one who renders another’s food impure or pours wine as a libation for idol worship, as this is also a case in which one causes damage that is not evident? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not due to </span>the fact that his payment <span class="gemarra-regular">is a fine, and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine, we do not learn from </span>one case that it may be imposed in other circumstances?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is not the reason. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">maintained </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">were concerned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to a large </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">loss, </span>e.g., the cases of one who renders another’s food impure or pours his wine as a libation for idol worship, but with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to a small </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">loss, </span>e.g., one who intermingles <span class="it-text">teruma</span> with another’s non-sacred produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">they were not concerned. And ultimately </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">maintained </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">were concerned </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to a small loss as well </span>and imposed liability.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But didn’t the father of Rabbi Avin teach </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially they would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who renders </span>another’s produce <span class="gemarra-regular">impure and one who intermingles </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> with another’s non-sacred produce are both liable to pay for the financial loss that they caused, despite the fact that the damage is not evident. <span class="gemarra-regular">Subsequently, </span>they added to this list, <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even one who pours </span>another’s wine as <span class="gemarra-regular">a libation </span>for idol worship is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>liable to pay a fine for the loss that he caused. It may be inferred that it is only because the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">subsequently </span>added to the list, that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>one who pours the libation is liable. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">they had not subsequently </span>added to the list, he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be liable.
The Gemara comments: Since one who offers libations for idol worship causes a large financial loss, the rationale offered previously cannot apply to this version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>that the liability for pouring another’s wine as a libation could not be extrapolated from the fine imposed for rendering another’s food impure or intermingling it with <span class="it-text">teruma</span>? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not learn from </span>the imposition of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fine </span>in one case that a fine may be imposed in other cases?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is not the reason. Rather, the reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">held in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Avin, and ultimately they held in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially they held in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Avin, as Rabbi Avin says: </span>If one stood in the public domain on Shabbat and <span class="gemarra-regular">shot an arro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the beginning of </span>an area measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">to the end of </span>an area measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the arrow <span class="gemarra-regular">tore </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">silks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shira’in</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the course of <span class="gemarra-regular">its travel </span>through the air, the one who threw it is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the cloth. The reason for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">that lifting </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">is a necessity for placing </span>it elsewhere, and therefore the entire process, from when one shoots the arrow until it comes to a rest, is considered to be a single act. The one performing it is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty for violating Shabbat. One who performs a single act for which he is liable to receive the death penalty and is also liable to pay money receives only the death penalty. Similarly, one who pours another’s wine as a libation for idol worship incurs the death penalty, and is therefore exempt from paying for the wine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And ultimately they held </span>that the liabilities are not incurred simultaneously, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya, as Rabbi Yirmeya says: From the time of the lifting, </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the wine and is therefore immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">money to </span>the owner. But <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty <span class="gemarra-regular">until the time </span>that he pours the <span class="gemarra-regular">libation. </span>Once the Sages concluded that the liabilities are not incurred simultaneously, they ruled that one who pours another’s wine as a libation for idol worship is liable to reimburse him.
§ The Gemara returns to the matter of one who showed another’s field to thugs. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Yehuda happened </span>to come <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the town of <span class="gemarra-regular">Bei Abiyonei </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Did any </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">incident come to you </span>for judgment recently? Rav Huna bar Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>There was a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew whom gentiles coerced and, </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he showed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another, </span>which the gentiles later seized. He <span class="gemarra-regular">came to me </span>for judgment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I deemed </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to compensate the owner for the loss.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> Rav Huna bar Yehuda: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>your decision in this <span class="gemarra-regular">case </span>and return the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to its owner, </span>i.e., the thug, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew whom gentiles coerce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and, </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he showed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>that the gentiles later seized, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from reimbursing the owner of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he </span>actively <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave </span>it to the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">hand, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to compensate the owner.
The Gemara adds that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: If he showed </span>the gentiles the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of his own </span>volition, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he </span>actively <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave </span>it to the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">hand, </span>and he is liable to compensate the owner.
The Gemara recounts another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man that gentiles </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">coerced and </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">he showed them the wine of Rav Mari, son of Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ḥisda, and </span>the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Carry </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">and bring it with us. </span>Complying with the gentiles, <span class="gemarra-regular">he carried and brought </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with them. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Ashi, </span>and he <span class="gemarra-regular">exempted </span>the man from compensating Rav Mari for the wine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis said to Rav Ashi: But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and manually transferred </span>it to the gentiles, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to compensate the owner? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: That statement applies </span>only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">did not bring </span>the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset; but if he brought </span>the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset, </span>it is as though <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">burned </span>it, as the gentiles then had access to the property. Since the damage inflicted by the Jew was committed by merely showing the wine to the gentiles, he is exempt from payment even though he later actively carried the wine with his hands.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a ruffian said to </span>a Jew: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pass me this bundle of grain, or this cluster of grapes, and </span>the Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">passed it to him, </span>the Jew is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the owner of the grain or the grapes. Since the ruffian was already present, it is evident from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that one who hands over another’s property to a third party is liable despite the fact that the latter already had access to it. Rav Ashi answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the Jew and the ruffian were <span class="gemarra-regular">standing on two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">sides of a river, </span>so that the ruffian did not have access to the item when the Jew passed it to him.
The Gemara points out that the language of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise </span>according to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>its ruling using the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pass, </span>which indicates that the ruffian could not have reached the item himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach </span>using the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give, </span>which would indicate that the ruffian was standing next to the other individual. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the language of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that Rav Ashi’s interpretation is correct.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>fishing <span class="gemarra-regular">net over which two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were quarreling. This one said: It is mine, and that one said: It is mine. One of them went and gave it to an officer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lefarhagna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the king. Abaye said: </span>He is exempt from payment because <span class="gemarra-regular">he can say </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I gave </span>it to the official, <span class="gemarra-regular">I gave </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">mine. Rava said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is it in his </span>power to do so when the ownership of the net is the subject of dispute? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: We excommunicate hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until he brings </span>the net back <span class="gemarra-regular">and stands in court </span>for adjudication.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who desired to show another </span>individual’s <span class="gemarra-regular">straw </span>to the gentile authorities, who would seize it. <span class="gemarra-regular">He came before Rav, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do not show </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and do not show </span>it, i.e., you are absolutely prohibited from showing it. The man <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will show </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will show </span>it, i.e., I will certainly show it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was sitting before Rav, </span>and, hearing the man’s disrespectful response, <span class="gemarra-regular">he dislodged </span>the man’s <span class="gemarra-regular">nec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from him, </span>i.e., he broke his neck and killed him.
Seeing Rav Kahana’s action, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav read </span>the following verse <span class="gemarra-regular">about him: “Your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons have fainted, they lie at the head of all the streets, as an antelope in a net” </span>(Isaiah 51:20). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this antelope, once it falls into the net, </span>the hunter <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have mercy upon it, so too </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the money of a Jew, once it falls into the hand of gentiles, they do not have mercy upon him, </span>i.e., the Jew. Since gentiles who seek a Jew’s money will kill him in order to seize the property, Rav Kahana acted appropriately when he broke the miscreant’s neck, as he protected the Jew’s property and, by extension, the Jew himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: <span class="gemarra-regular">Kahana, until now there were Persian </span>rulers <span class="gemarra-regular">who were not particular about bloodshed. But now there are Greek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who are particular about bloodshed, and they </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Murder [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meradin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> murder, </span>and they will press charges against you. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">get up </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">ascend to Eretz Yisrael </span>to study there under Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">and accept upon yourself that you will not raise </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">difficultie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the statements of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">seven years.</span>
Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>to Eretz Yisrael and <span class="gemarra-regular">found Reish Lakish, who was sitting and reviewing </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan’s <span class="gemarra-regular">daily </span>lecture in the <span class="gemarra-regular">academy for the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the students in the academy. When he finished, Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the students: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where is Reish Lakish? They said to him: Why </span>do you wish to see him? Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>I have <span class="gemarra-regular">this difficulty and that difficulty </span>with his review of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this resolution and that resolution </span>to the questions he raised. <span class="gemarra-regular">They told </span>this to <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish.
