Reish Lakish </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">went and said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: A lion has ascended from Babylonia, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master </span>ought <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine </span>the discourse he will deliver <span class="gemarra-regular">in the academy tomorrow, </span>as Rav Kahana may raise difficult questions about the material.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The next day, they seated </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first row, in front of Rabbi Yoḥanan. </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">stated a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">did not raise a difficulty, </span>in accordance with Rav’s instruction. Rabbi Yoḥanan stated another <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>again, Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">did not raise a difficulty. </span>As a result, <span class="gemarra-regular">they placed </span>Rav Kahana further <span class="gemarra-regular">back </span>by one row. This occurred until he had been moved back <span class="gemarra-regular">seven rows, until he was seated in the last row. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: The lion you mentioned has become a fox, </span>i.e., he is not knowledgeable.
Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">May it be </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">will that these seven rows </span>I have been moved <span class="gemarra-regular">should replace the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> seven years that Rav told me </span>to wait before raising difficulties to the statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan. <span class="gemarra-regular">He stood up on his feet and said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan: Let the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master go back to the beginning </span>of the discourse and repeat what he said. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">stated a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">raised a difficulty. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">they placed him in the first row, </span>and again, Rav Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">stated a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and he raised a difficulty.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan was sitting upon seven cushions [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bistarkei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> so that he could be seen by all the students, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since he could not answer Rav Kahana’s questions, <span class="gemarra-regular">he removed one cushion from under himself </span>to demonstrate that he was lowering himself out of respect for Rav Kahana. He then <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>another <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">difficulty. </span>This happened repeatedly <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">removed all the cushions from underneath himself until he was sitting on the ground. Rabbi Yoḥanan was an old man and his eyebrows drooped </span>over his eyes. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to </span>his students: <span class="gemarra-regular">Uncover my eyes for me and I will see </span>Rav Kahana, so <span class="gemarra-regular">they uncovered </span>his eyes <span class="gemarra-regular">for him with a silver eye brush.</span>
Once his eyes were uncovered, Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">saw that </span>Rav Kahana’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lips were spli</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">was smirking at him. </span>As a result, Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">was offended, and </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>as punishment for the fact that he offended Rabbi Yoḥanan. <span class="gemarra-regular">The next day, Rabbi Yoḥanan said to the Rabbis, </span>his students: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did you see how that Babylonian, </span>Rav Kahana, <span class="gemarra-regular">behaved </span>in such a disrespectful manner? <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: His </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of appearance <span class="gemarra-regular">is such, </span>and he was not mocking you. Hearing this, Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">went up to </span>Rav Kahana’s burial <span class="gemarra-regular">cave </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was</span>

Daf 117b

<span class="gemarra-regular">encircled by a serpent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akhna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which had placed its tail in its mouth, completely encircling the cave and blocking the entrance. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to it: Serpent, serpent, open your mouth and </span>allow <span class="gemarra-regular">the teacher </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>and be <span class="gemarra-regular">near the disciple, but </span>the serpent <span class="gemarra-regular">did not open </span>its mouth to allow him entry. He then said: Allow <span class="gemarra-regular">a colleague </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>and be <span class="gemarra-regular">near </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">colleague, but </span>still the serpent <span class="gemarra-regular">did not open </span>its mouth. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Allow the <span class="gemarra-regular">disciple </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>and be <span class="gemarra-regular">near the teacher, </span>referring to Rav Kahana as his own teacher. The snake then <span class="gemarra-regular">opened </span>its mouth <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>to allow him entry. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">requested </span>divine <span class="gemarra-regular">mercy </span>from God and <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span>Rav Kahana from the dead.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had I known that this was the Master’s manner </span>of appearance, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would not have been offended. Now </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master come with me </span>to the study hall. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If you are able to request </span>divine <span class="gemarra-regular">mercy </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will not die again</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I will go </span>with you, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if not, I will not go </span>with you. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the time </span>decreed for his death <span class="gemarra-regular">had passed, it had passed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan then completely <span class="gemarra-regular">awakened him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">stood him up. </span>Thereafter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he asked him </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">every uncertainty that he had, and </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved </span>each of <span class="gemarra-regular">them for him. And this is </span>the background to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which Rabbi Yoḥanan says</span> to his students on several occasions: What <span class="gemarra-regular">I said was yours is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">theirs, </span>i.e., I thought that the Torah scholars in Eretz Yisrael were the most advanced, but in fact the scholars of Babylonia are the most advanced, as evidenced by Rav Kahana’s knowledge.
§ The Gemara relates another incident pertaining to one who informed gentiles of the whereabouts of another Jew’s property. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who showed Rabbi Abba’s silk [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ametakesa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to gentiles, who later seized it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa sat </span>together to determine whether Rabbi Abba was entitled to compensation from the informer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Ile’a sat next to them.</span>
The judges <span class="gemarra-regular">thought to deem </span>the informer <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to reimburse Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">based upon that which we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 28b): If a judge <span class="gemarra-regular">issued a judgment </span>and erred, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquitted </span>one who was in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed liable </span>one who should have in fact been <span class="gemarra-regular">acquitted, </span>or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a pure </span>item is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> impure </span>item is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure, </span>and by doing so he caused a litigant a monetary loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">what he did is done, </span>i.e., the judgment stands, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the judge <span class="gemarra-regular">must pay </span>damages <span class="gemarra-regular">from his home, </span>i.e., from his personal funds. This indicates that one is liable to pay for a financial loss that he causes even if his involvement was only through speech.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ile’a said to them: This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: And that </span>mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the judge not only issued a ruling, but actively <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the money from the one whom he found liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave </span>it to the other party <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span> his own <span class="gemarra-regular">hand. </span>Consequently, it cannot serve as a precedent to render the informer liable in this case. The Sages serving as judges <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go to Rabbi Shimon ben Elyaki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Elazar ben Pedat, who rule </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>for damage caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action.
Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">went to them, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">they deemed </span>the informer <span class="gemarra-regular">liable</span> to reimburse Rabbi Abba, as it is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mishna: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the thugs seized the field <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the robber, he is liable to provide </span>the owner with <span class="gemarra-regular">a different field. And it was established that </span>the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">showed </span>the field to thugs who later seized it. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in the mishna would apply to this case as well.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">whom a silver cup was deposited. Thieves came upon him </span>in his home and <span class="gemarra-regular">he took </span>the cup and <span class="gemarra-regular">gave it to them. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabba, </span>and Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">exempted him </span>from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: This </span>individual is <span class="gemarra-regular">saving himself with another’s property, </span>and he should therefore be liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said, </span>in explanation of Rabba’s ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">We look </span>at his financial status: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">is a wealthy man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the thieves <span class="gemarra-regular">came with the intent </span>to steal <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>property, and he is therefore liable to pay, as he saved himself from financial loss by handing over another’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>wealthy, the thieves presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">came with the intent </span>to steal <span class="gemarra-regular">the silver </span>cup, and he is therefore exempt from liability.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man with whom the purse </span>containing funds collected <span class="gemarra-regular">for the redemption of captives was deposited. Thieves came upon him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he took </span>the purse and <span class="gemarra-regular">gave it to them. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabba, </span>and Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">exempted him </span>from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But this </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">is saving himself with another’s property, </span>and he should therefore be liable to pay. Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have no greater redemption of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> captives than this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the man used the money to avoid being harmed by the thieves, Rabba considered the money to have been used for its intended purpose.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who hastened and brought his donkey </span>onboard <span class="gemarra-regular">a ferry [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lemavra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">people </span><span class="gemarra-regular">boarded the ferry. </span>The donkey began to move around and <span class="gemarra-regular">was about </span>to cause the boat <span class="gemarra-regular">to sink. A certain </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">man came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed the donkey of that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">man into the river, and it drowned. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabba, </span>and Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">exempted him </span>from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But this </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">is saving himself with another’s property, </span>and he should therefore be liable to pay. Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This </span>owner of the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a pursuer from the outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he endangered the other travelers. It is permitted to stop a pursuer by any means necessary, including by destroying his property.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rabba says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pursuer who was chasing after another </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to kill him and </span>the pursuer <span class="gemarra-regular">broke vessels </span>during the chase, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pursued </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">or to anyone </span>else, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from reimbursing the owner of the vessels. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he is liable to </span>receive the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>penalty for attempted murder and is consequently exempt from any monetary liability he incurs simultaneously.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And a pursued </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who broke the vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the pursuer </span>is also <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the pursuer’s property shall not be cherished more than his body, </span>i.e., his life. Since it is permitted to kill the pursuer in order to save his intended victim, it is permitted to destroy his property for that purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he destroyed property <span class="gemarra-regular">belonging to anyone </span>else, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to reimburse them, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is prohibited </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to save himself with another’s property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pursuer who was chasing after </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">pursue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to save </span>the latter’s intended victim, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">broke vessels </span>during the chase, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to the pursued </span>individual, i.e., the individual attempting murder, <span class="gemarra-regular">or to anyone </span>else, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from payment. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is not </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">law, but if you do not say so, you </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">not have </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">person that saves another from a pursuer. </span>In order to encourage people to attempt to save the lives of others, the Sages instituted that one who damages another’s property in the process of saving a life is exempt from payment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">a river flooded </span>a misappropriated field, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>its owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you, </span>and no compensation is required. Since the field would have been flooded in any case, the robber has not caused the damage to the field, and is therefore exempt.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robbed a field from another and a river </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">flooded it, </span>the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to provide </span>the field’s owner with <span class="gemarra-regular">a different field. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Elazar. And the Rabbis say: </span>He is exempt from doing so, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you.</span>
The Gemara analyzes this dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they disagree? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar interpreted </span>the verses: “If any one sin, and commit a trespass against the Lord, and deal falsely with his neighbor in a matter of deposit…or anything about which he has sworn falsely, he shall restore it in full” (Leviticus 5:21–24), according to the hermeneutical principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">amplifications and restrictions. </span>The phrase: “If any one sin, and commit a trespass against the Lord, <span class="gemarra-regular">and deal falsely with his neighbor,” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an amplification. </span>When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In a matter of deposit,”</span> it has <span class="gemarra-regular">restricted </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to the case of a deposit. When the verse then states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or anything about which he has sworn falsely, </span>he shall restore it in full,” <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">then amplified </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> again.
Accordingly, as the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">restricted and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified </span>again, it has <span class="gemarra-regular">amplified </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to include <span class="gemarra-regular">everything, </span>with only a single exception. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is included due to the fact that the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">has amplified </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">has amplified </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to include <span class="gemarra-regular">everything </span>that one steals.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is excluded due to the fact that the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">restricted </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It restricted </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in order to exclude financial <span class="gemarra-regular">documents, </span>which are dissimilar to a deposit in that their value is not intrinsic, but rather due to their function. Consequently, according to Rabbi Elazar, land that was stolen is included in the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> stated in these verses, and one who steals land must reimburse the field’s owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis interpreted </span>these verses according to the hermeneutical principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">generalizations and details. </span>The phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And deal falsely </span>with his neighbor,” is <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, </span>while the subsequent phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In a matter of deposit,” </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a detail. </span>When the verse then states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or anything </span>about which he has sworn falsely, he shall restore it in full,” <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">then generalized </span>again. In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may deduce </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to items <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the detail.</span>
Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as the detail, </span>i.e., a deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is movable property and </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>the verse includes <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that is movable property and </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">land has been excluded, as it is not movable property. Slaves have been excluded, as they are compared to land </span>with regard to many areas of <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. Financial <span class="gemarra-regular">documents have been </span><span class="gemarra-regular">excluded because, although they </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, they do not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">intrinsic monetary </span>value.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robbed </span>another of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow and a river washed it away, </span>the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to provide </span>the owner with another <span class="gemarra-regular">cow; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Elazar. And the Rabbis say: </span>The robber can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is yours is before you, </span>and he would consequently be exempt. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to what do they disagree? </span>The rationale offered previously cannot apply, as a cow is movable property and has intrinsic value, and yet Rabbi Elazar and the Rabbis still disagree.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: There, with what are we dealing? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">robbed another of a field, and there was</span>

Daf 118a

<span class="gemarra-regular">a prone cow in it, and a river washed it </span>away. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as he maintains that land is included in the category of items that are not subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of robbery. Consequently, the robber acquires the land and simultaneously becomes liable to return it. Since he acquires the land, he acquires the cow that is on the land as well, and is liable to compensate its owner when it gets washed away by the river. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis </span>conform <span class="gemarra-regular">to their </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as they hold that land was excluded by the verse. Therefore, the robber does not acquire the land and also does not acquire the cow.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">with whom </span>another had <span class="gemarra-regular">deposited </span>an item, if any of these interactions took place <span class="gemarra-regular">in a settled area, he may not return </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to him in an unsettled </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where it is of little benefit to the owner and he cannot safeguard it. If the loan or deposit was given <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">may go out </span>and return it to the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">in an unsettled area, he may return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him in an unsettled area.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>to the mishna from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A loan may be repaid in any location, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item and a deposit are returned only in their location, </span>i.e., the same type of place, settled or unsettled, where they were found or received. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: A loan may be claimed </span>by the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">in any </span><span class="gemarra-regular">location</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Yet, if the borrower initiates the process of repaying the loan in an unsettled area, the creditor may refuse to accept the repayment until they reach a settled area. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">a lost item and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deposi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">may be claimed only in their location.</span>
The mishna teaches that if the loan or deposit was given <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">may go out </span>and return it to the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">in an unsettled area, </span>he may do so. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that an explicit stipulation to this effect is binding? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, as </span>the mishna is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the depositor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let this deposit be with you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as I am going out to an unsettled area, and </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I also need to go out to an unsettled area, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">if I need to return </span>the deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">to you there, </span>I will <span class="gemarra-regular">return it to you </span>there.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to another: I robbed you, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You lent me </span>money, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You deposited </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with me, and I do not know if I returned </span>your property <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">if I did not return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable to pay </span>the sum or item in question. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to him: I do not know if I robbed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or: I do not know <span class="gemarra-regular">if you lent me money, </span>or: I do not know <span class="gemarra-regular">if you deposited </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with me, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying </span>the sum or item in question.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara cites a related dispute: It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that if one individual says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession, and the other says: I do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> whether or not this is true, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay the plaintiff, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying.
The Gemara explains the reason for each opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay, because when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">and an uncertain </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the certain </span>claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">superior. Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying because of the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">Establish the money in the possession of its owner, </span>i.e., money is not taken from one’s possession without clear proof that he is liable to pay it.
The Gemara attempts to derive a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said to him: I do not know if you lent me money, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying. <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If we say </span>that the mishna is discussing a case where the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">did not claim </span>the money from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, the first clause </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>discuss a situation where the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">did not claim </span>the money from him. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why is </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay in the case discussed in the first clause? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna must be discussing a case where the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">did claim </span>the money from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, and the latter clause </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the borrower is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from paying, </span>even though his claim is uncertain and that of the lender is certain. This supports the opinion of Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, actually </span>the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">did not claim </span>the money from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, and the first clause </span>is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to fulfill </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to Heaven.</span>
The Gemara adds that it <span class="gemarra-regular">was also stated: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to another: I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in your possession, and the other </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I do not know </span>whether or not this is true, the latter is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay. This applies <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">comes to fulfill </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to Heaven </span>even though he cannot be forced to pay. This statement is in accordance with the opinion of Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stole a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">b</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from a flock and returned it </span>without informing the owner that he had done so, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">it died or was stolen, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">restitution </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>lamb’s <span class="gemarra-regular">owners did not know </span>about the entire incident, i.e., they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>know <span class="gemarra-regular">that it was stolen and </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>know <span class="gemarra-regular">that it was returned, and they counted the </span>flock of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep and </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">it whole, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara presents several ways to understand the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>In a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had knowledge </span>of the fact that their lamb was stolen, the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>to return it with the <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge </span>of the owners in order to be exempt from liability if the lamb is subsequently harmed. In a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> knowledge </span>that the lamb was taken, their <span class="gemarra-regular">count </span>of the flock after the thief returned it <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>the thief from further liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">counte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>flock of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep and </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">it whole, </span>it is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter clause, </span>i.e., the case where the owners were unaware that the lamb was stolen, as it is specifically in that case that the count exempts the thief from liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: Whether </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had knowledge </span>of the theft <span class="gemarra-regular">or whether </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not have knowledge </span>of it, their <span class="gemarra-regular">count </span>of the flock <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>the thief from payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And they counted </span>the flock of sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">it whole, </span>the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the entire </span>mishna, as this exempts the thief from liability in both cases mentioned in the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had knowledge </span>of the theft, their <span class="gemarra-regular">count </span>of the flock <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>the thief, and in a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had no knowledge </span>of the theft, <span class="gemarra-regular">even counting is not required </span>for the thief to be exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And they counted the </span>flock of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep and </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">it whole, </span>it is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to the first clause </span>of the mishna, as it is particularly in that case that the count is relevant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: </span>In a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had knowledge </span>of the theft, their <span class="gemarra-regular">count </span>of the flock <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>the thief. In a case where the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">had no knowledge </span>of the theft, the thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>to return the lamb with their <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge </span>in order to become exempt from liability for future damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And they counted the </span>flock of <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep and </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">it whole, </span>it is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first clause </span>of the mishna, where the owners were aware of the theft, as it is only in that case that counting the flock is sufficient to exempt the thief from further liability.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>

Daf 118b

<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning of Rav Ḥisda, </span>who holds that the requirement to return the animal with the owner’s knowledge is in the case where the owners did not know about the theft? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the lamb to take <span class="gemarra-regular">steps outside, </span>i.e., to leave the owners’ property, it will now require greater supervision, which the owners can provide only if they are aware of the situation.
The Gemara assumes that since Rava explained Rav Ḥisda’s reasoning, he accepts Rav Ḥisda’s ruling. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Rava </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? Doesn’t Rava say </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">this person who saw another lift a lamb from his flock </span>in order to steal it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner then <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">voice at </span>the thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">discarded it, but </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not know if </span>the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>the lamb or <span class="gemarra-regular">if he did not return it, and </span>the lamb then <span class="gemarra-regular">died or was stolen, </span>the thief is to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">restitution </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">it?</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>is this statement of Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>applicable <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">counted </span>his flock after this incident? Accordingly, Rava rules that if the owner knew about the theft, the thief is rendered exempt from liability only if he returns the lamb with the owner’s knowledge, which is not in accordance with the ruling of Rav Ḥisda. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>Rava’s ruling applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not count </span>the flock.
The Gemara examines Rav’s ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Rav </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? Doesn’t Rav say </span>that if the thief <span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>the lamb <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">flock that is in an unsettled area, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>his obligation to return it? This indicates that the thief is exempt from further liability even though the thief did not inform the owner of the lamb’s return and the owner did not count the flock. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanan bar Abba said: Rav concedes </span>that the thief is exempt in this case only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the lamb was <span class="gemarra-regular">spotted [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">birkuata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the lamb’s spots are distinctive, the owner immediately becomes aware of its return.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the amoraic dispute cited previously is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals a lamb from a flock or a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from a purse </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to the place </span>from where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>it; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The thief is <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>to return it with the <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">owners.</span>
The Gemara explains: The Sages discussing the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed that everyone accepts </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A person is prone to feel his purs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> constantly, </span>and therefore becomes aware of the theft soon after it takes place. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> was stolen with the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge, and </span>the dispute of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva is parallel <span class="gemarra-regular">to the dispute of Rav and Shmuel? </span>According to this explanation, Rav rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, and Shmuel rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>they disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a lamb that </span>was stolen <span class="gemarra-regular">without the knowledge </span>of its owners, i.e., they did not know that it was stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the dispute of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva is parallel <span class="gemarra-regular">to the dispute of Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Yoḥanan. </span>Rav Ḥisda rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva that the lamb must be returned with the owner’s knowledge, and Rabbi Yoḥanan rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael that the owners do not need to become aware of the lamb’s return.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: With regard to a bailee who stole </span>a lamb <span class="gemarra-regular">from the owner’s domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> everyone, </span>including Rabbi Yishmael, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>and the owner must be aware of the animal’s return in order for the thief to become exempt from further liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">And here it is with regard to </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a bailee who stole from </span>within <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">domain may return </span>what he stole <span class="gemarra-regular">to the place from </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">he stole </span>it that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree. Rabbi Akiva holds: His safeguarding was terminated </span>when he stole the lamb and he must therefore return it with the owner’s knowledge. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael holds: His safeguarding was not terminated </span>and he may return it to his own domain.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>us <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that with regard to the dispute over whether the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">counting </span>of his flock <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>a thief who returned a stolen lamb without notifying the owner, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robbed another and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">included </span>the money he owed <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>for the robbery <span class="gemarra-regular">in the calculation </span>of the payment for a different transaction, i.e., he compensated the owner by overpaying him for a different transaction, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>his obligation to pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">not fulfilled </span>his obligation to pay.
The Sages discussing the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed that everyone accepts </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A person is prone to feel his purse constantly, </span>and therefore becomes aware that he has been compensated soon after the payment is made. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not with regard to this </span>following point that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree: The one who says </span>that the robber has <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilled </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">counting </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>a robber from further liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who says </span>that the robber has <span class="gemarra-regular">not fulfilled </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">counting does not exempt </span>a robber from further liability.
The Gemara responds: One can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if we held in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak, </span>it would follow that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">counting </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>a robber from further liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak </span>itself that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage accepts </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak, and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage does not accept </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yitzḥak.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone accepts </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult: This </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which rules that the robber fulfilled his obligation, is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">counted </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">and placed it </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">purse, </span>which the owner will soon open and count. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>other <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which rules that the robber did not fulfill his obligation, is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he counted </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">and placed it in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hand. </span>Consequently, it is possible that the owner will put the money directly into a container with other coins in it and will never realize that he was compensated for the theft.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">counted </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">and placed it in </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">purse. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has other dinars in his purse, </span>but he did not know how many. Therefore, when he counts the money, he will not realize that the robber inserted an additional sum. Whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not have other dinars in his purse, </span>so that when he counts the money he will realize that an additional sum has been included in the payment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not purchase wool, milk, and kids from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shepherd</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who tend the flocks of others, due to the concern that they have stolen these items from the owners of the flocks. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and produce from produce </span><span class="gemarra-regular">watchmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But one may purchase from wome</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> woolen goods in Judea, and linen goods in the Galilee, and calves in the Sharon, </span>as women in these locations often work with those commodities and it can be assumed that they are selling the items with the owner’s consent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>items, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">told </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to conceal </span>the purchase, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited, </span>as there is good reason to suspect that the items are stolen. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may purchase eggs and chickens from everywhere, </span>as it is unlikely that one would steal and sell these commodities.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase from shepherds neither goats, nor kids, nor fleeces, nor torn </span>pieces <span class="gemarra-regular">of wool, but one may purchase sewn </span>garments <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, because they are </span>presumed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">theirs. And one may purchase milk and cheese from them in an unsettled </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but not in a settled area.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one may purchase from them four or five sheep </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">four or five fleeces </span>at a time, because it is unlikely that a shepherd would risk stealing such a significant quantity at once. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">two sheep, and </span>similarly, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">two fleeces </span>at a time, as it is reasonable to assume that the shepherd would attempt to steal this amount from the owner.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may purchase domesticated </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, </span>as it is unlikely that the shepherds would steal them from their owner, who would notice if they did not return home. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not purchase desert, </span>i.e., non-domesticated, animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, </span>as it is more likely that a shepherd would steal these animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">The principle of the matte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> is that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that the shepherd sells and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">perceive its </span>absence if it were stolen, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may purchase </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. </span>But if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">would not perceive its </span>absence, one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not purchase </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them.</span>
The Gemara examines the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may purchase from them four or five sheep </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">four or five fleeces </span>at a time. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it can be said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">buy four </span>sheep, as it is unlikely that the shepherd would steal such a large quantity at one time, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state that we may buy <span class="gemarra-regular">five? </span>The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>The meaning of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is that one may purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>sheep <span class="gemarra-regular">out of </span>a flock consisting of <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>sheep, as it is reasonable to assume that the shepherd would not attempt to steal four-fifths of the owner’s flock. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Four </span>sheep may be purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the shepherd of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small flock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and five </span>may be purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the shepherd of <span class="gemarra-regular">a large flock.</span>
The Gemara asks another question with regard to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter itself is difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">you said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One may purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">from them four or five sheep </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">four or five fleeces </span>at a time, which indicates that purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">four or five, yes, </span>it is permitted, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">three, no, </span>it is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">two sheep. </span>This indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">that we may purchase three </span>sheep at a time.
The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span>clause, which permits the purchase of three sheep, is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sheep are <span class="gemarra-regular">robust, </span>and therefore the owner is more attentive to them and would notice if three were missing. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>clause, which prohibits the purchase of three sheep, is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sheep are <span class="gemarra-regular">frail. </span>Consequently, the owner does not care about them as much, and it is possible that he would not notice if only three of them went missing.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may purchase domesticated </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not purchase desert </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. A dilemma was raised</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>the Sages: Is the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda referring to the first clause, and </span>his statement is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">a stringency? Or perhaps </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to the latter clause, and </span>his statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">a leniency?</span>
The Gemara elaborates: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to the first clause, and </span>his statement is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stringency, as he </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: One may purchase four or five sheep from them, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement applies </span>only to <span class="gemarra-regular">domesticated </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">desert </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">even four or five sheep </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be purchased? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to the latter clause and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a leniency, as he </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: But </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">two sheep, and </span>similarly, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">two fleeces, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement applies </span>only to <span class="gemarra-regular">desert </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">domesticated </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may purchase even two </span>animals.
The Gemara presents an answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to the dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may purchase domesticated </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, but one may not purchase desert </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. But one may always purchase four or five sheep from them. </span>

Daf 119a

<span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he stated </span>that four or five animals may <span class="gemarra-regular">always </span>be purchased, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that Rabbi Yehuda’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to the latter clause, and </span>his statement is a <span class="gemarra-regular">leniency. </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that Rabbi Yehuda intended his statement as a leniency.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase wood and produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from produce watchmen. </span>The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav purchased grapevine branches from a sharecropper. Abaye said to him: But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">wood and produce from produce watchmen? </span>The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply with regard to a sharecropper, who, like a watchman, is not the owner of the produce. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This statement applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a watchman, as he has no </span>share <span class="gemarra-regular">at all in the land itself. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a sharecropper, who does have </span>a share <span class="gemarra-regular">in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: He is selling </span>merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">from his own </span>share of the land. Since it is plausible that the sharecropper is selling his own property, it is permitted to buy it from him.
The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> which discusses purchasing items from watchmen: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">produce watchmen, one may purchase </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from them when they are sitting and selling </span>the produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the baskets are before them and the scales [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veturtanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are before them, </span>as in these circumstances it is reasonable to assume that they are not selling stolen merchandise. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where they said </span>to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conceal </span>your purchase, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to purchase from them, as there is good reason to suspect that the merchandise is stolen. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase from </span>a watchman <span class="gemarra-regular">from the entrance of the garden, but not from the back of the garden, </span>because if the produce is being sold inconspicuously, there is a concern that it might have been stolen.
§ Having discussed the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> pertaining to suspected theft, the Gemara proceeds to examine the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> pertaining to purchasing items from a known robber. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber, from when is it permitted to purchase </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">from him? Rav says: </span>It is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">until the majority </span>of his possessions are <span class="gemarra-regular">from his </span>own property, i.e., property that he obtained legally. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>It is permitted to purchase items from a known robber <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if only <span class="gemarra-regular">a minority </span>of his possessions are from <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own property.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda instructed Adda, </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">attendant, in accordance with the statement of the one who says: </span>It is permitted to purchase items from a known robber <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if only <span class="gemarra-regular">a minority </span>of his possessions are from <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own property, i.e., in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel.
With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an informer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one who informs gentiles of the whereabouts of another’s property, facilitating its theft or misuse, there is a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda. One says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to physically destroy it, and one says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to physically destroy it.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: The rationale of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to physically destroy it </span>is that an informer’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property should not be </span>subject to a more <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">than his body. </span>Since it is permitted to physically harm or even kill an informer, it would be unreasonable to prohibit the destruction of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the rationale of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to </span>physically <span class="gemarra-regular">destroy it </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he will have good children, and it is written: The wicked may prepare it, but the just shall put it on </span>(see Job 27:17).
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda had a certain sharecropper who would weigh </span>the field’s produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>Rav Ḥisda his portion, and <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>his own portion. Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">dismissed him, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>the following verse <span class="gemarra-regular">about him: </span>“A good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s chil-dren; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wealth of the sinner is laid up for the righteous” </span>(Proverbs 13:22).
§ The Gemara examines various verses pertaining to robbers. <span class="gemarra-regular">“For what is the hope of the godless, though he profits, when God takes away his soul?”</span> (Job 27:8). This verse is the subject of a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda. One says </span>that the phrase “God takes away his soul” is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the soul of the robbed, and one says </span>that it is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">soul of the robber.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: The rationale of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that the verse is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the soul of the robbed </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “So are the ways of every one that is greedy for profit; it takes away the life of the owner thereof” </span>(Proverbs 1:19), which teaches that one who robs another of his property is considered as one who robbed him of his soul. And the rationale of <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the soul of the robber </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “Rob not the weak, because he is weak, neither crush the poor in the gate; for the Lord will plead their cause, and despoil of life those that despoil them” </span>(Proverbs 22:22–23).
The Gemara questions each opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>opinion, i.e., the latter one, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it also written: “It takes away the life of the owner thereof,” </span>which indicates that the soul of the robbed is taken? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“the owner thereof”? </span>It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">its current owner, </span>i.e., the robber, who has acquired the stolen item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>opinion, who said that the life of the robbed is taken, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it also written: “And despoil of life those that despoil them,” </span>which indicates that the soul of the robber is taken? The Gemara answers that the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: What is the reason. </span>The verse teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that God <span class="gemarra-regular">will despoil </span>the life of <span class="gemarra-regular">those who despoil them? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because they despoiled the soul </span>of their victims.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Anyone who robs another </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perut</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he takes his soul from him, as it is stated: “So are the ways of every one that is greedy for profit; it takes away the life of the owner thereof” </span>(Proverbs 1:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it states: “And they shall consume your harvest, and your bread, </span>they shall consume <span class="gemarra-regular">your sons and your daughters” </span>(Jeremiah 5:17). Since they will consume the harvest and bread, it is as though they consume one’s children as well because there will be no food to feed them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it states: </span>“Egypt shall be a desolation, and Edom shall be a desolate wilderness, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the extortion of the children of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land” </span>(Joel 4:19). The verse here considers extortion like the shedding of innocent blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it states </span>with regard to a famine: “And the Lord said: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is for Saul, and for his bloody house, because he put to death the Gibeonites” </span>(II Samuel 21:1).
The Gemara asks: Since Rabbi Yoḥanan’s point was proven by the first verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>was the purpose of adding each subsequent verse by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it states? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the robber takes only <span class="gemarra-regular">his, </span>i.e., the victim’s, <span class="gemarra-regular">life, but the lives of his sons and daughters </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>taken, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the second verse, which mentions <span class="gemarra-regular">the flesh of his sons and daughters.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: This matter applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give </span>his victim <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation </span>for the stolen item, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where he gave compensation </span>for the stolen item, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>comparable to murder, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For the extortion of the children of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land.” </span>Extortion is referring to coercing someone to sell an item that he does not want to sell. It is a form of robbery, and the verse equates it with murder.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: This matter applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">where he committed </span>the robbery <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>direct <span class="gemarra-regular">action, but </span>if he committed it through <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect </span>action, the transgression is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>as severe, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“It is for Saul, and for his bloody house, because he put to death the Gibeonites.” And where did we </span>ever <span class="gemarra-regular">find that Saul killed the Gibeonites? </span>He did not do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, due to</span> the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">he killed </span>the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">Nob, the city of the priests, who would provide </span>the Gibeonites with <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>(see I Samuel, chapter 22) <span class="gemarra-regular">and food, the verse ascribes him </span>blame for their death <span class="gemarra-regular">as though he </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">killed </span>the Gibeonites himself.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may purchase </span>specific goods <span class="gemarra-regular">from women </span>in certain places. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase from women woolen goods in Judea, and linen goods in the Galilee, but not wines, oils, and flours, </span>as these are not usually sold by women and there is a concern that perhaps the women stole them from their husbands. <span class="gemarra-regular">And no </span>items may be purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">from slaves, or from children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba Shaul says: A woman may sell </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>up to <span class="gemarra-regular">four and five dinars in order to make a cap [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kippa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for her head, </span>as it is assumed that her husband allows her to sell these items in order to purchase additional articles of clothing. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">where they told </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to conceal </span>his purchase, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to enter into the transaction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Charity collectors may take something </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a small </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>women, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not something </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a large </span>amount, as it is possible that they do not have permission to give away expensive items.
