<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">olive pressers, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> purchase from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> olives in </span>a substantial <span class="gemarra-regular">measure, and oil in </span>a substantial <span class="gemarra-regular">measure, </span>as there is no concern that they would steal such a large amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not olives in a small </span>amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">oil in a small </span>amount. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One may purchase olives in small </span>amounts <span class="gemarra-regular">from women in the Upper Galilee, </span>where olives are exceptionally expensive, <span class="gemarra-regular">as at times, a person is embarrassed to sell </span>olives <span class="gemarra-regular">at the entrance of his house, and </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>some olives <span class="gemarra-regular">to his wife, and she sells </span>them. Since there is a reason to presume that the women have been given the right to sell the olives by their husbands, and it is unlikely that the women would sell them without permission, as even a small amount missing would be noticed due to their great value, it may be assumed that the olives are being sold with permission.
The Gemara relates: When <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina arrive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at Bei Meḥoza, the women of Bei Meḥoza came and tossed chains and bracelets before him </span>so that he could distribute the jewelry as charity, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he accepted </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from them. Rabba Tosfa’a said to Ravina: But isn’t it taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Charity collectors may accept something </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a small </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>women, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not something </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> large </span>amount? How can you accept jewelry, which is worth a significant sum? Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: For the residents of Meḥoza, these </span>chains and bracelets <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">something small, </span>and it is therefore permitted for me to accept them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Strands </span>of wool <span class="gemarra-regular">that the launderer </span><span class="gemarra-regular">remove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the garment <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to him, </span>as it can be assumed that the customer is uninterested in them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>strands that <span class="gemarra-regular">the carder, </span>i.e., one who prepares wool for use as a textile, <span class="gemarra-regular">removes belong to the customer, </span>as it is assumed that the customer would want them, since the carder often removes a significant number of strands. <span class="gemarra-regular">A launderer takes three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that were inserted at the edge of a garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are his, </span>but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>threads <span class="gemarra-regular">than this, these </span>additional threads <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to the customer. If </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">were black </span>threads <span class="gemarra-regular">on a white </span>garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes all of them and they are his. </span>As the removal of the threads improves the appearance of the garment, the customer does not want them.
In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tailor who left </span>enough <span class="gemarra-regular">threa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> attached to the cloth that it could be used <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to sew with it, or </span>if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a patch </span>of cloth <span class="gemarra-regular">that is three </span>fingerbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">by three </span>fingerbreadths left from the cloth given to the tailor by the customer, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to the customer. That which a carpenter remove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with an adz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belongs to him, </span>because an adze removes only small shavings of wood, which the customer is uninterested in; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>what he removes <span class="gemarra-regular">with an ax [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvakashil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belongs to the customer. And if he was doing </span>his work <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the domain of <span class="gemarra-regular">the customer, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even the sawdust belongs to the customer.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:13): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase strands </span>of wool <span class="gemarra-regular">from a launderer, because they are </span>assumed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">his. A launderer may take the two upper threads </span>of a garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are his. </span>

Daf 119b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a carder <span class="gemarra-regular">should not place in </span>a piece of cloth <span class="gemarra-regular">more than three stitche</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for each loop that he attaches to the cloth in order to stretch it out, as this causes the cloth to overstretch and require trimming. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he should not card the cloth </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its warp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., vertically, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its weft, </span>i.e., horizontally. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he may even out </span>the cloth by cutting it along <span class="gemarra-regular">its length, but not </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its width, and if he comes to even out </span>the cloth by removing <span class="gemarra-regular">up to a handbreadth </span>of material, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for him to do so.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the launderer may take <span class="gemarra-regular">two threads. But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that the launderer may take <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>threads? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>The ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which allows only two threads, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thick </span>threads, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>mishna, which allows three threads, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to thin </span>ones.
It was also stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he should not card the cloth </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its warp but </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its weft. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>The ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which prohibits carding along the warp, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">garment, </span>which is designed for durability, and one should therefore avoid wearing out the material by carding along the warp. The ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which allows one to card along the warp, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an elegant <span class="gemarra-regular">cape [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">besarbela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is made for aesthetic appearance and is therefore improved by carding in this manner.
The Gemara examines the next clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a carder <span class="gemarra-regular">should not place in </span>a cloth <span class="gemarra-regular">more than three stiches </span>for each loop. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma </span>with regard to the definition of the term stitch in this context: Does drawing the needle <span class="gemarra-regular">in and out </span>constitute <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>stitch, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>does drawing the needle <span class="gemarra-regular">in and out </span>constitute <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>stitches? The Gemara responds: The question <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
It was further stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he may even out </span>the cloth by cutting it along <span class="gemarra-regular">its length, but not </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">its width. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite </span>is true? The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>The statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which rules that one should even out the cloth along its length, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a garment, </span>where an uneven length would be conspicuous. The statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which rules that one should even it out along its width, is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a belt, </span>as the width of a belt is more noticeable than its length while it is being worn.
§ The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses which items may be purchased from a carder. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:12): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not purchase strands </span>of thread <span class="gemarra-regular">from a carder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because </span>it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not his. And in a place where </span>the residents <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed </span>to allow carders to retain strands, the strands may be presumed <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be his </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">one may purchase </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in every place, one may purchase from them a cushion full of </span>stuffing made from <span class="gemarra-regular">strands</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a mattress full of </span>stuffing made from <span class="gemarra-regular">strands. What is the reason </span>that it is permitted? The reason is that even if the carder had stolen the strands, once he uses them to make a cushion or mattress, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">through a change </span>of form.
§ Apropos the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> pertaining to weaving, the Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses which items may be purchased from various craftsmen. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:11): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase from a weaver neither </span>woolen <span class="gemarra-regular">wads [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">irin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are used to hold the bobbin in place on a shuttle, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor heddles [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor threads of the bobbin </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">punkalin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor remnants of </span>coils of thread that were left on the <span class="gemarra-regular">spool, </span>as there is a concern that these items were taken from the customer without his consent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But one may purchase a spotted garment from them, </span>even though the design indicates that it was made from strands of different colors, which the weaver may have stolen from other garments that he was weaving. It is also permitted to purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">warp </span>threads <span class="gemarra-regular">and weft </span>threads from them, as well as wool that was <span class="gemarra-regular">spun </span>into thread <span class="gemarra-regular">or woven. </span>All of these items may be purchased from the weaver because they have undergone a physical change, and have therefore been acquired by the weaver even if he did steal them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say: Now </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may purchase spun </span>wool despite the fact that it has undergone only a minor physical change, <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that one may purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">woven </span>wool, which has undergone a greater change of form? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it mentions <span class="gemarra-regular">woven </span>wool? It is not referring to wool woven into a garment, but to wool that was twisted into <span class="gemarra-regular">chains, </span>which is also a minor physical change.
The Gemara examines which items may be bought from a dyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may purchase from a dyer neither </span>pieces of wool used for <span class="gemarra-regular">tests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor </span>pieces used as a color <span class="gemarra-regular">sample [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dugmut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor detached </span>pieces <span class="gemarra-regular">of wool, </span>as these might have been stolen. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may purchase from him a colored garment, spun </span>threads, and <span class="gemarra-regular">clothes </span>fashioned from the aforementioned pieces of material. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may purchase spun </span>threads from the dyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that one may purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">clothes? </span>It is obvious that one may purchase clothes, as the clothes themselves are made of spun threads. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it mentions <span class="gemarra-regular">clothes? </span>It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">felt </span>garments, which are not made of spun thread.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:16): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives hides </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a tanner, the trimmings </span>of hide <span class="gemarra-regular">and the detached </span>hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to the customer, but </span>the substance that <span class="gemarra-regular">comes up </span>while being <span class="gemarra-regular">washed in water belongs to him, </span>the tanner.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the threads <span class="gemarra-regular">were black </span>on a white garment, the launderer may take all of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: </span>A launderer <span class="gemarra-regular">is called a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">katzra</span> in Aramaic, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he takes the short [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">katzra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>shreds of wool <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself. Rav Yehuda </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: All </span>the threads, even those usually removed from the garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">are counted toward the </span>minimum <span class="gemarra-regular">number of </span>thumb-lengths between the hole through which the <span class="gemarra-regular">sky-blue wool </span>is inserted for ritual fringes and the edge of the garment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But Yitzḥak, my son, is particula</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about these </span>threads, and makes sure that the garment is of the proper measurement even if the threads were to be removed.
The mishna teaches: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tailor who left </span>enough <span class="gemarra-regular">thread </span>attached to the cloth in order to sew with it, this thread belongs to the customer. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>thread is necessary in order to be able <span class="gemarra-regular">to sew? Rav Asi said: The length of a needle outside the needle. A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Did Rav Asi mean that the thread must be <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the needle </span>there must be an additional amount of thread <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle? Or perhaps </span>he meant that it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the needle </span>there must be <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>minimal <span class="gemarra-regular">amount </span>of additional string. In other words, was Rav Asi saying that the thread must be two needle lengths, or slightly more than one needle length?
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tailor who left the thread </span>attached to the cloth, but it was <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>the length necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to sew with it, or </span>if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a patch </span>of cloth <span class="gemarra-regular">that is less than three </span>fingerbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">by three </span>fingerbreadths left from the cloth given to the tailor by the customer, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is dependent upon the customer’s inclination: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the customer is particular about </span>such items, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to the customer, </span>but if <span class="gemarra-regular">the customer is not particular about them, these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to </span>the tailor.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to deduce the answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that Rav Asi meant to say that the thread must be <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the needle </span>there must be an additional amount of thread <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle, </span>then the ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that a slightly shorter thread belongs to the customer if he wishes to keep it is reasonable, since a thread which is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than that </span>length <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for </span>use as the stitching of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loop. But if you say </span>that Rav Asi meant that the thread must be <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the needle </span>there must be <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount </span>of additional string, then with regard to a thread that is even <span class="gemarra-regular">less than that, </span>for what use <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>that the customer might wish to keep it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, learn from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that Rav Asi meant that the thread must be <span class="gemarra-regular">the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the needle </span>there must be an additional amount of thread <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the size of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">needle, </span>so that the thread must be a total of two needle lengths. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which the carpenter </span>removes with an adze belongs to him, but what he removes with an ax belongs to the customer. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>to this ruling based upon a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">That which the carpenter removes with an adze and that which is severed with a saw belong to the customer. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which comes out from under a drill or under a plane [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rehitni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that which is scraped by the saw, </span>i.e., sawdust, <span class="gemarra-regular">these belong to </span>the carpenter. Whereas the mishna rules that the carpenter may keep what is removed with an adze, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rules that it belongs to the customer.
The Gemara presents an answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: In the place of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">there are two </span>kinds of <span class="gemarra-regular">blades </span>used by carpenters: <span class="gemarra-regular">The larger </span>blade <span class="gemarra-regular">is called an ax, and the smaller </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is called an adze. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the place of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, there is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>carpenter’s <span class="gemarra-regular">blade, and they called it an adze. </span>Consequently, the adze referred to in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is actually an ax and the rulings are therefore congruent.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he was doing </span>his work <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the domain of the customer, then even the sawdust belongs to the customer. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:18): <span class="gemarra-regular">Stone chiselers are not in </span>violation of a transgression <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery </span>if they take the leftover chips of rock. Furthermore, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those who prune trees, those who prune vines, those who trim shrubs, those who weed plants, and those who hoe vegetables, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is dependent upon the owner’s inclination: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the owner is particular about </span>the plant trimmings, the workers <span class="gemarra-regular">are in </span>violation of a transgression <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery </span>if they take the trimmings, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner is not particular about them, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to </span>the workers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: Dodder [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keshut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and green grain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veḥaziz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not subject to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery, </span>as they grow on their own and no one tends to them. But <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are particular </span>about the ownership of dodder and green grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are subject to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">robbery. Ravina said: And the city </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Meḥasya is a city where </span>the residents <span class="gemarra-regular">are particular </span>about dodder and green wheat.
